It's interesting to know why most pagodas and the palace located near the river. Recommend to take the tourist boat as it provides hop-on hop-off at only 150 baht and you can go all the way to Khao San road. The boat will stop at 7pm.

A vibrant river running through the heart of Bangkok. Chao Phraya is a vibrant river running through the heart of Bangkok that is fun to travel on by long boat. There are also inexpensive ferries that run up and down the river to the major attractions and centres. For the tourist it is fun to get on a one or two hour trip that includes the klongs. A great experiance that allows a different perspective of Bangkok and recommended.

The cheapest boat cruise ever. Hop in at Saphan Taksin and stop where ever you feel up to. Actually none of the pier stop surroundings is a dissapointment. Usually there is an interesting market or a Wat or some other attraction. Great way to move from Silom district to Khao San Road e.g.If you're not used to mive in boats, take your time on the pier watching the people enter the boat. The boat is not properly tied to the pier while passangers change, so it might freak you out. But just observe the movements and follow and imitate the others. Stay focused and all will be fine.We went as far north as Nonthaburi, which is the 3rd last stop. Costed just 17baht. It turned out to be the neighbor town with a beautiful wooden city hall, which is falling down sadly enough. Great floating riverside restaurant there. Really worth visiting!

25/12/15 - 10/01/16. Unfortunately this river is not very clean, from my hotel next to the river I could see lots of rubbish floating on the tide, all the streams that flow into it from bangkok are heavy polluted and full of plastic and rubbish, It's hard to believe that bangkok is world class in some of the shopping areas and yet behind the scenes it's full of rubbish and pollution. I took a walk from the hotel and found a small hidden path down to the river to a riverhouse. What a contrast in class (The wealthy and the very poor). I spent about one hour talking to a local who said the water was full of chemicals.

Sunset fun. Go visit Wat Pho and afterwards walk to the park and river some 200 m away. Grab something to eat and chill on the edge of the park to watch the sun go down over the river and Temple of Dawn. Also get food nearby and eat on the well kept grass lawn in the park. Take a boat cruise if you like.

River Cruise Delight. Take a long-tailed river cruise here. The water is dirty and it can get quite choppy when it is windy but the tour is excellent and the back river-streets of Bangkok are so interesting you could write a book about adventuring through them.Take care to get a cheaper price than advertised for long-tailed boats. The Thai people are good at bargaining!

River running through Bangkok. Taking a boat trip on th Chao Phraya is a must for all visitors. It will provide a more complete view of the city. There is a great variety of boats operating, private "long tailed" speed boats, which can be hired at the pier under the Taksin bridge, as well as larger bus like boats, which one can take to the Grand Palace. Day trips to the ancient capital of Ayudhya on luxury cruise ships operated by the Oriental Hotel, the Peninsula Hotel, the ShangriLa, and others. These boats are air conditioned, with outside decks and chairs, and serve a delicious lunch. Cold towels are provided upon boarding, having viewed the Summer Palace and the ruins of the old capital

Lovely trips along the river. This is just another way of getting different views of this great city. The public boats are cheap and quite comfortable and the many piers make it possible to stop wherever you want to.

Start and end your day with a ride along this fascinating working river. During a recent stay in Bangkok I took one of the river ferries daily, to various sights such as National Museum, Chinatown and Siriraj Medical Museum. Get a good map showing the ferry stops before you set out; if you're not sure where to get off, all the ferry staff know which stop goes to which sight. Take the Skytrain to Taksin station and just hop on any of the ferry boats going upriver (to your right as you face river). We discovered by chance that the commuter boats (that don't have a guide talking on a microphone) are much cheaper - only 18 baht compared to 40 baht for a "guided" ride. The guides are very hard to understand anyway so you are not missing anything by taking the cheaper boat. Also, you do not need to buy a ticket in advance if there is big line at the booth ... just hop on and a lady will come by and you can buy a ticket on the boat. Somehow she remembers who has paid and not paid even though dozens of tourists get on and off at each stop. The sights along the river are fascinating - you see the skyline, temples, fancy hotels, floating businesses and working boats passing by. Especially at sunset with a breeze going, it is a beautiful and relaxing ride affording many photo ops. Many of the ferry stops are also interesting in themselves, with markets you walk through en route to sights, including the Flower Market and Amulet Market. Do not leave Bangkok without taking this ride at least once.

AYUTTHAYA AND RETURN TO BANGKOK BY CRUISE SHIP. My wife and I took my family who were visiting from Seal Beach, California for the Christmas Holidays to the Old City Of Ayutthaya by private van. After viewing 4 temples we then boarded a brand new cruise ship for the return cruise down the Chao Phraya River to Bangkok. This cruise included a very nice buffet lunch. It was an excellent way to spend the entire day.

A 'working' river running through the heart of Bangkok. If you have a hgotel on the river you can watch the worls go by: large barges being towed, the packed express bpoats whizzing up and down ferrying people to work and to tourist attractions, the luxurious hotel shuttles taking you to Thaksin Bridge (close to the Skytrain station), the noisy longboats you can hire by the hour, the illuminated rice barges offering dinner cruises. Next to impossibly high sky scrapers nestle small buildings which seem to have been there forever. There is no promenade next to the river, the best way to experience it is by boat. There is a different world once you leave the river to enter the Klongs, the network of canals where you'll experience a world far away from the hectic of Bangkok.

Old But New, Refreshing. At times the city can be a bit hectic and overwhelming and the river renews a sense of peace and calm within. Although I only got to intake its beauty during an evening tour I found it to be quite amazing being able to see many large temples across the river as well as huge boats that are decorated with vibrant colors.

great way to travel. This river makes the city hum so to speak. You can travel the length of the city on the Chao Praya express for very cheap. Its rapid transit as well. I think its faster than the BTS or MRT. There are several shopping plazas and sights to see along the river. The river and scenery are beautiful at night. A definite do in Bangkok.

Don't get caught out!. Watch out if you get the long tail canal ride from the riverside just off Maha Hat Road.They drop you off by Wat Pho rather than where you started, probably so you can't be heard by the next mark when you complain that your hour trip was actually only about 40 minutes and was rubbish.Personally I thought the trip around the canal behind Wat Arun (not up and down the river) is poor enough without someone trying to rip you off for an exit tax at the end.

Murky waters. We went on a river cruise along this waterways. This is a major trasportation route for goods and travelers in Bangkok. The water looks murky and filled with boats, barges and cruise line. There are many hotes and restaurant along the river.
Should Try Boat. When i want to escape from traffic jam in Bangkok the good way to travel by boat is good choice. and you can see nice view on night time it is fantastic
boat trip. we went for a boat trip on the river, there were a few nice things to see especially wat arun temple

Good way to see life on the river.. Buy a day ticket for 150TBH to give you unlimited rides for a day. You will be able to get on and off as many times as you like to see the sights along the way. Avoid peak times as the boats can get extremely overcrowded.

River cruise in long boat. Traveling the channels of Bangkok's Chao Phrata river is a good thing to do. Whilst many sites from he long boat show broken down dwellings ( like a tired Venice ) certainly for. 1 or 1 1/12 hours good value for approx 2200 baht for complete long boat. We had 7 adults and kids and room for more will take at least 12 plus. Get on around palace area and take water as can be hot. Overall a good mornings trip

Nice to take boat in the evening. You can find many good restaurants along the river. One of easier choice will be hanging out a shopping mall besides river. Taking boat would be also nice. There were boat coming up and down the river at days of Loykraton.

PRETTY OKAY. We set off on an hour cruise in December. It was a nice way to see Bangkok from another perspective. Some temples here and there and also a glimpse of the modern parts of Bangkok. There is a peer where you can get in rates and decide if you want to go on the large boats with lots of other tourists or just with a few people. We got what we paid for and our boat driver did not speak more than two words of English. All the same I reckon it's a great way to see the expanse of Bangkok, take some cool pics and be able to tell your friends that you did it. It won't hurt giving it a try.
What makes Bangkok an amazing place to visit. You haven't been to Bangkok if you did not go to these places. However, be prepared for the very hot and humid temperatures. Dress accordingly.

Dinner Cruise . You should be Visiting this Beautiful River in the Evening as its the most happening places in Bangkok. Though a Bit away from Central bangkok but you have connectivity Via Sky Train also. You need to take the Dinner Cruise which is inclusive of Food and Entertainment on Board. You just need to buy your drinks and they have almost all Brands.
Blue Hai Pani Pani. A convenient way to cross the river absorbing the delights seen simultaneously by boat. Gets busy so be prepared to stand on the boat but that's natural at local attractions.

Excellent place to enjoy. One must not miss this trip. Wonderful, enjoyed full with family. Traditional thai welcome, delicious food, melodious songs, great hospitality. ......wow. Songs are so good, one will automatically dance. Mind blowing
40min tour. For 700 bahts you can enjoy some local sightseeing along the river. I recommend doing the 40min tour by sunset so is not very hot and u have a better view of Wat Arun.

One of longest the river in Thailand. This river is separate Bangkok into two sides. The river is so smelled unclean at all unlike Venice in Italy which it so clean and so nice to travel along the river unlike this river but we still use it for traveling
Best way to get around. Take the express boat and beat all other transport forms in time. And it's fun too. The most important temples to visit are near the river.

Very interesting and pleasant. Absolutely advisable. Very pleasant, by day or by night. It is must to do in Bangkok. May be the water is not very clean but it is not a disturbing issue. All the charm of the city can be appraised from the river. Many, many interesting places to visit and to see (the temples, the canals, the old and new hotels, the old embassies and European buildings etc.). You can choose the public ferry (which costs nothing) or a private taxi (not expensive for more than 4 people).

Fun Experience. To the traveler, you should try to ride a bot through this river, Chao Praya River and see the sunset at the evening. That's quite fun because you ride the boat like you ride a bus. The experience is really fun and interesting.
Life line of Bangkok. Most affordable and practical way to reach popular attractions of Bangkok. Safe anf fairly well maintained

Enchanting working waterway. The Chao Phraya river runs through Bangkok and has several smaller canals that intersect with it in a very similar way to Venice and its canals. Like Venice, Bangkok's Chao Phraya river is very much a working artery of the city. All kinds of water craft ply the waters in all directions. There are different levels of water taxis, express and local; there are also some specially for tourists which cost a lot more and there are smaller taxis for the smaller canals and then there are the long tail boats (think Venice gondolas) for tourists to glide along the smaller canals and see life along the shoreline. We were fortunate enough to experience all of them in the space of just two days in Bangkok. We could never have done this without the expert guidance of Swai, our guide from YourThaiGuide.com. We chose to travel exclusively via public transportation so as to avoid traffic congestion. A wonderful side benefit was that we got to 'do' Bangkok like a native.Swai would collect our money and buy our tickets and then we would wait for the ferries with everyone else. What an amazing adventure! Getting on and off on the Chao Phraya river ferries is not a problem at all. We did also venture out on the ferries of the smaller canals and those were very interesting. You must step on the side of the boat and then step down into it! There is a long tarp on the side running the length of the boat which is pulled up when the boat is moving to avoid spashback and wake from other boats. These smaller ferries barely stop long enough for people to disembark and embark so there is no room for slip-ups, pun intended. The main historical sites such as the Temples are along the river so taking the ferry is almost essential. Who needs the traffic of the roadways? You can also cross the river by ferry boat. The river is lined with businesses, hotels, temples, homes, apartment buildings and is constantly teeming with people. The skytrain connects to the ferry at one point so getting around can be pretty seamless if you know your way or have an expert local guide. Ours took us to three temples, to the Royal Barge Museum, Jim Thompson house and Asiatique, all by boat. Highly recommended!

River with lots of attractions. The river has many attractions like wat arun,wat pho etc. There are ferries every 30 mins from sapah taksin BTS station. The ticket cost 40 baht 1 ride and 150 baht for one day pass.

Cruising the best of Bangkok. The open public launches which convey passengers at high speed along the central river in this fascinating city are cheap, exciting and a great way to keep cool.Essentially water buses, they nip from bank to bank stopping at designated landings. Simple way to see the sights; great way to meet the locals and easiest access to the temples and ancient city. My wife enjoyed the experience so much I had difficulty removing her once seated and soaking up the smells and spray.And when you are bored with the splendour and daily living, drop off for a delightful meal at any one of a hundred inexpensive and delicious eateries.The main ferry journeys between the skytrain terminus and the King's bridge.

Nice but a little smelly. The river serves as a good medium of transport with he express boats and ferries, plus there are the river cruises going around, which is a pretty nice attraction for tourists. However, while using the express boat service, we found the river water a little smelly and dirty

A relaxing river cruise. This was one of the highlights of my time in Bangkok- I was intrigued by the mix of new buildings and shanty shacks. A real illustration of Bangkok life.The river is a spectacular way to view the city and the hop on and off aspect makes travel easy.A must do!

Gateway to main Temple Attractions and Asiatique. If possible book a riverside hotel for 2-3 days of your stay (Assuming a stay of 4-5 days). Most riverside hotels has a free riverboat to central pier. You can then choose Tourist Boat (1 day 150 bhat or 40 Bhat per trip or get local boats. 15 Bhat per trip) . Watch which local boats stop at which pier,, (done via Color Coded lines with Boats having colored flag flying).Wat Arun, Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Flower Market all are accesible easliy by boat. You can also get a Long tail boat (1500 bhat per 6 pax..- full boat, for some Klong-(canal) tours to see some local views) .Come evening a free boat to Asiatique night market will start and run till mid night. If not at riverside hotels. then Central Pier is easily accesible by Saphan Taksin BTS .

good and convenient. There are a lot of metro skytrain lines, which crisscross the city. But unfortunately do not reach to the Wat Pho, Palace area, Khaosan Rd etc.We took the local inland boat (not the tourist boat) to reach those places. This itself was a nice experience as one could see how locals in Bangkok stay and travel, from close.
Nice view. Nice view if you are on the main stretch (where the express boat services ply). Won't recommend the interior stretches.

Bangkok's river for all. Used for transport, scenery, etc. Water taxi alternative to avoiding traffic if in route to your destination. Not the cleanest river in the world but does the job. Still worth a looksy. Enjoy!

The water is not clear but riverside views are great. River's water look like chocolate water.Just kidding.But there's no trashes in the river.The buildings and restaurants on alongside river is fantastic and nice to see at night.Free shuttle boats to Asiatique come in every 15 minutes.Overall experience is good.A nice place to chill with friends.
You will love this. Just for the long boat experience alone. This will let you see how the Thai people live. Some poverty and some wealth all mixed together.

Excellent. Excellent trip to see the other side of the city houses on sticks right next to the sky scrapers, if your in in Bangkok during the light festival you will love it but like anywhere in Bangkok it's very busy but very much enjoyable.

Boat trip. Great little boat trip, just the two of us and a lady driver winding thru the canals. Be prepared for other boats to come out of nowhere to sell you the usual tourist tat but also a few cold beers. Good experience and value for money.

Nice trip along the river. Nice visit to Chao Phraya River over the Christmas period, there is tons going on around it with places to eat, shops, bars etc.
Many high rise speciality hotels seem to be along the river also, some of which looked amazing!
Worth a visit if your in Bangkok

Very best Bangkok attraction. I can spend hours on the river observing busy life ob Bangkok from the riverside. Take public transportation boat which costs only a few Bath, find a good seat if possible and enjoy the river and the city of Bangkok. I prefer this attraction to private small boats, which are expensive, noisy and to fast to enjoy.Also a good place for taking pictures. Try also night cruise with dinner boat. Food usually not the best but night views at the temples make it better.Don't do if in a hurry spend 2-3 hours on the river.Very recommended.

Get a brief view of Bangkok. A terrific cheap way to enjoy a nice water view of the city. Make sure you catch a local ferry not one designed for tourists. It is a simple hop on hop off system. Gives you a good idea on places to visit when you have a more suitable opportunity.
lovely to see bangkok from the water(river). easy to find and very cheap sightseeing on the river the view over Town is fantastic and many local people go here every day
Dirty green river. We crossed the bridge and see this dirty river. Some kids were jumping from the bridge and swimming in river. Do not deserve to say river.
Amazing site. Amazing, huge, with all kinds of commute, impressive high and low life, busy docs busy streets local food, exotic smells the best thing to do in Bangkok, go around the river

See the life blood of Thailand with no embellishments. We took a boat from one of the outdoor markets back to our hotel via the Chao Phraya River. The boat basically had a car engine attached to the rear. Once the motor was engaged, its horsepower lifted the prow of the boat above the water and we were off. The river shows Bangkok's past and present. Makeshift shanties with docks jut out into the water harkening back to a time when people lived off the bounty the river offered. Now the river is filled with floating garbage and remnants of things tossed away and abandoned. Rising above both banks are towering office buildings and hotels. The natural beauty of the river provides a naked glimpse of Bangkok's dilemma -a mix of extreme poverty and great wealth existing side by side.

More to it than meets the eye. The river it self is quite normal but there are miles of 'Venice' like waterways to explore and we took a boat trip that covered it all. A nice trip to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city

Convenient but a bit rocky with long tail boats....stick to ferry and hotel shuttles. I was not to comfortable on long tail boats but definitely a nice way to see Bangkok and travel fast. Amazing to watch at night time...so much is gaining on this river.....
GOOD VIEW OF BANGKOK RIVER SIDE. BTS directly connected to the place where once can get ferries. it was enjoyable to see places like china town & other temples from Chao phraya express boat.

Splendid way to see Bangkok. My wife and I planned to have a trip on a long tail (long slim boat with a massive truck engine & huge prop shaft that ships tourists around at breakneck speed) but in the event it was too choppy for her to get in safely so I went on my own. Great way to see the city, and make sure you get to visit the canals behind the Wat Arun side of the river, because these show a different aspect of Bangkok altogether.

Dirty River. I enjoyed traveling through the Chao Phraya River and loved the nice views of Bangkok. However, I found this river dirty and the water murky. a lot of dirt is carelessly dumped into this river. I do recommend my friends to experience cruising the Chao Phraya and have a close look at how Thai people travel in crowded and sometimes risky conditions through this river.

Loved the river flow by from the Mandarin Oriental. We came late night to Mandarin Oriental to eat at the veranadah restaurant and spend couple of hours sitting there admiring the river and the lit ferries go by. It was very scenic and serene. Worth a visit and spend time on the river.

Lively!!!. Most enjoyable at sunset or dinner time. Fabulous view & the dinner cruises add a lot of charm. Very lively & there is so much to absorb with some fine restaurants. I could spend hours by the river sipping a glass of Merlot....
Well Worth River Trip. Super little trip up and down the river getting off and on were it suits you to see so many various Temples and other sites of all types.
Beautiful. Although polluted it is nice to see the city from this vantage point. Take the time for a cruise or dinner boat.

Love the adventure. A good way to move around, relaxing, good views, cooling. If you can, give it a go. There are some stops that are central down- town feel, others central markets. Prices vary but all public 'ferry-type' boats are inexpensive.

Cruising Down Chao Phraya for Dinner. A memorable dinner experience with an array of delicious buffet spread on the cruise Princess. We were entertainment by a live band as we cruised along Chao Phraya by night . The lights of the buildings created a wonderful atmosphere.
Fun. Make a private boat tour in this river.Ypu can see their houses and vidit wst arun in the same day.Worth a visit to snake farm to see a show

River of enjoyment. We used a water taxi almost everyday to see and attend the different attractions that were close to this wonderful river. Yes and to save money as the water taxi's were much cheaper that a regular taxi or a tuk tuk.

Lifeline of the City. We traveled many places along the river using the ferries, which are quick, inexpensive, and cool because of the breeze off the water. You pay the "conductor" on board so make sure to have change. The ferries can get crowded during rush hours. Try to get a perch along the edge for the best views. We also took a longtail boat along the river and along the canals (khlongs) in Thonburi, on the west side of the Chao Phraya. There's a temple along the shore where you can buy bread from the monks and feed the enormous carp swimming in the river beside your boat. There are also interesting restaurants and shops along the shores of the canals. It's fascinating to see how people live with the river as their back yard.
Life on the river. There is a lot of life on the river and it is fascinating just watching the traffic. Night time is wonderful seeing the city lit up.

A must do if in Bangkok...... We hired a boat and driver for two hours at 2000 barts to take us around the canals. Amazing to see and humbling - so many advances in Bangkok yet so little has changed for so many. To come to this incredible city and not do this trip would make your experience just like going to Singapore, Dubai or Hong Kong - a big shopping mall.
Great Views of the City. We used all sorts of transport on the river; small boats the blue ferry and a private tour from Ayuthaya.

Want to go back again!. We traveled to Thailand and while there took a cruise. It was like stepping back it time in many areas. The Thai people are a very gracious and polite people. I was truly amazed at the dramatic and sudden transition from the "city dwellers" and the "country dwellers". My bucket list has an entry to go back to Thailand again!

Interesting way of moving around in Bangkok. For 14THB you can take a longboat and navigate the Chao Praya. It's interesting to see the great number of boats that run through the river and how they are used as a public transportation. It is a great way to move around the city.

You need to take a trip on a public boat. Whenever I visit Bangkok I take the Skytrain to the Taksin station (Silom line) and take the public boat up the river (14 Baht, a true Bangkok bargain). Get out wherever you want, i.e. in Chinatown or further up north near Kao San Road. Unforgettable. Not handicap accessible, getting in and out of the boat needs some skills and caution.
By boat in Bangkok . A must go when you are in Bangkok . In love to travel by boat when I amIn Bangkok . It's easy , convenient and the high bus-boats run very frequently .

Great cruise experience. We visited the river cruise on new year's eve and it was a wonderful experience. The cruise was comfortable, the music was great and the dinner buffet was sumptuous. Recommended for a romantic night on the river.

Nice. Was a nice river cruise. Nothing major to see although you do capture a few photo moments but not as many as you may think. Beware of asking the tuk tuk drivers to take you the pier. They take you to a non central pier where others try to hussle you onto a long tail boat or rickety ferry for 1k Bhat. We walked to another central pier although the tuk tuk driver told us it was closed. Tell the tuk tuk drivers no stops and only the central pier no others before you get in while negotiating the price.

Quick way to get to the Grand Palace. The river boats to the Grand Palace run from the Saphan Thaksin (Central Pier) towards the grand palace. Avoid the tourist boats and follow the queue to the extreme left of the pier as you get off the skytrain. Costs mere 10 or 20 baht for a ride.

Fun to explore. The river is nice to visit. You have two main choices: cheapest option is to go to BTS station on river then walk to pier and take a big boat (blue flag color) for 40 Bahts that will take you all along the river announcing the stops. You can get off wherever you like. Once you get off however you are not allowed back in except with a new ticket. Sites you can go to using Thai method: wat pho temple, Chinatown, and the grand temple. Second option is to take a private or semi private tour in the river. I ended up paying about 750 baht after negotiations for a one hour tour. Beautiful thing about it is that you actually go off the main river into small water alleys and between houses etc which is a fun experience. One boat even approached to sell souvenirs calling itself a floating market haha. Whichever way you choose to explore the chao phraya river: do it! And enjoy!
River cruise to see sights. Good way to see the sights of Bangkok river, Very crowdedCheap at 40baht one-way but 150baht all day pass is worth the money, get on/off as you please

Lifeblood of Bangkok. You almost have to visit the Chao Phraya River when visiting Bangkok - it's the best way to get to see the temples and have an enjoyable time too! There are various boats at various docks, and you pay a small fee to get dropped off at whatever location up want (they are marked off with numbers). The breeze is wonderful and you get a great view of the city.You can also book charter trips to take you along the river and side canals - very eye opening to see how people live. I definitely recommend doing this.

Different view of the city. I always love seeing cities from the water - i think it gives a completely different view. The river is actually much larger than it appears when just driving across the bridge. Its quite calm and nice to travel along. We did both a dinner cruise which was great to see everything lit up, and caught both the free hotel shuttle across and one of the tourist boats down it. The river is kinda brown in colour and does have rubbish floating in it, but it is still nice. It is also a lot more relaxing than catching a taxi and being stuck in traffic! There are lots of piers along the way to stop at and reach all the tourist spots. When you get to a pier just be aware that there are tourist boats and local boats. When you are at the pier it looks like the tourist boat is the only one available but that is not the case - just ask someone where the local boat goes from (we got caught out this way). The local boats are cheaper (14baht one way), but the tourist boat (40 baht one way or 150 baht unlimited travel for between certain piers) is nicer and has a guide up front giving information about sites and stops.

Central to Bangkok Life. This river is central to Bangkok life - not only in terms of tourism and the major hotels along it, but more-so in terms of the economic value (fishing, etc) to the local population.
best trip of tour. no better way to see a town than on its public ferry's, cheap cheerful and bustling would recomend a full day pick a dock no. and just enjoy the sights from the river

Big woderful and scenic.. You can get the tourist boat but it the speakers are so loud pointing out the sights it is deafening. We prefer to take the public ferry about 25c a ride . It is crowded at the beginning and at the end but thins out as it moves along the 32-333 piers and is very enjoyable and scenic . Maps of bangkok have the pier numbers and it is easy to get off at whichever attraction or part of Bangkok one wants to see.
Dirty. Very dirty river. It is cool to watch the long boats going back and forth. It also super cheap to grab a water taxi if you need one.
A must. This is a must if you visit Bangkok. Jump on a tourist boat or just a regular river boat. Jump from station to station.
Dirty but worthwhile!. Take the BTS på Dsphan Thaksin, get on an orangeflag boat, hop of at pier 15, Thawet pier, have a walk and enjoy a different Bangkok!

A great way to get around some inaccessible spots in Bangkok. Some people prefer to take a tour of the river but in my opinion it is best to incorporate the river within you day plan since some sites in Bangkok are best accessed via the river as it helps avoid traffic and these sites are not connected via BTS train. Some sites include Wat Pho, Palace, Khao San Road and Asiatique. To get to Wat Pho, Palace or Khao San Road, the most enjoyable and cheapest way is to take the BTS train to Saphan Taksin station and then take the ferry from there (2 min walk to ferry Terminal) for just 40 bahts (less than $2). The ferry ride is enjoyable, has a tour guide and you can get off at any of the several places on the way (restaurants, malls and historical sites). I would recommend getting off at the terminal by Wat Pho and visit Wat Pho and area. You can then get back on the ferry and go to Asiatique in the evening and enjoy some nice restaurants, artifact stores, massages and desserts. From Asiatique to BTS there is a free ferry.

Take a boat ride. A trip down the Chao Phraya river is a great way to see a cross section of Bangkok life and architecture. There are myriad cruises or you can hire an individual longtail boat, but for an authentic Bangkok experience take one of the local Express boats (like river buses): cheap, crowded, manic and unforgettable. If you head for Sathorn bridge you can pick up the Skytrain there and continue your explorations, still avoiding the hideously congested Bangkok roads.
An excellent cruise. We had a wonderful cruise on the river Chao Phraya.The city important points are visible.The food served on the cruise is fantastic.

Some nice canal and river trips. There are all kinds of boat trips available on both river and canals large cruisers and smaller long boats seem to be most popular . There are day trips and night cruises with dinner cruisers which seem very popular . There are numerous ferries on the river ,making sight seeing very easy ,lots of temples are on the river as well as royal barges ,skytrain also stops by river , making access to shopping very easy .We tried a canal trip , which was great as you can see all the local riverside properties ,the trip we did had to access the canals by massive locks which was fun .Be wary of floating traders as even after a bit of bartering are not cheap and if your on a local boat be cautious when they stop on the river as there is normally a tuk tuk driver lurking ready to take you to a tailor or jeweller . A pleasant way to spend a few hours .

Nice overview. We took on our first day the public transportation with express boat at one of the stations and went through the whole cit until end station. Very nice overview over the whole city and very cheap!

Dirty water. We took a longtailed boat and paid 500 baht to take us to the Wat Arun. It was good for the experience. Avoid the scam of going to the local floating market. It consisted of one boat approaching you with a few fruits for sale. Then he wanted us to pay for a beer for the boat driver. Total scam! We did get some mangos, but didn't buy the beer for the driver.

Great way to visit landmarks in Bangkok. I did the river cruise to visit the many landmarks and places of interest in Bangkok. This is a good way to do the visits. You can get the one day unlimited pass to visit the places of interest. Chao Praya tour is a must for visitors.

A Better Alternative in Navigating Bangkok. City streets are crowded. Dealing with cab and Tuktuk drivers can be very stressful too. I find river transport much stress free and faster. It is relaxing and just right to rest after each site/walking destination.

River Taxis. The Chao Phraya River can be best visited by taking water taxi (long boats). You don't need to take the expensive river boats to enjoy it. Just take stroll up and down the river. The river taxi can be accessed at Saphan Taksin (Sukhumit Line) and you grab the long boat to the famous sites, Wat Pho, Grand Palace etc. There is a color coding system, so just ask. You can pay for the ticket during the line or on the boat itself. It cost only 10baht or something. It was really cheap. But would not do it twice.A tip: pay attention to each jetty they stop.
Long Boat. We hired a private long boat for a 1-1/2 hour ride on the river and around a few klongs. Cost of 1,000bht per person. Like the roads the river is also heavily congested but worth a look.

Fast Way to Travel to Sites. Took a ferry up river to get closer to Grand Palace. Totally worth it. Taking a cab in Bangkok can be a potential nightmare - 13 million cars and a lot of traffic.Took a ferry to the Grand Palace to save time. The cabby who took us from our hotel to the dock said it was a good idea because a ride in his car to the location would have taken about an hour (in heavy traffic). The ferry took 15 minutes. Nice. River was fine...a bit choppy and plenty of debris in it...but that is not uncommon in Asia.
Awesome Night trip.. We booked the river cruise from River city. The trip was best part, dont miss out the Chao Phraya River trip. You won't regret later.

A great way to see bangkok. Other than the usual Silom or Siam shopping area, this trip bring us back in time. We see Temples, The grand Palace, Chinatown and many more along the river. Moving along the canal, we see how people lived alongside the canal or river.

Take a cruise and have fun. This is by far one of my most interesting and memorable river cruise. I first went on a river cruise when I was 15 during Christmas and I again visited it during December 2014 with my wife. You should try to go on a dinner cruise.

Interesting perspective of the city. We took a two hour boat tour going through the heart of Bangkokwithout encountering traffic. We saw homes of all sizes, the poor and the rich, facing the river with beautiful gardens or clutter in their front yard. It is an interesting perspective of how the Thai culture lives without going through their front gate.
Wonderful mode of transport for a bangkok experience. Beat jams to access places near the river. Great and cheap. Be sure to ask which boat to take to your destinations.
Must. You can take the regular commuter ferries that go up and down the river. It is an inexpensive way to see this city artery and the town from a different perspective.

Too many tourists. Too many under-dressed tourists squeezing, shoving and pushing just to see the 3 sights closest to central piers. Couldn't find a boat to take me to N20. Operators herd us like cattle.

A unique way to navigate the city.. Jump onto the public boats and jump on and off where ever you feel compelled. Old meets new,a great way to see the hidden gems of Bangkok,and therapy to day workings of river life. Make sure you don't sit in areas reserved for the Buddhist monks. Cheap and easy.

The heart of the city. The river runs through the entire city, so going on a boat while you're there is a must. Some boats go up and down the river, while others simply ferry you across. Sometimes you have to wait, but usually the price isn't very high.

Great way to see the river. Such a hub of activity, so many ways to see it, we used the public transport to get to the royal palace - interesting in itself seeing the locals hanging off the side - health and safety? We also did a dinner cruise (with Loy Nova), a great way to bring in the New Year, and took a private long boat trip down the river and canals

Boat trip. The boat trip was part of our highlights tour of Bangkok. Much easier form of travel than the traffic congested streets. Great to see the city from a slightly different perspective and a good way to break up the day trip
experience the local transport. forget the tourist boat at 80 baht go on the express boat service with the locals at 14bh tsee all the sites jump off and on as you please at any landing, Great fun
Good for transport. using boat is very good way of transport within the centre of the city - fast and cheap. Many of interesting places are arround river.

All day tourist pass on boats and incredible deal. For only 150B you can buy an unlimited pass on the boats plying the river. Hop on / hop off at maybe 10 stops along the river. The river is cleaner than it was 20 years ago, but that is not saying much. Beware: the boats are crowded at peak times.

Great river your . Make sure you barter hard There were 4 of us for a one hour 30 minute cruise including the back canals the local started at 4,500 bart, after a quick haggle we paid 2000 Bart for 4Going through the back canal was a real eye opening seeing how some Thai people live and survive Well worth it

take the boat with the orange flag. Best place to start the boat ride is BTS Saphan Taksin.Watch out: There is many different boats, mainly one tourist boat (blue flag) and the normal boat (orange flag). Tourist boat is a 150 Baht for the whole day, orange flag 14 Baht for one ride. The tourist boat only runs from 9 a.m to 4 p.m, the orange flag from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m.I always enjoy the 'normal' boat as it is a mix of locals, tourists and sometimes monks.It also serves more piers.From the boat you can see many of the tourist sites, but also huge 5-star hotels next to very simple huts by the river, Bangkok old and new, rich and humble.
Very busy and very choppy river to visit.. Brown water with lots of trash of all sorts in the river. Great at night when it is calmer and you can't see all the trash Night dinner cruises are great.

Different way to travel. I wouldn't recommend you fall into the river. I wouldn't imagine it is the cleanest...however, it is worth a trip down the river to avoid traffic and to see the city from a different angle.

On our way to the Palace. On our way up we took a fast long boat. Great fun especially at speed though a bit overpriced if I honest. A much better way is the hop on hop off ferry which stops at several interesting spots. At 40 bath this is a real steal.

Dirty, polluted, crowded and sketchy. Since Bangkok traffic is awful and getting to the major tourist attractions is not possible via the BTS, you almost have to take the express boats on the Chao Phraya River. My partner and I were expecting something more orderly, however my entire experience was chaotic, and extremely crowded. It was difficult to obtain help in English on the routes and tourists are charged 40 baht per person on a blue flag boat vs. 14 baht a person when you take a local orange flag boat. The difference is there is a "guide" on the blue boat that speaks in English (which you can't hear cause it's loud). The exhaust fumes from the boat is also overwhelming, causing my skin to break out and rashes to form. The drop off and pick up methodology is also very concerning as one false move and you can end up in the polluted river. We had no other viable choice but to take this boat/ferry thing.

Tourists are messed around . Unfortunately the locals want to make money out of tourists so it's difficult to try and take a cheap local taxi or a local river boat. You get pushed around and treated like rubbish and in the end it's just safer and easier to just take the Tourist Tour Boats for 40 BT each way.
Beautiful . Take a cruise down the river or come during sunset. It's part and parcel of bustling Bangkok and is worth a visit! If you are going to Asiatique there's a free shuttle boat!

Magnificent . This was a great experience for both my wife and I. Seeing houses and people nestled right along the edge of the river was astounding. We traveled to the temples from our hotel via the tourist boat. What a great view in the evening as well.

get the normal boat not turist. we enjoyed the ride, just be clever and take the normal boat with orange flag rather than the tourist boat - for same trip you pay 14TBH not 40TBH. get to the queue and skip the cashier to avoid overaging - someone will come with tickets to the queue if not you can still get the ticket on the boad
Plenty to see. Used the river to go to wat pho and always imazed how mighty this river is. It is worth a boattrip to visit some attractions.
Cruised. Nothing much to see along the river. Some new houses and very old houses on the slits. Only highlight u see is seeing wat arun from the river. Better if u take at night
Good place to spend the evening. Dont miss taking a cruise down the river -- great food in the evening and great views -- good way to just relax after a hard day sightseeing

Skip the cruise and take the local ferry to get a local taste. If you are okay with crowd then take this cheap tour. Take the skytrain to reach taksen. Then take a tickets to the last stop. It cost us 42bh for one person. You can get to see the lighting of the temples and the grand palace. Get down after the cable bridge and board a returning ferry. Many tourists travel like this and with my small kid who is a fussy eater this seemed a much better option than cruise with dinner.

Romatic travel way for couples. Must travel by couple a seperate boat,very sceneric you can visit Temple of dawn in Chao Phrya river also River cruise available with dinner in the evening in a luxury boat

Lots of things to See here. A lively river in Bangkok where some attractions lie. River transportation is frequent and being used by not only the locals but also tourists. Same as normal train or subway stations, the river piers represent stations in Chao Phraya's term.

Huge river. Its huge river in the middle of bangkok , many boats , sometimes it gets scary ride , over loaded boat , dirty water , but nice to ride sometimes to get to the other place faster like wat arun and asiatique

Watch your wallet. Be careful when trying to arrange a trip down the river, or you just might wind up going down the river. Catching one of the ferries or taxis is one thing, trying to catch one of the cooler lontail fast boats is much more difficult. It is very much a hassle or hustle that can quickly turn into a scam. You definitely have to negotiate the price and that price could be anywhere from 30 to $50 an hour or more to start. These are not small business man, they're more like games who run the fastboats on the river. Be careful of any taxi driver that tells you they will take you to the river taxi or ferry piers. they might say " there is a lot of traffic , it would be easier to go by River." What they will do is take you to one of the private piers for the fast tail boats. Once there, you will get the aggressive hard pitch sale. The taxi driver who brought you there , would of course get his cut. There are also "crews" that will sell you a ride at some of the ferry and taxi piers. If you use those, you have to negotiate the price well in advance and even then there's a good chance they're going to be asking you for a big tip after. It is certainly a fun experience but be careful as the boat captain tries to splash water on you for fun, no one wants that river water on them.
Must do . Take the CP express boat from Taksin to Nonthaburi Biggest bargain in BKK Jump on and off whenever you see something get lost and enjoy the real BKK
Great time to spend to know the place. Spend about USD35 to view the whole river- why not?; great experience and explore the activities along the riverside.

Nice but confusing boat system. There are different types of boats to see the river. Based on the boat flag color, it could be a tourist boat stopping at all piers near tourist attractions, or it could be an express boat stopping only at certain points. There are separate boats to cross to the other side of the river. Piers are crowded with people and vendors of all sortsIt's a good way to visit the attractions near the riverside if you could figure out where to buy what ticket for which boat. Dock and piers are slippery and may be unstable at times.

Long Boat trip ALWAYS BARTER - cheaper travel . Never accept their first price. And handy tip: only have max cash 1,100 (for 2 people) as they will accept this. Although we thoroughly enjoyed our trip we would have liked to know the pricing before we went. So we knew what to expect. We were first quoted for a round trip from the pier sight seeing and back 3,000THB ( =£60) and very quickly managed to get the guy down to 1,100. Plus that's all we had! For one day in Bangkok it's worth it to see things from the water. Really pleased we did. But warning: the water is rough! And a little scary first time round. But it's worth it.

Excellent. The Chao Phraya River boat Ride was a Excellent experience for me. The view was great and the captain did a good job slowing down and turning when needed. The ride was fun and there were paddle boats coming around during the ride. Over all the ride was excellent.

Beware of scams!. Don't get talked into doing a longboat tour of the canals when "the grand palace is closed for lunch", since the grand palace is never closed for lunch. The canal was filthy and you get no good views of any of the temples. There are better things to do along the river and in Bangkok, but avoid the canal tour.
Take the boat Taxi. Take the boat Taxi and local and affordable fun way to explore Bangkok by River, great fun and highly enjoyable
a different view of Bangkok. It is always fun to go on a boat on the Chaopraya ... lots of things to see from a different perspective and no traffic
Not so special. Not so special. The river is nothing compared to other famous rivers in the world. May be skipped. The view is ordinary. The evening dinner cruise is just ok.

TOO MUCH TRASH. Amount of trash floating around was disappointing but the sights along the part of the river we cruised were worth seeing. Had to wait in the river next to a police boat while one of the royal princes took part in the run for dad race (not sure that's the actual name of the event which was a run in honor of their fathers' day and in honor of the king). Made it was bit more exciting! This was a private trip as part of an overnight visit to Bangkok.
Beautiful princess. Went to Chao Phraya at night for a dinner cruise aboard the Chaophraya Princess from Orientel Pier. What a beauty the city of Bangkok looks from the river.
Lifeline of bangkok . Do take a cuise along the river on the ferry as it symbolises the city. Tourist boats are good .no need to take a private boat.
Great ride. finding to little boat for 1 hour rent there is enjoy full ride to watch famous Buddha temples great

Day ticket on the river. for 150 baht you can get a day ticket with which you can get on or off at any of the 9 stops up or down the river all day. A free booklet gives info about each stop. Really worth it to visit several interesting places and everywhere there is great street food.

Cheap and good ferry service.. Nice river. Plenty of cruising options. Good ferry connections. Great way to commute in Bangkok . Connected to the river are various canals with floating markets. Don't muss them
excellent. the river is an excellent mode of transportain..beautiful river with high rises all along the banks and the main attractions are by this river.the fares are reasonable.

Excellent views of the city from the river. A must see/ do activity is taking a ride in a boat on the river where you can get amazing photos of Bangkok not to mention view lots that you would not otherwise see. Recommended for all.

Worth doing. We got on an Orange flag boat and travelled the entire length of the route,for this the charge was only 14 Baht-we made notes of the piers where we wanted to get off on the return journey.The Orange boats do get very crowded but it certainly an interesting experience and part of everyday life for the locals in Bangkok.If you prefer a more leisurely experience,get the Blue flag tourist boat-this only travels half the distance though,costs 40 Baht but it is pretty much empty. They do a 'day pass' for 180Baht,so good value if you take 5 or more journeys in a day.

Cruising the River in BKK. I have had different river cruises and highly recommend this to you in Bangkok. Daytime cruise with lunch is a very relaxing way to see the city from a different perspective. The night dinner cruises are magnificent and a must do when in town the city lights from the river are breathtaking. Most of the better hotels can help you with a booking or go through a tourist booking shop. The night cruises are so popular that you must book in advance.
River Cruise. Taken from Oriental Pier and takes about 1,5hours. Trip goes to channels to see Bangkok´s everyday life and was therefore very good experience...

Take a trip at the river.. Almost everywhere Along the river there are plenty to see and experience. It is higly recommended to take a boatride. If you like the tailboats, you can easily find one, but be avare of scammers trying to take exorbitant prices for a ride. There are plenty of boats that transport the locals from place to place for a small fee.

Very interesting!. There's so much to do and see, you could spend a week around here and still not covered the area. Well worth a go even for an hour or two to experience Bangkok on the river. So many places to go and see, food, restaurants, bars and shopping malls. Not to mention off to different areas of water housing, floating markets and Thai industries. As I said there is so much to see.

Try it once, you will do it again!. Though not the cleanest body of water around, it is wide and long. If you take a "fast boat", basically a very long canoe that could seat 20, with a V8 engine that nearly flies, you can fly down the river just for the fun of the ride. You can rent the boats for a few hundred baht for an hour or more. For a more relaxed trip with a destination, take one of the many ferry boats that go up and down the river to the temples and tourist areas. The mix of ancient and ultra modern along the river make for some great pics. Should see it in the day, but the night lights make it very memorable. At night, you will not care if the river is not as clean as you would like it to be. It smells like a river and not anything worse!

Rent a longtail boat and take your guests on a journey on the Chao Phraya and adjacent canals. Amazing. Cheap too. We often stay at the Mandarin Oriental over the Chao Phraya and love nothing more than sitting on the terrace watching the boats go by. But what we highly recommend is renting a Longtail boat for an hour or two and going through all the back canals. Whenever we have guests in town we ALWAYS do this and it is always great---and the photos are fantastic as are the visual memories. And it's only about 800 to 1000 baht (cheaper depending on how you book it) for a private tour... I can't recommend this enough, and it's so inexpensive too. We recommend doing it in early morning or later afternoon when light on the river is beautiful---it's a bit more harsh and humid mid day.

I Love Seeing the Chao Praya River. I've been on the "River of Kings" many times since 1985 and it never ceases to amaze me. There's always something going on and people to watch whether on the river banks or on the boats.
A must for every first time visitor to Bangkok!

Good . Nice way to see the River canal area. Bargain the prices as expensive and end up paying only less than 1/2 start price.
They use the James Bond style local boats from the film and like to try and drive like him!!!!

Interesting walk and one canmake small detours from the river to look at the shops. One can walk from one side of town to the other along this river. We went my rail to search for some jewellery on this side of town as it was cheaper than Sukhumvit then found a well airconditioned multi story shopping centre to explore and cool down before decided to follow the river back to as close to our hotel as we could find and ended with a tuktuk ride home. A great day.

Good but slightly confusing . My family wanted to find a way to do something in Bangkok the day we arrived and needed to make sure we could combat jet lag so we decided to take the river boatThere were quite a few boats operating and ended up purchasing the 150 baht all day pass from the most popular company Chao phraya river tour boat.The boat took 25 minutes to come (which we should have been able to figure out ourselves from the schedule but were jet lagged) and once it came it was nice. We got seats on the window/water side and we got good views as we travelled up the riverThe only issues we had were figuring out when to get off the boat and then which boat was tied to the same ticket we had purchased.The people working on the piers where you are dropped off and picked up spoke no English and misdirected us several times to get on a boat going the wrong directionWe did finally end up on a local boat that took is back to the central pier starting point but is recommend finding an English speaker to help coordinate stops and times etc before you depart
Beautiful. You can use the public transport boats or hire a long tail boat, I used both and loved it. Another definite must do while in Bangkok.

Great way to spend a few hours. . This was a nice afternoon for my husband and I. We climbed on a boat near the Mandarin Oriental and took the 1 hour cruise. I'm not sure we went exactly, but we had a great time. Our driver was kind and courteous and he stopped at a friends place to have us buy souvenirs, which we didn't want, but were able to get a few beers for the trip. Overall a great time.
Beautiful. Bustling river full of life with lots to do. The river is the heart of Bangkok. Many places to eat and tourist attraction are all around it. Can't miss for Bangkok. Take a boat ride

just to experience travelling using the river transport. went to chao phraya river just to experience the river transport in Bangkok. and also to visit the reclining Buddha by boat. use the orange flag. cheap and easy.
GOOD BUFFET DINNER ON CRUISE. Journey was good on cruise.View was amazing while sailing.Worth Dinner for 2300 Bhats for couple with views

Amazing Waterway. I think the Chao Phraya River is one of the highlights of a trip to Bangkok. Each time we've stayed in Bangkok we've been lucky enough to have a hotel room with a view of the river. Of all the cities with rivers flowing through them, the Chao Phraya may be the most well used. During the day its a constant stream of commercial traffic, hotel shuttle boats and water taxis. Its amazing just to watch the activity. Plus, using the very inexpensive water taxis is the cheapest and easiest way to get to the key tourist sites along the river.

A river for relax. Every time when I got stressed from whatever happened to me I always take a boat along Chao Phraya River to see stunning view. We also can see temples which make you calm and away from worries.As well some Pierre you can fine simple or even fine dine restaurants too.It is very easy just go to Sathorn Pierre then we can fine so many boats.
Cruise dinner. The cruise dinner is not so special, you could see trashes on the river.. But then you could see a lot of tourism spots along the river.

Don't use the tourist boat!!. Use the ordinary taxi boats.....They are a fraction of the price and great fun.For about 17 bahts each you can go all the way up to Nonthaburi where there is a really good market and lots of eating stands.
Real Bangkok. Take a water taxi and experience the real Bangkok life. One of the least expensive but most authentic experience in Bangkok.

Love at first sight.. We stayed at Baan Wanglang and had an amazing riverfront view from our hotel room. I don't know what it is, but I feel in love with this river. The view of the old city is beautiful, as are the lighted boats and colorful sunsets. Taking the river taxis was fun and convenient. Yes, it's not the cleanest river, but I still think it's beautiful.

A busy waterfront with great view of the skyline of Bangkok. Would highly recommend to stay at a hotel on the river front. Take a boat ride or take the dinner boats . It is a busy river and its a great way to travel to some parts of the city. You can also go to Asiatique ( the night bazaar) or the Palace by boat.
Beautiful and cooling!. Check out this place to see the Grand Palace and other sights of interest. Being near the water is refreshing during the hot Thailand days.

River trip in Bangkok. Took a trip on the river in Bangkok and was surprised to read it's termed the Venice of the Far East. Nothing could be farther from the truth. The river and its offshoots were teeming with rubbish and broken buildings.

The cool breeze. Public transport ferries and private boats are available to cruise in this river. We had a private boat included in our tour so we were away from crowded shared boats, otherwise I don't think it would be a pleasure filled ride in a public transport with an infant.Anyway, the water is not clean at all in this major river of Bangkok. The best things were the cool breeze you feel while cruising through the river and also the waterways there are well managed by government by controlling traffic and constructing lift canals, etc to avoid water ingress in houses nearby.It is a must do thing in Bangkok but just once.

Not be to missed, sunsets along the river are marvelous. With ferries and longboats plying the murky waters for miles, we chose both larger ferry and longboat to access the Grand Palace, National Museum and the neighborhood canals.The Asiatique Night Market is magical at sunset and after dark, with the dinner and tradtional Thai dance show a real treat. The market itself is splendid.

Watch the world go by!. I love life on the river. Sit by the river and watch daily life go by, or hire a private long tail boat to explore the canals or for the more adventurous jump on a water taxi to travel up and down!

A must see while in Bangkok. There is so much to see along both sides of this river. You really must see it. Take a boat ride. Take a canal tour. Stop at random points along the river and take a walking tour. River transportation is cheap and efficient. You can spend several days getting on and off the various commuter boats making random stops for shopping, eating and just plain sight seeing. You can also take a river boat to the Sky Train.

Loved the river. We went on the Chao Phraya both in the evening and in the morning. We simply loved the boat rides. The firs time we took the boat to Asiatique in the evening. The river with the tall buildings lit up on both sides looks spectacular in the evening. In the morning we took a boat and went along the river till the last port. We enjoyed every bit of the scenery and also saw the traditional river houses. When on a visit to Bangkok, a journey on the river is a must do.

Totally recommend it!. The Chao Phraya River is a great way to visit Bangkok's different attractions. Using the Express River Boat, I bought a 150 baht day pass and went up and down the river and stopped at different piers to visit places such as the Grand Palace, China Town, the flower market, Wang Lang market etc.

Good Experience Bkk River Cruise. Done a few checks with river cruise companies and the charges varies.The hotel arrangement was cheaper with transport provided to & fro from the jetty.Night scenery of Bangkok along the river was beautiful & worth a try

The best!!!. We had a view of Chao Phraya River from our hotel room. The river is 365 km long.You could go for a lunch/dinner cruise on one of many cruise boats. We went for a Dinner Cruise on the Wonderful Pearl to celebrate Loy Kratong, a woderful experience. You are offered an international buffet. At night the brightly lit cruise boats look so beautiful. You hear the music from the boats and see people enjoying themselves. You could transfer from one area to another via Express Boats.

Cheap and fun. We got a day ticket for the tourist boats - you can jump on and off at each pier and spend time exploring the near by sites - great value for money. You can also buy tickets for the piers not visited by the tourist boats and these are also cheap.Lots to look at when on the boat. We also took a long tail boat to see the Klong - also very interesting and we saw monitor lizards swimming in the Klongs.

A good way to travel using this river. Loved the water taxis running on this river. Boats of all kinds where there. If you miss one there another one before you realize. Travelled by Chao Phraya cruise boats and buying a day pass was way cheaper.

Must do. For 14B you must travel like the thai's. The river is a little dirty but it is interesting to take this mode of transportation. There are many stops along the river but it is a 10 - 15 min walk to get into where you want to go, make sure you have a map and you know where you are at, on it

Big river, take a cruise at night for best view. There are a lot of options to experience the river. Either by the many boats transporting people across the river or by cruise boats which are usually at night. Some cruise boats offer dinner and then you can enjoy the scenery later around the river. The cruise that I went to didn't have any explanation of what are around us so I just talked to the locals.

TRAVEL AROUND CHAO PRAYA RIVER. well its new experience for me travel around with boat at river..well enjoyed bangkok from river side .and they dont cost us a lot of money..quit cheaper than I though..

Take the river taxi for the best views.. Great array of modern buildings, ethnic temples and buildings, ordinary riverside housing and docks.Elaborate dinner cruise boats docked along the way during day and lit up at night.

The river cruise on loykratong . It was a magical night on 25th of November 2015 which was the loykratong festival in Thailand and a full moon as well. We were on the massive pearl cruise along the river of King having dinner on the deck although it was very warm that night and the rain started pouring but we could still be enjoying the lovely view on the 2nd floor of the ferry. Lots of beautiful temples and the grand palace was magnificent. The rama 8 bridge is the most beautiful one among others. At the end of the trip we were watching the great fireworks shows by all the prestige uber hotels ie the mandarin oriental, the shangri-la, the peninsular, the hilton, the royal orchid sheraton. A must!
The Thai version of Fisherman's Warf. This downtown area of the riverfront is a tourists dream. Cafes, shopping, Thai fast food, and more all in one place!

Living on the Chao Phraya River. I moved to Bangkok in 2010 - 2015. I lived 50 yards from the river Chao Phraya and experienced the scenic activity on the river 24/7. Floor to ceiling windows graced my condo 19 floors above the river and overlooking central Bangkok. It was just so peaceful to watch the ships slowly navigating through the waters and the first morning light witnessed all the busy activity on the river to begin the day. The current where I lived was quite swift so no swimmers were witnessed, however I did see many yachts, speed boats and even jet skis and the rice barges - water to me is very peaceful so this river really added ambiance to my stay in the Kingdom of Thailand.

Romantic Getaway. This is a great way to spend the night with your loved one. It is very accessible via the BTS, few minutes of walk from Saphan Taksin and a small boat will take you to your floating restaurant. Depends on the kind of dinner you want, buffet or all carte. We chose Ala Carte as we are tiny eaters but this package came with a less exciting entertainment. We took the boat with a group of old local tourists who had fun that night singing local songs. We noticed in some other boats, which offered buffets and more expensive, had some cultural shows. The boat has a recorded narration explains the historic spots left and right as you go through your ride. It was breezy but you can still feel the humidity. The water was dark but fortunately it doesn't smell bad. However, you can smell the smog from the air pollution and the smell of the gasoline or crude oil from the boat. Nevertheless, it was quite an experience that you should not miss when traveling to Bangkok.

Peaceful river cruise.. What a fantastic way to see Bangkok from a different perspective. Catching the water bus was a lot of fun and we saw sights that you just can't see from on the land. Definitely keep your mouth shut if you are standing outside - you don't want to get any of that water in your mouth!
Take a RIVER CRUISE. A dinner cruise on the Chao Phraya River is well worth it to enjoy Bangkok lights at night. The cruise has dinner and music to let you dance as well.

See the 'real' Bangkok by boat. Whenever I have friends briefly passing through Bangkok and they ask what they should do for a day I never hesitate in recommending a ferry trip along the Chao Phraya River. Most people would begin their trip by taking the BTS Skytrain to Saphan Taksin BTS Station and walking directly to the ferry pier just a few meters away - so easy! For just Thai Baht 14 (US 40 cents) you can travel from Taksin to Nonthaburi Pier spending about an hour viewing Thai, Chinese, and European historical buildings, river vessels of all types and life along the banks as it's been for decades. There are many convenient stops en route so if you wish to visit the Grand Palace simply disembark at Tha Chang Pier, or Phra Athit Pier to visit Phra Sumen Fort and have lunch in many of the trendy restaurants along Phra Athit Road and nearby Khao San Road. There are plenty of maps available to plan your trip and if you are visiting several attractions along the river it may be cheaper buying the Baht 150 day pass rather than paying Baht 14 each time you board for your next trip.The regular ferries which the local Thais use can get very crowded so grab a seat as quickly as possible so you can enjoy the experience in comfort. Definitely more fun than dragging yourself through shopping malls, markets and the infamous Bangkok traffic!

pretty views. My boyfriend loves taking boats down this river. The views are nice and there are a lot of destinations along the river bank. Actually taking a river boat is a good alternative to the crowded BTS.

Confusing. Can get a bit confusing to which boat to get so its best to do some research! Can get the Bts right to the pier soo very convenient way to see Bangkok from the river side, its a crazy dirty busy river with lots to see, definatly have to try it while in Bangkok!

A MUST. Trips on the river ferries are a great way to see another view of Bangkok. Take the skytrain to Taksorn Saphon station.Ferries leave on trips from here,I recently went on a express boat up the river and back for 30BHT a 2 hour trip with stops all along the way(its public transport) for this trip just look or ask for the orange flag boat.Many other trips leave from here, ask for river boat map.Great for photos and videos.

the main city of Bangkok. Quite dirty. There is much traffic along. The advantage is that it is possible to get to different places in Bangkok by its waters for free. It is possible to get a 2-3 hour evening boat ride when the city is at lights and even with dinner on it.

Many trips taken on the river. I love using the river taxis to get about. They are fast, cheap and reliable. It's a good way of getting around town during peak periods. The downside, the water is filthy and this is a real shame as otherwise you could really make a day of it and enjoy it far more.

Great way to see the real city. Take one of the cheap boats and experience all sides of the city. Tickets were $3 each and was quick and took us right to the royal palace. Very fun way to start our day.
Do!. Make a long trip by a custom ferry boat between lot's of Thai people and monks. It's a really must do in Bangkok. The river is so wide and busy. Don't forget to visit the feeding fish place.

Great way to see the sights but beware of rip offs!. Myself and three friends wanted to make a few stops along the river to see some of Bangkoks sights. We knew that there was a cheaper river service than the tourist boat which charges alot more than the local service. When we tried to ask for the cheaper ticket the ticket woman was very rude and kept ignoring us. Luckily there was another man manning the pontoon who was very friendly and resolved the situation. If using the river ferry, which is great to see many of Bangkoks main tourist attractions I would recommend looking to see how many stops you will make and which different coloured lines (flags) are running on the day as you can get tickets for much cheaper than paying 40bhat single trip or paying for the full day tourist ticket.
great. easiest way to travel in bkk,great service,lots of options,and no traffic,many attractions by the river,markets,food,

Easy and breezy and you can see everything!. We caught the Tourist Express ferry up the river as we were visiting Chinatown. The ferry ride was so pleasant and cool and the views of the temples so enjoyable that once we had finished shopping we returned to the ferry pier and bought day passes for the Tourist Express just so we could spend an hour or two going up and down the river as much as we wanted! There are guides on the boat who tell you what you can see and when to get off. Worth every penny. Especially good for hot and cranky spouses.

Filthy but fun and exciting. The life blood of Bangkok crazy busy traffic but everything seems to work and be reasonably safe. Suggest buying the day tourist pass and hop on and off the ferry at your leisure , plenty to do and see and if you time it right try and come back when the sun is going down nice to see the BKK skylight waking up and the temples glowing.

So lovin it.. I visited Bangkok for 3rd time and this month was my first visit to ChaoPhraya River. omg using boat to travel the city it was fun lots of beautiful attraction to see along the river. I love bangkok.
great!!!. me and my family loved this, it was one of the highlights during our stay in Bangkok, so many great sights to see!! well worth it

The way to see Bangkok. There is so much of interest to see on and by the Chao Phraya river. Lining the river banks are new shopping developments, intermingled with old tin shacks, brilliant golden temples and high end hotels. Stunning crowded modern bridges, and dubious ferries crossing the muddy polluted waters. Yet fish seem abundant, and conversely, there is so much vegetation that the river authority has a number of dredgers / yellow mechanised weed collectors (is this water hyacinth ?). And, of course craft of all sizes including huge barges being slowly towed by what seems to very underpowered tugs. Great viewing - it is the way to see and travel around some of the main sights of Bangkok.

A New View.... Take the local ferries and get a real good view of the city and the people who live around these waters. The local river ferries give you a chance to be with the local people. A welcome from the touts and scammers that exist by the long boats. Some of the ferry docks can be a bit hard to find as a tourist and we had to ask where they were. Got many different answers and learned to ask the question more specific (ie: public ferry to the Forensic Museum). The water can be quite choppy. We were out on a windy day with cooler temperatures, which we welcomed. It was a good way to get from one side to another, however single fares add up quickly with many rides. So ride the ferries to a point where the metro is not to far away and then hop on it back to your destination or home location.
suprice river tour. marvallous fantastic rever tour with good food and music good for enjoy with group and family nice experience

One of the dirtiest rivers but I love it. The Chao Phraya River is certainly a river you wouldn´t want to swim in and the thought they it is used for processing its water to drinking water is quite frankly "worrying". But the views you can get when you take a boat trip (use the Express boats which are sooooo cheap) are priceless. I´ve spent the last few months here in BKK and every now and then I just get on one of the Express boats to "relax".

Chao Praya canal boat cruise- Venice of Thailand. I don't know if this is the same river for a canal boat cruise but I think it's the one...then it's a must do experience. There's also a riverside restaurant which is a boat on water they serve a buffet on... which is a nice experience.It's the Venice of Thailand.
Trash. It is something you dont want to go. There is something around the river but none of those are interesting.

The life blood of Bangkok. Jump on an orange flagged boat and go for the most inexpensive river cruise of your life. The orange flag boats are local transit and very cheap. You get an amazing view of the city from the river.
The soul of the city. Staying at a hotel by the Chao Phraya River is fantastic. The river really is the soul of the Grande Dame Bangkok,

Best way of getting around town. Stayed on the riverside for 3 nights. This was by far the simplest way of getting round town, the traffic can be pretty grim at peak times.....so what better way to get about!!!!!!
Can get busy and the river isn't the cleanest
Day ticket is about £2........ So what are you waiting for????

Interesting. The river itself is not that clean. But touring on this river worths trying 'cause you can see Bangkok in its differents faces. Using Chao Phraya express boat to reach tourist attractions like Grand Palace is a brillant choice!
Riverside. Beautiful if you go in night must see when you visit Bangkok,Reach the place after 5 and it will turn in to big tourist spot

Taking the Commuter boat/ferry on the Chao Phraya river. Convenient mode of travel in the region of Wat Pho and Wat Arun. Interesting to experience this cheap, convenient, popular mode of travel used by commuters as alternative to skytrains and metros.
Nice Boat Journey!!. We took this boat for around 2000 Thai Baht and had an excellent ride. At the end of the ride, we alighted at the King's palace. All over it was a nice tour.

Marvel at the Tugboats. I love to go down to the riverbank at Phra Sumen Park early in the morning when 95% of tourists are sleeping it off. It is nice listening to the birds and watching the myriad forms of river traffic passing by. Particularly impressive are the dimuitive tugs pulling massive barge chains. Walking the waterfront in this part of Banglamphu through Thammaset University is more than pleasant. Tip - the student cafeteria has excellent and extremely economical food.

Good way to see parts of Bangkok. It's nice to spend an hour or more touring the city by boat. You can take a private tour or for a more local flair take one of the public boats from pier to pier. Inexpensive way to see parts of the city. Stop at one of the nice coffee shops or restaurants .

Make sure you spend time on this very busy and fascinating waterway!. Make sure you spend time on this very busy and fascinating waterway! Take the tourist ferries, hire a longboat or find a bar or eatery somewhere on the river and just watch the varied and absorbing traffic go by.

The river taxi is a hoot!. If you want cheap travel from point-to-point along the river, be brave and take the local river taxi ... NOT the tourist geared boats or you pay double or more the price.The local taxi will wisk you up and down the river for very reasonable rates ... but be ready to get off when your stop comes up ... the boats get very, very crowded with locals and the drivers only pull to the docks briefly for those who want on and off. If you are not ready, you will miss your stop and have to backtrack ... trust me, I did! :) Still a beautiful river and a super fun way to experience authentic BKK life!

Nice way to travel in Bangkok. The landingstations are a little bit difficult to find. Taxi drivers tend to drop you at the private boat tours, which are very expensive. Be aware that during Christmas and New Year's Eve season services stop on some days, which are public holidays
Vacation. It was an amazing experience for me and my family. Choa Pharaya river cruise ticket includes dinner, pick and drop from hotel. The view is amazing in the night.
