Nice to watch the skyline from the water. We crossed Chao Phraya River in a flat boat from the from the Pier to Grand Palace passing a few temples and as well by a side arm of the river to watch local Thai homes living on the river.The trip was however a bit too expensive

The best way to travel and see Bangkok. Take the local ferries on the Chao Phraya River, 14 Baht about 40 cents US, per on and off. I suggest a full tour of the river and then come back and get off and on where you want. Smaller ferries will take you across the river at various stops like Wat Arun. There "Tourist Ferries" that for 150 Baht, $4.25, will give you unlimited on and offs but have fewer stops and boats. Get off and take a tuk-tuk from the Grand Palace say to Chinatown and then walk back to the river to catch a ferry. Its so flexible and fun.

Great to travel around BKK. I always us the Chao Praya Orange River Transport. You're in BKK but it doesn't always feel like. Beautiful views on the riversides. Wind in your face. Sometimes getting a little wet. But ...I love it! Get to the front and soon you will have a seat. Get your own map and figure out beforehand where you want to get of. I would say: JUST DO IT!
Panaromic view of Bangkok City. Wonderful experience of cruising over river Chao Phraya, but the lacking point is the quality of cruise boats used, they could have been more exclusive and luxe

Great James Bond boat ride.. While walking from the RecliningBuddha Temple we came to the Chao Phraya River where we found the riverboats plying their trade.We got talking to one of the operaters about different trip options on the river and finally decided to go on a one hour trip on a long tailed boat the type made famous by a James Bond movie. It was quite a thrilling trip down part of the river and into the canals,a bit like in Venice.boating around the canals through the residental areas where we saw all sorts of old houses on stilts and some very smart homes. Went past many locals kids swimming and fishing, they all gave us cheerful waves, they looked very happy. We were able to see first hand what life was like living on the waterways of Bangkok. The boat operater was very good ,we got on at stop 8 did our hour trip then he dropped us off at stop 13 which is where we wanted to walk around next.We paid 500 baht each for the trip and thought it a nice experience, not sure if this was a good deal but we loved the trip, give it a go especially nice on a really hot day like we had,to feel the wind blowing in the hair was fantastic.

River cruise . Taking a river cruise here with Indian cuisine is not a too good idea . The cruise and staff are good but particularly you are all among Indians in the ship with loud Indian music and people dancing after boose on that music is a common thing here.So all depends ,if u want to get the feel of being in India ,go for it .

Not for the faint hearted,,,. We took the public ferry from Stop 9 near the Grand Palace. It was confusing at first because this was a popular stop for the tourist boats that cruise along the river so there was a lot of activity and crowded. We showed the business card of our hotel in Silom to the man who was directing/yelling at people embarking and disembarking. Quite entertaining once you step back and not stress out. We waited 15 minutes to hop onto the correct boat which the man remembered that we had asked him about.Once we got on, we did not know which stop our hotel was in. The lady who collected money from the passengers did not speak English. We found a helpful young man who happened to be heading to Silom and told us when to disembark. Not surprisingly, nearly 2/3 of the passengers got off on the same stop.The boat is low to the water and moves around a lot. Not suitable for people with mobility issues. We found it to be a cheap way to see the City's poor and wealthy life. One minute you are sailing past slums, the other minute you are passing a deluxe hotel with its own private water shuttle.

Another side view of City. It's not to be completed to Bangkok without visit the Chao Phraya river,take the ride along this bustling river with the local boat that cost in THB 1000 on evening time, you could see how the difference of the city, and surely take stop to local food vendor that dwelling along the river
Long tail boat trip. A must if you want to see the "backyard" of Bangkok.Perfect wievs of some of Bangkoks most spectacular sites.

COOL BOATS AT NIGHT. I was dining at Sala Rattanakosin when illuminated boats would pass by at night. It was very cool because they're elaborately designed and when you're dining alone, it's a great distraction.

wholesome river boat ride. A little bumpy ride due to water current but nevertheless, manageable & safe. We rode the 40bth each boat colored blue w/ c is a bit expensive from the yellow boat 20bth. But even though it cost a bit it has a tour guide & faster than the cheap boat. The river boat ride is a very welcome treat becoz you'll be able to pass diff places around bangkok & each have designated port stops

Relaxing alternative view of Bangkok. Various river cruise operators provide commentary guided tours along the river, or you can pick up the regular public ferries, which cover the same route.Either way, the cruise is relaxing, comfortable with the breeze across the water even on a hot day, so see the beautiful BKK sky line and the various temples and government complexes along the river.There a couple of stops where the giant carp are literally churning the water next to the piers as the local kids throw food in. Something to see for sure.A relaxing 2-3 hours that gives you a general view of the BKK sites you've probably visited close up in preceding days. A good way to get your bearings also.
Nice ride thru Bangkok. This is definitely recommended , take a boat and just enjoy the ride . Also there are available boat that serve dinner which is also very nice experience.

Fun way to see Bangkok. I have fallen in love with traveling Bangkok on the river boats. It is a calm and peaceful way to see the city. There are a variety of piers that you can stop and explore such as Pak Long Talad (flower market), Wat Arun (Temple of the Dawn), the Grand Palace and Wat Po (Reclining Buddha). Avoid river boats in the evening as they get super crowded.

The best way to see Bangkok. The river is the true life of Bangkok! By far the the best way to navigate the sites and temples of the city. For 150 baht you can purchase a day ticket that allows you unlimited rides on either the Blue Flag Tourist Boat or the Yellow Flag Taxi Boat. Both boats have set stops all along the riverfront from north to south. All the boat stops are within easy walking distance to most sites and temples. Small water taxis also offer short shuttle rides from one side of the river to the other at the cost of 3 Baht.Book a Longtail boat (400-600 Baht) for a one hour sunset tour = 5 Starr Rating a must do!!! They will take you on a tour of the side canals to see the old world of Bangkok where the locals live and play. It's a magical one hour tour not to be missed!The waterway is the way to travel without the hassles of cabs, tuk-tuks, traffic and crazy crowds.NOTE: The tourist/taxi boats stop running at 8pm! The schedule changes so be sure to ask!

Beautiful river of Bangkok. Chao Praya River is one of the most important river of Bangkok. You can hope in and out to explore the river by boat. Taking public transport boat with local cost 30 bath. If you are on honeymoon, hire 1 hour sightseeing boat with local cost 1500-2000 bath and say hi with local who live beside the river.

Don't look down. Bangkok is a beautiful city at night and there is no better place to view the city then from a boat on the Chao Phraya River. The river itself is brown and polluted but at night you may never notice. When visitors come to Bangkok one of the first trips I like to take them on is a boat ride on the river to ASIATIQUE for dinner and shopping.
Non stop action. The river is busy, long tail boats, ferry boats, tourist boats, and working boats. Its all very interesting to watch.

Great shopping and great food court.. Great fun place to explore, shop and have something to eat in the many food outlets.MBK offers something for everyones shopping interest or relaxing massage or nail job and pedicure for the ladies.

Commute and see the city. Bangkok has very busy road traffic. You can use the boat to move around and enjoy at the same time. Public transport 'Express Boat' run very often and cost only 14 baht. Takes some time to find out how it works. Tourist boats are more adapted for sight seeing and easier but price depend on your negotiation skills ;-)

Simply Wonderful River of the Bangkok. We took this trip on our second day in Thailand, we saw the most awesome thing of Bangkok with several temples located by the river, skyscraper...etc. In fact, it was very interesting experience!

35 degrees but comfortable along the river. Took the two hour tour departing from River City at 2 pm. 900 baht included one hour on a long boat along the river and then along some klongs. Then we transferred to a rice boat where we continued the tour. Fruit buffet and beverages provided on this part of the journey. Very hot day but comfortable on the boat. We booked at the Sheraton right beside River City where a tour guide picked us up and took us to the boat. A cool place to wait.
Nothing can beat the skyline !!. Offers one of the stunning views of Bangkok skyline. Especially in the night, it is the best view. One should go experience it, words are not enough.
Great to see, nice to travel on.. River taxis run along this river, so it's easy to travel on. Lots of shopping and places to eat on both sides of the river. Definitely worth seeing.

Amazing view.. I was really admiring the sun set view above chau praya river from the 24th floor Which is situated at horizon club in Shangrila hotel Bangkok. The views are just awesome when you look at it with all the cruise ship are just moving around slowly with people's are just partying on board. Trust me its worth.

A fun way to travel. This is a convenient way to travel from the hotels around The Peninsular to Wat Pho, The Grand Palace and Khao San Road - and cheap! The pricing is confusing. You can get an all day ticket for 150 bah (about £3). The first day, I paid 40 baht for a single. The second day just 14 baht!It can be crowded and the river needs to be cleaned up. But it is fun to see local life and there are a few interesting buildings to view from this perspective. It is also a refreshing change from the car fumes!

Nice Boat Ride Down The River. To get a view of the river end to end, just for the experience, my partner and I did a boat ride down the river. It was a sunny hot day, but not overly hot, and my partner enjoyed the ride

The Changing scene of Bangkok. on a riverboat on the Chao Phraya River, you can see a glimpse of the whole of Thailand. From the modern skyscraper hotels and office blocks, to the homes almost floating above the surface of the river, from the Shrines and Wats, and Kings Palace which one passes by, this just makes this river on that is fascinating . There is hustle and bustle all along the river, signs of extroadinary wealth and abject poverty, and it can all be seen from the river.

Bustling busy river - great way to explore. Using the local river boat system you can hop on and hop off these busy and fast moving boats and visit tourist and local areas without being stuck in traffic or queues. There is a kind of lane system in operation, the middle reserved for the tug boats who tow huge heavily laden barge boats through the city - tourist boats chug along, next to long tails and the local ferries - you can use a tourist boat to explore the canals too. We loved whizzing up and down and planned our journeys using different boats in diffent routes to reach our destinations - the Chao Phraya river is a great area to watch Bangkok working away.

Cheapest river trip ever. Orange express. One of our favourite things to do in Bangkok. Go to Saphan Taksin on the sky train. Walk to the pier and go upstream on the orange boat to pier 30. This takes you right up the river for 14baht. In any other capital this would cost much more. Get off and walk to the local market, very interesting. We walked passed the market and had a lovely meal in a very new and clean restrain on the right hand side (sorry don't know the name). Anyway 330baht for all we could eat and drink.
Worth a trip if you want a cheap river cruise.. The river ferry goes up and down the river,, worth a trip just to see the local river culture and great photo oportunity activity.

Real Bangkok as it has always been.. Bangkok has been really all along river and canals.just float in boats on Cho Phraya river and its connected canal system to see the real Bangkok As it has been for centuries.dinner cruise adds to the experience.without the river Bangkok is not Bangkok.

Great boat ride down the river. Came here with 2 friends as we were wanting to get to central Bangkok from where we'd just been shopping. Got on a taxi boat for 40 baht that took us on a 30 minute ride down the river. Was very enjoyable

Hideous modern architecture but a good medium for public transport. Not worth going on river as an attraction. (Modern architecture is hideous, ancient sites not well viewed from the river. Back canals lifeless and boring.) Express boat on the river is a good way of getting about, however.

Try to book Chao Phraya River Cruz for dinner. Had a dinner in Chao Phraya River Dinner Cruz. Which was really romantic. Food was pretty okay some items are really good some not. Budget trip for family and really good for couple. We were at honeymoon that time, so had a great time with my better half. You should not skip this trip.

Nice adventure . We were on the river to get to the grand palace.. We went early morning and the ride was nice, a bit rough that day but the boat was big enough it made it as smooth as possible. The sites and bridge are a nice view to take in :)
One Young World cruise.. As part of the opening ceremony we cruised down the river, informative and friendly hosts and a great way to see such a beautiful city!

Longboat Excursion. Hire a longboat at Sathorn Pier and ride through the canals and up the river to see the Temples. Its a great way to explore deep into the everyday life of city dwellers who live along the river and a convenient way to negotiate the city - no traffic, just river boats. Awesome views of Bangkok. Well worth it.

you can choose your boat !. the river is good, clean. you don't have to worried. they are serve their best.. which boat do you like to use? orange flag (local boat) 19 baht, tourist boat 40 baht or taxi boat 100 baht.. in my opinion i suggests tp use local boat, its cheap haha

THIS IS THE PLACE !. the chao phraya river is the only place you should stay while visiting Bangkok. there is activity from early morning until late in the evening. if you do not stay on the river you have missed half of Bangkok !!

A convenient way to get around the tourist sights. We were staying at the shangri-la, close to the tourist boat dock. Since we're seniors and only wanted to do one major site a day, we simply bought the 40 baht one way tickets. Very convenient and inexpensive public transport to/from the Kings palace, national museum, etc.
Take the Local Boats. Enjoy the major rivers by taking a trip on the local boats, these are very cheap, and provide great views.

So easy for tourists now.. We haven't been in Bangkok for a while, and now my husband uses a walker. First of all, for new tourists, you can get an all-day pass on a special Tourist Ferry, which I highly recommend. Second of all, there are now quite a few free ferries, such as the one to Asiatique. Beautiful on the river day and night.

Indian dinner cruise.. We had opted for Indian dinner cruise( being an Indian) it was very well organized. With Indian cuisine and Indian songs.
I had great time on the cruise.

A trip up the river is a must. You can easily get to most of the tourist attractions using the river. The river is so central to life in Bangkok that you must use it. Its also a very convenient way to get about and very cheap if they get around to asking for a fare.

Best Place in Bangkok!. If you stay near the river, you can explore all the beautiful things by the river. Temples, Grand palace, shopping places etc are by the river, and very easily accessible if you take a boat. A day pass costs 140 bhts.

Best river transportation in Bangkok. The river transportation developed in Bangkok give you much easier access to many tourist attraction locations such as: Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Wat Arun, China Town, etc. Some piers are beautiful with convenience shopping mall, a hotel, or just a place to relax and have some food, but some are really a mess in a traditional market or a dirty housing area. But, still it is the best way to travel thru the amazing Chao Phraya river. Prepare with the information about boat route beforehand.

A good alternative to road transport. The ferries offer a good alternative to road transport especially during peak traffic hours. It also offers a good view of the important tourist places in the city.
Beautiful. We went there for the Dinner Cruise and was so beautiful to look around at night and the dinner was taste I was more enjoy that night

Love riding the water taxis. Our hotel is near the river and so we hop on the water taxis to get to almost all our sightseeing locations. We beat the serious Bangkok traffic and it cost 14baht per ride! If you love the water and boats, and the water taxi wherever you need go.

Nice way to spend half a day. Go to sephan takin sky train stop just before the river and try and find the public boat which goes along the river. Not much wrong using the tourist boat except more expensive. the tourist boat gives you a running commentary of the places to visit. you and get on and of the boat on the same ticket for the day.

Excellent!. The Chao Phraya River is fascinating to watch the different sizes (and speed) of vessels travelling up and down as well as across the river. I took the water taxi to visit temples and mosques on the other side of the river from near the Grand Palace for Baht 5 (single trip). The river is spanned by several bridges that link the 'two halves' of Bangkok. I walked across the Phra Phutthayotfa Chulalok Bridge.

Quick to move around town. The river is ok. It's looks dirty and there are many boats, ferries and taxis that speed through it all the time. Chao Phraya tourist boat is a great way to move about. It costs 150 BHT and stops at major sights. There are 8 piers that they service. You can hop on and off the boat. Sathorn is the central pier. It is close to the Skytrain station (BTS Saphan Taksin).

An exciting way of getting to the sights. You can buy an all day, hop on hop off ticket at Central pier, adjacent to the Sky Train station, for 150 Baht (currently less than £3). This can be used on all boats,but the Tourist ferries have a commentary on the sights. They also provide a booklet which shows where to get off for various attractions, with instructions as to where to go from the ferry pier. It's a good way to get about a,d thee's plenty to see on the river.

a trip on the river local style. You can take a trip on any of the Tourist boats but they will be as crowded as the local boats and much more expensive. The best way to travel the river is to start at Saphorn Taxin and take a local boat which costs only 25 Baht regardless of where you get off or how long you stay on. It calls at over 30 piers on both sides of the river and you can spend hours just watching all the temples,and Bridges go by. If you are new to Bangkok this is a great way to spend a morning or an afternoon planning which of the temples and other attractions you will see from the river, you would like to actually visit. All for around 50 pence UK.
Long distance . Great and enjoy view of river. However, the boat has not enough seats. Can see three bridges when boat pass them.

November escaped . The boat ride is nice way to go to places around Bangkok at the same time the local guide will give u a quick introduction about the places around such as the hotels & consulate etc.. Btw if your planning to take the boat to visit wat arun.. Don't buy the 150bhat unlimited ride until 7pm as its a rip off!! 1 ride cost 40bhat then u need to interchange & pay additional 2bhat as its a different type of boat.. If you wanted to go to asiateque the boat is free of charge!!!

Great way of reaching the palace or chinatown. Took the boat from the pier near the Saphan Taksin station. The boat ride gave a good view of the magnificent structures located on both sides of the river. A cooling ride to rest your feet on a sunny day.If you are for budget travel, wait for the orange flag boat which offered ride for 14 baht !!! Alternatively, you could always support Bangkok's tourism industry and opt for the blue boat which seemed to be more comfy with narration or the long tail boat. Both alternative options were pricier.Apart from going up the river in the direction, the pier at Saphan Taksin station also offered a free shuttle to Asiatique, a large open air mall with a ferry wheel of Bangkok's very own.
The family enjoyed it... We did a 2 hr tour of the river and really enjoyed ourselves.You get to see how families live on the river. How they bathe, wash their laundry. Mind opening for my children.
long river with quite cloudy water. long river with quite cloudy water. I took the public boats many times on the river it was really nice and cheap.

Other side of the city. I got here by taking BTS. There are many options for boats and piers. From here you can see the city and people lives along the river. This is a nice way to get to Chinatown. If you want to get back to the main city by BTS you should take the boat back before 4pm.

Chill out maybe. It's Ok for an hour or two, to chill out and view the city from the river. Not an expensive trip and very handy way to get about. I use when I bring friends to thailand, as a way of accessing some temples. I travel to central pier on the bts

Commerce and romance. Taking a river taxi is exciting from Silom to Chinatown. But if you have the money, there's nothing like a room at the Shangri La or Peninsula Hotel with a view. Such a variety of barges drift by, and rooms are silent. Very idyllic and relaxing.I like the Mandarin Oriental, too, but it's a bit over the top with butlers and really too many service employees. The Shangri La is very friendly and accommodating. The Peninsula is luxurious, too.

Take a water taxi. In addition to being a practical way to get around, the process of lining up, getting rushed into a boat and then charging down the river is something to experience. Not for those uneasy in crowds.

HOLIDAY. The Chao praya river is a muddy river in Bangkok, and it poses a threat to the community or society in Bangkok.The water of Chao praya river is not recommended for Drinking.Bottled water is recommended for drinking , and don't drink Tap water if you are in Bangkok.Chao phraya River is accessible by Water Taxis, Small Boats and this Boats and water taxis are used by Tourists for sightseeing , for example if you want to go to the Grand Palace, or Floating Markets or other attractions.

Romantic Dinner Cruise. Had a lovely evening river cruise here; lovely views of the temples from the riverside and other attractions too. We were lucky enough to be going down the river when fireworks went off which was fab!

Long tail boats. Take the long tail boats. They are fast and fun. The view during the boat ride is great. You will see popular high rises and hotels and temples everywhere. The long tail boat on the Chao Phraya is a must do.

A cool place to be.. This river is the major artery for the city of Bangkok. It was historically central to transport and communication here, and remains so. Even though Bangkok has increasingly good mass transit, the river is still the best way to reach many of its main sites and neighbourhoods. There are places to relax along its shores, though these are increasingly being edged out by big money developments, (they know the best place to be!) you can still find cheap places to eat and drink and watch the sun go down over a Wat in Thonburi. And best of all, for a cool climate denizen like me, the air by the river is cooler in temperature, and usually has a good breeze blowing. Numerous boats offer tours, or a five minute crossing, but the Chao Phraya river boats are a great deal for about 50 cents and can take you a long way up or down stream.

Great fun. The rivier and the neighbouring canals are great fun for a group boat trip. The river is full with fastness moving board, ferry's, charters etc and is a easy way to travel to many of the tourist attractions.

Good as a mean of transporttation. Travelling on the Chao Prya river is a nice way to view parts of the city, some temples and to get where you want, as the roads are congested. A dinner by the river is also nice.

We love the Chao Phraya River. Best place in Thailand, every time we go to Bangkok, its the first thing we do, go down to the river and get a 2 hour Longboat ride around the river and the surrounding canals. Its the perfect way to start any trip to Thailand. Gets you in the mood for what Thailand has to offer.

Lovely . Good river to sail down and see the sights of Bangkok. You are able to see alot of dofferent sights from sky scrapers to temples to industry to bright lights... Good way of doing it traffic free :-)

A quick way to get to main attractions. Not really scenic. Dirty smelly but the quickest way to get from point A to B in Bangkok. Our hotel had a complimentary river shuttle that took us to the main river taxi, river shuttle, tourist boat and sky train station. The tourist boat was 140 baht for all day...around $5. This boat has a guide which is interesting the first trip but the important thing is he announces the stops and the main attractions at each stop. If you get on the other boats be prepared for your stop 2 stops ahead as they will not wait and the boats are very crowded and it can be difficult to get to the back of the boat. One way trips on regular boats are 40 baht..around$1.
Convenient water taxi service. If you want to travel without traffic jams and go along the riverside and have great views on the city: take the water taxi! It's cheap, very convenient!
Fun to see. Staying at The Peninsula, we crossed the river to get into town. Strong current and dirty but a fun way to experience Bangkok--especially at night.

Thrilling/Scary!. Great experience. Around 100 BHAT per person for a skinny boat. The river is not smooth, several time I wanted a life jacket, but that is part of the fun! Fast way to travel from the Skytrain to the temples.
Beautiful. Get away from the chaos of Bangkok and take a trip down the crazy river. The boat I was on had monks, tourists and locals. The best way to take a step back and see the city.

A river of sights. To make a optimum vieuw of the river, take a ferryboat, the Yellow/orange line, starting at the Central pier at Saphan Taksin station of the BTS line. The ferry takes you to the endpoint at Nonthabury. The ferry runs from pier to pier and gives you a wonderful vieuw of the life on and along the water. You can make several stops on your way, to go e.g. to War Arun, the Royal Barges, Narional museum etc. At the endpoint you may find a nice Chinese temple and a floating restaurant where you can enjoy your lunch before returning on your trip.

Public boats. The best and cheapest way to explore is to use public water transport. It is very authentic. And you can visit all famous places. Also it is one of the fastest way to travel through the city.

Great way to travel. Most of the hotels and river cruise companies use the Chao Praya river. It avoids the traffic and is quick and cheap to travel. River cruise dinners from River City are also highly recommended - a great way to see Bangkok by night and to sample Thai cuisine.

Day & night different view. The river is actually quite dirty with rubbish Travelling to temple area is quite fun by the boat, but not suggest to elderly as the staff will keep rushing you to be fast,as soon as all step in the boat, it drive off. No clear instruction given, on our return from Wat Pho to Saphan Taksin Station, we actually took the wrong boat. We actually asked before going up,they said yes,and collected fares from us, but it reached the end station and they said need to change boat to Saphan Taksin Station. So we alighted and guess what? This station ticket counter insisted us to buy tickets again in order to go back to Saphan Taksin Station ! We are really pissed off ! With no choice we have to do so, but really felt that we are cheated !So be careful.

Seeing Bangkok on a Barge at the Chao Phraya River. We went to the Pier to join the Manohra Rice Barge Dinner cruise at the Chao Phraya River. Dinner was served at the elegant, restored wooden barge as it cruised along the river. It is a very spectacular and memorable experience as we cruised along the river at night and pass the Temple of Dawn, the Grand Palace and numerous other famous temples and landmarks. The delicious Thai Dinner included delicacies such as Thai dumpling, prawn skewers, spicy soup, stir fries and fresh seafood with a traditional Thai dessert is finished it of.

Very fascinating cruise!!. Very relaxed and authentic atmosphere.Great views of some amazing temples and the most interesting thing was to see the way the houses are built on the river on stilts. Was most fascinating. Including the huge OMGGGG!!! coconut drink that arrived in true island style.Very nice experience.
Polluted and crowded. I dream one day that big cities in Asia will find a way to live in harmony with their environment. The river is the lifeline of the city, yet it is treated as a dump.

Working river. a well utilised river in the heart of Bangkok. Courtesy boats take patrons from the pier to the restaurant or accommodation they require. At night the dinner time cruises litter the water. A lovely site.

lots and lots of choices - from cruises to restaurants to shopping. As I live on the river, I rarely need to go in to the city as everything you need is pretty much available from cheap eateries, good quality restaurants, shopping, parks, river cruises (for friends visiting) to places to just chill out...
Great place to see. Don't miss this with various modes of transport available you can see the homes of the locals intertwined with Bangkoks landmarks and skyscrapers. Wonderful

A MUST GO PLACE IN BANGKOK. Go and join this river cruise tour at night . When it is not so hot .Enjoy the beautiful night scenery of Bangkok and enjoy the cool breezeYou can view much of Bangkok without having to walk a few kilometres .

See one of the world's greatest cities for almost nothing!. Hop on a public boat for a few baht and ride the river. You may have to stand at some times of day, and be sure to save the noted seats for monks. You can see the same sights for 100 times the price on several tour lines, but you won't get the delightful local flavor.

Cheap and Cheerful Travel. Hire a boat for a few Bhat for anyting up to a three hour trip up and down the river including the floating markets. Noisy boats and chatty operators give value for money including some visit stops. A highlight

take the public boat. Chao praya is very much a working river with hughe barges, longtail boats for tourists, and evening cruise boats. Do experience the public baot its like the underground on the river a great way to get from A to B

Nice way to get to the old city. We took the tourist boat from River City to the old temples. It was reasonably cheap (40 THB per person) and very quick way to get there. The view from the boat wasn't great, but still not too bad. The river is still probably more a way to get somewhere, rather than attraction by itself.

It needs a major clean up. Not exactly romantic because the river is filthy with plastic bottles floating around. It is a very functional part of the day to day lives of locals which is wonderful. The local river boat costs 15 baht for a single trip i.e. 50 cents.

A must do when in Babgkok. We did this boat trip last year & thorougly enjoyed it. We paid Bht 40 each for a one way ticket, however you can get all day hop on hop off tickets. There are touts all over the place as you enter the ferry terminal so beware you'll be hassled. There are speed boats which looked interesting, maybe next year! There was no safety brief & no life jackets worn. The tour guide on the boat was difficult to understand so I just switched off & just took in all the wonderful sights. It's pretty impressive as you go along the Chao Phraya, the skyline & building are awesome. The river is s busy place, lots of traffic, I'm surprised there are no accidents. There was a lot of debris in the river. The boat felt steady which is a bonus if your the sickly type, however when you do disembark it can be a bit scary due to the rocking of the boat. There are numerous disembarkation stops, we got off to go to China Town. If you can try for the side seats as they offer the best views & you can also sit up front on the boat but it's limited to 6 people & you have to sit down.

Good place to see the skiline of Bangkok. Do not be lured to take for one of the long tail boats. Simply take public ferry on the first day for 14 Baht one way and travel the whole Bangkok. Th ferry calls at botth river sides and is an excellent way to get acquianted with the city.
Amazing River. Take the public boat and discover Bangkok from the river. Much better than a car. Do not use the tourist boat.
Must Do. Chartered a boat to see the klongs. Booked at hotel Cost 2000bht. Well worth it. You could pay a lot less if in a boat with lots of other paeople. Join the boat next to the Shangri La Hotel.

Very Good Day Out. Used the BTS to get to Saphan Taksin, quick walk and you are at the river.Cross river here for the reclining Buddha Temple, or enjoy a boat trip, prices are displayed BUT it is possible to haggle for a small discount.On hot days ensure that you're wearing sun screen and a hat

Dirty. It is a long dirty river across the city of Bangkok. For people who want to visit the river I think that the best is to take the public boats.I took a private boat: it was expansive and the tour similar to the public one. During the tour people can see the poorest part of Bangkok for example poor houses...But of course there are beautiful things also..Really a guide told me that public biats, cheaper, are really fast while private ones are slower; furthermore the private boats can go in small canals, while public boats can't do it because they are too big and too fast. Many boats organize the dinner but I have never tried them

Must try boat . It was two hours boat tour. I was thinking it might be too long to take boat for two hours. However by enjoying view time was flying. Once in Bangkok, should try it. We can find many things from this boat and we feel a bit more close to culture in Bangkok.

Let's play musical chair. Yeah, that's what you will find this experience to be if you are taking the boat (especially the orange one) across the Chao Phraya River which is quite buoyant. The top of the tops hotels are located around this river which also connects you to Bangkok's mainstream attractions - Grand Palace, Wat Arun, Wat Pho.
take a boat trip!. I love taking a river cruise. It is easy to go to the pier and hire a longtail boat for a tour of the major site. Highly recommended activity. So much fun.

River & Dinner trip was okay. We just felt that this was too "tourisy", very crowded and to many people. We were seated downstairs but the vibe was much better upstairs! The entertainment was so, so and the food was not bad!

Great way to get around Bangkok. The river is a great way to move around central Bangkok. At 40 baht a journey it's also cheap. An added bonus is the tourist boat(identified by blue flag) as you get a guide who describes all the points of interest along the way. I should add their descriptions vary depending on the individual, some a god some aren't.
Must check out the river on a riverboat. Travel either on a public ferry or a thin riverboat with massive outboard, it's a must do experience when in BKK
Fascinating river. Great to travel along and across. Public boats and jetties and all the hotel shuttle boats. Particularly magical at night when they're all lit up. Take your camera!
Great evening cruise tour. Spent one evening in chao phraya river cruise. The cruise is 2 hours long and serves delicious food. Tom yum soup was one of the best.

for transport. Used to transport a mere connection across the river between the two sides as well as for long-distance transportation, and also for sightseeing cruise. We have completed my-holiday participants.

Great trip. We took one of the river taxi and truly enjoyed the trip. You will see many temples along the shores and the outline of the city. It is a good way to reach all the temples. The river is dirty but fish abounds here and you will see shoals of it .

Chao Phraya River in Bangkok. Nice river, but the city needs to clean up all the debris. I love taking the water taxis. Good views and cheap. They take you from one end of the city to the other. The nightly dinner cruises are an excellent value!

Such a busy river, yet so relaxing!. I am lucky enough to see the river from my home and I never tire of it. There is always something to see on the Chao Phraya river which is truly the lifeblood of the city. Rice barges heading North or South, reckless long tail boats, hotel shuttle boats, river express ferries or dinner cruises, it is a permanent show that never stops. Amazingly, considering the very heavy traffic, things usually go very smoothly, even at night. I would recommend to anyone visiting Bangkok, even for a day or two, to come on the river banks or at least do a river trip on a ferry, to experience its magic.

convenient travelling option with very spectacular and pleasant view. Chao Pharya river is very convenient option to reach to wat pho, grand palace, shilpokorn University, Bangkok. You can take regular orange and yellow ferry for very low cost up to 14 BHT.Its very pleasant.

A great experience.. First time in Bangkok and it's quite a few years ago now we had dinner at one of the restaurants on the banks of the river. It was fascinating then and it's never worn off. I've just had a few days in Bangkok again and the first thing I do now is to get on the Tourist boat (cost 150 Baht) which goes well up the river with many stops along the way. Get off and get back on again wherever suits you best. It's probably the best value available in the city and takes me most of the day. I must have done this trip 15 times by now and it's always an highlight of my time in Bangkok.

The river that is alive.. day or night.... Beautiful river that separates the two sides of Bangkok. The popular tourist side (East side) and the business and residential side (west side). If you are in Bangkok you must do yourself a favor and take one of the longboat tours, you will see a side of Bangkok that most tourists don't see. There are many different ways to get around the river here.

good trip. there is a shuttle boat service from ramada plaza will take u to the skytrain stationdont forget enjoy a nite dinner cruise with chaophraya cruise get on board from river city shopping complex.very amazing and i like it

Famous Chaopraya river. First time i went to this river was in the evening time and i was stunning with the evening view along the river. Romantic was my first impression when i took boat to Asiatique. The river is the hub to unload most of the commodities 24 hours non stop. Its a nice place for lover or group to spend evening time with stunning spot by the river

Cultural Vein of the City. If you visit Bangkok you should definitely take a trip on the Chao Phray River. This is truly the life vein of the city and has been since it was founded. One can hire a long tail boat to tour the river and some of the side canals or simply find a way to go on a free trip down the river via a hotel or shopping area that provides such. It is not the cleanest river you will ever be on but it is well worth seeing and learning about. This is also a great way to see the skyline along the river and view all of it's sites.

Boring . I was expecting a little bit more for this tour. But I am not pleasant at all . First I was the only person on board,secondly the guy who handle the boat is sleepy. The water was so dirty,not worth 1500b for the tour. Not recommend this tour.

Chao phraya river. This is the blood and veins of Bangkok. The public and tourist ferry run up and down the river to many of the tourist spots like wat arun , the royal palace, china town market and the night market Asiatique, this is a great way of getting around on the water and can be quite cheap, although on the down side you can get covered in water spray if the boat is moving at speed, there are also water taxi and long boats which will take you on tours of the canals and floating market using this kind of transport don't forget to bargain.

Cloudy, rainy day, astonishing river !. Took the boat from the sheraton pier heading towards kao San st !
Me and my wife disembarked at station no 9 near the king palace and walked to the kao San st !

Dirty, dirtier, dirtiest. We took Shuttle Boat from our Hotel across the River t the Asiatique Market. Very pity that Thais and also Tourists throw everything into the River. You see the water is so dirty you do not even dare to imagine how toxic the water must be. I don't like that kind of Asian mindset to throw everything in the water or on the ground and harm and destroy nature in that way with huge impact.However the size and length of the River was very impressive and also how the Thais deal with it. I can imagine that a dinner on a special boat what can be booked for the evening is very nice.

The lifeline of Bangkok. The Chao Phraya River is the artery that runs through Bangkok. It connects the capital to the provinces. Enough rain is a good thing; too little or too much is a disaster. In times of natonal celebration, the King will take to the water in the Royal Barge. A flooded river can put the low lying capital under water.

Another must visit site in Bangkok. Straight after the Grand Palace we stopped in at the terminal and took a1 hour quick ride around the River. Was meant to pass a fish farm which really was only people living in the river that feed the barbel that surface. Fun to watch and great to see for a first timer. The river and houses give an idea of how some poorer locals live. River quite dirty though. Stop at floating market and pass Wat Arun which was currently under refurbishment. Have to bargain..and even then I think you probably overpaying.

hours of fun for just a few cents. Riding the ferry on the river is the most economical fun I have had in a while. We took the ferry everywhere in Bangkok. Sometimes we just rode without any destination in mind for the pure joy of it. The people watching is unparalleled. The scenery is beautiful. And we enjoyed many laughs being herded tightly onto the boats that were filled to capacity as travelers of a hundred nationalities bonded together to help one another avoid being pushed overboard with a comical array of facial expressions and sounds. Where else can you enjoy hours of fun for less than a buck?
Iconic river. Choa praya is iconic river for its history. Take a boat ride to some popular destination like asiatique and enjoy the great view. Bangkok have truly come along way.
A lively river. Artificially straightened throughout history means the river has a mean current. The affordable boats are a nice way to travel up and down the river

The River is the way to see the temple sites. I travelled with my daughter to Bangkok for a long weekend and stayed near the river. We wanted to see the temples and other historic parts of the city, and found the river the most pleasant and relaxing way to get around. By chance, we ended up taking several different modes of river transportation including a private boat (the best if going to a fancy restaurant as we were), the Orange flag boat, the Blue flag boat and then one of the long boats. Since the Blue flat (tourist boat) only stops every half hour, it was a bit inconvenient. However, the Orange flag boat stopped more frequently, yet was a bit more crowded.
Life on the river. An interesting look at Bangkok from a different perspective and not quite as busy as being on the roads

Dinner Cruise. We did a dinner cruise on the river and it was great. The entertainment was good and the buffet was not bad either. We went on the Star Princess. You get to see many of the temples all lit up from the river and it gives you an overall idea where they are located. We took a boat from the central pier to Yodiman pier. Since all the boats stop running at 6 getting back to the BTS station is a little more interesting.Would do it again and seeing all the activity on the river during the day is interesting.

Cruise. If you want to see a lot of Bangkok attractions from a distance and have dinner at the same time try a river cruise and if you do so by night you might be treated to some onboard entertainment if you choose the right company.

Chao Phraya River. Our guide took us on a water taxi ride through some of the canals and the river itself. This was a fascinating glimpse into Thai life. Many people live on the river, and from the boat it's easy to see their homes and glimpses of their day to day lives.

Superb. It was a never forgettable experience.I did not expect it to be as good as it was.The people jave made so intelligent use of the river in the form of Cruise Dinner.It was an amazing experience.There are so many amazing and beautiful structures on the banks of this river,which one can appreciate especially at night time.
Boat trip. Chopper than I expected. The boat tour was 1000 baht from Tha Chang but was very underwhelming. I would have liked to see more of the canal system.

River of Life. This is The River which transverse the greater part of Bangkok. I have read about it in my geography books. We got a vantage view point from the hotel jetty of The Shangri-La Hotel. Indeed surreal to finally have an up close and personal encounter with the great river.
wonderfull to see all this going around.. A trip that you will not forget. All kind of ships will pass by. Specially a nighttrip is to be considered.

Very crowded. We took the local water taxi ( orange ) on the river up past the Royal Palace It was very cheap but too crowded to enjoy and the fumes were awful. Perhaps we picked the wrong time to day 4 pm and maybe we should have chosen the tourist boat . Would be great if less crowded
Nice. The river not so clean but quite nice. There are a lot of historical building along the river. The guard pier in the wat pho not to friendly in talking but it's all for our own good actually.

Fascinating river views of Bangkok. It's possible to take a public or private longboat ride on this bustling river, diverting down longs (canals) to feed huge catfish, spot giant monitor lizards and see a mixture of extreme poverty and immense wealth in people and property, from shanty towns to five-star palaces and temples. Public ferries are cheaper. If you decide to go private, avoid touts and be prepared to bargain. Dining on a boat at night is a delightful extravagance against the Bangkok night line, especially if you time it for sunset on a non-rainy day. Because the riverside is being developed, it's possible to travel by boats owned by top riverside bars and restaurants from public piers and catch some gorgeous views free of charge.

not very great views. You can enjoy a dinner cruise in this river as you can really see the water. However, during the day, it looks really dirty. All the water through out the city is not been cleaned. However, on the sides sometimes you can get some good views.

Excellent river boat cruise. This is a must do when in Bangkok. There are plenty of places to take a boat to one of the attractions along the river bank. The boats can get busy and you'll see plenty of monks on them too. The river is dirty but the experience and views are good.

Easiest Way to see the city. If you are going to the grand palace/wat pho/wat arun and can make it to the river, this is by far the easiest and cheapest way to travel between all the site. Plus you get a great view of the river. It's super cheap. 150 baht per person per day for the tourist boat (blue flag) or you can be more adventurous and ride the crowded local boat (orange). We found the tourist boat to be only half full and a very comfortable ride. It offers english commentary but it's all indecipherable. However, all the staff are very helpful.
its a river. Full of loud engines and people, the river taxis are very handy but it can get rather confusing trying to figure out which boat goes to where.
Totally Delightful!. We enjoyed the day trip so much we then did so again in the evening and are hard pressed to say which we enjoyed the most!

Chao Phraya River. October 2015 . I bought a One Day River Pass for 150 Baht . I think that is the very best you could do . I booked it at Si Phraya Pier near Rivercity and you can use it the whole Day .It is very interesting , i made a Trip to Thonburi and back . You can see a lot of nice Things left and right of the River . Do not use the Tourist Boats .

One Day Tour in bangkok. During our visit to Bangkok we have full one day to travel around to Bangkok so we decided to travel in BTS and Chao Phraya River.Our hotels in the Phaya thai area(Hotel season) from the BTS station we traveled up to the starting point of river i.e Taksin (Sathorn) From there we have purchased the full day tickets(Hop on Hop). cost is 150 Thia Bhat per person .A great way to travel in Bangkok, nearly as good as the BTS. A day ticket is very good value and allows you to travel on most boats and visit lots of temples (Reclining Buddha (Entry Fees 100 Bhat per person and Grand palace 500 Bhat Per person) etc. Don't expect any luxury as far as the boats are concerned, just cheap and cheerful and wonderful guides trying to give a commentary ( which i didn't understand ). Wonderful way to get a quick picture of the heart of Bangkok.
Best way to travel in Bangkok . Cheaper than the bts. And much more fun! 150bahts for all day boat rides.! It's quite convenient as there are many piers along the river.

A case for the blue-flagged boats at rush hour. The river boat system is efficient and comparatively inexpensive. But the same rules apply to both the boat and Skytrain systems: peak hours on work days are not much fun. We were just traveling to the major boat landings so we decided to take the boats with orange flags. Going upriver at 2 pm, the boat wasn't too crowded. And we wondered why so many people used boats with blue flags at Baht 150 ($4) per trip instead of the orange-flagged boats at Baht 15 (40 cents). At 4 pm we soon understood the reason. The orange-flagged boat going downstream was full to the gills, and we sardined in with everyone else. It sure felt good when we reached our destination. The blue-flagged boats were not crowded at 4 pm. Next time during rush hours, we would gladly pay the Baht 150 for a place to sit and enjoy the view and the breeze.
Not Very Pleasant. . The river was our principle means of transportation however it appears very polluted and the stench from all of the transportation boats made it very unpleasant.

A working river in a world class city. The Bangkok stretch of the Chao Phraya River is a distinctive feature for the city. It is a working river busy with barges and water taxis. The shores are lined with hotels, condos and shopping areas. This is unlike some other cities that have factories, power plants, garbage dumps and the like along their waterways. I don't know if the river is healthy, but it is a beautiful feature.

Travelling the river. Our hotel was situated directly on the river with a balcony And the view at night was fabulous. We travelled to the palace with the tourist boat, very lovely. Then we took a boat to the final destination where we had to get off as they were going for lunch. We waited à long time for the next boat And ended up taking the local one all the way back up the river to the other end. What an experience, end of lunchtime, people going back to work and school. Overcrowded, impressive, but fun.

Fun express boat!. Our time in Bangkok was limited, so we opted for a blue flag one way tourist boat from Phra Athrit near Khao San Road, and saw all the sights down the river. The boat guide mentioned landmarks all the way down stream. We caught the orange commuter boat for the way back after dinner. The lights at night were amazing! A must.

Long Tail Experience. We took a short one hour long tail boat tour, just my husband and I. We went through the neighborhoods and winded around past a couple of floating market boats. (Try not to get sucked in, the goods are cheaply made and your boat driver gets paid off).It wasn't the weekend so we missed the floating markets but a pretty cool experience anyway.

Use the local ferry and explore the river....... We used the local ferry, not the tourist one, as it is so much cheaper and has much more atmosphere. We went quite a ways up the river....not quite sure exactly where.....but we stayed on the ferry to the very end. Not too many tourists this far up the river, and no English signage or spoken English. We discovered a great market and some very yummy food to sample. I just love Thai marlket food....and so fresh and tasty.

The AORTA of Bangkok City. All revolves around the river a lot of things happen there every Day. What would Bangkok be without Chao Phraya? If you can`t go with car - the boat will always find its way!People live in/along the river, they have their livelihood from it in a lot of ways, transporting things on huge barges, fishing,driving people to & from work, showing tourists the beauty of Bangkok and so on.yu can spend the most of the day and night looking at it and it is never still, it always has its own life.Ride the ferries, visit temples, have some nice food on the riverside, just palinly enjoy the waters that amde Bangkok!

HEART OF THE CITY. A great way to travel in Bangkok, nearly as good as the BTS. A day ticket is very good value and allows you to travel on most boats and visit lots of temples etc. Don't expect any luxury as far as the boats are concerned, just cheap and cheerful and wonderful guides trying to give a commentary ( which i didn't understand ). Wonderful way to get a quick picture of the heart of Bangkok.

Beat the traffic. We utilised the river ferry service every day of our week long stop in Bangkok. Our hotel was situated near the Thewet Pier so each day we would travel the river looking for interesting places to stop. It was easy, cheap and very convenient to travel on with many attractions close to the many piers along the river. You can also witness daily life along the banks and the barges moving their goods up and down the Chao Phraya waterways.

Worth the visit. If you go to Bangkok, you need to go to the Chao Phraya River. Granted, it is not a beautiful river...but it helps you understand the life and activity of Bangkok. Our last trip we actually stayed on the river at one of the hotels and even took one of the river dinner cruises. This trip we did the river and the canals on a long boat.
Klong longboat. Interesting was to see the sites, saw a place that sold bread to feed the catfish! Very dirty river, and hard to get out of the boat as it sat very low in the water(I had a bad back)!

Ride the Express Ferry - Fast Access to other parts of town.. This is a great travel experience, but most of all this is a way many Thais get to work. Especially from Khao San Road district the Chinatow,, River District, and across the river.
beautyful. you have to try a trip on the Chao Phraya river, you can relax taking the boat and it is very cheap and at the river you feel so relax because no traffic.

Fish seem to thrive in this. A trip along the Chao Phraya river is a must. It is Bangkok's heart. There are many modes of travel on the river. For tourists the tourist boat, the blue line is best. It has a full complement of life savers for passengers. The others for locals appear not to. 40 baht for a single trip of 150 baht for the whole day of hop on hop off style. Most enjoyable.
Dinner cruise. . It didn't meet our expectations as the river had vegetation floating, some people may like it as the views were good but for a romantic dinner it's not that appealing.
Transportation. very good a efficiant way of moving in bkk.even for just an relexed trip for half an hour up streem and back

No way to miss it.... The Chao Phraya is the main thoroughfare for water traffic and is central to life in the city... it's one of the key features of the city and you will see plenty of it while in Bangkok. Life around the river is interesting so be sure to take a trip on a water taxi or in a long boat to take it all in.

"Beautiful River". This is an amazing river with some of the most beautiful views you will ever experience! If you have a chance take a boat ride down the river and experience it for yourself. Have a great time!
Take the yellow flag boat!. This transport over the river can be very crowded. Cheapest way is to take the yellow flag boats, only 14 baht, no matter were you exit.

Quick way to get from one side of the river to the other.. It was nice to get a different perspective of Bangkok from the river. Cheap to ferry across from one side to the other. Dinner cruises are also offered. Nice way to spend an evening.
Water taxi. We used this with our kids to get around the city between Chinatown and the Royal Palace. No need to barter, no worries about being lead astray. Cheap, frequent and efficient.

Exciting experience. Beautiful trip that takes you into the heart of Thai life. The river is the lifeblood of the Thai daily existence. This is where you realize why you needed all the medical shots. Some of the most exotic scenery in East Asia; and only a few miles from Bangkok but so different. Look for the stunning flowers that adorn houses along the river. This is the reason you traveled here.

scenic view of Bangkok. we booked a traditional barge tour of the river, passing by a handful of temples, floating markets and countless shanty areas, but the day was extremely enjoyable, safe, and non-rocky. finding hidden areas you wouldn't find by walking.
the floating market was the highlight as it was interesting on how everything works, while passing from barge to barge.

It's a river. Don't get any water in your mouth.
But there are plenty of fish to feed if that is what you like doing. The ferries are great and come often. Good way to get around Bangkok like a local.
Very cheap.

A huge river running right through Bangkok.. We opted for a guided tour of the river and its sights and were not disappointed.The river is incredibly busy, but very smooth so you won't get seasick.The shanty towns we saw on its edges, or the expensive restaurants and houses were such a mix.We stopped at one location and fed the river fish, they were huge and were in there thousands but it was a fantastic experience.If you don't want a tour, the river ferries/Taxi's are cheap and a good way to get around.

Chao Phraya River, should try... We did a tour on the river to have overview of Thailand. We heard about the history of the river and the city. The river of memory is the blood vessel that runs through the heart of the Thai Kingdom. Experience to fed fishes on the river that will be fun and nice touch to Thailand culture.

this where the BKK begins...... we love travel especially city tour. Chao phraya river is a nice place for sightseeing. you see this photo we taken while we on the boat. the girl in blue is our tourist guide named SASA, she is very friendly, jolly and knows how to make tourist happy. anything you ask especially best restaurant and place to shop she knows. Excellent Job Ms. SASA. You never make your tourist feel bored on that trip. if you see this 2 vendor selling souvenirs on you, pls dnt bargain, actually is already cheap compare to the market. you better buy from them because thats the only way they can feed there family and thats the only thing you can help them. im not advertising but im telling the truth....

Good access to key tourist spots. Chao Phraya river is a great way to travel to most of the places of interest in Bangkok.The Chao Phraya tourist day pass (150 bhat) is great if you plan to visit a few places in a day. Otherwise a single trip usually costs 40 bhat. The Chao Phraya tourist boat (marked with blue flag) is furnished with large seats, and good English MC introducing the places of interests for each stop. If you are more adventurous, you may board the boats with orange flags (cheaper, more local crowd, smaller seats and more stops).At the piers, beware of touts offering boat tours along the river. They quote as much as 2000 bhat for one-hour boat ride which is exhorbitant! Buy Chao Phraya express boat tickets at official counters.A good place to start is from the Sathorn Central pier (next to Saphan Taksin BTS station) and take Chao Phraya Express Boat to various key tourist spots -a) Ratchawongse pier (N5) for Chinatownb) Tha Tien pier (N8) for Wat Pho (temple of reclining Buddha) and Wat Arun (temple of dawn) across the river.c) Tha Chang pier (N9) for Grand Palace, Wat Phra Keow (temple of emerald Buddha) and National Museumd) Phra Pin Klao Pier (N12) for Royal Barges National Museum
It was polluted. It was a dirty river with wonderful resteraunts to the side it was a good attraction as river side mall was wonderful the river was badly polluted

One of the cheapest means of travel. If you are in Bangkok Dont miss a boat ride in Chao praya River. You can enjoy the views in both sides of the river. We travel to China Town from the grand Palace in boat. It was only 14 bhat.
wonderful at night. we did a dinner cruise along this river & it was beautiful, everything on the shore was lit up & the cruise itself was wonderful
Bangkok river. Many boats on this river, ideal for moving trow the city when there are traffic jams. Hard to find the gateways to the express boats

Excellent fast transportation, always fresh air staying near it. I prefer staying at a guesthouse near the river, for the fresh air coming from it, and wind in the evenings. Using the boats as transport is also an advantage. A nice clean safe park on the river is Phra Sumen. Good to recover after visiting noisy Khao San. Wat Pho is reachable by river boat also.

See Bangkok at night. Worth taking a ride either at night or evenings, beautiful!!
Amazing trip & a must do in Bangkok, words are not enough...
Just go !!!
BKK by Water. This is the big "don't miss" the only way to travel, whether you're in a hurry or on an afternoon lunch/cruise.
So Windy !!. When you visited Bangkok, as a traveler you must visit this river, this is the biggest river in Bangkok !!
Christmas Eve Memorable Cruise. We spent an amazing Christmas Eve on a beautiful cruise on this river. ...It was a breathtaking experience

For a different view of Bangkok. Worth taking a boat out onto the river and cruising down the canal network. The boat goes at a steady pace and you can take in the locals homes and businesses along the route. Well worth taking photos. If you are lucky you will see plenty of water monitors (large lizards) basking on the banks. Outside one temple you will see a sign for "feeding the fish". Take some bread with you to feed them, as these fish are enormous and go into a complete feeding frenzy next to the boat! There are hundreds of them and it's quite a sight! You will also come across one or two local floating river vendors along the route who will row up to the boat to sell their wares, whether it be touristy gifts or drinks. They are happy to barter with you and sell some very nice gifts. Going by boat just gives you a totally different aspect of Bangkok and a very enjoyable trip.
Dinner Cruise. Dinner was average...experience of having food and ambience was great... though we did not get the value for money as expected
The real life in Bangkok, Thailand. Lovely long tail boat ride along Chao Phraya River. You can see the real inner canals live of local people-poor and rich. Very interest ride. We loved it.

A different view of the city. The Chao Phraya river offers you a different view of the Bangkok and a good way of public transport to some of the most important monuments in the center. Moreover it is quite fun to see all the hustle at the river with all different kind of boats rushing in both directions.
Pretty at night. Went on night dinner cruise which is very nice. The scenery is very pretty, however, there are very pungent smells in certain areas of the river.

Quick way to get around. The boats are a quick and cheap way of getting to tourist sites near the Chao Phraya River. The river itself is a working rivers so there is always plenty to see as you travel on the river. We use it often to get to Wat Pho etc.

Make a boat trip on the river . Buy a one-day ticket for one of the boat lines and enjoy the trip until the final destination and back. It was unbelievable how many fishes are in the "dirty" looking river. If you feed them, houndreds will come.

Lifeline. You must get on the river while in Bangkok. Whether a water taxi or day trip to Ayuthaya, this will give you an ancient feel. Long before traffic jams and concrete jungles, this was THE way to travel. It still can be. Get on a boat!

Gateway to all the top attractions ...... Get yourself to Saphan Taskin train station, go down the river and to the booth at the end of the pier and pay 150 tbt for a hop on hop off all day travel pass.The Chao Phraya Tourist Boat is a cheap way of touring the sites and easy to get around. You get a helpful small guide of each stop.You can also do organised tours of the river but there isn't much need given what you get to see on this boat.Would recommend.

A must do. Threre is always something happening/to see on a river or on the side.Quickest way to go to certain parts in BangkokThere are different express boats (orange, green, yellow and no flag and the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat)It’s really convenient, quick and cheap.

Always great to sit on the bank at the Oriental hotel. Our must visit in Bangkok is the river cafe on the river. Don't expect to clean water, expect the interesting tourist ships mixed with cargo ships, small authentic boats. I recommend to have the Oriental tea with milk of course...

nice & clean river. there is only one river in bangkok that is chao phraya river. you will find so many good hotels around river side. which offers great view. also there is a market located on he riverside for shopping
working river and excellent to cruise down. I love rivers and this is so busy! great to cruised down lots to see. Great to get you to many sights and easier than the taxis!!
River Cruise Dinner. It's amazing to do that. Very nice atmosphere . Good Food and live music .I chose chao phraya princess 5 . Nice Cruise Boat . Very friendly staff .

Must feel if u visit bangkok. I had a ferry ride in Chao Phraya River in my visit to bangkok in july 2015. got down at BTS Saphan Taksin and took a ferry till Wat Pao. ferry was crowded but still enjoyed the ride. teriffic view both sides.

Great day out. We started out from the ramada hotel aboard there complimentry boat that leaves every 30 minutes to the main boat terminal,where we got aboard a water taxi and traveled to the end taking in all the sites it was really amazing we then purchased a return trip at 80 Thai Bart was worth every cent.you could get of at difrent stops along the way if you wish,as there are plenty of things to do at each one.will do it again

R & R in Bangkok Do try !. I always spend some time on the river when in Bangkok. The views,culture,peace & the wonderful refreshing breeze on the river, easy to stop for food ,drink or attractions. Long tail boats (with the car engine mounted on the back) are fast but very loud. Should you want a peaceful, relaxing outing after a day or two shopping, sightseeing,nightlife in Bangkok ! Try to find an inboard to rent. We found one on the jetty near The oriental Hotel. Next time I would like to try "Small Teak Boat Canal Adventure" "Pandan Tours" a 6 hour trip 2,330 baht per person which has very good reviews here on Tripadvisor.
Calm way to see the city. Bangkok is frantic and overloads the senses , this is a lovely way to travel between hotels and the city or to take a trip out of the busy areas
River Cruise!. Brilliant experience on the Cruise! Great Majestic view of the city in the night. we started at 7:30 pm and its a cruise for 2 hours. with Live music and dance on the cruise!!

Coconut Barge Day River Cruise. Wonderful cruise of Chao Phraya River, changing boat half way through the cruise, the tour guides were full of local knowledge. Staff on the boats were very efficient and helpful. Well Done.
Best Boat Ride. We had lovely an hour boat ride in Chao Phraya River. The experience was wonderful as we pass by amazing buildings and malls.

Must do.. I loved this, bit nervous about negotiating the fare for the long tail boat ride. Got in with a couple of guys from Germany. I went for the hour tour round the canal. Fascinating to see the houses right up on the canal side. Extra bonus , we saw a huge monitor lizard on the bank.
Dinner on the River. This is a must do if you visit Bangkok. It is very nice to see all the different buildings at night.

Such a lovely area. Take a dinner cruise along the river at night. It's so beautiful and shouldn't be missed. The river is a hive of activity. The best hotels run along the river. My husband and I rode push bikes (on tour) along the river. It's lovely.

Fun Time in Bangkok. Its a nice view when we enjoy the Chao Phraya River, with the motor boat we can see the Bangkok city from the river and the stop by to the Golden temple,..what an amazing view arround us,..

Its different and its interesting. We did it both ways to the Grand Palace, one way with publick transportation ferry (40 TB per person) and the way back renting a pirate long boat (1200 TB including small canal tour) . Of course we enjoyed most the way back, having the opportunity to see going through the small side canals how the locals live. I think its a must do action, although visiting one of the 3 floating markets near BKK may be cheaper and mope scenic.

Nice but not clean. Nice to take some sail on it even the water is not clean and you get some splashes somtimes.Can use it also as transportation to other parts of Bangkok.Don't take tours on it since the price usually is non logical to what you get.

Many restaurants along the river. The river is not good for swimming - although I often see Thai children swim in it from our condo. You can access many off the temples from the river, co it might be a good option to rent a long tail boat for that purpose.
great to know Thai culture. we travelled by charter boats to view grand palace n temples.very systematic n convenient with good pier stations which are walkable distance to major tourist attractions

The Chao Phraya River. The river runs along runs along the side of Bangkok city. It is quite easily accessible from a number of piers along the bank. A river cruise especially at night is highly recommended with all the monuments lit up, its a sight to behold. There are regular ferry services too.

Ferry Good. And backwaters a must do. Dead easy to get up and down on the ferry through the centre of BK. We did this and also caught a tail fin boat and explored the waterways/canals. This showed you how BK once was, how important the waterway is and was a real eye opener in terms of the fish we saw and the mini-croc lizzard guys......
Different Culture. I have to be honest, it's not a very clean place to visit, but the culture difference and the way Thai people lived on the river makes this trip an unique experience.

A trip on the river is quite scenic. We went on a private cruise with a group of us, with the option to stop unto 5 stops.We stopped at some riverside shops who make there own sweets etc. These riverside people are known Mon people who originally came from Burma.

The way to see Bangkok.. It is such an eye opener seeing life on the river, and a speedy way to get round some of the sights. Get to know the stops and where you can access other transport and moving around this busy city gets easier. It is also a welcome relief to get a breeze away from the heat.

Leisurely views. This is a lovely way to spend some time when you're sick of walking. Try the tourist boat on the main river. Start from pier 13 or pier 1 for the full trip. It's also great to see the canals but beware the unscrupulous 'tour' operators who lurk by every warf. It may be best to book a canal tour through your hotel.

Historic and the lifeblood of Bangkok. Impossible to review as the river takes on so much different character as it winds through the city.
Cleanliness in some sections is on par with most rivers in SE Asia. Love its historical significance also.

A must when in bangkok!. We spent a few hours on the river getting off and on at various spots.It's perfect for sightseeing as many of the temples and tourist areas have boat stops. A lot easier than trying to get a taxi cab, a lot less traffic on the river than the roads! Quite cheap to use aswell, especially if you buy a day pass.
love the river. i have always loved the Chao Phraya River..the life on the river..so much going on and love watching life ...We stayed near the river for a reason..

interesting experience. Travelling by ferry on this river I have always found an interesting and enjoyable experience. You have a choice of regular ferry boats [orange flag] and tourist boats [blue flag] and both serve their purpose. They are not luxurious and you do have to embark and disembark quickly so wear sensible shoes and carry small change.

Nothing extraordinary just way of transport in Bangkok. Nothing extraordinary just way of transport in Bangkok. It`s a good way to travel around Bangkok especially if you plan to visit old town and chinatown

Surprisingly rough but great views. Was not anticipating too much from taking the water bus / tourist boat but actually it is a good way to get too different locations rather than using on land transport. The waves are surprisingly large so I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who gets sea sick..
Very good for sightseeing.. The river is very good for sightseeing due to you reach every kind of area here. But some of the longtail boats can be extremely expensive.

Jump on boat and see where it takes you. The lowland areas of the Chao Phraya watershed in central Thailand have been designated as the Chao Phraya freshwater swamp forests, a tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests ecoregion,[13] an area about 400 km (249 mi) north to south and 180 km (112 mi) wide.The original swamp forests have almost entirely been removed as the plain has been converted to rice paddies, other agriculture, and urban areas like Bangkok. Much of the wildlife that once inhabited these plains has disappeared, including a large number of fish in the river systems, birds such as vultures, the Oriental darter (Anhinga melanogaster), white-eyed river martin (Pseudochelidon sirintarae), and the sarus crane (Grus antigone)[14] and animals such as tigers, Asian elephants, Javan rhinoceroses, and the much-hunted Schomburgk's deer.[15] Today we can only estimate a description of the original habitat and wildlife by comparing it with neighbouring countries. It is believed that the area would have consisted of freshwater swamps inland and salty mangroves on the coast and the river estuaries. The swamp would have been covered in Phragmites marsh grasses. Today there is a small area of this remaining in Khao Sam Roi Yot National Park, a relic of the original landscape.As so much has been cleared or altered the potential for creating large protected areas to preserve original habitat no longer exists. However much wildlife does remain in the rice fields and steps may be taken to preserve these as urban and industrial development on the plains is ongoing and the Industrial Estate Authority of Thailand has very little control or planning over this. Particular threats come from the conversion of rice paddies to large-scale production of prawns by pumping in seawater, and the use of pesticides to eliminate the introduced snail,Pomacea canaliculata, which damages rice plants.There are populations of threatened birds, including colonies of breeding water birds such as the world's largest populations of the near-threatened Asian openbill (Anastomus oscitans), and other birds such as the wintering black kite (Milvus migrans). Endemic mammals that remain are the limestone rat (Niviventer hinpoon), Neill's long-tailed giant rat (Leopoldamys neilli), and the near-endemic Thailand roundleaf bat (Hipposideros halophyllus).The Chao Phraya basin is home to about half a dozen endemic dragonflies and damselflies; the conservation status of most of these in unclear (they are rated as data deficient by the IUCN), but Cryptophaea saukra is critically endangered and Caliphaea angka is endangered.[16]There are few areas of wetland protected as national park and these are mostly very small.

The traditional lifeblood of Bangkok. We were staying in Silom and felt that travelling by river ferry was the most scenic way to access sights like the Grand Palace and Wat Arun. Plus it would beat taking a taxi only to get stuck in a traffic jam! It was fascinating to look out at the riverbanks and pass Chinese temples, a Catholic church, historical monuments like the Old Customs House and even renowned hotels like The Mandarin Oriental. The Chao Phraya is such a major feature of the city that you cannot imagine Bangkok without it.
Short visit. Great river view and market near by with Grand Palace . The boat fare depend on distance . Advisable to take tour along Chao Phraya River if time is permitted.

Very nice and interesting river cruises. I loved the boat ride on the river. Apparently tourists need to be careful to select the right operator. There is one that is professional and the rest not so. I just wish I remember which is which.
River-canal travel. Connects to over 300 miles of hand dug canals truly the "Venice of the East".Tremendously interesting long tail boats and even mermaids here and there.
Romantic. Nice way to spend evening away from chaos of the city. My girlfriend loved it and I was rewarded later. Try to avoid big cruise as they are usually crowded.

Nice river, rip-off boats. We are well used to negotiating prices but, even with our best efforts, we paid far too much for a 'long-tail' boat down the river. It's not true that you can't go in a boat with another party, it's not true that it takes 30mins to get to Wat Arun. If price matters, get the regular water bus: it's 14 baht!
