Be aware that we noticed that in the same operator in different days we were shown a price list with very different prices from what we had seen the day before. if you get a quote somewhere from 400 to 500 bath for two persons take it. dont spend much more than that on this sort of tours
Can't miss it. A great place to sit and spend some time watching the boats passing by. It is like a big avenue crossing the city. Lots of temples can be seen when you take a boat and go up and down

Go with the locals. you can hire a boat for up to 6000baht, go on an organised tour of this impressive waterway or hop on a local bus boat for about 20baht and kept your eyes open. It has about 40 stops and you'll do half of these in about an hour. Hop off and take the next boat back. You'll have travelled with monks and locals and it's the cheapest and most picturesque river journey you are likely to do! A bargain - if you want the history explained - take a tour and book locally or at your hotel as riverside options can be pricey and limited - enjoy

Go for it - an experience!. There is the Chao Phraya River Cruise and there is the Ferry. We did the Ferry hopping on and off and saw the City from the other side with the historical perspective to go with it. We also did the Cruise down from Ayutthaya. With the ferry, is archiac and risk taking while the Cruise is relaxing with an impressive lunch. Both are just as good in its own ways.
Chao Phraya river cruise. We did a 2 hour trip in a longboat along the river, through a lock and along the canals. A very good trip that gave a different perspective of Bangkok from the water.

Relaxing in the capital. Every time I come here. I like the boat to various locations overlooking the river. I like to visit ports that are major tourist spots in Bangkok. A trip that much more enjoyable activities. If anyone wants to come by boat on the river, remember to bring a camera. And sunglasses

Birthday special. This the area that totally made me go crazy about Bangkok.I loved the place.We bought cruise dinner ticket about 5000thaib for 2 me and my son because it was his birthday and wanted to celebrate it in style .I recommend it 200%.the food ,music and view of buildings !!!
Great Experience. I took a full trip on a water taxi and it was very cheap with a tour guide. I Enjoyed the trip and it was wonderful experience to me.
interesting. Take a tour in the river... the best way to see hidden places, the old Bangkok and of course, some big reptiles!

Enjoyed the Cruise experience. Chao Phraya Cruise was a great experience around the canals and water ways beautiful scenery . Had a look at Bangkok ,lovely breeze,Music,Good Ambiance and the houses built on stilts in the water. Good Indian Food on the cruise

Chao praya boat trip. We spent a few hours cruising around the canals and water ways on a long tail boat. Had a look at the old bangkok and the houses built on stilts in the water. The conditions of the housing was horrendous. A good indication of how the other half live. Definitely worth doing tho and having a look.

Efficient way to get around by water. Stayed right on the river and loved it. We had a nice hotel and using the shuttle to asiatique and saphin taksin which was our main source of transportation. Quick and easy to get around to the places we wanted to get to. Many small tug boats moving sand and building materials. Surprisingly large number of large cat fish coming up to the surface at times ( maybe for air as the water may be abit oxygen deficient) Overall a great way to get around.

Happy time with boat ride. I did not take tourist boat, but chose to go with local boat. The price is different and there's no guide. I went to Sripraya pier to take a boat and took a ride to somewhere I couldn't remember the name. The river view is absolute amazing.

Holiday spirit!. I love taking boats on the chao phraya river even if I only do it 1-2 times a year. It is slow but cheap and you get a great view. You also feel like a tourist on holidays and that's an awesome way to forget you have to go back to office the next Monday!

Must visit place. Very neat and clean. We had the river cruise and dinner in Chaopraya princess. Really impressed to see that they have utilized the river opt for tourism. What has attracted me is the suspension Bridge across this river.

Longtail boat ride for thrills. There are many ways to enjoy Chao Phraya from dining alfresco alongside at Asiatique or taking a leisurely dinner cruises to daytime ferry or longtail rides. A longtail ride is perhaps the most versatile choice for family groups and the sightseeing route may be tailored to your desires ... from floating markets deep in the canal system to main river palaces and temples. Stop off and view the Royal Barge Museum or grab take-aways to eat as you cruise.Should you wish to enjoy high speed thrills, choose a longtail with a BIG engine and ask the skipper to go fast "leow leow" when in open river ... our 6 litre Isuzu diesel monster roared like a 747 at takeoff!

Awesome river boat tour. Booked the tour thru an agency in hotel lobby. We are two persons in the tour and got one tour guide which let us ride a small boat around the river. It's a bit scary with the small boat but still we enjoy the tour along the river with some fish feeding along the way.

one of the worlds great rivers. Absolute must when visiting Bangkok. the Chao Phraya river is surely one of the world's great rivers...so much happens on it..so much to enjoy..don't come to Bangkok and miss it..Take a boat..a local ferry bus..and run up the river..enjoy one of the hotel boats..
Watch life on the river...

The Riverside. Well the river is dirty as in the water is dirty but still a touristy place , its a like necessary experience if your in Bangkok. There are a couple of options for the kind of cruise you would want. Evening , Dinner .. Luxurious , less luxurious .. well that all depends on your preference and budget. There is also a great shopping side located by the river called Asia Teak .. its a good experience. The river view is also pretty good with good hotels , skyline and temples

You should take a boat along Thai most beloved river.. Same with Star Ferry in Hongkong, take a boat trip on Chaopraya river is once in a lifetime thing should-not-be-missed. You will in love with this pretty river at first ride, guarantee.

River Dinner Cruise. We went for a dinner cruise on the river on the Loy Nava Boat which is a family owned business. The boat is authentic and beautifully decorated in a romantic way. What an experience. It was simply stunning. We had a 7 course meal and the food and service was fantastic. The entertainment on the boat was local dancing and music. We absolutely loved it. The cruise took about 3 hours up and down the river. We would highly recommend it.

Must do when in Bangkok. The river is bustling with boats of all different kinds, I stayed in a hotel near the river, so the water taxis were an Ideal way to get around and also to sight see from the river.

Amazing River. An amazing river and one I fell in love with. All sorts of boats ply up and down and across, from passenger ferries to small rice boats owned by the hotels. Also always a lovely breeze which is refreshing in Bangkok. Stay in a hotel on the river for a lovely experience

The beautiful Chao Phraya river ride. At the hotel we all took a quick one hour nap while the other was in the shower, that way we had our share of power nap while utilizing the time. We were ready in sometime and also set to explore the traditional side of Bangkok, also referred to as Old Bangkok. We asked the hotel receptionist for directions around old Bangkok, and they were really helpful to guide us with all necessary details and a map.And we took off, admiring the many shops on the way and after making our self a quick coffee and ready to eat noodles easily available in the departmental store. Within 10 minutes of walking we reached the Chao Phraya River side. The hotel guys were so helpful in advising us to not take a tuk-tuk (local 3 wheeler transport) which would cost us around 100-150 thai baht, and instead go via the quickest and cheapest transport, the ferry which hardly cost ur around 10 thai baht. Not only that the ferry ride is too beautiful. The river side if full of big fishes which is amusing to watch.Imagine yourself in a ferry and any direction you see there is heritage and tradition and the culture of the Bangkok. The ride itself seems like an attraction. One of the local guys helped us identify the ferry with a reddish orange flag as the one that would take us.Read full article on:http://ghshart0.wix.com/ourlittletravelbook#!One-night-stand-with-Bangkok/cmbz/55c0f7380cf265ef515e4d66

Did a boat tour of the river. We went on a day where it was not too hot and it was overcast. That made a great difference. The driver of the boat was nice to let us direct her to some places off the main river. There we saw some beautiful trees, and several water iguanas which were very big.

On the river. Often catch the local " tourist boat" anywhere along the river from Silom Road , through to Kao Sahn Road. Price is 14 baht, or 40 baht for the boat with commentary added...often indecipherable). A shorter, more pleasant alternative to the #53 bus to Khao San (next to Hualamphong train station).

Amazing floating way around Bkk. Taking boat along the Chao Phraya river is consisted in the daily tour and enriched my knowledge of the Thailand much better in different view. The river naturally splits and builds a traffical network, thus making a very awsome kind of transportation here. All the canals has its name like land streets. The means of transportation here are almost machine boats and canoes, and riverine residential shelter is stilt house along every canals. One of the most interesting activities that impressed me much is to feed the swarms of catfish in a certain distance by breads. They are friendly and naturally eat things we fed. For the spiritual thought, people here doesnt catch these fishes. The floating transport give a hand to enlarge the variety of trafficle mean in Bangkok as well as a lively attraction to the tourists through out the world. In the end of the tour, the boat drop us off at an attractive restaurant nearby a busy pier at the time with crowd of traveler. the food is obsolutely delicious with typical dishes as shrimp " tom yum", papaya salad, .... spicy, soury, sweety and...tasty.I love it .....

So-So But A Necessary Experience. The river is very murky and you need to make sure you have a high boat lest you get splashed. But Thailand has done a good job of systematizing this transport system. How I wish the boats and docks were cleaner.

Nice way to see the river area.. This was a lovely way to approach the Grand Palace, the trip from Sathorn, S6, takes about 30 mins and is refreshing in the breeze. Some lovely hotels including the Orientsl Palace which we visited later.

A nice cruise...... Ok, again I got lucky. I came down a bit later one afternoon to the dock and found a boat for just me. Yes, only me! So no issues taking pictures through someone's head, trying to maneuver, etc. The trip was much fun seeing Bangkok from a different vantage point. You also see how much of the city lives once you are away from the glitz and glamour of the skyscrapers. Just families doing daily living tasks: fishing, washing clothes, eating dinner. Admittedly it can smell a bit (and don't look too closely in the water) but really a fascinating trip into a part of Bangkok you would not see otherwise.

Entertaining Experience. My friend took me for a dinner on a cruise on the river. The food on board was okay but the view from the boat at night was very pretty. In particular Wat Arun or the Temple of Dawn looked spectacular dressed in lights.

Beautiful river with a lot of tourist trap. This is a very beautiful river whereby you can see the temples on the opposite bank. However, there are many tourist boat operator who keeps asking you to take the boat around the river. It range from 2000 baht per person to 5000 baht per person. I did not take it as I felt that the price is a little overprice

River Cruise. The wife and I went on an evening river cruise with some friends. The boat ride was smooth with good food (something for everyone), good music (Live Band) and the views were awsome. Several uniquley constructed bridges which are well lit and other interesting structures along the river.

River cruise . It was definitely a fun experience... not a cruise kinda person. But the view of Bangkok from the cruise .... the ambience, music and cocktails/ food made up for the price tag. A must if you're doing a leisure trip.

Different Boats-different prices. The orange flag boats are 15 baht, the "public ferries" are 30-40 baht...not a big deal, but if you are using the river a lot, just look for the cheaper public ferry. at one of the stops you can nook a long boat for a long tour...negotiate a good deal for 2 hours...worth it.

Chao Phraya River Ferry Boat Day Day Trip. The best way to go on the River is to take the BTS train to Saphan Taksin Train Station. Walk down and book a Chao Phraya Toursit Boat Day Ticket. It consist of Riverboat Ferries which Travel up and down the River on both sides. it is a unlimeted ride from 9.30am to 7.30pm You can hop off and on on all Piers where they stop.You will recieve a nice Booklet which explai all the Piers where it will stop and what You can see here.Best shopping is at the Tachawongse Pier N5 Chinatown. Walk on the right side from the Pier along the Street and you come to a sideway, where here is cheap and good shopping.This calledthe Phahurat indianMarket and the Sampheng market. Here you can buy anything.Good Museum at Pier N6/1 where is the Museum of Siam.Also along the Piershere are plenty of Tempels, Landmarks and also the Grand Palace which is worth a visit, and cheaper than a Tour. Entry to the Grand Palace is 500bath. Here are free tours in English.You also see how the people live at the river, Tug Boats and plenty of smal boats.

Great way to get around Bangkok. We stayed in Easton grand and had really easy access to skytrain. One stop away was river and boat stop. Boats are frequent and stop at different points on river where you can get off to see main sights like grand palace. It was busy with tourists but locals too. Cost is cheap and you get to see lots of interesting stuff along the way. Really because Bangkok is jammed up with traffic this is a great way to get around.

Unique way of public transportation. One way of travelling in Bangkok and it is very unique to see temples and building alongside the river. It is like being with the local and travelling like them. Always remember to enter the orange boat/flag and it cost 15 baht compared to the other boats that would cost you up to 40 baht. You can pay when you are in the boat.

Mesmerizing place which should be on your to do list. This is a very beautiful river and you can visit this place while on boat journey to Wat Pho and Wat Arun. Surrounded by big star hotels and cafes nearby, this river journey should be on you to do list while on your trip to Bangkok. There are different boat stations from which you can take a boat to do a journey of this river.

Meandering Through Bangkok. The Chao Phraya River, Thailand’s “River of Kings”, meanders for 231 miles (372 km) across its flat alluvial plain, draining over one-third of the nation’s tropical land mass. On its way to the Gulf of Thailand, the chocolate-brown watercourse moseys through Bangkok.To experience the mighty Chao Phraya we took the BTS Skytrain to the riverside Saphan Taskin station, where several river cruise options are available at the nearby Sathorn Central Pier. With limited time and a desire for a less touristy more authentic experience, we boarded the orange-flagged boat, which lacks English narration and stop announcements, but only costs 15 Bhat (US$0.43) for any length ride. We purchased our tickets from the pier-side stand, but could have paid the onboard ticket-taker just as easily.With capacities of up to 120 passengers, the wooden, single-screw boats, complete their 26-mile (42 km) round-trip circuits from Wat Rajsingkom (S3) to Nonthaburi (N30) and back. We cruised north to the Tha Thien pier (N8), and visited nearby Wat Pho and its magnificent Reclining Buddha. Then, for 3 Bhat (US$0.09), we crossed the river on a covered raft-like ferry to the Thonburi west bank to admire Wat Arun and the Temple of the Dawn. After returning by ferry to Tha Thien pier, we looked back over our shoulders across the Chao Phraya to watch the sun set behind Wat Arun and its world-famous spire, colorfully illuminated against the glowing horizon. As night fell, the river boats ceased operation (7:30 pm daily), leaving us on our own to mosey the meandering streets of Bangkok.

Relaxing. We had a short 3 hour river cruise with lunch to get from one temple to another, and it was quite a leisurely boat ride. The only blip was the scorching morning heat, very uncharacteristic for the time, but this was soon solved by going indoors into the air conditioned boat. The river was nothing spectacular but pleasant enough.

Best way to reach many places in bangkok. It's absolutely the best, fast and cheaper way to reach a place in Bangkok if it's near on the river. Use the orange line (20 bath fixed price) and reach grand palace, chinatown, silom, asiatique. I can advice to sleep in silom road and use chao phraya ferries to reach the other zones of Bangkok

Grand river meanders through Bangkok to the sea. The river meanders a long way from the provinces up North to the sea and provides a major transport hub as barges are towed up and down, mostly bringing construction materials such as sand into Bangkok. Lots of river cruises and floating restaurants.

Nice way to see a different Bangkok. Take the normal taxi boat avoid the "tourist" boat. It is cheaper and you can get off anywhere, you can do the same as the tourist boat it might just need more 'international communication skills'

Cheap or expensive you choose. You can book guided tours and pay 1,000+ bhart or you can jump on one of the regular taxi boats. I recommend the taxi for 40 bhart one way you can travel up the river with the crew giving you a description of the places you pass and what you can do / see if you get off at the next pier.A good way to travel with no grid locked cars

Sunset in Chao Praya. Beautiful river. One of the great thing in Bangkok. It is good to take some boats between Sathon pier to Mararaj Pier. You can take BTS to Taksin station and go to Sathon or Bangkok pier.
A Good Boat ride. Please collect Concerned map from tourist information center and always use express boat service. That is very cheap. If you choose tourist boat that is okay for only one time.

Take the ferry like the locals do. Take a ferry ride on the Chao Phraya River. Try taking the local ferry with different coloured flags indicating different routes. Be sure to take the correct coloured flag if you are going to a specific location. Otherwise, if you have time to spare and feel like exploring, just hop on to a ferry and alight when you feel like it! Also, before alighting, be sure to be ready standing at the drop off area of the ferry, they will not allow you to alight once they start to move off.

Great Day Trip. Good way to spend a day in Bangkok and suburbs. When you buy a return boat ticket it allows you to get off, explore and get back in at any stop. This is good value and gives a lot of photo opportunities and sight seeing, also many places to have meals along the way. if you are more adventurous you can hire a private boat and explore along the many small channels that connect Chao Phraya river.

Good way to see the city. You can get your ticket at the center pier. Especially the blue flag boat which mainly for tourist. It's 40 bath person per way and children are free. It's not the cheapest but its worthy as there's explanation in English and Thai along the whole trip. It's a fun trip for my 4 yo boy.You may take this to visit grand place. Stop at N9 dock.

Lovely cool trip in a water taxi, good way to see another side of Bangkok. Their are water taxi's that take you up and down the river, plus past many canals that people live on. Very Interesting to see how people live
Interesting. The river is majestic at night! Take a boat ride and you'll get to see a different view that you wont see when riding other means of transport.

Another Side of BKK, travel with the locals. Buy a cheap ticket 30B and ride up and down the river. A great way to see a different side of Bkk, also it's much quicker that the tuk tuk or taxi to get around.

Must see when in Bangkok. Some great sights and cruises along the river both day and night. Its one of the things you really must do when in Bangkok.You can ride the ferries all day and have some great memorable experiences for very little money stopping off at various places.Or you can splash out on a dinner cruise, a very romantic way to spend the evening.

Exciting tail boat experience on Chao Phraya River. We went for a cruise on the Chao Phraya River. It was a nice way to see parts of the city which you usually don't see in a taxi or tuktuk. We went on a tail boat for about an hour. It was incredible to see rural parts of Bangkok and where some of the local people live. A must do for all tourists.

Try it if you can. You can take local speed boat to explore the river. There are many kids of boat service. Pls check more details. Some are for tourist. Some are for local people. If posible take the local one.It is nice and very cheap. You can see more than you expect. Besides the scenery, you can see the way of life of local people.Also if you prefer to take dinner cruise( of course for tourist!),you can since it is the major river of Bangkok.

Great. We had a trip on a boat there....be sure that you will pay about 30 bhat for that....because all around is a lot of scum agencies who will try to charge even 500 bhat+ for that...Just try to find a pier from where locals travelling.

Eclectic mix of life. The life blood of the city and it's inhabitants. You cannot be in BKK without using the river for travel and relaxation. It is fundamental to getting around and understanding the history of the city/country. It is fast flowing and a busy highway of activity. Evening boat restaurant is a must.
Snake of BKK. Like a snake this "Mae Nam" is meandering through BKK. Use a boat for a cruise to simply cross the river or go upward to Ayutthaya.
Nice views. Have some nice views occasionally. Worth taking at least once, especially if heading to Wat Prao Kaew from the south.

A busy bustling and interesting river. The Chao Phraya river is a bustling hub of activity. If you are lucky to have a river front hotel with a view of the river, it is lovely to sit and watch all the activities. From early morning until around 7pm, the local boats sail up and down the river transporting people to numerous destinations. The river route is much faster than travelling by road to venues served by the boats as traffic in Bangkok can be vey slow. There are also tourist boats that have a fixed fare and offer a good river experience to people unfamiliar with the river. There are dinner cruise boas on the river as well There is also the option to hire a longtail boat to travel up the smaller river branches called Klongs. Here you can see the locals using the river for their daily activities including washing clothes and dishes!
Ferry experience. You can take ferry to cross the river. It is not that exciting, but I think it is worth to experience. River itself is not that clean, though.

Interesting and exciting experience. Chao Praya river boats are part of the Bangkok transport system. We took a longboat on our way to the Grand Palace. The trip takes an hour through a canal with 100 year old local houses on the side of the canal. There are also river crossing boats at the piers travelling for Baht 3 from one side to the other. A single boat ride cost Baht 40 which will take up and down the river. A mix of very old and very modern houses/hotels/businesses to view on both sides. This is also the easiest way to get to riverside hotels, What Phra Kaeo, the Grand Palace, Wat Arun, Wat Pho, and Khao San Road. Day tickets are also available for a pleasant cool journey up and down the river on a hot day.
Nice Must Visit. Its a nice river we had experience the white orchid river cruise with dinner in the river and we had a lovely experience
amazing. great boat trips,dinner cruises with amazing views of the skyline and temples at night.Great hotels with river view rooms, as well as good shopping and yummy food.

Sad. The one negative I have for Thailand which I have a great deal of affection for is the state of its rivers. An immediate ban on plastic bags is needed this poor old river is so choked with rubbish and pollutants if you fell in you would be pretty much guarenteed a long stay in a hospital. For a country that relies so heavily on tourism I just cant fathom it attitude towards rubbish.

Ferry across the river for a quick ride to the temples. Plan your visit, if you can, to the grand palace + Wat Pho by taking the ferry across. It takes verry less time to arrive at the destination, is cheap, and you get a glimpse of Wat Arun from the outside.

Amazing riverfront and cruise. The river front is amazing, and even better is the cruise. A must for everyone visiting the city, they will take you through the history of Bangkok, and visit places of interest through the water way. The city looks glorious in the evening with lights on, and coupled with the music on the cruise, definitely a must go!
Excellent river cruise . If you like a romantic evening cruise with dinner or just a good time with friends .Remember to take a reliable cruise operator .

Bangkok's River. Go to Sathorn pier on the BTS and grab a water taxi with the locals. It's the cheapest way of seeing Bangkok from the river, including waterfront temples, wats, palaces, hotels, restaurants - all in the "comfort" of an express boat. Recommended experience
Interesting. I found it peaceful cruising along the river in the middle of a busy city. 600 baht per person on a private boat. Water not so great, but experience was.
Bangkok by Night. A great way to see the city by night on a river dinner cruise or just enjoying the view of the city from your hotel room or restaurant.

A Must visit in Bangkok.. The river that splits the mainland in 2, the old town and the new town. Lots to see on both sides of the river, lots of vendors too selling everything from chopsticks to fresh fish. Well worth it for a few hours just to see the variety of life. The water is dark and murky...but the locals don't seem to mind !

One way to go to the Grand Palace. Easy and pleasant way to travel.Not too expensive especially ferries for the locals. But you'll not have the commentary about the sights. No big deal really as it was too noisy to hear it.I cannot remember how much I paid for it though.

See bangkok from the river. You can see bangkok city from the river. I prefer travel in the night and bring my camera to capture night bangkok view. There is free boat from satporn area to asiaquatic. Even tough short trip but great experience to see around in chao praya river.

Beautiful river flowing through Bangkok City !!!. Must visit for tourists to take a Boat taxi in the Chao Phraya River that flows through Bangkok city giving us a fusion of Nature and Urban characteristic scene of Bangkok. There are few temples that are established on the river side, so you can plan a ride in the boat taxi and cover these temples as well the breathtaking view of Urban Bangkok skylines from a boat that is cruising through the Chao Phraya River.

Travel like a local. Took the local ferry from Saphan Taksin BTS stop to Kho San road. A very cheap way to explore the Bangkok riverside (don't waste money on a private boat - the local ferry is about 60 cents) Try and take the local ferry (orange flag) and be on the river around 5PM so you can experience the sunset from the river as well as passing by the local tugboats!

Just once, try the regular river ferries. Every year I travel the length of the river for a few Baht each way on the river ferry... noisy, smelly and whistle(y). But this is how the Thai's travel..office workers, stall holders, monks, students... and it is a real working river. Beats the sanitised tourist river bus hands down. Try it, you can always get off and head back if it gets too much.Catch the ferrry from Sathorn Pier (next to BTS stop)

Local ferry 150bht all day Great fun and sights. What a great way to experience Bangkok,you will see huts falling into the river with people living in them alongside of multi million dollar properties,get on and off as many times as you like ,all day for only 150bht,an experience that should not be missed.

Thailand's Mississippi!. We took the river boat down from Ayutthya, which took about 90 minutes. But whether doing a tour or just using the river taxi, a ride along this really beautiful river is a Bangkok "must do."
Nice view, however depends the weather. You can take a bout and go through some canals, please take care that you have a good price. Take some small money to buy bread for the fish

Your visit to Bangkok won't be complete without this. This is our second time visiting Bangkok in a twenty years span. The first time we stayed at (used to be the Marriott on the Southeast side of this river). We took the complementary boat trips few times a day between the hotel and the city. Sights and sounds on both sides of the river have changed beyond anything we could remember. Take a private longtail boat is our favorite way to explore this river and many waterways leading into the river. Strongly recommended, if you're not too concerned with the sun and heat.
Nothing special. Basically used for Thai people for commerce or tourists to visit the Wat Arun. There is nothing special on it to get there just to see the river
a must do. take a long boat trip on the river and you will explore some of the canals where people live with fast food available Bangkok style!look out for the large lizards!

It's alright. not great. Took a sketchy boat ride - was afraid of A) where I was going and B) Of falling in. Major polluted water. Good views I suppose of Bangkok but I def can think of better things to do.

Great way to get around this part of Bangkok. As many will know there are 2 types of boat that go up river from Central Pier the Tourist Boats and the ordinary boats that stop everywhere. The Express boats are well worth the small extra cost for the fantastic commentaries that explain what you are going past. The river is a real feature and hopefully some idiot on the pier earlier this week wont put anyone off.

Great but could be cleaner. One of the great experiences when you are in Bangkok. I took the river route to go and see the reclining Buddha statue. Its a great experience but the boats could be more modern (like the metro trains) and the river could be cleaner.

Chaophraya Cruise with Family. The cruise terminal is a good size mall with quite a number of shops to browse while waiting for the boat. Modern and good size cruiser that accommodate easily 200 people with excellent food, music and entertainment. One can choose between in door and our door dining, but with the wind it is easier to dine in door then go out the enjoy the night breeze. Bangkok has always been a safe city to visit, I am sure the bombing is an isolated case carried out by sick and cowardly individuals. Thai people are all in arms in getting the culprit and sure they will. Let's not this scare us away from a beautiful city and its beautiful people.
Historical river. Plenty of cultural slong the river.We can see a lot of temples , traditional house beside river either or luxury condominiums.

Do it like the locals!! . The title says it all. Forget the ridiculously expensive private long tail boats or the allegedly romantic dinner cruise (as romantic as rows of couples having the same set dinner in a restaurant on Valentine day) and just grab the local ferry boat. Yes it's v crowded and there's no security measures such as life jackets, maximum number of standing people etc yes it's noisy and the guy kept whistling but that's how he communicates w the driver whom he can't see in the sea of people on board ... this is as authentic as it gets! We loved the slow ride down the river as we took in the mix of old (temples and other) and new (5 star hotels abound) ... The smell of the water, the breeze, etc We stopped just after the Grand Palace then walked around and caught the boat slightly further up when it was relatively empty, thereby beating the crowd onboarding at the palace and temple.Would definitely recommend unless you are travelling w young kids. If we had our three kids w us we would not have attempted the ride as its too crowded and cramped for their safety and comfort.

River travel Bangkok. Our hotel in Bangkok was right on the river and part of our Introduction to Bangkok tour involved travelling on the river both by private hotel boat and public water taxi. Great experience and great to see Bangkok from this perspective

How do you rate this...hmmmmm. Well, I was thinking under which categories do we rate it, appearance? Cleanliness? Scenery wise? Socioeconomic? I guess my overall impression is that the river is not necessarily the most beautiful place in the world, but it does make a whole lot for Bangkok. The cruises, the transport boats, the little "taxis", the many ferries crossing from side to side, etc etc etc. this gives the city a very unique feeling and it is also a majorly important transportation vein for all locals and tourists. It helps a lot on all those traffic chaotic days where no taxi, car, tuc tuc can help you get to your place. Then take the boat, I never saw a traffic jam in the river!! And if you are a walker like me, then there is always a boat that puts you in a fairly good walking distance of many of the main attractions in Bangkok. It does not solve it all, but a lot.

Wet?. It's a riverWe got tucked up by a taxi driver telling us where we wanted to go was closed & without thinking we went on his mates boat who took us to various places where no doubt commission was exchanging handsNever mind, it wasn't a bad morning. Just say NO fir,lymwhencer the boat stops & they all seem to leave you alone to explore in peace
Super Ride. A 40 Baht, Super Ride from Central Pier to Grand Palace is always a Nice Experience, I always make it a Point to have this Ride when in Bangkok. Not to be Missed.

Feeding fish. From the grand palace you can directly go to this object by renting a boat. Just walking from palace and you can find the boat rental. The river is very big, and you can feed the fish from the boat. Normally the boat has provide breads for the fish. It is awesome, for thai peoples, they believe that the fish is one of their God's pets, and we can not catch nor eat that fish.

Dirty and not much to see. Water was very dirty and rubbish was floating around. We chose to do a private tour which cost 1200 bhat. I guess we could have haggled the price down more. The river was very busy with barges and tourist boats stopping at piers. At first i thought the boat was going to break down but once we started to gain speed it was fine. Be careful because water can splash up and no way you want to consume or touch the water. The way locals live on the river is quite eye opening but that was the only facinating thing to see.Be careful when on a private tour because there are floating stalls in the canals and the driver refuses to leave until you buy something then they ask you to buy the driver a can of beer for a ridiculous price.

Life blood of Bangkok. This is the river that flows through Bangkok giving it its life blood. With sky-scrappers lining the banks on one side and the old city with gilded temples and ancient buildings on the other, this river provides the skyline for the city of Bangkok. A visit to this city is not complete without a river ride or cruise on this river.

A Romantic cruise. You would love this cruise , only if you love water bodies , or you are with someone , you are madly in love ..I was with my wife ...Choose an extreme corner seat out of the crowd on the extreme end of the deck on the first floor and enjoy a candle light dinner..it would have been more great if in place of that lady singing the song would have played Hindi Bollywood dancing Numbers ..Overall a romantic 2 hrs.

Chao Phraya River. Bangkok is huge and the river is the heart of the city. The transport system up and down the river is excellent and extremely cheep and definately the way to travel. Unfortunately the river its self is filthy and all the numerous canals stagnent, full of sewage and extremely smelly. The canals require to be dredged to flow again, the sewage requires an infastructure system that stops the majority of the cities sewage hitting the river and the people themselves must take more responsibility and not use it to despose of their waste. The river has such a magnificant potential in this vibrant city and i really hope they put in the effort to get it right

spend a day to visit different area between the river. you can spend a day from here. The first ride for the main visiting point (from the station of Saphan taksin) cost 40 baht for one way. Then you can find an express boat only cost 3 or 15 baht. So if you insist to visit every pier, you must get the one day pass. But i suggest you spend more time to each area at least 1-2 hours, so you don't need this.And don't forget to wait at one of the pier which can enjoy the sunset. The day i stay at the river walk, sunset with rainbow color..The view was stunning! If you stay at some of the hotels near the pier. You will have free ride to the main area. So lets have fun~~

Make time for the river.. Bangkok is built on the river and rivers have always been important in Thai society. Take a trip on the river, by local ferry and look at the many different styles of building and architecture along the river. You will get an idea of how much and how fast the city is changing. Best if you get on up stream from Tha Tien, Tha Change, the area around the Grand Palace, you can probably get a seat. Try getting on at Tha Thewes for example. There is also a local restaurant overlooking the river, right next to the ferry pier "In Love"A riverboat with an orange flag will take you all the way to Saphan Taksin, which is below the Oriental Hotel pier and it will cost all of 15 Baht.

Must Visit !! beautiful. The Chao phraya river is beautiful and it takes you between the Old and New bangkok. On one side you can see the Skyliners and beautiful luxury hotels and on one side it will give you glimpse of old bangkok and temples and monuments. The fairy service is very cheap and organised with a descent frequency of boats. everyone shall visit it once.

River in Bangkok... Only place where you get to see water. Mostly hotels and commercial buildings surround this river. Both day and night cruises available but better to negotiate and take without food.... Nothing great just goes around the river. Best place on Chao Phraya River is: Asiatique.... Open mall, with thousand of boutique shops, restaurants and lots of fun things for family, couple and friends to do.....

Nice sight seeing. Nice way to see some nice monuments and buildings alongside the river,especially at night time this is real fun to do on one of the many boats.There are also dinner cruises but in my opinion the food on those is not so good,but that could just be me because i prefer street food :-)

Experience the beauty of river on Chao phraya river cruise. We have been on chao phraya river cruise departing every day evening at about 7 pm .This is the best way how you enjoy the beauty of the river through cruising ! This cruise also offers dinner and bollywood base theme music,which is making the trip more enjoyable and remembarable .
Nice. We rook a small (kayak style) boat around the river and we saw all kinds of old authentic thai houses and views it was truly beautiful!!! The water is a big huge let down though :s too dirty

Cruise. After we went to Wat arun, we took a boat to cross the river to go to Wat Pho. Then we road another boat all the wat to Asiatique. The river is muddy but there wasn't any garbage. Actually you can see a lot of amazing sights when you tale a cruise especially at night. Many hotels are located near the river, such as Shangri-la, & Westin. The view at night is wonderful, you'll see many lighted boats and the buildings full of lights are nice. Boat ride cost us 40 Baht each to asiatique.

Delightful!. The ferry ride on the river is a great way to experience the bustling metropolis. It is particularly majestic post sundown when the Wat Arun and the many majestic hotels on the river bank get lit up. Almost all the piers are dotted with lovely riverside restaurants. The rides are extremely cheap as this is a common mode of transport for the locals. It costs arouns 15 baht(could vary slightly depending upon distance). For me, it was the best bang for my buck , ever.

Busy. After a busy morning of sightseeing and shopping we decided to venture to the Chao Phraya River. We found a local restaurant on the banks of the River, where we watched the locals go about there business and the tourists transit back and forth. A reasonably relaxing way to spend lunch, but when is it not when eating lunch beside the water?

The sign of BKK. Maybe its muddy and dirty,but its the sign of BKK,and also its worth to have severals trips with boats from different people so u can have a better opinion...and i cant imagine the view from my hotel without Chao praya

Go to Nonthaburi. Take the local express boat for 15baht. Ask for the Nonthaburi - the tourist boat does not go so far and thet will not send you to the line for the tourist boat. It is a nice and scenic ride.

River of Kings, Monks, and Good Eats. You haven't truly visited Bangkok until you've taken a ferry down the Chao Phraya. Spend the day floating down the river and stop at historic Buddhist temples along the way, like Wat Arun, or Temple of Dawn as it's called in English. There are many excellent options for dining with good views. For a special treat, have lunch at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel's riverside restaurant. Later on, take a walk through Bangkok's Chinatown or do a little browsing at River City or Asiatique.

Amazing River Experience. We were visiting Bangkok as part of a cruise so it was a bit of a whistle stop tour!One of the things we did manage to fit in was a boat trip along the Chao Phraya River. I have to say it was more like a thrill ride but I really enjoyed it. The boat zoomed along the river but it was a great experience, especially as we saw several buildings that are "must sees" in Bangkok. The river itself is very dirty with a lot of weeds. One of the stops was to feed the fish that live in the water, huge scavengers! It was a great way to see life along and on the river.There are lots of boats that do these rides. Definitely would recommend the experience.
Nice one. River Boating is nice experience . You will find it good during sunset but the water is muddy. its easy to take orange boat

River and canal tour also a must in Bangkok. The same day I went to Wat Arun, we hired a boat for a river tour and a tour of the canals nearby. It is amazing to me how many people live right on the water in the back canals, often when their only respective access is from the river itself. Lots of traffic of other boats on the water also. An iconic way to see a vibrant city set right on the river. There is a longer tour of the river which goes up and down, this was more boat around for a while and check out the canals. The river is the life line of the city and represents the oldest way of transport in a really congested city in any event.Worth checking out for sure.

Relaxed way to travel in Bangkok. One of transportation you can use in Bangkok to visit places. Highly recommended for visiting places like The Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Wat Arun, Emerald Buddha, China Town, Thonburi Railway station. There are different type of boats and ferries, Ferries are usually used for crossing the river from one bank to the other and costs no more than 5 Baht. Chao Phraya express boats are used to travel up and down the river to visit various places along the river.There are different type of boats - no flag, orange flag, green flag.... - thorough detail is given in Bangkok.com site. Orange is high recommended for travel up and down the river becoz it runs on all days, stops at most of sites you want to visit, the ticket person on board speaks English and will guide you properly, costing just about 15 Baht per trip. Frequency is 20 mts. During peak hours it will be crowded.Thonburi station to take a train to Kanchandburi, Bridge on the river Kwai is 5 to 10 minutes walk pier N 11Grand Palace and Wat Pho near pier N 9.China Town is close to the river too though many use the MRT also to reach it.Take a boat ride from one end to the other in an Orange flag boat just for the thrill of it. you will enjoy the ride.If you want to visit and ride through the several canal there are private boats for hire. You will have to bargain. They will take you out for an hour's ride or more. Cost will start from 600 Baht per person, you can bargain. we were offered a ride for 500 Baht two persons in the evening and the same thing in the morning when asked was 600 per person. You will have to bargain. If you want a better bargain go in the week days.

The river was filthy.... It was convenient, cheap and fast to use ferries. But it could kind of dangerous sometimes since they do not have things to cover both sides of the ferries, and the river was kind of filthy, trashes everywhere...

An amazing river you should experience up close!. The Chao Phraya is amazing! Depending on where you are staying (probably on the East side of the river) be sure to take a boat ride across the river to go to another MUST SEE: Wat Arun. There are sightseeing boats and dinner boats that one can also rent / book passage on to see more of the river and some landmarks that are better seen from the river.

Chao Phraya Loop in Nonthaburi. In Nonthaburi, the river makes a western loop, and forms a small island. The island is called Koh Kret. It is very nice and a tourist day trip destination for Bangkokians. If you are looking to get a feel for Thai country life and the laid back atmosphere try visiting. There is a boat "cruise" around the island that makes stops to restaurants and temples around the island.
Loved it. The best way to travel around the heart of Bangkok is to take one of the river taxi/buses between A and B...

A relaxed way to explore the city. Bangkok is very busy and the river offers something different. It's possible to get to places through public ferry boats, which is a very cheap means of transpirtation. There are also tourist trips with special boats, night cruises etc.I love the opportunity to get away from the hectic traffic and just experience the spirit of the everyday people and place

Yin-Yang of the Chao Praya river. river is dodgy, boat travel is cheap, but sometimes erratic and way crowded- take the free shuttle to Asiatique- free boats also to major hotels- scenic way to avoid auto traffic

Amazing river ... a life line for th city. The river cuts across the city, and quite a few of the tourist sites are on the river or easily accessible from the river. The river has different types of boats for passengers such as the Orange line, blue line and yellow line.. It is a great way to visit most of the sites and is fun also. Its kind of hop-on hop-off service.

a good Sunday afternoon cruise. I traveled the river as part of a tour. Cruising down the river gives a different perspective of Bangkok. A bit like looking into the neighbours back yard. Avoid getting plashed by the water as its a bit of a sewage dump

So Much To See On The Chao Praya. I suggest a long tail boat ride during the day that includes a canal tour and the Taling Chan floating market.... then one of the many dinner cruises for the glorious night time views.

Take a water taxi to experience this majestic river!. I stayed at the Royal Orchid Sheraton Hotel and access to this river is adjacent to the hotel. In fact, you have numerous water taxis which ply their trade at the hotel pick up point (in the back of the hotel). Either a room overlooking the river or taking a water taxi - will provide memorable views. Personally, I found it very relaxing to take a water taxi along the river and would definitely recommend this mode of transportation, in combination with the Sky train, to see the sights of Bangkok.

Great way to view the City. What a fantastic way to see the city and beyond.Make sure you visit the canals as well and visit floating markets and feed the fish.Don't be afraid to ask your hotel to get you a price for the river boats and taxis, they often work out much cheaper than at the river bank.
good 2 hours river tour. travelling long tail boat along the river is fascinating. the river is quite polluted. take the long tail boat to visit the local villages.
dirty river. there is many boat on the river make the river are polluted. the public ferry is always full of people, it is dangerous..
I'm on a boat. . Definitely a must to go traveling to see everything from the rivers perspective. Beware piers charging 1000 baht plus for tours. You can do better.

Loved it. The tourist boat is a great way to get around this river. You can either buy a day pass, or just tell them where you want to get off and it costs very little. There is cometary all the way, telling you what the next stop is, and what you can see if you get off at the particular stop. Be ready to jump straight on as soon as it arrives as they don't wait around long before they are off again.

Actual face of bangkok. I have taken the complete tour here. where guide will take u from the old city as well. Which is build on river. During tour saw many people are outside there house smiling at you waving at u. I heard during heavy run they have to leave there house,In case of high tide. But lovely people always smile on there face. Saw floating market. some of them approach , again bargain is key here. after that old but cute face of bangkok. You will they the new face with all big constructions , awesome hotels around river cost. over all lovely experience . The tour was end at Wht Arun temple. Which is another nice place to visit in bangkok.

Cheap and cheerful. We took the tourist boat from Saphan Taksin to the pier for the grand palace. The ride was only 40 bhat one way(free for children under 1,2 meter, 4 feet, 150 bhat for all day) and for us was just a different route than taking the taxi or bus. There isn't much to see really, but there is a guide who tells in quite intelligble english what you can see at all the piers and you are allowed at the stern of the ship, though only a limited number of people are allowed there at a time. Still it makes for a nice picture. But for basically what a BTS ride would cost you, you get a pleasant and quick ride on a boat, which for its route is probably the quickest way to get to some places, since there is never a traffic ham on the river.
Local Boat. We want from Saphan Taskin Pier to the Grand Palace but a local boat rather than the tourist boat.Was really easy and cost a fraction of the price - would recommend it!

A trip by longtail is a must do in Bangkok. We took a longtail boat private trip. Poor english (but funny) speaking boatsman. The trip went into a narrow channel and we saw the living conditions and animal life close-up.

Exploring the city via boat.. Another way of exploring the beautiful city of Bangkok is via boat. There's a Chao Phraya Tourist Boat that would take you from the Chao Phraya Pier to Asiatique Riverfront (Night Market). There's also a free boat going there.

Boat trip on wooden long boat. Excellent. Went a lot faster than we thought. Youngest son quite scared. But we loved it. Saw big lizards and back waters. Lasted about an hour. About 1200 baht. Went past all sorts of land marks. I would diffinitely recommend it.

Always nice. Chai Phraya River is the main river for Thailand and there are million of history along this significant river. The river with Thai lifestyle still remain at some part. Take boat tour where you can buy day trip at Taksin Pier where connected to Taksin BTS Station. Temples are
Surrounded.
Recommended for family and children and all other.

Nice walk along the river side. We walked 15 minutes from our hotel to the river Chao Phraya and it is nice to admire the nice buildings along the river.
Very colorful image of the many boats with tourists also.
Boat Ride. Nice river passing through the city. Try the boat ride for an experience of local culture and mingle with locals.

Great way to travel cheap around Bangkok. This combined with the BTS is to me the best way to travel around Bangkok. I took the local boat routes (between 10 and 14 baht) and not the tourist boat (150 baht unlimted travels in one day). Even if you have no specific place to go, this is a great (cheap) way to travel along the river. Make sure you get a map with the piers and that you undertand the coluor routes and the times (I recommend checking the Chao Phraya Express Boat website).

A quick and cheap "tour" of Bangkok via the public ferry on Chao Phraya river. If you don't have much time (or much money) take the public ferry on the Chao Phraya river. You can have a distant view of the the temples along the river plus it's nice to have a feel of how the locals live. Bonus is you can get to your next destination if you want to try something other than the usual train and taxi. Ferries are large and spacious but can get crampy at rush hour

Great way to relax. Picked up the water taxi to visit Wat Pho, and decided to go right up the river and then go all the way down the river. Great experience of observing river life, the river traffic and just watching the world go by,

Enjoy the river at your own pace, with little expense.. the Chao Phraya is an excellent and inexpensive way to explore parts of central Bangkok and beyond, whilst escaping the heavy traffic and fumes of the road system. There are numerous adverts for guided tours but I find their rigid itineries limiting. A very inexpensive alternative is the Express Boat Service, stopping at piers dotted all along the river through central Bangkok and connecting to the BTS Skytrain network at Central Pier. The relaxing boat trip will give you good views of the riverside wats (temples) and other prominent buildings, with the opportunity to hop on and off to explore on foot from the numerous piers. You will see the local dwellings built on stilts over the river, commercial barge trains and a generally different view of the city. We took a trip north to Nonthaburi (end of the line). We hopped off the ferry into a pleasant hassle free shopping street with market stalls and prices aimed at Thais - not a Farrang in site.You can also arrange a day hopping on and off at some of the old city's major attractions such as the Grand Palace and the Reclining Budha. You do have to pay each time you hop on but at 15 baht a time on the orange flag Express who's complaining. There is also a blue flag Tourist Express at 40 baht a time or 150 baht Day Card.
Good for a boat tour. The river is good to have sight seeing via boat and is also frequented by boat taxis. The side channels can be also recommended.

Lifeline of bangkok. I've been to Bangkok a few times now and although I wouldn't drink it ...I really like the river. It's a great view of the city, interesting watching life go by. As a cheap option just take the local taxi boats and go up and down the river. Maybe just pick a stop and get off for a walk and see what delights you find. On a recent trip I had my girlfriend with me and we ended up paying a long tail boat to take us round the canals. A first, me being a budget traveler, I was against paying so much but have to say it was great to see these canals, river houses and how they connect with the main river

No visit complete without at least a river ride.. Took a river crossing with the locals, fantastic. a few pence for a ticket, hop on. Needed more time to explore the river which seemed a busy vibrant part of the city. You dont need a tourist trip when you can just experience the boat travel from a to b.

Barter hard!. Barter hard! We paid nearly half the original price for a boat with just two of us, only slightly more than on the big boats. Keep your camera primed! Missed taking a picture if an enormous gecko!

One of the most pleasant ways to spend an afternoon in the big mango.. As a former resident of Bangkok and longtime resident in SE Asia, I can say that taking the public ferry boats from Saphan Taksin is probably the number one answer to the question, "what should we do today?" Try to avoid rush hour commuting traffic, as it is actually a means of public transportation, not a tourist boat :-) Tour boats are widely available, but tend to be overpriced and boring by comparison.

The River of Life. We had the opportunity to experience this magnificent river from 2 perspectives - From a "River View" room on the 12th floor of the Chatrium Hotel where early morning you will see a flotilla of yellow service boats heading off to collect the rubbish from riverside dwellings, followed by the passenger ferries plying their trade to the numerous piers along the river. Then come the big boys - Tugs slowly pulling strings of 3 & 4 massive barges loaded with all manner of bulk goods. Finally the river is always a buzz with "long tail" boats and all the hotel private ferries taking their guests to the central Pier.We then experienced the river 1st hand as part of a tour. Spending over an hour cruising the "Klongs" - man made canals - where you will see a variety of houses, industries, temples and cafes. In these areas the residents use the river water for everything except to drink. We would recommend such a trip to see a different perspective of family life on thr "River of Life".

Pleasant ride with comprehensible english guide. Spent 40 baht to have a comfortable seat with English guide on express boat to grand palace. Return waited a long time under the boiling sun by 15 baht boat which is extremely crowded that i could only stand. The boat rode towards the pier less then a minute and still a lot of people weren't be able to get on the boat and it went on. View is OK not really stunning but it's quite relaxing to spend an afternoon on the boat.

Not a bad way to spend an afternoon. There are several entrance points to ride a ferry along the river. The most common are at Saphan Thaksin Bridge and near Wat Pho. You can get public ferry for roughly 40 baht a person. Traveling down the river gives you a unique perspective on the city and well as allowing you to relax in the shade and with the breeze of the river.

No trip to Bangkok is complete without traveling along the river. For certain key tourist places, (e.g. the Palace, the Golden Temple, Oriental Shopping Emporium and many others) there is no nicer way of arriving than by river taxi. Pick up one from your hotel if you're staying on the river, or go to a pier located near a BTS stop and pick up a taxi boat there. They are cheap, quick, and very accessible - plus there is something very special about viewing old Bangkok from the river, taking in the many historical and cultural sights along the way. Whenever I visit Bangkok, I always include a trip along the Chao Phraya.

A must. For those who'd like to have short river trip, I recommend Chao Phryaa boats http://www.chaophrayaexpressboat.com.You can take round trip in about one hour. Day tickets are available. The first berth is close to BTS station. Fast, cheap, English language guide.

Good way to see a bit of Bangkok . We went for a ride on a dragon boat along the Chao Phraya river. This was a great way to see some other parts of Bangkok. We went past various temples and saw some of the housing on which the Thai people live. This was not an expensive tour and I would recommend it, especially if you have not been to Bangkok or Thailand before.

Interesting experience . This was a very illuminating experience that showed the difference between the rich and the poor in Bangkok. Went by long boat and it cuts a lot of time spent waiting in traffic.

Water Taxi experience. A great way to see the river, and see the day to day workings of the river. It can be a little confusing to work out which boat to be on, ( orange flag boat is the best), and which line to be in, but if you get lost, get on the wrong boat, get off at the wrong stop doesnt really matter, just wait for the next boat to come along.Definitely an experience not to be missed.

its not Venice nor Thames, its Chao Phraya River, Bangkok. a different experience having chance to go for river cruise in Bangkok, I was not cruising by the posh boat, I did not sitting on the private boat but I swing up and down by regular boat which means more fun and blend with locals and Monks too, it's awesome.I believe most of reviewers here have mentioned for boat fares and I shouldn't have to repeat that again. What I would like to share to you is; better start the cruise around 5.30 pm as the sun and heat are more friendly to your skin. but if you have no problem with humid and heat, do it whenever you wish as long as you bring drinking water, hat or umbrella during dry seasonthose who'd like to go here from Siam station by BTS Sky Train please disembark at Thaksin station (one stop after Surasak station)Enjoy Bangkok everyone..
Great Alternate View of the City. In a crowded city, a long view is difficult to find outside of skyscrapers. River boats give a sweeping perspective.

Boat taxis gone crazy!. Taking the water taxis up and down the river, on the one hand this system is amazing to transport people so efficiently. On the other hand, you risk life and limb as the drivers speed around with overcrowded boats. I was told to keep my mouth closed so no water gets in it, as it is extremely polluted. I was literally concentrating on what to do if we tipped over...grab that lifejacket and hold my breath!
Party at night. traveling medium during the day time and this turns to a party place with several cruises sailing around with dinner and dance. A place for late night happiness and joy.

Boat ride is always a good idea. We have a ride on one of local boats every time we visit Bangkok. Even if you're not interested in any particular place that can be reached by boat, still do this trip to enjoy a look of the city from the river. Especially in the evening!

an experience to remember. after trying our hardest to work out how the hell to travel from the museum of forensics to khao san road we found a way across the chao phraya. as we went to Thailand last minute we had not learnt too much Thai which may come in handy when try to organise a boat trip. the river was so busy and I didn't even see 1 crash! took about 5 minutes to get to the khao san road and was a really pleasant experience. maybe see if you can get a map though in English,

The way to see Bangkok. I became addicted to the Bangkok river ferries - you can see the whole city by boat - tips: orange flag boat is local ferry for 15 baht, blue flag is touriest ferry for 40 baht - same boat, same stops, just the local boats get more crowded. Another tip: get on say at Baglamphu (Kao San Road nearest stop) & go right till the other end for 15 baht & take a city map, then you'll know which stop to get off for which site - you can do most by boat & it's fun
music food and dance. Good to go with friends as there are lot of good food with music and dance. worth the experience and good to enjoy

A glimpse of Old Bangkok. Thoroughly recommend a trip on the river. Take the local public boat and hop on and off - it begins at Sathorn Pier but you can pick it up at other main stops. Although the river has changed much, it still offers a glimpse into the traditional way of life from Old Bangkok with landmarks and side khlongs. Sadly, many old landmarks are vanishing and huge condos and shopping malls are changing the landscape forever.

Transport Gold. Quick and easy form of transport that allows you a cheap and regular form to visit some of the top 10 places to visit. I always use the local boats, at 15 THB a trip, for single trips, if you intend to stay up and down the river all day a tourist pass is ok.

A must visit. It is a legend river..you just cant visit Bkk without visiting the Chao Phraya river...without sail around the Khlongs, or sail from south to the north towards wat arun and grand palace..

Chao Phraya River Cruise with Dinner. We booked the dinner cruise with complimentary pick up online.From our hotel in Siam area, it took us less than 30 minutes to reach the pier. It was early at 5:45 pm and we had an opportunity to observe the life along the river while we wait for our ride. It was the busiest thoroughfare for locals and tourists.For 15 Baht, you could avoid the horrible traffic on the roads of Bangkok. The converted teakwood rice barge came on the dot. The moment we set foot on the boat we were greeted warmly by girls in Thai costume who turned out to be the performers for the night. We were ushered to our table and the waiter briefly told us about the menu. It started of with a traditional Thai appetizer, pomelo with bits of tuna fish wrap on a betel leaf. It was unfamiliar to us so we gave it a miss. While waiting for the next dish to be served, I turned my gaze outside to admire the view, perfect for a romantic dinner. No drizzle, unlike the night before, made it more perfect. Unexpectedly, the river has no smell like other rivers that run along a densely populated cities like Bangkok. Except for the deafening roar of boats passing us by, it was a quiet ride in general. We passed by Temples, parks, hotels, restaurants, homes, government buildings, clubs, houses and occasional shanties on stilts. We were pleased with the service and the experience was priceless. The dinner and cruise lasted for about 2 hours . Oh well, time passes us by when we are having the best of time. KhabKhun

Good way to get around Bangkok. Catch the BTS to Saphan Taksin, from there you can get tours of the river/canal system (which are well worth it) get a slow but expensive boat to key points up the river or you can get the cheap ferry service which is quite fast and stops at all the key tourist places. The River City Complex which is worth a visit even just for a coffee and watch the river traffic go by, Temple of Dawn, Wat Pho and the Grand Place and up to Khaosan Road. The beauty of the cheap public ferry is you can get off and on and visit the various attractions without it costing a fortune.If you want to visit any of the major hotels up and down the river they have free shuttle boats.

A lots of things to do along the river. Mostly we started at Sapan-Taksin pier ride along the river and hopping into the temples and the end of temples blessed when stop to WangLang for yummy street foods near Sirirat Hospital. Also this area is second cheapest area to buy medicines. The well-known one called Petcharat. Also have a handmade bags, clothes, toys, hair accessories etc selling in this area too. I and my visitors friends we could spent all day ride the boat and hopping around.

The River Highway. Although it has been a few years back I can still remember the excitement of the river. We stayed right on the river with the longboats chugging up and back. The most efficient way to commute was a water taxi and not the busy Bangkok streets.

Nice scene and like the feeling. Nice scene and like the feeling. Was very clean and very nice during sunset. Not many people on the day we have visited. Water looks ok but not very clean.Could improve on the surrounding area a bit.

Fun and refreshing. . Fun way to get around Bangkok tourist destinations. Take the "tourist boat" line, which is a faster way to get around the popular destinations and temples. Its 40 baht for a single ride or 150 baht for day pas.Its a nice (but crowded) boat and it even has english speaking guide while sailing. Bewate : Sometimes you need to cross the river - costs 3 baht, but check your payment - they often try to rip you off by not giving correct money back.
Take cruse ride in Chao Phraya River .. Chao Phraya River is life line of Bangkok. If you really want to see lighting at night , take a cruse ride , run in Chao Phraya River.

Dirty, majestic and exciting. Went on the express boat and then picked up a private long tail boat tour of the khlongs (canals). You must do this if you are in Bangkok . It is around £20 each per hour but we did well and had 1and a half hours actually.You see what life is really like in Bangkok as you look at some of the ancient river houses and see a lot of different temples etc. we saw lots of iguanas in the water and on the rivers edge, some small then a massive one. A bird was in the river a drowning and our driver stopped the boat and turned back. He picked it out of the water with his hands and a little later on put it outside one of the temples. How amazing is that... It made my day and my trip yes the water is dirty, yes it smells in places but it's an experience worth having.
Dirty and Smelly River. Apart from its riverside bars full of prostitutes, there is nothing around the river, and I found it dirty and smelly

Amazing. Excellent food and service by the locals. To no surprise the people are friendly and very hospitable.
Hope to back soon....

Best thing in Bangkok. You can't visit Bangkok without at least one river trip. The river gives great views of the city and is a quicker way of getting about than most roads especially if you use the orange flag commuter boats which are cheap and frequent. Can't see much point in the more expensive blue flagged tourist boats. Especially good views of temples from the river at sunset.

Loved riding up and down the river. I was lucky the first time to stay at the Peninsula situated right in front of the river, taking a boat across to the train station and then taking the boat to the different temples and the lying Buddha, a must do experience in Bangkok, just wear comfortable cloths and get a ready for a local experience. I love Thailand and its people.
Good Food. Good Food with nice ambience.but better reach by 7 to enjoy.quite place to be.Try Grilled Fish and Prawns
DIRTY AND SMELLY WATER. The water of this river is so dirty and smelly. One good thing is there are many places of attraction along this river.

Amazing River. We stayed in the Shrangrai La hotel right on the river. Our room looked out onto the river and I spent every morning looking at the boats and tugs moving along the river.We went on a river cruise with meal included. Well worth it. We used the river to visit the Grand Palace and many other attractions. Wonderful experience.

A tour to see how Thai people lives. We took the boat and we went the river tour.Amazing pictures around in one hand the big hotels with the rich buildings and in other the small houses made sometimes from rubish plastics and old metal things all over th river tour. There you can see how the poor people lives along the river in those very dirty water.Sometimes water splash on us and you understand how dirty was.In one of the smallest canals some small young boys they take they swim in this dirty water..Anyway is an experiance for us the people from Europe to see a different world.

Fantastic. We had several trips on the ferry between Phra A Thit pier and Taskin Bridge pier during our stay in BangkokThese ferries are those used by the Thais in the daily travels and are a great way to see the city and riverThe river is busy with ferries, tourist ferries, long tail boats, barges and cruisers all going about their business. Any trip on the river is interesting as it continually changes due to the river traffic and you get a good view of Thai life by the riverI can recommend a trip up or down the river just to have a look around, get off somewhere and have a look around you might get a nice surprise

Such Fun And A Real Experience. Took the local water taxi from Sathorn Pier to Tha Tian (drop off for The Grand Palace). Friendly staff and at 15 THB one way an absolute bargain. Try it - do not worry if you do not speak Thai, the staff speak excellent English. Took the "express ferry" back and a little more expensive at 40 THB :-) but had an informative guide. Travelled with two small children (6 and 8) and would recommend if your children can jump on and off by themselves ie no pushchairs.

Must Try. very nice and soothing views. The boat ride was superb. Make sure you wear your safety jackets before leave the Jetty. Please get a tour guide to explain you on the way as you can see many ancient temples and palace along the river side. A fun filled good for family trip for who loves water ride.
Wonderful experience.. Went on a cruise along the river at night. It was an old converted rice boat. Meal was included in price and it was amazing to see all the temples lit up at night.

Drink it.. Beautiful river, so clear that you tend to overlook that its colour is blue, a deep, shiny blue resembling the eyes of Nazi generals in old propaganda posters. It smells good as well, like the skin of a happy toddler after a brisk walk in the Alps.Not many people know this, but the water is actually drinkable. Why shouldn´t it be? Bangkok is a hot city, so when i used the river-buses i some times scooped up the water from the river with my hands to quench my thirst. The river has pink dolphins as well, flirting with butterflies that egress from its waters, usually in the afternoons, in the mild, purple dusk.
A different city. It's really a nice waterway through boat, a different city with waterway system, houses in water......not very costly,

Easy way to see attractions. Take the Skytrain to Saphan Taksin station and you can catch the express boats at the dock below. Easiest way to get to Chinatown, Grand palace and Wat Po, the flower market, and Khao San backpacker district.

Only way to travel. Best way to travel in Bangkok (and can do it with Skytrain). Get on one of the orange taxi boats - so cheap (very busy in rush hour and very few please and thank you's from the crew but such fun. We just used it to get to Grand Palace but wish we'd gone up to end and back.

Never failed to impress me!. I have always enjoyed the boat ride on this mighty river; having a glimpse of the life of the local people; their mode of transportation, their houses and the way they live. Interesting!
Good. I choose to had a river cruise with my family which includes kids. and all of them loved it. it was a nice experience.

Nice experience. Take a long tail boat to go to the Grand Palace. It is really nice experience, although sometime you feel worry by the speed of the boat. This is the better way to travel in Bkk with many trafic jam.

The lifeline of Bangkok. The river itself is fantastic although a bit dirty. But it is a great time spent to sit along the shores and watch life goe by in shape of Long tial boats, barges and other vessels. I can highly recommend a private Long tail boat tour but take a smaller boat as to be able to visit the small side arms of the river.It is amazing there are thousands of People living on the river and y the river, entire communities and all Services such as mail delivery and garbage collection you guessed it are completed via boats.Enjoy

Relaxing and sightseeing on the river. Great views of the city and faster transportation that roads. Convenient docks and boats, tickets not too much and worth taking the trip.plenty of operators to choose from.

Great experience! (Especially at sunset). It is advisable to take it early in the morning or late at night because otherwise it gets pretty hot. The views from the river are beautiful (for either side). It is highly recommended to take a boat at sunset to enjoy a unique view, when the sky is filled with colors. The only disadvantage is that the river is very very dirty, it is a shame how little the city and many people take care of it.

good river trip. we took it from the beginning to see all BKK shores until the big palace. the one we took was straight forward to the big palace without making any stops ,,, I think it was the tourit express , so if you are running out of time, esure you take that one. very dirty water , but you can see different views of bangok while sailing

Dirty and smelly full of sewage, public boats are awful. If you are staying at one of the high end hotels on the river, DO take their boat as a quick way to get across. I wouldn't recommend taking the public boats though, very dirty and unsafe.

Long boat trip up river. I visited Bangkok in May and took a long boat trip around the canals - very interesting (and of course hot!). The floating market is well worth a look, and the contrast of extreme wealth and extreme poverty is striking!Even more striking is the attitude of the very poor - they still smile and seem happy!!Be careful not to get wet though as the river water is foul!!
Great way to get about. The river boat is a great way to travel through Bangkok. Really cheap; 15THB. Was the easiest way to get to the grand Palace and felt like a part of the Bangkok commuters.

Chao Phraya River. This is a good experience in the day time going over by barge . You can take this easily and have a good time. At night it is safe and a delight to see all the buildings lit up amd by the river very cooling and a safe experience.

Cheap and effective travel.. What an amazing experience. River boats are very cheap and so simple to use. The quickest way to get around. From Taksin station you have a short walk to the sky train and you can go right to Nation Stadium for minimal cost. The tourist boat is also very useful if it is your first time using the boats.

Very interesting. A great way to see Bangkok from the other side !! It is a very busy river and you can get a real feel for the lifestyle of the working people. Make sure you travel the canals too! So brilliant to see some very very old wooden homes, and some very new expensive ones too!

Unforgettable memories with the Chao Phraya.. To tell the truth, I visit Bangkok almost every year, but it has been 10years since I took a boat in this river. This time , it was not intended beforehand.
