Just my husband and I were supposed to enjoy dinner at the Thai restaurant in Mandarin Oriental Hotel - sorry, I cannot remember the name of that place right now.We were very excited to hear that we had to take a boat to get there, because the restaurant is across the river separated from the main building.Yes, honestly, the Chao Phraya is not the crystal-clear riverbut I think it contains the lives of people in Bangkok, which makes this river more attractive.While having fabulous dinner at the outdoor resaturant, we watched many excursion ships sailing with their own character-really intense -and it was like being another kind of Moulin Rouge!!!!I have to confess I'm so romantic...But I won't forget about this experience and really thank the Chao Phraya.

heart of bangkok. tall wide river, you can jogging you can walk or just sit down and take a fresh air from here, nice view in the morning till sunset, almost modern design of the town building here, you can get tour to see around the river here, ride from Bangkok to Ayudhaya or dining in cruise in the eveningแม่น้ำที่เป็นศูนย์รวมของคนกรุงเทพ

Great transportation option. I loved how flexible this option was. You could get on or off at any pier, all day long! The Express Boat was easy to use. The tour guide was helpful and friendly. It felt nice to catch a breeze and see the city from a cruising boat.
Filthy. Like disgusting. So polluted and putrid, we went on the ferry and I was horrified and the rubbish floating on top of the river, heaven forbid if the water got in your mouth. yuck

Cheap. great way to see the city. The ferries leave regularly and stop all along the river. They are incredibly cheap and a good way to experience the city and visit the Grand Palace area. There are 3 types but we were told the one's with the orange flags were the best bet. There were also many traditional places to eat overlooking the river and ferries run until 10 pm.
Very convenient.... Very convenient to visit different location on cheap boat services..they offer a day pass and a simple ticket for visit..For tourists, I would recommend a day pass..
Boat taxi ride: cheap & great fun. You should not miss a boat taxi ride while in BKK. Cheap and fun. It will literally be one of the things you remember from your visit!

Lifeline. The economy of the city is dependent on this river and there is tremendous movement on it. You can take up a full day ride on the ferry also or you can take up point to point. There are various markets to visit too. But the river is very dirty and it needs a cleanup soon.
River thur BK. Good transportation system up and down the river. You'll get to see many temples and sights along the boat ride.

Refreshing river ride for a dime. For me this is a hidden gem. Look at Bangkok from another side, by using the locals daily transport; the river ferry. It's very cheap, it's refreshing and shows you a different side of Bangkok.

Use the ferries to get around downtown Bangkok. I stayed up near Khaosan Rd and found the ferry to be a great way to get to Wat Pho and the Golden Palace. It's an efficient way to get round Bangkok and there's great views along the way. The tickets for the ferry are very cheap (bought either at the pier or on the ferry) and there's no messing around on price (unlike the tuk-tuks or taxis).

Beautiful river. We ( wife and i ) walked 2.5 miles by the river, under 40° celsius ... We almost died but the views were tremendous ... !We are crazy, i know that but, it was a very interesting day. Taking pictures along the way ... Fabulous. We walked from Hualamphong Station to Wat Pho ... Stoping here and there ... Always with this beautiful scenario ;)

Cool transport. What a fantastic way to travel in Bangkok.
The river is so much less frantic and HEAPS cooler than road transport.
An end-to-end ferry ride provides a different outlook of life in the city.

An affordable attraction for the whole family to enjoy. Many ways of enjoying Chao Praya from a 40 baht one way trip to a gala dinner cruise. My suggestion is to rent a small speed boat directly from boat owners, just in the shore off the Saphan Thaksin BTS. For 1000 baht, you can enjoy a 1 hour customized tour along the river. It is half off the regular price usually charged by tour companies

Price of day ticket is very cheap and it is an experience but the river is filthy and the setting is not so pleasant. Cheap tickets. Dirty river. Unattractive scenery. Boats were cramped but that was kind of exciting. Easy to hop on and off at different stops and see a variety of different locations. China town is fun, bustling and busy. Think the all day ticket cost about 2.50 GBP
Great ferry. Best way to get around in Bangkok, just forget the tourist boat for 40 bath but take the orange line for 15 bath per person. Enjoy the whistles!
Cheap transportation. This is a good way to see Bangkok from a different perspective. If you go with the public transportation it is cheap.

Enjoyable ride. Take the public orange flag boat for transport over the chao phraya from bts saphan taksim to wat pho, wat arun stop 8 , grand palace stop 9 or banglampoo/khao san or v.v., just 15 baht and every 10-20 min a boat

Great way to see the city when it's too hot to walk around. Use the Chao Praya Tourist boat all day ticket 150 Baht, jump on and offwherever you choose. Lots of great cafes to choose from along the way.

Great way to travel. Took a river boat form central pier to Wat Pho. The ticket one way was 40 baht. From the boat you can see many of the main sites of the city including the temple of Dawn which stood out to me. The only down side is that it was a bit of a wait for the ferry to arrive at the pier and my family got a bit scared after a rather bumpy return journey.

Fun fun fun!. Take the water taxi and cruise the river all afternoon... take time for lots of pictures and be careful of the spray from the boat, not water you'd want to swallow. The Chao Phraya river is scene of sights, sounds and smells from all over, an amazing experience you'll never forget

Day and Night is interesting..... We did a fantastic dinner cruise - and the views with the lights were great. A lovely way to see the river. Just make sure you look around for the cruise that suits your tastes. We are a little older, so really enjoyed the quieter cruise with the singer. After dinner the singing was dance worthy and the waiters couldn't do more for you. Expensive, but worth the extra money.During the day we took a boat along the river which was just for us and the driver. We went down the canal where the locals lived and it was very interesting.Unfortunately we weren't thinking and paid a fortune for a hat and few magnets - try carrying a conversion card with you so you know exactly how much you are paying for things.Also remember to take a map with you to look at the landmarks.Both trips are worth doing if you've never been to Bangkok before, just to get an idea of the city.

Best viewd by night - appreciate the light-scape. Ok for a beginner.
Probably best recommended at night to appreciate the surrounding city lights & boat lights.
Much more picturesque at night time.

Performance very boring with no verity on food menu. Overall It's disappointing because of too many Indian people on board on that day. So all over Indian dishes and which was totally test less food and later on singer start singing Hindi song and dancing as well. it's feel like we are somewhere in India so all performance that is totally not enjoyable to us and we can say boring because it's should not be like this ... Only the Good thing is outside view which is very beautiful but can't enjoy a lot due overall atmosphere.

Best. Great way to see And explore Bangkok. I recommend hire boat just with your friends. If you have smaller budget you can still go on tour with another people but it's not very Nice as you end up sguashed in small boat with many people.Won't enjoy and hard to take nice pictures. Also have to watch your belongings more then enjoying view. We went on river tour like couple as well and had a great time. It's not that expensive and you can still talk down the price with the locals.also he can take you places which he won't take you as a huge groupone of the best experiences in BKK

Great day on the river. Great way too see Bangkok. You can purchase an all day ticket for approx £3 and cruise the river all day or choose to get out and explore at each port. Your guide will give you all the info about each stop and what you can find there. If you want to see something on the opposite bank of the river, no problem. You can get a boat to take you across for 6p.....not a typo.......
Excellect. Excellent food and fantastic staffs Easy to access , Indian Vegitararian Aldo available book through the agent is cheap
Busy. This is a good way to move arround bangkok!a lot of boats are on the river but it is all safe! sometimes you have to wait, but not longer than 20 min.

Truly Ethnic.... The Chao Phraya River is one of the best rivers found in the midst of a bustling city, in the world. Numerous popular hotels line up this river while the Thais go about their daily routine of selling fresh agricultural products in their bancas. Interesting activity.

Peaceful atmosphere amidst bustling Bangkok.. Chao phraya, a major river in Thailand flows through Bangkok and then into the Gulf of Thailand.A cruise along Chao Phraya River is the most pleasant way to explore the city once dubbed "Venice of the East" (beacause it was laced with Canals) .One can book a tour from local travel agents or can directly rent a boat for the river cruise.Even though Bangkok has become a modern city, the Chao Phraya River as well as the canals are still charming for whoever wishes to seek the peaceful atmosphere amidst bustling Bangkok.

Calm and peaceful experience. Best thing to go if you have less time to visit a beach. The shuttle services from hotels on river side makes the river more reachable. The water is not that clean, but can be a good evening if spent on river side.

Take a cheap view on Bangkok from the river.. Chao Praya River is the big river that splits Bangkok in two parts. Riverboats with blue, yellow, white and orange flags bring you to different piers along the river. So its easy to go from Banglampu (Khao SAN area) to the Kings Palace (Tha Chang pier) or Chinatown (Tha Tien pier) or to the BTS (Saphan Taksen or Central pier). Price for the boats ,about 17 B , are paid at the desk at the pier or on the boat. For toerists the boats with orange flags are most convenient.

nice at night. Best at night take a boat tour or dining cruise, many offers from cheap buffet boats to exclusive river cruises. Most attractions are very well light and also the famous hotels look gorgeous. By low water levels the river can get somehow smelly, mostly from May to July before the raining season.

Longboat ride. Got a longboat from the pier at the Shangri La and for a family of 4 we paid 1500bht for a private boat. It took just over an hour to travel up the river and then down one of the smaller canals. It was a great way to see Bangkok and get a good feel for it. Was great to see the locals living in the over water houses and to feed the fish outside the temple. Would definitely recommend.

Needs to be cleaned!. This river is sooo busy! Interesting to watch the long boats cruising up and down. One negative is that it is filled with floating debris, so if you happen to have a meal on the river, don't sit along the water. We lived in Bangkok from 2011-2014

Three types of river rides. My Thai family invited me for a river cruise on the Royal Yacht which has been fitted out to carry many passengers in dining room comfort. The meals served were varied and delicious. We were seated near a small stage where live entertainment was performed most of the round trip. Our cruise departed late afternoon and we were treated to a glorious sunset as we travelled South down river. On the return leg night fell and the Bangkok riverside neons lit up the waters in colour. A wonderful relaxing and socially enjoyable ride.I visited a friend at the Sheraton hotel on the river and enjoyed their courtesy ferry to the BTS station just 15 mins downstream. Treated with cool refresher towels and fresh water to drink while sitting on plush red leather in this beautiful old vessel was delightful.My final was the ferry across from the Sherraton to the opposite bank in order to catch a taxi after visiting the market there. This crossing is utilitarian simple quick and inexpensive with an open view to the river activities.

Cheapest way to see BKK. Jump on any River Taxi and go to the end of RouteNorthern end is Nonthaburi Pier which has a Museum showing how the English school system was started by Rama, and local pot making etc.Total cost under $5 US, great views of Bangkok and the River snakes through the centre of the city.

Wild Waves. We took a longboat ride on the river, visiting the canals and seeing some of the waterfront neighborhoods.It was a great way to see the good, the bad and the ugly...something all cities have in common.
River tour. We hired a long tail boat for 800 baht for an hours tour of the river and canals. Fantastic experience visiting the residential canals to see the real working Bangkok.

Chao Phraya River - The Heart of Bangkok. On my first trip to Bangkok over twenty years ago I stayed in a fairly non-descript hotel, found the streets hot, smelly and noisy and got hasselled to death by Tuk Tuk drivers and tailors - this was a short stay on the way to Phuket and a dive trip. At my second stay (many years later) my partner suggested staying by the river and booked the Sheraton Royal Orchid. I love boats, working harbours and the comings and goings of ferries and water craft of all kinds - I used to catch a ferry to work in Sydney and for ten years drove them - so I guess you can say I am a somewhat kindly disposed to life near the water. The Chao Phraya is a busy water way - large barges of every description are towed back and forth carrying fuel, construction materials, crates of coca cola and Chang beer, and huge numbers of ferries carry people across and up and down the river. take a tour of the canals and you will see a very different side to Bangkok - peaceful water ways full of catfish - huge monitor lizards sunning themselves and even the odd freshwater turtle - this river may look dirty but it's full of life. There is nothing better than eating breakfast in the early morning and watching life in Bangkok pass by - and if you stay in a hotel with it's own boat you can get free transport to the Saphin Taksin Skytrain station and explore Bangkok more widely without getting stuck in traffic. My views about Bangkok have certainly changed - it's streets are still hot and noisy, and in some places very smelly indeed - but it's become my favourite big asian city, I enjoy the odd high speed ride in a tuk tuk after dark (opt for a cab with a/c in the day if you need to leave the Skytain) and still make a point of catching a ferry or hiring a long tail boat on every visit to see a side to Bangkok away from the crowds and the traffic.

River taxi..... We took the Sky train to the river and bought a ticket on the taxi. I believe that there are about 14 stops along the way. We would get off and on at various stops to explore and eat. The Grand Place was a regular stop for us.

The Mighty Chao Phraya. If you are visiting Bangkok even if its a stop over make sure to include the mighty Chao Phraya Bangkok's main waterway. Whether it be a long boat ride that takes in the quirkiness of the canals or a luxury river cruise with a banquet dinner the views from the river never cease to amaze. Temples, historic houses and buildings as well as a gateway to such other sites such as Chinatown can all be accessed via the Chao Phraya. In so many ways the river epitomizes the culture of Bangkok.

Average ride. we took the Chao Pharya River cruise to visit the famous reclining buddha.
Expreience was good but the river was in bad state with floating cans & food packets.

BKK in another way. This river is the heart of BKK i think, the locals use it for many things. Its the most important way for them for transport things. You can do nice cruises on the river, group or private. Alot of things to see like the Temple of the Dawn, the bridges..especially at night its beautiful. Theres also a possibilty of doing dinner cruises...wonderful feeling. A must do when you are in Bangkok !

Unique. This is a great way to get around! Get a day pass for the water taxis and plan to see all the sites the sites that are close to the Chao Phraya River. This way you don't have to worry about the different fares for the various boats. There are great apps that will let you know when the water taxis will arrive/depart. The water is clean and offers great views of the city.
Amazing river with excellent boating facility. I enjoyed the boat ride on this river surrounded by excellent buildings and bridges. Food & music on the deck are never forgettable
Pleasant River Cruise. Many boats that serve as a water taxi service. Take a cruise of the canals, and bring rolls to feed the fish.

Nice way to travel. Used the river to explore a little and took the tourist boat. Overall the scenery isn't too spectacular, I would imagine a private boat that went up the smaller rivers feeding into it would be more exciting but the cost is more than reasonable and if you actually stay in your seat instead of pulling a Kate from Titanic up on the front bow like I did you will learn a lot from the boat crew. We used it to get up river from the main pier for about an hour and then just walked back through the markets. Highlight of our trip to Bangkok to be sure!!!! The flower market at sunset was unbelievable, and just walking the streets for hours was a great way to experience true Thai life. The river is definitely the way to move around though. Traffic is infuriating, and constantly negotiating with tuk-tuk drivers or scammy taxi's gets to be a bit much.

Chao Phraya River. Their are a lot of attractions that you can reach by taking a boat ride along the Chao Phraya River. You can also see the Temple of Dawn along the river, great for taking pictures especially during sunset. See another side of Bangkok.

Working Waterway. There's lots to do in Bangkok and one of the most fun things is to explore via the river! The river has a great ferry system to transport you from Old Bangkok to New, but also provides transportation for travelers and trade routes. Use the express boats to get to nearly everywhere that the river takes you. Use longtail boats to explore canals and tributaries.

Powerful river. Take a boat, a regular one: 15 baht from bts Taksin to Wat Pho. A houses on the shores very funny looking, I made a dozen of pictures! River is ~1100 km with Nun river, one of the largest in the Asia. Also, keep in mind: Bangkok started at one of most curved places. Therefore, it is so convenient to use river for transportation in Krung Thep.

A great different view of bangkok. Get to see a different view of Bangkok - with little effort. Take a boat trip along the river and get to see the canal side residences and kids swimming. You won't miss a shopping opportunity - boats will come to you! Be prepared to haggle for a boat at the right price - check out the price of organised tours first. Best to pick up from river city.

Noisy, but convenient. I wouldn't say the Chao Phraya is a tourist attraction. Rather, it is an essential means of transportation. Bangkok does have a very modern public transit system, but it does not extend to most touristic sites, which are in the oldest parts of the city. You will need to take a boat on the Chao Phraya to travel from one site to the next. It is all quite simple (there are colored flags on the shuttle boats and number signs on the docks) and very inexpensive.Be warned that travel on the river is always cramped and very noisy. The boats all have old engines that could power tanks or jet airplanes...

Chao Phraya River. Just take a boat ride down Chao Phraya river. Take in the breath taking views of Bangkok and don't forget your camera. Architecture at its finest with tower blocks to wooden Thai houses built on wooden stilts by the river.

Must be try!. Bangkok's main river. Not very clean, as like all urban rivers. The important transportation route in those areas of the city,which have no BTS / MRT. Very cheap and fast boats,sometimes too fast.Very convenient and very cheap way to get to the main attractions as Grand Palace, Wat Arun etc.

Worth doing. Visited the River by Longtail boat, a great experience, cost was around 1500 Baht for the two of us in a private boat.Checked out Wat Arun, the Klongs (canals) and saw the back waters of Bangkok, a lot of homes in need of some love. Our driver was great and stopped to point out large lizards etc.The river is busy with numerous barges being towed up and down the river. The only time we had to put on life jackets was when the Police boat was approaching, would recommend that you wear them as the river gets pretty churned up with all the traffic.Disappointing to see all the rubbish in the river, there are rubbish boats that are cleaning up the rubbish, but it looks like they are losing the battle.

River Cruises. We were on the river several times. Be careful when you arrive there for the fist time. Just go to the local river cruise like a bus service it only cost about 15 to 20 baht to your pier. Very fast and lively. Great experience

Fast, cheap,exciting travel option for the city sights.. jump on and off and explore the lesser seen areas of Bangkok, We went to the northerly end of the route and found a market and good food with few tourists, the cross river Boats need some guidance but the locals are happy to help if you smile as sweetly as they do.take change not big notes. And It beats the hassle of tuk tuk drivers.

Bangkok's River of Life. Love how Chao Phraya River is very well maintained and utilized as a transportation avenue. We got the free river ferry to Asiatique. On the way back to the hotel we got on the first ferry available, cause there was a long line for the free ferry. It's amazing how the people in Bangkok traverse this body of water regularly just like using a bus or jeepney... it's part of their life.

Nicer at night. Our hotel (Chatrium) provided a shuttle bus which went along the Chao Phraya River, we did this at night, with all the city lights and calm if the river it was lovely. I could imagine a proper evening cruise being better. If you can find a bar on the river it's also great. During the day you can see the river's true colour and various building sites so not as pretty.

Cruise in Bangkok. I feel all should experience this cruise at river Chao Praya...With Live Musice a lot a food varieties i just loved the cruise...Thai Lady singing Hindi Songs were the highlights...As ther is nothing much in Bangkok a evening experience at the Cruise will be too Good...
a unique experience.. We took the express boats and the tourist boats. The express boats were really cheap but it was hard navigating the stops. What a unique experience especially for the kids.

Must take.. A cruise in the evening with a cool breeze all the buildings and temples were lighted.A guide told us all the salient landmarks.Great buffet.Lovely show with singers.My girls joined the dancing.Great fun.

Interesting river. Its very nice to have a Hotel near the Chao Phraya River.We were in the Centre Point Hotel and would go again if we are in Bangkok.Day and night its very busy on the river and so very interesting for us.

Good for sightseeing while seated. Took the longboat cruise of the river and canals. Got to see some interesting things near the river while seated on the boat. But the river is nasty and dirty and unappealing. Could do with a major cleanup. The cruise ended near the Grand Palace area so it fit into our other sightseeing plans.

James Bond 007. Post over visit to the temple of dawn, we took a canal tour in the James Bond speed boat, giving you a glimpse of the life of Thai people who live on the canal banks, their houses, their mode of transportation etc. nice experience

best way to avoid the traffics ! cheap and chill :). chao phraya is the only big river in the heart of the city like Bangkok , amd you know how bad the traffics is . there are express public boat that sail from Nonthaburi to Sathorn (sky train station) and pass so many toirism attractions such as Khaosarn road , Wat Phrakaew and Thonburi etc. that's why you choose travel in chaophraya river ! it's cheap and chill :)
Good Experience. The view along the river is nice. You can see a lot of amazing temples with different architecture. Beside you also may see a lots of old houses.

so much to see. a must do, buy a day ticket and travel from the main pier Sathorn which interchanges with BTS skytrain, then travel north along the stops, many good photo ops. We have uploaded the Chao Phraya river tour eBook to see whats avail as well as photos of each Pier location .. all in this page FREE http://www.thaibis.com/bangkok/transport/river.

i love it. this river is a must visit place, we can cruise along the river and have a pleasant view of bangkok city also visit temple2 along this river. the river waves is a little bit strong so prepare for the shake when on boats, but it was so fun ^,^
Nice place. Woow,.....splendid place to go, majority all the tourist know Chao praya river. We going for Dinner cruise in this river, and so crowded, many tourist and amazing experience.
Great trip. We loved travelling about on t he boat taxis. Amazing experience and cost so little. Good way of seeing the city
Jonny walker. Had dinner in a restaurant by the river side,on the last night of 2014. Nice food, elegant location, looking out at the river passing by..

Sailing with 10-40 Baht. If you visit this place, I am sure you will not regret it. This river is the main river which attract a lot of tourists in Bangkok. You will see how the city life of Bangkok from the waters of this well-kept and clean. Costs to explore this river is not expensive between 10 to 40 Baht, and give high satisfaction for most people.

nice river view in Bkk. actually I went there in 2013, so it's been 2 years already.. I just have the chance to write the review.. So this is like the biggest river in the heart of Bangkok. You have to take the trip across this Chao Phraya river if you want to go to Wat Arun.. and you can also join river cruise in the evening in which you pay for the dinner buffet and entertainment on board while cruising around the river where you can as well see the beautiful night view of the city, watching the lit up temples and other buildings along the riverside.

A river cruise to remember!. Chaophraya river cruise was amazing! We got to see Bangkok from a different perspective. The experience itself was refreshing. It has a live band and dancers which entertain passengers. The food was great! Its variety is suitable for everyone on-board. I always include this optional tour on every Bangkok quotation I made for passengers.

Relaxing travel with a tasty lunch. We enjoyed this cruise with an early lunch as a part of our tour. It was a great break from all the walking. The views were great, and we could walk around the boat, or relax inside with the AC.

River Boat Down Chao Phraya River. Chao Phraya River is like the main artery running through Bangkok. Was lucky enough to have river view from hotel and was fascinated by the greenery/branches floating down the river every day. It is a very active river system and there are boats everywhere. Definitely quicker using river transport at peak times depending on where you are going. This is a must do cruise down the river whethere it be functional or just to have a look. Some of the boats will be a culture shock to some but they make the experience so interesting.....it just works!

Smooth as silk. I love the river, a great way to travel in Bangkok, you can take the BTS to Taksin Station, then travel by ferry up the river to River City Mall where there are gallery after gallery of Asian antiques, or travel to the famous Wat Po to see the enormous reclining Buddha, or get a real Thai massage from the original Thai massage school on the grounds of Wat Po. Just up rive is the Grand Palace, and the revered Jade Buhhda. You can also go to the end of the line and have a nice meal there before retuning on the river.

Up and down the river, great way tomove around.. Lovely travelling up and down in various boats taking in the sights and sounds. You can get off at various points of interest to visit temples,palaces,markets. A great way to get about.

Take you time to see the sights from water level.. Since the Skytrain doesn't go into the old part of Bangkok where the Grand Palace, Wat Arun, Khoa San are, try the boats on the river. Take the day ticket on the tourist boat or just use Orange flag local boats

best way to Bangkok city centet. I use the ARL on a daily basis and it sure beats trying to drive and park down town. The train is usually crowded I seldom have to wait for the next one. Best way to get from the suburbs to city center.

a very nice expirience!. nice expirience talking to other backpackers riding on the ferry. we met a young french women during the trip and she decided to come with us at khao san road after visiting some temples and until now i still have contact to her. safe ride on the ferry but since its summer its not that much comfortable.
Dinner & Cruise - Not to be missed!. The cruise on the Chao Phraya river is an experience not to be missed. The cruise is a rather beautiful way to see another perspective of this colorful city!

River Cruise. Excellent value to buy the all day ticket to hop on and off as much as you wish. Booklet provided explains all the local attractions and sights. Just check the boat timetables to plan your stops and be alert for your stop as its a quick changeover each time. Great way to see a lot in a short time.
The lifeline of Bangkok. A visit to Bangkok without going down the river does not count. You need to make a trip, and going with the Orange flag boats you get the best price.

Boat trip. I love doing a trip on the long tail boats up the river and through some of the canals. There is a temple on one of the canals (boatman know it) where the monk will give you bread for a donation to feed the river fish, warning keep your hands inside the boat
cruise. Went for chao phraya river cruise - it was a wonderful experience, the only problem that i have is they are not on time :(
Good!. Chao Pha Ya River is the most important river for Thai people. It pass many provinces of Thailand. You can take a boat along the river.There are many station to drop off.
They keep it clean. What a great way to go see the temples just drop on the skytrain and go to the river exit and take the river boat to the temples

bangkok river. Visited Bangkok for the second time in May 2013. On one of my visit days took a boat from Taksin pier to Wat Arun. Indelible memories. Boat a bit uncomfortable, lots of water splash, but nothing wrong with that, still alive and spirituality enriched even more

Scenery Hotel. Nice scenery and can view the night river scenery at night.
quite place and well service staff.
Easy get taxi
A must to experience in Bangkok. A boat trip on Chao Pray is Very pleasent and serene. A must to experience since it's Bangkok avoid best. The price should be 1500 bht for a private ride.

Dirty river but gives Bangkok its scenery. Take any of the taxi boat (they are very cheap) in order to move easily along the river. Avoid longtail boats that offer you tours, you do not want to get splashed by the water of this river...
Good means of transport..... When I go I usually use the river taxi to get around. It's cheap, calmish and has a nice breeze. Good way to avoid being stuck in traffic

Cheap and Fast ride along the river. It's our first time to Bangkok and taking the local boat along Chao Phraya River. It was fun to cram with the locals. We had no seats, standing all the time. It costed us 15 baht each. Remember to always hold onto your ticket because there's conductor around to check it. It's scary when it's time to get off the boat, you have to find your way off the boat because the boat is too crowded. People will make way but you have to be fast or the boat will move to the next pier and you will be stuck. It's also really convenient for tourists who plan to visit places like Royal Barges Museum, Wat Pho, Wat Arun, Grand Palace, Chinatown, Pak Klong Talad Flower Market etc.
Ease of use. Used the many boat services for travel up and down river, very frequent and. Cheap great views from boats gives access to many temples if you need to visit without a tour

nice sight seen. This river is heart of thai people and longest river of Thailand , along river it has build very fine five stars hotel ,you can hire boat and can enjoy to see beautiful seen with family ,,,,,

Fascinating. A great way to get around in busy Bangkok and see some of the sights at the same time. Many passenger ferries travel along the Chao Phraya so it's easy to get on and off at one of the wharves to access temples, shopping malls, hotels and local markets (the flower market was particularly interesting). The ferries are usually very crowded so there's a rush of activity at each brief stop, quite chaotic at times. There's a roar of the engine against the current, the excited shrill of the ferry boy's whistle and a rush of people joining or leaving the ferry. Boats of all sizes use the river transporting people and goods. Apart from just a couple of modern runabouts, all the traffic is of an aging traditional solid wooden structure. There's no recreational fleet here. A fascinating experience and well worth it during a stay in Bangkok.
Evening or early morning trips are better.. Evening or early morning trips are better for photographers for a nice side light. Nice city view and pleasant journey. Worth enjoying the boat trips!

bangkok by boat. To get your bearings in bangkok its simple by boat on this river as you will get to see so much, and best of all was my trip for dinner at night on a great cruise that lasts for a couple of hours and so much wonderful food onboard you must be happy with the night sights so beautuful I, d say to all visitors-make this trip a must !!

Shows the reality of Bangkok. The tour on the river takes approximately an hour. It takes you all around the canals. You can see temples along the river, local houses build on the canals, local children swimming in the river along incredible big and weird creatures that live in the water. It is an eye opening tour to see where many locals live. It is another side of Bangkok, very different from temples and nightlife. It is more of a real life.To rent a boat they might ask you up to 1000 baht. It's better if you find more people to share it with you. They also promise that you will see a floating market. Well not really.. you will see one floating boat... and a little old lady that will try to sell you silly souvenirs. Don't go if you just want to see the floating market. Go if you want to see local people's reality.
Just hop on the boat. Take the public boat from the first pier of the south towards last pier of the north was a great experience and it is the cheapest way for you to see the river.

An Original & Unique River in Bangkok!. Having tried the sampan (Thai local bumboat) as it cruised along this Chao Phraya River to Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn), I was impressed with its great view of all the tall rise apartments and hotels located along the riverside.High recommend to all tourists visiting Bangkok, do take a bumboat ride along this Chao Phraya River, you'll capture lots of great pictures and its definitely value-for-money too!

Busy Commercial Traffic - Detracts from Ambience. If you have never been on a river excursion, then I guess this would be worth the effort. However the river is full of barge and commercial ship traffic at all times and although you can enjoy some scenic views of landmarks, the river itself is full of silt and pollutants.

Using the correct boat. We used. The river to get to where we needed on a daily basis whilst visiting Bangkok recently.In some instances you can travel for free by using the hotel's free ferries, especially to get to Asiatique as they have a free ferry too.( go eArlier to avoid queues if you can)Though going further up or down the river, the orange flag boats are cheaper but not promoted to tourists, they want tourists to use the blue flagged boats.Have fun and try the different boats, we did.

A must for every first-time visitor.... The river flows through the city and is a major transportation route for Bangkokians commuting and shopping.Great for a sundowner or discovery tour via ferry boat or longtail taxi.
Great views of Bangkok. Always fun to explore a city from the water. Bangkok is no exception ! Tour the canals or observe the skyline and water traffic

Travel by Express Boat is Cooler than local buses.. If you want to see Bangkok from a different perspective why not take a trip on the Express Boat? If staying in Kaosan Road or thereabouts, the nearest jetty you can take the boat from in Phra Pinklao Bridge. If you walk along Phra Arthit Road, which then becomes Phra Sumen Road ( Thanon Phra Arthit or Thanon Phra Sumen in Thai) You will come to a small white painted round fort situated in a little park beside the river. It dates from the 19th century and has cannons poking out over the battlements. If you go past the fort on your left side towards the Phra Sumen end of the same road you will see on your left a government building with tall Asoka trees in the grounds. Near this also on the river side is a sign for the Express Boat directing passengers down a short alley to a small pier.You can get the Express Boat which is a long one story boat usually filled with people. Usually a man blows a whistle rapidly to signal passengers to quickly jump on or off. Then the boat speeds away. You pay for a ticket on the boat when a lady with a cylindrical ticket clipper comes along. Most journeys are only about 10 baht. You can go to the Grand Palace or right down to the old Oriental Hotel which is near the big GPO. If you go in the opposite direction and pay more you can go as far as Nontaburi in the north of Bangkok. This can be a nice day trip, but go in the morning because last boats are about 5pm. Check to make sure when on the boat.There are lots of places you can go to by boat including the Royal Barges and Wat Arun. It is nicer to go by boat than tuk-tuk or local bus because it is very cool from the breeze. If you want to go on a trip around the various klongs (canals) you can also hire a long tail speedboat, but these tend to be quite expensive because it is like hiring a private taxi instead of a bus. However you can bargain the price down from a few thousand baht to a few hundred, which can be Ok if split between four or five people. Always have a card with the name of your accomodation writen in English and Thai so you do not have trouble getting home if you get lost. A Bangkok Bus Map can be bought for about 40 baht from any small shop in Kaosan Road to help you get around. It usually has a map of the skytrain too and information about places of interest.
Basic and cheap enough. 40bath for 1 ride (1 way) or 150 bath for full day (until 17h30). Recommend to buy a full-day pass. The boat is not too bad and they also have a English-speaking tour guide.
Leisure trip. Nothing fantastic to me, just a huge river. Heard there is river cruises on the river but never try. But a nice place to see the skyline of Bangkok though.

A blast for 1000 Baht. Hire a longboat by yourself for 1000 Baht, The tour starts at the Saphan Taksin Bangkok MRT stop. Get off walk 50m and your there at the river. Pay 1000 Baht and jump in for 45- 55 minutes of great scenery and photo opportunities. You can get off the longboat at any stop along the river on your return. Some stops don't have train or bus transport.This is a must for your stay in Bangkok. Go around the canels and see where people live, fish, swim, eat.

A great way to see the beauty of Bangkok in an hour. If you have a very short time to explore Bangkok, but you still want to take picture of the landmarks, you can take the shortcut through the Chao Phraya River. Bangkok's first five star hotel Mandarin Oriental, Old Customs House, Portuguese Embassy, China Town, Grand Palace, and Fort Phra Sumen from the late 18th century, all are accessible and clearly visible from the Chao Phraya River. What you need to do is, come to Saphan Taksin BTS station and walk to the Sathorn Express Boat Terminal/Pier (less than one minute walk). Board the Chao Phraya Express Tourist Boat and take a round trip (One way 40 THB, Return 80 THB total, Day Pass 150 THB). In express tourist boat, announcements are made in English. On board, a tourist guide will point to the landmarks and tell about the history of the landmarks. Details about the boat timetable can be found onhttp://www.chaophrayaexpressboat.com/en/tourist/index.asp. After 6PM, you can take a dinner cruise that will serve dinner and show you around. However, that is certainly an expensive option (Starts from 700 THB). Moreover, taking picture of the landmarks at night is bit troublesome from a vibrating boat.

An alternative way to get to Chinatown. Stay cautious though!. Grand Palace aside, the Chao Phraya River Cruise is also a great way to get to Chinatown (Yaowarat), especially for those looking at taxi alternatives. My family took the BTS to Saphan Taksin Station, where the Sathorn Pier is located directly next to it. The ride on the yellow flag ferry costs 15 baht. Buy the ticket from the lady standing by the side of the ticketing counter (and NOT from the counter itself because that one sells the tourist version at 40 baht) - the 15-baht ticketing lady is usually seen with a silver metal cylinder - that's where you receive your tickets.Chinatown is at Ratchawong Pier, which is the fifth stop. After the fourth stop, make your way to the back of the ferry and alight from there. Take note that there is very little time to alight, and there is no staff to shout out the pier's name - it's always better to make your way swiftly to the back once the ferry approaches the dock.Be cautious and alert too, as we happen to witness tourists getting scammed by ferry operating companies. Try to avoid talking to smiling locals when they strike a friendly conversation with you, talking about a 'local' method to travel. Keep your maps so that you do not stand out as a tourist. I believe the 15-baht ticket is already the cheapest method available out there via ferry. Good luck!

It was fantastic experience.. We enjoyed the River Cruise. The total duration was about two hours. The food was really nice. The music and the entertainment options are very well thought. The view of the city is excellent especially the Wat Arun and Grand Palace. Would be happy to visit again. Strongly recommend an advance the reservation. Overall a great memorable experience

A Great Way to See Bangkok. This is definitely the way to go if you want to avoid peak hour traffic on the roads of Bangkok. I made my way back to my hotel on a river taxi and it was wonderful. You get to see so much, the beautiful and the not so beautiful parts of Bangkok.

Must do despite the cheese factor. Get over the jazz trumpeter and the sultry songstress and the crap buffet. The views are amazing and it's the chao phraya river! Be prepared for a hectic on boarding though.
river. this is one of the lifeline of Bangkok. the boats plying ferries commuters across Bangkok at a nominal rate. use this mode of transport to see Wat Arun.

The most exciting river I have seen. The Chao Phraya River is like a busy motorway carrying goods and people back and forth day and night. The variety of boats is unbelievable from the most basic of barges to elaborate floating restaurants and boats that look like old traditional Thai wooden houses. There is never a dull moment on the river and it is fun to watch. However, it also offers a bit of peace and cool amidst the hot and bustling city of Bangkok and water taxis or tourist boats provide a pleasant way to see a lot of the city.
Very polluted. Title says it all. River was way too polluted. Styrofoam boxes and plastic bottles seen all over, ruining what could be a good sight.

Take safety Precaution When Travel on Boat.. Need more safety precaution when take the boat to travel along Chao Phraya River. My family took the boat service from the Jetty to Asiatic place in the evening, the boat are full of passenger and the wave are strong when two boat close each other the boat was so shaking.

Nice and cheap mode of transport . Those who are staying near the Chao Phraya River might want to consider taking the boat as the mode of transport to visit places like the flower market, the reclining Buddha, the royal palace, Chinatown, the golden Buddha temple or Emerald Buddha. One way ticket: 15Baht or 40 Baht (for tourist boat)They also have 150baht for one day unlimited ride that end at 1900hrFor those not near the river can go to the nearest BTS station (Saphan Takin) to enjoy the river side view.
Disgusting. Filth, garbage, & disgusting conditions. It is a terrible shame that people have to live the way they do along this river and associated canals. No reason to pay money to go see it.
Smelly but still relaxing..... It took me a few minutes on the boat to fall a sleep. This is not the cleanest river on earth but it is very interesting to look at the buildings around it.

I don't recommend swimming in this river. It was very interesting and amazing to ride on this river. Very busy with all kind of boats, from speedboats to large barges carrying rice, water taxi's and ferries. Fun looking at how the locals live along the river from the rich to the poor. Always something to look at.
relaxing place. had a great time exploring the main river.. the river is polluted and busy but its also one of the faster way to get to one place when the road traffic is bad..
River cruise with good lunch. Travelled the river as part of a trip to Ayuthaya. Interesting commentary with lots of different things to see along the river.

Very relaxing place. Very nice and peaceful to sit and watch the world go by from one of the parks along the river. River is very busy and rather polluted but if you go in the evening it is a great place to sit and watch a beautiful sunset.
great ferry. The local ferry is excellent value.A pass to get on and off is only a few bhat,so get one and do some exploring!

What a mixture - busy main river and quiet canals.. Had a great little trip exploring the main river and then off around the canals. Plenty to see with ramshackle buildings down some of the canals. Opportunities to see fish being fed outside one of the monastery's, floating shops and water monitor lizards. Tail boats aplenty zipping around.Also used the water buses later in the day to visit some of the sights along the river - another opportunity to see river activity up close.

Boat Rides in the Heart of Bangkok...!. Its a Nice Boat Ride, You may get a Little of a wierd smell at times, but its a part of the Asian Experience. Have a grand time with family and for first timers, you would'nt want to miss this Ride in Bangkok.

Experience another side to Bangkok. Given the Chao Phraya used to be an integral channel in Bangkoks transportation, it's well worth jumping aboard a water taxi, or renting a long tail to take you for a trip along the river and into the Klongs. Here you'll get to see what life is like for those who live right on the water, and also experience some of the sights of Bangkok from a different angle.No trip to Bangkok is complete without it.

Coolest place in Bangkok. When you are waiting for transpo to another place, and you have seen all you want of the big city, there is no place better to find yourself then tooling along in a boat on the amazing Chao Phraya river. It must be 15 degrees cooler there than in the city. I first found this out when I took a water taxi from Bhanglampu to the main General Post Office. I couldn't believe how wonderful it felt. Next time don't sit in a hot room. Don't get yet another T-shirt. Take a lovely, cooling trip on the river. Trust me, it's worth every bhat!!!!!

Must do. Excellent trip along the river and back through the canals to the old city. Can't remember the exact cost but approximately £10.00 for two of us and had the boat to ourselves. Slightly nerve racking to begin with considering the sheer size of this river and that it must be one of the filthiest rivers you can imagine, but after a bit of shifting around, the boat was balanced and off we went. Met a few floating shops on entry to the canal selling beer, soft drinks and the usual Thai gifts, keyrings etc for next to nothing. Great to see Bangkok as it once was, wooden shacks somehow still supported by pillars wedged in to the canal banks. Huge lizard spotted on the final leg of our journey and another nerve-wracking moment with a massive ship on our return to the main river. We were dropped at a different jetty from where we boarded where a local tried to charge us a 'landing fee'. Sure this isn't necessary and with only notes on us, blagged that we had no Thai bhats so he took a bit of english shrapnel that was left in my pockets instead. Would like to have ventured further back through the canals and will perhaps hop off in the depths for a look around next time.

Relaxation on THE RIVER amongst the hectic pace of Bangkok.. Really enjoyed relaxing along the shore of the Chao Phraya river. On a hot day in April my girlfriend and I took a break from the hustle and bustle of Bangkok to enjoy a cold drink in the shade along the shore of the river near the Peninsula Hotel. Neat watching the long tail boats go back and forth and the ferries carrying people from one side to the other. You can get another good view from the nearby bridge connecting both districts of Bangkok. Nice way to just relax for an hour or so.

River Boat Trip to Asiatique!. We took a free river boat ride from the Saphan Thaksin BTS station to the Asiatique (an incredible restaurant and shopping venue)! The boat ride was awesome, but a bit too crowded for me, and I bet they didn't have a life preserver for all the folks that they cram on board!

The best place to stay. Stay away from the hustle and bustle of the city, stay at any hotel that is close to the river. The river has much to offer, head to the Sathon Pier to find the many cruises of the Klongs (canals) and the long tail boats up and down the river. Take a all day tickets and jump on and off where you like for the day

Relaxing Ride. After we visited the Royal Palace, for 15 baht per person we took a boat ride up the Chaophraya River to Non Buri. It was a great way to see different boats, various building and water travel in Bangkok.

Very scenic in the Sathorn area at night. The river provides a vital transportation method for many people in Bangkok and has a lot of activity. Water transportation is inexpensive. In the Sathorn area, river views are very scenic with all the buildings along the banks that are lit up at night.
Best way to see the city. The river is the fastest, cheapest, most breezy way to travel. Take the orange flag boat from most piers for only 15 baht/person. Absolutely no need for a private tour.

Brilliant experience . Rent a private long tail boat.. Rent your own boat for 1 or 2 hours and get lost in the tiny canals where the locals live a seaming,y very happy but incredible poor lift. Kids happy to use a big sauce pan as a boat.very dirty water and a few dead dogs. Very exciting. Call in to golden temple and others en route.Look at great hotels and tiny shacks ( houses) Buy food and trinkets off boat sellers.

Chao Phraya River, Nonchaburi and Trains. We decided to have a day exploring the different stops along the Sky Train so bought a day pass and off we went. We got on and off as we wanted and we even had a Thai lady tell us we were going the wrong way as this was not a tourist area. Anyway after lots of fun on the trains we went back to the river and decided to go north to the last boat stop which is Nonthaburi another province of Thailand but classed as a suburb of Bangkok due to being so close. We used the tourist boats to the end of the line which is Pier 13 (Navalai River Resort) where everyone gets off including us then we used the express boats to carry on to Pier 30 the end of the trip at Nonthaburi. What fun this is, I though express meant missing a few stops, but no this boat still stops for about one second, people just jump on and off so quickly, absolutely no waiting for anyone even is your 2 seconds from getting on the boat.  Nonthaburi was fantastic; everyone was very friendly and happy to talk to us as we walked along Pratcharat Rd which is the main road for a few minutes to the Central markets which will be on your right. These authentic Thai markets are amazing, packed with everything you could possibly think of with stall after stall of fruit, vegetables, fish, flowers, spices etc along with some delicious food stalls.After a good look around here and something to eat we caught an old style bicycle rickshaw back to the pier for another 30 stops/pier stations to our starting point.  We will definitely go back to Nonthaburi and have a better look around as there is so much to see and do in the area.

Seeing Bangkok daily life from the river. In order to go to the palace you can go either through the congested city or take a boatBe careful there is a touristy boat and you are charged 40Bhat or take the express ferry for 15 Bhat.the touristy one has a commentary which you can skip.at the per they push you to buy the day pass for 150 skip it and take the local boat.it is fun and you can visit different places
Busy attraction. We live beside the river, there is always something happening on this river, the tour boats, ferry's and taxi boats all go about their business all day and into the night

Dinner cruise you should never miss!!!!. It was our honeymoon and we were taken to this cruise by our travel partner...must go if you are in Bangkok. Tge food was lavish and you have great variety to choose from...the cruise takes about 2 hours to spend time......

Lovely Dinner on a Cruise. Really enjoying our night with Chaopraya River Cruise.The buffet was lovely with fresh seafood, great tom yum soup and fresh mango platter.Got a table on the lower deck with a singer entertained us with some classic hits.We closed our cruise by dancing together with our group.Just lovely experience!

Canal tour. Picked up a long tail boat from Wat Arun to get an hours trip around the river and its old path. Very interesting to see the old pathway of the river (what you see now around Wat Arun etc is man diverted). Good value too.
Nice. the view along the river is nice. you can see a lot of amazing temple with different architecture. any the river does not smell at all.
A Good Way To See Bangkok. It is low cost and can get you to many places along the river and has some atmosphere with all the activity on the river. Use the public boats and do not take a tour.

Magnificently!. A great way to arrange a tour of the Bangkok river for very little money! You simply buy the ticket on the boat for 40 Baht - that's how we taxi, the boat has its own route and stopping. You can drive from end to end and see the city. Or exit at any stop you like) To do this you need to go to the BTS station Saphan Taksin and then go to the right way to the pier.

DO NOT TAKE THE TOUR: RIP OFF For nothing. There is absolutely nothing to see. they offer 1 hr tour for at least 600baht and i even negotiated to 300 and it was absolute waste of money as they bring you along an uninteresting dirty canal with nothing to see and they say it is the "Floating market", we just saw 2 tiny boats and thats it. DO NOT GO! just take a regular boat for 10 baht and it will take you along the river to any destination.

Lovely part of Bangkok. The chao phraya river is a lovely way of seeing the temples and attractions its fairly easy to get a round as many of the staff have enough english to tell where to go and as most of these places plenty of touts overcharging for long boat trips etc of course if you want a tour up and down the river there are plenty of choices to travel
A beautiful serene river. A lovely river in the midst of Bangkok with some excellent cruises with some amazing views of Bangkok especially in the nights.

Amazing River.... Worth visiting the Boat cruise. There are multiple cruise operators for this river. Best time to visit is during the evening. Chao Phraya river cruise is the one we went for, which offered Veg Options for dinner. Once you get in the cruise , settle down at one of the table first. get comfortable. the boat starts, with the starters being served at table. Dinner is like buffet and you have lot of veg options (Indian also). the cruise is across this river and covers most of the landmarks like temple of dawn etc., which are very brilliant to see in the night. when the boat crosses the bridge, you can see the sky high bridge ropes, worth taking photos.

nice way to see the city. we paid 900 baht for a 1hour boat ride up and down the river. it was certainly a no frills experience but My three year old thought it was great and my wife and I got some good pictures.

a MUST for every Bangkok visitor . Visiting Bangkok also means to see the town from the water side. I recommend to hire a long tail boat for a private trip. If you bargain a little bit you can get your private boat for 1,000 Baht per hour, even you are a couple or a small group of 4 people. Even the water is not really clean, but the fresh breeze on the river let you forget the heat in town. You will pass some old thai houses and get a little feeling of the Thai floating market. Be careful when you buy something from the other boats. They will charge the tourist more than double (a can of beer 100 Baht - Supermarket price is less than 40 Baht). Tell the boat driver to drop you at the Flower market (Pa Klong Talard). You should really see this place too.
It is a must while in Thailand. I like to take a slow boat and travel on the River it sure is great experience best around the sunset time

Efficiently used National Treasure for Thailand and Beautiful too. Chao Phraya River is a giant river that flows past Bangkok. Water is definitely not the purest, but Thais have made maximum use of it. There are several boat services along the river which are cheap to travel. There are several boat stations from which you can board them. Fascinating things about it:(a) The giant river itself.(b) Boat rides are exciting.(c) A lot of attractions along the way like Wat Arun. Easy access to Grand Palace too. Please see a map for all attractions.(d) Really useful during peak hours.(e) Much much cheaper than other mode of transport.(f) The river also connects to the inland canals.(g) During night, really beautiful.

Nice to feel the breeze to beat the humidity. I used the boats that traverse the river to get to the BTS station at Taksin bridge. It provided a nice respite from the midday sun and heat and was a great way to get around this part of Bangkok which is thin on the ground in terms of public transport options.As the main sites in Bangkok are on an Island, the trains and metro don't come onto the Island, so getting north to south means you have to rely on the express boat services.

Free River Cruise!. we were at Asiatique shooping mall and decided to walk to the water front and were surprised to see a free river cruise, which we obviously took. It plies between Asiatique and Sathorn piers. Each journey takes almost 15 minutes. Though there is no commentary, it was an interesting ride. The river is very clean

Cruising via river. It's an awsome exp to see d city of BKK thru river cruise. The tourist boat is really a gd way to explore the banks of river n the tourist attraction places. Though in d month of May june it's dead hot n u vl hve to take proper care before u step out. Rest it's a gd exp

the only way to beat the traffic. there only 2 ways to get around bang kok without gettingtotally frustrated, the chao phraya and the mrt soooo I alwaystry to find a hotel with easy walking distance to them both !!!cars taxis tuk tuk not happening especially in the morningor in the evening..forget about it !!!!!
Good way to get around and watch sunset. Take one of the boats to get your way around the city and especially during sunset you'll have a good few.

Take a River Cruise. A nice cruise on the river is a very pleasant way to explore the City. Their are tours available at very reasonable prices. The river connects to canals that the locals use for transportation. If you plan to hop on one of the Canal Taxis, you best tarry....on and off is done in about thirty seconds. But we had fun doing it b
See it. Get a river view hotel room with a balcony and enjoy the view with all the boat activity. A nice way to end the day.

The perfect road for foreigners to appreciate BKK. Riding by boat this river, along with other boats going back/forth gives the gist of Bangkok - Confusing yet functional.The landscape, either by day or by night, is a summary of what Bangkok has to offer to tourists, with plenty of restaurants, bars and hotels near each pier.
River cruise with Indian dinner. good ambience especially on the deck-Bangkok very picturesque at night . Indian songs sung by the Thai DJ made it memorable.

CHAO PHRAYA RIVER. Beautiful and lively river with easily accessible boat transportation. Hire a longtail boat to drop you off at several different sights located along the river, and have them wait for you. Many hotels located along the river. Can easily pick up the skytrain from the river. Don't miss this
ride with the fish. The dirt but fishes were treted with respect by the people who givethem food. Boy were they big! The ride was a bit bumpy but I enjoyed the scenery
Beautiful. The whole experience was good as we went on a sunset cruise. The view was just spectacular even though it was hot on that day and the sunset cruise is only on weekends
Wonderful Experience. We had taken a cruise along the river. It was beautiful and one can see lovely hotels and buildings on both sides of the river bank.

Princes On The River. An enjoyable way of seeing the Chao Phraya river is an evening cruise in one of the four ships named Princes..All ships are modern and depart from the River City Complex at 8pm. You are collected and returned to hotel by minibus. Cruise lasts about 2 hours. Excellent buffet and good live singer. Cost about 1500 baht. Tip-buy ticket from local travel shop of which there are many in Bangkok. Hotel will surcharge c.100% for ticket.

The magic river of bkk. This river is one of bkk magical places.why,? Because by day life going on as has for 100s of years ,floating taxis rush hour cars on the bridges ,traders going from deal to deal etc, by night wooosh!!! Lighting to historic palaces building royal boats ,I recommend you take your partner on a river restaurant a two hour ride no matter the weather sit back enjoy going 300 years right up to state of the arte buildings that make bkk one of the top 10 capitals of the world to visit, there many boat restaurants available we went thru the marriott hotel garden resort a must if your staying in bkk

A Relaxing Diversion in Downtown Bangkok. The river borders the Hilton Hotel, so it is easy to take the Hilton boat shuttle to the metro stop, from which you can catch a water taxi to the Temple or the Palace. Well worth the ride.
River boat Ride. The have free river boat rides or you can pay a river taxi (free is better in my opinion). The night ride is awesome with the city lights.
A nice river ride.. A ferry ride down this river gives you a good look at the diversity of Bangkok. It is an easy way to get to some of the Temples and Palaces.

Experience the waterway full of life and must sees. Take a "long tail boat" to explore the tiny forks and enjoy the view from the river. Luxury houses along with modest cottages, all in good harmony. Unbelievable that there are so much fish in this heavy traffic river. Water buses are also excellent way to move from one place to another.

Exhilerating Night River Cruise. Enjoyed the night cruise with on the Princess ferries with live band and wonderful buffet dinner all the way to the Taksin Bridge and back. Got excellent night views of the Wat Arun and the Royal Palace. Not to be missed on your Bangkok itinerary!!
maddness. Got a boat and did the river. Really good fun and gets choppy. No health and safty so be careful but adds to the fun.

Chao Praya is Thai life. I know Chao Praya from long time and every time I'm in Krung Thep I cannot miss it. Look at the river early morning, you can see the simple and true life, the activities, the people, the sacred river. Don't miss a simple cruise there, early morning, going to Wat Arun, temple of Dawn...
Take a cruise. Took a dinner cruise and was a great way to see the palace and the temples and avoid the crowds. La Noya was the one we took and the food was great!!!

Worth a ride. Taking some kind of river boat on the Chao Phraya is a Bangkok must. Its a beautiful way to see this part of Bangkok. Houses, hotels and businesses cram the banks. Boats and barges in constant flow. Lots going on and lots to see.

Bangkok riverside.. Love it down this area of Bangkok sit in one of the many riverside bar/restaurants and watch this busy river go by.
I have also traveled on the the river cruises many times and love it each and every time. Perfect relaxing way to see Bangkok including the old city by long tail boat.

Great River, Inexpensive means of Transportation. We were teachers with very little money to spend, so taking the boat to reach tourist spots was heavenly sent. We spent only 15 baht each ( one way) and yet the views along the way we're beautiful. The river is clean with lots of boats plying its route. All boats are full of tourists, rich and not so rich. What we missed is taking this boat at night which could have given us a view of the city in all its splendour. Years before, my husband and I have taken a night cruise ( US$ 50 each with buffet dinner) and was awed by all the developments made for tourists delight. Will surely comeback.

Sailing with the debris. Unfortunately, this waterway is so polluted with debris and vies of poverty and disrepair along the banks, I cannot really say that this was particularly enjoyable. Nice boat ride. I would not do it again, however.

Excellent alternative to avoid Bangkok traffic and get to the touristy sites. The ferries on the Chao Phraya river provide a good city excursion between sites and are also excellent alternatives to avoid Bangkok traffic and get to many touristy sites. There is a ferry line run by the government which arrives/departs every 15/20 miniutes and costs only THB 15. One word of caution is that, avoid private Ferries which cost more to cruise on the river. Especially on Sathorn pier tourists are hounded by private ferry lines which cost THB 40 or more. One is better of avoiding them as the service is not different than the one provided by the government.

Choose the tourist boat for 40 baht over the orange flag boats. Much more relaxed and tourist friendly. You avoid the express boat rush. There's even a guide who tells you about the attractions on the way.

Culturally Interesting, Disappointingly Polluted. This is a vital, working river snaking through the heart of city, accentuating the skyline and speaking to Bangkok's history. Barges, longboats, ferries and tour boats all ply the waters, keeping one's interest and sparking one's curiosity. Look closer though, and the water is industrially dirty, with pollution both visible and unseen. Dead fish, floating plastic, murky gray....The Charles and the Hudson once were in despair and now have returned to life...I hope one day to return to Bangkok and see a river once more vibrant and clean.
Chao Praya. An absolute must for any visitors to Bangkok. Take the local boat until the end station, takes about 90 min, and there you'll find a great floating fish restaurant.

A bit odd to "rate" a river. The Chao Phraya (pronounced something like "jao preeya") is a major artery in Bangkok. I could watch it for hours.Massive barges carrying who knows what towed by all sorts of vessels from bigg-ish tug boats to not much more than small runabouts wend their way up and down all day. Then there's the tourist boats, the dinner cruises, the "orange flag" commuter/tourist boats, the police boats ... you name it.I find the vibrant river a fascinating sight, and look forward to future trips to Bangkok and exploring the river.Tip: use the Orange Flag Express Boat to get up and down the river, from major hotels to major tourist attractions. Great value at B15, and lots of fun.

Boats, Barges and More Boats. It was interesting to see the wide variety of boats on the river. I was surprised by the amount of plastic in the river.Nothing spectacular but it is good to go and see it once.
Great cruise and views. It was a nice dinner cruise at Chao Phraya River with nice views. The lightings were topping on the cake. But the food could've been better.
Not to be missed on a Bangkok trip!!!. Definitely not to be missed on a Bangkok trip!!! I just love the athmosphere in this area and also gives you some air to breath again ;)

Lots of choices. yes, you can opt for expensive river cruises but there are also a range of other choices. From central pier you can catch the yellow boats at 15 baht which take you to wherever you want - we went to Chinatown, pier s5. On another day we opted for the blue boat (tourist boats) which are either 40 baht a trip or 150 for an all day pass, get on and off wherever and whenever. We went all the way up the river and then back, great way to see the river without costing a fortune. There is even commentary on the boat. Lots of the hotels on the river have free shuttle boats which is also handy and there is also the free ferry to the Asiatique, which is well worth visiting, open in the evenings from 4pm.
;;;. Waste of money another money making trip for them dirty locations that you are taken to .spend your money else where if you think you are gonna see fanstic views your wrong .wont recommed
Enjoying. Sightseeing Bangkok with the river transport, cheap and worth it! across the river to many tourist Temple attractions
A must do. Dragon boats here to hire. They will take you all around the avenues where the locals live, a must to see, ending up at the buddhas temple, then you can get a taxi back .

a must do while in Bangkok. The river-canal cruise in one of the long tail boats is a must do. People living in houses which are connected only by the canal with canal street name and house nos. is really worth seeing. The boat ride is refreshing and thousands of cat fish in front of the temples just wanting to have a bite of the bread that you throw is wonderful. It takes almost an hour and for the full boat we paid 2000 bhat.

King . My hotel sits right on this river and it's fun just to sit and look at all the traffic go up and down the river just going about their business. However a ferry ride up or down this river will show you the diversity of Bangkok

Amazing views. You can get a real picture of Bangkok on the banks of the Chao Praya river, the tops of the wats (temples) lead to amazing restaurants at the end of the ferry line near Khao San - renowned for it's backpacking district but very up and coming. Favorite is a little spot called In Love - live band, Rama bridge view, sunset is just magical.

The River of Kings. Chao Phraya has been called the River of Kings and it's sort of king of Bangkok still. My hotel was right along the river so that we used the launches to get around for sightseeing and even some shopping. At night, there were long dark eel-like barges slowly wending their way. In the daytime, a kaleidoscope of color as ferries, boats of many sizes, often crammed with passengers, come and go. The river has been cleaned up immensely since my first visit to Bangkok in the 90s.
Cruise. Very good experience can see Tall high rise apartments and amazing temples on your sail from the harbour. It's enjoyable experience, must recommend this to people visiting bangkok

Unforgettable Moments . Explore the Chaopraya river with the Princess dinner cruise was a great experienced, not because the dinner since the food taste was just so so. But it was because of the view of the surrounding and tye Bangkok city at night. The gold from the surrounding temple and from the palace was so stunning, It feels so shiny that makes it really nice to see at night than at the afternoon and it's good too to take a memorable picture on there. Never regret to had this trip.

Great fun. I had a wonderful boat ride up the river to a resturant. The river is very busy with all sorts of crazy craft on it,and the trip showed another area of the city of Bangkok that is not seen from the overpacked streets.

Chao Phraya is amazing. We visited this plcae during our stay at Hotel (IBIS Riverside) in Mid may 2015 and we enjoyed this river a much.We crossed the river in evening from Hotel IBIS Riverside to near Hotel Sharri-La.It takes 3 Bhat charge to cross from 1 side to other,during this time in early evening you can click some good pics of this river backfront.
Grat experience !. Must go trip in BKK. They serve you dinner along with music over the deck. It is really very romantic and great experience.

Another view of Bangkok. Thai travel the river by boat for work or for visiting the various temples on the river. Foreigners enjoy the trip on the boat as they can see a little of the traditional and original Bangkok. The boat rides are inexpensive and can take you close to most interesting sites, in particular the reclining Buddha.
GOOD PLACE. especially boat fares are very cheap and good. on the both ends you can find good stuff to eat :). they have many good place around too

love floating down this river. Don't miss a river dinner cruise. Seeing the river and city at night is very enjoyable and the food is good. I also did a tour that came down the rover form the North during the day and it was nice to see in daylight what I had seen at night.

spend time exploring on and around the river. The ferry system on the river provides a great, inexpensive way to get around. Try to go after the morning rush hour, though, as it gets really crowded onboard. Take a good street map of Bangkok, get off at any stop, and just explore for a while. There are interesting sites on the Thonburi side of the river, too, and the ferry stops at a couple of piers there. And take the ferry all the way to Nonthaburi - a fun town to spend some time in.

excellent mode of transport. Travel along the river on one of the many long boats. This can be expensive to youll need yourbartering skills or ask a local to help with price. I managed to get my price for 900bhat from 3000bht by doing this. This was an amazing way to travel along the river and grab some bargins from the local sellars along the river and canal.

Surprised how clean it is!. We hired a boat just down from the Royal Palace for 1 hour. We went first up, then down river stoping at a couple of temples and the royal barge storage. We even had a little supply boat stop alongside in the middle of a side canal to replenish drinks and snacks. The water was much cleaner than I expected!

Great relaxing way to spend a day. Best way is to buy a daily tourist pass which allows you to go right up the river to the bridge passing many of the attractions of Bangkok such as the Grand Palace, Wat Arun, and many others. You can hop on and off as you choose, then catch the next boat. Easiest way to get to the river is by the Skytrain which terminates at the river, and is b8th cheap and frequent
more than a river...a way of life. Sights to see, passing cargo ships and many other river vessels, helpful staff at jetties, a good way to see Bangkok..relaxing on a ferry up and down the river.

Great fun. If you can get a local boat or ferry it's an inexpensive way to get around on the river. The long boats are expensive but fun. The rice is dirty but there are so many interesting things to see all the way along. Tourist boats have passes that allow you to get on and off at multiple stops to see the many sights

Take a boat trip. There are a number of ways to get on the river. From the very cheap public ferry's, to a private chartered long boat. For a long boat expect to pay 1200 Bht for a one and a half hour trip of the river and some smaller canals (klong). Or get an all day pass on the ferry for 500Bht and hop on and off at 13 piers located near some of the cities major tourist hot spots. Make your way to Central Pier under the bridge. Spruikers will try and tempt you on to a private charter on the right, the cheaper ferries are to the left
Good mode of transport. Good mode of transport and cheap to get to places and skip the jams, that Bangkok is notoriously famous for

Dirty but good for transit. Not the kind of water you would want to swallow but it is very convenient for transport with multiple boat options going up and down or across the river at various points, including Chinatown and the Grand Palace. Links with the BTS Sky train at Central Pier.

A couple of hours on the river is always a highlight for us.. Spending a couple of hours on the Chao Phraya and the surrounding khlongs is always a must do activity when we're in Bangkok. The river gives a completely different of the city thgan you will get from any other form of transport, with the added bonus of not having any traffic to worry about.Whether you choose to take the everyday transport boats that the locals rely on for work or the more leisurely options of the tourist boat, an organised tour or hiring a long tail boat yourself, you'll most likely be amazed at what you see during your time on the river.We have done several options - the local transport, which is fast and a bit chaotic & you have to be faster getting on and off. The organised tour (through AsiawebDirect) which involved a noisy but interesting long tail boat ride with commentary & a rice barge tour afterwards with heaps of freash fruit and more drinks than we could possibly finish, including whisky. And we have hired a boat ourselves, but didnt like the whole negatiation ritual and didnt feel that we got vaue for money this way.When we go again, we'll probably do an organised tour and also the public boats to get to where we're going, and we will definately spend time on the Chao Phraya.

Fun way to get about. The river is a well used link in Bangkok for commerce and tourism. Watching the long boats speed down the river with their tale of water spraying out behind is impressive. There are several hop-on hop-off tickets available and these make it easy to navigate the main temples and tourist attractions.
Longboat ride. Go to one of the piers and take a longboat tour of the river and the area. It's really interesting to see the houses built on stilts and to see the city from the river and canals.
