Better than that of Venice. I visited Venice canal too but I was more attracted by this river crushing n it really was a great pleasure to be on it only thing I did not like is uncleanliness n not proper management. Any way one visiting Bangkok must enjoy this.
Good Transportation!. We took the river boat to see the major attractions closer to the river....its a cheaper mode of travel

Great way to get to attractions. Like many other reviews mentioned, just hop on the ferries. We only took the orange flag (15baht/pax irregardless of distance, payable on board) ferry, but you need to know the direction you are heading towards because the go both directions at the same pier and there's no indication on the boat other than the direction it faces.if taking mrt, you can go to hua lumpong and walk over (quite a distance)if taking bts, you can take to saphan taksin station, and it's just under the station.you can see wat arun from the ferry (though there isn't much to see when I was there as the whole place is under reconstruction.

Fascinating and relaxing. We had a tour along the river and smaller interconnected canals as part of our tour with BKK Tours and it was definitely one of the highlights of the day. Seeing the way that people live alongside the river - some in charming homes and others in homes that look to be falling down around them - is really eye opening. Feeding the fish (and seeing the frenzy) was fun too - especially for my daughters. I think this is a particularly good thing to do with kids who will enjoy being in a boat on the water, but I also found it a relaxing and wonderful way to spend an hour or so in Bangkok to see another side of the city.

Lifeblood of the city, many interesting sights. Whether the purpose is business or pleasure, the Chao Phraya River can be both a conduit to a destination, or the destination. My hotel was right next to the main dock for the river ferries, and they were convenient transportation to sites such as the Grand Palace, and river front dining and shopping complexes.The river itself is not a resort destination (swimming NOT recommended in the river), although resort-quality hotels line it (with pools that have clean water). Riding along on the ferry boats, for which there is a nominal trip charge, or the cost of a full day pass, one sees a cross section of building styles and land uses. Numerous temples dot the shores and some of them are open to tourists. A stroll through local markets on the west bank give a look at the way of life for people who live in the area.Many very nice restaurants look out over the river, in fact some are physically over it. For a few kilometers, paved and lit walkways allow easy passage on foot between the bars, restaurants and shops. (No fee for use of the walkway.) Plans are afoot by the government to expand and improve further the amenities along the river, and hopefully private investment will provide further development of appealing facilities while preserving the historical and cultural sites along the way.

Use the ferries. The going rate for tours is about 750 Baht per person,but if you simply take the riverboat it is far cheaper. The lowest fare is 15 Baht , for the ferry, or 40 Baht for the express ferry or a day ticket is 150 Baht allowing you to travel as much as you wish all day. Many taxi drivers try not to go to the ferries as they get a bonus from the tour boats , so ask for the Sheraton waterside and the pier is next to it down the lane to the left hand side of the hotel as you face it, and happy river trips!
scenic and good for travel. Chao Praya river though not clean but is good to travel to major attractions. Express boat service is very convenient.

Good transportation. We used the orange line to go from one point to the other. For all sightseeing spots which are close to the river and I think these are many, this is for sure the bast way to travel fast and cheap.
Great views!!!. a relaxing boat ride on the river with lots of different things to see all the boats and barges going by... all the different hotels... very nice we enjoyed ourselves...

impression with fish on the river. you will impress with the fish on the river Chao Phraya river, in front of buddish temple, nearby the ghost building.you have to buy somethings to give the fish on the river and take a photo with peace birds here
River of life. don't be afraid to use the River, the views are fantastic and it shows the varying lifestyles in Bangkok from the large plush hotel to the shanty shacks

Lively River Chao Phraya. This massive river provides so much for the people of Bangkok, largely evident while I took the ferry to visit Wat Pho. It serves as one of the main means of transportation still in Bangkok, and is a huge part of the charm of Thailand.

Cool off on the river!. Well, you can just get a little over heated in Bangkok. We always head to the river at night to jump on a boat and feel the cool breezes and see life teeming there...locals and tourists going up and down the river ...for work, for play...just to take a ride.
Always fun.

Nice way to get around. Chao Praya river boat trips are a lovely way to see the sights from the river and get around. We used the orange flag boats because they stop at every pier (Tha). The cost is very cheap and the fresh air is cooling after queuing in the humidity. Always carry small change for the fair which you pay on the boat to a lovely lady conductor. Pay attention to announcements as they're generally in Thai, so you need to understand the pier number and name where you want to get off.

Have a Lazy afternoon watching the barges and hotel ferry boats go by. Have breakfast or afternoon tea at the Shangrri La hotel terrace or the Peninsula hotel garden cafe and watch the river scene with barges and hotel ferry boats go by. Get away from busy Bangkok central shopping area and enjoy the lively bustling but yet relaxing scene

Great perspective to have of the city. It was easy to get around using the Chao Phraya River Tourist Express boat service and also to access other cheap boat services. The boats all offered exceptionally good value, for instance the day Tourist Express pass is approx £3, whilst single journeys were also cheap. Boats are operated efficiently, however until you have your bearings regarding where you want to get off its difficult to understand some of the conductor's announcements of where the boat is stopping and on one occasion the boat failed to stop for me.
life line of Bangkok. need to make a river cruise, sunrise or dawn, witness the life and commerce going on on and by the river, connect to major thai places. enjoy your life on bangkoks famous river
Loved it. Best way to see the area. Get on one of the hop on hop off tour boats and see all the temples in a day!

Recommend the night cruise. The cruise at night is well worth it. Lots of night lights and a great opportunity for some nice photos. The cruise aboard the chao praya river cruises boat, provides a nice all you can eat buffet, it could be served a touch hotter, as in temperature but overall very enjoyable, with entertainment also provided.

Well maintained. We did the canal tour in a private boat and river cruise for Asiatique. The most amazing thing to do in this river is feeding fish near Buddha temple. The size of fishes will surprise you as fishing is banned in this river.

I'd avoid the fish.... ... from this river should any be hardy enough to live in it. Flowing through Bangkok, the river bustles with taxis, barges and touring restaurant boats carrying (in our instance) horribly tone deaf Karaoke singers. Heading downstream from the Chatrium Hotel Riverside Bangkok, we sailed past some beautiful temples, witnessing Bangkok by night from the water, on a three hour return journey that gave a flavour of sites to be seen on a more relaxed and leisurely visit. Horribly polluted however, it's not one you'd want to have a swim in.

Must do it!!. One of the several nice things that Bangkok has to offer, the boat ride is nice and I would recommend that one does it during the evening and then maybe eat at one of the restaurants on the river front. The view is very nice and one can easily spend about 2-3 hours and not feel bored.

A must. A must to visit. From the river point of view you can have a good vision and idea about the city and the people life along the Chao Phraya. But it is sad to see a lot of garbage floating around...

A bustling River experience.. The River Chao Phraya really is a bustling, working river, with barges with long tows and up to 3 or 4 laden barges behind them on a long steel or rope tow, to busy restaurant boats and then the shuttle ferries taking people across the river to catch other transport systems such as the BTS Sky Train or just to get to hotels or other attractions on the other side of the river. Most boats go fairly frequently, but there can be a fair wait at times if you are wanting to catch a free ferry to a particular hotel or restaurant, as the service will be run by them themselves. The Peninsula has a reliable service running all day from early morning.

Nice river with nice night view. Just casually hop on to the local Chao Phraya River ferry which is cheap if you want to look at the river. Evening time will be the best. You can enjoy the view along the two sides of the river of Bangkok changing from daytime to night time.

Chao Phraya River Dinner Cruise. So much impressive dinner. The long historic story of the river is real interested. Also, it was very attractive to see the modern Bangkok Skyscrapers, mixed with the long story buildings/temples, all along the river. The Grand Palace is wonderful at night.

The only way to travel. Using the river as transport to get around is great !, buy a day ticket, jump on the boats ( they will display a yellow or blue flag ), and away you go, you can jump off any where along the way, to see places you would like to visit, Chinese flower market, Wat Arun, Wot Po, Grand Palace, etc, and then catch the next boat to go up or down the river, or just sit and watch the river traffic with an ice cream for an hour or two !, very relaxing.There are also the chance to have a cruise on the river with dinner and Thai dance shows.

I felt I am a traveller. Not so clean, not so beautiful, not calm, but i love this river. When I got on a boat, I felt I was a traveler. And I felt happiness and deeply understood I came back Bangkok.
Life on the water. A great way to see how life runs on the river is to catch the local water taxi, or get a long tail boat on the river and up the klongs to see how these people live.

Rice Barge Cruise. Went on the rice barge cruise on the river and also canals, great half day tour moving from very urban to seeing the more rural canal housing and lifestyle. Narrator knew her stuff there was lovely fruit platters and drinks also. Long live mango and sticky rice!

Good, but the ticket counters are cheat. I had used your boat serve on 14th March and I was robbed by the ticket counter lady at Sathorn.I had purchased a 40 Baht Single Trip Ticket and had given the lady 1000 Baht. The lady only returned 60 baht and stated I have given her only 100 Baht.I had requested her to check the Camera and she said there is no camera and please go. This is really not acceptable in any cash transaction place there no camera install. They should have camera installed in all places where cash transaction happens.I had tried to call the numbers mentioned on the ticket, however it was not getting connected.The security guard said "Sir, Leave it this happens all the time". So this is a known fact, So please be very careful while purchasing a ticket.
Boat tour. Took the Shangri-La Dinner Cruise. 2 hour cruise passing by a lot of interesting sights. Interesting boat traffic ranging from barges to speedboats to party boats. Fun to watch.

Don't fall in!. It is very impressive with excellent views of the Bangkok skyline, but I would hate to fall in, it is quite dirty. We got a tour of the canals where the local people live which was a real eye opener, and explains why you can't drink the water (the mains water pipes run along the surface of the canals) and have water monitor lizards living in them. But a really good experience.

Cheap!. A much cheaper way of getting around the city than taxi or tuk tuk. Skyscrapers and temple rooves line the river. It's interesting to see where and how the general population live on the river banks.
Boating at Phraya River. You can see the beautiful Bangkok during cruising on this.Cruise are available for Dining also.If you want separate boat, please bargain as much as u can

The real BKK!. As a foreign tourist you think about this River in a different way that some of the locals might perceive it. Of course that you can enjoy a meal, drink or even dinner on one of the various "bateaux parisienes" kind of boats but if eventually u decide to go on a sightseeing tour during daylight you can appreciate a different kind of atmosphere, where you can see locals with their captivating smiles rowing their artisanal boats, feed fish or more, absorb the fact that part of the city population is still struggling and that the gap between the rich and poor exists.

Its a beautiful sight to see the city while on the river cruise boat. Its the evening breeze and the grandeur of the palace and temples shimmering in the evening lights. The dinner on the cruise is not great and the place is crowded. The loud singing and dancing went overboard and did not like that part.
A must visit!. It's a must visit in especially for cruise dinner and cultural dance show in the evening. Also, can visit Asiatique nearby.
Cruise Dinner. Its just a cruise and romantic dinner with ur beloved...lovely evening just to dine together on the cruise..

A leisurely way to see Bangkok by the river.. Took the orange flag water bus after visiting Wat Pho and headed towards Saphan Tasksin. One way to see the river and sights and the locals computing on this river bus. It's runs frequently and only cost 15 bahts per trip. Try and do this just before sunset and when you arrive at Saphan Taskin change a free shuttle to visit Asiatique and spend an evening there. It's best to go after 5pm when all the shops and restaurants are open.

Use it for getting around (best at day). The ride is OK - nothing spectacular. Easy to get around depending on the attraction you need to go to. If you want to ride the river just to see the sights from the boat, your time is better spent on foot elsewhere if you do not have much time in Bangkok. At night, it is pleasant but you cannot see the few sights much except that it is lit up.

Enjoy a picturesque ride along the Chao Praya River!. Hopping on the (FREE!) boat ride from the Chatrium Riverside Hotel to the Saphan Thaksin pier is one of the added pleasures of holidaying in Bangkok! For Bangkok visitors who want to 'sample' top class restaurants at any of these 5-star hotels along the Chao Praya like the Millennium Hilton, Sheraton, Anantara - catching a free ride with their respective shuttle boats moored at the Saphan Thaksin pier is the best way to do it! "DO TRY I" - as a very famous tea ad goes!!!

Nice river that decongest traffic of Bangkok. This river helps decongest traffic in Bangkok. It's a short cut way going to important places in Bangkok. Nice view from the top of the hotel room where we stayed specifically in the Chinatown area.
Must experience the boat ride.. The boat operators were loud and obnoxious. Seems reckless to me most of the time but had a wonderful experience everyone should try, despite...

Quick travel. Take the skytrain to Saphan Tasksin and walk 5mins to the public ferry with the orange flag. Costs 15 baht per trip. Jump off at the Grand Palace and The Reclining Buddha. Many other stops too. Make sure you get off quickly or it will take off! A nice way to see sites. Beware of boat companies that try and charge tourists expensive trips. They will approach tou.

She irrigates the rice basin of Asia .. s gentle flowing river that flows into the gulf of Thailand. This gentle giant of a river help to irrigate all the rice land of the Thai Tibet delta, where most of the rice of Asia comes from. Boat trafic is busy in the day and I hope there will be better polution control so as this gentle but mighty giant will not be oxygen stave.

You must experience a river trip !. Hot, chaotic, noisy, unpleasant at times .. but fascinating, just experience the crazy busy river from a long boat or ferry, tourist boats go up and down continuously, but equally interesting and not so well known are the klongs or canals, along backwaters,which take you into an unseen part of Bangkok. Like being in the jungle! You barely know the skycrapers are there!

Busy waterway. The local ferry service is good and you can get on and off at so many of the main sights as well as getting a good view of many of them from the river. There are many hawkers selling expensive tours but if you are happy to stay on the main river then use the standard ferry.
Chao Phraya River Cruise. Cruise was excellent but food could have definitely been better. It was fun overall though. Standing on the deck with your loved one is an experience to savour.

Great way to spend an hour or two. We took a two hour tour that we paid 2000 bht for. The one hour does the same thing, but they just drive faster. We could have gotten off at Wat Arun, but decided not to as it was covered in scaffolding. We really enjoyed it. You see the good, the bad and the ugly. People will come up in their little boats to sell you stuff. We did buy some beers after the first hour at 100 bht each.
Lovely lazy hour on the river. We had a private boat (cost 1200 baht) to take us for an hour along the river and canals. Definitely a good way to see parts of the city you would ordinarily never see.

It has to be done!. On a budget with the kids and so we had researched how not to use the tourist boat and instead how to just get on a pay peanuts to get to Grand Palace on regular boat. Anyhow despite our research this did't happen we ended up on tourist boat haha. Shame as only a few stops down the river, but it has to be done. We got a tuk tuk back after, which was a blast.

Take a dinner boat cruise!. 4 of us took a dinner boat cruise on the river and was beyond beautiful. The food was amazing and the view of the city at sunset made the experience! Why not get an overview of the major city sights while eating a good meal ?
River Cruise. Very relaxing, crushing around the rivers of Bangkok, see some a among sites, and how some people live in this mad city

Amazing river. Fortunately, my hostel location near chao praya pier so going to grand palace is faster and easier using boat. The water noy clean but the goverment is maintaine the river as transportation!! U can see some bangkok life style from here too

Nice river. The Chao Phraya River has a variety of Boats plying this mighty River that Straddles Bangkok and the Nearby Provinces. there are the Chao Phraya Commuter Boats that transports you from one side to the other side of the river and to other bangkok klongs, the long tail boats, used mainly by tourists to tour and locals to haul supplies

Like other river is Asia.... I feel bad to put overall rating as Average. To somehow I enjoyed the Chao Phraya River trip by boat. Not once. But more than 3 times!I put title "Like other river in Asia..." to keep us aware of the important to keep the river clean. Sometimes we often forget that river is not a rubbish bin. No matter how small the ting that we throw to it. It will lessen the life of the river.It's a different way to look at Bangkok from Chao Phraya River.Think of the river long long time ago, before a foreigner like us wondering around there?Chao Phraya Trip is a must in Bangkok. When at the same time we can help Thailand to keep the river clean.Also other rivers in Asia :)
Great buffet. Travelers can enjoy the sumptuous buffet while travelling from Ayutthaya to Bangkok (cruise) via the Chao Phraya River.

Good way to spend the afternoon. We have done the river tour in the past but decided to go again. We paid 1000 BHT for 90 min for the 2 of us. We rode in the fast boat. Yes the river is smelly but we enjoyed seeing how the locals live. Must do once.
Chao Phraya River. Along this river, there is a few pier for transportation to opp side of the river.Visiting Temple along the bank of river. Cheap fare from 3baht onward (1way)
Mindblowing, Romantic. Dining on the cruise with really good music, good food and awesome view. A must visit place for all honeymooners

Very different form of Travel. On our second day in Bangkok, we decided to go to Grand Palace Bangkok via exploring the Chao Phraya River. We took the BTS train to Saphan Thaksin Station and then the express boat from Sathorn Pier to Pier Taj Maharaj. The journey was amazing with wonderful views from both sides. The journey was entertaining, the boat tourist guide shared the history of the various riverside buildings and their architecture.The river was busy with lots of boats, some for locals, and some for tourists. The journey definitely value for money and it was an enjoyable experience. I recommend this as an alternative mode of transportation to go to the China Town area, Flower Market, Wat Pho and Wat Arun.You buy the ticket from a small booth for the Express Boat service. You can buy single, one-way tickets, or a day pass. The day pass allows you to get on and off at any of the stops. But remember, by late afternoon the number of tourists returning to the BTS Saphan Thaksin stop is quite large and the boats soon become full of passengers.Overall, the journey experience was very good and was very different form of travel compared to the train or taxi in order to go to Grand Palace Bangkok.

Always my favourite!. We always do a river trip when we come to Bangkok. It is always the highlight of my trip to see the hustle and bustle of the Chao Phraya River. If its your first time definitely book a good tour guide in advance. You can also jump on the tourist boats just next to the Shangri-la hotel. They're like hop-on hop-off busses and will drop you at all the famous attractions along the river.

Best mode of transportation. Boats across Chao Phraya River are the best when it comes to transportation within the city- You can either go in for 15 Bhat ticket to each destination or 150 Bhat one day pass which is valid till about 6PM in Orange flag boats. If you are staying anywhere on the banks of the river- reaching the Temples, Grand Palace, China Town, Pak Khlong flower market are very easy if you take the boats- quick, safer & tension free compared to haggling with Taxi/ Tuk- Tuk guys.View of the modern buildings, ancient temples, Rama VIII bridge are fantastic- Boats can be a bit crowded, but that's the whole point- getting to experience a part of the actual Bangkok life!!

tranquille!. really what a beautiful way to cross the river than to use the river buses, so much charms! then this river gives you a quick look about some bangkok famous monuments and it will get you to ayuthaya another beautiful cruise! go of it, it a pleasurable experience!
One rude bull horn little lady, all else very chill. Nice way to inexpensively get to the Skytrain, Tha Taksin, from Tha Phra Arthit in Banglumpoo by Khao San Road.

Convenient means of transport. Just to be clear, the river per se doesn't have much to offer. It's so polluted, you don't want to touch it with a pole! Not much to see, so take that into consideration should you want a river side hotel.Nevertheless, it's still worth a ride from maybe Spahan Taksin to the last pier - about 40 minutes. More to gain an insight to the way locals travel and it's cheap.And, it's a convenient way to get to certain parts like Khao San or Chinatown. This is probably the only reason I can think of for staying at the riverside hotels.
JOY OF LIFE. Pick up the right tour operator so that you can enjoy the river trip. Make sure you don't travel when the boats is over crowded

Good way to explore one side of Bangkok. This river is one of the must see/do when exploring Bangkok. We were going to book for a nice dinner cruise but they're too expensive, prices starting from 1500 thb pp. We then figured that we could catch the BTS to Saphan Taksin (cost us 42 thb each from Siam) and then from there catch the tourist boat, pay the all day fee of 150 thb each. Done! The tourist boat stops at a few places along the river, and each stop will take you to certain tourist attraction, such as the Chinatown, the Wat Arun, Wat Pho, Grand Palace, etc. You can get off/on as much as you like. Catching the boat and BTS is definitely much better than catching the tuk2 smelling fumes. I'm glad we did this rather than the dinner cruise. Worth experiencing.

A nice river boat trip. I did a nice boat trip for about 1-1.5 hours boat trip by a long boat While doing so you can see some of the Temples (wats) in a quick view (some of the city tours offer the boat trip and the boat is taking you to the Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) that is now (May 2015) under construction.The trip gives you another glance of a cross Bangkok "city tour" in a fast forword mode
all day ticket-150 baht. hop on hop off river cruise for all day ticket...we didnt get to Asiatique as line was too long but would like to next time...

Alternative way to get around easily. Be sure to take the "express boat" and travel like a citizen if you are looking to save a few bucks! We didn't know better and ended up taking the 'tourist boat' on our way to Wang Lang and paid way more unnecessarily, unless you want to listen to the history of chao Phrya route (but we could hardly hear a thing with all the noise from the ride). Watch out and ask for the Orange flag boats.

Carnage . Boats are cramed full stations are mental busy its hope for the best when getting on boat as other boats bump in to each other continuously when boarding and you can quiet easily slip into river which very early happened to us over all great fun tho and great way to see the city

A must try. We used it on a daily tourist pass ...but would have been cheaper to pay per destination...Every one uses it to reach different temples ...keep a map with you to show and inquire accordingly...don't trust Pier staff ...ask locals and other tourists..Water of river highly polluted..

River boat trip. Paid for the all day ticket. Which meant you could get off at any point and get back on again or stay on and do the round trip, only 150 bhat for all day. Takes you up the river showing all sights on the way.

The other way to see the old Bangkok. Many tourists might know what Bangkok has to offer on the other side of the Chao Phraya river..and if you are going to Bangkok soon, you must take the tourist boat tour.. wherever your hotel might be, just take the nearest sky train or (BTS) and get off at Spahan Taksin station and there would go downstairs and a grab a ticket... you can hop on and off to many piers... you can go to the Thonburi side as well.. which is the other side of the river.... I hope you wouldn't be disappointed...

Alternative mode of transport . It's always packed Over carriage With rude piers staff But it's a very important mode of transport after BTSIt brings you to most of the major tourist spotsAnd it's a great experience after allA must visit I would say

Bangkok seen by a Chao Phraya river cruise is a must see.. If you like water and sight seeing the river cruises are so good. You see Bangkok from a totally different perspective ie the river houses perched precariously on bamboo poles.

Touristy but fun nonetheless. The river has long been a central artery in Bangkok and I believe it represents the ancient origins of the city, so it's interesting to cruise a small part of its length to see some of the Thai style houses and the teeming life that still abounds on its shores and the shores of some of the side canals. Sure, it's quite touristy and sure you will be pestered by vendors in small boats trying to sell you tacky, overpriced souvenirs but so what? A river cruise remains part of the sine qua non of the Bangkok experience.

Bangkok at its best. Jump on the cheap, fast and frequent ferries and cruise up and down the Chao Phraya to soak up the BKK sights, sounds, smells and lifestyle. Many attractions can be seen from the river and it gives one an opportunity to orientate themselves. Once you decide where you want to visit simply get off at the nearest ferry terminal. Easy!

Ideal way to avaid the traffic.. The tourist ship will cost you 40 Bhat for one way. And it has got 150 Bhat ticket you can hop on and off during the day. But it does not worth. Take 15 Bhat one way ticket each time for your destination. The minimum taxi cost is 35 Bhat in Bangkok and this is the cheapest way of traveling between the best attraction in the Bangkok.
woww. such a beautiful view.breathtaking.Espeically at night. after noons were quite hot but the night perfectly describes its beauty in a sophisticated manner.really want to go there again

Very good. Well stayed beside this river at Ibis.Enjoyed it very much.EvenING ride on the boat is very much recommended. Boat ride is comparativelying cheap and good for location of Grand palace,Wat pho Wat Arun Khao shan road and flower market.
River Cruise. Fantastic experience in the night with gentle breeze and charming scenery. It was great river cruise experience.

Chao Praya River Adventure. It's relaxing to just sit on our small private boat as our Thai Private Tour Guide TJ discusses the history of Bangkok and everything we see :)
Few minutes ride to rest our feet after the temple tours :)

The cruise is good.. If you have kids, this ChaoPhraya river cruise will be a fun thing to do. They have a good buffet, they have live karaoke singers onboard and it can be very entertaining.
There's options of various types for the cruises. Theres one cruise for mostly Indian travelers and they play Bollywood music. :p i didn't take it. :-pp

take a river cruise. a very good way to see Bangkok is by taking a river cruise
or just take the ferries and hop on & of at the various jetties

Fascinatiing view of life on the River. A 2 hour trip was far too short. Previously I had been on a half day trip around the Canals followed by a visit to a Orchard Farm. We then returned to Bangkok at sunset on a Barge on which there was a variety of Thai food amply washed down by a selection of local spirits.

A nice change from crazy Bangkok. We did a private boat tour which lasted about 45 minutes. Was a nice change from our crazy day in Bangkok. Interesting to cruise along some of the smaller canals. Especially to see how the driver steers his boat around turns. You gotta be sure to watch that.

The best way to see Thais at work and play. Some of the most stunning views of Bangkok are to be gained from a ferry boat on the Chao Phraya River. Buy a tourist ticket, which allows you to jump on and off the boat at the various key sites, and prepare to be stunned by flying dragon boats, packed commuter ferries and fishermen plying their trade. The buildings vary from the traditional and ancient to the modern and stylish and it's all so very relaxing. The ferries also have guides on board, who talk you through the various key sites, which can be very useful!

Water Taxi. do not take the tourist boat which charges 40bhat ( blue flag), however in this boat there is a lady speaking and informing about each stop. if you want save your money, take the orange flag boat (15bhat).

Interesting to see life along the river and canals. Our guide arranged for us to take a boat ride along the river and into many of the canals. Its amazing to see how people live along the river and canals. Everything happens along the river and people have made their lives there. Yes, the river and canals are dirty but I definately wasn't repulsed by what I saw.

Chao Phraya River Offers So Much and More. The Chao Phraya River that runs right through Bangkok is one of the first places I would begin exploring and touring. I have been to Bangkok many times and have a long way to go to explore the many waterfront restaurants, shops, monuments, Buddhist temples, churches, and other sites including a short walk to China Town. Take one the water taxis with a day pass to the many stops along the river, and simply enjoy the tour.

Lots of Fun!. Loss count of how many times we travelled up and down the river! Caught the boat up to see the Palace one day and it was far more interesting than getting the sky train or taxi! Really nice to chill out and enjoy the amazing views either side! Go past Wat Arun, china town and all sorts! Best way to travel if your visiting somewhere near the river! Came back later in the evening for a dinner cruise with White Orchid....amazing night! Views of the city at night are so beautiful!

Long nose boat . It was great felt a little vulnerable on the river but soon in the quieter canals .saw a tiny floating market and some if the temples .Such a nice way to experience some of Bangkok....so good I did it again

Greatest River in Thailand. Chao Phraya River is the water lifeblood river of Bangkok and so many communities in Thailand until the River runs out into the gulf. Beautiful River dinner cruises, water taxis, boat tours, so much to do on this beautiful river.

The River of Kings - spectacular!. The River of Kings - spectacular! This major river is well used with cargo, dinner cruises, public traffic, hotel boats, and personal boats cruising this winding river. I now live by the river so I thoroughly LOVE the Chao Phraya River!

Refreshing break. We discovered the river while travelling over in the Skytrain - a good way to sight see. Had a nice cruise up river and stopped at one of the piers not overcrowded. Plenty of different cruise style and boats.

good acces to Wat Arun Temple!!. Commontly river..not so big and clean but because in opposite there's a beautiful and historical temple name's Wat Arun so many tourist come to chao phraya accros the river using boad to the temple ( a good acces to there)....better go there with group the price for the boad more cheaper...

Cruise!. The Chao Phraya is a major river in Thailand, with its low alluvial plain forming the centre of the country. It flows through Bangkok and then into the Gulf of Thailand.Recommend to take express boat service

Beautiful edge to the City!. Several big boats taking you from the starting pier to the ending one and vice versa with stops at every pier in between. One way tickets are 40 Baht or you can take a day pass with unlimited boat trips at 150 Baht.It is the best way to see the City as you can get down at any pier to see that part of the city and re-board another boat ahead to the next pier. You can also take long tail boat and see around the floating village (at about 1000 Baht per head).
Simple way to see most attractions.. Just get one day pass or single ride ticket and you are on the way see a lot of attractions. When you buy tickets you get map with all points of attractions.

Small Group dinner cruise. My wife and I enjoyed a dinner cruise on the river with about 40 others from a conference we were attending in the city. It was a private boat. The buffet dinner was simple, but very good. The cruise was very relaxing and scenic. We went up the river in the daylight and returned to the port after dark, giving us two unique views of the city. April is a hot and humid time in Bangkok, but the breeze on the boat was very pleasant. The boat was very clean with a clean and functional "western style" toilet.

Good historical significance. There are several options for traveling along this river. There are the "tourist" boats for about 40 baht, which provide narration along the journey, and the commuter boats with no narration, but which cover the same areas for a lot less, and the long tail boats. The color of the river water reveals its filthy condition with debris, trash and other waste floating along the river edge, however if you keep your eyes above the water you will enjoy views of historic sites. Even saw a man standing in the filthy river, fishing.

Beautiful and unexpected escape from the city. Used the tourist river boat which was only 15 baht per person and took us 30 minutes up the river, where we saw the most amazing sights, temples amongst modern hotel skyscrapers. Manage to get off the boat and wander up into the streets and easily got back to the next boat , plenty of boats. Don't be pushed into taking private criuises which were expensive and would not give you the real experience of travelling like the locals.

Muddy cruise. I would not do it again. Once was enough. Yes, you can see some of famous tourist attractions from a different angle, but smell of dirty river and so-so service is not worth wasting your time.

Amazing experience. It's interesting to take BTS transfer boat to Asiatique the riverfront. The Asiaatique is a mall as JJ market, but it's more comfortable and smaller than JJ market. Many 5 stars hotel by the riverside, for example : four seasons, chatrium, Sheraton, etc. You might have one day tour there.

A different way to travel. I liked this river because it made us see Bangkok in a different way. One can buy a 150 Baht boat ticket (good for one day ) that would take you to the different sights and important places in Bangkok. The main ferry station nearest our Chatrium hotel is S. Taksin pier. One can buy tickets in all the piers.

Romantic boat ride. We took the skytrain to the river and then jumped on one of the ferries. If you take one that has a more leisurely trip down the river a guide lets you know what sights you are passing. Coming back we jumped on the locals mode of transport and it was fast. You have to be ready to disembark rather quickly as they only stop seconds at each jetty. Great way to see some of the out of the way sights.

Best way to see the sights and relax. Taking the tourist boat to the sights is a great way to avoid the crowds. You also get the bonus of a nice breeze to help keep you cool. The downside can be that the guide who explains what you are seeing is inaudible due to speaking too fast and the poor sound quality of the loud speakers.

Tourist trap. Just another tourist trap, another effort to milk the tourist of their wealth. The river tour is so commercialized & there are litters of operators everywhere, all with different price but offering the same lame cruise of the muddy water of Chao Phraya. The tour basically consists of a boat ride along the main river with nothing much to see, before detouring off to smaller canals where they will make a compulsory stop at a crocodile farm. There is a fee and if you decline, the operator will ask you to get back in the boat, and in a rude manner. One trap leads to another.. I guess that is the case with most "attractions" in Bangkok. What a way to blow some dough and waste a good 2 hours.

Exiting. You can use the river as a means of transport or relaxation and recreation.If you use the large bus type boats it is a quick and cheap means of travel just make sure you have a map and check where you want to get on and off or if you are not going anywhere you can just enjoy the views or you can just get off where you think looks good (careful not to get lost) then get the opposite boat back The Long Tail Boats are also very good but try not to go with a taxi driver or a tout as the price will be inflated and they will get commission go to a proper station There is one next to the Royal Orchid Sheraton you can get the taxi driver to take you there and say where you want to go and what you want to see these are for sightseeing and relaxation not really for transport.

The pulse that runs through the city.. Bangkok can be a pretty hectic city. The traffic, the crowds and all the surrounding activities can be overwhelming at times. It's great to be able to go to a restaurant, bar or hotel located on Chao Phraya river and relax. Sit back, enjoy your drink or meal and enjoy the boats going up and down the river, or better yet, go on one of the river boats and enjoy dinner and a drink on the boat and see the City like never before.You can't go to Bangkok and not experience Chao Phraya.

clean and famous tourist attraction for evening hangout. River Cruise is famous in tourists for sight seeing and dinner. Surrounding this river many of famous hotels are there. They have their private boat to enjoy nightlife of Bangkok. Asiatiqu river front market is best place and Temple of wat Arun are famous spots for enjoy evening with family.

Not quite the Kowloon ... but definately a site. Stayed at the Chatrium which overlooked the Chao Phraya River. River can be extremely busy and noisy with the amount of shuttle boats / cruise boats travelling up and down but it definately makes travelling to certain areas eg Chinatown, Flower Markets, Asiatique and Khao San more accessible!

A Trip to cool of. Get the ferry from Taskin pier.not much to see other then the muddy waters lots of boats and debris around,either side you will see Temples,hotels ad should you wan't to see the Palace,China town and little India,again you have the Sky train to get around cheap the use the taxi service

Great tour.. Get down from Saphan Taksin station to the river. 150 baht all day pass for the ferry to travel along the river. Service time 9.30-17.30. Although its very dirty ,but you can travel in the city without heavy traffic.There are 13 stops which includes to the China town , Grand palace , Wat pho and many more. Service time 15.30-19.00 free ride to Asiatique .

Great way to see Bankok. The best way to experience the river is trough a long boat that can take you trough the canals and see how the city interacts with the multiple waterways. A couple of hours can take you trough many intresting sites. River ferrys are also fun.

Great ride!. We love heading for the river and engaging a boat trip up and down the busy River and the canals that will remind you of places in Europe where people live and work right on the water. Lifeblood of the city without a doubt.

Good to have some fresh air. Good , way to get across town while being linked to some sky train stations. Enjoy a cheap trip and see the sights (such as the Wats).Take care when the river floods but apart from that it is a good experience. Stop off near the flower market and pick up a pack of fresh orchids ot take home!

great times. Get a river taxi day pass. What value for money, fantastic. You can get on and off at any pier. Recommend get off at last stop and check out khao San road then make your way back via the temples and grand palace. China town and the flower market a must see. Have a drink at Shangri la hotel to round off the trip.

good for run away from city traffic jam. it is very convenient to travel in the city through the river by boats and escape from heavy traffic.besides it is a great way to see the city landscapes.unfortunately some of its parts are dirty.

I recommend viewing the river at night. I recommend viewing the river at night through one of the dinner cruises; it's beautiful. We used WanFah dinner cruise and it was very good. The food was good and so was the traditional entertainment!

River of Kings. Chao Phraya is well named being a huge waterway cutting through Bangkok. Take the BTS to Saphan Taskin and look for the tourist boat, get a day pass and you can hop on and off at your leisure to take a look at many of the Bangkok treasures such as the Grand Palace or Wat Arun, get a guide book, the riverside is littered with places to see. For the shoppers take a free trip to Asistique a modern shopping outlet with food and usual attractions plus a reasonably sedate "gatoy" (ladyboy) show if entertainment is needed.

Nice way to see Bangkok. cheap price for the boat,really cheap, clean river altough the water are brown, but there's no garbage at all. Lot of tourism place near Chao Praya and it's really easy to go there. Oh, don't forget go to market near the pier, try to eat Phad Thai. Really yummy, and cheaaap :)

Easy thing to do and good way to see the city. It is a great way to see the city, the boat is quite packed so either wait to be first in line or get luck to stand on the rails outer sides of the boat so you can get a good view.
Boat on the river. This is cool transportation when you go to Bangkok. After you try plane, skytrain and bus you must try this boat. Cheap but cool.

Best river in Asia. I worked with Thailand for so many years but I never really realized that it had such a wonderful river. Now with the Skytrain serving the river area I could stay in a beautiful condo just facing the river and it was the best experience I had for years. Fat transportation.

A boats galore @ Phraya river. We (me and my wife) had gone to phraya river to catch a boat and visit few of the temples on its way. The river is good , but needs a bit of cleaning. Beautiful sight as you travel through the boat. Very cost effective.
Dirty River. Although the river was very dirty the Asiatic market was the best!The boats are very interesting and the river canals must be visited!The temples next to the river are a must see!

I felt like I was in a James Bond Film!. It is so much fun to travel up and down the Chao Praya river in any form of boat - you just have to do it. The river is absolutely buzzing with life - brilliant.

Great Views - Transport Lacking. Fascinating. An ever changing view of the old and new Bangkok. There were derelict shacks to the waters edge. A backdrop was the modern high-rise city buildings. Be warned about the boat on which we traveled. - Boarding was quite difficult. The roof was too low and caught many heads. Leg room was also at a premium. In summary, the sights were great but the transport was lacking.

Cheapest way to travel. Very convenient for the sky train and a trip up river costs about 20 - 40 THB. Stops at Wat Pho and The Golden Palace as well as Khao San Road.Great views of barges buildings and long tailed boats. Cruise with dinner I am told is worth doing.

Very good ride!!!. We booked the long wooden boat for 4 people and it was very good but costly, but the ride is very good we saw waterways which goes through the city, you will find some vedors selling the stuff on boats on the waterways but please bargain if you wish to buy anything.

FAst and furious. Get on one of the long boats that have the truck V8 engine and long prop shaft hanging over the back and hang on. Had several loverly dinner cruises along this river. Food and service on all was amazing, with plenty to eat.

Busy, Hectic but great.. Thoroughly recommend taking the local ferries up and down the river. You pass many sites, temples, hotels and Bangkok life. Large ferries wind their way along the river hauling sand or rice and are like slow dinosaurs. You can get on and off the ferries anywhere and experience something new. They are very cheap, and you can buy the tickets on board.

dirty water good for travel and go to flothing market. dirty water good for travel around the river, thar is boat evrey few minuts so you could get to the bts saphan taksin station in from thare continue, you could get with bot to china town, the grand palace, kaho san road, and a lot of other araes, thar is a lot of travel agents how will offer you a boat to f flothing market thay stay by the by the saphan taksin pier in by other pier,
Great in the evenings. We took a dinner cruise from the Banyon Tree which was briliant avoid the party boats they looked and sounded awful not traditional at all. Great way to spend an evening

A nice way to see the city. We have traveled the Chao Phraya river on the ferries a few times over the years, and it is a wonderful way to see the city and and the hustle & bustle of the waterways. You can either buy a day pass to allow all day travel on the blue flag tourist boat for THB150, or as we do and just jump on an orange flag boat for THB15 for each trip. Depends upon whether or not you want to jump off & on and explore some of Bangkok's sites, or just sit back and watch the action. Either way it's a cheap way to spend a day.
nice expirience. we wne to chao phraya river to take water taxi to wat arun,, the pier is quite old,,, but the staff on blue boat is quite entertaining..

The Water Taxi System is Impressive. I've been to Bangkok countless times and have never taken the Water Taxis! I realize this is unbelievable as they are so easy and convenient. I love the food stalls and markets at the piers and cruising with locals, other travelers, and monks on the river is so much more enjoyable than walking or taking a taxi or expensive took-tuk. Best Deal in Bangkok!!
Easy travel. Cheap easy to navigate and a lot of fun loved the ease of use and definitely way to get around would recommend to everyone to use

Great boat trip ridiculous price. We travelled on the water taxis all the way up and down the river
We got to see all of the sights that are viewable from the river and there are many of them
The total cost for two people 110 baht absolute steal for a 3 hour boat trip along an amazing stretch of water

An average river ride. The river is pretty dirty. That's obvious seeing the population of locals and tourists.There are two kinds of rides on the river at night. Ship/cruise with dinner & music , another is small personal boat ride,both take around 45 mins to-n-fro (both cost way too different, so choose wisely) When you book cruise make sure you are booking the upper deck of the ship. If its lower, its a complete waste. The view on the banks, hotels on both sides, glittering temples visible from the boat is nice. Be prepared to wait. Boats never start on designated time. Do take care of children and friends if you are travelling in a group. It is very crowded post evening when ferries depart. Cruise is costly foe a 45 minute ride and average food. The service and staff inside the boat although is good.
It's okay. Pleasant ride along the chao phraya river, but not as exciting as other reviewers seems to refer to.

Great way to see the Sites!. The Chao Phraya River is a great way to get around to some of the historic sites of Bangkok. There are many different boat options. We took a City tour boat where you buy a day pass for 150 Thai Bhat and hop on and hop off all day. We did this for awhile and visited some of the popular sites and then decided to just stay on and view the sites from the boat. This was the best part. The boat has a route and then turns around and does it again. I strongly recommend this. The river is busy and lively with all kinds of boats and it's a fun way to see parts of Bangkok. Excellent value for the money.

Great way to get perspective of city . Keep in mind you will see both extreme wealth and poverty as you use the boat system to get around. Easy access from a sky train stop. If you are going to get/on/off frequently paying the 150bhat might be the way to go. We just did one way and the used the smaller boats back (which was also an experience)

Cheap and pretty way to travel around Bangkok. Travelling by river boat in Bangkok is a really enjoyable and cheap experience. It would be beneficial to have a bit of an understanding about which pier you need to go to for each attraction, but once you've done one trip you will really get the hang of it. There are different coloured flagged boats that stop at different piers so check if they are going where you need to go before you get on. Single journeys usually cost around 40 BHT which is an insane concept if you come from London like us where tube fares are four times that for tiny journeys!

Alternative way to commute. Best way to reach the temples and Grand Palace when coming from the BTS Silom Line. However, the river is quite murky and smelly, and at busy times locals use the ferry too and language and conversations can be quite intimidating and difficult to understand.

Nice views of the old and new. Took a cruise down the river. There are lots of other small boats in and around at the same time. Water can be quite choppy. If you get sea sick, better take a pill (meclizine). Nice views of new and traditional Bangkok.
Its a boat. travelled along this by ferry boat a couple of days. Great way to see the city, the dock wasnt the easiest to find though

Sit back and enjoy. This river flows through the city although rather polluted. It is a bustling and exciting river that will take you anywhere you need to go,The Grand Palace is easily accessed from the river.Sit back and enjoy the view.

Saw a baby crocodile!. Negotiated a price (normally around 1000 baht/boat) to take a tour on the river to Taling Chan floating market and back. Goes through the canals and amazing to see the riverside life of how the people live in Bangkok. Well worth the trip! Only downside was that the driver wanted to go from A to B and wouldn't stop for us to take photos, except when we saw the baby crocodile! Top tip, take an umbrella! We had a sudden thunderstorm and got totally drenched ......

Beautiful views and easy transportation. Using the river for transportation is very easy and cheap. you have fantastic scenery and a night it is lit up from the many beautiful attractions that are along the bank.If you have chance, stay in a hotel on the riverbank like the Chatrium and use the waterways to get around.

The lifeblood of the city.. Bangkok moves at a slower pace on the river and sitting at one of the numerous hotel cafe's or bars and watching the river breath is one of lifes true pleasures. Recommend the Sheraton Royal Orchid for great views and good value!

What a River. This river flows like an artery through the city. It is a chaotic, bustling and exciting river that will take you anywhere you need to go in the city. There are water buses galore, tourist trips, long tail boat rides (brilliant) and great hotels situated along its shore. Not to be missed.
Handy view of Bangkok. Dirty and polluted, but a great way to get a view of Bangkok, and get around the historic parts of town.

Good River Cruise. We had taken a boat ride to visit the Grand Palace and the Wat Arun temple. Later we also had a two hour cruise on this river. very nice scenery on either side of the river. Worth a visit if you are in Bangkok. Best times to go in early morning or later in the evening during Summer.
Dinner on the river is a must. Nice meal, nice sightseeing and there was good entertainment, Thai dancers were very good. You can book a trip thru your hotel.

A great river. What's to say about one of the world's great rivers? Here you find the 2000 year history of Bangkok, and see countless interesting sights ranging from traditional river houses, great condos, river vendors, fantastic temples and the heart of drainage for the great Thai basin.My favorite is the day tour to The ancient Capitol. A nice boat ride and meal both ways makes a very enjoyable day. It is good to take a tour boat rather than ground transportation.

It's great evening out. River crucise is very enjoyable and fun evening out for couple or family. Good food lot of sight seeing and entertainment for every body.Don't miss out ! am sure you will enjoy it.

Interesting To Watch. I had a great view of the river from my room on the 19th floor of the Millineun Hilton. Lots of activity to see day and night. Very colorful boats navigate up and down the river providing a free show.

THE CANAL TOUR. Was really lucky for us to request this canal tour to our guide in Bangkok , we were taken to this river and enjoy the view of the canal and to see how the local people live around the canal area, Amizing experience.
Should coming back for this tour again !!

Evening River cruise with dinner on the chai prays Orincess. Took the two hour evening cruise, the boats are spotless, the service is great and the food was good, the river is a great place to relax and see the sights lit up at night!The food was very varies, good quality and was a help yourself buffet, the staff were very attentive and immediately filled yor glass with iced water as soon as it was ready, although there is a good bar onboardNice relaxing night out, good food, nice music, worth doing the cruise, to see Bangkok from a different perspective
Smelly but fun. Great way to see landmarks excellent value for money hop on and hop off. I couldn't really understand the map supplied however there are always other tourists or locals to ask

The lifeblood of the city. Getting on the river gives you a real feeling for the city and a cool breeze and all the hot hot days. Just observe life on shore, both ordinary and unusual. the long tail boats are an experience but only for tourists since they are too expensive for the citizens to enjoy. The luxury resorts offer good viewing of the river while enjoying a nice drink.

A different way to travel in and see the city. A totally unique experience to travel / commute with the locals. But take heed this is no tourist boat as a guided tour. One can travel quite far up-river for peanuts, and can take a quick look of the various temples on both sides.
Beautiful and nice looked river. The Chao Phraya river is a very good visiting point by enjoying ferry service and sight seeing. Many service providers offer boat service or cruise service.

impressive. i took a small motor boat along narrow lanes in the river for 1000TB, I think i could have paid less if I bargain a little, the boat ride is worth doing it one time to see around, I got a good look at the river banks and many temples

Night boat tour of the river. This is a fantastic evening with great entertainment, food and spectacular views along the river of all the temples, bridge and eye; the places get booked fast so get yourself organised.

A Guide to Boat services on the Chao Phraya. The BTS Skytrain provides transportation links between the newer parts of Bangkok. It does not extend to the older quarters where the river takes over as the major means of transport. Less than £1GBP will buy you a ticket that covers most of the popular tourist attractions. Due to the endless traffic jams on the roads I recommend the Skytrain and River boats over taxis every time.The various types of boat transport available and the reason for their different coloured flags are confusing for a first-time visitor to Bangkok. For that reason I hope that this review will help summarise the services available.The Thas or piers are numbered and have clear signage in English as well as Thai. The Central Pier (Pier 0 or CEN) is called Tha Sathorn and is next to the Saphan Taksin Skytrain station. Piers to the north of Central Pier are labelled ‘N’ followed by a number and piers to the south labelled ‘S’ followed by a number. The most popular tourist attractions are located between Central Pier (0) and N13 and the trip between the two takes about half an hour.List of major Piers and their associated tourist attractions:• N15 (Tha Thewet) – for Thewet plant and flower market• N14 (Tha Rama 8 Bridge) – for Rama VIII Bridge• N13 (Tha Phra Athit) – for Ratanakosin Island • N12 (Tha Phra Pin Klao) – for Klong Bangkok Noi and Museum of Royal Barges• N11 (Tha Railway Station) – for Bangkok Noi (Thonburi) train station• N10 (Tha Wang Lang) – for Siriraj Hospital and Medical and Pathological Museums• N9 (Tha Chang) – for Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaeo (Temple of the Emerald Buddha)• N8 (Tha Tien) – for Wat Pho (Temple of the Reclining Buddha) and cross-river ferry to Wat Arun (Temple of the Dawn)• N7 (Tha Rajinee) – for Chinatown vegetable market and cross-river ferry to old Portuguese Quarter• N6 (Tha Memorial Bridge) – for Phra Poklao Bridge and Chinatown• N5 (Tha Rachawongse) – for Chinatown• N4 (Tha Marine Department) – for River city shopping, Holy Rosary Church and Royal Orchid Sheraton Hotel• N3 (Tha Si Phraya) – for Portuguese Embassy• N2 (Tha Wat Muang Kae) – for Old Customs House and GPO building• N1 (Tha Oriental) – for Oriental Hotel and O.P. Place shopping• Central Pier (Tha Sathorn) – for Saphan Taksin Skytrain stationExpress Boat ServicesThese serve different routes and are identified by coloured flags. Not all services stop at all piers and different services end at different times of the day. Check the route map to see which coloured flag boat calls at which Pier number. When on the boat, move to the front. Protocol suggests that the rear is reserved for people wishing to get off at the next stop.Tourist BoatsThese are more expensive but are less crowded and there is also an on-board commentary in English to highlight POIs. A one-day unlimited ticket costs 150 THB (£3GBP) or 30 THB (£0.60p GBP) for single journeys. The service runs every 30 minutes from 09.30-16.00Orange flag boats cost 15 THB (pay on boat) and run daily every 15 minutes from 06.00-19.00 between Nonthaburi (N30) – Wat Rajsingkorn (S3)Green flag boats cost up to 32 THB (pay on boat) – charged according to distance of travel) and run every 15-20 minutes Monday-Friday 06.15-08.10 and 15.30-18.05 between Pakkred (N33) – Nonthaburi (N30) – Sathorn (Central Pier)Yellow flag boats cost 30 THB (pay on boat) – charged according to distance of travel) and run every 30 minutes Monday-Friday 06.15-08.30 and 15.30-20.00 between Nonthaburi (N30) – Sathorn (Central Pier) – Ratburana (S4)Local or Standard boats (no flag) cost up to 14 THB (pay on boat) – charged according to distance of travel and run every 20 minutes Monday-Friday 06.20-08.05 and 15.00-17.30 between Nonthaburi (N30) – Wat Rajsingkorn (S3)Hotel shuttle boatsCross the river continuously between the major riverside hotels including The Oriental, The Peninsula and the Bangkok Marriott & Spa. Most boats are free and run to and from the Central Pier (Tha Sathorn)Cross river ferriesAre available at most piers for crossings to the opposite bank. Fare: 2-4 THB (usually paid on Pier)

must take a boat ride!!!. Taking a boat ride to go sightseeing 2 sides of Chao Phraya river should be an unforgetable memory when travel to Bangkok. You can stop at boat piers to visit some famous religion pagoda such as Wat Arun, Wat Pho, Grand Palace, etc, and can see daily activities of local people living in river bank. It's so easy to go to boat pier, take BTS, then stop at Saphan Thaskin, you can see centrel pier immediately. Take the yellow line boat, just cost only 15Bath. If you buy tourist boat, it's cost 150Bath, you can have a tour guide who give you some information about attractions around the pier you stop, but in my opinion, it's not worthly. Whatever you chose, i highly recommand you to join this boat tour!!!!

River Cruise along the river. There are many choices of cruises at Chao Phraya River and most of them is buffet. I took the cruise without the buffet as i am not one big eater. I really just wanted to witness the spectular view of all the architects built along the river. So, i went for the cruise that offer an ala-carte dinner. The price was reasonable and the food was great as well. As you indulge into the local delicacies you can enjoy the spectular views of all the temples. They seem to glow like glittering gold at night. Only one word to describe....spechless

Venice of the East. Take a trip down the river after visiting the Palace. You will get another great perspective on the city. Amazing photo opportunities and the ride is also another quick way to see and feel how the locals travel.

Pleasant Surprise. My fiancee and I tried to visit the Grand Royal Palace on Sunday, and much to our disappointment, we arrived at 3:40PM, and the palace grounds closed at 3:30PM. What luck. After walking up to the entrance, a very friendly police officer started talking to us, asking where we were from and what we had done in Bangkok so far. He then told us that we want to go see the river, and spoke to a local walking by instructing him (in Thai) to take us to the river boats.This was a little strange to us, but we wanted to see the river, so we followed the local. He was very nice, and stopped every time we fell behind. We then approached a market where he told us to follow him, that the river is inside. We both looked at each other a little bit confused, wondering if this was a translation issue or even a scam. But our guide lead us straight up to a tour desk and told us to have fun. What a nice guy!Anyways, a lady at the counter talked us into an hour tour around the Chao Phraya River so that we can see the floating market, and all of the surrounding temples and locals. The tour cost about $70 all together, but we figured it was a must see in order to experience all of Bangkok. Plus we were exhausted from negotiating at the weekend market earlier in the day. So we signed up, she gave us each a loaf of bread to feed the fish, and a drink for the road. We were then rushed to the doc where we got our own private gondola! We were still a little bit confused about the whirlwind that went on, and how we got our own boat, but the ride was so much fun. We saw so many sights that we can only experience on the water. I bought a little Thai fan from the floating market, we fed thousands of catfish, were squirted by children with squirt guns, and even waved to a few young monks. We took tons of photos and giggled the whole way how we stumbled on this little gem.For more tips on Bangkok, and more travel, visit andivance.com . I post reviews of many attractions and cities we visit :)

Cheap fare and travel in Bangkok by river. We took a river taxi from Sathun to Pier 9 Ta Chang and it's cost us just 15bath person. I did enjoy the ride and view. We were here on dinner cruise 2 day before and the boat give us a tour around the river. It was nice to see the place by the river by day and night. I really enjoy the ride so much

Be careful. We walked from our hotel to the Sathorn pier really straight forward paid at one kiosk and got on to get off at the Thai pier which is for the Grand Palace. 200 baht no problem. We then came back for the return and it was complete chaos groups taking precedence private hire taking presidence and the tourist police were sorry, useless. All it needed was two signs one 'public service' in Thai the other groups. We asked for public service were pointed to the Jetty the Police said push through the queue, we did the boat staff ignored us the organisers ignored us wouldnt even look at us, they both got vocally told thank you. And the group guide who tried to push me out of the way won't do again.So if you want to do it privately go the one way, walk a bit back to where you came from and then get a Turk tuk or taxi.Thailand tourist board you are killing that with groups organise more money better visit ie loads of stalls right off the pier adds to the chaos put them on the grass outside the palace more space more time more fiancé.

Chao Phraya River--be sure you take a ride on it.. Any trip to Bangkok must involve this grest river. It flows through the city and visitors will cross it via many bridges. The river is close to the Grand Palace and Wat Arun. One river-based treat i like to take is to ride a waterbus. These go up and down the river just like land busses. They are a very inexpensive way to see the city from the river--more "local" that the tourist-laden cruises. The river is always active and busy. There's lots of barges going down river heavily laden with rice and going back up empty--note the difference in how low the full ones are in the water. You can use the river as a base for trips to the floating market of for trips on the powerful Thai river boats (I forget the name).

No place like a river taxi. Wonderful transportation of the river! The river taxi is not expensive, and it has free shuttle to Asiatique... very brilliant and it's one of the unique transportation of Thailand that I would very much like them to preserve!

A River that Smells Thai. One of the must-sees in Bangkok. Not to mention the bazaars and shops dotting the banks, a quick simple yet breezy ferry ride and a two-hour cruise tour would definitely make it a worthy trip. Brilliant nightview and nice assortment of buffet dishes. Kids love eating on the deck. Hiring a taxi back to hotel can be challenging. Better go to the adjacent Sheraton and drivers at the drop-off point are very kind and not marking up the fee.
A different view of Bangkok. An excellent way to see Bangkok from a different angle and would highly recommend, perhaps combined with a cruise along the Klong (canals) of Bangkok.
Nice breeze. First of all, the ticket is very cheap. By that ticket you can cruise around Bangkok which is a great experience. But a little bit too crowded.

Great ferry ride.. I rode the water ferry several times from the BTS stop bought a day pass for 130 Baht got on and off many places, many sights to see from there, and interesting ferry boats. Stop # 30, end of the system has a floating restaurant with excellent food very inexpensive.
Manohra river cruise. A brilliant experience on a full moon night , saw the lunar eclipse while dining on board. Most recommended

Great day out on the river. Using the river in Bangkok is a great way to get around.We always use the public boat and not the tourist boat as it is cheaper and just as good.You can jump of at different piers to visit temples etc., The full journey to the last pier takes about an hour and is a good way to see lots and relax.

Landmark of bangkok. Just sitting inside the express boat to go around some temples or khaosan road in bangkok, we can see the beautiful of chao phraya river. Even this river isn't clean, but seeing the scenery around is very interesting.

day trip on the river. try the river trip with traditional boat. by the end of the trip you may find some local culinary. Some advise for those who consume "halal food" only, ask the vendor first if the food contain pork.

15 baht ferry. spending time floating down the river in the local 15 baht ferry allows you a different perspective of Bangkok- peaceful and calm, crowded and chaotic- depending on when you go! Easier (and cheaper) way to get from one end of the city to the other

Rolling down a River...... Take BTS to Sapan Taksin river ferry station and then get off at Khao San rd. exit station.One of the most enchanting dreamy river boat rides for me to share with you.I have been taking this ride for over 30 years and its always a travelers treat.Passes by old Thai navy gun boats right out of' The SandPipers' moored on the Chao Phraya river. River ride boat view of' the Temple of Dawn.. Wat Arun'.The old East India Company trading center where Rudyard Kipling must have visited.The charming 'Oriental Hotel 'where Marlon Brando stayed while making 'The Ugly American'.Just oozing with old romantic Bangkok charm.Put this adventure on your must fly list. Great fun take your camera!

Relax and avoid traffic. A great way to visit some of the best shopping areas or just a great way to visit historic sites. This is a a very relaxing way to see Bangkok. A visit to the floating market or to visit the king's barges..all without the hustle and bustle of Thailand's traffic.

Holy River and Canals….. Awesome. Thought this would be nickel and dime but connected to another tour so did it… Took so many photos and those narrow bullet boats are just awesome to ride in,,, they don't over speed but they could easily be in a James Bond Movie,,, V-8's, Water jet powered, they watch for the oncoming waves and slow down so don't get nervous sailors… Life in those canals for people another world,,, Loved it as much as the Wat, so surprised… The kids will even enjoy when they stop at a big pier and the monks sell pieces of bread, pennies, to break up and feed the giant catfish that come right up to the surface… Good clean fun…. Watch close along the banks of the canals,,, people harvesting greens and putting in nets for fish, up to their chests in water…. Sit back and relax….Rollin on the river…...

Bangkok's breath. take a ferry (speedboat) just before sunset and have a ride. it's cheap and charming. Bangkok reveals itself in all its beauty along the sweet Chao Praya. And it,s also the best way to move from Khao san road (Pra Athit) to Taksin Bridge, Silom, Chinatown.

Uninspiring. We took a three hour cruise down this river from Ayutthaya area. I did not find the trip down the river to be exceptional in any way. It might have been nice to sit out on the front deck enjoying just the ride but it was way too hot to do so. Also, inside the cabin was not air conditioned very well and was stifling. I would not opt to do this again.

Lovely on a hot day!. There is a public transport system on the river which is great value for money and worth riding because its a good ride and a cool breeze which you don't often get in Bangkok except from a fan. I don't recommend swimming in this river but you can get to some interesting places on this boat such as the museum at the university and an interesting market.

Busy busy busy. We did a cruise, having gone out to the old capital on a coach tour. The return journey by river was very relaxing and comfortable on a hot day. Also used the local boats to get too and from the Grand Palace. Need to be quick getting on and off and pay on the boat. Very cheap form of transport.
TAKE A RIVER CRUISE. A great way to see Bangkok is to take a ride on this mighty river which you can access from the many hotels that line its banks.

You can watch it for hours. And you will notice how it changes constantly.First of all select a hotel on the river, making sure you have a high viewpoint. Then start watching the traffic on this water motorway, it never stops.Big barges, small and fast boats, shuttles and tourist ships, commercial traffic, lights and music, you name it.Of course you have a different viewpoint from the water, definitely the best experience, but also a high view will give you enough to watch.

Good to Go. I read many reviews on the boat rides and know that I should take the orange boat ride but what I never read was there are 2 sides of the orange boat ride. 1 side towards Asiatique and the other towards another side.We took the wrong side and ended up the other side. Cannot remember which stop but we got off and had great noodles there.The boat ride seemed much better than khlong (much cleaner) and you get to see a lot of locals and even tourist taking the rides. There are a lot of restaurants and bars along the river.Overall it is worth a try! Something that kids will be amazed with cos you will have seawater splashing on your face - not going to drench you through those kind... the boat seemed old and going to break anytime but I guess that how all those traditional wooden boats are.
Ferry Delight. For a view of everyday life get the local ferry with the day ticket ,good value and all the main historic sites are accessable

a very interesting 2-hour tour by boat. We rented a small boat for a 2-hour tour of the river of of the side canals. It is a very interesting tour. That enables seeing house on these canals, temples, new hotels, etc.The river is very polluted, and I assume that mosquitoes are a problem at certain moments of the year.The tour itself was really interesting; but you have to negotiate the price, which will depend on many things. We took our boat from a small pier next to the Mandarin Oriental.

Vein of Bangkok. I think this lactation shall be the most beautiful landmark of the world and Bangkok, any way you can see the river that is the vein of this city than you can seek somewhere to eating and drinks at meantime.

Brillant!!!!. My 10 yr old son and I got a tuk tuk from our hotel, the Siam@siam. The driver took us everywhere for the whole day for only 200 baht. One of the places was to the river in Bangkok. He took us down an alley to a makeshift wharf and we boarded a long boat with the driver a local thai lady. For 2000 baht we had a 1 1/2 hour boat ride along the river, through the canals where we saw thai villages, floating markets and stopped for 20 mins at a temple. It was a steaming hot day, they gave us water, slowed down in places so we could take photos and pointed out landmarks. Our hotel was trying to sell us the same experience for 7000 baht. It was brillant!!!!

Lifeline and main street. Travel up and down the river is so easy and ordinary it is almost underwhelming. You can be packed in with locals, tourists, students, and professionals. Of course the river is also a working waterway with tug boats pushing barges, and ferries hauling folks from one side to the other. It has a swift current and teems with fish near the docks where the temple feed them and no one can fish for them.

awesome. as the sun sets the view of this river changes drastically.. cool wind, river waves, boat rides and the lighted city all around.. a journey beyond words..u can enjoy the river taxi or dinner cruise available with plenty of service providers.. cruises are for all sorts of budget but bookings need to be made early.. from saphan taksin u get free cruise to asiatique river front, river taxi as well the dinner cruises..grand palace and wat pho looks gorgeous at night from the river..if you are with your loved ones then this river is the best place to spend an evening in bangkok.

Chose your tour company carefully.. Many tour groups operate river cruises. Some are much better than others. This time we went on a long tail boat tour with another couple. The sights we saw were worth the money but the guide/captains English was very limited & his repertoire consisted of 'Temple!' & 'Tip!!'..We left from a small pier a little way up from the Sheraton & disembarked at The Grand Palace.Be Very aware of aggressive touts (even dressed as police) and tuktuk drivers that are hell bent on trying to take you to shoddy tailors.

Good way to travel but was ripped off. We caught the sky train to Sathorn, we wanted to catch the tourist taxi boat (blue colour), having reviewed the prices before hand we wanted an all day hop on hop off ticket for 150 baht. I handed the 300baht to the cashier who gave me the two tickets. We travelled to the grand palace. On getting back on the boat i was asked to pay again only to discover i had been given two one way tickets worth 40 baht each. The guides on the boat did question this with the cashier at Sathorn who misteriously failed to admit her swindling ways, okay i know its not much money but they dont call Bangkok 'rip off city' for nothing.

Unique transportation. I was staying a bit farther down the river from the Palace and many of the other big tourist areas, so I frequently used the ferry to go up and down the river. It was very cheap and for some reason I thought it was the most enjoyable form of public transportation in Bangkok, maybe just because it was different than anything I've experienced before. It felt like riding in a public bus in any other city, but on the river instead. The views were very nice. I felt like I got all of the scenery of a river tour just on my daily commute. I'd definitely recommend the ferries as a good way to get around town.

Great river to get around on. This is a really convenient river to travel on. We loved taking the water taxi to our destinations. It's also a nice river to sit at a restaurant next to and enjoy some good Thai food and conversation.

A great way to explore Bangkok. Water Taxi is cheapest and fastest way to get up and down the Chao Praya river - 15bhat anywhere.
