Unfortunately the only negative part of this River is that it provides an outlet to the city's drains who unabashedly discharge all their filth into it. The dirty water has to be seen.We took the 40 Baht one way ticket to travel by the express tourist ferry from Saphan Taksin to Wat Pho (7th stop), from where we took the ferry across the river (3 Baht) to Wat Arun, which unfortunately was under renovation and could not be seen at close quarters. The 3 baht ferry is a pretty basic one which only has to continuously ferry people from one side of the river to the other side and back, but as I said before, is a part of Bangkok's lifeline.Anyhow, this review is about the river, so I will not dwell much more, except to say that on our way back we took the normal ferry which charged us only 15 Baht. Its only disadvantage was that it stopped on each pier stop, made a lot of noise and there was no commentary which the express 40 baht ferry gives.This transportation cost is much more economical than any other form of travel, with the added advantage of being free from traffic jams, pollution and gets you to your destination much faster than if you had to travel on the same route by road.It also affords you the luxury of passing by Chinatown and the many hotels such as Peninsula who adorn its banks. It also gives you the added attraction of a dinner cruise, but more of that at a later time.This is certainly one of the highlights of Bangkok which is not to be missed at any cost.
Back waters cruise. I loved ruding in a long tail boat around the back water off of the chao phraya river. Our boatman was great and its so interesting to see the houses and life along the river

Easy way to see many sites. We rented a private boat at the pier for 1300baht for 90 minutes. We just ventured up and back again without touring any of the canals. It was a great way to see some of the major sites, but the ride itself wasn't great as termites swarmed all around us and we got splashed a few times with the river water. Glad I ticked the box, but wouldn't go out of my way to travel the river again, especially with young kids.

Take a river taxi from the Grand Palace to the Oriental Hotel -. Great taste of the river scene and not the expensive cruise alternative. Walk straight down from the Grand Palace, through the hawker stalls and to the ferry. The Oriental is about 7 stops and the journey takes around 30 minutes. THB40 flat rate or buy a day pass. It is a marvel how some of the buildings are still standing!

The best of Bangkok is the Chao Phraya. For me the river is the best part of life in Bangkok, whether that means travelling by river boat or just gazing at the intense, but mostly silent, passage of river traffic. I chope a mid-market hotel (a step up from what i'm usually willing to pay) just so I could sit day- (or night-) dreaming on the terrace overlooking tne river. A respite from the chaotic din of street traffic, but alive and active at all hours, the majestic Chao Phraya is the place to be.

Dirty river in the heart of Bangkok. What do you expect a river to look like when it runs through a centre like Bangkok?? It cant help to be anything but filty, brown muck that you wouldnt want to fall into let alone swim in!! The views from the river are great and the construction and industry is abound. Worth a look but not if you want to see pristine waters.

Great to enjoy a ride at the ferry. Its fun n relax to go from Bts taksin station. To take the ferry to a few stops can be by orie tal hotel, or by the flower market as the view is nice and as well don't be shy to talk to locals many speak a little bit English and they are lovely people.

Beautiful at night. I took white orchid dinner cruise. It was so much fun. I really love the ambience. You can see grand palace, etc while you eat your dinner. You can take a photos in front of Rama Bridge, it so beautiful at night.

Good way to travel around. yOu don't have to line up long to get onto a ferry and it's a good way to see some of the sights you don't hear about on the way to the temples and markets, easily accessible by BTS skytrain and cheap for an all day ticket.

It is worth one time visit. One boat trip is 40 Baht, so you can decide how many stops you need to go and based on that you can go for this or the day pass 150 Baht, which is valid only from N1- N13 pier and till 7:30 pm.River is not very clean, with drains and old wooden houses too on the line of new infrastructure. This is the most easiest way to reach Grand palace, Wat Pho and Wat Arun.You can give it a try once.

One of the place must visit. The Chao Phraya River also named Mei Nam, the landmark of Bangkok. The better way to visit is buy a boat ticket at Saphan Taksin BTS station with 9 piers stop to see the different place of the river embankments. The golden Buddha and the Palace are located at the pier stop easier.

Stay at a riverside hotel. For some great views of the Chao Phraya river in Bangkok you should stay at one of the many hotels alongside the river, making sure you have a room with a river view! Our choice would be the Millenium Hilton Hotel, but other options would be The Peninsular Hotel, the Sheraton and the Shangri-La. All these hotels have their own complimentary river boats to take you across the river, and connect to public ferries, and the sky train. They also have riverside terraces, restaurants and bars. Watching life on the river is fascinating - the long- tail boats whizzing by, the hotel boats that look like little houses with twinkly lights outlining their roofs, the passenger ferries carrying the locals to work or shopping, the large dinner cruise launches with their onboard chefs and musicians, and the huge, dark barges with their mysterious loads hidden by tarpaulin, being towed by little tug- boats. You will be entranced!

Wat Arun stretch of the river. We walked a little of the river opposite Wat Arun, which was quite nice. We then went to the small port where you can get a boat across the river for 2-3baht, which was also veey good and provided for some great views without the expense of a tour.

Thames of Thailand.... It gives the feeling of Thames of Thailand... It gets more beautiful when the sun sets! Take the boat service on the river to have the real fun... The view of Wat Arun by the river in the evening is an unmatching experience...

The Cheapest way to tour the Chao Phyraya River. We have been to Bangkok numerous times and always like to do something different. This trip we went down to Central pier at around 5.00 pm and jumped on a local ferry. The conductor asked "where you go" we said to the end. Ok 20 Baht, so off we went with all the locals. the Ferry get along at a good pace and only stops if people want to get off or on. So an hour and 20 mins later we were a long way down the river with no sign of turning around. We asked the conductor does this ferry go back to Bangkok. He said "No have to catch another one I tell you when" . A couple of stops later he said "You catch this one as wel moored there was another ferry on the next wharf ready to go. So we jumped off and on to the other boat. The conductor came over after about half an hour and asked for 15 Baht to Central pier. It was now dark so the river boats, temples and bridges were all lit up and looking amazing. So daytime photos on the way up and nighttime shots on the way back. What a great way to see this majestic river and surrounds ,three hours all for 70 Baht for two people great value.

Loved this. We really enjoy the river experiences anywhere, and this was no different. Really enjoyed the boar trip and evening stroll here. There are several companies offering boat trips and there are enough eating places around. Do take time out for a stroll around.

enter or life. it is a must to navigate the river, to understand how quintessential it has been to the life in Thailand. if you can, take long boats, use ferry for public transportation, navigate upstream to Ayutthaya, look at the houses, floating restaurants, floating docks, and take a detour to the flower market.

The boat trips fantastic and cheap. It is a beautiful day in December, and you can see a lot of scenary.
The keep the river very clean, removing kelp and trash all the time.
It's like a clean taxi on water, and you can ride the skytrain to there, and then take the river boat to all the temples

Seeing the real babgkok. For a cheap return ticket the local ferry calling at various points is a must but also an important mode of transport for the locals.. Crowded but what major city transport system isn't but plenty of atmosphere. Great to see the busy river life and the shanty building along the banks.

Well worth a trip on the river, but go the whole route and don't take the tourist boat!. The Chao Praya river cuts Bangkok in two, and is pretty big. It's also pretty dirty, so don't fall in!There are evening dinner cruises, but as an 11 year resident of Bangkok, I don't fall into the tourist traps. More information on these expensive (and often short) dinner cruises here - http://goo.gl/maps/sn2o5Then there's the tourist version of the river taxi here with a good map - http://www.chaophrayaexpressboat.com/en/tourist/This is all very well if you ARE a tourist and just want to see the main sites, but be warned, it only covers a short stretch of the main river taxi route, from Central pier neat Saphan Thaksin BTS station (soon to be obsolete and closed) to Phra Athit pier (Khaosan Road). It's also expensive at about 40 baht compared to 15 baht anywhere on the normal boat. See the website and map referred to above.Far better, in my opinion, is to get the normal orange flagged boat from Central Pier all the way to Nonthaburi pier (Ta nam Non) and have your camera ready - there's loads to se, but be warned, it will get very full and if you are on the wrong side of the boat some of the best sights can be obscured.When you get off at Nonthaburi, which is NOT one of the nicest towns in the area, you can walk about half a mile to the market, if you don't mind the smell and the chickens cut in half showing their eggs in various stages of development ... It's also a very crowded footpath to the market.And of course, you can get off at any stop, and mooch about - do some research first, of course. At 15 baht a ticket any distance, it's one of the cheapest ways to get about and also a good way to fill in a day.

The Heart of Bangkok. Can't miss it. The main artery, full of great variety, people and traditions. Try doing it slowly on a converted rice barrage. Then on a high speed longtail boat. One of the reasons for going to Bangkok. Has everything from markets, hotels and restaurants on its shore.

Good outing for river cruize. After whole day of hard work dinner in a traditional boat with traditional Thai food was excellent. The river is apparently clean in comparison to many Asian rivers. Third gender people danced in the boat with traditional music.

Chao Phraya River. City River is impossible to see in my city. We took river ride and even though it look dirty but its not smelly. That's a good sign it's not dirty. The River ride is awesome because it get you to fantastic places near the river. -regular pay is 15thb-special is 100thb unlimited for those going in a tour-boats are all clean
The river is nice. The river is very dirty I wouldn't want to touch the water for fear of sickness. Lots of cool tour boats though I would recommend taking a long boat tour

Get the best out of the river. Used it for getting from Sukhumvit hotel to the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. Skytrain to Saphin Taksin and find the ferry landing underneath. Cuts travelling time to a lot of places. Fast, cheap, frequent.

Once the heart beat of the city. Take a ferry, only a few baht, on this busy river and replace the noise a grim of the street for a different noise and grime. The air blowing by is refreshing and cooling and you see a lot. Simon Tarascon
Take a river boat trip. This is a fun way to get around. For sites near the river, it is a very worthwhile way to go. It is very popular with locals as well as visitors.

A window to life in Bangkok. As we were staying at the Shangri-La Hotel, which is situated on the banks of the Chao Phraya river, we were often in close proximity, whether relaxing in our hotel or travelling on it.Our hotel balcony overlooked the river & we often just spent time observing life acted out below; whether it was watching one of the many vessels en route to its destination, or at one point, watching an elephant bathing! Staying so close to Central Pier, we took the express tourist boat down the river to visit Wat Arun. You can buy a single ticket @ 30 baht each way or a day pass @ 150 baht each which is great value if you intend stopping at more than one pier. They are easy to use & they have commentary on board so you know what you're seeing along the way & of course, where to get off. You can, if preferred, pay for a boat taxi to take you wherever you wish to go.There are also evening dinner cruises down the river, which we did on our 1st visit to Bangkok some years ago through the same hotel & which showed us the City lit up at night.

Stay upwind of boat spray. The river is great way to get about and costs 16THB using normal river boats for Thais and not TOURIST boat unless you know you will spend most of day on and off boat which is then cost effective.

Daytime trip worth the fee. For $15 US the "get on, get off" ferry service is a great way to see the sights along the river, while getting off at one of several temples to tour. Get back on and see the next sight. Each stop seemed to have its own gauntlet of food and souvenir vendors waiting for ferry passengers as they boarded or disembarked, a colorful and chaotic scene not to miss. Unfortunately, lunch at stop #8 was less than good.

Good way to see some sights of Bangkok in a different way. . We decided to take the Chao Phraya River Express boats for the day to see the sights around the river in a different way. The day pass was 150 baht each and we felt we got good value from it moving up and down the river. The boats were safe and well run and we had a nice walk exploring around Khao San Road from one pier which was great. Make sure you take a good map (or the trip advisor bangkok guide app that includes a great offline street map).The river was bustling with boats and goods and we loved it.
Dance, Dinner & fun.. all in one... Nice voyage on the cruise.. evening gala dinner with live music was wonderful.. Foul smell from river was a negative..

With a long tail boat through the small side arms of the river. As a lover of long tail boats it is always a must for me to rent one and recommend the driver to drive slowly through small side arms of the river. You see the life of the locals, you encountre old womans in there small rowing boats selling all sorts of stuff, from food to daily nesesities and of course souveniers. Take an hour or two, you will remember it

USE FERRIES. Phraya is a quite impressive river. It's very large, dark and with many waves dued to ferries, longtail boats, taxi boats and cargo ships. It is really usefull to travel in Bangkok by ferries. With a lot of piers and very economic fares that's the best way to go around.

Excellent transport through Bangkok. Went on the ferry across to the Temple of Dawn, only 3 baht. It was nice to see the river been used to this extent and a bit of traffic. Great views of the Temple, would do a cruise next time with more time.

The lifeblood of the City. You have to respect the river. Bangkok is very dependent upon it. Truth be told, this river is NASTY! I would rather swallow the vomit of a skid row curb urchin than accidentally ingest a drop of this river water! I took a river boat tour and saw a lot of sights but shuddered everytime a drop got on me thinking about the bacterial colony count in that single drop! But then I would see people drinking....yes, deep breath...drinking the water and children swimming in it. Meanwhile, upstream someone is dumping their poop bucket in the river. Needless to say, I wont be volunteering for any river swims any time soon.

Just ride from end to end....... ....and take in the vista.
15THB gets you a lovely journey on the river taxi and it's a perfect thing to do on a steaming day.
Get off at the far end and have a walk around a much less touristy part of Bangkok, have lunch and then get your 15THB ticket back from where you started.
River cruise. Did the river cruise one evening which was a pleasant experience with buffet dinner, live band and view of various temples by the riverside.

River as crazy as the roads. So yep it is a river and quite a muddy murky one. its really big and there's definitely a lot of boats that are back and forth and doing trips and sightseeing. Traffic on the river can be as crazy as the roads and cab also get a little choppy

Dirty river with some nice views. It is unfortunately a dirty river, but does offer some nice views, especially at sunset. Even if you dont go on a river taxi, sitting along the rivers edge can be enough.

Thailand 2015. Did a luncheon cruise as the end part of a tour package. Cruise lasted about 3.5 hrs and covered the river from the north side of Bangkok down to the south side of Bangkok. Nice cruise and a decent lunch

Mandatory. Bangkok its so unique that a cruise around this river might be mandatory to assist you going around the city. The river itself is not the cleanest neither the most appealing but a lot of attractions are situated within its shores. There are lots of cruising options from the standard cruise services (with the minimum fare), to an express ferry service or a private long boat style cruise. There are also luxury yachts but for Chao Phraya rive that would be too much in my opinion. Your choice, would depend in the amount of time you want to spend in this river. The main station is Sathon, just a few meters away of a BTS Metro station and 15 minutes away from the city center. In my opinion, if you want to see the old city and the palace, going by the river its the most relax way of doing it.

Lots of color and flavor. Lots of color and flavor, best way to spend an hour or two. Affirds a different view of the city that can't be observed by walking around. Can be smelly depending on temperature conditions though. Many boats/tours within different price ranges, overall, an attraction that shouldn't be passed up.
The best thing in BKK.. This is by far the best thing i ever did in bangkok. I love all the temples. And the fee isnt that expensive. Wat Arun is my favourite temple among all others.
The River. Took a trip on the Chao Phraya River, its really really good to see Bamgkok from the water, everyones going about their daily business, cheap fares:)

A Good Experience.. The longest river in Thailand, not very clean but worthwhile going on a cruise to get to a temple or for a joy ride as its a good experience.The huge Barges carrying goods on the river too was a novel experience. Also the small floating markets with people selling food & souvenirs was also interesting.

Interesting views of the city when you take a river cruise. There is not much I can say about Chao Phraya River which has not been mentioned yet. I think a cruise on the Mother River should be on your to-do-list when you visit Bangkok. While the boat ploughs the muddy waters you will be able to contemplate the beatiful views of Bangkok, much prettier at night with all the illumination. Many companies offer evening dinner cruises which can be easily arranged by your hotels, depends on the hotel, of course. Some of the hotels will push you to book for the cruise they work with although you have already chosen another, better or cheaper one!There is also an option to go to Ayutthaya by bus or other vehicle, scrutinize the ancient Thai capital and then get back to the modern capital Bangkok by a boat while having a dinner onboard.When we were in Bangkok we went on a boat ride (fast boat, no any facilities, except the seats and the life-jackets,:)) during the day which included some part of Chao Phraya and then we had a long trip through the khlongs. What you can see in the khlongs is definitely not what a tourist would dream of! But nevertheless you will experience the reality.We also used the boat express to cross the river when we went to Wat Arun. What I can advise is: if you don't have a special occasion to celebrate onboard a fancy boat, or just don't want to waste money, or you prefer to travel like a local, you can cruise the river in an ordinary boat (much cheaper) and blend with the locals. You will not be served dinner though on these boats ;).Probably it is not anything new to most of you but for some it will of help, so here you can find a lot of info about Bangkok and will help you to plan your stay there: http://www.bangkok.com/dinner---shows-tours/

Pleasant river cruise. this was pleasant. The river is quite muddy coz there are proper water taxis plying around. the views on both sides are quite nice and scenic especially of the temples and palaces. recommended.

Interesting to go on and watch the activities. Great catching the boat especially during peak hours. It works so efficiently even though absolutely no safety is taken into account. The river is so busy all the time so interesting to stop and stare at all activities. Disappointing thing is the amount of rubbish in the river as all over Thailand. The Thai government really needs to start doing something about correct waste disposal.

Great river. I stayed in a hotel on the river my last visit here and experienced a different thing of Bankok . Mostly it was how easy it is to get to places using the ferry service . So much simpler than using the taxi or roads. Its a very trustworthy and useful river to get around on .

Nice and interesting. Definetly need to try some of the cruise excursion or as I recommended just use regular boat for 15-20 bhat to have a look at the city from river side.And as a other part of attractions try to night boat. it may be even better because you will not see dirty river :)
Mother river. This is very nice scenic river, flowing through the heart of Bangkok. We took regular ferry and also river cruise. Both options were superb and you could see life, sightseeings,....

Old boats. we did a ride with the local people, it's not so special, just a ride in a boat, in polluted waters. There are very nice views and very poor too. People living in good apartments and some houses in very bad conditions.It was ok.

Exciting boat trip. I made a few boat trips on the Chao Phraya River which is a really exciting experience. You should bring a map and pay close attention since little English is spoken and you might miss your stop.
old river in bangkok. i have been many times in bangkok and every time i have been ride a lot in chao phraya river and i recommend all tourist to visit this river and dinner at cruise also.
Great Ride. The best views, sights and sounds. Go on the ordinary boats with the locals for a real (and cheap) Bangkok experience.
Nice view. We took a boat ride down the river to the asiatique riverfront. It is a free ride and you have an excellent view. We did it at night, so with the lights it was extra nice.

Busy river in a busy city. There are a lot of different boats on the river, tourist and commercial. If you get a chance to take a trip down the side canals it is like Venice but Asian style and gives a better sence of how many locals live

travel like the local. My friend and I just took the public boat to get from "Khaosan road" to place near to our hotel and was fast and reliable experience . faster than taxi or "tuc tuc" - so don't worry to use the boat instead of other kind of transport

Historic Main Method of Travel. A river cruise on the Chao Phraya provides an idea of how traffic and goods moved through Bangkok. If you visit Ayutthaaya, prior capital with an abundance of temples and wats, you may take a river boat with lunch included for your return.

Means of Transport. This river has been the main means of transport in Bangkok for a long time and the river taxis are amazing and efficient (except when there is a major event going on in the Grand Palace area). Plus they are really cheap, this includes the cross river ferries. Just be warned don't fall in and try not to get any of the splashing water in your mouth....

Evenings are must spend at Chao Phraya Riverside. If you are in Bangkok, you need to take out time from 6pm to 8pm and take the Chao Phraya ferry tour. What you will experience is the sheer beauty of this river and the graciously lit monuments on both side of the river. If that doesn't fill your stomach, you would like to get down at one of many piers for some riverside restaurant and have a sumptuous meal with your loved ones on the banks of the river. Watch the lovely Wat Arun and Grand Palace brightly lit during the dusk.Prefer taking the Orange Boat ferry as that will cost you only 15 Thai Baht for one way tour. You can take the one at 6pm and the return one at 7pm from any of the Piers where you want to get down.There are also tour boats which will offer you dinner on cruise but are on the expensive side. So if you want to have a romantic evening on cruise, this is your option.
MAjestic. We didn't know that this river was so beautiful until we decided to stay in a vacation rental in BAngkok, TheriversideBangkok. Living by this river is an unforgettable experience.

maybe pre-book tour with hotel?. My cousin and I just went to the dock and booked one of the tours we saw offered there, with about 10-15 people to a boat. It was fine, and we saw the floating market, could make stops at Wat Arun, etc. However I think this could have been better - it would have been nice to have our own boat so we could go at our own speed. I also think there may be more than one floating market area... not sure what I saw was everything/the best. Next time I will do more research and probably pre-book to make sure I get the best experience. The view of how people live is really quite great, this is worth it no matter what.

Splurge for a drink by the river at the Shanghi-la. We love the Chao Phraya River, and ride a boat every time we get a chance, and often find a condo or a hotel with a river view. But our absolute favorite way to sample the sights and sounds of the river is to buy a drink at the waterside (between the pool and the river) bar at the Shangri-La hotel and sit there for a couple of hours. For some reason, there always seem to be a free table right by the water about sundown.Yes, the drinks are expensive, but the view if free, so it's a bargain overall. We don't stay at the Shangri-La unless we are on an expense account, but we find our way to this waterside bar regardless of where we are staying. The only bar food offered is a list of tapas. Delicious, and another nice splurge for a dinner.

Don't fall in. Fantastic for quickly getting around Bangkok, however....We were on one of the long boats speeding along at break neck speed when we crossed the wake of another boat, the fusion of flavours that sprade into my mouth will never be forgotten. Fully expecting to be doing The March of the Penguins to the toilet sometime this evening.

Water is fun. When on rivers, lakes or the sea, I always enjoy to be on water. Buying bread to feed catfish was interesting. When I ate a piece of bread, the old salesman was waiving and making gestures "No, this is for the fish, not for you to eat..." :)

Interesting experience. If you arrive in Bangkok for no plans, the river sightseeing is the thing you can do. Traditional living and architecture of houses, complex of modern and history on the river.
Old Bangkok. The river is probably the best place to get a glimpse of how Bangkok used to be like when it was a city dominated by rivers.

Worth doing a river boat tour. The water may not be the cleanest to look at, but an afternoon (or evening) on the river is certainly worth doing, with stops at Wat Arun and the Grand Palace, etc. If booking a boat tour via the scouts at one of the river piers, be sure to clearly state the route you would like to take and where you want to stop/get out, etc. Oh, and don't forget to bargain!! They will tell you it costs THB 1,000 per person for a one-hour boat tour, but you can easily get this down to THB 300, maybe less.

Chao Pharaya River Cruze a Great Experiance!!!!. When we reached the Cruze Terminal it was like a 5* hotel,our Cruz was also very good,when we boarded the Cruze the music played was quite romantic,as the night progressed the lady started singing Kajrare Kajrare,the dinner spread was also very good.

Great experience. Used the River Taxi to get to and from seeing the Reclining Budda. Seemed to be very organised with a ticket desk at Sathorn... but a little more chaotic further down river. We just paid the 40 baht for single journeys but you can get a day ticket with unlimited stops for 150 baht.It was great experience travelling down river and looking at the sights and a very convenient way to travel.

The best way to visit the old Bangkok and Chinatown. The Chao Phraya river is very special and is highly recommended as a mean of transport to the Old Bangkok and Chinatown. It is also a good idea to do a dinner river cruise catered by one of the leading riverside hotels such as the Anantara, the Oriental or Shangri-La.

wedding dinner cruise. After the wedding ceremony some of us caught the ferry to the shops and returned to tour the markets, prior to the wedding reception on a river cruise. What a pleasant enjoyable entertaining night that was. The host a former chef organised the food and drink selection which was an absolute feast. The boat had great character. It was highly polished timber and charming. The scenes of the river at night were an interesting way to see Bangkok from another view. When the boat docked back in we found it hard to leave as there was more entertainment via bar and band for the general public. The lead singer noticed there were plenty of Aussies and so the he sung some great hits of the past and never missed a beat. We stayed much longer and some of us even sang along with the lead singer and well worth the tip. Never judge a book by its cover.

Beautiful to see and experience.... Make sure you take a long til boat while visiting this river in Bangkok...or at least find a spot ...at the Peninsula Hotel or the Mandarin Oriental?? while having a lunch to view it upclose...another way to enjoy the river is to take their small guest boat across the river from one side to the other...both hotels and the Shangri-La as well, are part of this...it is pure fun to cross the river and enjoy the hotels as well...

The ONLY way to get to Bangkok Big 3!. Cruising the Chao Phraya River by the Express River Ferry is the ONLY way to get to the Bangkok Big 3: Temples of Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew), Reclining Buddha (Wat Pho) & Dawn (Wat Arun). You avoid all the car traffic and get an excellent, overview of Bangkok life along the river. Don't take the "tourist" ferry (overpriced, uber-crowded). Take the regular ferry from Saphan Taksin Pier (beside Skytrain & Shangri-La Hotel) for bargain basement price of 15 Baht to Tha Chang Pier for Temple of Emerald Buddha or Tha Tien (Thien) for Temples of Reclining Buddha and/or Dawn (across from Tha Tien by cross-river ferry for 3 Baht!). On the regular Chao Phraya Express River Ferry, you get to mix with friendly locals and monks. The whole ferry experience is a true highlight of any trip to Bangkok!

See Bangkok from a Different View. One of the best ways to see Bangkok is taking a tourist river ferry or local ferry up and down the Chao Phraya River. You can buy an all day tourist ticket for 150 Baht or pay for local trips. There are numerous piers along the river where you can hop on and off the ferry to enjoy the sights of Bangkok such as the Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Wat Arun etc.The river itself is a busy river with numerous Longtail boats speeding up and down along with large boats carrying produce from the Gulf of Thailand.You can also enjoy an evening dinner trip on the many river dinner ferries.
Great alternative to the crazy roads. Grab a water taxi, a cheap and easy way to get to the city orfrom the city to the palace and Wat Arun, also the cool breeze helps.

The Only Way To Travel. Buy an all day tourist ticket for 150 baht or just jump on a 15 baht local ferry. Either way your boat will be crowded as you take in the sights on this wonderful river. Try to get on early and grab a seat to avoid the pushing and shoving, and also to get the best photos. Wherever you go the river activity is endless. A longboat canal tour is another great way to explore this amazing city. What a buzz!

Life in all its glory is here. Our hotel is on the river and the little boat that takes you to Central Pier is fabulous. The boats to all the places of I Teresa are crammed full of sightseers and locals alike, hot, sweaty great fun

Express Boat. You don`t need to take a tour or privat Boat to explore the Riverbanks. Just take the EB for 15B one way and travel as far as to the end of the line. The orange Flag has the longest route. Very recommended

Messin' about on the river. We had a great time using the orange flag ferry boats on the river. Cost is 15 Baht per person per trip and you can go as far as you like. The Non Burri market at the end of the line ( approx 1 hour from Central pier) is well worth exploring, cheaper than town with lots of street food. At some of the piers people are encouraged to feed the fish and the water is roiling with large catfish - fascinating to watch. This is a cheap, easy way to see a bit more of the city without the noise, traffic and fumes.

Get out of town-the cheapest excursion in Thailand!. One of the best little- known photo ops is to take the ferry boat from Saphan Thaksin (BTS station) to Nonthaburi. People may know the Tourist boat ( blue flag) which takes you to the tourist traps and is quite expensive but few know about the orange flag boat. For just 15 bhat you travel about an hour to Nonthaburi. On the way you see Wat Arun, the Naval bases, the bridges that got Bangkok the title of 'The Venice of the east," Wat Poh, Thai river houses, Historical colonial buildings and many more cultural gems. The last 20 minutes or so the river opens out and you can relax and enjoy the fresh air.At Nonthaburi get off the boat, walk around the Thai shops and then take the ferry back. You can get off at the pier for WAT PHRA GAO to see the emerald Buddha, Khao San Road (the backpackers street), Saphan phut (pier 6) For the fabulous flower market, China town (Pier 5). However the best place to get off is Pakret. From here, take a small boat to Koh Kret, a small island that has traditional Thai sweets, cooking, pottery and very interesting Temples. Enjoy your cheap Thai day out!

best way to see bangkok. take a private canal tour and you will see how people live in bkk but expect to wait for canal locks to open and close as you sit in the long boat.my favourite way to travel around Bangkok is by longboat down the river but renting them can get expensive if you want be on and off boats all day the 150 baht travel pass is a great idea you just hop on and off the large river buses as and when you please and you can really get around Bangkok avoiding the hustle and bustle of the manic streets which tuk tuks and meter taxi's have to take.

Pride of Bangkok. River connects to many attractions of Bangkok. Express boats are safer and cost effective for tourists. Connect to BTS at Saphan Taksin station. Both sides of the river are full with Hotels and establishments.

"Worthy Cheap way to explore the River". Without My Wife’s experience, both of us would have made it on Chao Phraya River boat ride. We took the boat from Rat Burana Pier near Phra Athit and got down at Tha Tien Pier to venture the Chaophrya River. The cost was about 24bath per person, “so worth it”. Though the ride stops at every pier and it could be crowed where locals and tourist venture the river, if you are lucky you could get to seat "we were lucky" hence it was a great sightseeing where you could see many magnificent temples, the Grand Palace and architectural buildings including the Church and the Royal Thai Navy Dockyard. Be careful hopping on and off the boat as the tides could be rough. It was one of my unforgettable moments enjoying the boat ride with my love one. We hope you do too..
MUST FOR BANGKOK. When in Bangkok you have to do what the locals did. You must ride tge boats its fun and easy way to see the city cheap and fast and to beat Bangkok traffic jams.

It's OK.... The views from the river are fairly nice, though few things were set up alongside the river for optimum viewing. If you take a night cruise you can get a few good photos of temples and the bridge. It was all memorable, but only because the experience was so bad! I don't regret, per say, checking this out but I won't do it again and when I visit Bangkok with my family I won't have them experience this.

More beautiful at night. The Chao Phraya River is an important mean of tranportation in Bangkok. Along it there are several piers and taxi-boats They are more bus-boats) stop at each one. The views at night are superb: the temples, the king's palace, the Asiatique all brightly lit. I spent the New Year's Eve on a boat and it was spectacular!

great views. best time to do this is in the evening. all the hotels and temples are lit up nicely. go with the rice boat so you can get a meal and a drink. go with a good guide. cool breeze . may need a sweater

Great river motorway. Cutting through the city with long boats and river taxis it's the easy way to get around and the cheapest with all the views and markets near by.look out for river city it's one of the best places for nice bars and shopping..

LongTail Boat Tour is fun. You cant come to Bangkok without experiencing a long tailed boat tour. We wound out way through the canals and observed life along the waterway. Stopping halfway to feed the giant catfish. There were so many it seemed you could walk on them across the river! I like being on the quieter canals and was amazed how the drivers could maneuver their boats around corners of the block. Take sunscreen!

ASIATIQUE The Riverfront. for any new or return visitors, do not hesitate to take a boat cruise on this river. There are many landmarks to see. I was able to go to ASIATIQUE The Riverfront ...a wonderful place. Great shopping and many restaurants. The prices are very reasonable...I was surprised and food is excellent. Get a good seat on the boats which travel on the river, but be careful, you can get wet, they move pretty fast.

Hang on. You have a number of choices of boats to travel on the river. The tourist boat at 40 Baht a trip (or 150Baht for day ticket) which only stops at the big tourist areas and has guide in board telling you what you wee I'd you off at each stop. The other is the other is the express boat that stops at every pier on the river, this costs 15 Baht. The river can become choppy and the ride gets a bit bouncy at those times. It's a good way to see the city, the goo and bad.
Amazing sights. The most amazing scenery at night It's more then a must!!!Please just do it on a dinner cruiseSo many beautiful stunning sights

you got to ride on it. I didn't take a tour. Instead I took the river taxi up and down the river. Download the add beforehand. It's helpful. Take the orange flag express river taxi. I didn't do any of the right things & learned the had way as I do in all things. I ended up traveling all 1 to 30 by river taxi. That could have been 30-45 min up the river. 1 all day pass would have been 150B, yet I ended up being hurried & paying 15B per ride. It was a lot of fun. It's busy & loud. The fee collector shakes a purse of money near you & gives you a ticket. The collector can make change. Keep the ticket. Someone may check it again. Dirty water spits up at you when your on the edge. The river is littered with garbage. But it's an easy way to get around. The express comes often & covers area. I used it to get to my hotel, Chinatown, Mandarin Oriental.

Good experience. Traveled on the river using a day pass ticket cost about £3 per person we traveled to the royal palace it was worth it.
The water is dirty & has rubbish in some areas which is a shame,
I would recommend trying it for the experience also it's quicker than traveling by road to reach the palace and other attractions.

Take the River Bus. We bought the cheap all day ticket which gets you on and off any of the express boats as many times as you like and saves you having to sort out the small coins for individual fares. The boats have coloured flags on top to show which route they are on. We just got on one at random and sat on the same boat all the way to the end of the line and back. Just watching the life on the river was fascinating. There's a good view of some of the attractions such as the royal barge museum and you get to be with the local people. We watched fish feeding, water irises and flip flops floating by and all sorts of people just doing every day things. We simply sat there and watched it all happen in front of us with no effort required. Also the River had a nice open spacious feel about it so it was a break from the rest of Bangkok which is so busy crowded.

Great way to see the city. Our family took the boat tour from one of the many piers in the city. The price is often inflated so ask around for people getting off the boat about the price before picking one. I think we got 40% off the quoted price. Tuktuk drivers get hefty commissions and will steer you to the place with the best payoff not the best experience.I think we spent about an hour on the big boat and the only people on it were our family which was nice. Some of the houses on the river are completely falling apart and some are very expensive so it was interesting to see how the locals live in those conditions.10 baht to feed the millions of fish in the fish feeding area was worth it for to experience the frenzy.

one of he kind. close to the daily life of bangkok. you must really take a boat ride on the legendary chao Phraya river. it is best to pay for a private long boat and do it at your own time. You will see the daily life activities of the Bangkokian going to work, to eat or shopping.You will need to pay cash to the boatman. from Baht 500 to Baht 1000 depending on the hours you spend .and of course the whole architecture of old Bangkok, with its palaces, the royal barges, to the new skyline of Bangkok.Go inside the klongs to see more of the old bangkok life and houses. Still genuine and authentic.Swaadee kap.

Bumpy ride. This is a fun boat ride which is interesting as you see the sites from the water. You will encounter vendors selling food and beer from their small boats. There are many boats so the going can be very bumpy.

Too crowded. For years, an afternoon trip on the Chao Phraya River Express Boat to Nonthaburi has been my favorite activity to escape the heat of Bangkok and enjoy some peace and quiet. Apparently too many travelers have read my reviews and the increase in the number of passengers on each of the boats that I traveled on has become disconcerting. Unless you are at the beginning of the line you won't get an "outside" seat. If you attempt to exit the boat before you reach Nonthaburi, be prepared to push people out of the way. In addition, the number of boats operating on Sunday is inadequate. Unless service is increased, I would suggest looking for alternative means of transportation, particularly on Sunday. Also consider traveling earlier in the morning or later in the afternoon. Still the biggest bargain in Bangkok.
Stay on the river. This is the throbbing heart of Bangkok. IF you stay inland, Bangkok becomes a hot, dusty, smoggy place. Stay on the river and you won't regret it.

Loved traveling on the Chao Phraya River. Our first visit the the main dock/station was a bit confusing, but after that it was a fun ad cost effective way of traveling. We mainly relied on the Orange line, which stops at all the stations. 15 baht one way. They can get crowded & confusing with all the hub-bub, whistles and the shouting Of the tiicket / fare collector, so not for everyone.

Endless River & Eternal. Best Words to describe Chao Phraya River - "Endless River & Eternal" !!! Connects all major points of Central Bangkok - Nice to travel in the evening and night along the river and nice to view during the day ! The Crossing Bridges adds to the scenery ! .. Highlight are the traditional, iconic as well as modern day infrastructure alongside the river ... ALSO APTLY CALLED AS "MAE NAM" Mother River in Thai !!!

Great way to get along to river based attractions. The ferries up and down the river are frequent and cheap. Don't bother with the tourist boat (which has a commentary you cannot decipher) but take orange flagged boats for 15Bhat one way, get off where you like. Great for starting at Saphan Phra bridge and going up to Wat Phra and the Grand Palace; Khao San Road and the Throne Hall up near the King's Residence (well worth a visit but hardly frequented by non locals).
Relax. It is relax, no hussel, you just board the boat, buy ticket and enjoy the scene & time. No need to plan, worry.

The great dirty river in "Bangkok". I travelled by long-tailed on Jao Phra Ya river from Taksin Pier to Tha Tien Pier, boat guards didn't care anything about the tourists and they just wanted everyone come on the boat as fast as they can. Before Tha Tien Pier there was a speed boat came very fast, dirty water of Jao Phra ya made me sticky and awful.

By ferry. Nice, but I don't think you have to book a tour company. It's nice to just take a public ferry from Saphan Taksin BTS and go up and down the river, get on and off. Lots of information on internet.

Long boat down the Chao Phraya River. Was advised by a Thai person to go to a pier that both Thai and tourists use in order to get a long boat. I went on an hour's trip (on my own) for 1500 Bhat. The day before I had gone to another pier and they wanted to charge me 2000 Bhat (I didn't try and barter with them and sure I possibly could have but instead went on the ferry). The long boat was ok but I have done many river trips before (India, Vietnam, etc...). Possibly if you haven't done it before, you will enjoy seeing the houses on the river and ordinary Thai people's lives.

David on Tour. Don't get scammed into all of the ways you can go on the river, if you want to go on a long tailed boat negotiate and offer a third of what they ask and be prepared to walk away. There are two lots of ferries running up and down the river, the tourist one 40 Bahts a trip and the locals ferry, same size boats but 15 bahts. They stop at the same places but with no commentary. Tourist ferry has a blue flag at the back locals has an orange one.

enjoy a cruise. when in bangkok i allways set aside a day for a nice relaxing cruise down the river.i allways use the "river buses" as i only want to use one pier [15baht for one way]if you wish to visit multiple piers you can buy an all day tourist pass for 150 bhatt.but i prefer to just jump on and pay the clippie

The river well. We were actually approached while visiting a temple for going on the riverMyself,wife,daughter,my eldest son and wife we had a long boat.The day was warm ,and water a little choppy.We got to see where the king off thailand stays or lives in a hostpital on the river.We saw how the other half off Bangkok lives To see the barges and river life great,stopped and met some floating markets,and also for feeding the fish in the riverIt is not the best thing in Bangkok but everyone should try it.Make sure you get a guide that can speak English otherwiswe you don't know what is going on anyway have a go

nice but not clean. The Chao Phraya River is a good way to travel around town especially with the chao phraya boat express which is only 15 bahts a way. You get to see a lot of "attractions" along the river. One thing, the river seems to be full of fish but does not seem very clean.
One of the best authentic experiences in Bangkok. I love taking river taxi up and down Chao Praya river. IT's cheap, convenient and you're never stuck in traffic.

Good for Bangkok (Don't expect Siene or Thames). After a hectic day of walking around and soaking in sun, evening river cruise is a great way to relax. The boat companies take you around for a nice tour and gives you a different view of the bustling city. I recommend to go in evening, so you can enjoy both day time and night time views. It is relaxing to stand by at the pier also, and just munch around. Don't expect the romanticism of Siene or Thames, but a must go if you have time in evening. Carry a light jacket during winter months.
Shame about tour guide. This is anexcellent way to get around Bangkpk if you can ignore the rude your guide.At 150bht a day value for money.

Cruising Down the River. Many different boat companies can take you from hotels or riverside stops to others. The boats are swift and sometimes the signs are not market in English but people can understand your pronunciation of the name of the stop and tell you where to get off if you stay with them. Trips are great ways to cool off in the heat of the day.
Fantastic....the world goes on this river. To see it, and the myriad of things going on. Simplicity of travel on the river...many river taxis, long tail speed boats...avoid the traffic
My love, my life. To fall a sleep with a view over the river, to wake up to the same view, to live the river life thats life. Nice cool air awaits you ...

Usefull link. It is not simply his way up to the river and there are not many places where buildings do not go all the way out to the water. You can find the båtpirerna through signs and you must usually pass through a variety of stalls in an anonymous building to arrive at the bus stops.There are several different options on how to transport yourself on the river: Dinner Cruises, public transport, longtail boats, etc. We went with the Chao Phraya Express, public transport, which worked pretty good but a bit disorganized. The boats are fast and efficient and you pay before to get off to a person walking around the boat yelling something you dont understand. =) If you are looking for sightseeing, I wouldn't recommend these boats because the view from inside the boat aren't that good. Another tip is to bring a map and keep track of where you are.If you choose to hire a longtail it might be good to have some naval experience when boarding seames a bit hazardous.

A must do in Bangkok. Get the river boat and watch Bangkok as it is and has been since the 80s - large barges floating up and down, fast riverboats, ancient temples and now the modern high rise increase. Tip = there is the local boat -15 baht, and a more expensive but much less crowded tourist boat - 40 baht. take your pick.

Wonderful. We boarded the public ferry where we rode to the end of the line out in the suburbs, well over an hour. We disembarked and looked around and came back. The Grand Palace complex is only a few stops from Taksin station - saves you from haggling with the taxi and tuk-tuk drivers outside the palace.

Do take a boat ride. The river is very busy with ferries and tour boats vying for space at times. The banks are littered with temples, hotels, modern and historic co-mingling. We took an evening dining cruise that was less than £50 a head and this gave a wonderful opportunity to see the sights from a riverine perspective and to enjoy an excellent Thai meal. The only negative was that we chose a Thai wine to drink that was rather expensive and not to our taste.

nice to visit. It was great to spend a late afternoon if you are not a night person. The shops there are open for night time. If you don't like the crowd go there around 5pm to eat and look around. Leave before it gets crowded.
Confusing price and pier. Got confused when I was taking a boat there as the price is not stated clearly if it's for round trip or just one way. better u ask 1st.
A very interesting mixture of modern and traditional ways of living. A quick and relaxing way of transport,and also to see the mixture of a modern and wealthy way of life with the traditional one.

Super river "taxi" (as suggested by Lonely Planet), but not great "cruise tour" option.. I used the Chaya Praya river boats a lot to get around. Orange flag boats are local "commuter" boats (cost less) and blue flag boats are narrated "tourist" boats pointing out sites along the way but they both make the same stops. Orange flag boats--just get on (you don't need to buy a ticket ahead of time-someone comes round and collects $ after the boat is moving) On my first day in Bangkok I took the blue flag boat figuring the narration would help me orient to the city. Problem was even Asian's who speak great English can have real pronunciation problems and the loud speakers were bad so I never understood a word. The river boats are a GREAT way to get around though (down to the Royal Palace area etc) and you get a good view of the city. (Yes, they are crowded and good chance you may end up standing with lots of other people like a crowded subway, but the river ferries combined with BTS/MRT are a great way to get around) So 5 star transport system but 2 star tourist cruise. http://wikitravel.org/upload/shared//3/35/Bangkok-transit-map.png

Out of space and time trip. One of the things you should absolutely do in Bangkok, is to take a boat and do a trip on the Chao Phraya . I recommend to stop at the Oriental Hotel, by the evening, and take a drink there, in front of the river . You will see the show of the boats , and all the beautiful lights on the water. Absolutely amazing. If you have more budget, you can also eat there, it is worth it the money (it is out of my price range, so I have down ones, but now I only drink , and enjoy) :)

Soothing transportation. Whether you wish to use the boat to reach a suburb in the north like Nonthaburi or going on a dinner night cruise you will enjoy riding a boat while observing the busy river life of this huge river flowing through Bangkok and Thonburi. You will get a good impression of this metropolis with its bridges, temples, high-rise buildings.

A must when visiting Bangkok. There are so many different options to travel on the river that there is some type of boat to suit all. It can be a cheap way to see Bangkok from another perspective if using the ferries or you might hire a fast moving longboat and have it all to yourself. There are numerous party boats that leave from River View Shopping centre if you're into music, dancing and food. Alternatively there are dinner cruises but these seem to be very group orientated.
Relaxing. If you are in BKK on a clear and sunny day then a boat ride along the river is a great way to sit back and just watch all the activity going on.

Bangkok's Lifeline. No trip to Bangkok would be complete without ferrying on the Chao Phraya river. It gives a new dimension to the views of Bangkok. If travelling by the crowded ferries, keep an eye on your wallet.

If you want to see life on the river in Bangkok, then catch the Chao Phraya Express boat service.. A great way to travel in Bangkok. The express boat service 3 different lines, indicated by the colour of the flag they fly. (A map can be picked up FOC) A nice breeze as you cruise the river, passing houses built from timber on stilts above the water, some looking as if anytime they will sink below the murky muddy waters below where people wash their clothes, fish, or swim. Amongst some of the tallest modern sky scrapers in the world. Avoid rush hour as boats are often overloaded and look to be dangerous.

A must see for all!. A trip to Bangkok is not complete without a day or night on the river. For 150 THB you can buy an all day pass on the river ferry. With this you can visit all the major temples from the river. Also a dinner cruise is a must. The food is always adequate but you're not there for dining. You're there for the ambience and to see beautiful Bangkok at night. Enjoy my adopted home!

Cruising Views. We cruised during the day, with a buffet lunch on the River Pearl. Interesting views and good guide of landmarks, but food was mediocre and the whole experience sounds better on paper.

It's prettier at night. Go on one of the local or express boats, not a tourist boat. It's the same ride and much cheaper. There are a lot of old, falling-down, metal roofed shacks right on the water -- near the luxury hotels. At night, the buildings are lit up and it's very pretty.

Love the 'Muddy Old River' (to quote Murray Head). The Chao Praya river is in many ways the heart of Bangkok, and is certainly a working river, filled with not only ferries, river-buses, long-tail boats, and dinner-cruise boats, but also tugs pulling huge loads. There's always something to see.Sitting on the river, perhaps enjoying a drink or a meal is one way to enjoy the river. In the daytime you'll see it is very functional, and at night it all lights up especially with the dinner-cruise boats.We definitely recommend using the river-buses for travelling up and down - you can use the tourist one if you prefer, though it is more expensive. The non-tourist river-buses are more fun, more authentic, and cheaper, so we prefer to jump on with the locals, monks, and other less pedestrian tourists, etc.It can also be a lot easier using the boats than taxis etc. to get to some of the attractions along the river such as the Royal Palace, Wat Arun, etc.Definitely recommended to experience from either the shore, on the river itself, or both.
Best way to see Bangkok. Only £1.50 for day ticket, travel up and down river all day getting off to visit main sights that are close by .. if visiting Bangkok then this is a must do ..

Self Service Sightseeing in Bangkok. The Chayo Praya tourist boat was 150Baht well spent. We had a great day getting on and off the boat. Visiting the Grand Palace- Boat Stop 9, Wat Pho- Stop 8, the flower market- Stop 5, etc. The tourist boat ticket does not give you access to get across the river to Wat Arun, but it was just a couple baht to take that boat. . . we paid in change not bills so it was less than 10Baht, probably closer to 5- sorry I can't remember the exact amount. Have lunch at Boat stop 9. There are numerous food stands between the river and the Grand Palace. We had some wonderful Pad Thai and fruit and were ready to keep on trucking.

Breathtaking. I thought the river would look like a typical Asian river with black water and bad smell. it was not at all. the river was flowing softly, sometimes it was raging. the view on the left and right was very traditional. the cost was a bit unreasonable for a short 30 minutes trip, but it was acceptable.

Ewwww. Some people love this tour - seeing the temples by water. Personally - I'm repulsed by the pollution and plastic crap that lines the shores and bobs in the water. I hope Thailand figures out what to do with their garbage.
Not Clean. Like most of the rives in a developing countries, this river too not a clean one, with murky waters. Better to spend time elsewhere than to see the river.

Riding the river. We took a boat ride up the Klong...so this might not be the right river. We quickly went into the canels as the main river was very choppy. It was interesting to see business conducted on the river, houses you can only get to via river, and another glimps of Bangkok . Some temples you can only get to via the river. It was an intersting hour or two.

River Taxi. Don't be fooled into buying expensive boat trips, you can travel on public water taxi boats carrying a hundred or more for just a few baht or buy a hop on hop off pass for 150 baht ( £3 ) for the day. favourite trip is to The Grand Palace or the Leaning Buddha. easy to use and a great view from the river.

Great to see the Venice of the east!!. We stayed next to this river. Great sample of life. Always different. Always active. Note the tourist ferry charges 40 thb and the local express boat 15 thb. The local ferry is all we ever used as much the same thing!

Ok at best. The river is dirty and at times smelly. The cruise down the river is ok as there are a few temples that dot the riverside which is nice but look better when the sun is setting.It's often hard to find the piers as they are down small back streets in some places and the fares and boats are a bit confusing when you first get there so have a quick read of other reviews for advice.

Navigate on the Cheap boat. The river is definitively the heart of Bangkok. Here, you can see many contrasts... building that resemble Miami and houses that holds people below the line of poverty; temples and discos; cheap stalls of food and luxurious restaurants. Absolutely you must take a boat and navigate the river. My suggestion is to get the cheap communal boat (the one like a floating bus that stops many times), there is no use to pay so much for the touristic one... if you want the real feeling of the city, merge with the local and take the one I suggested (fyi we took the private one and we regret doing so: you end paying a lot for the same or even worse cause you miss the local energy).

Bangkok division. Cut in two by the Chao Praya river, Bangkok is considered as the Asian Venice. Either on a private boat or by ferry the experience and diversity will show you another view of Bangkok. For main sights get the ferry. For little canals and a better view go with a longtail boat private.

Great way to beat street traffic. After sitting in traffic for almost an hour, we took the water taxi whenever possible. Inexpensive and relatively fast. While the water is filthy, the sites along the river are interesting. Also, our hotel had a complimentary water shuttle that was very convenient for visiting the Asiatique night market or travel to the BTS.
Excellent River Cruise. We took the Chao Phraya River Cruise with dinner. Really superb experience . Would recommend to all to take this lifetime experience.

A must when in Bangkok. Sure you can take a taxi, a tuk-tuk, or even the BTS or MRT to see many attractions in Bangkok, but taking a trip on a Chao Phraya river ferry is efficient, cheap, and an attraction in itself.There are two types of ferries going north and south on the river: orange flag and blue flag. Orange flag are local public ferries that cost 15 baht per ride. Blue flag ones are tourist ferries and cost 40 baht per ride. You can buy a blue flag day pass for 150 baht.Pros and cons: orange flags are cheap but can get crowded. Blue flags are more expensive but sometimes less crowded.There are also ferries that only go from one side of the river to the other and these are cheaper. Also, there are a few hotels like the Mandarin Oriental and Peninsula operating their own boats across the river, but you can use these for free as well (they go to the hotel's "private" dock).There's no limit to the length of your ride, meaning you can get on at N1 and ride all the way north some thirty stops and receive a "poor man's river tour" for either 15 or 40 baht. Likewise on the way down. You'll see many sights along the river including Wat Arun.The Chao Phraya is a working river, meaning you'll see lots of daily life going on from barges to cruises to people fishing, washing clothes, etc. Not a clean river, but certainly lively.It's great if you can get a seat on the ferry, otherwise it may be standing room only. Engine noise and whistles at the back.It's a pleasant way to get from Silom/Saphan Taksin to Khao San Road with the breezes off the river.

Always something to look at. The water may be dirty but when you focus on the activities and sights you can get a glimpse of life for many Thais. Take the express water taxi all the way to Nonthaburi (last stop) 15 baht ride and have lunch at the restaurant on the river. Good toilet there and food is inexpensive. See barges loaded with goods, kids sing, men fishing, ferries crossing river and commuters just getting to work.

An Experience for the brave. No trip to Bangkok should be without a journey down river on a public ferry boat or a long tailed boat. The masters of these boats have amazing skill and dexterity in ensuring the boats don't collide. You also can move about the city quicker and get a great view of both sides of the river. Be brave and have a trip!
Nothing special. Dirty river, not worth going along the river with the boat service. Better stay at one of th bars along the river and enjoy a cocktail or two

Chao Phraya River - What is nicer to embark a waterboat taxi and smell the atmosphere. Like in any other city, a river five something special to a city. It brings movement and beautiful bridges. The river is always like a moving painting. And Bangkok is the BEST !!!

Morning cruise. This is an excellent way to get out of traffic and see the city. View many traditional thai homes built on stilts on the river. View many Thai and Chinese temples located all along the rivers banks. Stop an feed 100s of catfish. A relaxing city tour.

Great way to get around Bangkok. We have just spent the last 5 days in Bangkok. We used the water shuttles all the time. Great way to get around to a lot of the tourism sites as well as connecting to the transit system.There is a tourist water shuttle, which charges more, but is worth it if you want to get some good photos of some things on the riverfront, almost double to the public shuttle, though.

Wonderful experience. We took the Chao Phraya River boat in order to go to palace and few other temples. The service is amazing. we took one day pass and enjoyed the river and view of various buildings, hotels on it's bank. Their is enough water to create the current so you get a nice experience. The boats are clean but just clean and spacious luxury is far away though. You can hire a small one if want a private luxurious expereince of river. On our way back we stopped at Asiatique mall, had a good walk, window shopping, food and then hoppen back on the ferry. Nice and recommended!

Do this in the evening and watch the sunset. Great breeze too!. This was a great way to unwind after a long day. Here are some tips.* Orange flag boat is 15 Baht* Get an outward seat to see the sights* Watching the sunset was awesome* The end of the line is Stop 30. Took us an hour and a half. The city center was awesome. No tourists. New local foods (Tom yum potato curls)* street market was awesome with amazing prices and local goods. * go to the "food court" a few blocks down the main road. Best street food EVER! Look for the stall in the pictures We went back the next night for more!* take Bus 97 back to bangkok it stops at Victory Monument where you can transfer to your hotel. 12 Baht.

Interesting mode of transportation. For tourists on a tight budget though, be mindful of the type of boat you are taking as special tourist boat charges 40baht minimum as opposed to 15baht of the public boat.

Best to take the dinner cruise arranged from Shangri- La or view from oriental Hotel. The cruise river dinner are best to cruise along the river and take a good view of the the temple of Dawn. The river view can also be appreciated at any of the restaurant outlet of Oriental Hotel.

Spectacular view of the city but there's so much rubbish.. It's a beautiful view of the city from the river, both during the day and at night. It's a must see but the view is spoilt by the huge amount of litter that is floating on the surface. We spent a few minutes in a boat queue watching a crane balancing on a huge pile of rubbish. It's a huge shame as it's such a magnificent place.

Great Experience. It's worth the effort to use the local boats if just to see how the fare collectors manage to get everyone to pay their way even on completely packed boats. Don't use the tourist boats and DO find out what the flags mean on each boat - it can make the difference between an OK experience and a journey remarkable for its value. See the changing moods of the river and enjoy - the memories will stay with you for years. The skill of the drivers of what are big boats is quite fascinating to watch aided only by a system of whistles from the conductor. Magic.
Great river cruise and river. A good experience and a great buffet, I think we ate so much than the river cruise cost, the river looks better at night with the temples lit up.
River that leads to many attractions. This river leads to many tourists attractions such as Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Wat Arun and Asiatique.Boat Ride Tickets is value for money with unlimited rides.

I took the White Orchid Dinner Cruise,A MUST!!!!. Enjoy Bangkok at night on a 2.5-hour dinner cruise along the Chao Phraya River. See two of the city’s top attractions — the Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) and the Grand Palace — illuminated after dark, and feast on a variety of Thai dishes. An onboard band provides musical entertainment. Hotel transport is included from select locations.This is how I spent Christmas Eve,what a memorable experience,I shall treasure for a very long!!! They were so kind,as I've called them to ask whether they had some dishes for vegetarian.To my delightful surprise,I was served all my favorite thai food right at my table!

The heart beat of Bangkok. Chaophraya river is a must see when in Bangkok , in fact in my opinion if you don't see the river you haven't been to Bangkok . The bat traffic on the river is exciting to watch both by day and night and it cost nothing just to watch and soak up the incredible vibes of the river

Sunset river cruise. Our 1st time on the river cruise was beautiful. Once the sun set all the buildings, monuments, temples and even boat houses were lit up. It's a relaxing cruise. Once is enough though.
Cruising the river. This a great way to see parts of Bangkok. The local boats are 15 baht and you can go anyway and hook up with the BTS. Great views along the way.

Great way to see all the big sites. If you have only a short time in Bangkok I suggest that you catch the BTS down to the ferry and travel it up and down the river. A number of key sites and monuments in Bangkok are located on this river.

a must in thailand. river cruise is a must in bangkok, unfortunately there are not so many attractive programs, usually more on visiting temples. however, you can discover many things about culture and lives of people.

Pleasant Manner to Travel to Parts of the City or to Relax and Eat/Drink and Enjoy the Views. Visiting the Chao Phraya River is definitely worthwhile. Along the river were an abundance of fancy restaurants and hotels. Other areas were not as nice. There was a mixture. The Wat Arun can be viewed along the river. Taking a boat ride down the river is a great way to see parts of the city. We used the river-taxi system. It was a little confusing at first to figure it out, but, once we did, it was an extremely cheap and easy way to take a boat ride down the river and to get to and from our hotel as our hotel was long the river. The tickets for river-taxi system were $0.50 or less. One night we enjoyed cocktails and appetizers along the river and were mesmerized by the beautiful sunset.

The real heart of Bangkok. Although nowadays it tends to be obscured by high-rise buildings the Chao Phraya river is still the beating heart of Bangkok. To experience the river and its historical landmarks buy a one day ticket for the ferry. You can hop on and off at any pier you like all day long and visit different interesting neighbourhoods close to the river.

It is not a river boat tour, it is a type of public transport. If you want to have a river cruise and pay a lot of money for it, it is fine. But, you can simply use the boats locals use to move around the city. It functions like a bus, it has several stops on the way (Chinatown, Wat Arun, The Grand Palace are some of them), it is cheap, boats are decent and fast and that is it. Nothing fancy, but nothing pricey either. You can even get a daily pass. The staff member will annoynce the stop and you can easily get off. The river is a huge one, spectacular sight, though not really clean. The view is good, you can make some nice photos. Of course, you can run into touts anywhere, so it can happen here as well, be alert. We were approached by a member of the tourist police, who advised us to go deaper into Chinatown if we want cheaper stuff and to be aware of the touts.
Unique experience. We basically were sitting on a boat and was able to see Bangkok from the river side. It was very windy and was sleepy after a while :)

Point of view. This is not Rhine! Sometimes somewhere the river is nice and sometimes somewhere the river is not. Along the country side it is mostly nice, not spectacular, but nice. And when you situated yourself on those fancy restaurants on high-rise hotels in Bangkok, it is nice. Avoid the rest.
Chao phraya. I love travelling down this river, try to do it on every visit. You can catch the local boat for a fraction of the cost and embark at any stop. A must for tourist

Travel the Klongs and use the Ferry Boats. The city of Bangkok is Asia's Venice, with ferry boats and water taxis linking almost every areas on a circular system of canals called Klongs and the Chao Phraya River. Riding the low cost ferry boats through the Klongs and up and down the river should not be missed, as you pass an unending array of temples, schools, institutions, and markets and pass by the backyards of half the populace. This is an insider's view of Bangkok and very fun. Half of the fun of riding the boats is riding next to Thai citizens from every walk of life from Buddhist monks to teachers and families. This is a charming and addictive pleasure.

Great way to see the sites!. Forget the private boats unless you need some privacy! Buy a day pass and jump on and off at the sites on your itinerary! The earlier you start the less busy it is. We started at the Central pier where the sky train station connects. Some nice views of the cityscape as well!
Must do at night. strongly recommend evening cruise to admire the lightened temples and skyscrapers and avoid seeing how dirty is the river

Pick your river boat/taxi with care. The Chao Phraya river is truly majestic. It is well worth visiting and spending time visiting the many beautiful temples alongside its lengthy banks. However all visitors to Bangkok need to understand that there are, like in any other city, good and honest operators and less savory ones. If the operators appear aggressive, hostile or overly friendly please be aware as there are syndicates that work parts of the transportation tourist industry, They typically overcharge and some tourist experiences can be unpleasant. Take your time and evaluate whether the cost and response appears to be reasonable...you can ask around and local friends can definitely help you decide which operator to opt for and suggest reasonable fares. Unfortunately there is not much recourse in real terms if things go wrong so being aware and prepared is the best weapon.Finding a good guide is key to an amazing experience.
nice river. very cheap ferry servicenice way to cut the trafficvery convenientmany choices: speed, cruise, canal, regularnice views at night time.

A cheap boat ride to see life around the (polluted) river. You don't need to pay for a guided boat tour, just take the local express boat (orange flag) from the Saphan Taksin = Sathorn = Central Pier (all names for the same stop). For 15Baht (0.45 usd) one way you can ride the boat all the way to the end of the line--Nonthaburi stop #30 on the orange line. Since we were jet-lagged upon arrival in Bangkok, we decided to take this easy boat ride to get the lay of the land/river. We knew we were going to use the express boat to get to the Grand Palace/Wat Po/Wat Arun, and Chinatown later in the week. Note: any time you get off the boat and get back on, it's always 15Baht per ride. An attendant comes (shaking their money box) around the boat collecting your 15Baht and will give change if you don't have exact amount. Have small change on hand.The river is polluted & smells in some places (oil/gas from the boats, maybe poop?) and littered with trash (plastic bags, bottles, etc). Along the way, we saw some floating dead fish, kids swimming in the river, a man in shorts taking a bath w/ soap, and a street vendor washing his pots & dishes (after seeing that we decided to eat only hot bbq skewered street food). Interesting view of life, homes, and construction along the river. You might think it's a boring (long) ride, but it was a relaxing and non-stressful way to get some daylight/sunshine to recover from jet-lag.When we got to Nonthaburi pier (about a 1 hour ride one-way), there is a small village with a main drag perpendicular to the pier. We saw lots of catfish at the pier where you can buy fish food to feed them. We walked along the main drag, got some fresh baked buns from a Thai version of the 85degree bakery (a well-known Taiwanese bakery chain) and some Thai coffee. There are a lot of street vendors selling goods--bags, belts, souvenirs, etc. On the return trip back to Saphan Taksin pier, make sure you go to the correct pier landing (i.e. the direction of the boat going towards the left as you're facing the river).

Interesting Way to Travel. A must see in Bangkok is the busy tourist boat of the Chao Phraya River - especially if one wishes to see the temples located on the river. The price is very reasonable (15 Baht or thereabouts). Well worth seeing - easily accessible from the BTS.

The best way around. I have found the river and ferry to be the most convenient way of getting around and a great way to see a cross section of Bangkok -- whether you take a water taxi or the ferry or come back from Ayutthaya on luncheon cruise. All life (and all the city's waste) undoubtedly flow through there at one point or another.

Long boat tour through the canals.. A must in Bangkok is to take a long boat tour through the canals and see how the other half of Bangkok lives! Amazing! Temples, monks, school children and homes that look like they are about to sink. Thai people fishing, smiling and waving at you! Tours range in time. One hour is enough. Totally worth it!

Just a big river. Its just a big and not very clean river. But helpful if you want go to China Twon or the Grand Palace. Take the tourist boat and you not stuck in the traffic jam in Bangkoks streets.

Murky but interesting. The river itself is nothing to visit, its dirty and wide and best seen at sunset and nighttime BUT the travel cost is cheap and the sights by the river are fascinating to fabulous with some areas even hitting trendy these days.

River life. Go in the late afternoon when the light is golden. What better way to get a real feel for BANKOK. It is also a great way to visit the Reclining Buddha.Oh and our kids love the ferry rides.

Moving Life. The river itself is fairly unremarkable and brown. But the attraction is on the life that lives around and on it, the sheer number of boats, barges, and water taxi's moving on the river. It is Bangkok using the watery highway, always something to see.

Hire a long boat its worth it..
