Don't take the boring ferry boats hire a song thaew one of those long boats and zip around the small side Klongs (canals) a great experience and see basicaly how Bangkok evolved.That is if you want a treat and a great sight seeing experience.As has been said river taxis are dead easy and quick too.Its impressive is the old Chao Praya.

Biggest River in Bangkok. This is the biggest river in Bangkok. Thai people use this river for transportation. Don't forget to take a tour or ride a boat when you're in Bangkok.Check the flag on the boat before you jump in. Different flag means different fare.Blue flag is the most expensive because it's for tourist.Check the map also to check which pier that the boat stop before you embark.

Dinner Cruise. For our last stay in Thailand, my parents and I decided to try Dinner Cruise at Chao Phraya River.The place was nice but the event was not organized. We didn't know if it was our turn to ride the ship. We just followed the people in the entrance. When we reached the front area, the attendants told us we need to wait for a different ship. They asked us to go behind the line but since people were already going inside the ship, we were sorta got trapped.After a few minutes of being bumped by people, finally, someone assisted us. We waited several minutes for our ship.When we got in, the ship was very nice. The food was okay. The experience was delightful. There was a live entertainment that my mom really loved.We get to see different views of temples and the Palace. I'm glad we did the Dinner Cruise even if it was quite expensive.

Best mean of travelling and enjoying!. Heart of the city! I never saw such a public transport before - boat service in a big city - so was really impressed! My hotel was close to pier 1, from where I would catch a boat to pier 8-9 for the sightseeing spots. The hotels, temples, buildings seen by the river are beautiful, especially at night when they are nicely lit up.

A somewhat tranquil place among the hustle & bustle. A nice place to walk along, take in, or take a ferry along the river as a different way of exploring the city. The views are beautiful, and the air is a little fresher near the river. If you happen to be down near the river in the evening stay to watch the sunset, it is magnificent.

Bangkok's water vein !. When you're in BKK it's quite hard to avoid the river - it is definitely the life vein of the city. We frequently used the water taxi and it's a cheap way (15 baht one way) to explore the waterfront and hop on and off where you think it's worth a stop. Unfortunately it isn't the cleanest river with a lot of garbage on the surface and the waterfront is not that spectacular or typical, but yet we enjoyed the breeze during our cruises more than the freezy aircon in MTR and BTS. Just do it !

Must take a boat tour. Taking a boat ride from the Central Pier off BTS Saphan Taksin Station to attractions like Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Wat Arun is a good experience and cheap (40 THB). It is also a convenient way instead of taking a taxi and found yourself stuck in a bad traffic for hours. The river is a bit muddy and is vey busy with tour and local boats speeding around. Also, be careful getting on and off the ferries as the piers are always overcroweded with people.
I love the river. I must say without this Bangkok will lose its beauty. This alone can be an attraction or on the other is also one of the main mode of transport.

Go only with a local guide and have a personalized adventure. We booked a day tour with Thai Private Tour Guide and Am provided us with an amazing boat ride. Instead of the long, sweaty, frustrating lines, we were whisked to the front and had our own personal boat tour.On the tour, Am stopped and bought us loaves of fresh bread to feed the fish. It was a highlight to watch the fish jump out of the water!Also, Am pointed out all of the attractions along the river, which was an excellent way to see all of Bangkok.We only had one day in Bangkok and were glad we booked Thai Private Tour (see review for them as well) and had a boat tour away from the crowds with our personalized, tailored adventure of Bangkok by boat.

Best thing. I really enjoyed the river. I used the ferries to get around (most of the big temples and important sight seeing spots are on the riverside or near enough as doesn't matter, so they all have designated landing sites) and took a Khlong river tour twice.Be aware that the ferry ports are very busy and not well sign posted, so keep your wits about you. Also, be aware of scam artists, who hang around on or near official ports, I got taken in by one at one point! (I didn't mind, I enjoyed myself anyway!) The water is pretty dirty, so have a care not to ingest any.

The river is the best way to get around. I enjoyed the boat as a quick means to get to the different important sites like the temples and grand palace as you can get there in 15 minutes and also gives the real feel of the Thai life.However the river itself is deep and very very dirty so make sure you dont touch or swallow any water . The boats also have not much safety equipment so you are taking a risk, but hey thats the way of life in the east. You can pay on the boat for the ticket so dont que up before just have lots of 20 baht change.

This is the heart of Bangkok. I love the river. This is the heart and spirit of Bangkok. If you want relaxed and easy access to the Palace or to the great temples or to the flower market or to Ko San Road, the public ferry will take you there for less than $1 US. It will be packed with locals, including monks and students so you get to see a cross-section of Thai people. Feed the fish to give yourself some good Karma. Eat a snack at a local food shop. I love this more than any other part of this great city.
Great way to see Bangkok . Worth a visit when discovering Bangkok! Easy and cheap to go to a wharf and pay 25 baht to get on board a local ferry and take it to the other end of the river!

Short ride on the Chao Phraya River. We crossed the Chao Phraya River twice while going to the Asiatique Market. We had taken the free ferry ride to go there. It was a very short ride on the river and not much could be explored.

Confusing boat ride. We arrived at one of the stops but it wasn't clear where we had to buy tickets. Several companies stop at most stops. They told us to buy them on the boat. We were on the boat for a while but no-one came because people kept getting on and off. Appearantly you have to go up to the usher responsible for ticketing
Beautiful view. Use the ferries to navigate the river. Beautiful scenery of the bangkik skyline. Do this whule visting the various temples on either side

River boat cruise. We went on a cruise along the Chao Praya River on a boat called Princess 3. We enjoyed international buffet dinner on board. Food was good mixture of western & thai. Quite a good spread. Better to cruise at night where you don't see the rubbish floating on the river. Otherwise no complaints. My cruise was arranged by Oriental Escape agent. I suggest that you book your seats on the upper deck for a better view and preferably book the newer boat called Princess V. Much more spacious and elegant looking. Cost of the cruise is 1000BHT per person which is most reasonable for cruise and dinner. Goggle chao praya river cruise in Bangkok for more details

You should always try Express Boat on Chao Phraya River. The river has many beautiful views, which would only be seen from the boat. And the Express Boat is not only convenient but also very cheap, and a good way to avoid traffic jam in the city. There are several kinds of the boat, which are distinguished by different color of flags, e.g. a boat with blue flag is for tourists, which only stops on sight spot and takes 40B for one trip; a boat with orange flag is much more cheaper, which takes only 15B and stops in much more piers and ordinary Thai people are also taking it for daily traffic. You can also spend more money to have private trip on boat. This service could be find in many piers. And there is a free boat service from Central Pier to and from AisaTique every 15 mins after 16:00 everyday. Make sure you can make use of this good service. :P

The river is dirty! . This is a one of nice way if you want explore the city by a boat. Grand Palace, Wat Arun and the others. They will transit to every small harbour they had to fulfill the tourist. Don't ever expect the clean nice river. Brown water, trash everywhere , evenmore the disgusting smell. I will never going with this again.
Nice and exotic. I like to see the view and people who live around the river .Had the dinner and night trip along the river ,is the unique experince .

Avoid the Tourist Boats. This is a great way to get to the old city, the Grand Palace, Wat Arun, Wat Pho, while seeing the city of Bangkok from another perspective. The locals take the regular boat (10-20 Baht) with the fare collected on the boat. There are also booths trying to sell tickets to tourists. These are much more expensive but I was informed they do provide some tour guide information. I doubt the 150 Baht all day pass would ever pay off. Yes, the water seems dirty but one could say the same thing about Venice or Shanghai.

a good way to discover the City by boat. unfortunatly most of the spped boat desappeared like the famous Tuk Tuk. however there are many boats which can be used to travel from one place to another oike a bus on water, and you can rent a boat to go and visit temples built along the river. WAtching the trafic is also interesting. so many boats are using the river. From multi barges "train" to small fishing boats or house on water. kms of river will surpise you all the time.The river is unfortunatly very dirty...

All day river pass THB 150. After 9.30am (and all day weekends) THB 150 will buy you an all day boat pass on the river valid for the public boats and the tourist boats running up and down between the numbered piers. It is the way to travel. The river connects more places than the metro, the skyrail or anything fighting the traffic on the roads. It is not the world's most scenic cruise as the river is the prime heavy lifter but enough temples, pagodas, five star hotels and shopping centres (not mall size) are along the way to keep it interesting, and even the pieces between have a certain charm. If you take the popular trip from Central (Taskin Bridge) to stop N8 opposite the Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun), then a further THB 3 (10c US, 6p UK, €0.10) pays for a ferry across - every few minutes. And the Temple's worth it as its (relative) isolation makes it less busy and if you take the near vertical steps up, some terrific views.

Great cheap way to see the city and escape the heat. Getting on the ferry with the locals and seeing Bangkok from the river is a great experience. The express ferry boat (not the tourist boat) runs every 20 mins from dawn to dusk. One way as far as you like is 15 Bhat which is about 30p. Only thing to watch out for is the engine towards the back of the boat is quite noisy so sit towards the front. You can buy your ticket on the boat and the ticket person is easy to spot as they come around shaking a tin.

Ok. The river is nothing special from the parts I saw in the boat between central stop 1 and 9. It's pretty dirty and varies in terms of what is on the river front from 5 star hotels to run down properties. To fair maybe I cannot expect much more but expect in 10 years there will be a lot of new development as old buildings get knocked and replaced by new. It's a shame I couldn't find any specific walks along the river front.

Locomotion. I would say that the Chao Praya River is more a transportation option than anything else. Since the traffic in Bangkok can be very bad , the river can be the best option, of course, depending where you go.Some hotels offer private boats to certain piers.There are some boats where you can have dinner . Nice chance to see the city illuminated from the river.

Efficient way to get around. I’m reviewing the portion that runs through the west side of Bangkok. It’s a nice, wide waterway made for easy commuting and sight-seeing. Highly recommended over a taxi if you want to see Wat Arun, Grand Palace, and Wat Pho – take the BTS SkyTrain’s Silom Line to Saphan Taksin station, then board a ferry. I liked seeing all the skyscrapers to locals’ homes to historic sites all from a quick boat ride. The river bustles with day-to-day life as well as commerce. I knocked off a point because we were overcharged by an unscrupulous staffer on the ride heading back. We tried to fight it but were unsuccessful.

Iconic but had better days. If you have never been on it, a boat ride up and down it can still be an eye-opener. The banks are more gaily decorated when there are royal events on but it looks rather drab on other days. If you are a shopper, stick to the Siam area...

Take a local ferry down the river.... This river adds to the beauty that is bangkok. We were lucky enough to be able to walk from our hotel to where the ferry stopped, and then make our way down to the royal palace and the reclining buddha sites. Take the local ferrie's, they are quick, tourist friendly and cheap. Enjoy the river, and it's aspects.

Chao Phraya Tourist Boat. We used the Chao Phraya Tourist boat to get to several of the major tourist sites in Bangkok, including Wat Arun, the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. It's easy to access Sathorn Pier (Central) from the Saphan Taksin station of the BTS Skytrain.You can get a day ticket for unlimited rides for 150 baht, but a single trip ticket is only 40 baht. Since we tended to go to just one major attraction a day, we bought two one way tickets. If you do this, you need to be aware that you have to buy a ticket before boarding the boat at some stops while at others you can get one on board the boat.There's plenty to see from the river, and it's refreshing to get the breeze and a rest while cruising up and down the river. There is a guide narrating the journey in English and in Thai, but sometimes it was hard to hear over the engine and the general noise. It didn't matter since it was clear where you were most of the time. The step on and off the boat could be a bit intimidating - except for Central, they don't stop and tie up the boat properly - the captain just pushes the boat up to the pier and everyone jumps on and off. Could be a health and safety nightmare, but the crew will help you on and off if it seems like you need it.

Had a great ride in a speedy Longtail Boat!. We enjoyed a 90 minutes boat ride in one of those nice, slim and super-fast long0tail boats. They take you over the large river and then through sluices into the canals of the city. It is a nice way to see more of Bangkok.
Chao Phraya River ride. Had a chao phraya river ride along with the temple tour. The overall package with the boat ride, feeding the fishes and cruise lunch was good.

Busy. Went on the river to experience it. First of all you have to wait for your boat and then wait for the boat to arrive - no signage or timetable, just listen to a lady shouting out orders. Then push your way onto the boat and make sure you push your way out to get off at hopefully the right place. Could have missed it.
smelly. handy for transport v cheap .. all boat tix £3better than using the roads ..pretty quick too n scenic

River view travel. Me and my friends got on a 1,5 h boat-trip around in Bangkok. we were told that we could get of if we wanted to see/do something. We paid a upfront a overprized ticket.. When onboard we weren't allowed to get off at any place, we got the slowest and the most noisy boat on the river. we were all very dissapointed and when i asked for a symbolic refound for 1,5 h waste of time, the manager started to argue and yell at us. River view travel was the name of the company. Spend your Money somewhere else. Or at least make sure several times you can get of where you want. (The managers answer why we couldn't get off?- it would have cost 30 baht / place in parkingticket. sooo what? I would gladly give them the double just to get off)
excellent boat ride. we took a boat ride through this river and it was an unforgettable experience..its right across houses on both sides....amazing ride it was !!
Energetic. Loved the excitement and business of the river. Much cooler and lots of good fun taking the local boat as far as you can up the river for 15 baht a person!

Nice cruise. I like the services and the trip are nice and you can see different view of bangkok during sunset! well the charges are worth every penny spend with lovely services, helpful guide and excellent thai food!

Relaxing boat cruise and awesome skyline.. Within easy reach for tourists, affordable.. Do not miss other tourist attractions which are nearby. Grand Palace, Temple of Dawn, and if we are not mistaken, the Eminent Bhudda as well. A short taxi ride will take you to Victory Monument. Our disappointment was not able to go inside the Grand Palace because we did not know it closes at 4 pm. We came after visiting Tailing Floating Market which we truly enjoyed the experience and the feasting . Unbelievable, able to see all these places in one trip. We did not see the Eminent temple also because we assumed on a see one see all basis.Tailing Floating Market is a small market, but it did not disappoint . We struggled with having to travel 100 km to see the main floating market where all the tourists go or the easy one and we were glad to make the correct decision . We met German and Canadian tourists who made similar choice.

Bangkoks bustling waterway. A trip along the Chao Phraya gives you a great opportunity to see both sides of Bangkok from the modern and hi-tec to the old temples and older ways of life. The river is very busy night or day and it seems incredible that there are not more accidents as it seems very chaotic. Masses of Water hyacinth flow down the river along with monitor lizards and various other forms of wildlife and birdlife, the taxi boats tear about at breakneck speed alongside the huge barges, it really is an eye opening experience.

Day or night, simply many things to do!. Chao Phraya River is the main river flowing through Bangkok and there are so many sights that you can visit along the river during day time or to get a nice dinner cruise by night. I did both and I can recommend that both of them needs to be done if you are over there! You can find really good deals for the dinner cruise and the last around 2.5 hours with buffet dinner, and you get to see all the main sightseeing by night. During day time, get a daily ticket for the Chao Phraya Boat service that costs 150 TBH and take the boat from the main platform near BTS station Saphan Taksin, and just hop off and on in every sightseeing that the tourist guide will say. Chinatown, Grand palace, Oriental Pier... and many more! Enjoy!

Great Way to See the City. I've visited Bangkok several times and gotten stuck in traffic or watched the city pass by while on the BTS, but this time, I stayed in Silom, near the Central Pier (and a BTS station) and I have to say, the river is the best! The ferries make visiting the hard to get to spots ...easy! And how cool is it to see a reclining Buddha from a boat...

If you want a taste of the local life.... This was a good way and cheap way of travelling around to visit Temples in Bangkok, the boats were often, but don't expect to get a seat or sit in luxury, this is the boat which the locals used as their access to work, which I loved being a part of, but thought they needed more care. Still worth doing though.

The Hub. There are many things to do around the Chao Phraya. Go down by the Flower Market and you'll get plenty of ideas. At night they light all the boats and have fireworks in the evening. It looks great from the Sky Bar at the top of LeBua Tower. Many day trips stem from the river. The long tail boats ripping up and down are a hoot. Get a ride from down by the flower market.

Night time is better. We did a 2 hour evening cruise with a meal and the illuminated sights were very good, but difficult to photograph. Most of the passing ferries, water taxis and cruise boats are attractively illuminated. The on board entertainment was of mixed quality but the food was plentiful and the service crew were good. Having them salute you on arrival and departure seemed a bit over the top though. We also did a longer one way daytime cruise back from a tour and the riverside sights that were revealed were often less attractive than those on the evening cruise, with plenty of ramshackle waterfront houses and derelict boats strangely mixed up with temples and ornate landing stages. The river does seem to be abused as well as used by the locals. All part of the character of the area, but often rather unattractive. The riverside buildings in the city centre did seem to look better when illuminated at night rather than in daylight.

Busy Chao Praya. Chao Praya river never fail its commuters who enjoy and need to travel on it.Tourists boats ferry anxious happy tourists on its banks and you can see the golden lovely sights of temples beaming in the sun. It even stop for tourists to feed the fishes for a while before continuing its journey.You can also book a cruise on the Thai cruise where it also serve lunch or dinner with a traditional dance.Nice relaxing ride in the Chao Praya river.

A memorable experience... Not for the faint hearted.. hahaTake the express boat for 100+baht from taksin to the reclining budha temple dropoff. The experince is something youll NEVER forget ;) its really fun.. be sure not to speak and laugh during the boat trip.. heheADVICE: take the back seats..Cover much parts of your body too ;)Most dropoff demands 20 baht payment..

so so. Famous river in the middle of the city. Has some charm and reminded me of how Bangkok must have been in times gone by, but it isn't that clean and on my boat trip could smell and see the pollution.

Chao Phraya River. Some interesting trips up and down the river,definitely take a boat trip up the Klongs (the waterways of Bangkok) or across to Wat Arun or futher afield to Auttaya historical park to see the ancient ruins. Also take a night trip on one of the floating restaurants

Take tourist boat, not cruise. There are tourist boats at regular intervals travelling up and down the river to the most popular tourist sites. You can get a day pass if you want to hop on and off, or 30baht per trip. Great way to travel in Bangkok, as roads are so congested. You get to see the sights of the city from a great perspective. Can get really busy, but highly recommended. Only drawback is that the different piers change a bit tricky to locate!

nice ferry ride on river. ferry ride gives you the nice insider view of the city, and also tells you the prosperity of the city. It also gives good view of many city sky scrappers. It is must to have the ferry ride on the river. Choose from your budget.
Just OK. The cruise on this river didn't meet my expectation, may be its better going for night cruise then day cruise, there weren't many tourist around, water was muddy.

Easier than other public transport. The river taxi is super cheap, though not that easy to find. The place I stayed (Phiman Riverview Guesthouse) was right on the river and in between two stops. Not recommended for swimming as there's a lot of pollution going in there, and if you see something floating, it's best to just look away and not try to guess what it is. Tons of tourist boats going back and forth constantly in addition to the taxi and the longtail boats, and also barges can often be seen.

Great alternative to travel in BKK. The river taxi which plies along the Chao Phraya river is a good alternative to the public transport system. This method is a cheap way to reach the Grand Palace. Take the river taxi from Sathorn Pier and alight at Tha Chang pier. One way costs between 15-20Thb, depending whether the service is semi express or not. The boats can be very crowded during the peak hours - just like the trains and buses which ply around the main roads. It's a great and affordable way to see the sights along the river.

Real Bangkok. The Chao Phraya is an excellent way to get around, if you catch the public ferries you are rubbing shoulders with real Bangkok. The main terminal is below the Sapphan Taksin BTS station. You can go with the touts who approach you for "Luxury Cruise" or "Guided River Tour" especially if you have limited time and/or knowledge. But for good fun, join the queues of locals near the proper wharf and take an ordinary ferry. This is certainly the best way to go to the Grand Palace. You pay your fare on board (have some change handy - fares range between 10 and 40 baht depending on the type of ferry and distance.) Hold out your coins and try to pronounce the name of where you're going. The ticket-sellers are quick and efficient.We like taking the ferry all the way to the terminal at Nonathonburi (not sure of that spelling) potter around the local market, have lunch at the Chinese cafe on the riiver downstream from the wharf, and then take the ferry back to town, but we allow ourselves a relaxing non-shopping day for that expedition.

A couple of rides is all you need.... It isn't necessary to take a long journey or do an organised tour to get a feel for the river. Organising a walk that takes in a few hops gives you the full flavour. To just get across can cost as little as 3 Baht. One thing that is a little confusing is knowing which boat is public transport and which is the more expensive tourist launch... an easy way of figuring that it is just to look at the majority of the people in the queue!

great way to get around the city, cool and fascinating. Traveling around Bangkok using the Chao Phraya ferries and the canal boats is on of the fastest and easiest options for getting loads of places. You can connect to a ferry stop using the skytrain so it makes traveling by car seem crazy. Enjoy the break from the traffic and get there quickly. How great is that! Also an evening cruise is a restful cool way to end the day.

River Taxis. If you have a little time, jump on a river taxi from anywhere, take a seat a relax as you watch the city pass you buy. They start at the southern end close to Sathorn (or this is the best place to start) and go all the way up to Pathum Thani in the north of the city. The boats are a great way to see the city and allow you to leave and join at many of the best sites (Wat Arun, Grand Palace and many more). You could, of course, just spend an hour criss-crossong the river and enjoying the view, as I do frequently.

A nice boat ride. We enjoyed a boat ride down the Chao river. It was a nice way to see the sights of Bangkok including the hospital where the King is, the palace, fishermen, Singha brewery, housing, etc. We didn't stop at any places along the way as we were with a group, and perhaps that would make it more of a must see. Without stopping anywhere I considered it a nice boat ride, but not a huge cultural experience.

Convinient but Dirty. This is the major river flowing through Bangkok.You can take one hour or 4 hour cruise.Also you can take ferries or boats to go visit attractions. I took the boat from Grand Palace to Wat Arun and took 10 min and 3 Bhat one way. The river is used mainly for transportation and the water is dirty.

The real Babgkok. The river is still a very important transportation system for Bangkok. Huge barges tug up and down the river. Long boats roar past and school kids, monks and locals use the public ferries. Lots of hotels have courtesy ferries to take you across the river or off to shopping malls. For me catch a local public ferry. Jump on and the ticket lady will charge you a few baht. Start at Taksin bridge a,d go to the Royal Palace or Wat Po. It is a real experience.

it is amazing trip. it was amazing trip with both side view of the river.it shows the natural life for the other side of the city, how they live near the river and they depend on the river on most of their lives. it worth for the try.

Explore the river with the hop-on-hop-off boat.. See Bangkok on the other side, the Chao Phraya River. The Chao Phraya Express runs regularly between the different piers it frequented. Since Bangkok was built next to the river, therefore most of the historical sites are located near the river. Put on your loose clothes and comfortable shoes and explore Bangkok by the river on the CPE and your feet. It is the cheapest and the most enjoyable way to know the city. Beside the sightseeing of historical sites, there are several market places where you can pick up your quick lunch like Pad Thai, etc. Your day in Bangkok can be as exciting as your night!!!

Ferry Ride. this is a 3 Baht ride that allows you to see the side of Bangkok that a lot of tourists don't even take the time to see Crossing this river lets you visit the Medical Museum ,the Wang Lang Market and much more. Get off the organized tours and try these things on foot

must include river. Bangkok trip is not complete without this! period, if you have only one evening to spend out in bangkok city, go to the nearest express boat or ferry docks and take a boat ride up/down the river. You will see a few attractions even without getting off the boat. We took an express boat from central pier outside Siam BTS station and travelled to N.8, cost per person 40 THB

Awesome place!. You can get to most attractions using the ferries and various boats. There are tons of places along the river to get a good view. It's crowded, isn't the most clean water, but it's a great artery through Bangkok. Gotta do it!

The easiest way to see multiple attractions . Catch the BTS train to S6 then walk down to the water and buy yourself a ferry day pass for 150 Baht . That gets you a day pass and a book telling you what attractions are along the river and how to get there . There is enough to do along the river to keep you busy the whole day . At night there a various points along the river to catch the lights of the city of Bangkok . This is one of the attractions cannot miss if visiting the city .

River & Canal cruise with Tuk Tuk transfers. This is a trip we made up on the spur of the moment and it turned out to be a great half day well spent. We walked out the front of our Hotel (Pathumwan Princess) and a spruiker talked us into a Tuk Tuk ride to the River for 5 THB each (we had planned to catch the Skytrain). On the way we stopped at a classy jewellery store and a tailor store. We didn't plan on doing this but we agreed to it because it helped the drivers get free petrol vouchers from the stores as commission, and we were not in a rush anyway (I ended up buying 4 beautiful shirts that were delivered to the Hotel). The ride was exciting to say the least, and much more fun than taking the Skytrain ! The river cruise we chose went for 2 hrs (you can select less time) for 3000 THB ($110 AUD) for 3 Adults & 1 Teenager. It is really quite amazing to see how the locals live their lives along the river and canals. It is such a shame about the condition of the river as far as pollution goes. Hopefully one day they will realise the effects it is having on their environment and clean it up.

How is this an attraction?. I mean really, it is full of dirt, wreckages , noisy boats and oil . We used it 2-3 times from Khao San to take the BTS , i did not enjoyed it , i liked the suspended metro much more as mean of transport or the taxi when i had my zen mood on .
must do. if you have time in the evening this is a must do in every traveler itinerary in bangkok for the first timer.

Chao Phraya River Bangkok. Dont book on an organised tour, you will be be overcharged, take the BTS skytrain to Saphan Thaksin station which is right on the river, from there the river boat buses run all the time, dont go on a boat with a guide it is more expensive and you just cannot hear what the guide says, they just shout into the microphone non stop which becomes annoying,Just buy a cheap ticket on the normal river boat bus, go Northbound, that has the best views, Southbound is just factories and industry, go as far as Nontaburi, about a 30 min ride, nice views on the way, get off at Nontaburi which has a market and places to eat then get back on the boat bus and take the trip back to Saphan Thaksin, a very pleasant and enjoyable trip.
River of King. Choa Phraya River in Bangkok is good for sightseeing along the river bank by Cho Phraya Express Boat the Local Boat service

Must do. No visit to Bangkok is complete without a trip on the Chao Phraya River. Serveral different options, have lunch, Sunday Brunch or dinner at one of the many hotels with their free boat service from Taxin BTS station. Book a long tail boat tour from Taxin station. Or take the local ferry to China town and its market from Taxin station.

River Cruise on Chao Phraya. The Chao Phraya river is a must visit for any tourist to Bangkok.There are cheap cruises available, however taking the local Motorized Canoe with a covered top beats it all. That canoe can take you to the small in-water lanes with houses next to the river.There is a place where one can feed the fish and get off to see the famous temples.Very scenic tour indeed.

Fast way to get to several attractions. The river taxi might be one of the faster ways to hit several attractions that are along the river, including the Grand Palace, several temples, Chinatown, and the Sririraj Medical Museum (not for the faint of heart). Taxis may have to wind around or be stuck in traffic but the river taxi is fast and direct. If you don't want the Chao Phrya Tourist boat with tour guide that costs 150 baht for unlimited rides, just take the 15 baht one-way river taxi that the locals (and increasingly, tourists) use. Check the map/sign at the jetty to see which taxi flag color you want (some only run weekdays), and tell it to the person selling tickets. Weekends - it is usually the orange line.

Ride on a steamer. Visit to Bangkok is incomplete without a ride on the steamers which run left right and centre through this river. The steamers have however polluted the waters but it acts as an extremely easy way for many islanders to reach their destinations quickly and easily.

SCAM Alert. If you walk along the main street towards the big temples Thais will approach you, pretending they are tourists or teachers mentioning that there is a big bank holiday today and a special offer on a River (Market) Cruise.
They will even help you get a cheap Tuk Tuk to the place.
Say thank you and walk away.

Take the river tour. If you want to see the life of bangkok people, you should take the river tour.it will take you to see places that even normal bangkok people don't get to see.you can stop by at temples or markets along the way

boat trip. will recomadent first a day trip, than take the taxi boat from shangrila go upsterem for 1-1.5 hrs stop and buy some local food se the people sit down, it is intresting to go witout a guide
in the evneing take a resturant boat with bufe for example from shangrila,orientel.ps you my bring your own favorite wine,

Do not take a tour, it gets better. If you want to see the river take a water taxi to the top and back to the BTS train station great views, quick and simple. If you want to do a dinner cruise, do not pick one of the big boats, go with http://www.yokyor.co.th/english/yokyor/promotion-boontarika.htmlAla carte menu and its 100 bht for the cruise.... and you sit on the roof of the boat..... Better food. It only sails at 8pm. You need to be on the boat by 7 30 ordering food... AMAZING

Good for transport from Saphan Taksin BTS. The Chao Praya is a nice change from taxis, motorbikes & tuk tuks in BKK. A good way to get along some of the major tourist attractions in BKK. Connects to Saphan Taksin BTS stop. Make sure when lining up for the river taxi, to be in the 15 baht queue.One under-rated attraction available via the river ferry is the Sirijaj Medical Museum.

Worth a visit. Water is filthy with all sorts of litter and weeds floating around. Had an all day unlimited ferry pass too look up an down the river was cheap. Worth a journey on jus to see what sort of different boats they had and all the buildings on river frontage from millions pound hotels to floating wood huts. Further inland there is loads of fish at a few of the stops ( can't remember which ones) But that's interesting seeing a swarm of 100s of fish get 1 wotsit!

Orange ferry. Make sure you have a map showing all the piers along the river, starting at e.g pier 0 called Sathon, just near Skytrain station Taksin. Take the orange flag ferry that stops at all the piers northbound. Frequency: about 3 or 4 times per hour. Price always 15 baht. Can be crowded, but this is the way to get the west side of Bangkok that has no metro or skytrain.

1 Day Bangkok River ticket - Hop on and off. If you are looking for a boat trip up and down the Bangkok river (Chao Phraya) that allows you to also site see by getting off and on (like many a city open top bus ticket) then may I suggest the following solution and not get pushed onto a one those (expensive) fast boat rides.For 150 Baht per person you can get a ‘1 day’ river pass and combine this with a day’s site seeing adventure.Having just visited the Siam centre, we took the Sky Train Silom Line to Saphan Taksin station (34 bhat) exit the train station and bear left at the bottom of the stairs - ignoring the ‘Fast’ boat ride men trying to catch everyone coming off the train. You are looking for a small kiosk selling the ‘Chao Phraya Tourist Boat’ one day river pass – Don’t get distracted.For your 150 Baht you will get your ticket and small booklet (with map) indicating the nearest and ‘How to walk there’ instructions for the common sites to see along the different piers that the boat stop’s at. For example Pier 9 is right next to the back of the Grand Palace, not that you would know walking down the road. Most of the Piers have some market stall’s or other distractions covering the entrances, so if you are picking the boat up at one of the other Piers you need time to find them.The Boat service starts at 09:00 from the Central Pier and the last boat returns at 22:30 (time table included), so you get a full day and also you are able to see the river at night and all the lights etc.Piers include – Central, No.1, No.3, No.5, No.8, No.9, No.10 and No.13 – Our hotel was no where near the river, so starting at the Central Pier using the train to get there was our best option. If you are close to the river, then I suggest you ‘Google’ the river and find your nearest Pier from the list as your starting point.Naturally you won’t see everything using this service, and you may have to purchase other tickets and other trips to see specific points of interest, but it’s a good starting point and during a long day just sitting on the boat going up and down may be all that’s required.Enjoy

Amazing. The Chao Phraya River is a major transport route through the huge city of Bangkok. We sat and watched the river taxis, water buses, restaurant cruisers and huge giant barges towed by tugs moving up and down the river or simply criss-crossing from bank to bank in apparent chaos. Wonderful to watch by day, beautiful to watch by night with the highly-decorated vessels lit in numerous colours. Many of the hotels front onto the river and have bars and restaurants along the waterside. It is also possible to take a high speed long boat along the river, then passing through a lock, into a labyrinth of canals where you can see another side of amazing Bangkok!

Best Part Of Bangkok. Having A Boat Tour Along CHAO PHRAYA River Is A Thing You Must Do When Visit Bangkok. With beautiful View Along 2 Sides Of The River. Start The Tour From Central Pear Seeing The Big And Beautiful Hotel Like Sheraton, Shangrila, Mandarin Oriental, Peninsula And etc, Then You Will See The Beautiful And Stunning View Of Temple Of Dawn (Wat Arun), Grand Palace. My Most Impressive Part is The View Of Rama 8 Bridge. Couldn't Say More. You Must Experience it Yourself And You'll Never Ever Forget CHAO PHRAYA River,
chaopraya river. its one of the cheap transportation, you can see beautiful iew along the river unfortunately there are some dead fishes and the river is quite dirty.

Fun way to beat the BKK traffic. Although the river isn't very clean and you can see garbage and debris floating by the moorings, it beats being stuck in traffic in the heat.Best way to get to the temples IMO.

Cheap way to visit and sight-see in Bangkok. We took a cruise up and down the river viz the Chao Phraya express boat. There are a total of 5 boat services-no colour, green, yellow,orange and blue flag boats all serving different no of stops along the river. We bought the 150 baht blue flag boat tickets (tourist boat) which allows us to visit various tourist stops accessible along the river eg grand palace, chinatown etc.In fact, we got to understand that the tourist ticket can also be used to board all the other boat services (used mainly by the locals) for unlimited times throughout the day. The tourist boat ticket can be bought at Central Pier directly and comes with a booklet detailing the various sight seeing spots -very good, cheap way to move around and see the various tourists spots if you have a day to spare and do pier hopping.http://www.chaophrayaexpressboat.com/en/home/From the same central pier, there is also a free boat shuttle to Artisque ( many dining options) from 5pm forth.

Cruising the river is a must do activity.. A Chao Phraya River cruise is a must do activity when you visit Bangkok. Take a high speed long boat to see the sights, particularly the backwater canals. It's an exhilarating ride and you do get to glimpse the life lived by people who rely on the river for their livelihood. Note of caution though - don't overpay for your one hour ride. We were charged 1500 BAHT for our party of four as an example.
River life worth seeing.. It is great to get out on a river boat to watch life on this busy river.It is also a very useful and inexpensive transport option.Gotta be done when in Bangkok.

DO IT!. Take the BTS to Taksin (usually have to change at Siam) and walk to the pier (down the stairs and too the right). If you go to the left, you can walk over the bridge over the Chao Phraya....and it is great to just watch the boats and energy. Take the less expensive boat up the river (a few baht....like 30) and you can go up almost 2-3 stops. Keep going and take it in. The river is the original economic core of the city, so this area is a must see. Some of the food along the river stops is a littler more expensive, but it is actually good. Try the Peninsula hotel lounge for a beer or tea if you have a few baht to kill......it is a fantastic "watch".

Great way to get round many tourist sites. A very busy working river with loads of traffic. The river taxis can get very busy so we took the tourist boat which cost 150 bhat for the day. It stopped right outside our hotel and at all the important tourist spots up to Central Quay.

Cool Transportation. I always try to add boats and water to my journeys because it is such a different point of view from standing in the city. This also added a nice breeze to very hot days!The express boat is also a public transportation system and a wonderful way to see the historical sites. Highly recommend.

An essential part of the Bangkok experience. Catching the river ferry from the central terminal up to Khao San road is an essential part of your Bangkok experience and dirt cheap as well. Enjoy the scenes of real Bangkok river life, but keep your mouth closed to avoid the water spray!

Worth just to watch. All boats and ferries are so nice to watch when the cross and cross the river fast from a place to another. Nice to just sit and watch Bankok wakes up and people need to take the ferry to their jobs,schools and so on. Lots of shops, places to buy drinks, water and so on.
try to ger a hotel overlooking the river. you can sit and watch for hours. take a boat ride- also a private one to the canals circling the city. it is wonderful

I love to sit by the river and sip tea. There are many hotels by this river and I love sitting and watching boats pass by. It has a calming effect. Only negative thing is that this river is dirty, a cleaning project is long over due.

A ride which is not worth my life!. We wanted to get to the Grand Palace from Sathorn Pier. I think we took a wrong decision of getting tickets at the counter which was right at the entrace. They put us on a long tail boat with no proper life jackets and the river was literally bouncing up and down. I had a hard time convincing myself to get on that boat and for about 15 mins had put my 2 young children in a very dangerous position. Ask to see the boats before buying your tickets unless you are a thrill seeker.

Excellent way to travel around Bangkok. Once we left the airport, we never took a land taxi. The water taxis are a convenient, economical way to travel to the main tourist sites. The river is pleasant and less crowded than the city proper.
Pure Indian Cruise. The river princess is the best one especially for Indian !!The Host is really thumbs up...shes got excellent Voice with bollywood numbers.great indian food on board...

Fun to see.. We did have a hotel with a view on the river. Its was fun to see all the boats: pull-boats, longtailboats,fisherboats, ferrys, amd boats transporting clients for the differents hotels. The river is still very important for Bangkok.

ultimate experiance. bangkok Dinner Cruise, Chaophraya Cruise The truly exotic Thai Cruise Dinner and Large Modern luxury Cruise on Chaophraya River in Bangkok Thailand. me and my family enjoy indian dinner and dance there.
dinner cruise in the river. A great way to spend your night with family. The dinner cruise offers lovely view of the bangkok city in the night, cultural show on the cruise, and great food and wine.

Once visiting Bangkok you have to ride the ferry up the river. That is how you will be able to see what the city is like. The real people take the ferry. And the ferry takes you to most tourist attractions. Watch out which ferry you take. If you try pay more for the tourist ferry it takes longer for the next ferry to com. Don't buy ticket at the booth. Take the regular ferry and pay inside. You pay a fraction for the regular ferry and it comes faster. You will also see at a distant the hotel with the gold dome where Hangover 2 was filmed.

It's the life blood of Bangkok. Always busy, always active, the river flows through the centre of bangkok, between what is effectively the old and new cities, although today you would be hard pressed to notice the difference. The banks of the river are frequently packed with shacks desperate to squeeze in another few centimetres, and gain waterfront space, local boats act as 'water buses' constantly cross-crossing he river and large vessels ensure Thai trade continues to flow. It's alive, interesting and a trip along the old town river structure is a must for anyone new to the city.
great view. free shuttle boat arranged from BTS station, good sight seeing & shopping location, even though there will be a bit pricy

Not a river is a septic tank! highly overpriced, part of a TukTuk SCAM,. We were unwillingly taken to these boats by a Tuk Tuk, after being "persuaded" we accepted to sit down and talk to an agent who offered 1 hour tour for THB1800 for 2 ppl... Since you can do the same trip in a water taxi for less than THB300 we left. On our way out we met another disappointed couple who were being charged US90 for the same trip, after chatting we decided to go on a group and split the cost between the 4 of us.Ended up paying US 80 for the 4 of us and boarded the boat.On the way, we went trough the suburban houses at the bank of the river, I saw people trowing bags of rubbish to the river and at one point not to my surprise I saw a toilet door open where you could see that human waste goes straight to the water .. and we were all being splashed with this water in the face... so refreshing :) Then we happily eat the fish caught in this "river" served in "nice restaurants", get sick and wonder why... Looking at the hygiene standards of locals and the lack of reliable water and electricity systems, it is obvious that this river works directly as a septic tank and a dump.Then the trip is really not worth it, we basically traveled no more than 3 Kms at 10km/h, jumped out for 15 mins for sight seeing and went back to the pier.Horrible!
Watch the world go by.. I moved to hotel with a Riverview just so I could watch the river and its traffic. I rally feel like I'm in Bangkok when I'm on the river.
nothing special about it. Dark and Smelly water. Its good for transportation purpose or have a nice dinner on the one of nice restaurants on the bank of the river

Racing the Klongs. Going for a trip on Chao Phraya river is OK, but the best experience is to go for a boat trip through BKK Klongs. There you wil experience part of real life, maybe visiting floating market, or local fisherman. Offcourse it's very tourist oriented, but a must do visiting BKK.

Take a night river cruise. You will not regret it. It is a delight to see the bridges and temples from the water. Great food and local finger dancing is to be enjoyed. You can also partake in karaoke if you enjoy that, too.

Great views at night, but very crowded at day. It is good to see it from somewhere high.. being there you have a lot of good places to take pictures, especially the temples (Wat Arun, most).. in night it is more beautiful with the buildings lit, and less taxi boats around.

very terrible bad experience. Feel cheated.. rent a small engine boat for a 2 hour boat tour which recommend by local tuk tuk driver . It cost us 2,000 baht. Feel CHEATED. The person in charge promise to bring us to floating market from the jetty, but end up we stopped after the royal shipyard. 3 sampans came out and offer us some drink and snack (very expensive price). We end our journey after visit the Wat Rakang. Suggest to those who interested to visit the river, can take the ferry from the nearby jetty, which is much more cheaper.
love it everytime. I can't be in Bangkok and not have take the boat on the river. i just love it. You get a different view of the city this way

Great rivers of the world. It is one of my favourite days out wether we go on a dinner cruise or water taxi even the hotel shuttle boats I love this river it is majestic. When you drive over one of it,s bridges it is awe inspiring knowing how long it is and how powerful and the fact it shaped the dynasties that are now Thailand. Most of the roads in Bangkok were once canals all filled from this monster of a river it's diverse comers is unreal you can sit and watch the world go by from it's many backside Hotels restaurants and bars then come the night it is a different world. If you come to Bangkok do not miss this timeless treasure

Good for a hour or two trip up the river. Go on one of the free hotel shuttle boats or take a paid trip. Well worth it and a good way to while away a couple of hours of time. Much cooler down on the river than inland. We watched fish jumping about and you get a good view of the city from ten river. Go to Asiatic for a bite to eat or drink or just go from one side of Bangkok to the other. The new single cantilever suspension bridge is a feat of engineering marvel. Good fun.

River Trip to Nonthaburi. Guide books recommend a ferry trip to this large town about an hour upriver. We took the Express (orange flag) boat and the river itself was fascinating as always with plenty to look at. Unfortunately the town itself was a big let-down being generally grubby and run-down with pavements in a very poor state of repair. The town's biggest claim to fame is the huge food market selling everything eaten in Thailand - fruit, vegetables, fish, prawns, turtles, frogs, eels, etc., etc. This was all very interesting but the narrow passages between the covered stalls are quite claustrophobic and unpleasantly hot/humid - also you need a strong stomach in places. There are no facilities to eat and drink unless you wish to risk street stalls. Vast shoals of large fish gather at the ferry pier to be fed and reasonably clean toilet facilities can be found close by. The ferry only costs 15 Baht each way, paid on board to a ticket lady holding a tin can. On the trip up we were scammed as she did not issue us with tickets when we paid; an inspector boarded the ferry a few stops later and of course we could not prove that we had paid. We told him that we had paid but the ticket lady swore blind that we had not. The inspector obviously believed us (what tourist is going to argue about 30 Baht in total?) and he suspected that the ticket lady was just pocketing fares from tourists. He asked us to make an official complaint but we did not want to ruin our day by filling out forms and making statements so we just paid again. In conclusion, any trip on the river is absolutely fascinating but Nonthaburi is not worth a visit.

Riding Phraya river using small engined boat. Riding Phraya river is very interesting specially if you take a small boat with engine to watch the small wooden houses for poor Thai people. This part of Bangkok is showing important part of the simple people living on the river with basic life needs. Around the river you can see these small houses and new building at the same time. Recommend to go with small boat with driver to be your own guide through the river and stop wherever you want.

River of Live. in past till now, Thai people live and survive by the river. Chao Phaya River is the long way river which BKK people and Thai people reply on. If you visit BKK, you should take a chance to visit the Chao Phaya River by either express boat or longtail boat to see Thai's living style and culture, including the significant places along the river. I would recommend to go either morning or afternoon time. So it's not too hot. You can also experience the sun dawn in the evening time.

Best way to see Bangkok. A cruise on the Chao Phraya River is the best way to see Bangkok, from the high rises to the slums. Don't take a tourist boat. Take the Chao Phraya express boat. The orange flag boat costs only 15 baht and you can travel several kilometers from central Bangkok to Nonthanaburi. The view along the riverbanks is delightful. The boat has stops very convienient for Wat Phra Keo, Wat PO, Wat Arun and Khaosan road. At the Central pier you can connect with BTS skytrain to go just about anywhere in the city.
The river runs through it. It is fun and interesting to take commuter boat. You can see a lot of non tourists. I imagine how it's like to take the boat regulary.

My favorite "road" in Bangkok. To be travelled by the water bus, nicest and cheap way from one end of Bangkok to the other. My usual hotel is near Thaksin Bridge and by boat it takes less than 30 minutes to the old part of town.
Take the express boat to Nonthabury. A very cheap way (15 Baht) of watching the riverside. Nonthaburi itself is totally boring but the time on the river is awesome.
better to take the passenger boat. better to take the passenger boat service and travel through the river than paying huge amount for private boat for tourists.

Nice Tour. We had a tour on one of long boats, paid 900/- bath for 45 min tour. Quite worth for a family. Waters quite choppy in afternoon, only 2 life jackets in boat. A short stop near small boats selling some food and drinks along with small souvenirs.While returning back we decided to cutback our tour to Wat Arun as waters were very choppy, didn't felt safe with small kids. Overall good experience.
A very nice night out on a river cruise. I like to night out cruising on the river with great view. The food on board was ok. The view and the company you bring is what count.
Nice riding. You can travel fast at the river as a way of transportation to avoid traffic and see some temples of bangkok, but you should also go to dine at the apsara in this river.

Evening dinner ride in Chao Phraya river is must !!. It was a date with amazing evening where you are with your family and dinner at running big boat and good music.Dinner at boat was excellent and night view of city was adding life to everything we experienced there. Must to experience!!

Dinner cruise on river. Our family of 4 enjoyed a banquet cruise on the day of husbands 50th birthday. Good food - plenty of it and a dancer and birthday music - enough to embarass him - as well as a teddy as a gift. Beautiful cruise along the lit up buildings. I think we went round a few times.

Use the local boats. We travelled on the River as a way of making our way from our hotel to the Grand Palace and Wat Pho.We initially took a tourist boat which cost more and had aeros. Pointing out sights on the river. It's cheaper to use the local boats, a little more crowded and less comfortable, but it is fun!We found it a good way of getting round and seeing the sights on the river.The river is a sight in itself, travelling on the river for me was a highlight of Bangkok and is a must do!

First time floating in Bangkok. It was a new experience for me, i took a boat from tha prachan to the sky train station. it was fun at first but when a lot of people came in and the temperature at that moment. it make me sick, it really hot. instead of enjoyed the moment, i have wiped the sweat from my face. I will give another try when i back to Thailand again

Great way to take in the city. Whenever possible I love getting out on the waterways of a city. It is a great way to get an overview of the city. There are many options for crushing and dining here. A great way to escape the noise and businessness of the roads. Time well spent!

Memorable experience. If you visit Bangkok, you must visit the river.The kings palace and the Temple of the Dawn are on the river, you can catch them from the river.You can experience the downtown life of Bangkok .

Nothing special. Just like any river in the world, this one is not much different. Beautiful to look at in the night time, but it goes for any other river. A short boat ride across the river is kind of fun though

Dinner Cruise. Had a dinner cruise down the river and passed by the sites. Tour organized through our tour operator (Tong Tours). It was a nice warm night and we had a good time. The River also Knowns as Kings River is very important to Thai Culture and is an important water way running through the city.

Dinner Cruise and Lunch Buffet Cruise. me and my friend booked a dinner cruise to cruise the chao phraya river. it was fun, we saw the Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) at night. It's a beauty i can say. we spent like 2 hours for the dinner cruise. Then on our last day we booked a whole day tour to Ayutthaya and it includes a cruising the Chao Phraya again from Ayutthaya back to Bangkok so we saw what it's like in the afternoon.

This river is the essence of Bangkok. What a great river it is, full of the essence of Thailand. Steeped in history and culture thousands of years old, this is the place to see where Bangkok arose from, for without this river Bangkok would not exist; Temples litter the riverside, in between high rise condos and hotels or 5 star ambiance. Huge Dinner-Cruise ships travel up and down in the night adorned with lights that light up the river. In the day heavily laden barges festooned behind tiny tugs boats agonizingly make their way against the currents. occasionally a traditional one man canoe drifts past as the old men navigating them cast their nets out.Thai Ferry-Buses will take you for a 2 hour trip up the river for about 15baht! Or you can use the Tourist Ferry that will give you a running commentary BUT.... you can't get off without paying again once you get back on, I believe it is 150baht? each time you get on, whereas the Thai Ferry-Bus is only 15 baht each time. Perhaps travel up the river on the tourist boat and make a plan for on the way back to get on and off at the stops mentioned by the tour-guide (a bit of planning is needed). My favorite is Watt Arun (Temple of Dawn)you need to visit this at early morning or late evening to see the sun shine on it and sparkle in the light.Sanam Luang (near the Temple of the Jade Buddha - Watt Prakaew), walk along the streets and see people selling millions of buddhas in every form (some authentic, some not), many have set prices too. From here you are in proximity to many other places of interest such as Kings Palace, Sanam Luang, other temples, not far from Kao-San road, etc...The last stop is Nontaburi, not much to see or do there (unless you can find out something I don't know about). Finally just sit back and enjoy the ride, some great photo opportunities. Take some water, it's a long 1+ hour trip in the mid-day. From Saphan Thaksin BTS, you can also find people touting Long-Tail trips for about 1,500baht? (it's what I paid), they said for a 1 hour trip which ended up being 1.5 hours (no extra charge), we traveled along traditional canals with houses and temples all along, it was very entertaining and again, lots of photo op's. Well worth the Private-rented long tail (3 of us but could easily fit 8++. There are some options about where to go but my elderly parents didn't want to walk anywhere so we chose just to sit and travel the whole time.

Chao Phraya River. I took a 1 hours boat ride on the Chao Phraya river with 2 of my friends. It was extremely informally arranged. A guide went and personally made an arrangement with a random boat "driver" along the banks of the river. She clearly didn't want us to know how much money she was making out of this - she made us stand far away while she arranged it. Anyway...it turned out to be a very good experience. An excellent way to see Bangkok from an unconventional perspective. Sights include; small temples, houses - modern and traditional, fish-feeding. Definitely recommend this for anyone visiting Bangkok.

Boat ride on Chao Phraya River. Took a boat ride on a two hour trip by a fast long boat the one used in a James Bond movie. Never knew Bangkok had such an extensive water way to touch all major tourist spots and hop on and hop off. The Chao Phraya river divides the city North and South and is a lifeline to many small traders who go to the regular floating markets dotted across the city. Would recommend this to anyone who visits Bangkok for a few days.

A must do!. Julian, Australia: An excellent way to quickly see the sights of Bangkok from a dsitance. Would highly recommend the Grand Chao Praya River Cruise with international buffet dinner and entertainment.

I love the chaopraya river..... I visit the chaopraya river on a regular basis. It has such a wonderful atmosphere and there is loads to do. Sit outside and have lunch at one of the small pubs/restaurants at river city, take a ride on one the long tailed boats which will take you through some of the many canals, have lunch at one of the many riverside hotels or if you go in the evening, visit Asiatique. If the hustle and bustle of Bangkok gets too much, this is where you should go to. The BTS (Skytrain) is probably the quickest way to get here.
Boat ride. took a boat ride here.it was ok i guess.nothing special.still it was fun and you can see the city and the locals that lives near the river.
Must do. the only way to see the city of angels. Catch the tourist boat at step pan takin and see all the best spots. Best bête elm 9am and 3pm

Bustling alternative link to sights. We loved the River, you get to embrace daily life and immerse yourself with the local commuters, characters and colour of Bangkok. I'd definitely recommend buying passes for a couple of days to cruise along the river to the majority of the sights. the river itself is a little dirty, unloved and bordering on abused but it's a great way to travel through this vibrant metrolpolis and have all of your senses gently assaulted.

River Adventures!. Me and my friends decided to go for a ride at the Chao Phraya River. We all thought that we all carry our camera and do some photo river adventures. Firstly, you must be careful with your gadgets. It's pretty crowded out there especially when going inside the boat so take extra precaution. Secondly, the place is really beautiful but sometimes water splashes too.. Thirdly, with the cheaper price of transport, it's also very convenient and you will for sure see some traditional Thai ways of life along the river banks. Overall, our Chao Phraya trip was worth it.. and oh yes, you can also move from different places once you're at the Sapan Taksin Station.

Take a Cheap Boat Ride. This review is quite late. The Chao Phraya River is an important body of water in Bangkok. Notwitstanding the modernization this city went through the locals still use this river as an option for cheap transportation in getting around the city. I took a ferry boat ride at the Chao Phraya River to reach Wat Arun. It was a short ride but fun.

Rent your own boat - and have a fantastic 2 hours on the river. Today we took the BTS to Sapham Taksin station and rented a boat for two hours taking a roundtrip on Chao Phraya river. After some bargaining we got our private boat (not the quick longboats, but a slower one that you actually can take pictures from..) and paid 2500 baht for 3 persons. It was worth every penny. We took off from the main canal 20 minutes downriver and had the most remarkable trip in "Venice of Asia". Don't expect much coaching from the captain, the boat motors are too noisy for that, but just the views were fantastic. Bangkok is built in a swamp, and here you really got to see the lower backparts of the city. Not to be missed! (Another cookie-point: the air is much cooler on the river :-)

I love the Chaopraya. The Chao Praya is one of the great, working rivers of Asia.It bustles with life, be they barges, tourist boats, commuter boats, long-tails, you name it, you'll see many on this magic river.Its interesting too that the river is now really being discovered in Bangkok. Before, the city was very Sukhumvit centred, but now, well, its a dynamic change thats underway.Many, if not all the major historic attractions are on the river.Don't miss seeing it.Take public boats. Fast, efficient, friendly and cheap !

Oh what a river. Every visit to Bangkok should include a trip down the Chao Phrya River. It is the best fastest and cheapest way to see both sides of the river that runs through Bangkok.Go to the boat departures right next to the Shangri La Hotel or take the sky train there. Then get a boat that goes up to Nonthanpuri. It's about a 1.30 houre trip up to the last stop. Try and get a two seater row on the right hand side for the trip up and then an the left hand side going back.The Price one way is 30Baht for which you could not even call a taxi in europe.As we have been going to Bangkok for the better part of 20 years we know what changes have taken place (for the better) One goes past the kings Palace and the ride is so enjoyable that my wife and I do it nearly every day when we are in Bangkok for 4 weeks.Try it and say what you think.
Unavoidable. Integral part of Bangkok, but murky waters makes it not very appealing. Any boat ride will suffice, but would not go put of the way to experience it.
Return from Ayyuthaya. Return to the capital from Ancient city trip on a boat, food was very good and a great way to see a part of Bangkok, great guide who even changed some £s to bht for me.

Cruise. I would recommend all the tourists to take a boat tour in this river. It is an amazing experience. They have rides starting at night with music,dance, booze and food.Worth spending your quality time.

You should take a boat tour. You can take public boat that stops on every pier locates in both banks of river or you can pay a little more and take express lines that stops only in selected piers. You can get out to the front area of some boats to have a full view. It's a nice way to explore the city.

Awful waste of money . I went on the dinner cruise along the river it was awful food was terrible no body ate when l was looking around the drinks were not included which were expensive entertainment was rubbish couldn't wait to get off

We took a long boat tour, would have preferred the local ferry.. Our party of 4 wanted to do the river trip. I had research the trip and I wanted to take one of the local ferries as I'm quite comfortable with getting around on local transport. When we arrived at Central Pier we were jumped on straight away by the high pressure sales people selling the long tail boat tours. The others in our party preferred to go on the long tail boat trip, which was a lot more expensive, so that's what we did. After we'd paid they told us to stand under the cover and wait, we had to wait ages for our turn, probably about 1/2 hour. The tour was ok, much more expensive though and personally I don't think it was worth the money and you were on a time limit where ever you stopped, which was annoying. We did get to see along a couple of the smaller canals which was interesting. We stopped at one place on the canal where we were expected to eat but it wasn't very appealing. It was good to see some of the local canal houses though. We also went through a loch to get into the canal, which was interesting. We also stopped at Wat Arun, it was worth the visit (see my review), we then took the long tail boat across the river to the pier near the Reclining Buddha and decided to finish our journey there rather than head back to the beginning so we could spend our time wandering around the temples and not be on a time limit, which is the problem when you hire one of these long tail boats. Overall if you are not confident taking a local boat and you prefer a guided tour then this was an interesting trip, but I would have preferred the local boat and wander at our own leisure.

The Pulse of Bangkok. I love this river, whether I'm traveling on it or watch the boat traffic from its banks. Any time, day or night there is always something happening on the Chao Phraya. In the morning commuters and school kids are ferried up and down the waterway, dodging trade craft such as rice barges and other commercial vessel. In the evening parts of the river are transformed into a light show as floating restaurants festooned with colored lights parade up and down stream. And then there is the high pitched scream of long tail boats racing at top speed, conveying passengers to their destinations. In short, there is something on the Chau Phraya to hold your attention any time of the day. Don't miss it!

River Boat ride. My brother wanted to see Wat Arun and the Royal Palace, on a few hours that we had in Bangkok on a Sunday. I decided that the best way was to buy a 150 baht ticket on the tourist boat that runs up and down the river. Turned out to be a great idea as it is a huge time saver, not having to hop in and out of taxis or tuk tuks, on the congested Bangkok streets. Also, you can join the local people using the loca boats that cross from river bank to river bank, for just 3 baht. As with many big cities, the river can still be the best way to get about and safe too.

Nice view of night scene along the river. The best way to appreciate the river is to take the dinner cruise along the river. The lighted bridges and buildings along the river bank are so beautiful especially Wat Arun which is majestically lighted up.

Take a break from Bangkok's traffic and hop on a boat. Bangkok is once known as the Venice of the east. So while you are in Bangkok, don't miss the boat experience to explore the city on a boat. You can also take a one-day cruise trip from Bangkok to Ayutthaya.There are many expensive tour agencies conducting Bangkok sightseeing river cruise but you can take public boat and make a few stops at any pier you want. It's pretty much like the BTS or MRT ticketing system, pick the pier and pay the fare.Since no BTS are available in the old town area (where the Grand Palace&co are) and the traffic are usually bad, you can go to BTS Saphan Thaksin or any pier and get a boat to Ko Rattanakosin area. Convenient, no traffic, and cheap.Chao Phraya river is especially beautiful in the evening. Don't miss the sunset and the city lights at night.

Enjoyable tour. We took a boat tour down here as we were looking to go to the Grand Palace and we were told this would be a good way of getting there. Maybe we were misunderstood (!) when we asked where the water ferry was, however we went on about an hour long tour across the river for 700baht per person, which in hindsight was probably a little expensive! We enjoyed the tour as there was so much to see and it was a really enjoyable way to pass some time and see a side to Bangkok we hadn't yet seen. For our journey back we took the transport boat which was almost free in comparison to the fare we paid initially. Bangkok isn't the easiest place to get about as a novice here but with views like is, lessons aren't hard ones.

Gorgeous at night. Best way to get around for cheap, in my opinion. After dark the view is something to remember as you look into the banks from your vessel. The temples and other sites are all lit up and sparkly.

COOL & WELCOMING ONE OF THE BEST WAYS TO GET AROUND BANGKOK. Away from the hustle & bustle of the crowded city streets......is the crowded local ferry...crowded, but cool and a great way to travel, wait for a few people to get off if it's busy and you can generally get a seat. Only 15 baht each time you get on will get you up and down the river for over an hour if you choose to stay on board. The Chao Prya River is as busy a traffic way as most of the roads, and I find it hugely interesting to watch, The various kinds of boats seem to find space to get by....and avoid the huge clumps of floating weed. Get off at any stop (including China town,), take a look around then get back on and go to another tourist stop. If your language skills are limited, there is usually someone around to help. Most Thai people are extremely helpful and gracious towards tourists. If you're hot and uncomfortable, find you way to the River, it will make you feel better.

Cooling Cruise. The Chao Phraya river is a cool place to be, especially in the oppressive heat of the day. You can buy a daily pass and hop on and off to your hearts content on one of the many tourist boats.. But be careful of getting off and on and going in the right direction because the entrances and exits are not properly marked. Of course you need to get on the right boat operator as there are many. Sights to see - wonderful buildings, colourful temples, awesome bridges, abandoned barges and the many long boats plying the river. Off course the river also yields some jetsam, bright green marine growth and huge catfish that you can see from the boat especially at the end of the line. At night the sights are even more impressive, highlighting a vibrant Bangkok and the very many hotels visible from the water's edge.

Important Sight!. This river is very important to Bangkok as is the capitol city to the entire nation of Thailand. Very scenic- worth a trip down or up via long tailed boat, hotel shuttle, ferry, dinner cruise or even just the river boats used for commuting.

River ferry. A great way to move around Bangkok. It only cost 15 baht to board and there is no traffic jam. It is quite a sight to watch the crewman used his whistle to communicate with the ferry captain. You have to be nimble and fast to get on and off the ferry. You don't need to join the tour boat to see the river and the sights. Just use the orange flag ferry and hop on & hop off real quick, and I mean Real Quick.

Highligtlht of Bangkok. Like every city which have river across the city, Chao Phra Ya river is one of the highlight of Bangkok. She look nice at night. So many hotels around the river which use the river view as the point sale. Any how, they are quite expensive especially for the new year Eve. I might recommend Barbecue Garden on top of City which I went there every year. It is quite cheap comparing with the hotel with open air atmosphere and clearer view of the fireworks at midnight.

A break from heat and traffic and fast commuting transport. I always enjoy a good boat ride on the Chao Phraya river.Even just crossing from one side to the other of the river is a "must do"! This is one of the fastest mode of transportation after the sky train and underground. You could travel both ways either toward Satorn road or Nontaburi. The ticket is usually very cheap, about 30 baht or less.

A memorable Bangkok experience. When in Bangkok, you must spend some time on the Chao Phrya River. Catch a public ferry, or rent a long-tail boat from the Saphan Taksin pier (BTS station). You can visit many attractions from the river, including the Grand Palace, Wat Arun, floating market, Chinatown, and the Royal Barge Museum. Have high tea at the Shangri-la, Mandarin Oriental, or Peninsula Hotels nearby, and watch the river traffic. Go on a dinner cruise. I always think of James Bond in "The Man With the Golden Gun" when I visit Bangkok and see the Chao Phraya River!
Boat cruise. Better than the stinking Nile by a far.Well worth a trip if in the city!!And the floating Hyacinth makes the river smell wonderful as the boats carve them up.

Instant Bangkok. A journey by boat down the river early morning and late afternoon is worth it. Travelling from one river bank to the other will take you to another world ,well worth the effort.Remember it's hot do take a bottle of water and a small towel to mop up the sweat.

Great way to see the city. Get a ride on the river however you can. We rented a longboat to take us up some of the famous canals. This gives you time both on the open river as well as the quieter canals. A must when in Bangkok.

Great under night sky. This might not be the cleanest river you get to see everyday but the scenic beauty you get to witness during the cruise rides along the river bed is mesmerizing.The cruise rides are the best .every ship has it's own way of pleasing the travelers and the food served in these boats/ships arnt bad at all.The water may be green and ugly but the experiences surrounding it make up for it. If you want to take a small peak of what Bangkok is all about in 2 hours then this is the best way possible.

Easier way to get around than a taxi. The river snakes through bangkok and the regular, reasonable priced ferries are an easy way of getting from A to B, especially to the Grand Palace and Wat Poh. Take the Sky train to span taksin then gste 3 on the station exiting to the ferry piers. 1 way ticket to Grand Palace pier is 15bht. The ferries are usually quite crowded

Tip : Try to manage an early morning trip. If you visit Bangkok, you must visit the river. But recommend to make a trip in the morning starting 6-7 am. In this time, you feel how the life is hard in Bangkok. You can see the houses on the river, taking the water from the river, the bad smells etc every time. But in the morning, you will see the employees working in the city's plaza's leaving their houses with black suites, ties, ladies with skirt etc...And only for not returning their home on the water, they work overtime because they are happy in the city. My Other comments are not different from the other comments you can read.
