Greta River Trips. Greta trips available easily accessed from the BTS Sky Train Saphan Thaksin Station 200 meter walk to the piers
Greta evening restaurant Air con boats and daily excursions

Beat the Traffic with Ferry Taxis. Being a big city, Bangkok is one of the most notorious place to be caught in traffic jams. To ride a ferry boat in Chao Phraya river to get from point A to point B is one way of beating it. The river is polluted and nothing much to see really but of different perspective perhaps. A dinner night cruise would also be a better deal where you can enjoy the lights and sights of buildings, temples, and bridges from the river.
Dinner Cruise along the river is a must. I spent a night for dinner cruise along this river. Great view at night time which u can get the view of city at night. Must do in Bangkok

Fascinating a changing landscape.. When visiting Bangkok a ride on the Chao Phraya river is a must. Whether it's using it like a taxi, dinner cruise or going into the Klongs.We used it to get to our hotel from several places on a longtail boat. It's great to see it being used so much to such a vast array of big and small boats.It's a lovely to spend a few hours. We also used the free shuttle boat to Asiatique which was fun to get to.
Cutest little boat ride. It's like 15 one way to any stop, honestly it's awesome and actually quite convenient too. If you're in a quite place go somewhere busy or vice versa

Lot of Attraction. Hire a boat with DSLR, Kids and family. This trip is having dozens of attractions. Such as Bridges, Buildings and Temples Both Day and Night view also excellent. Shouldn't Miss this Trip.

A boat trip provides wonderful riverside views of Bangkok. I took my son on the river taxi boat using a one day ticket. We started at Saphan Thaksin having taken the sky train to this location. The boat affords great views of a lot of old and new buildings on the river front. Whilst we could have got on and off multiple times to visit the various sites, we chose to stay on the boat until it did a U turn and got off where we started. The boat also offers an alternative to taxis, or buses, for visitors to the Silom area to visit the Grand Palace.

Chao Phraya River trip. We caught the Skytrain to Thaksin Pier and bought a ticket for the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat - 1 Day River pass costs 150 Baht - which includes a handy Travel Guide indicating the stops for all the tourist attractions en route. You can get on and off the boat at your leisure - taking in the tourist sites along the river - a guide on the boat also tells you about the attractions at each Pier. The boats run roughly every half hour. A good way to see the sights of Bangkok. The river is very busy with lots of different kinds of boats travelling up and down the river. Plan your trip so you know where to get on and off the boat. Think it is a "must do" if you have the time.

Little adventure. If you want to have a authentic impression of Bangkok, you need to travel on the Chao Phraya River. There are different lines you can choose. The kings palace and the Temple of the Dawn are on the river, you can catch them from the river. You can see different boats and ships and yachts, and you receive an impression how the people live on the bank of the river. Many interesting buildings as goverments buildings, schools, temples, villas and old houses bordering the bank.

Take a ride.... The Chao Phraya is a pretty cool piece of Bangkok. Its pivotal in the shipping/trading sector of the country, but it also gives tourists and workers the ability to move around this traffic packed city a bit more easily and with great views. Jump on a ferry and explore.

long-tailed boats. Staying close to the river is a great way to see the real life of Bangkok. There are ferries that run across and others that run up and down the river, always full of commuters. The river is busy with tugs and barges, tourist boats and the swift long-tail taxis. There are bars and cafes by each wharf, looking over the river. Hiring a long-tail boat to tour the klongs is the best trip possible - for 1000 BHT an hour you can people watch, photograph waterfowl and monitor lizards, feed the fish, see the real city.

Magical. We went on the river twice during our month stayFirst time we got a tuk tuk for 100 baht down to the river and we just hopped on the back of a water taxi and ride it for about 2 piers then got off2nd time we got it during the day and went down to Wat Pho (reclining Buddha) it was 150 baht for a full day ticket or 50 each wayAmazing sights and pictures and best way to travelThe river has a lot to offer

The best of Bangkok. Taking a water taxi from Pier Thaksin up the Chao Paraya river is an amazing half and hour. The guide explained well about famous spots along the river in English and Thai. Good to have such information but more enjoyable is the movements in the river and views. Interestingly some old mansions on the river bank are already lower than the current water level and still well maintained and kept alive.

best day out in Bangkok. Bought day ticket and travelled up and down, jumping off to see the crowded overpriced official sites.Most had guides explain the history, so we got a very good understanding of the way the river was used and built up.

Catch a ferry and see more of Bangkok. Choice of public and sightseeing options. The public one being crowded but awesome value.Helpful conductors and something different with a better view from the river

Great Dinner Cruise with beautiful views. It is a memorable experience, having dinner on a moving cruise along Chao Phraya River for 2 hours. I was able to see different parts of Bangkok starting from living area with houses along two sides of the river, then cultural landmark, temples with decoration lights, city views with tall luxury buildings and industrial area. I think the reason that I love this experience is because it shows me the beauty of Bangkok in different angles that I can not get from else where.

cool. in march this year, we just crossed the river to go to asiatique from anatara. however, a few years back, we spent a whole day on the river, stopping at piers to go discover wats, palaces, etc. there were small restaurants at times at the piers and i would wonder about the hygienic conditions of the food... but people are eating and they seem to be doing well. we used a day-pass to hop on and off tourist boats and it was great as there was no traffic. it was a great day! you get to see a different side of bangkok. the river itself is very very deep and quite murky...

sight seeing of bangkok. Great place for sightseeing. The centre pier is very easy to reach by sky train. You can experience the local downtown life of bangkok in this beautiful cruise. The ticket for ferry is very low price.

Smelly and dirty but you should see it.... Chao Phraya is a very convenient way of travelling from one distant district to other. The traffic on river is quite high - from small boats to tourist ships. It is very dirty and also a bit smelly but still useful and offers great view on the city.We skipped all tourist cruises and "floating markets" and decided to buy cheap tickets for express boat. First we took blue line (40 baht) and then came back with one of lines with flag (orange, yellow, green - the difference between those is their route). Whole trip cost around 60 baht per person. It's very cheap so you can see different parts of the city at a low cost.NOTE: if you'd like to travel more comfortably pay 40 baht for tourist blue line. Other lines are very crowded (especially during rush hours) and you will not have opportunity to find sitting place or even you'll might not enter the boat at all. If you're looking for a cruise with taking photos and enjoying the view just choose blue line.

It happens on the river. Everything happens on the river, it's absolutely relaxed to have diner over there or take a boat, tehe bus boat is very cheap and is going to the main attractions (china town, grandpalace and khoa san road)

Fun River Tour. It was a fun river tour for me and some of my fellow travel agents. We took a roundtrip boat ride so we could experience a cheaper yet unique way of getting to Wat Pho and the Grand Palace. There were a lot of things and places to see; there was even an English-speaking tour guide. It's funny that out of coincidence, we got her as our tour guide again when we rode back to Saphan Taksin station. Although it's somehow funny that Chao Phraya River reminded me of Pasig River (In the Philippines) definitely without the smell. Hee!

Take a River Tour. This is an exciting way to see Bangkok from the vantage point of a Thai national. Look closely and on very warm days you will see workers who have jumped into the water and being pulled along, In order to cool off.

The most popular river in Bangkok. Chao Phraya river is circled in Bangkok and its surrounding areas. We took a river cruise by a boat and went to the other side of the river to have food. Loved the river cruise. I heard the view from the Khlongs (River Taxis) at night is amazing. Recommended.

Lots of ways to have fun on the river!. A main artery of the river with so many ways to enjoy it. Sit and eat beside it, use the public bus, travel across it with one of the hotel river busses or take a private tour and explore the small housing areas on the outskirts, with small floating vendors selling to local home owners everything from fruit to bread or lunch! We loved this river.

get the river taxi !!!!. There are ways to go up the river....I lived In Bangkok one year and the best is river taxi and also the cheapest...get on Saphin Taksin off BTS and ride to Chinatown...you can get off along the way of course at the many stops..don't waste your time with about boat...now of course if you like you can charter a long boart for the day at 1000 baht maximum to take you on the side canals which I really recommend if your budget stretches
Beautiful Evening. The view of Bangkok riversides was beautiful and very exiting.The food is really tasty and nice.I love it.

Wonderful night. What a beautiful night it was. Great seeing the temples of a night and all the city lights. Food was plentiful and enjoyable music was great and so was the dancing . A must do in Bangkok.

Romantic at night. I loved the quaint little ferry boats bobbing from side to side, and the stormy clouds above the high rises.. The river allows for some stunning landscapes that are very rare in the city of Bangkok due to the density of the buildings. The only drawback is that it can be a little tricker to reach the lovely parts of the River due to the Skytrain and Metro not having lines/stops near that part of the city.

Loads to see. We were lucky to have a view of the river from our hotel and there's lots going on. Everything from small ferry's crossing from one side to the other to tugs towing 3 or 4 barges. At night there are many dinner/disco boats which are brightly lit.We took a trip down the river from our hotel just as it was getting dark. I think this gives the best view of Wat Arun which is illuminated at night and quite spectacular. We also used the river taxis and express boats as a fast and effective way of getting around.
Love the river taxi's. This is a must if you want to visit AsiaTique or the hotels across the water. Easy access by Train. Fun place to watch the locals and tourists also.

Different of Bangkok. Taking a ride down the river is a different and you see a lot of things that you miss from the road side. It's the quickest way to get from place to place. We went on 4 different boat rides to see various places Wat Arun, Wat Po and the Grand Palace. Well worth taking a ride, the prices are cheap as well.

Chao Phraya Dinner Cruise. Cruise dinner usually takes 1 hour. there are 2 step deck on the cruise. try to get the upper level. the food was so so. avoid seafood if you have allergy some of them just not that fresh. if you fill just so so experience on the cruise u may need to try bars once the cruise finished.
good exprience. nice opportunutiy to see bangkok from another way you can go by long tail or by another boats for long tail do not forget to negotiate

River and Canal Tour. This was a boat tour I took through the hotel (Westin). I was picked up and dropped off back to the lobby. I took this tour on a Sunday and truly enjoyed it. We were a smallish group and was on a boat that went through the canals. The tour guide gave us the history and information about the locals whose homes were along the canals. Because it was Sunday, the families were outside enjoying their day off.

The express boat experience is fun and dinner cruise was amazing. If you visit BKK, the must do list is Chaopraya river.. Both day time express boat and night time dinner cruise.. (Recommended the Wonderful pearl cruise.. The brand new 200 millions bath ship!)

Important artery of the region. We took a four hour boat ride up the river to visit the Summer Palace about 30 miles outside of Bangkok. We thought the trip was great. We enjoyed seeing all of the river traffic and various other local sites along the river.
Authentic. A really good way to move in Bangkok. Refreshing, popular.And very cheap! Better than a taxi. A good way also to take an healthy fuel vapours.

River runs through it. A good way to get your bearings without getting stuck in traffic. There are cruises and ferries but I would recommend getting a more expensive long tail and taking a trip to WatArun and down the Klongs. It gives a wonderful perspective of how most people live in the city. It's a simple but but poor existence but at the same time almost enviable.

Easy, cheap way to get around. The river is the fastest way to many of the sights to see in Bangkok. Don't always opt for the tour they are selling......grab yourself a ticket for a.few baht and float on up the river stopping at each place. It's easy to get to via the train~bts. Just head for central pier. It can get a little crowded at end of the day as many people use this transport to and from work.
Great night view of Bangkok... Had good time with family on the cruise. The night view of Bangkok is breathtaking. There is good food and great music as well.

Chao Phrya. The river trip literally costs pennies and many attractions can be visited by taking a river boat trip. Long tailed boat trips are expensive comparably. Get on at the Skytrain station in Silom, name forgotten, and for 15 baht you can travel for about 1.5 hrs. Look out for scores of river fish by the rivers edge
too crowded. the greatness and vastness of this rever does not attract due to being overcrowded. since all sort of commercial activities are allowed,it is very difficult to spend peaceful time
Must do. If you' re in bangkok you must take a boat in the chao phraya river. I took it at the afternoon and its a unforgettable experience.

Very Interesting !. It's a very interesting trip. Very exciting and awesome. Take the Orange flag boat. It cost only 15 Thb per person. They charge you per entry on the boat. You can take the boat all the way to the last stop from the first stop for only 15 Thb. But if you decide to stop at the next stop and get back on again, then you will be charged another 15 Thb.Overall it's is worth the trip.Stop at Nonthobohuri . The last stop, an authentic Thai town.

Nothing to do? Cruise the river.... Gives you a glimpse of a different Bankok. You get to observe the Bankok skyline from a distance and some quiet river life. Though the water is not clear, it's at least not dirty. Plus it gives you a chance to breathe in some breeze aside from the exhaust filled city air. It was pleasant.

Save money by taking a river taxi. Instead of getting ripped off by tour boats, take one of the many taxis running up and down the river with an orange or yellow flag. Pay for your trip once you are on the boat.You can take it to the end of the line to Nonthaburi and see the free museum there or just take it up to the Flower Market, past Wat Arun and the Palace to Khao San and back to Central Pier again (or from wherever you are staying)
Great Experience. Must take a boat ride down the river if you get a chance. Your trip won't be complete without this experience.

Cruising along Chao Phraya River. Had cruised along this river by taking twice a private dinner cruise, River city shuttle boat and rice barge boat tour in the afternoon. There are lots of landmarks that can be seen along the river including the Grand Palace, the Temple of Dawn, River City shopping complex, The Oriental hotel, and Royal Barge museum to name a few. You can take boats that will take you to tourist spots. Cruising along the river is a great way of exploring the city. A must do when in Bangkok.

Good to see. Not at the top of the list but a worth while adventure. You can take the river taxi for 15 Bhat, just remember that service stops at 7. Didn't know & got stuck at end of line instead of coming back.Dont know where I ended up but got back by bus and subway thankfully.
Always something to see. Enjoyed trips on the river, bought a day pass which let's you on and off various piers such as the royal palace and other great places to visit,

Fancy a Boat Trip - A Secret!. For all foreign tourists: Shhh! - a money saving trip to savour the sight and sound on the River of Kings for a few baht or dirt cheap in cents or pence; and save your money for a fancy dinner river cruise at night. This northbound river boat trip to Nonthaburi will take you past few bridges, several Wats and give you a view of settlements along the river. It is a worthwhile and interesting boat trip. First, get some small Thai Baht notes or coins because you do not want to be troublesome paying your fare with a 500 or 100 Baht note. Go to Tha Chang, N9 (North Bank 9) pier stop near the Wat Phra Kaew (The Emerald Buddha Temple). At the pier, queue along with the locals for the Chao Phraya Express boat with orange flag and pay the fare onboard the boat. At peak hours in the early morning and later after 4:00 pm, there are other boats with green and yellow flags (small price difference) which can also be used for this northbound trip to Nonthaburi. The fare may still be 15 THB per person each way and the journey takes about 50 minutes as people embark and disembark along the route. Get off at the northernmost stop, Tha Nonthaburi, N30 pier stop.Along the northbound route, you will go past bridges like Phra Pin Klao, Krung Thon, Rama 8, Rama 7 and Rama 5; and several Wats for your photoshoot. Disembark at Tha Nonthaburi N30 and go walkabout the town centre and find something to eat and drink. If you are there early before 9 am, you may visit the Nonthaburi market; or if you are adventurous, you may ask the local here and find your way to visit Koh Kret, which is an island in the Chao Phraya River.When it is time to go back to Bangkok, go back to Tha Nonthaburi and board the orange flagged boat or, depend on the timing, there are also the green and yellow flagged boats. This a fun and enjoyable boat trip which can be had for a cheap fare as paid by the local. A unique experience as well, rubbing shoulder with students, monks, Thai men and women from all walks of life commuting by boat.

Heart of Bangkok. Chao Phraya is the heart of Bangkok. It is one of the best ways to travel across Bangkok, and to avoid the horrific traffic jams. Best of all, we could while our time watching boats, barges, passengers, etc ply the route, visiting the riverside wats and other landmarks, and imagine life as it was decades/a century ago.
Unique experiences . Great way to experience the old part of town, it also gives you a realistic I site to locals everyday commute along the rivers of Bangkok. Well worth it!
James Bond Feelin. It was a great experience. Was a very enjoyable ride but beware of floating boats trying to stop you and sell exorbitant prices drinks.

see culture through the river. Large river which divides the city of bangkok, which in his time this river becomes the main transport route for residents. Today many attractive offers for tourists to enjoy this river, they can have lunch or dinner on board while cruising along the river to see people's activities on the river. This is the second time I visited this river and in my opinion, the best way to enjoy this river is sailing along this river using public transportation just like the locals. You can enjoy the local culture through their public transport. By using the Chao Phraya Express Boat, you can also visit some of the tourist attractions that exist along this river. Select the Chao Phraya Express Boat was flagged orange, with costs around 15 Baht per person each way, you can get off at the dock that you want to visit the attraction. (Study the map of the Chao Phraya River, in order to know the pier where you should go down) For my visit to the Grand Palace this time, I chose to use the Chao Phraya Express Boat. While enjoying the bustle of the morning along the river, I sailed from Sathorn pier and down in the Mahraj pier, then a little walk to the Grand Palace. Sailing along the river in the morning becomes a unique experience in my holidays.

Boat trip not to be missed. Grab a boat from the pier near the Shangrila hotel in early morninga dinner boat trip is great fun, decent food but wonderful views of Bangkok. Boats to Wat Arun in Thonburi and even Ayuthya also available. Avoid the "Long Tail" boats as noisy, too fast and open to too much sun. Great Bangkok activity.

The lifeline of Bangkok. NO trip to Bangkok is complete without a visit to the riverside areas; the lifeline of this wonderful city. Would recommend a trip in one of the long boats to see the city line and some of the monuments and temples from the water. Be weary of boats trying to lure you to the floating markets! The real floating markets are not here!

Boat trip on the river. In Bangkok, the Chao Phraya is a major transportation artery for a vast network of river buses, cross-river ferries and water taxis, also known as longtails. More than 15 boat lines operate on the rivers and canals of the city, including commuter lines.It is cheap and convenient to use the riverboats to get around and at the same time enjoy the sights along the way. Always worth a trip or two. Can get crowded. You see the state of the river which is filthy and very polluted.There are dinner cruises on the river but those boats are probably plush. Did not get on them so whats it like.
Amazing view and sights. Brilliant lights and view from the ferry as we cruise along at night. Breath taking and relaxing, except for the noise from the ferry.

River cruise. We went on a night time river cruise... having only 3 days in Bangkok everything was rushed but I'm glad we did this, as It was a brilliant cruise. Seeing the city at night from the river was beautiful.
Polluted and smelly!. Bangkok could have taken great advantage of this impressive river. Instead over the years the city used it as a Grand Sewage. Pity!

The Chao Phraya River, Bangkok. Take a leisurely cruise along the river using the local boats and get off at the fascinating tourist sites like Wat Pho, Wat Arun and the Royal Palace. It is just a few pence for any length of journey, no need to buy the tourist day ticket as that is overpriced. Just pay the ticket person on the boat and rub shoulders with other tourists, locals, monks, and students. It is one of my favourite things to do in Bangkok
River boat. Good boat in evening at river in Bangkok.Very Nice buffee for romantic People as travel togetherGood prices...and cheap
main river of Bangkok. very long river and it is the main important one for bangkok, full of histories and culture. try boat trip and stop at wat Arun was very beautiful

Interesting!. Despite my anxiety about being on the water - not good for me - this was very interesting. Ferry across to then board the long boat - well, that was an adventure to get on and off! Ride along the canals is quite an eye opener. Stopped at a war on the way and bought bread to feed the huge catfish! (I thought our guide was doing his shopping!) Then back on to the main river and a hair raising five minute ride to cross the river traffic!
Very dirty river. The river is very dirty. There are many boats all the time crossing the river because there are many ports along the river. It is very dirty, with garbage and a lot of plants.

Range of river craft experiences. Used the tourist boat to get to the flower market, a local ferry to cross the river and a longboat ride up the canals. Great way to see Bangkok and easy way to get around pleased to stay off the roads. Loved our canal ride, fed huge catfish outside a wat.

Dinner river boat cruise with Shangri_La Bangkok. Loved the buffet dinner and the evening was just perfect. The Wats and various well illuminated buildings that dot the river banks are amazing to see at night. The cruise was very peaceful and the passengers were not your party goers - well mannered and respect at the buffet table. A pleasure to be on this dinner cruise. I will go again whenever I visit Bangkok
Excellent. Brilliant best way to travel, hotels on river offer free shuttles , use them, they stop at most of the hotels and sight seeing complex s. Along with the markets and shopping areas

Not that I am familiar with. took it going to Asiatique if i am not wrong. As long as I was in a boat going to Asiatique. The hotels around the river are very impressive and I wished that I could be able to stay there but its fun taking a ride in the water

good means of transport. Taking the tourist boat (not the long tail but the ferry) is a great and cheap way to get around to the main tourist sites. River itself is dirty but lots to see during the ride.

The River of History. I love bus boat travelling where you can enjoy seeing differences along the river. Many good restaurants and cafés that you can visit.
Anyhow, the floating water hyacinth spoils the scenery.

No trip wil be complete without it. As part of our day we hired a taxi to take us around and as the pier is close the Grand Palace we took the river tour. It lasts an hour and the cost is reasonable and as my partner is Thai she is able to get discount or free entry into many heritage sites. We had a boat to ourselves and the boatman made sure we saw all that was worth seeing, water buffalo, giant swimming reptiles and huge fish

Impressive. Everytime I visit I love to travel on the river. It is such a mix of culture and decadence. One second the are huge, expensive 5 star hotels, then rundown slums with building looking like you could blow them over. Then a top range condos next to Wats and temples. Ok, the river is filthy but teaming with fish.

Most memorable. The high speed boat takes you through sights of temples and china town on both sides of the river. A sweet little stop mid river to feed the fish near a temple is a unique experience. Then you transfer to a rice boat and go to the south end of Bangkok. The boat crew are the sweetest humans ever. A very generous spread of exotic fruits, juices and drinks are put up for you to enjoy while cruising down the river with all you can eat and drink for free. You board and conclude from the pier of the Sheraton hotel and will find yourself in the company of mature and meaningful tourists from all over the world.

What a unique experience. Very useful, unique, and undoubtedly efficient mode of transportation in Bangkok. Clever way to explore Bangkok without spending time being trapped in traffic jam. The pier is located in strategic area near tourist attraction, easily access. Some hotel even provide free shuttle boat from hotel to nearest tourist attraction.
good. the river boats are a great cheap efficient way to get around the various monuments , temples and sights of Bangkok. well recommended

Touring the Chao. Highly recommend droig one of the dinner cruises, the buffet is excellent and buffet on the river just taste that much better. Try to combine the river cruise with another attraction like Ayuthaya that way you take the bus to Ayuthaya and take the river down back to the city
a little dirty. nice view of the city from the river but riding in a water taxi a little bumpy. Bts is better as you can go in all different ways of Bangkok
Floating down the river. It was interesting to see the river and the sites from the river. It was a little bumpy though due to all the boat traffic

The Cheap and Expensive Way to Cruise the Chao Phraya. Expensive: Rice Barge Cruise along Chao Phraya for Dinner or Afternoon Fruit Cruise. We did the Fruit Cruise for 700 Baht each. Nice experience but there's not really much information that the tourist guide can give as you cruise the Chao Phraya.Cheap: Just take the Express Boats from 3 Baht/way to cross (Wat Pho to Wat Arun) or from 9-30 Baht to cruise down the length of the river (with several stops). You get the same view as a paid cruise.I have posted our experience on the Fruit Cruise along Chao Phraya on http://dhappyretiree.blogspot.com/2014/09/bangkok-packaged-tours-my-experience.html#more. If you want to try the public ferry and explore Bangkok by public transportation, check outhttp://dhappyretiree.blogspot.com/2014/09/2n3d-bangkok-d-i-y-itinerary-best.html#more

ordinary river that bangkok can make it extraordinary. actually it just a really ordinary river ( a bit dirty actually) but somehow the government of bangkok can make this river important for their residence and also for tourist.it is not mandatory to use this river to reach all the palace actually, but for tourist i think it worth to try to. they have 3 boat (correct me if im wrong).1. tourist boat +/- 40THB2. Yellow flag boat +/-15THB3. blue flag boat - sorry i forget for think one.my advice, if you want to go to Grand palace etc just use the yellow flag boat, this boat is for locals (and so many tourist using it to). its really cheap and it bring u to the same place anyway.beware of some people will try to SCAM you with a "Long tail boat" things. its quite expensive.Happy travelling ^^

Very good way to travel. The boats are a very good way to move along areas near the river. Most stops have signs in English and Thai. We had a copy of the stops from wikitravel and found it very useful. It can get very crowded though. The locals were very forthcoming despite the language barrier. We found them guiding a lot of tourists who didn't know which direction they were to travel towards.Not wheelchair accessible but safe for people with moderate walking disabilities.

long tail. Went for a ride on a very nice Long Tail boat . We went up the main river then through some smaller canals and saw peoples homes and general river life / very fast and fun . Tip get a trip from one of the boat operators and Bargain them down
Old place to visit. This is not a place I would go for a second time but the waterfront and pier are lovely to look at and a great variety of shops make it an interesting outing in bangkok

A River Runs Through BKK. Take the BTS to Saphan Taksin and follow the crowd walking toward the river. Watch out for high price tickets. Look for the best deal. You will see Temples, Hotels, Tourists from all over the world, Boats, Gold Wats and get a tour of the sights. Have fun and talk to people who have knowledge of the best places to go. Enjoy!
Love the river crossing!. Love the river crossing! The ferry boat ride is something I want to do it over again, and docking to the other side of the river for a lunch is so charming an idea.

Lifeline of Bangkok. Very long river which is not very clean and with many canals.Best way to enjoy is to hire a long boat for 1 hour and then see various temples which are on the riverbank, feed the fishes and see living style of people

good time pass and bangkok view. this is one of the main river of bangkok,we took the motor boat and it was around 60 minutes trip where boatman took us to the river and shown many intersting monuments enroute.the local people sells bread-loafs which can be fed to fishes, the river is dirty at many places and needs cleaning.intersting to visit if you have enough time to pass and enjoy while in bangkok.
Busy river. The river is quite busy and amazing to watch the barges and tug boats go in and out of the river traffic.

The water freeway of Bangkok. The express boats on the river are a great way to get around. Unless you're making more than four trips, don't pay for the day pass on the tourist boat, use the express boats and pay as you go. Just walk on board and the ticket seller will pay you a visit. There's a sign at the wharf that explains which boats stop at which wharves. Look for the coloured flag above the stern of the boat as it approaches. The orange flag boats run more frequently than the tourist boat as well.The river itself is a dirty waterway that has been transporting people and goods through the city for a thousand years, so it's prettiest from high above at one of the riverside hotels, or at night from the Loy Nava dinner cruise. When you're face to face, it's a gritty, authentic, watery bus lane.

a one time experience. We took the one day tourist ticket for 150 Bht which gave us a daily access to the boat and river for the whole day. We decided to start early and visit all the sites along the route. all the sites are interesting and it was quite a day . highly recommended!
Interesting ride. Great experience, was peaceful and we got to experience the locals who live on the water, how they live and travel around on their little boats. Wonderful scenery.

So relaxing. We always take the boat from the sheraton because we work very close by.The chao Phraya river it is a great area to spend your weekends, travel with friends to tours, etc.All the great old hotels are located through the river. You should try Sundays as everyone goes to Sunday brunchs!

Boat ride. Took the normal boat ride that locals used. It was cheap, but a little confused as I keep looking out where I am at to avoid missing my stop. Got a bit tanned from the noon sun haha... good experience. Try it!
clean. This is Thailand's major river. It is quite impressive because they were able to keep this river clean.

Amazing tour.. We traveled in White Orchid River cruise. It was a great experience. Reasonable price. International Buffet. lot of entertaining activities....like cultural dance, cabaret dance, live music etc..

wasted $40. came here to eat in a ship floating chao riverspend $40 for all u can eat to find food was not good. cold, tasteless and horrific.it's good to ordered some beers and see the view of the river, but not for the food.spend $60 for all u can eat with some beers.

Beautiful area. We stayed at the Marriott Hotel on the river and they and their own water taxi. If not, it is definitely worth paying for a water taxi. Most of the upscale hotels are located on the river with excellent dinning rooms.

Multipurpose River. It is impressive how large this river is, but even more impressive is the way it is used. In the middle of a big city you have tons of people commuting to work, school etc via the river. The boat rides and dinner cruises for tourists are a must do. Sailing into the little canals to see how Thai people live right on the river, from the very poor houses to the huge mansions it really depicts the life and people that live in Bangkok.

Great value!. If you take river express, not the tourist boat, you will end up between many locals which makes this experience so much more interesting. It is amazingly cheap and fast as well! There are many stops at main attractions.

The River of Life. Snaking through the heart of the Bangkok metropolis, the river has carried goods and people for centuries, from way up country down to the Gulf of Siam. It is the heart, life and soul of Bangkok, being crossed by quite a number of bridges, taking one to the east f the country. Best viewed from the Oriental Hotel, on the city side, or the Peninsula Hotel on the Chonburi side.

A quick look into Bangkok life. Loved the hustle and bustle of merchants on the river coupled with the serenity of boat travel( if you hold on tightly enough!)Really enjoyed the Bangkok, back in the day feeling it gave me and the feeling that I was really in another country!
Cruising Away. The thing that I liked about the cruise was the beautiful, breezy night and seeing the city with the lights shimmering all around

Cheap and fast. The riverside has a beautiful view. If you want to cross the river, it's very cheap. For example, If you have visited Wat po/Grand palace and want to go to Wat Arun, it will take only 3 bahts to cross the river. we can visit many temples, museums along the river. most of the riverside lies at Old Bangkok town. There are many boat packages where we can have dinner and watch the dance in the boats. Ask local vendors for various packages and select the best one for your choice.

Transit by ferryboat. A different and scenic sight of Bkk by ferry. You must be agile and fit to jump on and off the boat as the stops are quick and precarious. Make sure you know which stop you want to get off at, otherwise you'll find yourself on a joyride to the end as only Thai is spoken! Can get rather crowded and hectic during rush hour as the locals use it as their mode of transport from work home. No safety regulations seem to be in place, there is no limit to how many passengers they can pack on and there are no life jackets to be seen.The river is very busy with a constant stream of ferries, longboats, barges, towboats, cruisers, etc. zooming up and down. For the adventurous and easygoing. Not for family with young children, elders, physically disabled and easily queasy sensibilities. Ride at your own risk!

A River run through Bangkok.,. It lovely when we were taking the ferries on this River., Cheap, and Easy to use., Following, colour of, the running, services., White, orange etc. and the time it operated., 15 bahts each.Rather a big river and can see the temples as we pass it., Ferry can be quiet and can be very crowded. But it an experience to go on the ferry and other alternative is get the night cruise to go on it., The water make it cool to travel.

River of destinations. On this one river there are so many amazing destinations, from the Royal Place with emerald Buddha temple, mint and crown jewels museum, Chinatown with people packed into tiny alleys and the smells of cooking treats, to the creepy hospital museum of forensics with babies in bottles and that is naming just a few attractions. The river in Bangkok is like a main road for water taxi's. You can buy a day pass which means you can get on and off as you please. It can get busy but that's part of the fun. There are soo many things to see from the river itself including amazing temples, architectural building and historic places. Chao Phraya is also home to some of the best hotels. Check out the river itself for fish, yes really it looks dirty but there are some good sized fish in the river.
Easy and fast. Very easy with the many piers. Don't forget to get up and wave when you want to get out! Cheap and fast way to travel

Well Worth the trip though not very clean. Take the water ferry which costs 15 bahts per stop or if you are going early 150 bahts per day with unlimited stops. Great way to see different attractions e.g Grand Palace, Reclining Budhha, Temple of Dawn and many other areas.

Crasy Bangkok by the river. Very good, fast and cheap way to see Bangkok by the river and not in a traffic jam.
Quick way to get around and easy walking acsess to all major places,
Always a boat coming so no long waits but can be very crowded.
A must do in Bangkok and recomended

River Access. One of the locals directed me to the Water Taxi on the river as an easy way to get up an down the city. The public taxi is dirt cheap and stops in a multitude of places. I loved the ride, the river is great and you can see a large portion of the city or at least those up against the river. I was on the river for several hours and loved the sights, sounds and smell of the rides I took. Most everything you need in the way of food, bathroom, public transportation is accessible off the Chao Phraya and I used it often. Wizardofwhere.com

So Vibrant and Real!. Chao Phraya river is one of my favorite places in Bangkok because it is brimming with life of the city. Taking a commuter boat and watching everything going by is like going on a meditative trance: local people coming and going on a boat, longtail boats zooming by with panache of a race driver, huge barges carrying commercial loads — all of it is happening in front of you like in a dream.This artery of life is framed by a variegated city skyline that includes old houses on stilts, grandiose modern high rises and spires of many temples. You ride along something so vibrant and real.

Long tail boat around the clongs (canals in Bangkok). FANTASTIC - however, make sure you know the price of a long tail boat, ask your hotel, the locals will chance their arm when you enquire....beat them down considerably. The clogs will include stopping alongside a monastery, they will come out and offer bread to feed the fish so make sure you have a little baht, this is great fun, the fish come right up and will suck the bread from your fingers, some are huge! The clongs gives you a realistic view of true Thai life, we have done them four times now and never cease to enjoy it!!!
Peaceful Bliss. Enjoyed a river dinner cruise and stayed at the fabulous Shangri-La and loved watching the world go by on the Chao Phraya River.

A great way to travel around Bangkok by day. you buy a day ticket and you can jump on and off at the various stops.. we went to china town and it was soooooooo busy. the ferry takes you to all the tourist areas so well worth a try

Top tips for visiting Chao Phraya River. - ok this river is not exactly close to Bangkok city but nevertheless you could get there via the train then catch a taxi or bus when you come out from the train station- Sign up for a Princess cruise or take the normal ferry service which is around 30 baht each person. - I suggest you stop at Wang Lang stop because this place is not that touristy compare to the floating market. There are lots to see at Wang Lang market especially the old vintage market with old clothing and antiques.- Finish your trip by visiting Yaowarat (Chinatown of Bangkok). If you think my reviews have been helpful to you, please click 'Yes' for 'Was this review helpful?'

An evening on water :-). Its an attraction u must nt miss if u r in Bangkok, the Chao Phraya River Boat Cruise. Take a dinner cruise on boat named Princess 4 (if u r an Indian), thts the one on we took the cruise. Its a 2 hour long cruise on the river serving u grt Indian food, giving u a view of almost all the famous temples n buildings of d city, grt Indian music to dance on n on top of all their crew really enjoying with u n while serving u. They welcome u very warmly onboard n thn onwards try to make ur experience a one to cherish. The RIVER CITY mall through which you go to the pier is also nice. It costed us about 1100 Thai Baht per person which included our transfers, cruise, dinner. It ws the best attraction of Bangkok ad per me, a must do.
Dirty. A nice river and huge in size, surely a highlight for people living in Bangkok, however the dirt and smell that comes with it makes it a more negative experience
Dinner cruises are plenty. Many restaurants along the river operate a dinner cruise.The best bargain is operated by Yok Yor Marina, but you will have to cross the river to Thonburi side.

bangkok by night ..... this was one different experience ... as your cruise sails live perfomance will start singer was so good . she was singing indian songs and was so nice to here from her mouth 'made in india song .....lots of verity of food . bangkok by night is amazing ... you get to see all big temple and kings palace and many more famose building in this river cruise.... worth visiting chao phraya river cruise
Not to be missed..... Go on a river bus, a river taxi, a river cruise....whatever....but a great way to see the city and quicker getting about than on the road in rush hour....an experience!!

Heart beat of Bangkok. In modern Bangkok, the river is not as important as earlier days. However, it is still impressive. You cannot go to Bangkok and not see the Chao Phraya River. You can just watch the comings and goings on the river or take the river taxi to various stops, Chinatown, Wat Arun, etc. You see a different Bangkok, not just the busy streets. You can also take a guided tour of the river and canals. See how and where the ordinary people of Bangkok live. Take care, these tours can be a bit of a rip off. Negotiate the price before paying.
Great water transport. Water transport still part of people's life. Good experience along the river. Can see actual life of Thai people.

Nice River. Took boat from Saphan Taksin and went to Grand Palace, Wat Pho and Asiatique. You should plan one day itinerary too. It is easy for you to visit nearby attractions. few color boat can take, and just need to buy tickets on board, just tell the person where u wan to go. In this river quite many different boat. It is fun. Careful when u take out your camera and take photo :)

Nice river but confusing on which line to get in!. Loved taking the public ferry for only 15BT, but you really had to know which boat to take! It's the one with the orange flags on it. The people on the dock always try to sell you the more expensive tickets for 40-150 BT saying it's more direct without stops, etc... There are so many different lines of people for different boats. Be sure to ask and ask again! Lots of them aren't friendly when you say which line is the 15BT. Then they say 40 is cheap and try to get you to pay that price. That annoyed me so much!

Lifeblood of the city. Take one of the ferries the locals use to get around and you get a long and very inexpensive sightseeing tour. The river isn't the cleanest but there are heaps of workers on barges and boats cleaning it up. You see where people live along the river, from hovels to mansions.

Relaxing on the river. I love to take a boat after visiting the Wat Pho and Grand Palace. They are easy to find and I am sure you will enjoy it as much I did. The best is to cruise down the Chao Phraya and to stop at the Oriental Hotel or River city to get a drink there.

Thai history from another perspective!. The view of anything from the water offers a much different perspective. That's the case with seeing all the great historical landmarks along this famous river.
A great tour. If you want to see Bangkok taking a river tour is a must. It is surprising as well as fascinating. And good choices to hop off and tour
1 hour ride by boat. Interesting. Different view of the city from the river. Feeding the huge freshwater fishes was a good experience.
Chao Phraya River. I enjoyed the boat trip round the Chao Phraya river. The people stay in their homes round the river and sell foods. Enjoyable and memorable
Dragon Boat!. We loved cruising down the river. A nice way to cool down a bit & get a view of the city from a different perspective. I would say this is a must do in BKK. Great fun!

Less hectic. After smelling all the fumes from the tuck tucks one must try out the boat alternative.
We got around by boat and took in the sights. We jumped on and off very easily and found it more scenic.
River Cruise. We took the river cruise with lunch and it was great. Huge variety of food and efficiently catered. The narrative was great to sit and listen to as you leisurely take in the sights.

Dinner Cruise on Chaophraya River. I was travelled to Bangkok on 15 July to 22 July 2014. It's was an exciting and memorable 2 hours long evening cruising and dining along the Chaophraya River. The buffet dinner is served with the live band musical. I felt so relax and enjoy the surrounding while the cruising along Chaophraya river pass such as Rama I bridge (Memorial Bridge), Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun), The Royal Grand Palace..etc. It's was so beautiful night view. I loved it. For this Dinner Cruise on Chaophraya River, you can join the local travel agent for the reservation. They'll pick/drop you from the hotel to the River City Complex (main entrance)

I did this twice. There is something quite relaxing about the river cruise. I love being on the move with the wind in my hair, especially in hot and humid bangkok. Its quite long so it really feels relaxing and you can get on and off and see the temples. Best way to do it really.

River traffic. I could sit & watch the ferries going in & out of the Taksin Pier all day long. The amount of other traffic on this river is amazing, it's a great way to visit several tourist attractions.
awesome. definitely ride on the long tails up and down the river -- go into the back waterways and feed the fish by the temples. Note: there are more than one place to feed the fish, so don't worry!

Long Boat Tours. You have to do it, it will take you to the heart of the water transit system and through the lock system, there are many stops of interest along the way. We took a half day tour it was amazing.

History. The great river going through Bangkok. It looked nice in the brochure but when we arrived at Samhain takin bridge the river was dirty and very smelly, there must be no life left in the river, Bangkok could do a little more to revive the river again

Life line of Bangkok. Had a great time on Chao Phraya River. This was a my favourite part of being in bangkok, to hop in and out of Ferry at different Piers of my interest or to take a cruise in evening. A Must experience for every traveller in Bangkok!!

River and Canal Trip. We chartered a long tail boat for an hour at 700 bhat. The captain took us on both the river and in the city canals. It was very interesting to see the ultra luxury hotels and businesses next to a sheet metal house on stilts with laundry drying. I highly recommend doing this as a way to get a quick grasp on the river area and other things you may want to take a closer look at.

Big winding river - Different side of Bangkok. Travel on the River for several hours using water taxis, long tailed boats or other boat services. You can visit some interesting stops along the way. I like to just get on a water taxi, go one or two stops, get off and wander that neighborhood, then get on and do the same thing over again. A great way to explore and lose yourself in Bangkok.
The Best way to see Bangkok. the River cruise is one of the best way to see Bangkok at Night.The city is really beautifull at night and full of Lights.

Just ok. We used the local boats which are extremely cheap, but the views are not fantastic I am glad I did not pay for an organised trip.we got the boat to the grand palace and then went further down the river and back to the starting point. Overall I am glad we did it.

Life along the river. Main thoroughfare for anything big that needs to be transported along the waterways of Bangkok. Good view of the river from theShangri-La Hotel, Peninsula, Mandarin Oriental and Sheraton.Take a river cruise to experience how the locals live along the river. The floating market is unique and a "must experience" when in Bangkok
tuk tuk. it is a bit expensive for me and use taxi meter service is better. However i think everyone should at least try once.

Relaxing and enjoyable experience. People had warned that the River was dirty and smelly. I agree I would not want to swim in it or drink the water accidentally, however did not find it smelly at all. We enjoyed the water taxi experience and it was very cheap, clean and comfortable for the short trip. I was happy we go to experience the ferry/taxi. I am not sure though that I would choose to do the dinner or lunch boat experience, since there are many other things of interest in other parts of Thailand than to spend extra time in Bangkok.

Worth a ride. Not the cleanest river around but one with a lot of activity on it. Its a great way to spend a day or a few hours as you take in the many sites along the river. Best way to visit the Palace
A nice relaxing cruise.. I have taken a paid cruise,used the paid public transport and taken the free boat rides.All very different but worth the time and effort to do.

A Must Visit. We took the BTS to Saphan Taksin station, then short walking for 5 minutes before reaching the main entrance to buy the ticket. There's also a lot of tour package by boat provider/owner. You can choose which on is suitable. They provide short trip (15 minutes-1 hour) and long trip (>1 hour) to many attractions near the riverside.Chao Phraya is a must visit if you are in Bangkok. Feel the difference and see Bangkok from another perspective.
a wonderful way to get around. Though the ferry system is very chaotic at the various docks, but once one is on the correct ferry, it is the best way to travel up and down the river.

Worth it !. We took the BTS to Surasak Taksin station - the pier was a short walk. A regular express boat (15B) was a great experience to see the city from a different perspective. The boat takes you past several tony hotels and other landmarks and a great way to get to the Grand Palace. I am sure it would be an equally worthwhile experience at night..
An excellent place to relax. i liked the professional approach of the service and the environment there. better to visit during the cold months.
Take a local boat. Extremely pleasant way to while away a few hours on this fascinating river. Very cheap and plenty to photograph along the way.

Experience it to believe it !. It was a nice dinner cruise. Luckily got table on upper deck. Gusts of cold winds flowing, music, drinks, dance & friends - what more do u want from life. Go enjoy it !!!

Packed. Travelled down the river to get to the Grand palace. Decided to use the public boats as they only charge 15 bht compared to 150bht if use the tourist boats. Whatever boat you decide to use be prepared to be squashed in like a sardine and yelled at to move down into the boat even when there is no room to be found. The river itself wasn't as dirty as people say and there are some lovely buildings and temples along the banks. As i travelled during the day i didn't get to see everything lit up at night which i believe would be lovely.
amazing. I love rivers and I find the Chao Phraya very beautiful! It is so good to see the Wat Arun on the other side! Magical!
A must do. Buy the all day pass as it allows you to get on and off the river ferries as often as you want. This is the best way to explore the best of Bangkok!!

What a river!. When visiting Bangkok it is a must-do to experience the Chao Phraya river by boat. It is so easy and tourist friedly to use this kind of transport. The cheapest water taxi is the Orange Flag boat @ THB15 per person per way. These boats come along very regularly (every 15 / 20 min) and docks at each pier on either side of the river. You can either go Northbound or Southbound. Just make sure you embark /disembark the boat quickly, because the boat only stops for a short time at each pier before its off to the next stop. You can travel from Phra Arthit in the north to City Pier in the south in less than 30 minutes. Just keep your ticket for the duration of the trip to show the boat conductor that you had paid. You can get off at any pier in between to go sightseeing, visiting the temples or do shopping. Just keep in mind that once you got off, you have to pay THB15 for the next trip. Very convenient and fast way of transport especially when it is so humid and hot.

Cheapest or Free trip up/down the river by riverboat. Don't take those expensive guided tours of the Chao Phraya river instead take the BTS train to Saphan Taksin stop (close to Shangri-la Hotel) and walk down to the River Boat terminal underneath. For 20-50 Baht you can ride up and down the river on the public taxi boats or alternately take the FREE hotel river boat shuttles (Hilton, Anantara, Sheraton etc) which also ply the river usually every 20-30 minutes, Sign board clearly show routes and which boats stop and with berth. Fun for all ages.
Chao Phraya River cruise. The experience was priceless! You get to see Bangkok, in a more laid-back manner. The host and the team was very entertaining. Believe me, you'll never get bored.
The highlight of my Bangkok visit !. A must do in Bangkok is the long tail boat ride , private ride, it takes about 1h and it is a wonderful experience !
Nice. I was so excited to take a boatride through the Chao Phraya river and enjoyed another side of modern Bangkok.

The Best View in Bangkok. It you are in Bangkok, drop by the river front. There are plenty of food to choose from as well as different river cruise to pick from from different operators. Most if them are good.

Interesting !!!. Took a boat tour of the river. I am not quite sure whether to recommend it or not. The surrounding was beautiful but river is very dirty and somewhat stinky. I probably won't do it again.

Very nice to take boatride. It is very interesting to take a boatride through the Chao Praya riverSee how the people live and see little floating boats with all kinds of fruit, drinks, beer and souvenirs
Lovely. I would recommend getting a daily pass and taking the ferry up the river to see the grand palace and wat arun. Really cheap trip and the views of Bangkok from the river are awesome.

Great way to get a first view of Bangkok's tourist highlights. I thoroughly recommend taking the tourist boat cruise from Central Pier ( right by Saphan Taksin BTS Station) to Phra Arthit pier (in the backpacker area / Khao San Road) to get the best initial views of the tourist highlights in Bangkok and to orientate yourself. From the river you get great views and a commentary of all the major attractions for just 40 baht. After our initial trip we used the ferry boats that the locals used to get along the river (distinguishable by the orange, blue and green flags that the various companies operate under): at only 15 baht a trip. Being on board and watching how the boatman ( who attaches the mooring rope) and the boat "driver" operate these very long and awkward boats using just a series of whistle tones leaves you in disbelief; the river has a very swift current, there are numerous other boats on the river to dodge and the skill those guys display is quite amazing. It's a great way to spend an hour and the sights that you see as well as interaction with the locals going about their day makes for a memorable time

Great by rice boat. Lots of activity on this river,great trip on a rice boat with nibbles and drinks or just fun taking a long boat or many hotel shuttle boats. There is a local ferry boat that leaves from pier1 and takes you to Grand Palace for 15baht.

Fun!. We had a river cruise which was really great to do. our took us around all of the river houses down the canals and past the sites. Really nice to see how the locals use the river.
worth paying to do and not very expensive... but haggle!

Used water taxis all day everyday. Our 2nd visit July 2013. On our first trip to Bangkok we were nervous and went on organised tours. Our second we travelled around on our own for 7 days and it was amazing. The water taxi is so cheap and the Chao Phraya is a huge river and main arterial route. The Grand Palace and many of the temples actually have river stops not to mention all the hotel restaurants etc. It is a simple easy way to get around. Everywhere we went was two events in one as you got a boat trip day and night and you got to your tourist destination or restaurant. We were conned by taxi drivers almost daily in the city on our first visit so this way you are travelling with locals and it was safe as it's government run. The river is wide - churns different colours depending on the weather - I've seen it deep blue and almost brown after a rain storm. You pass some fantastic impressive sites, you also pass the not so impressive signs of poverty and neglect. The further out you go you see the countryside flanking the bank. Even if you take one boat trip you will not be disappointed.

Fascinating. We hired a private boat from the pier by the grand palace and went around the main river and the side canals. The latter was more interesting and it was fascinating to see the variety of greenery and life on the canal. Cheery greetings by many Thai children swimming in the canal and a few large lizards lounging on logs.
Not the prettiest river but great for transport. We used the ferries twice to easily get back and forth from our hotel for touring. It's also a nice change or pace from a taxi or tuk-tuk.

Interesting but once is more than enough. It is certainly beautiful to look at Bangkok from a boat, but after 15 minutes I felt that was fine, then we passed some kind of temple (on the backside) and after we came to some sellers in their little boats. It was charming but they were pushy and when they realized we were not buying anything (simply because we did not like what they had to offer) suddenly they were not that kind and happy any longer :) I don't like to be treated as a walking wallet, and that is pretty much what some people see tourists as.
Boat trip fantastic. We went down the river on a lovely boat we had dinner on there which was lovely bad the views are well worth and a must

Over priced. It is cheaper to fly from Bangkok to chiang rai then it is to hire a boat for an hour! I know which I would prefer! Saying that once you you get past the smell it is quite relaxing and the huge monitor lizards are a highlight

River dinner cruise. We loved our authentic dinner cruise on a converted rice barge. The food was authentic Thai food which was lovely to try, but beware of the chilli condiment if you have senstive taste buds. Each couple had their own dinner table with individual courses brought to your table. There was authentic Thai background music and dancing. The views along the river bank were beautiful. We had a very enjoyable evening.

Just take the ordinary express. For about 15c we went on the Chao Phraya all the way to the end of the ferry used by the Thai people. It was great fun. We also went on the Cha Phraya tourist boat but the commentary in English was hard to understand and it did not stop at all jetties.

Long tailed boat trip. The Chao Phraya river is a must do when in Bangkok. Hire one of the colourful long tailed boats and away you go. They can be rented from "jetties" near the Shangri La or the Peninsula hotels. The ride will take you through the canals and show you an interesting part of Bangkok life/ living. You can also stop and visit some temples. Don't miss Wat Arun and climb up to the top!
Old & new Bangkok. You get to know a town by boat, it's the same with Bangkok. Old & new, together with rich and poor and magnificent temples, you can't wait to visit

Good example of Bangkok day to day life. A trip on the tourist boat along the Chao Phraya River is a good way to see the contrast of cultures in Bangkok. During the cruise, you can see everything from ultra modern 5 star hotels to wooden houses on stilts plus a view of the imposing Wat Arun Temple. The tourist boat is also a very handy way of going to other places of interest which are situated close to the river. If you intend to be a frequent user of the tourist boat during the day, then a day pass may be the way to go.

Interesting means of transport. Experienced both free shuttle to go to Asiatique and also the 15 bath public transport to go to Grand Palace, these boats are really an attraction on its own. It is not some kind of a romantic ride a la Venice gondola, however it is interesting for the fact that, despite the polluted river, locals really use this method of transports to go to places and it is deemed super efficient and fast!

Catch any of the boats. I thought I would only catch the tourist boat for 40 B with the commentary which was good, but actually the long boats were just as useful and stop at more places so have more options. Main thing to note is they stop at 5.30 except for Night Market free boats.
Interesting. Easy & cheap transport. Very interesting sights can be seen on the boat ride. The river is very polluted & quite stinky.

Insight into Bangkok & great means of travel. Hiring a Dragon boat for an hour or two is well worth it. Aside from the exhilaration of zipping around ferries, you get to see an uncluttered view of some of the best sites of Bangkok and travel up the side canals to experience what Bangkok was like not so many years ago. It's also a fantastic way to travel within Bangkok, avoiding the endless jams or sitting.g at traffic lights!

Means of transport and an attraction on its own. If you want to maove from the north of Bangkok to the sputh, or vice versa it pays of to take one of the ferries. If you want to go to the royla palace it's ofte. Even faster to first take a skytrain to the river and then one of the boats. The cool breeze makes it a joy ride and there's lot to see on the banks. Take a boat to Ninthaburi and then a taxi to Ko Kret for a fun day out.
Good ride. Its very easy to transfer yourself over the Chao Phraya river, there are several stops. Just take the cheap boots and not the touristic one, look first were you want to go and then hop in.

Always something to see...... There is always something to see on the river..... and the rivers boats are the way to see it. getting on & off them can be interesting (sometimes) but go with the flow. have the camera ready for that picture.... Wat Arun is always a site to see :)
Worth a memorable trip. If the color of the water is what you are looking for, forget about this river. If the beautiful surrounding & landscapes mesmerizes you this is the one
Great!. Worth to visit! We used river for transportation road since taxi could not come to all areas du to "revolution". But view is stanning. Very interesting place to visit.

Forget about the Seine or the Thames. This river is what life is about, I would travel up and down the whole day long, and at night also, for absolute peanuts, you have great sights, meet amazing people, locals and tourists, monks and hippies..............a hop away from great temples, restaurants, shops...who cares I stay on the boat :)

Some good sites along the river. The river is extremely dirty/muddy water is brown and lots of waves, not good for someone who gets sea sick, however the sights along the Chao Phraya River of the city is sure to amaze, just ensure that you bargain with the boat guy, cause as usual they bump up the prices if they suspect your the usual gullible tourist
River view. Never a dull moment from a river view hotel room, handy for getting up and down to the Palace. Guess I just like boats

The cheapest way to get to the Grand Palace from Central Bangkok. We decided against a tour and wanted to make our own way to the Grand Palace. If we did it, you can too! We took the BTS Skytrain from our local station, Nana on the Sukhumvit line and changed to the Silom Line at Siam (this is considered the centre of Bangkok). Get off at the river station which is called Saphan Taksin.There are different types of boats. For fun, we wanted to travel cheaply for 15 Baht with the locals. If you do too, look for the boats with the orange flags. For the orange locals boat, you buy a ticket on the boat, so head to the jetty on the left and join the queue that starts behind the ticket booth. Have your money ready to pay for your ticket on the boat. Most people use a 20 Baht note. The tourist boats have blue flags and cost around 100-150 Baht. For these, you need to buy a ticket from the booth. For your massive investment of 15 Baht, you get a one-way ticket and can get on and off any stops along the way. Be ready to get on and off the boat fairly quickly. Have a map so you can identify the stops as you go because their are no announcements and the signage is not easily spotted. For the Grand Palace, get off at Tha Chang.On the way home, repeat the process. There is a seated area where you can wait and you'll see people starting to move when the orange flagged boat arrives. Including BTS Skytrain fares, our entire transport costs were 288 Baht for 2 people and we had the satisfaction of doing it ourselves.

Murky water!. The main river of Bangkok. We travelled along the river to get to Wat Pho. Some very modern hotels etc interspersed with very poor looking rickety dwellings alongside. There are some beautiful wats along the riverside and plenty of landing stages to hop on and off to visit various attractions. More of a watery highway than an 'attraction'.

Great River Boat Ride. A good way to see Bangkok from the river. You can get off at any of the numerous stops and later get on another boat. Somebody is always speaking giving information about the sights. You can get there on the MRT system.

not necessarily the heart, but at least a major artery. A local friend has referred to this as the "Coca Cola" River in a tongue-in-cheek nod to the color. We have traveled the river in a number of ways: on a regular "commuter" boat, on a tourist long-boat, and on a crossing ferry from temple to temple. The public conveyences are shockingly inexpensive, and this and the commercial traffic moving up and down the river demonstrate how vital the river is to the day-to-day existence of Bangkok.It is definitely worth a visit for a view into an essential aspect of Bangkok life.

Jolty and not so clean. I took a boat ride over the Chao Phraya River with the public ferry boat at the "steep" fee of 3 Baht one way. The journey was jolty and bumpy and I had to sit down to keep balance. Looking into the water it was dark brown and a lot of stuff was floating in the water. The water way was very busy with long shaft boats and empty barges that blocked our journey, the return trip was the same price and the same adventure. Nice experience, not a must.
An eye opener!. A cruise through the Chao Phraya River will take you through a journey of Thai life style. You will learn how people use to live in the olden days.
Take a Evening Cruise. to enjoy a dinner on the boat as the lighted riverside of Bangkok passed around you like a video. Wat Arun looks amazing and so does a hanging bridge on the river.

River best way to get around. If you are visiting the major temples and palace near the river, I found the best way to get around was to jump on and off the local river taxis, avoid the congested Bangkok traffic. There is a ferry stop very close to where you can get the BTS to travel to other parts of the city.
a bit dirty. It was good to see all those fishes but the river was a bit dirty. the ride on the river is worth taking though!

Take a River Taxi. Great freedom ,to get off and stay as long as you like .Often there is a map on the the underside of your ticket.Enjoy the day at minimal costs and remember to start heading home no later than 18.30

Good way to see the sights or get around. If you've only a few hours in BKK, take the public ferry boats and see the sights from the river. If you've longer use them as an alternative to taxis to get around, esp combined with the MTR.

Lunch or dinner on Bangkoks waterway. Great boat trip with choice of meals on board (evening trip is deliteful with fairy lites all over the river)and lovely tour that shows BKKS magnificent skyline of skyscrapers

Evening ride.. Went to took a cruise on this river. Went at evening time. Passed a few temples with the sunset.
A cooling breeze n nice scenery.
Chao Phraya River Cruise. Lovely experience it is such a lovely evening at night. Bangkok is so well lit on the river side, it is real fun
Nice and Romatic at Night. It was a nice experience to sail the river and to have a nice diner on the side of a thai dancing show, recomended for a romantic night!
Memorable experience though a dirty river. Memorable experience though a dirty river. A return in the future is on the cards. Pleasant trip along the network of these rivers.
Beautiful. By boat this is the way I travel in BKK very fast - saw many temples, old style houses, and restaurants. I and my friend stop at a pier to give bread to fish. Bread and boat cost are cheap

Very convienient to travel via river routes in the Bangkok city.. The Chao Phraya river perhaps is the lifeline of the Bangkok city.Travel in this crowded city is very chaotic, the river ways provide much relief to the crowds of the roads.Actually i realised the usefulness of river routes at the 2nd last day of my 7 day visit to the city. next time i would use these routes much better. There is a ferry which goes around the river and there are pick up and drop points spread throughtout the city- ( one can google and find the route and stops) the fares are exteremely reasonable.There is also private boats youcan take- costing ~2000 Bhat. however this is costly- i got trapped first time and paid 1500 bhat for a single journey, which otherwise would be ~80Bhat in a shared boat.
Easy to get around. I recommend the river for traveling to see the major sites. There are many spots to get on and off and routes are clearly marked. Less stressful than the road!

Best way to travel in Bangkok - cheap, cool, fun and interesting!. Travelling on the public boats up and down the river is the best way to get around Bangkok - whether you want to get somewhere specific, or just enjoy the scenery.There are a few different types of public boats, but the orange flag ones are especially useful as cheap (currently 14 baht for any length of journey in one direction - this is much better value than the blue flag tourist boats and you get to travel with locals too) stop at almost every pier, and travel frequently in both directions (every 20 minutes during the day).If you haven't been to Bangkok before (or even if you have!) and you want to do some sightseeing, it's a cheap, cool and breezy, fun and convenient way to see much of the city in just an hour or two - just travel all the way to the end stop in one direction, and then travel all the way back again. You get good views of the city along the riverbanks and of the other boat traffic.Be ready to get on and off reasonably quickly, as they don't stop at any of the piers longer than necessary to unload and load passengers. Also keep an eye on the pier names/numbers as you get nearer your destination, as the announcements aren't always easy to hear.Check first boat times if wanting to travel very early, and last boat times if travelling around sunset, as the service only runs during daylight hours.
cheap boat rides. we got a boat to wat po had a lovely experience boat fares were very very cheap i would definately recommend this

Economical option of exploring Chao Phraya River... No need to opt for costly cruisers while exploring the river.. you can get the same experience for a mere fraction of the cost. You can choose to take river ferries (Orange flag boats) with ticket costing just THB 15 per head for the entire ride from end to end. We found this an excellent option since we could get down at any pier, explore the local area and get on the next boat for our next destination..Its fun adventurous of enjoying the river and it's various attractions.

Great for getting around Bangkok. This is the best and cheapest transport anywhere. Something like 12 Baht for a fairly long trip along the river, with lots of stopping points where you can get off and look around. If you get lost, just ask someone where the river is and you're back on track.
Great way to beat the fumes and see the city. We took a longboat on the river and through the canals. It was a nice change from the never ending chaos of Bangkok streets

Enjoyable albeit a bit pricey. 350 Baht for the 45 minute ride is a bit pricey for me but since it was my first time touring Thailand, I knew I had to. It was very nice and enjoyable to see the sites and sounds of the river. Seeing the famous landmarks of the city from this point of view is amazing.

Enjoy the river experience like a local. Don't hire a 1 hour boat, because it is not worth it. Get one of the public boats at any station and enjoy the ride. Whenever you're ready to go back you get off at the station and take the next boat. It is a great way to see the city!

Bustling river. This river is really busy and i wonder how the boats navigate with such efficiency, there are huge barges, long tail boats, speed boats , atches, ferry's and all of them have a way around it, one must not miss the boat ride because it gives a historic perspective and a modern outlook of the city while you ride through.
The day ticket is good value. It is an easy ride up the river and allows you to bob around . If you sit near the front you can hear the guide which is really rather useful.

Relaxing, cheap, and you're on a boat.. This is one of my favorite things to do, and I do it every time I come through Bangkok. Cruising around on these boats, touristy or not, is a great way to see the city, it's people, and the diverse facets of life. Locals, tourists, monks, everyone rides, from temples, to Chinatown, past hotels, hi rises, and stilt houses. Also, as a food snob, I will reluctantly reveal that one of the absolute best spots to eat in the city is very close to the Wang Lang station (also home to Sri Raj hospital, where you can visit the preserved serial killers and intense forensics museum...although, you might want to do the food another day, trust me...).

A heap of fun. What a way to get aroundBoats galore and amazing to seeTook along boat and laughed the whole way even when our driver stopped to do some repair work to the boat (welding the exhaust on )Watching the boats shifting dirt etc was unbelivable and a great photo oppertunity .To sum it up best way to get from one side to the other with less traffic thatn on th road
the place is nice did enjoy the food and the cruise. something memorable for us my husband and me...the place remind us of the cruise we did 40 years ago....

Great way to get around Bangkok. The Chao Phraya River provides Bangkok with a different type of transportation other than taxis. You can use the river taxis to take you to many destinations around the Chao Phraya River. Also Chao Phraya River cruises are a nice way for a nice dinner in Bangkok

great day out. took the bts to sathorn bridge to take the boat to the wat phra temple .done this trip years ago .although the boat is very packed .its a lovely experience to remember.you can hop off/on at different locations along the river .and we took the boat to wat phra .plenty to see along the river with a guided speech of the sights as you go along .cheap to take the boat 23 baht .
Excellent View!. An inexpensive way to get around. And using this transportation method provides an excellent view of temples and other sites.

A river tour is a must in Bangkok. Though it may seem a bit touristy, after doing it I think a river tour is a must. You see the city from a completely different angle. You can access a number of interesting attractions straight off the river. And this is the only way to see the canals and experience the reality of life there.

Crazy beautiful busy and fascinating all at once... whether on it or observing it from up above.... The Chao Phraya river is a busy waterway running through the heart of Bangkok. On our first visit to the city on leg one of a round the world trip we treated ourselves to a five star hotel over-looking the river - a last little bit of luxury before the back-packing ahead.
