From our high balcony the river is a working water way, big international liners slowly heave past, small but crazily long boat trains float past - several concrete platforms linked together carrying goods and somewhere on the middle ones you see a shack-like hut where the crew live aboard, hotel touristy junk boats whizz across the river turning suddenly, somehow narrowly avoiding each other, and then small individual long-tail Thai fishing and worker boats with their long whirring outboards zip about... it's an amazing place... Our hotel ran a tourist boat from the hotel to the main ferry points. Public ferries as well as tourist ferries run the length of the city and are a great way to cross the city - we picked the public ferry - there is a map with the stops and you just work out the nearest one to where you want to go - jump on and jump off - it's a pretty quick turnaround but great fun and much cheaper than the tourist ferries. If you're travelling up and down the city - take the Chao Phraya river at least once - the sights on the river and along the river bank are fascinating, and the river itself is the crazy busy lifeline of Bangkok.We visited Bangkok and the river several times over 2009 and 2010 - but I couldn't select these dates for the review below so it says 2013!

The river crosses Bangkok and is used by bus boats for public transportation.. This river is the main river in BANGKOK and crosses the city. Unfortunately, it is not kept clean, people throw all kind of garbage in it. There is a very nice curiosity in this river: sacred fish people feed and do not catch. You may see this at pier 14 and also other piers. You see parents giving bread to their children to feed the fish. You also see many beautiful temples along the river.

Fast flowing and very busy. fascinating to watch the ships' captains manage the fast flowing river. Heavy traffic from tugs pulling huge barges to local ferries, visitor ferries and the local private craft powered by huge four and six cylinder engines sitting in the open air in the stern of each boat. They really travel fast.Good view of the city as you cruise past the city or visit the floating market (Saturdays till 1:00pm)

Great Temples just along the riversides. There are important temples along this river. A newer night market, Asiatique has just started as well. By taking the Chao Phraya Express Boat (Ferry) at Saphan Taksin BTS station, you can visit all the major temples along this river especially The Grand Palave and Wat Phra Keaw, Wat Pho and Wat Arun.
Dinner on the river.. Dinner on the river is a must. Nice meal, nice sightseeing and there was good entertainment, Thai dancers were very good. You can book a trip thru your hotel.

Brown as expected, but amazing at night. The Chao Praya river is brown, polluted, but not smelly, and all round what you would expect of a river running through the centre of Bangkok. However, it has several excellent experiences available. Plan trips along the river, particularly to Wat Arun, and take the ferry. The variety of boats you will encounter, like the river taxis which have what look like giant rocket engine on the back, are a treat. At night the river can light up, so a river cruise, especially on a night like for the Loy Krathong festival, can be an amazing experience.

River tour. nice temple and river along the river for just 150 baht you can enjoy unlimited boat ride.but some jetty the tourist boat does not stop u have to change boat to get across the river for 7 baht or along the rive for 15 baht.

Weekend Exploring. Another little advertised day of inexpensive touring. Buy a Day ticket for the weekend tourist boat - information booklet & map included. There is a BTS station 5 mins walk from the dock and you can hop on and off at any of the stops up and down the river and have fairly easy access to many attractions. Be prepared to walk as some of the attractions are a good walking distance and other you will want to explore thoroughly. During my day out I hopped onto the wrong river taxi and ended up goodness knows where, but I did get to see things I didn't know about previously. Yes, the river taxis are crowded and can be noisy but if you are up for a little adventure then give this a try.

Leisurely. The two hour river ride in a long tail boat is better than getting on the local ferry which is over crowded and noisy. We thoroughly enjoyed seeing the out of the ordinary sights of life by the canals and river.

Super easy to navigate. The ferry system on the river is extremely easy to use. The blue flagged boats a for tourists, yellow for commuters and orange for everyone. We used the orange boats for 15bht per trip, whether you go one stop or up the whole river. Be aware though that not all boats stop at all piers and be quick when getting on and off. You will get jostled in peak times and my husband and I got separated when I dithered just for a second and the boat left without me! Don't be scared of these boats, they are a great way to see the city and extremely cheap.

Nice was to explore Bangkok. I explored Bangkok most from the Chao Phraya River as I stayed at The Peninsula Hotel as well. It is very fun!! A tip, be aware if you need to get the Yellow Flag Boat, the price is only 15 Thb, but they always try to be smart with tourist and charge 40 Thb instead. The 40 Thb is only for the Blue Flag Boat.

The heart of Bangkok. If you don't go there, you'll miss a major part of Bangkok and you wont understand this city at all. An absolute must-go.There are numerous ways to see chao phraya: with commuters boats (orange, blue or green lines), costing few bahts, private longtail taxi boats with absurd V8 engines and crazy prop shaft, refurb rice barges, mass-tourist boats (chao phraya queens 0 to 4), small ferries. Just pick up one. Don't swim though.

Good way to spend quality time.. Visited in Dec-12. What a beautiful night it went on...u can saw Bangkok's famous buildings through Cruise. i highly recommend Cruise to couples! Buffet Dinner was also there also lady singing Indian songs was the highlight of the theme.
Beautiful experience. The hotels organize bus trips to the boats and there fore you are cared for. You can barter the price which we did.

Relaxing alternative to seeing Bangkok. To see Bangkok by river was very relaxing and comfortable. Many of the city's major attractions a located along and accessible by the river. We decided to use a guide and bought the Rice Barge Cruise (with round/return trip transfer from hotel to pier included) offered by Asia Web Direct for THB700 per person. It was a reasonable and worth the fee paid. We were taken on a long 'express' boat up Chao Phraya and was introduced to Chinatown, the Grand Palace, Wat Phra Kaew (Emerald Buddha), went past the Royal Barges Museum (had a peeked at the beautiful ancient barges!), explored the riverside living, scenery and kelongs of the Bangkok Noi river and Wat Arun. It was well informed and English speaking local guide so much was learned during the relaxing boat ride. On the way back, we were transferred to a rice barge where cold towels, a buffet of tropical fruits, cocktails/mocktails and drinks were served. From the river cruise, we could plan and decide which attraction to see next. We thoroughly enjoyed it and was worth the fee.

Great river trips !. I find it a great way to see different parts of bkk along the river. Just hop on a public boat that doesn't cost any pain. just follow the thai people and walk into their rich culture, thats the best part in travelling.

Well worth the money. You can get a ticket to hop on and off the boat all day. It another way of travelling around to various attractions as well as view the city off land. At night it looks spectacular, like a different place from the day. You can also hire a speed boat that will wiz you around in no time but you dont really get to get off and see anything, just for fun and very pricey no set price so can get scammed big time here, especially if the taxi or chuck chuck drop you off, they get a commission.

Good way to get around. Lots of small and large boats. The ticketing and payment situation was a bit confusing at first but proces were low, so it got all worked out. A fascinating view of Bangkok. People told us the water was very, very dirty but very little got on us so no problem.

The ferrys are cheap and easy to use.. The Chao Phraya river has a ferry service that stops at different places. It cost 15 baht. If you want you can take the express ferry for 75 baht. It is a cheap way to travel the river. There are also ferrys that take you straight across the river so you don't have to find a bridge to walk over.
"Row row row your boat". Cheap but noisy ride.Temples to go to - Wat Arun, Wat Pho, Wat Phrakaew (Grand Palace).A few hotels are located along Chao Praya if you want scenic views from your room
relaxing. Relaxing and great sunset. It is great to go with the boat and see so many beautiful temples on the river coast.

Must try it. The Chao Phraya river itself didn't impressive at all, looked dirty on some place, but the scenery along the river cannot be missed. The pier that most easily reached by MRT/BTS is Central Pier, which is close to Saphan Taksin BTS. I explore the river using 2 different kind of boat. First, I go with tourist boat (blue flag) which cost me THB40/way and ticket should be bought on ticket booth before boarding. In this boat all the passenger can sit and there's a English speaking tour guide that explain about tourism spot that we can visit in every pier, and it help us a lot with many kind of information. On the way back, I using orange flag boat that cost me only THB15 and pay on the boat. The sitting area on this boat are minim, and almost one-third of the passenger are standing. I really like standing on the back and feel the breeze...^_^. Don't try it for children cause it slippery.

A Good Journey. we traveled on this river a few times and it is great to watch all the boats whether they are large or small all going at speed but avoiding each other,a great way to get around the city,and very cheap as well.
a dream river cruise. nothing but praise full of enjoyment and the lights temples palace to go with the night cruise and food just a wonderful way to see bangkok.

I'm glad we survived. The boats are quite old and they get too crowded at times. The brown colour of the water makes you scared when you imagine falling down into it. Besides the stations are very old and they looked very insecure to me. But the river is huge, they even have freight boats/ship what you may call them.

A Must Do. My family took a longboat and traveled the canals. Fantastic. We did an hour trip , long enough to see the different landscapes along these water ways. Gives you a different concept from the water. Worth the money.

Very touristy. it is a nice way to travel along the river and see modern buildings.When buying a ticket try to get the fare for return and not for a whole day travel unless you want to hop on off for the day

good clean up effort. Our hotel is by the Chao Phraya River, I am glad to say that over many years the effort to clean up the river had paid off. I notice less rubbish, less pollution, and spotted occasional fish swimming in the river. Keep up the good work!

The stench. Jumped on a overpriced boat and took a ride around the canals, look, we all know it stinks and is nothing more than a sewerage outlet, but the bigger concern was people swimming in such filth. I saw two giant lizards swimming the waterways and wondered who on earth would be game enough to swim in this. Like much of Bangkok, it fails to live up to expectation.

Water front travel was a good experience. Though, not the cleanest of rivers, the water transport system which has been built is a boon for the tourists. It helps you cover a number of places along the river side.
Bangkok's wet highway. You have to spend a few hours on this central artery of Bangkok. Or, sit on its banks and watch Bangkok float by.
Good experience with private long tail boat. Have a great experience with private long tail boat, river might not very clean, but can know more Bangkok's citizens lifestyle.

River of many sights. The Chao Praya river is the life line of Bangkok, forget the cruises, just jump on one of the water Taxi's and for a minimal fee sit with the locals and travel the river, head several stops north or several stops south and take in the sights, for those who want the dinner cruises take a trip on one of the cruises that run in the evenings from River City shopping centre and enjoy the excellent food and entertainment provided, and for those staying in hotels along the Chao Praya, with river views sit back and relax and watch Bangkok river life

We had a buffet meal and cruise down the river. We did a cruise and buffet meal down the phraya river. It was well planned with lots of people on the cruise . The meal was great with lots of variety and the lights at night was great with the music in the background .

A must see in Bangkok. The river is a vibrant waterfront running through the center of Bangkok. There are numerous dinner cruises to see are the sites in the evening. I also took a canal boat tour that shows you a unique view of Bangkok through the canals and locks through the city.
Great Scenery. I would say I enjoyed the boat tour of the Chao Praya River, great scenery. Can board the boat at Thaksin Bridge area.
Long & winding. We just passed by going from Bangkok to Pattaya. Our driver & tour guide explained a little to us. Of course, we have learned it during our school days!
easy way to get around. tie in with other transport it is a great way to see the sights and get around parts of the city you would otherwise miss.

Interesting Area. Very different vibe than most places n se asia. worth a visit and stroll. beware of the various types of boats and ticket hawkers. Be sure to know which boats you bought ticket for. If you are not a fan of the water get a ticket for the huge wide tourist boats. Very stable. If you like adventure and having to jump on/off a moving target often being pushed go for the smaller "orange" flag boats. Crowded, tipsy, cheap, wet but fun. Have more thrist for adventure hire a private skeet. The narrow fast boats with the guy on back steering the long propeller outboards.

average quality of water. I used the transport system by boats. its good way to save the time but the water in the river is dirty. Needs to get cleaned. There are a few tours with dinner cruise which are pretty nice.

Another side. Beginning of the trip is inspiring, then when the river gets more narrow it gets bit scary and finally getting to small channels makes you curious to see the simple and sometimes lazar living, that shows another side of poverty
Lovely dinner at the cruise. The river cruise in the evening at Chao Phraya River was marvelous. Lovely hostess and lovely food. Worth every single penny spent.

Easy way to get around. We spent a day using the water taxi to get around the attractions in Bangkok (seeing the temple of the dawn, touring the golden palace, visiting the temple of the golden buddha, etc.). It was a great way to get around and see a lot of attractions (we used the free guide map provided by the taxi). However, I would caution- be sure to get on the correct water taxis! At the end of the day we got on the wrong taxi and spent 30 minutes going the water route AWAY from Bangkok before we realized the error. The taxis are so crowded we did not realize that we were no longer on the tourist loop of the taxi (some of the taxis run multiple routes depending on the time) and, with no one speaking English, it was difficult to communicate our predicament. Just pay attention when boarding, because it gets crowded during rush hour and masses push their way onto the boats during the evening commute.

Nice experience. The river cruise is a must. The cruise is for around 3 hours and costs 40 us dollars per head inclusive of buffet dinner. The spread is also nice. The ambience is very romantic and enjoyable if you with the right companion.

15 baht regular boat trip is great fun. Why pay for the tourist boat when you can cruise this so little. Get on board and away you gol, on a hot afteroo, the wind and the sprey cools you down and the life on that river is always fun to watch. Enjoy

Must do for a different perspective of Bangkok. Chao praya river provides a very different perspective to the bangkok's skyscrapers. Here on the banks of this river you can find both the skyscraping hotel buildings and the overflowing houses and precariously parked cars on the banks. The river transport is cheap to travel around. For the romantic ones, the candle light dinner aboard the rice barge would be something to hold on to for some time.

Real Life Thailand. Traveling down the canals of the Chao Phraya river really opens your eyes to how some people really live in Thailand. It was fun to see the different houses and canals. The ladies in the small boats come up to you and sell you different things. Everything is cheap so its ok to indulge in a few things.
A must do. You wouldn't think there would be so much water in and around Bangkok. It's so interesting to see Bangkok from this vantage point.

Commercialized river cruise. For USD45, the food is just average. Another commercialized tourist attraction. The city night view along the river(plus the river breeze) is the only plus point. Too crowded and bad human control.

Alternative to taking tuk-tuks. We took the boat and surfed the Chao Praya River after getting tired of haggling with taxi drivers that do not want to use their meters. The water is pretty much what you expect (turbid and brown) and saw lots of debris and even a huge dead catfish that really put me off. Then again, I grew up in the Philippines where I saw worse. All in all, if you are a visitor in Bangkok, you should try taking their ferry, it's worth the experience being squished with the locals plying the Chao Praya...it's like being a local yourself!

Really interesting. We stayed at the Anantara Riverside Resort and our balcony opened up to the Chao Phraya River. We used the free shuttle daily to get across the river and as we used it and i stared endlessly i realised how important this river is to Bangkok for transport of goods, tourists etc. Regardless of the brown water its a beautiful things to see and it does not give off any smell (even being so close to the river). Keep an eye out for the massive swimming monitor lizards! Its interesting to see luxury hotels, apartments and then the slums, a great eye opener!

A must do. One of the great things about the Chao Praya river is that it presents an ever-changing montage of bimbling commercial, large gaudy tourist and long-tails blasting along sometimes at huge speeds.The rooster tails that the long tail rivercraft throw into the air a very impressive, with the brown tropical river water turning into a silver curtain of spray.We stayed at the Shagri-la, and used the hotels riverboat to get up and down the river as a pleasant alternative to Bangkok street traffic, and took a longtail cruise up to the locks past the Thai Royal Barge mooring, they were worth seeing just on their own.A very good, cheap and pleasant experience, especially when we encouraged the longtail skipper to crank it up and really get moving.Heaps of fun, and well worth looking at an ancient city from this perspective...

An interesting trip. We took a boat to go on a trip off the river itself through the lock and into the various waterways that are off of the river itself. This is a really down to earth view of how people live out of sight of most people. The buildings vary from tumbledown shacks to luxury houses, temples and schools. It is a real eye-opener to see what is there. Coming back to the river through another lock, we stopped off at the temple of the dawn. (a further review of this elsewhere)

An indispensable waterway for Bangkok City. We stayed at the Anatara Riverside Resort last year (this summer we're staying at the Novotel (on the same river Chao Praya - there are loads of places to stay along it) and somehow I simply fellin love with river. It is quite a beautiful sight even thougn the water is brown. It is it's commercial importance that struck me - every day from dawn to dusk it is an unending to and fro of working trawlers, tourist longtail boats, dredging boats, etc. It is one with Bangkok city.

what a great way to see the locals going about their daily lives. It cheap, its easy to navigate and its a lovely cool way to see Bangkok travelling with the locals. Would recommend it to everyone and give the tourist boat a miss and use the express boats.

Great. After being tired of travelling the busy city and shopping, it is great going on boat on the river. You can observe lots of interesting things from the boat. Air is much better then in the city center. Just dont forget taking some water with you cause it is very hot

The heart of Bangkok. Although during the day it's a bit grungy, you can still see that this was the lifeline of Bangkok - water taxis speeding along and the occasional barge being towed. My favorite is at night though when the waters quiet down a bit and you can appreciate the tranquility of the river at dark.

River Cruise. One must experience the Chao Phraya River cruise which takes you to see the spectacular view of the city from the river side.the onboard meal is amazing and the live music make you go thrilled to dance on the floor till you get exhausted.
Nice to try. Nide to try though once is enough. You get to see several areas in one end to 3nd ride but wouldnt understand a wod from the guide describing each srea.

Busy and.... busy. It is quite the experience on the longtail boat but for us it was too much of a hassle doing this on our own. Next time we will use the Lebua concierge service to arrange it for us.

Bucket list. evening cruise with dinner is a must do when visiting Bangkok.
We cruised the chao phraya river on the grand pearl.
Great buffet meal and entertainment.including Elvis impersonator
great night.

wonderful experience. Visited this place on May 20, 2014 as part of my family's Thailand Holiday on May 19 to 26, 2014. We went to this place as part of the Loy Nava river dinner cruise. It was wonderful seeing the thai long boat for the first time. it was also interesting to see how the local boat captains navigate their boats in and out of the different docks along the river. The sights along the river is also beautiful. However it doesn't compare to what we saw along the river bund in Shanghai, hence the rating of only 4 stars. Having said that however, we still recommend experiencing and seeing this place when in Bangkok.

interesting trip. Did this after a lot of rain had fallen up the country so the levels were high .we didn't take a lot of notice until half the crew came up on deck and asked to duck down on the floor as we were approaching a low bridge the boat didn't realll slow down a we sailed underneath with about 300mm to spare.Only in Thailand !

Access to many of the major sites. We used both the rather crushed but incredibly cheap boats and the tourist boat to get around. A day ticket on the latter is good value and you can see several of the major sites by hopping on and off.The river is itself a tourist attraction and we treated ourself to a 5* evening cruise available through the Banyan Tree Hotel.Our apartments overlooked the river and so it was very much central to our holiday and I loved the changing moods of the river during the day.

Great way to spend a couple of hours.. If you find yourself at a loose end and in need of something to do, you could do a lot worse than travelling up and down the river on one of the many ferries, getting off and wandering whenever the fancy takes you. The prices are great and stops frequent. Rub shoulders with the local commuters as they travel to and from work. The only downside is that the boats can get very crowded at times and you need to plan where you want to get off well in advance, or you'll miss your stop.

hop on hop off. An excellent way to see the river in Bangkok. We didn't realise we would get a guide who pointed out landmarks along the way so we got on at Central Pier and stayed on all the way to Phra Athit Pier. We then came back getting off at the places of interest to us. Lots of interesting information, lots of interesting and varied places to visit along the way.

Very busy river. This river is amazing. It takes a lot of traffic of the Bangkok roads. There are many jetties that can take you to all parts of the city. Along the way you can take in views of many of the top riverside hotels not to mention Wat Arun anf the Emeral Buddah temple and Wat Po. It's very cheap to use the public water buses so often used by the locals and a great experience to watch the river at work.

river cruise. It was a good experience and enjoyable. A private cruise with a good tour guide can be very helpful. He will explain into very detail as you cruise along the river. We were fortunate as our guide was very good. I do recommend the river cruise.
river taxi. I took river taxi to the Wat Pho and it was very good experience-fast, cheap and an easy way to get there. The river is dirty and not interesting :)

A nice touch. A dinner cruise was part of our package, and glad it was. After our buffet dinner we went outside to enjoy the beautiful sights by night. The boat was not exclusive to our group and we enjoyed speaking with the other passengers from all over the world.The temples, stupas and bridges were all lit beautifully, and the contrast of the modern lit up buildings with the old was stunning.

Worth the trip up the river. We usually catch a water taxi and go to the end of the line up the Chao Phraya River, its a nice cheap ride and you can get off at any of the stops along the river. The water taxi veers to both sides of the river and they travel regularly up and down the river throughout the day. Its a nice ride up the river and you can see all the houses that are along the river and all the buildings that also stand along the shores of the river. The ride is pleasant although is sometimes very busy and full of people going to various places along the way. Well worth the ride even if you dont really have a destination.

Great to see sights along the way to where your going. Very cheap travel. I stayed in a hotel along the river and watching the water taxis or buses go along it I was amazed to see how popular it was and efficient it ran we went along the river to see sights and also to get the connecting skytrain to Chatachak market. Very easy and relaxing to use the river buses

Watch out for the long boats. Great viewing from the river itself, but be aware it's not that east getting in and out of the long boats, probably best to take one of the larger river taxis and get off at different stops. Long boats not suitable for elderly or people with mobility issues.

Good experience. Its a lovely way to spend your evening- a dinner cruise down the Chao Phraya - Thai cuisine, decent live band on board Be careful which tour who choose though because we once had a really good experience where the food, entertainment etc was good and we we also had one not-so-good experience...Also specify whether you want to sit upstairs or downstairs while booking.Your photograph will be taken with Thai girls dressed in their ethnic best and it will be presented to you for purchase at a premium while onboard - my suggestion would be: carry your own camera!

Long boat trip.... I haven't been to the river for a few years but when I did go, it was an exhilarating experience.You see the "boat/river" people living in all kinds of accommodation.Some of the "boat houses" had flooded lounge areas at the time I went. Not sure if that is normal but very interesting indeed.Barges and boats cruising up and down the river gives you an insight of "business" on the river. Some beautiful temples including Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) can bee seen from the river.Overall a great experience to see everyday life on the riverWell worth the trip

River cruise. There are multiple ways to tour the river. Via the public river taxis or you can pay to take a dinner cruise or luncheon cruise. I think it's worthwhile to check out. The public river taxis are crowded but I found traveling on them to be an easy way to get to tourist destinations. If you are less adventurous take the tourist taxi. It's less crowded and you will not have to be in a very crowded situation while on the river. The dinner cruise at night was also worthwhile
river cruise. The dinner cruise is enjoyable. The food is average but the traditional Thai dancing is outstanding. The lounge singer is usually very good. The night sights are excellent.

Calm relaxing and worth a ride. Whilst not the cleanest, if you have enough time it is definetly worth going down the river with a public boat if it aids in your transportation (if you have enough time), nice and relaxing and get to see many points of interest on the way

Take the boat to explore the river. Well it may not be the cleanest of rivers but my advice is to take the river shuttle (the slow boat has no flag on top!) that goes all the way north to Nonthaburi. Exit to have food in one of the many restaurants and go all the way back to the Oriental Hotel pier.

Stay away from tour boats - take the public boats!. The public transportation system of Bangkok runs several boat routes up and down the river, and this is a cheap, inexpensive and great way to get around and see the city from the water. Tickets are about 15-30 Baht and can be bought on the boats. There are different routes, indicated by the flag colors.This is definitely the way to experience the Chao Phraya!!

The way to go!. Virtually anything worth seeing in Bangkok is easily accessible from the Chao Phraya and the river taxi system could not be easier (or cheaper) to use. Twenty baht will get you almost anyplace you want to go on the orange flag boats. Just get on. They will come for the fare. Make a little time and take a boat to the end of the line. Then turn around and go back. A fun way to see Bangkok for about a dollar. Watch out. The blue flag tourist boats cost MUCH more and stop only at tourist spots.

Not very clean. I took a boat trip with family during the day time but was not very impressed. its very dirty at some points as all the trash and garbage is being thrown into the river from near by house and even factories at some places. The government shall take some hard steps to clean this to avoid any pollution in the area as Bangkok is already very heavily polluited

Boat trip in Bangkok. We took usual public transport boat, just to see how the city from the river. This is really simple way how to travel long distances in Bangkok, especially in rush hours. Also air over the river is nice and refreshing.

At very little cost. There is much on offer along the river, tours and services. But!!! The best value that we found was buying a 15 Baht ticket on the local Orange service ( we used Google to help with what we were seeing) that allowed you to travel one way until you decided to get off. The Blue Line is 45 Baht but ask at the ticket box what that includes.

Very interesting and it gives you a glimpse of the city. This was a highlight of my visit. I took a water taxi and it allowed me to see the temples, royal palace and many interesting things in the city. Be aware of scams! Some taxi and tuk tuk drivers would try to convince you that the only way to see the river is by taking a private tour and they are very expensive!Just take the water taxi that all locals take, the tickets are very inexpensive about 0.50 USD and the service is very reliable, safe, relatively clean and they come often.
Interesting. Love the mode of travel .It was quick no hassle .The boats were on time and plentiful. Cheap way of travelling .No hassle .,no dislike
a river. I was excited about a trip on the river, but I must say... nothing special... boats are noisy and just full... its good to come around but not as a trip in my opinion

Amazing Dinner Cruise Place. We visited this place to enjoy Dinner Cruise and it was as per our expectations and we thoroughly enjoyed the 1 Hour 30 minute trip with dance music and lavish buffet.... Veg options are also available at Chao Phraya River Cruise but in limited numbers....

Good for a fast tour. Take the river taxi. It's a large boat that only costs about $5-$15 depending how far you go. It's rocky, but safe, and you will only hear every other word. You can get off a any stop you want, but there is no transfer if you want to get back on. Nice ride through. IF YOU really want to have a river experience, take a smaller along boat with a V-8 long pole engine. Lots of fun and more I interesting. Have him take you down the smaller klongs. Cost, maybe $25 an hour. BUT IF you are really adventurous, and cheap, go to the end of Soi 13 or is it 15 off Sumkavitt road. You can travel forever on a few bucks. Just remember where you got on, if you forget, what the hell, take a taxi!

Take a boat tour along the Chao Phraya River. During my time in Bangkok I took one of the long boat tours down the Chao Phraya River which made a change from being in the centre of Bangkok. Our tuk-tuk driver took us to one of the river piers and then waited for us to return from the boat trip. We hired one of the long boats from the pier which took us along the river and down one of the tributaries to see the floating houses that are on stilts over the river. The tour took us past The Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Wat Arun, the Royal Barges Museum and the Wat Talingchan Floating Market. Initially the boat ride was quite smooth, but then the river gets quite wide and the waves are quite large for the long boats. However the driver handled the boat well. The whole tour along the river took about two and a half hours including the time we spent in the Wat Arun temple. There are many hotels and restaurants alongside the river that have outside terraces where you can sit and relax along the river.

Ship and u. The wonderful Chao Phraya RiverChao Phraya RiverPhra Arthit Road runs parallel to the Chao Phraya River, stretching from Phra Sumen fort to Thammasat Universty. Lined with quaint shop-houses, cosy hole-in-the-wall restaurants, bars and cafés with live music, this is where the artsy type convene after sundown before hitting nearby Khao San Road. The nearest river pier is Phra Arthit Pier.Thewet is scintillating. People come here to make merit by releasing fish or to feed the school of frenzied catfish scraps of bread. There's also a ramshackle yet photogenic wet market, and the Royal enclave of Dusit nearby. The nearest river pier is Thewet.
The boat ride was too good!. I did not know there were boat rides which were fun rides and very economical! This time I experienced it 3-4 times and was very happy to do so!
Buy the one day pass. Buy a one day tourist pass or 150baht and the hop on and off the ferry at any of the pier stops. We thoroughly enjoyed it.

Give it a go.. For a great day out you have two choices here. Pay upwards from 1500 baht for a private 'tour' on a long-tail boat or 150 baht for all day roaming the river on the ferry boats. For me it is a no brainer. Hop on a ferry at any one of many piers and for 15-20 baht you can hop off anywhere the boat stops. Trying to hop off before the boat stops is not advisable!These ferry boats are used as a mainstream form of public transport and are often crammed but this is all part of the fun. Stand or sit back if you are lucky and watch the panorama of Bangkoks riverside as you glide past. 'Glide' possibly not the best description as these boats do sway about a bit and the river can get a little choppy.My favourite route is from the Sathorn Pier right up to Tha Nonthonburi for a visit to the markets. An hour or so up the river on the boat, a walk around an area with very few tourists, cruise back. All for 30 baht! Give it a go.

Authentic Thai way of life along the river. Feeling like being one with the locals in commuting via ferry. Availed the THB150 unlimited ride for one day especially affordable and convenient for tourists. One can hop off and on again from one temple tourist attraction to another. Getting there early can make you finish visiting all the ferry stops accessing major tourist attractions. Trip commences at Sathorn pier and commences at A pier near Khao San. (August 2012)

Love Chao Phraya River. A visit to Bangkok is not complete without at least one trip on this fascinating river. Over the years I have travelled by water taxi, long tail boat, regular commuter service, private charter and restaurant cruisers. There is so much to see in whichever direction you travel-I never tire of watching the river transport. There are huge rice barges being towed by seemingly small tugs, there are the tourist long tail boats heading for the floating markets, the water taxis crisis crossing from one side to the other-such variety. You pass by huge five star hotels, many Wats-significant as well as the ordinary, government buildings, Thai housing etc etc. It's a fast flowing river and at one time was almost choked with water hyacinth but now there is very little of it to be seen. Such an inexpensive way to observe so much of the Thai lifestyle!

A must do.... A must do, definite positive experience. There are many options to take in exploring the river...we chose a quick and basic one, we chose to get on the government owned and less crowded ferries from Central to Wat Arun, the government owned ferries have a blue flag and cost THB 40 pp but are way less crowded than the private ferries which cost THB 15 pp, these ferries fly an orange flag and can get pretty crowded. Be cautious when the ferries are about to do a stop off, I witnessed a family get split up because 2 off them were fast to get off but the other 2 were not. Otherwise a flawless trip, I'd go it again.
iNTERESTING. Very interesting river trip, with many sites.Great monitor lizards swimm the canals.Varied types of residences and buildings throught the generations to see.

Love Boating on the Chao. Was only in Bangkok for a day and a half and the one attraction I went to was boating on the Chao Phraya. I've been to Bangkok several times previously so I'm familiar with what's available and the river filled the bill.Unfortunately, I made the mistake of taking the tourist boat upriver from Thaksin but at least I only bought the one way. Must have been jet lag! <-- my excuse. Enjoyed the ride up, got off and wandered around for a while and had some lunch before properly taking the local ferry back.

One of the must do- river bus ride or boat cruise. One of my favorite must do when I am in Bangkok is to take a river ride along this scenic river, especially at night. Many hotels such as Grand Sheraton, Hilton, Peninsular and other top hotels are located by the riverside. These hotel typically offer free boat rides to nearby BTS station (Saphan Taksin). Also there are public boats running at various stop points along the river. Good view and dirt cheap for public ride.

Nice to View from Hotels and Good for Transit Too. I’m currently nearing the end of a 3-night stay at Chatrium Hotel Riverside Bangkok and have an incredible view of this river. It is nice to look at throughout the day and evening as you see boats of all types passing by. This includes boats lugging materials such as concrete, speed boats zooming along, and the transit taxi boats with the orange flags. The hotel has a free boat shuttle to the main pier every 15 minutes. From that pier you can take the orange flag taxi boats for just 15 baht to many locations such as Grand Palace, Wat Arun and Wat Pho, or head to Chinatown. There is also a shuttle to Asiatique which is one of the neatest markets to see in Thailand, and is another place to hang out and view the river too. This is cool both to see and transit on. The transit option allows to avoid all the heavy traffic that is involved in Bangkok ground transportation. There is also a 150 baht per day tourist boat option that stops at main sights and comes with a map of where the stopping points are.
Relaxing cruise. It was nice and relaxing to see the sites as your cruising along the river. I went with a tour guide and lunch was catered for. Plenty of options to choose from.
must see. A trip down the river is a must when in Bangkok. It gives you a glimpse of their culture. From the river you can have a good view of the temple and can access the old market.

Need to travel on the river once. You need to take some form of boat ride on the river when in Bangkok. We took both a ferry and a long boat to tour the river. Its a lot of fun to cruise seeing all the buildings lining it new and old. It's also pretty crazy with all the boats out there. Locals use ferries to cross all the time, freight ships are always coming through, dinner cruises all lit up, tourists in long tail boats. Plus there are a number of canals of the river you can ride through.

River, Boat House, People & Ruin. WoW ! must say this was first time experience and must have ride. exception should be Venice and Holland people who have enough of such canal. Traffic & signalling system inside the river city which is in very poor condition was amazing. also saw Giant Lizard and Crocks resting riverside living almost with people on river. Boat market was funny to see as they were selling fruits, veggies, cloths and hats in the river. Overall experience was good.
Its was busy....thats life. Need to travel on it to feel and experience it.....for me it was good to see how people travel on the ferry and its so fast, easy and cheap.....

Exotic ride. We took a boat on Chao Phraya River in December, day before New Years Eve. The ride is wonderful ! It did not cost much at all. Just sit and relax, enjoy the beautiful sites. Along the way you see many Bankgkok's landmarks as well the way many local people. I had Thai people talking to me on the boat, just having a pleasant friendly conversation. We got off and were immediately submerged into absolute local life - hundreds of food stands offering delicious foods.....we loved it all ! Catch any one of the thousands bike taxis, thrill all by itself. Every minute was fun. Go and enjoy !

A journey by Boat. There are many types of boat for a ride on the river. We had a big and a nice one. The evening breeze was cooler and I guess was a relief from the humid hot weather of Bangkok. The view is usually the big buildings around the river and other passing by boats. As long as the sun was up, it was not a pleasant journey due to the heat and the direct sunlight. The evening was better, cooler but except some lights along the banks. nothing was visible.

Try it at least once!. If you're staying at a hotel along the river, it's worth boating around if you can. If not, I recommend at least trying a dinner cruise once just to see the city from the different perspective. The river itself is not that pretty but it's just amazing to travel on it once. If you're not Thai, try not to get ripped off. Do you homework before to check the prices of the boats so that you come prepared, what I recommend is walking into some of the riverfront hotels to ask for their recommendation.

Different perspective. Stayed at the Chatrium Hotel Riverside, which has a free shuttle boat to the Sathon Pier (about 5 min away). Hence it was really convenient to jump on a boat and go to the Grand Palace, Emerald Buddha and Reclining Buddha via the Chao Praya River. The local boats are the least expensive option. I took the orange flag one for 15 Baht. But do get off quickly, cause I did see tourists miss their stop because they didn't get off in time. And of course it was crowded. The other option is the tourist express boat (40 Baht or 150 Baht for whole day). The night market, Asiatique, also has a free shuttle boat from Sathon Pier. The nights that I stayed in Bangkok, there was always something going on at the Chao Praya River, either fireworks (2 different nights) or a soccer match on a huge boat. Downside, look its not the most attractive river (brown, dirty, etc)

The artery of Bangkok. and possible partly the sewage system. However, this is a working river you will see tug-boats hauling material up and down the river and most of all you will see plenty of long tail boats for charter. I did the long tails year's ago and remembered it to be a good experience, however this time I just took the boat up and down the river checking out the sights along the way. There are three other options, besides chartering a long tail: Option 1 - jump on the tourist boat. One way ticket 40 baht and full day ticket 150 bahtOption 2 - jump on the local boat. One way ticket 15 baht. It is the more economical option but the backside is that the boats don't run as frequent as the tourist boats - so be prepared to wait.Option 3. Do a dinner cruise but be selective - I would recommend something smaller such as Loy Nava dinner cruise, I did their cruise years ago as well. Food is good but adjusted to not being to spicy. Regardless of option traveling up and down the river is a nice experience.

Great dinner cruise on the river. My wife and I very much enjoyed our evening dinner cruise on the vessel Loy Nava. The boat is a refurbished old rice barge so is not very large. Everyone seated for dinner had a good view of the river and the food was a really tasty selection of various Thai dishes.There was a very pretty girl playing a traditional Thai stringed instrument and another very pretty girl performing traditional Thai dances as we enjoyed our dinner.The views of the various lighted stupas along the river were spectacular at night. As a civil engineer I especially enjoyed the light playing on the cables of the new cable stayed bridge as we passed under it..
Good expereince. Its a good one time experience, just check the timing before you go or else you have to wait for long.

Interesting excursion. As we were staying at a hotel on the river it was simple to board a tail boat & explore the klongs ie canals that criss cross the river You will experience village life with older properties that line them along with various temples

be carefull of expensive charter traditional ship. we rent a boat and crossed the river to see wat arum, floating market, feeding river fishes and look around the village..overall it was nice but the river is too dirty

Hustle & Bustle. We took a slow cruise up and down the river for about 90 minutes with a stopover at Wat Arun. A great way to travel and to see the sites. There is a lot of activity on the river and lots to see.

Take the boat. Hopping on one of the river ferries is one thing you have to do. It's cheap, it's efficient and a great view of Bangkok. Try to avoid the boat with blue flag (the tourist boat) but take the boat with the orange flag. This one is cheaper and you have to listen to all the announcements

If you don't see Bankok from the river- you haven't seen Bankok. What better way to see Bangkok than to take a water taxi - everywhere! They're cheap, fun and you can go where you want. An evening cruise down the river is also a good way to soak up the atmosphere of this wonderful city

Dirty.. Our friend told us not to go on the cruise as there was nothing special and you pay a lot for it. We decided to take the free ferry on this famous river to Asiatique. Not something I would want to experience again. The first thing is that the water was smelly, brown and muddy and imagine that splashing on your body or face!! The ride was bumpy and there was lots of people in the ferry too.

Cruise through Chao Phraya with Hindi songs and Indian food!. The river cruise in Bangkok reminded me of the river cruise in Bur Dubai though the Bangkok cruise was bigger, swankier and more organized. A 2-hour cruise through the Chao Phraya river giving us good views of the city on both sides of the bank, we spent decent time on the double-decked mini cruise liner. Every guest has a table reserved for them for dinner. We got one on the lower deck but they graciously put us to the upper deck on request. For the ones who prefer AC, the lower deck is idle. For the ones who like open air dining, the upper deck is apt (though its not as windy in Bangkok). Our cruise - 'River Star Princess' was entirely dedicated to Indian tourists (who comprise the biggest percentage of tourists in Bangkok other than the Chinese). So the food was perfectly Indian and even the live singing on the cruise featured only Indian chartbusters. Interestingly the host and singer was a Thai female who sang with an accent but got every word from Hindi songs correct. If you are not the singing-dancing types, you could simply sit on the tip of the open deck and spend some serene time on Thai waters. Chao Phraya River cruise is decent for a one-time experience!

Polluted, smelly and underdeveloped. Sadly this river is the outlet for most of the untreated sewage of Bangkok. It absolutely stinks to the high heavens and the rubbish strewn across the banks, is absolutely terrible to see. It is a shame to see what must have once been a magnificent river, reduced to such a state. Do not let a drop of that water touch you in any way - your stomach will pay the price (as it did for us). The smell was so strong that we even had headaches. Avoid it unless viewing from a distance.

If you're seen it once, you don't need to second time.. Basiclly nothing special, once you've been there, you've seen all... Maybe good for couples in love at night time, can be romantic. Daytime, worthless..

good ride. We orthopedic surgeons from all over India on a academic ortho conference went on a river cruise was a pleasant ride wiht a good food and a entertainment. We all enjoyed it took almost 3 hours for the trip.

RIVER STAR PRINCESS. We loved this River Cruise. We were on the top level of the boat at it was just fabulous. The woman singing got everyone involved and singing along. We had a blast. Everyone had a turn singing and got up dancing. Great views from the boat. We had people in our group who were inside the boat on the lower level and they hated it so I assume it must be very different atmosphere DEFINITELY book for the top deck. Food was fairly average and I must admit it is very hot when the boat is going the opposite way to the wind. Only complaint was that when you arrive you are left in a expensive shopping complex with no where to sit for over an hour waiting to leave on the cruise this was very disappointing and something we did not enjoy especially in the heat. Would highly recommend this tour. I booked through Bangkok tours online before arriving in Thailand and I recommend this.

The heart of Transport. Amazing how this place is the centre of transport for all ! business people, couriers, tourists, locals etc etc.smells a little bit but the smell doesnt stay with you ! interesting history behind it - check it out!

Hop on Hop off. If you want to check out whats happening along the river just hop on & off the many hotel ferries for free. We had lunch & glass of bubbly at the Peninsula Hotel overlooking the river then headed over to the Shangri-La for coffee. It's a great day out.

In the river, take a dinner-boat ride. A wonderful way to finish a day in Bangkok is to take a river cruise up the river in one of the boats serving a delicious dinner while seeing the temples on each side of the river. Beautiful at night and also during the day, coming from the north and seeing the same spectacle over a nice lunch.

Best value in BKK.. Is there a better or cheaper way to spend a couple of hours in Bangkok? Any visit to this city must include a trip on this living & working river. And while you can spend considerably more if you if you wish, for a mere 15 baht each way jump on the orange line at Sathorn Pier, settle back and enjoy the ride!

Chao Phraya River. Great sightseeing from the beginning to the end and back. Very inexpensive. Also, doubles as a river taxi to numerous drop off points along the river for exploration. For example, Chinatown, Wat Po, Grand Palace, Khao Sarn Road (although need a taxi or a longer walk). A must do when in Bangkok.
Boat Cruises. I am not a water person but enjoyed people watching especially the locals at the Chang Pier harbour or port I'm not sure what's the correct word.

Take a river/ canal tour to truly see Bangkok. My Thai guide set me uo for a River/canal tour in one of the little motorized Thai riverboats. It was great ! I got to cruise the river through downtown Bangkok, then enter the real Bangkok along one of its many canals. It is the very best way to see the amazing and varied life in Bangkok

Refreshing. It was quite refreshing. Just take the local express boat rather than the overrated tourist boat which cost 150 baht per person. You use the ferry to visit the temples, and also the best way to travel to Khao San road :)Just make sure you get on the right boat, I hopped on the wrong boat and arrived at this deserted pier (waited around 30 mins for the right one to get back to Sathorn pier)

beautiful. Nice clean river with boats, ferries running around. Specially at night, the lightings on the boats adds to the beauty. So if you are getting a bit expensive hotel room or apartment with a river view, it's totally worth it!

Chao Phraya river. A very nice break cruising along this river than being caught in a massive traffic jam in Bangkok city. I took the local ferry which cost only 10% of what you are to pay for a tourist class cruise! Although this local ferry is without a guide, you can elect to drop off any where along its route to visit temples or have a meal break at the restaurants along the river banks.

The river of life. This is the longest and most important river in Thailand. It runs tortuously across Bangkok and end up in the Gulf of Thailand. There are so many high condomineum buildings,big hotels and restaurants along both sides of it. Old buildings and traditional Thai houses can be seen scantly. There are also several beautiful bridges across this river. The attractive thing to do is having a dinner in river cruise around two hours,which you can see the beautiful night scene of the river.

Once a life time experience.. I'd a rare opportunity to travel ChoaPhraya River as often as I like as my chosen mean of transportation for the entire month to escape from Bangkok sticky traffic jam and the HEAT. Each and everyday was a different experience, whether with the morning hour rush, afternoon lazy cool breeze or beautiful evening sunset. Never gets boring... Watching the landscape and natural daily lifestyle of Thai people along the busy ChaoPhraya river, the major artery of Thailand.
Great day on the water. I love getting on and off the local ferry (15 Baht) all day visiting amazing locations and meeting friendly locals. A GREAT way to spend a day when in Bangkok
Heart of the city. The Chao Phraya is a major river in Thailand, with its low alluvial plain forming the centre of the country. It flows through Bangkok and then into the Gulf of Thailand.

Great views along the river. I'd recommend taking a boat trip along the Chao Phraya River. There are some great views along the way and it's a great way to get about and see some of Bangkok. Plus, you get a fantastic view of Wat Arun from the river.It's definitely one of my favourite things to do in Bangkok!

Life by the river. Chao Phraya River has been the main stream of life for Thai people. Made up of 4 rivers from the north, the river goes out into Gulf of Siam. One can go all the way to the old city of Ayudhaya on a day trip and see the life along the river.
lots of attraction. clean river, lots of attraction (aquatic, wat pho, wat arun), cheap ticket to enjoy chao phraya by boat

Nice for a different point of view. really nice viewpoints of different structures from the many many boat cruises you can do ... or even just take the 15 baht boat ferry down the river to explore it..

Check out the river for free. Why not check out the river and many of the hotels close to its banks. The easy way (and acceptable way) to do this is to get on the MRT and get off when you reach the Main Pier station. You'll recognise it, there is a huge river there!Head down to the jetty beneath the bridge and you will find motor launches running free taxi services to all waterside hotels. Just jump on ans away you go. We used to do this and have coffee at one, lunch at another, etc, etc. Honestly, they don't mind.

Very inexpensive river tour…. The Chao Phraya River felt like the heart of Bangkok to me. So much life happening on that river… and if you wish to tour the city by boat, simply take the public transport ferries, they are super cheap and you can see everything. It's also a great place for a fresh breeze when it's super hot there.

The life blood of Bangkok. The Chao Praya River is called the River of Kings or the Kingnof Rivers. It is the life blood of Bangkok, always busy with all kinds of trafic. Rent a long tail boat e.g. at the ferry sport by the Sky Train stop bu Taksin bridge. You should pay around 50USD for an hour in a boat with room for 8-10 persons. Go for a loop in the smaller, quiet canals on the Thonbury side of the river for a look at little homes, temples and banana orchards that will make you forget about the noice of the big city.
Busy and very congested with traffic. If you want to see this, take a boat up and down the river. If your hotel is on the river, they offer complimentary scheduled boat rides

The River of Kings.. The Chao Phraya River has always referred as the River of Kings. It was the main thoroughfare of Bangkok since the creation of the capital. All the important buildings were built on its banks eg. the Royal Palace, Siriraj Hospital, Thammasak University, Temple of Dawn and various embassies. Therefore the Chao Phraya River is the place to start in learning Thai history and culture. The river itself is quite lively and enjoyable simply to watch people moving about it. My recommendation for tourist that want to see the river on their own is to take the Chao Phraya Express which is the river bus and stop in various piers and explore the landmark sites nearby.

too much chaos. we had been booked on a cruise with indian food. there are too many all male groups coming to Bangkok. these people do not behave very well on the cruise. it is embarrassing for people with family
Chao Phraya River. The view is exhilarating and the boat ride is very neat. Many popular attractions in Bangkok are accessible via the Chao Phraya River.

River transport. Another way to see Bangkok is on the tourist ferry ,150 baht for an all day ticket , it has about 10 places to explore and finishes at koasan rd, but with the all day ticket you can get on and off all stops

Great way to experience the beauty of Bangkok. Take the BTS to Saphan Taksin and follow the signs to the ferry. Make sure it is not the tourist pier and get on the boat with the orange flag. You can take the boat all the way up to Nonthonburi and back for 30 baht. It is a nice, relaxing, and smooth trip and you keep cool as well. Try to go in the afternoon and come back to Bangkok after dark. It is absolutely beautiful along the river at night (especially Wat Arun).

Grand Pearl Cruise down the river. I took a Grand Pearl Cruise down the Chao Phraya river with a group of friends. In the cruise, we had a buffet and there were performances. The cruise took a total of 2 hours, and it cost about $60 usd. Although it is really expensive, the atmosphere, and sights of at the banks of the chao phraya river was well worth it. We could see the Wat Arun litted up in the night and it was beautiful.

It's Big and Beautiful at Night. This is a big and busy river. I love to sit and watch the river float by in the evening when it's dark and the buildings are lit up. Then the boats gently float or speed past. Barges, ferries, dinner cruises ...During the day, take the boat down to the floating market and as the boat starts to turn about to dock, look back up the river where you just came from ... but have your camera ready, it's a stunning view!
อ้อน. การนั่งมองสายน้ำทำให้เราสบายใจ โดยเฉพาะเเม่น้ำเจ้าพระยา ยิ่งตอนล่องเรือช่างมีความสุข i love thailand and i missing my home mort of the time i alway miss thailand

Lots of stuff to see and do and keeps you cool between sites. I like riding down the river as its nice an cool escape from the concrete jungle. Lots of places to hop off and experience. DO not do the tourist boat, its way overpriced. I did the orange flag boat which may stop at non tourist stops in addition to the ones made by the tourist boat and may take a little longer on weekends but you can ride 10 times before you get to the $150 one day fee of the Tourist boat.Today i primarily stayed around N 8 Tien stop. I grabbed the ferry from there across to Wat Arun. The ferry is 3 baht each way. After exploring for 2 hours or so i hopped back on the ferry and visited Wat Pho. After a few hours there i rode the orange to Rama 6 bridge and explored the neighborhood before catching the last orange flag boat back to central pier

the river is nice. My wife and I stayed at the Peninsula Hotel for 3 nights in April, which is right on the river. At first we considered it inconvenient that we needed to cross several times a day on their ferry service, to access the skytrain, etc. However, by the end of our stay we were actually looking forward to the boat ride, especially in the evening. We also really enjoyed the views over the river from our room, as you see some pretty interesting things coming past. We didn't have time for a canal tour, but we will on another visit. Stay here if you can.

Impressive. This has to be my 5th trip on the Chao Phraya & this interesting river has never failed to impress me, over and over again! It is full of live & surprises; to see and meet the people who depend on it, as a way to travel in their daily life.TIPS: - - Sunscreen is essential as you will almost certainly get burned without it during the hot afternoon.- Go in the late evening; to catch the beautiful sunset over Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn)- Bring your camera and probably another battery as you will take plenty of pictures : )

I watched the river for hours during my stay.. Staying in the Horizon Club at the Shangri-La hotel the windows overlooked the Chao Phraya River. Watching the boats, ferries and barges travelling along the river was one of those simple but immensely satisfying pleasures.
Bargain river cruising. Do your own river tour with the tourist boat - excellent way to visit many sites in Bangkok - with a bit of fresh air thrown in

Great experience!. I made a booking from the Absolute Bangkok tour and I had such a unforgettable experience, where they tour us to the village and experince on the feeding large and numerous catfish waiting for the bread to come down from our hands. During the boat ride, I manag to bought some souvenier items from a old lady selling stuffs while rowing her mini boat. I observe that this river really helps a lot of Thai locals to earn money from tourist It is also the easiest way to travel and helps to avoid heavy traffic in the land.

Great water taxis. The cheapest and most beautiful way to get up and down in Bangkok. They to the main temples and monuments, and many neighborhoods. Ride with the locals, it is so much more interesting.

Take a ride. If you're staying at one of the excellent hotels alongside the Chao Phraya River, get your concierge to tell you about boat trips to a floating market. The long boats are an adventure in themselves - the operators hold a long pole that is directly connected to a big block American auto engine. It's noisy, fast, fun.

Chao Phraya River Tours and Boats. We stayed at the Shangri La Hotel adjacent to the Sathorn (Central) Pier. (Pier and hotel are adjacent to the BTS Skytrain station.) The Chao Phraya Tourist Boat provides a very enjoyable, cost effective, and easy method to travel to many of the top Bangkok tourist sites while avoiding traffic,

Bangkok - Chao Phraya River - Great way of getting around and also relaxing from the hustle and bustle. We used the river a few times to get around Bangkok and I must say it is easy to do, cheap and a great way to relax, if only for a short while if you are not travelling far. It offers some great sights from more local areas to some of the main attractions but the one thing that stood out for me was the amount of catfish. We first boarded on the Thewes Pier and to see the catfish here was amazing. They were fighting each other for a spot of water never mind air or food. Then when crossing the river they were continually popping up everywhere. They are big fish too and I would have hated to have fallen in as I would thought you'd struggle to keep you head up. Use the transport on the river it is a great alternative and you have to see the fish. Amazing.

Nice view. See and explore the Chao Phraya River during visit Bangkok with family. Nice river view combined with buidings and temples. Then lights view in the evening. You can have a trip with boat and have a dinner there. Unfortunately, we didn't have much time there as we just stayed in Bangkok for 4 days. But It's ok for a short experience. Wish can be back to explore the river more next time.

Very Dirty River. Yes, it is a very dirty river, you cannot see anythings to the bottom, but you can take the boat and see the temples around it, it is a good things to do in Bangkok but not expects too much for the view and the river.Join the tour for a dinner (2 hours trip) is much better than the day time view.
Nice for taking fresh air. Either alone or with your children, take a private small boat for 2 hours on the river. The cost for this is affordable and it is worth doing it

Do NOT take the private tour boats unless.... We went to Old China Town via subway. As we were getting out of the station, we were approached by a friendly guy giving us direction to China Town. Then he tells us it's too far to walk to China town and it's dangerous due to the protest going on so it's better for us to take Tooktook for 50 Baht. It turns out he was a tooktook driver so we get on his tooktook. Then he tries to convince us to get on the boat which will take us to the temples and even throw in a sightseeing of the beautiful canals. Where he took us, there was a lady sitting at a desk telling us she can have us see first the temples and then the canal all in 1.5 hours for whopping price of 2400 baht. After giving them almost all we had in our wallet, the boat driver takes us on to a remote canal first killing more than 30 minutes of time slowly sailing through filthy canal to get to a shady area where a small boat with tons of tourist souvenirs approached us calling his boat a "Floating Market". We told him we didn't have money and were not interested. He was pushing us to buy a beer for our boat driver. We expressed our frustration to the boat driver stating our understanding was that we were supposed to visit the temples first. He finally took us to the first temple which we spent most of the time looking for an ATM to withdraw more cash to buy the tickets to enter the temple. By this point, I was very upset at myself that I bought into this expensive private boat scam. I ended our boat tour after the first temple and told the boat driver to take us back to China Town. It left a very unpleasant memory of Bangkok.Do yourself a favor and do your homework - know all your transportation options (there's public ferry option too) and costs before you make your way out there. If you can gather more people to hop on the private boat to share the cost, it totally is not worth paying 2400 baht (80 US dollars) for 90 minute boat ride for two people.

Must do it if you are in Bangkok. We met a local our first day in Bangkok and he told us to go to the Chao Phraya river to see the "Real Thailand". What an amazing experience, you see all the people living with nothing and all the happiness in their faces, the tranquility and the nature, it's a really good experience.

Much to do along the river.. Our day started in Chinatown and we worked our way to the end of the line going South after boarding at Pier 4. A lot of the ferries skip this stop. If boarding the river ferries from Chinatown make your way to pier 5. We hopped boats and headed North making our way to Pier 9. This is where you disembark for the Grand Palace. The river is alive with activity. A great place to observe the day to day workings of Bangkok.
Nice. The river is surrounded by all the temples. These temples look really very good in white and yellow light.

Good Experience. Take a local boat which is cheaper than the tourist one to get to the many temples along the river. Each time you get off the boat you'll need to purchase a new ticket, costing 30 pence! Lots to view along the river.
Fantastic Living River!. I could watch the action on this river for days! Best place to view it is from a riverside hotel on a high floor. From barges to ferries to colourful taxi boats - wow!

Take a non-tourist boat from Saphran Taksin. If the station is still open... take the BTS to S/T and then a non-tourist boat (cheaper) up river to Phra Aphrit (not sure exact) which is a stroll from Khao San road. On the way are bookshops, and all sorts of stalls and restaurants to distract you. It's about a 20-25 min boat ride, and you get a real sense of the city from the boat.

Lots to do/see on the Chao Phraya River. The Chao Phraya River runs through Bangkok and can be enjoyed in many ways during trips to the city. We have enjoyed spending time on and around the river during many trips here and consider this a fun place to spend time in Bangkok. There are restaurants, rooftop bars and sky bars with excellent views of the river for visitors to enjoy. Similarly, you can stay at riverside hotels in several areas of the city, allowing you to view the temples on the other side at various times of the day, evening and night. We recently stayed at the Sala Arun hotel, near Wat Po. From here, there were excellent views of the imposing Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) just across the river. This was a reasonably priced hotel that we would recommend for those interested to stay along the river in a convenient location. Rooftop bars like Eagle Nest and Sala Rattanakosin make for great places to catch a sundowner while admiring the Chao Phraya River views. Some good riverside restaurants in this area include Bitter Deck, ESS Deck, and The Deck. Meals are a bit pricey but we found the food quality in these restaurants to be quite good. Views were very impressive. One of the fun activities that we enjoyed on the Chao Phraya River during our recent trip was watching the catfish being fed near Wat Rakang. Here you can buy fish pellets or bags of bread (฿10-20) and feed the the thousands of large catfish, waiting near the pier. It is considered good luck to feed the fish and and there was a constant stream of locals doing so, making for an ongoing feeding frenzy in the waters around the pier. Tourist boats were stopping by as well, allowing passengers can throw bread into the water to fish the fish. You can do the same at the pier next to Wat Arun but the fish are smaller and in much reduced numbers. You can also take tourist boat trips up and down the Chao Phraya. These are found at most ferry piers, along with public transportation ferry boats and simply ferry crossings, which can take you back-and-forth, across the Chao Phraya for as little as ฿3 per ride. Overall, we very much enjoyed spending time near the Chao Phraya River during our recent trip to Bangkok and can recommend visitors to Bangkok try to allocate some time to do something along the river during their trip to the city.

River & Canals. We had 'done' the sights on our last visit so our guide had to find things to visit we had not seen, the Royal Barge Museum and a lesser visited Temple (forgotten its name) and then we took a tour of the canals, not just one in the city but one which left the river and went right out into the country, have you ever sat in a dragon boat with your seat nearly on the base and the back rest too upright to be comfortable for THREE hours! Still it was very interesting seeing how people live on the canal.

A must for any visitor to Bangkok. Get a taxi or BTS train down to Saphin Taksin and take a trip on the river.Nightime is best and ther are many "wine and dine cruises offered by Yok Yor cruises,the booking office is at the riverside.My favourite river trip is free and it is the shuttle to the Anantara Hotel on the opposite side of the river.It takes about 15 minutes each way and once ther you can relax at the riverside cocktail bar and watch "the world go by".

Great way to get to the temples. We travelled from Central Pier to Stop 8 and then transferred across the river to get to Wat Arun temple. We caught the 'locals' boat which cost 20 baht each as opposed to the Tourist Ferry which cost 150 baht each. Just make sure you get in the line that says 'No Tickets' and catch a boat with a green, orange or no flag.

Wonderful Experience. We went on the Grand Chao Phraya Dinner Cruise and experienced the river and the surrounding on the luxury yatch, whilst having a sumptuous buffet dinner. We got a very good deal (almost a 40% discount) for the cruise through the website: hotels2thailand. Access to the cruise is from the River City Mall.
Beautiful Cruise. I jumped onto the tourist boat with English guide and she introduced some places along the river. The view is good.

A wonderful way to view Bangkok. We enjoyed a river view from our hotel, the Shangri La, during our stay in Bangkok, and also enjoyed a long boat ride on the river itself - the boat-drivers are obviously experts at navigating not only the river, but the river traffic. The river provides the easiest method of transportation and some of the best views of Bangkok.
Beautiful river. This river is the backbone of Bangkok and hums with activity day and night. At night it is simply stunning

lunch on the river. How do you rate a river ? well find a restaurant , have a drink or have lunch and sit and watch the traffic on the river go past . Really fascinating to see all the types of craft on the river , taxis tugs pulling barges . etc., JB

Long tail boat a must. Took long tail privately - go to see the smaller canals across river from old city. Mixture of traditional and modern canal houses very interesting. Note the locks. Be certain the Royal Barge Museum is open. We missed it. Floating market looks uninteresting from river, but is well worth a visit for the photo ops and the food!

River is life blood of Bangkok. River boat travel is historically how the people of Bangkok used to travel and many still do. It's a must do if you can while in Bangkok. I took the sky train to the river and then got a ferry to the Grand Palace. There are many ways to enjoy river travel - large cruise toys ships for tourists to small 8-10 person motorized long boats.If you are unstable on your feet or traveling with a handicapped friend, focus on the larger tourist type vessels. Either way you will have a grand trip and be able to see the river and it's attractions.I've done several types of boat travel on along the Chao Phraya River. I am able bodied but getting into the small boats was difficult as they don't have any railing on the dock or boat to hang onto. Some kind passengers helped with a hand but I could see a nasty accident waiting to happen.

Nice. We took a dinner cruise down the river. It was an enjoyable experience. We enjoyed the food, the sights and sound ( there was live music and dancing on board) of Bangkok. 2:30 hours worth spent.

River is soothing. We arranged for a boat ride along the Chao Phraya River - a boat that catered to just three of us and a friendly boatman rowing it. It was a long and sturdy boat despite the fact that we were travelling at rather high speed.It was an enriching and enjoyable experience because the river breezes were soothing and comforting; it was even exciting as we cruised along the river on a speed boat. We got to see many different sights along the way in one shot - the Bangkok naval base, dilapidated attap houses, different shophouses, temples and other buildings all in one tour. It was amazing. Some of these are things that we may not get to see unless we travel specifically to certain parts of Bangkok, and we gained a better understanding of the different ways of lives of some of the locals.It was inexpensive, but truly a good time to spend an hour. We also got to feed fishes along the way, and passed by some of the boat markets - where the peddlers sold fresh produce such as fruit and vegetables on boats.For more detailed information and photos, do visit:http://thearcticstar.blogspot.sg/2014/01/tackling-thailand-bangkok.html

The hub of the city. The Chao Praya is the central hub of Bangkok. On a really hot day there is nothing better than cruising the waters by ferry or boat. At night is becomes filled with restaurants and party boats that light the banks with colour and movement. It is not always pretty but is always interesting.

good experience. As we stayed in a hotel with a free boat service to train and ongoing river boats we enjoyed the river experience. At night it is amazing with the small and large boats all lit up against the city backdrop.

Definitely go on a long tail boat. We went on a long tail boat ride with Tour with Tong. I expected the water to be smelly and dirty - it wasn't. It was a very relaxing and interesting trip seeing all the houses on the waterways. It was also Thai New Year, so we got dumped with water along the way. It all added to the fun of the day and kept us cool!

Ferry along the river. Heading for the Royal Palace, decided to go by ferry bus, it was great!! Bumpy along the docking, but fun, loads of photo opps, was cheap, being 15THB for one way...
Only thing I didnt like was the bloated, floating, dead dog we saw, but hey
The old heart. The river is the old heart of the city. Have some boat tours but mostly its a bit tacky and the river is a bit stinky.

romantic. if you sit near the river it was very romantic and fantastic.
have many restaurant and hotel near the river

great tour. we rented a private long tail boat for 1 hour trip throughout the river and it's small canals. we even saw some Varanus. It is amazing the the houses from the river. it's a different point of view u can't miss

The River in Bangkok. The lifeline of Bangkok, Chao Phraya river, is a special feature of the city. All the major tourist attractions are located on the banks of the river. The notable Wat Arun (Temple of the Dawn) is located on one bank, while most other attractions such as Wat Pho, Grand Palace & Emerald Buddha temple, China town, Flower market etc are located on the opposite banks. Several navigable options are available to suite your need to explore the city & the river, be it a night illumination cruise with dinner or a Thailand Tourism operated tourist boat ride during day time.

Big river. We took a private long-tail boat along the river, and through the smaller canals in the city. Beautiful ride, and make sure you stop to feed the lucky catfish at the small temples in the canals...
