A Different Kind of Venice. Some of the great cities of the world have a network of canals which have for years served to move people and cargo - Bangkok is one of these. The canals on the east side of the Chao Phraya River, in the Old City area, were part of the defences protecting the Grand Palace, etc. We rented one of the narrow, long fast boats to take the two of us for a one hour tour of the canals connected to the Chao Praya river, ending at Wat Arun, the Temple of Dawn. It was a great way to see houses on the canal banks built on stilts, many more Wats, canals teaming with fish (catfish and others), large mats of aquatic plants such as lotus, and working boats and barges of all shapes and sizes. The cost for a one hour tour was 1000 baht - about $33US. One can direct the boat operator to cruise the main river instead of the canals - they are flexible.

Chao Phraya Tourist Boat is Transportation Only. The Chao Phraya Tourist Boat is only a transportation boat. The only tourist thing about this is the poor English and higher prices. There were no audio announcements on the sights seen on both sides of boat. Only announcements were about the stops – I think since I barely understood the female voice. We bought the 150 Baht all day on and off ticket. We only used the ticket once (to Grand Palace). Even though the cost is small, a better purchase would be the express boat for 5 times less. Overall, this “river cruise” did not meet my expectations.

Very interesting. The river is so interesting, very busy with so many different watercraft. A cruise down the waterway is a great way to see life in Bankok, from the numerous ferries, cruise lines,barges to the smaller fishing boats it's a constant changing scene.

Dirty and polluted. If you take a cruise on the Chao Phraya River during your time in Bangkok, make sure you close your mouth when on the water. This river makes the Ganges look clean in places! I took a Klong alongside the river near the Peninsula Hotel (I saw many posh boats plying their trade, too) but did not enjoy the experience. The smells were bad. However, it is a major artery of the city, and at night the river takes on an altogether different personality, with many of its parts illuminated.

Lively, beautiful, real BKK. Be prepared - the Chao Phraya is very much a "working river." You will be many barges carrying cargo and many commuters. For these reasons, it is a fantastic experience. I've taken the express boat (mostly Thai locals commuting to/from work). This is an experience in itself, as it is very cheap and very quick. You can also have a great meal at many riverside restaurants (Mandarin Oriental and Shangri-La are pricey, but awesome view).There are also khlong (canal) tours which will take you through the smaller canals just off the river. It's great seeing the homes, monitor lizards and slice of real Thai life. (We chartered a private longtail boat from Tha Tien.)If you're a visitor, start at the central pier (Sathorn), as the English there is pretty good. You can get there easily from BTS (Saphan Taksin station).
Candle Dinner Cruise. We took a candle lite dinner cruise on the first night of our visit to Bangkok. This is a good way of orientating yourself. Expensive but we enjoyed

Well worth a go. We started at Nonthaburi pier in the north. The boat took an hour to get to central pier downtown. Lovely watching the city approach and the fields retreat. Free boats are fun between the main hotels especially when the river flow is fast - they hurtle across. Go to Asiatique by boat from the central pier. You can also get a private long tail boat to take you over the other side of the river, through the lock and around the old area, fascinating

Bangkok city on Chao Phraya River. The Chao Phraya river is synonymous with the existence of Bangkok. Most of the tourist attractions of the city are located on the banks of the Chao Phraya river. Except the Wat Arun (Temple of the Dawn), all other attractions such as the Grand Palace & the Emerald Buddha temple, the Reclining Buddha temple, China Town, Flower Market, etc are all located on the other bank of the river. Exploration of the places of interest is thus convenient and enjoyable by using the tourist boat hop-on hop-off type service, departing from Sathorn (Central) Pier.

Great way to see Bangkok. Whether it's a dinner cruise or just on a shuttle boat, it's good way to spend time in Bangkok. Just watch the bangkokian life goes by. It's also a great way to commute as the traffic in Bangkok is getting worse everyday.
Pollutted water. Speed boats available to travel to all nearby attractions (Wat Arun, Wat Pho, Grand Palace and so many other temples)
Beats the thames. Could watch it all day long from our hotel. Great to travel on it in the hotel shutlle boats and the long tail fish boats. You must stay on the river when you are visiting Bangkok.

Take the cruise for the view not the food!. Nothing spectacular about the river cruise buffet dinner, nothing stands out at all. The outside view however, was actually one to see. The night lights along the river of the various temples were really beautiful and quite romantic actually. A good way to spend the evening.

join the commuters on the long tails. forget the tourist only boat trips. the best way to catch the river life is on the regular long tail boats running like water buses; and venture further afield into the suburbs via smaller canals.

Perfect River Cruises. We went through Chao Praya River in our last day in Bangkok. The river was clean, the service was good, the view was stunning (especially in the afternoon to evening). Tourist may choose whether they would like to take the tourist boat (with guide) or the normal boat (without guide which is cheaper for sure). By cruising in Chao Praya River, you can also visit some other places of interest.
clean river with on-time boat transportation. We went to Asiatique with boat/ferry. The river was clean, and there's a lot of lighting building throughout the river
Great view. You must try experience. Bring your sun glasses on the day. Bring your scarf on the night its kinda windy.

Great. We took a trip with 40bath each to get ourselve to Wat Pho and Grand Palace. And because we were too excited, we even took private small boat through Old Bangkok canals, a bit pricey 1500bath - 2 person - 1 boat. But hey worth spending when you were travelling, lol. We were in farm fish, gives fishes some bread bought from a floating boat shop.

Must Do. If you go to. Bangkok you must take a boat and see the city from the river. Day or night. What i do is to visit the main temples and the. Grand palace by boat. It cost you $30 an hour for a private boat, you get out of traffic (that is chaotic in. Bangkok) and the experience is unique!
Scenic Cruises. We did a river cruise and it was a lot of fun - Wat Arun looks lovely at night, and so does the suspension bridge

Enjoyable. We booked an afternoon river cruise at our hotel travel desk since we had the afternoon free till our flight back home. So glad we did as it was very enjoyable indeed! The boats were spacious and not crowded and a guide was provided to explain the major landmarks along the way. Great way to click some photos from the river. We were able to feed bread to some fish in the river as it is a symbol of doing a good deed for the coming new year. After about half an hour we were transferred to another boat which had an array of Thai sweets and fruits drinks. Came back to River City after cruising for about 1 hour.

The River. I live in Bangkok and never tire of a trip on the river. It is handy for reaching riverside spots such as Khao San Road and the Grand Palace. The service is frequent and cheap. It is also cool often with a breeze. You can also visit some other places of interest such as the area around the hopsital which recenly served a s aplace for the King.

Ferries all the way. You can't beat river travel & Chao Phraya doesn't disappoint. You can catch an orange flagged ferry for 15 baht to any stop on the river wether it be one stop or 20 one way & 15 baht return.... Cheap and the fare collectors ( usually ladies) look after you letting you know where to get off if you are not sure. I would give the tourist boat a miss & get adventurous with the locals on the ferries.
Don't miss this!. We enjoyed our trip on the river so much we did it twice! Went with different tours each time and saw different things. Very restful way to see so much activity and daily life.
Wonderful. Inexpensive to go on a boat ride lovely atmosphere and great to get away from the hectic traffic in Bangkok.

So much to see. We spent 3-4 days going up and down the river, there are so many things to see. We were recomended by family to get the express boats as they are cheaper, however they seemed so much busier and its difficult to know where they are going and some go to different provinces. We opted for a day pass on the tourist boat, costing 150 baht (£3) which allows you to get on and off whenever you like. Or simply ride up and down the river to enjoy the sights and get out of the sun for a while. They also give you a little bok with info on the main sights and which stops to get off at as well as directions to them from the pier. This was very handy.We also went out on a longtail boar for 1 hour, costing 1100 (£22) going around the canals, which we really enjoyed. This can be booked at the numerous stands around the pier and prices are negotiable.

The joy of river travel. The Chao Phraya River could easily become your favoured way to get around Bangkok. For a touristy experience you can get a long tail boat - they are the narrow ones with really loud engines, they fit about 10 people.More practical is the Chao Phraya Express Boat. This wont cost you more than 40 baht for a cross city journey taking 30mins. It can be confusing but 2 stops are the most important. Tha Chang (Stop 9) in the north - next to the Royal Palace, and Sathorn Taksin (Central Stop) in the south - next to Taksin bridge and Skytrain station.On the boat there is a section reserved for monks at the back. You pass a number of sights - most notably Wat Arun, Temple of Dawn. Next to this is a small white fort - home to the Thai Royal Navy. After this another temple Wat Kanlayanamit. Just before Taksin you pass the Oriental Hotel. If you go north from the Royal Palace stop you will go under the impressive Rama VIII Bridge.

Enjoy the inexpensive ride.. I spent very good time cruising around Chao Phraya River by boat public transportation. It costed me less than only 20 Baht to travel from Tha Chang dock to Tha Nam Non dock.

River Star Princess night cruise. My husband and I booked an evening cruise on the River Star Princess (through our holiday rep) whilst staying in Bangkok. We were collected on time and arrived an hour before the boat set sail allowing time to wander around the many designer shops at the Pier or enjoy and leisurely drink whilst watching the sunset. The River Star Princess is luxurious and all staff were lined up to greet us - we were shown to our seats - top deck where tables were laid out silver service and drink orders taken by the waiter. Huge selection of starters/mains and desserts in the centre of the seating to help yourself - everything was very fresh and excellent.Whilst enjoying a leisurely sail down the river we also had a band playing and various traditional dance routines. Great way to see all the buildings lit up and boats on the river whilst enjoying music and entertainment - lots of photo opportunities.Tables were well spaced apart and no cramped. Service and food excellent as was the entertainment.Highly recommend this trip when in Bangkok.

River dinner. The variety of food on the buffet table was good but needed labelling in some of them. The serving dishes needed to be topped up more frequently. The long queue reduced my appetite. Overall it was very good but room for improvement.

The River of Kings. The Chao Phraya River is like most rivers that flows through big cities. My first introduction to the River of Kings was a few years back when I competed in the Bangkok Triathlon - the swim was 1.8 km downstream. Amazingly the water was clear, unpolluted and in a perfect temperature to swim in. Subsequently I have seen parts of the same river further downstream which are polluted and almost unrecognisable as a river. There is so much action on the river from the river boat taxis, barges and ships. The trips down the Klongs (Canals) are well worth the money spent If you choose well you can see so much of Bangkok from the river and avoid the congestion of the traffic of the city.

Private Chao Phraya river tributaries trip. A Thai friend of ours recommended a gentleman that would take us on a private (just the two of us) trip around the tributaries and side khlongs of Bangkok to see the houses and wats that the regular trips do not see.As I write this I cannot remember the gentleman's name but he was a fantastic, lovely old man who spoke very good English. He was borne and raised in one of the houses on the khlongs that he showed us. He met us a the jetties at the back of the Royal Palace (where he shooed off the con-men trying to charge people to walk on the jetty) took us to his personally owned, long-tail - which was immaculate and his pride and joy - and took us out for two hours on THE of the most enjoyable trip that we have done in the ten years we have lived in Thailand. I cannot recommend this highly enough. We saw fantastic, old-style, Thai houses, kids swimming in the khlongs, waving and chatting with us, HUGE Monitor Lizards swimming and sun-bathing, beautiful wats and people going about their daily lives and businesses in areas of Bangkok that most tourists (and many locals) never see. Periodically, we would stop at attractions and he would take picture for us. It was so relaxing, informative and romantic that it really was the best day trip out I have done in years.Oh yes! The whole two hours was VERY cheap! Too cheap, in fact, for me to write the price on here, as I feel he should charge more and also that he might have given us a special price because of our mutual friends. Even so, we would gladly have paid a lot more for the fun we had. His name is Khun (I will try to edit this as soon as I get home!) and he can be called on +66895162465 or +6624100989pornpent@ratch.co.th

best way to avoid the traffic. I used this a lot when i had to go to Bangkok for travelling. From Siriraj Hospital Pier (wanglang) Pier to Sathorn Pier took only at least 15-20 minutes and you can take the BTS Sky Train to the town. Easier than taking taxi or public bus. Along the way, you will see the very nice and beautiful things such as the temples and the old building (building mixed with thai and europian). I like this a lot!

A Fantastic Way to Get Around. Taking a river taxi along the Chao Phraya river is a wonderful way to get around Bangkok and see some of the ways people live. It avoids all the traffic especially if protesters are leading to road blockages. It's also a cheap alternative to taxi's. The river taxi's are marked with different coloured flags which denote which stops they make and the internet provides a map you can download with the stops. It's just so relaxing.

Good day trip. Take the boat up the river to the floating market. See Thai people living in their homes and also other boats will come along side you to sell clothing , souvenirs, and food and drinks. A must see for the tourists.

Great little adventure!. No matter where you are in Bangkok, take a metered taxi to Khao San Road, its a great day out or can be done at night too. The metered taxi from say Sukhumvit Terminal 21 shouldn't cost you more than 120-130 baht ($4.50). Get off at the start off Khao San Rd and walk through the street, it has many stalls with cheap trinkets,garments,shirts,souvenirs etc.Once you get to the end of the road, you need to cross it straight across and through a temple with many bells,walk through the temple until you reach the net road that runs parallel to the river, you then cross the road and turn right,walk about 50 metres until you get to the Navalai Resort,walk through to the end and you are at the pier!From here you can catch a boat for 30 baht($1.00) all the way down the river passing many interesting places such as Wat Arun(Temple Of Dawn). Your trip will be around 30 minutes and its refreshing on a hot day! Get off at Sathorn(Saphan Taksin) pier and catch the BTS to Silom or Siam.Ultimately you can spend a little money and stay at hotels like Chatrium Riverside or Navalai for an excellent view day and night!

Always busy and interesting. Surprisingly deep, with huge shoals of catfish, longtail taxis, and local ferries (the best transport option including 2 - 3 hours for next to nothing). Not particularly photogenic especially since many of the local wooden stilt houses have been replaced by hideous up market hotels. Lots of pretend chinese junks, some operating as floating restaurants.

Shuttle service. Prices vary a lot in Bangkok and the ferry service escapes all the problems,you pay with small change,it is incredibly cheap.Get yourself organised with a simple map available dockside and match it with your travel map and find easy short-cuts up and down town and cut out trafficjams that are quite prevalent in BKK.Might take a while to get used to,but definitely faster and cheaper.And a very simple flag colour code system to help select your ferry.Getting off at jetties is a little challenging when crowded but found staff very helpful and concerned for your safety,heed their instructions.

Head on up the River. We ride one of the many ferries that ply the river mostly as a means of transportation from one point to another. There are so many interesting destinations along the way.I am always fascinated by the structures along the shoreline and while not a tourist I behave like one once on board. I always take photos.You will have an excellent opportunity to see modern Bangkok as much construction activity has been taking place the past few years as well as the exotic city of the past. Go now, these older structures that depict a way of life mostly gone by are disappearing

A breath of fresh air. If you are staying in a riverside hotel, you will be familiar with the river, but if not, it is worth a visit. Easiest way to get there is by MRT to Sapan Taksin, the pier is right by the station.There will be many quite polite touts trying to get you to rent a "long tail boat", but unless there are 4 or more of you, this is not a cost effective option.The riverboat is the best way to go, a large white and orange boat with seats and people blowing whistles, don't mistake it for a ferry that goes just to the other side. The easiest way is to go to the booth and buy a tourist ticket, at the time of writing this is a mere 70 Baht for all day unlimited trips.Another good way to see the sights is FREE!, The major hotels have free shuttle boats and will take you to the riverside hotels for absolutely no charge, remember all falangs look the same, and they have no idea if you are staying there anyway. Best trip is to the Anantar Riverside, about 15 mins and you are at the hotel where you can walk round the gardens etc. maybe have a drink, but there is nothing mush outside the hotel, so just enjoy the river trip. Back to the pier, and another boat will be there in minutes to take you back to Sapan Taksin. You can now go to The Hilton, Sheraton, or Peninsular etc. have a look round and get dropped off at River City, next to the Sheraton, for a bit of window shopping or some food. A good afternoon out for next to nothing with lots of photo opportunities.A clear fresh breeze comes down the river, a real breath of fresh air. and easy to get back to the city from Sapan Taksin by Skytrain BTS.

Bustling With Commercial Traffic. The Chao Phraya River is a wide, meandering body of water that carries major amounts of barge traffic. When I had first lived in Bangkok in the 70's it was the heart of a complex of canals where people lived, worked and conducted daily business. Water taxis still work the river and if you go up far enough you will find authentic floating markets and entire villages that depend on the river. I would recommend avoiding the tourist version of "the floating market tour." There are many 5 star hotels that line the River and I would recommend sitting in one of the outdoor cafes and enjoying a beverage as you watch the river traffic.

Must-See!. Not a whole lot of things to do in Bangkok besides breathing polluted air, shopping, and visiting a Wat. I enjoyed the public ferry on the Chao Phraya, as well as the ferry provided by Asiatique and my hotel. Crazy to see all the dilapidated buildings and dwellings that would be condemned elsewhere, but still enjoyable to go on a boat to get a bigger view of Bangkok.

A Great Way to Travel. Take the boat from Saphan Taksin pier (behind the bts station) and cruise all the way up, for 15 baht, to Khao San road. You can get off at any point in between and even stay on (each boat has either a yellow, orange or red flag - each one stopping at diff piers - just ask at the station what colour you need) all the way up the Chao Praya to Nontaburi. At Nontaburi you can pop onto Koh Kreb, a cute little island that has some markets on it. Anyway, the boat taxi beats sitting in a taxi for an hour and it's a nice way to travel up and down river. Oh, do not get the 150 baht all day pass. A single is only 15 or 25 baht, and you only need 2, or 4 at max. You can also just line up and pay once you're on the boat, as opposed to going to the ticket counter at the pier. It's fun. Trust me, I've used it 50 times, as I live here and don't like sitting in traffic for hours on end.
The main river. This river connected you to the historical site area. Like The temple of the dawn, etc.. Hop on to the boat..
East trvael out of traffic. Brilliant way to get around and avoid the traffic. Very cheap but boats are crowded. See life as it is on the river.
Busy travellers. Good to avoid traffic jams in roads. I used river transportation whenever possible. You can visit Wat Arun and come back to City side and reach Samsen Road by taking different boats.

Relaxing boat trips. Taking a boat cruise on the Chao Phraya river is an enjoyable way to spend a lazy afternoon, or a romantic late evening. The towering buildings along the river and the cable stayed bridge will stay in your memory!
Fun way to travel thru Bangkok. Fun way to travel thru western part of Bangkok! Very pricey as well! Make sure you get off at the right place...long way between some of the stops!

Beautiful, interesting and hard working river.. This river runs through town, and many of the major sights are nearby. Also many of the major hotels are right on the river. There are a variety of tour boats, water taxis, dinner cruises and ferries that run on the river, as well as working boats and barges. There are a number of canals branching off the river into residential neighborhoods. We took a 2 hour cruise which spent half the time on the river, and the rest wandering the canals. At night the river is wonderful. The river comes alive with boat traffic...especially the brightly lit dinner cruise boats. The major temples are also illuminated, and the hotels and restaurants add to the beauty. From the river Chinatown and the flower market are nearby. This is a great place to stay when in Bangkok....hotels, restaurants, shopping, transportation and a beautiful, entertaining locale.

Wonderful. we went for dinner on Chao Phraya river. the boat was full and dinner had good variety and quality. but a little crowded on dinner time. we went for more than two hours and enjoyed the ride, food, music and dance.it was temples, palaces and beautiful landscapes around the river.

great views, cheap way to travel. We used the river as a means of travel. For 150THB (£3 at April 2014 exchange rate). You can buy an all day on and off ticket to basically wherever you want to explore. The Tourist Boat goes from Central Pier/ Sathorn all the way Khaosan Road and as you can get on and off where you like you can see more than one area in a day, if you have the energy in the heat and humidity! It runs half hourly from 9am to 9pm.

Great boat tour and great value. Our first day in Thailand and in Bangkok, we decided to take the Chao Phraya tourist boat river tour. We paid the 150 Baht ($5) per person for all the day pass which is fantastic value. We started by taking the express boat (which stops at about 8 of the piers) all the way up and all the way back just to see Bangkok from the river then we transferred over to the standard boat (all included in the same price) so we could go further up the river (this one does 30 piers) and also stop at the various piers whose attractions we wanted to see. I suggest you google the Chao Phraya tourist boat to see the extensive list of attractions and markets available at the pier stops. This is a must do in Bangkok

Take a Dinner Cruise from River City Pier. The river is best enjoyed during the night. There are many dinner cruises starting from river city pier. The Chao Praya Princess cruise is really good and they have an excellent dinner menu with Jazz entertainment.

Shop around for your tour. We took a tour a short way up the river in a long boat,to the Temple of Dawn and thru to the canals, bit of an adventure, skipper was very loud & cheeky, paid for tour at a pier then on the way back he demands a tip for him.

We did the long boat tour. Took a long boat up and down the river. Certainly worth doing, there is a lot to see. drivers seem to handle the water chop well, so dont be too concerned if the river looks a little rough.

Great form of transport. Use the express boats rather than the tourist boats. They run more often and they are very cheap. You can get tickets at the quayside or get them when you get on. It's a great experience.

river ride. Boat experience was great . More over for some trips boat is faster to avoid traffic. specially if you are going to see grand palace or Asiatic try boat its faster to take u there and will be good experience as well.

Must do river cruise!. There is a river cruise that picks you up at different points and can drop you off at the 'grand palace'. It's an absolute MUST DO in that you get to travel through all the canals - literally the banks of the canals are homes of the local people and businesses too, so you get to experience the life of the locals from your boat. Also, there are people who sell stuff on smaller boats and will paddle up to your boat if you're interested. Once you get off at the Grand Palace you enter through a veggie/fruit market - make sure to pick up some pomegranate and bananas! Yummy!

Always fascinating. I spent almost two weeks in Bangkok visiting relatives. I enjoyed several morning trips from the central station to various tourist locations along the river. In addition, I had a 3 hour trip down the river after visiting Ayuthaya with a tour company. The Chao Phraya River bank offers glimpses of so many aspects of Thai life, from regal residences to some very humble buildings. The array of boats to be seen is also fascinating. Always take the opportunity to go by river - far better than taxi or tuk-tuk.

Relaxing Cruise. Chao Phraya River seems to split Bangkok in two. It is a good way to get to the many temples that line it. For 150 baht you can ride it all day. I'm sure there is a local, cheaper way to catch a boat, but I didn't bother looking for it. The river is dirty unfortunately, but you get some fantastic photo opportunities with the long boats and barges passing in front of the temples. Don't miss the opportunity to take a riverboat ride at least once when you are in Bangkok.

Great and unique to Bangkok. We took the orange boat for BHT 15 to the last stop (N°30?)There is a very interesting and important local market.The river has a unique athmosphere and typical scenery.It is worth doing when you are in Bangkok

great way to see the city - and slightly cooler. be aware of the difference in boats/routes/ prices.. only certain boats do certain stops, and the tourist boat charges 40 baht per trip, local colour-based boats - only 14/15 baht per trip and just as good..... lovely and cool on the water....

Cheap and easy!. This is the best way to see Bangkok from a local perspective. Very cheap and worth it! You can reach the piers tuk-tuk or even BTS (in some of them). Use one of the 5 lines (identified by different colors of the flag) and travel for about 30 piers in the river. We also use the boat to go to the flower market, there is a pier near the market! The only negative point: the pollution of the river.Tip: maps and fares@ http://www.chaophrayaexpressboat.com/en/home/

Cruise in the evening. Travellers are fascinated by the river cruise in the evening from river city ,it's well organised nearly two hour sailing with food dance and music with view of the vital buildings well lighted on the banks of the river
The right way to get from A to B.. If you get the right boat (not the tourist ones) it is a great and cheap non-tourist-way to travel the city. Just ask the locals!

Take a Ride and Enjoy Bangkok From The River. This river which dominates the commercial and scenic life of Bangkok is a joy to explore in one of the many motorboats that each hotel offers gratis. The ever expanding skyline of Bangkok is best viewed from the River and will also cool you off from the sometimes oppressive heat of the city.

Unique way to get from place to place. Take this orange express boat to get from one site to another and/or to a place to eat. Just know that this is really a commuter system--the boats stop running at 8PM during the week and at 7PM on weekends, so make sure you can get a cab back to where you need to be!

Beautiful View of Bangkok Ciry View. We stayed at Hilton the in-out boat was a treat. We loved it, my son just want to take this boat all day!!! We stayed the very top floor so the view of BKK is awesome
day ticket - up and down the river. I just bought a day ticket and enjoyed rideing the river. There is always some spray, there is always something to see. Good fun. At a very reasonable prize.

Life on the River. The Chao Phraya River is the life-blood of Bangkok. The river traffic is non-stop, with ferries, long-tail boats, hotel shuttles, barges all travelling up, down and across the river. Very entertaining to watch!
water transport in bangkok. bangkok was divided by river and one of it transport was on boat. i suggest for anyone who got seasick not try this kind transport. it shaking very much

The heart of Bangkok. You haven't seen Bangkok unless you have been on the river. It's really the beating heart of the city, and you will see Bangkok from an entirely different perspective. Whether you take one of the public boats or a boat meant for visitors, make sure you get some time on the river.
I could spend all day watching the river!. I just love travelling by river ferry, it's fascinating and a great way to get about Bangkpk and void the crowds on the roads!

River cruise (Beware of Scam!). Firstly, my friends and I were scammed into paying a lot more for taking this cruise and it all started from near the Grand Palace area. We only realised that it was a scam at the end of the day.A Thai woman came up to us when we were walking near the Grand Palace, pretending to make small talk and told us that the Grand Palace was closed for lunch and prayers, and recommended us to take a cruise, which we were planning to take anyway, after visiting the Grand Palace. She told us to go to this particular jetty, where they will charge only 800Baht, and not another jetty because they will charge very high like 3000Baht. In actual fact, the latter jetty had police patrolling around. She said a tuktuk ride to the former jetty will only cost 20Baht. Just after she said that, 2 tuktuks came to stop beside us and we happily took them. Upon reaching the jetty, a man welcomed us and told us that the cruise is 800Baht per person. We managed to haggle it down to 600Baht and went ahead to take the cruise.Overall, the cruise was interesting at first as we got to see the villages and old houses on water, some temples and even people selling souvenirs on their boats. It got a little too long and draggy though. I would still recommend it if you visit Bangkok, as it is a very unique attraction apart from all the shopping and temple visiting.Do beware of the scams, they are everywhere in Bangkok and they like to target tourists travelling in groups. We realised that we were tricked because from online reviews, some people paid only 200-300Baht per person for the cruise. And recalling what happened to us, everything actually happened at the right place and the right time. They are all a syndicate. Was the Grand Palace really closed on that day? Nobody knows.

Big river, big city!. If you want to experience the river, don't take a tourist boat but the big express boat ( orange flag ) that takes you up and down the river as much as you like for a ridiculous amount.

It's all about the river. No trip to BAngkok is complete with out a boat ride down the river. Choose from a long tail excursion around the waterways/klongs or take a water taxi to the night markets at Asiatique.

Boat station just below the "Saphan Taksin" BTS Stop. Take the boat which is locates just below the "Saphan Taksin" BTS Stop. 40Bht per adult, you can go all the way up to the Temple of Dawn (which is stop number 8). You will enjoy the scenery and take lots of nice pictures of Bangkok during the boat ride. *Avoid long tail boats- its just too expensive.
The river is massive. Very cheap way to see Bangkok and get your bearings as to where everything is. Jump on and off the water taxis. Be sure to take your camera.
River cruise. A brilliant trip with good international buffet , live music very good staff good a very enjoyable evening.

The life line of Bangkok. The river is huge and many different boats use it daily. Ive been on a long boat tour along the river, ive had a night time dinner cruise, ive used the public transport boats and the boats that simply ferry you from one side to the other. There are taxi boats, huge garbage boats etc etc. The river is massive and its not dirty or smelly. Its an essential must see/do in Bangkok
Cruise dinner on charopaya river. we went there on our honeymoon. Its a must see if people are going to bangkok. The cruise dinner on charopaya river was all together a different experience.

Love the River. On several visits to Bangkok we find ourselves enjoying the river. It is cooler and there are lots of places to get on and off to see some of the main sites of Bangkok. We have rented our own longtail boat and done the Klongs as well as taken the various ferries up and down the river. All was a welcome relief and quite enjoyable.
The best way to travel in Bangkok. A very cost effective and efficient way to travel to a number of main attractions in Bangkok. Good connection with the Skytrain system at Central Pier.
See the City. What a cheap way to see the city of Bangkok, from the river. Its cheap, about 15 Bt for 5 stops. Views and no traffic. Do it.

An amazing spectacle. All life is here. The express boat service goes along the river, pier to pier. Some are more express than others. The coloured flags flown have significance, so swot up on the significance. Some are commuter style, some are tourist with a guide. Some are limited stop. The commuter ones are very busy and are very crowded, many standing. They zoom off almost before the last person has stepped off the jetty.The water taxis with the long pole outboard motors are fine but only for the agile. They sit well below the pier so it is a long step down and a haul back up. I saw middle aged people struggle with others trying to haul them off. Without the western world safety rules, they look like accidents waiting to happen.The river is the city artery so it is an experience to be seen

Chugging along Chao Phraya River. If and when you feel the need to step out of the big city, Chao Phraya Riveris one perfect place to unwind and enjoy the skyline of Bangkok from another angle.Relax, rent a boat, and stop at any location possible for a couple of hours tour, and see the sunset, as you slowly marvel at how Bangkok would look at night, then head on for a perfect dinner, in many places available in the surrounding area, whether at a local private Thai restaurant hidden along the river banks, or at one of the 5 star hotels, the Oriental Bangkok, or the Shangri-la, and the Sheraton Hotel, that are all right on the river..

long tail boats great. we took a great trip on the long tail boats up the clongs a really must do and see so interesting seeing how the people live by the river and the temple of dawn was amazing but you must be very fit to climb up

Good Day Out. Very interesting on the river you can choose the tourist boat for 150baht which you can get off and on all day long, or the public boats which are great value for money at 15 baht a trip. Much better value. A nice way to see Bangkok.

The River That Never Slips. This is one of main "roads" of Bangkok. The transport along it as well as from one side to another is perfectly organized and veeery cheap - ie 3,5 BTH for one way trip to the other shore. Many best hotels of the city are placed next to the river with restaurants and best rooms facing it. Lots of different level restaurants are also on the shore. There are many cruises with dinner organized by various companies - from cheap, for mass turists, to gourment dinner on the Classic boat (ie Apsara cruise organized by Banyan Tree hotel - a very good one, however pricy - 2200 BTHper person EXCLUDING drinka, service, tipsów and VAT, so you should ADHD 50% on top).Also half day trip sto Ayuttaya can have return via river and that's a good option.

Fun, but once is enough. Took a round trip by rent boat at Chao Phraya River, we could see the surround of the river. Start from near Grand Palace, pass Royal Garden Barge Museum, then drop by Wat Talingchan Floating Market, and end at Wat Arun. At first, the flow is nice. But once near and entering the big part of river, the waves too big, and dangerous. I think, once is enough. You can just sit at the cafe at the side of the river, and enjoy the scene. I want to come again, but to enjoy the sunrise and sunset. If you want to go to Wat Arun, use the public transport which cheaper than rent a boat.
Great place. Great place to cruise on the river with local boats there are also a few parks to relax in which are lovely. Really nice for days out and to see the Bangkok

another view. Going by taxi boat on the river gives you another view of this vibrant city.Many houses along the river is places you would like to stay in - while others look terrible and not kept in good condition.Sounds like Bangkok right?

Fun Fun Fun. Spend about half a day here. Enjoy your beer at the cafes. Buy snacks from the street vendors. Sit a the park near the river since there is entertainment at night. You can see the bridge from this park. My wife's condo is on the other side of bangkok. Most taxi driver will not take you back. If you get stuck take the MRT

Nice and breezy ride down the river. I would suggest travelers take either the blue-flag or orange-flag boat. I think the difference in cost is 15bht or 30bht, something like that. You pay when you get on, so it's best to have coins -- the ticket lady walks through the boat shaking a can. The taxi stops are marked on tourist maps, and there are maps of the stops at each boat stop. Figure out the number of your stop, and then there are signs with that number when the boat clonks into the dock. I wish I had had time to ride down to the end and back up again. As crowded as it looks, you'll probably be able to get a seat.

Not for swimming but a great way to get around. The river snakes through the city with many stops and landings on it close to the major attractions (for those seeing, not shopping) and some hotels too. A great way to travel is to get a 1 day travel card - less than £2 - where you can jump on and off the boats going up and down, but not across, river. Wat Arum, Wat Pho, Golden Palace can all be reached this way. Beware com men telling you something may be closed, or selling you the entry ticket, as you get off the boat. Buy on the door always - and they rarely close.

So much fun and character. This has to be the best way to see Bangkok from a local perspective. It is only 15 BHT for any stops along the river. We took the orange flag boat all the way to N30 Nonthaburi to go to Koh Kret. You will get splashed along the way , depending on wind direction, but that's part of the fun. We also used the boat to go to the flower market and Asiatique. About 5 pm onwards the boats get very full as locals use it to get home. You can catch all boats from the Central Pier at Sapthan Taksin BTS station. They run till 7-8 pm at night. The tourist boats are priced at 150 BHT whole day and comes with English speaking commentary. You might want to consider these if you intend to do many stops along the river otherwise just use the local orange/green flag boats.

Combine transport with attraction. Part of the Bangkok experience and great way to move around. Many stops along the river, usually near main attractions or shopping centres. Either cheap public transport or private long-tail boats when sufficiently big group.

Dinner cruise. We did a river cruise with dinner. Interesting to see the temples lit up at night. The meal was a buffet, the boat was crowded. There was music and entertainment. Seems to be a big attraction in the area.

Ride in a long tailed boat!. So much fun! All of our family members enjoyed the wild ride from our hotel dock to the Grand Palace stop & back. This is a great way to see the city and get plenty of fresh air. Do it!

splashy fun but crooky manners. Nice long river adventure but beware for splashy surprises of a not real very clean river. Try to avoid Tuk Tuk connexion to it they just crook you away with commission and bring you to boats with whom they have an agreement. Overprised boatlocation with driver will be no surprise for not awared tourists =payed for two persons 2000 bath where the normal price should be at max 1000.

Great transportation. It is sometimes called the Venice of the East. which I could see why when you consider the number of times we jumped on the water bus to get around. The public bus cost 15 baht per trip. Very cheap! There are some shops and hotels along the river. I wouldn't recommend it as the best location for your hotel but if you stay along the river at least you will have easy transportation. It's not exactly Venice but I would recommend taking at least one ride to take pictures.

Hilarious. Stuff the tours and water taxis. Take the Skytrain to Saphin Taksin, grab an excellent coffee in the station, walk down the stairs, grab a few snacks and walk 100 yards down to Sathorn Pier. Make sure you have a tourist map showing the river with piers numbered. Sathom is N1 and each pier is clearly numbered N2, N3 etc. towards the Grand Palace. If you get confused just ask anybody for the 'ferry' !In busy times the boats get crazily overloaded but the ticket collector squeezes through no matter what. Pay on the pier or when aboard. These little people scream their orders to move on down the boat but fight your way to the rail and stand firm. Your fare of just 15 baht will take you any distance. Hop off at any place, take a walk, especially from the university from the Grand Palace along the river side walkway to another pier and pay your 15 baht again. It won't break the bank if you make a mistake and go the wrong way or miss your destination.The experience is amazing. Watch the river life unfold and relax.

water taxi. The water shuttles on the river are a great way to get around ,buy the all day pass if going to use more than 1 way each works out cheaper 150 tba for the day , lacking a bit on information on the stops but ask and they tell you, but good info on the sites you see and pass
Somewhat smelly. The river in general is good for transport and views are good. Its a good transport option. But the wate is dirty n smelly sometimes.

Excursion down the river. Our party of 6 hired a boat for private tour of the river which was quite revealing, we travelled downriver alongside houses built at the side of the river, saw plenty of wildlife and a peddlar selling goods from a rowing boat.

Enjoy both day and night. enjoy the day by taking the very cheap river boat (aroung THB 20) and enjoy the night by taking the dinner cruise ( around THB 300) will makes a very different experience. Though the river is not that clean, but the scenery when you ride the boat is awesome.
River trip. Very big river to do some exploring on by passenger boat, you can see the famous sky bar from the film hangover 2 when on the river..

A wonderful cruise on the river. We went on a dinner and show cruise on the river. The night was beautiful and the sights along the river was nice. However, I was not crazy with dinner. Although it was a buffet, the selection was not to my liking.

A trip to BGK would not be complete without a boat ride on the Chao Phraya River.. Well, they certainly pack you in and instructions are somewhat vague due to language - but you have to experience the Chao Phraya River by boat at least once while in BGK. The water is dirty and if you have a "window" seat, you're sure to get splashed.

Ferry ride.. We went down the river on the Chao Phraya ferry, there is a guide on board who tells you about all the various stops and what you can go and see from them. We went all the way down and back then decided to get off at China Town and have a look around, we were not disappointed. The very narrow streets crammed with people animals and scooters were a sight to see. A couple of hours later we made our way back to the ferry point and got back on as it was passing. The fare is only a few Baht and you can get on and off all day.

Always a crowd pleaser!. Buying the Chao Phraya Express 150 THB ticket is one of the first things I tell visitors to do! You really have a cart blanche to go anywhere on the river and it makes the whole language barrier easier as you just keep flashing your pass to the ticket takers rather than trying to figure out individual tickets!One thing I noticed - if you go for one of the long tail boat rentals on the river, be wary with expectations. Taking them is phenomenal just to see the inner canals of the city, but ignore the hype they put on the supposed "floating markets" and "famous sites" you will stop by, they are not what makes the trip and will be tourist traps. But wonderful for people watching and getting a more detailed look at the inner workings of Bangkok waterfront!

Must do. If on a budget the river taxi is a good way to see the river side site. For 15 baht each way you can travel the length of Bangkok on the orange line. The tourist ferry costs 150 baht for a one day unlimited on/off ticket to the popular spots and supplies an informative guide to the sights.

More than just a river. Chao Phraya River is clean and strategically located. Thai is smart to take advantage of it by having water boats as one of their pubic transportation system. I find water boat cheap and efficient to get around the city. Definitely one should try the water boat, it is a great experience!
great. we were in Astera sathorn hotel and the river taxis were great. must go to the asiatique where you can eat, be merry and shop

A River for All. The Chao Phraya River must be seen at night and in the day. During the day we stopped along the river at some of the many Historic sites but at night we were in a special dinner boat and enjoyed an amazing Thai dinner as we past these same sites lit up at night as we dined. This is a busy river with commuters, tourists, and boats pulling loaded down barges. This is also a popular area for hotels along the river.

Busy, dirty but a great way to see the City. We took the tourist boat which allows for you to get on and off as many times as you would like. It was hot and smoggy and after a few hours we both wanted to get back to our hotel and relax by the pool.We took a number of pictures while on the boat and these show the radical difference between the old and new, which exist side-by-side throughout Bangkok.The tourist boat simplified things but was much more expensive than simply buying a regular ticket. For perspective, much more expensive was 150THB or $5 each for the day.
nice boot tour. the scenery left and right side of the river is very rich.A lot of nice temples and thai buildings to be seen.The commercial ships on the river are also very interesting.

Long Boats on the River. We fully enjoyed the long boat ride on the river. A bit choppy, we had fun in the middle of traffic. Then the boat toured side klongs to see some of the older homes on the river. The area by our hotel is all redone so none of the "old" Bangkok remains. It was fun floating by some huge Wats and their statues.

a must do. if you're still in soi 11 take the bts skytrain from nana to saphin takhsin on the silom line ,(thus change at siam station ).at saphin takhsin take a ferry (orange boat)and head up the chao phraya river......a wonderful noisy and colourful experience .you might even get off at pier 13 and walk through the wat to khao san road road....for yet more shopping and engaging eateries

Loved it. All life is to be found on the river. My advice is to pick a hotel, hop on and off the river taxis and enjoy! If you stay on the river your hotel will have a free boat to Sathorn Pier where you can get the MTR, taxi or tuk tuk.We bought a one hour tour at the pier to see the floating markets and canals. There were only the two of us on board but the "floating markets" were actually two boats selling cola or beer - we had some laugh at that - innocents abroad! If you want to see the real thing you'd better do an organised tour. It was interesting sailing round the canals though.

Take the tourist Ferry. Travelling the Chao Phraya River by tourist ferry is a great way to sit back on take in the sites after a busy morning visiting the Grand Palace, Wat Arun or Wat Pho.Take a long boat for a chance to see the city by the canals.

An easy way to get around Bangkok. We bought a day ticket on the Chao Phraya Tourist boat at a cost of 150 Bahts which was excellent value.You can travel up and down the river all day and the boat services eight piers which enables access to most of the famous tourist attractions of Bangkok.Great value.

A great way to get the measure of the town. Bangkok is essentially a riverside town, and many of its major monuments (as well as fascinating minor monuments) are best visited from the river. Boats are cheap and plentiful.
A spectrum of wealth and architecture. Get a day ticket for the tourist boats. Hop on and hop off. Absorb the sights from the boat and enjoy the visits you can do from each stopping off point.

Great way to get around. There are two types of main boats apart from the long fronted tour boats to use. The Blue Flagged ones or the orange ones. The main stop is Saphan Taksin (Central.) You can pay on the boat one price for how far you want to go. The blue boat cost 40 B each and is less crowded and has a really good commentary and explanation of where to get off to see what attractions. The orange boats are more crowded and only cost 15b each and stop at every dock. We did not use the whole day ticket as the Grand palace and Wat Pho take most of the day. If want to get off at lots of stops then maybe this is a better way but you have to use the same colored boats all the time. We used the first boats than came and paid on board. A great way to see the rest of the river.

The heart of Bangkok. I always love to make a boat ride on the Chao Praya River, its a nice and relaxing way to see some of Bangkoks skyline. This time I made the mistake buying a so called unlimed 1 day travel boatticket. This appeared to be valid for a so called tourist boat. First of all we had to wait a long time before the boat was leaving. And then it was a man only blurting the whole trip trhough a microphone useless information (like: here we see a hotel, it has 5 stars) in very very bad English, soooo annoying! This boat is a shame for well organised touristic Thailand, Better take the ordinary boats, fast and no annoying screaming comments.

Best way to see the city. We try to stay at a Chao Phraya riverside Hotel at least once every year. Bangkok began on the river known locally as Mea Nam or mother water. The best hotels both old and new are located along her banks.If you have the money to spend, it is well worth staying at one just to experience this aspect of Bangkok. The hotels have beautiful wooden launches to take guests across the river to restaurants and sightseeing. In the evening one can watch the neon-lit riverboats on dinner cruises. There are tugboats pulling train-like barges, commuter ferries, tour boats.......Check it out!
cruise. it was very peaceful n good view. i think princess 2 & 4 serves Indian food, so enquire before hand the type of cuisine on board before booking!
A romantic cruise. Loynava cruise on the river is every penny worth spend. Provides a cozy environment for couples. The food served is excellent and view across the river is worth every memory

A Different Way to See Bangkok. Take a longtail boat ride on the River and view Bangkok from a different perspective. See the homes along the river, the fish jumping out, the Grand Palace, the Wat Arun and life on the river while relaxing on the boat. Variety is good!

Fantastic and cheap Ferry rides. This is one way to see heaps of Temples from the comfort of a fast river ferry. Take the cheap "public" ferries from the Sky Train crossing of the river. You can get off and on all along the river and see any and all the temples etc, you might have to pay another 5 THB each time.

Nice way to spend and afternoon to relax. We went of a rice boat tour of the canals. We had only just arrived in bangkok and were too tired to go exploring too much. Although it was very nice to see all the sites on the river, this can be done just as easily and much more cheaply using the river buses. Our rice boat did go down some of the canals, but the river level was too low to go too far so i did not feel we saw much more then you do on the larger boats.

Easy way to move in-between the touristic points. The view from the rooftop bars makes the river way more interesting than it may seem from the street level. It is a useful, fast and cheap way of reaching the touristic places. There are many restaurants with a view to the river, it was great having lunch in front of it :)
Boat trip is well worth it. We took a boat trip on the river which also went along the canal system so we could see first hand how people actually live. It was a fascinating experience.
Most interesting transfer way in Bangkok. This is the most interesting and fun transfer method in Bangkok,in an hour every body could get a sense of different view of Bangkok's life.

Yok Yor dinner cruise. We went on a Yok Yor dinner cruise (they pick you up by ferry from under the Sathorn Bridge). This is one if the cheaper dinner cruises (we paid B1660 including drinks), and is good value.

Great fun for a couple of hours.. We paid 600 baht each for a tour of the canals .The feeding of the large fish and buying from the boat ladies was great fun.Views from the canals of birds and huge lizards as well as temples was interesting.We did the river tour AM and walked around the temple area in the afternoon.The speed of the boat was a blast in open water,as you pass other tourists and locals using the river .

Pulse of Bangkok. Take time to get on the river.Firstly it will get you out of the stiffling city.Secondly you can discover the unique life on the river.Yes it has become touristy but if you are a first time traveller rent a long tail boat and enjoy.

Be careful. The ferries are fantastic and very cheap. be aware though that if this is your first time you can easily be swept along by "helpful" ferry operators to a longtail boat ride instead of the frequent ferry. Fun but more expensive, and you have to pay for landing at Wat Arun jetty abeit only pennies!

sightseeing for little money. We took the public boat to the very last station about 1 hour north of the central pier. This is a great and very cheap way to have a long sightseeing tour on the river mingled with the people on their way to or from work or on their daily business.

Great for hot days.. It's a cozy choice to ride a boat and have a trip along the river on a hot day. I rode a boat ferry from Wat Pho to Yaowarat, it only costs me 15 baht. A great way to escape the traffic.

Dirty Busy beautiful river. This river is the lifeline of Bangkok. It has traffic on it 24x7 so naturally its very dirty. Best place to watch and enjoy is on the park just behind of the palace. You can also take many rides on the river.

Tip for chaopraya express and tourist boat. I have a tip for tourist who will use chaopraya express and tourist boat so you wouldn't trick by seller.The public transport in Chaopraya river is called chaopraya express boat that start from 6am - 7pm and the company bring large boat to served tourist during 9.30am-16.30pm and called chaopraya tourist boat.Tourist boat price is 40 baht/one way and 150 baht for one day pass. The tourist boat come every 30min. Express boat have many line and price but during day and the best line for ordinary people and tourist is Yellow flag line (Thong leung) and Orange flag line (Thong Som) you can see the flag above the end of boat. Express boat price yellow flag is 20 baht/line, orange flag is 15 baht/one way one day pass of tourist boat can be use in express boat, the boat come every 15-30 min.Important point is if you start form Central pier that connect with sky train, Express boat and Tourist boat always come in the same time and at another pier, express boat is come often than tourist boat and stop at same station (In website they told tourist boat stop at Maharaj pier that near to Grand palace and Emerald buddha it's not true, Maharaj pier is cancelled you can stop at Tha-Chang pier that more closed to Grand palcae). So if you only go by express boat it's not necessary to buy one-day pass 150 baht can buy 10 ticket for express boat! The Pro for Tourist boat is 1. It's larger (always have seat available) 2. They have guide on the boat (but guide isn't help, some staff have poor english) 3. less people because it's more expensive. If you want large boat and take a seat select tourist boat. If you want to save money, you should use express boat and buy one way ticket,oh! don't forget to prepare enough 20 baht bank notes or coins.
The river that ever sleeps!. Very busy river, from dusk to dawn there's always some kind of boat traveling on it. We went on a boat ride to asiatique and it was exhilarating .

The River of Kings. If you can book to stay in one of the hotels on the banks of the river.It is fantastic to sit at one of the restaurants any time of the day and watch the huge barges going slowly up and down the river or the various river busses talking people on their local commute.This is what all "city" rivers should be like.

not very clean. Its just a big river like any other rives in the other countries. But sad to say that it is not being maintained properly. looks dirty at many points. It can be a good experience it the rives can be kept more clean. However its a good and cheap way of local transport in the rivers by a boat as it can save a lot of time also

an Exhilarating Experience... It is best to see Bangkok by way of the local transportation.. you get to see a lot more of the actual Bangkok than just being a tourist..The Chao Phraya river which runs in the middle of this city is used as a ferry by one and all in Bangkok to travel from one place to the other.. we were in Bangkok for 2 days and on both days we went up to the river and took the ferry.. on the first day we took the tourist ferry while on the other the local one.. with a number of tourist attractions scattered around this river, it is the best way to commute.. the experience of seeing Bangkok and its local architecture along this river was an exhilarating experience..
Its so romantically romantic... Nice Experience, with great music and ambiance.. Couples and families with kids will have a great time.. For Vegetarians, food is a problem..

A Unique Experience. Using the river boat on the Chao Phraya River is the only way to see the city. High rise luxury hotels nestle next to temples and Thai families living next to the river. It is extremely cheap by anyone's standards, and you get to travel with local, monks and tourists all at the same time.

An artery in the city. There's a wide variety of river boats to take passengers to see the various sites in Bangkok and always activity to watch 0n the water. There are small tugs pulling huge freight vessels, small boats speeding along with individual passengers, taking them to the canals off the main river where people live on the water's edge. There are dining vessels, lit up at night, and large ferry types just transporting large numbers to their destinations along this wide and well-used artery through the city. Hotels line the river, enjoying great views and opportunities for boat-watching and boat-hopping. The water is dirty and constantly churned by boats but the river is an essential thoroughfare through Bangkok.

Great experience. used the boat to Asiatique shopping mall as the main road can be jammed up. Located just by the river. They provide free transportation from Chao Pharaya Express Boat pier. Located next to BTS too. Very easy access. well recomended.
take a longtail boat from the top end of Kohsan Raod. bargain hard, should be no more than about 700 Bhat for an hour and take the backwater tour. Stop by a stilted shop, gets some beers, and enjoy
Great way to get around. Faster than car, walking or even biking. It's a fantastic way to get around the city and also see the sites of Bangkok.

A good alternative. It's a good alternative to BTS when travelling around Bangkok. The boat around Chao Phraya river is amazingly easy. Get the 1 day pass and you can get on and off the boat. It is nice to go around and see the tourist spots around Bangkok.

Useful, Convneient and Interesting As Alternative Transport. Use the public ferries to visit some of the main tourist attractions facing or near the river. It is a cheap and easy way to go for a river cruise. The boats are also used by locals and can be packed at certain times, for example, when major tourist sites close. Boats fly different colored flags to indicate the route that they will take and the stops made. You can buy tickets from a conductor on board; have coins or small banknotes ready.

Nice trip and great service. Took a trip up the chao phraya river which was nice as makes a change from the hustle and bustle in Bangkok and also stopped off down as Asiatique which was nice to roam around for food and upmarket outdoor markets.Also took the chao phraya river express boat to the pier for the Grand Palace. Much cheaper and actually quicker than the tourist boat.

Best way to see historic Bangkok. It would appear to be one of the world’s busiest rivers, and as a result fairly mucky. However it is the best way to visit many of the tourist attractions (Royal Grand Palace,Wat Arun, Wat Pho, Royal Barge museum, etc). The main pier is Sathorn Pier, which is adjacent to the Saphan Taksin SkyTrain station. You can get a one day boat pass for 150 Bhat (£3), which is excellent value for money. There are also free shuttle boats to the River City Shopping Mall, and the Asiatique night market (from 1600 hrs). Routes can be identified by the coloured pendants flying from the rear of boats (orange, blue, white etc).

A Very Interesting Ride.... We took a private long tail boat ride for about an hour and a half a saw things that were not only interesting but extremely eye opening. We saw the way some of these people live and compared to folks in the USA, it really is hard to believe that people can live in such property. At the same time, there is much beauty to experience. This is indeed a must see attraction when in Bangkok.
CRUISE YOUR WAY TO THE TEMPLE. Boat is the best way to get around the temples in Thailand. You can see many magnificent temples and architectural buildings.

River tour. The tour lasted too long and stopped too many times to wait for the water dams ("water elevators"). Quite boring indeed and too expensive (6,000 baht) for the benefit. Water heavily polluted and sometimes splashed on the boat passengers. the boats not seems to be a good example of safety.

The original heart of Bangkok. No visit to Bangkok is complete without a visit to the river, and preferably a ride on a river taxi. It is crazy busy with all sorts of boats including tourist ones, but also big low barges. On our first trip to Bangkok thirty years ago there were elephants bathing on the banks on the opposite, less developed side of the river , but now it is fully built up. The river taxis are high speed, skinny boats with lots of power. Not expensive to take a trip. You can also book dinner cruises which would be fun but we did not do. Recommend lunch or dinner by the river at one of the grand hotels ...eg Oriental, Shangri-La etc. There is a public transit stop at the river and the hotels have their own boats which regularly stop there and can take you to the hotel.
try it!. you should give it a try... jump on the expressboat and let it take you to a new place, just jump off when you feel for it :)
Great fun. Riding in a long tail boat along the river is fun and a great way to see the sights. Tourist boats along the river are cheap and it is an easy way to get to the sights.
Cold and Adventure. It was very good, and it has restaurant and the food is good, and many souvenirs outside landing area. Entrance fee are okey and very calm place.You must try it.

great fun. they'll try and sell the tourist the 150 baht daily ticket which you don't always need. however it fast tracks you onto the taxi boat first...especially good at rush hour.water was filthy...don't let it spray into your mouth!!!we went on late in the day when we arrived in bangkok just to get our bearings of where we wanted to go sightseeing. valuable for first time in Bangkok.

Smells bad.... Was quite a let down! The water is brown and it smells horrible with the boat's gas... If you're crossing the river probably won't matter that much, but 40 min trip along the river is too much.

Awesome river, prob not what you'd expect. It's brown. It's a brown river. The beauty of this place isn't the colour but the culture. Keep looking off to the horizon then track it back down to your boat. This is a great vantage point to see just how much of a mishmash this City is :) Amazing.

Take a ride on the water highway of Bangkok. A busy artery of transportation cutting through Bangkok is a must-do. You can choose from multiple forms of transport; either a hotel-operated boat, the city ferry or hire a private boat for less than 30 dollars. Take the canal tour through the neighborhoods on the west side of the river-very eye-opening and another side (I say more realistic view) of Bangkok.

An unkown way of traveling and seeing Bangkok. In the center of bangkok at yo have the Chao Praya river; on a regular base you can take the water boat which brings you from one part to the other prt of bangkok and have the scenery of temples, royal palace and other nice views; very cheap 15bath. some of the places are connected to the BTS and MRT network, the underground and tram sysytem of bangkok. You are not alone on the water boat but it has something magical to take the waterway to move in busy trafic bangkok.
Great River. Love going up and down the Chao Phraya river taxis are great, you can virtually go anywhere, we used the river taxis to go to Chinatown, The Royal Palaces, Pier 10 for local shopping.

The river and canal - wonderful!. We never expected the canal and river tour to be such a highlight. We had a longtail boat to ourselves, as we crossed the choppy Chao Phraya river. We were deeply jetlagged and exhausted, but this experience certainly perked us up! We had a couple hour tour along the canals. Saw many monitor lizards lazing along the banks. I had expected the canal to be dirtier and odorous, when in fact it was just fine. The air was fresh, our boat comfortable. It was a joy to cruise up and down, catching the sights.

Wonderful Experience. Sailing along the river was a great experience and a great way to see Bangkok instead of the shops. You can hop on and off along the river. We travelled to see The Grand Palace and found the journey just wonderful.

river ride down to Shangra La Hotel. well another wonderful experience, you have to careful where you get onto the boat on the river as being tourists they will rip you off - we agreed our price down by a third! as told him we would walk and get a taxi or tuktuk instead - TIP! keep your mouth closed a river water can be very dirty but the views were great

Best way to get around the temples. Plenty of choice for boats, large and small. Ferries are very cheap but can be a bit like cattle herding! Trips around the city canals normally start on the river. Great views of the city landmarks and hotels.

Take a small taxi and brave the waves. The waterway is dirty and filled with boats and debris, but a skilled taxi driver will navigate you between it all. We took one to the Grand Palace area and enjoyed seeing life along the riverbank.

Basic boat travel. We used the river to get from grand palace to the stop called "thewet" to head to the zoo. Was a cool ride, 15 baht per person. It was the basic transport for the locals. You pay when you're on the boat, if they come around. They didn't ask me and I tried to give money to the wrong people in the end, we got off and had the ride for free.

Many ways to enjoythe Chao Praya River. The Chao Phyra river plays such a gigantic role in culture of the Thais it would be sad to view it from only one dimension. I had the opportunity to enjoy the river on dinner cruise with a group of new friends. It was cool, breezy and clear. The lights were lovely and the musicians added to the pleasant ambiance. An extra special evening was spent with a long tiime Chinese friend on the terrace of the Oriental Hotel and watching not only the boats going up and down, but the hotel's water taxi taking people back and forth.My daytime favorite was going up River and after a bit of a wait entering one of the "private"( not Really) klongs. You may see alligators swimming about. On the left side going north is a small hotel,waterside, that looks like a reasonably priced place to stay in the high rent district. Unfortunately, I do not know the name, but would strive to find it for a return trip. With the water taxis plentiful it would make a great mode of transportation to other sights or the sky train.Serious SUNSCREEM sunglasses and a hat are a must.

The heart and soul of Bangkok. Virtually anything worth seeing in Bangkok is easily accessible from the Chao Phraya and the river taxi system could not be easier (or cheaper) to use. Fifteen baht will get you almost anyplace you want to go. And if you have a little time to kill, you can take in the action on shore and on the other boats as you ride to the end of the line. Then turn around and go back.

Chao Phraya riverside Bars and Lounges. I've been travelling to Thailand for 31 years, the first hotel I stayed in was the Royal Orchid Sheraton on the River. Since then I stay at other hotels 'downtown' but ALWAYS return to the River to soak up the ambience. This 'working' River with all its boat whistles, hoots and boat engine sounds in the distance is a pleasant contrast to the hustle and bustle of downtown Bangkok. An enjoyable afternoon can be had by catching the BTS to Saphan Taksin Stn and walking the short distance to the Shangrila for a Wine and the great view of the River. Then walking to the Oriental to 'soak up' the charm and history of this great hotel, then a boat across the River to the Peninsula to experience one of the finest hotels in the country, then a free hotel boat back across the River to the Royal Orchid Sheraton for a wine poolside (the 2nd pool downstairs) then at about 4.45pm jump on a free boat back across the River to the Hilton Millennium Hotel and take the lift to the top and visit the 360 Bar. Best views of the Chao Phraya and a special deal.. buy 1 drink and get 1 free (beer or wine). The 360 Bar opens 5pm and even though it's only the 32nd floor, it's the best view in Bangkok. From here you can get a free Hotel boat back to Saphan Taksin BTS. FYI - The Royal Orchid Sheraton has a very good Beatles cover band every Monday and Wednesday night from 9pm. They're Thai, but look like the Beatles and sound like the Beatles. Be sue to check out my video coming soon (Feb 2014) to YouTube called.. "Bangkok - Rooftop and Riverside Bars".

Amazing to watch this River. The best way to enjoy the Chao Phraya is to sit on a terrace of one of the many hotels and watch the boats going up and down all the time. Then take one of the boats and just travel up or down a few stops. This is a fantastic experience.

Good Transportation Alongside Chaopraya River. This boat taxi river is the best way to go many tourism area alongside Chaopraya river. To use it, best way from Central Pier (N1) which is easily reach by BTS from/to Saphan Thaksin BTS Station. From there walk down to the river side and you can see the Central Pier river boat station. Unfortunately the info is not too much in English (so better get preparation by browsing it before). They didn't give enough informaton about route info, cost average etc, and even where we need to take line up queque. But BASICALLY they offert 2 different services which is BLUE TOURIST BOAT service (1 day whole pass about 150B, which is pay on the locket) and ORDINARY RIVER BOAT (it depends the route 'flag' colour, which is around 15B for 1 trip which is pay on the boat). 1. BLUE TOURIST BOAT, which is cost abot 150B for one day trip usually they will offering to any tourist once they approaching on the locket. Actually they are not scam, they do honest and just to sell their business and it's depend on us to use their service. The lack of info is they may not inform us that other possible ORDINARY RIVER BOAT way is available. And they also stop only some pier like ORIENTAL (N1), SIPHRAYA (N3), RACHAWONGSE/Chinatown (N5), THATIEN/Watpho (N8). THACHANG/Grand Palace (N9), WANGLANG/Local Market (N10), PHRAARTIT (N13). And in the afternoon they also adding to ASIATIQ Pier (see their booklet for more info schedule). So, BLUE TOURIST BOAT :* If you planned whole day to visit some/every tourism place on that Pier, it's good to use this service since ticket is 1 day valid and no need to hassle for paying boat fee. Just show the ticket.* Boat providing English spoken guide and they will give tourism information alongside the river and the next Pier that boat will stop.* Excluded area on the pier while awaiting the boat arrive. Also their staff will calling tourist to ready and help them in/out from vessel* Boat is not too crowded with people, easy to get chair to sitdown* Only more time needed when waiting the boat coming, seem they dont have much boat in operating (expect about 30min to wait the boat)2. ORDINARY RIVER BOAT :Normally they are some service boat with some colour, but we recommend to use ORANGE FLAG. It's the fastest, cheapest, travel and stop almost in every PIER. The fee will be billed by officer once you aboard onthe vessel. It's give a little waiting time in PIER comparin with BLUE TOURIST BOAT service but much crowded people onthe vessel and line up of queque (especially in the morning/afternoon rush hour). Well, imagine that non tourist Thai people will commonly use this ORANGE FLAG service as well when travelling between the pier.And for other boat services, if you need to cross the river, looking for boat with mark FERRY BOAT SERVICE. But not every PIER have this FERRY service, normally only on CENTRAL PIER, THATHIEN (N8)/Watpo to WatArum and THACHANG (N9)/GrandPalace to N10.Also if you stay in some big hotel alongside river, they may provide their own boat service/shuttle. Usually the boat will have different design, like wooden one.

Use a long boat. Use a long boat, they hired for your party private fir no extra charge. They are more authentic and the work-related very friendly. For only around £20 you get the private boat fir you and your party, it is driven for you and it takes you to all the main attractions and waits 30 mins fir you to go inside. Loved it. Although being on the water makes you realise where the awful smell in bangkok comes from.

Dinner Cruise was awesome. Get a dinner cruise if you can. You won't regret a penny. the river's peaceful, the night's breeze is perfect, the views are amazing, food is not that bad, do it with company so you'll enjoy it better. :)

Take the public ferry. For 15 baht you can take the orange flag ferry and travel along the pulse of the city, seeing interesting architecture, temples and communities. Much better deal than the more expensive tourist boats!
River express boats. A great way to get about and miss the traffic jams and only flat fee of THB15 for any lenght of journey

Hop on hop off CHAO PHRAYA TOURIST BOAT. Fascinating trip no real need to pay boat tour prices one of the best bargains to be had for a great day out is the day ticket. CHAO PHRAYA TOURIST BOATTake sky train to Saphan Taskin down to the bridge buy ticket comes with booklet detailing the attractions at each stop along the river. Ticket 150 baht for the day. Lots to see along the river great way to get to the reclining Budda. Grand palaces, Riverside shopping. If you have time take a trip the whole length of the river -life along the river is so varied and interesting.

River Transportation. We used the river to get around Bangkok everyday we were there. It was super easy to figure out which boat to get on. We never had to wait long for a boat and the fare was cheap. They were crowded though. Loved that there was a pier at a skytrain station too!!
River Cruise. Spectacular night scenery along the river banks. It took two whole hours as we had buffet on the cruise liner with live band entertainment. Worth the price we paid.

Cool place to see Bangkok. I took a river taxi to and from Wat Arun near Wat Pho and enjoyed the area. Lots of other boats and river traffic to see and the view of the city is pretty cool. Sunset at Wat Arun is not to be missed.

Nice Way to Get Around. I was originally intimidated by what seemed like so many routes on the river, but I came to realize that it's very well organized and a great way to get from place to place near the river. It's a nice respite from Bangkok traffic and a great way to beat the heat. Visited Wat Arun and Asiatique on the river.
worth a go. Try a day ticket for the tourist ferry so you can get on and off as often as you like all day, the guide commentary is naff but you see a lot in a short time

a private cruise.
