I suggest to have a private cruise on the Chaopraya by the regular boats.first,you travel with local people,monks ,tourists and share a dayly life experience .with a regular boat you can choose anytime to stop ,visit a temple (there are many,not only the most celebrated Wat Arun),a market ,enjoy local food or a shopping at local price,then catch another boat and go on.it,s a nice,enjoyable,easy and very cheap experience.

An Amzing View Into Life On The River. We took an hour and a half long tail boat ride up the Chao Phraya River and through some klongs to see some of the smaller waterways.This is not the floating market tour, which is touristy but interesting on its own. This trip simply takes you along a very busy river and into neighborhoods so you get to see how much this river impacts Bangkok. we arrange the trip though our hotel lobby tour operator.
take the orange boat. we buyed ticket boat for tourist for 40 bath, but when we queued we realize we should not buy ticket but take orange boat which pay on boat more cheaper (15 bath).

Great way to get around.. The river boats are a fantastic way to get around BKK particularly at the moment with the demonstrations,get the BTS to the river and jump on a boat,great fun,cheap and get a real feel for the city.We got on and off at around 6 different locations and used that then as a base to explore.In general watch out for touts everywhere feeding tourists lies about what may or may not be open due to demonstrations.We were approached on numerous occasions but ignored them and found them all to be telling lies,really don't know what they get from this?Many of them claim to be police officers or tourist guides,be aware they are not!! I can only assume that they want you to go with them and be ripped off at a friends boat/restaurant/shop.Be careful.

great way to travel. an excellent way to get to the palace, wat arun, the reclining buddha and even china town and kao san road is on the public ferrys on chao phraya river. take the sky rail to the river and travel on the ferrys with orange flags. you pay on the ferry. you can also buy tickets at the terminal for the ferrys with blue flags which are more tourist friendly and give a commentary as you travel. orange ferrys are 15-20bht and blue flag ferrys are 40bht

too expensive for what it is. we took the boat and paid 150 baht for an all day pass. The trip itself was good and like other contributors I recommend going on the river during your time in Bangkok. However, you can get a one way trip up or down the river for 15 baht using river taxis, which is just as much fun.
A river runs thru it!. This is the highway of the city. The ferry ride is the best ticket in town. Loved looking at the temples and river traffic. The heart of the city. Helpful people on board.

Take the public Boat. We took the public boat with orange flag from Sathon Pier to nonthaburi, which is the last stop and its out of Bangkok. It takes about 1 hour to reach this last stop. One way trip cost per person is 15 Baht. We took the next boat back to Bangkok
All on board. We charted a long tail boat for 1 hour it was very interesting to sail down the canals but the river was fantasic real good fun,nice hour on the river

Must see. Hey if you go to Bangkok and you don't take a boat on the river or experience the canals and home life Thai residents then what can I say.? It's yet another must do when visiting. By the way I experience some of the most beautiful flora and wonderful fruits as I have eve seen and tasted in my life !

Interesting!. We took a boat from one part of the city back to our hotel. It was about a 20 minute ride. Interesting to see how people live along the river and all the commerce. The river can be a bit rough, so be prepared to get a little wet!

Fast and full. We used 150 bht day ticket so you can get on or off. Boats always full,but did have one to ourselves later in day. Some boats said to be free but very very busy and standing room only.can buy 1 ticket for 45bht

Nice Viewpoint from which to see the City. I am so glad I took to the river one day of my time in Bangkok. It was so nice to see the city from this perspective. I took a long tail one way, a ferry on the way back. Both were fun experiences and a much nicer way to get around than taxis on crowded streets. Get out on the river at least one day!!

The life of Bangkok. We've been in Bangkok a lot and now we don't stay anywhere but on the Chao Praya river when we're here. Being able to hop on the public ferry or long boats or dinner cruises is a treat.....and avoiding the city traffic and congestion by being near the river has made Bangkok one of our favorite cities. Plus it's cooler and the air is better! Get a 150 baht ticket and ride all day. Getting to the Grand Palace, Wat Pho, and Wat Arun, Chinatown, the flower market, etc....is so much easier by ferry.

Great river. Went on a long tail boat it was great my son loved it we was the only 3 on it plus the driver, it was like our own little tour, their was so much to see, little thai ladies on their boats stopped you to sell you things like drinks and gifts lovely people. It was amazing to see how people live, if you come to Bangkok you must go on the river it's lovely.

Our favourite thing to do !. What we loved most about the city is cruising up and down the river.Always things to do and stuff happening on the river ,other boats,barges,vessels of all sorts,very busy and gorgeous by night too.A cheap way to get around the sprawling city.

Beats the Hustle and Bustle of the streets. No trip to Thailand is complete without a trip along the river. Its a different way to travel and can be quite a relief after spending days in busy Bangkok tuk tuks, subway or taxis.plus, you get to see some of the fantastic (and not so fantastic) sites along the way from the incredible hotels to the locals fishing and playing on the rivers edge. If not actually on the river it can be quite nice to sit and watch the world go by as the hotel river taxis bob along. You will also see the fishing boats, barges and goods ships making their way along the river.

Good way to pass an hour, but not fabulous!. The longtail boat keeps to the Chao Phraya River and the main canals, and not into the smaller ones where domestic life goes on, so not very interesting stuff to see. I was dismayed that the locals encourage feeding the fish on bread - not good for them at all (and they're supposed to be holy fish?!). Also the boatman we had was a real cowboy, and thought he was really clever by speeding up to such an extent that the boat was hardly in the water, and thudded across it with bone-rattling smacks, and horrendous noise. Dreadful; in fact I thought it was reckless.

Excellent experience.. The view from the river, highrise buildings, the palace, Buddha Temple is Just awesome. Due to disturbance in the city we could not visit the Palace & the Temples, then we chose to go on river cruize. The river runs within the city and various type of cruizes are organized. However, jus standing beside the river & looking around is also very good. There are many entry points to this river, we had gone from a mall the name I dont remember.

Best way to travel to the City's attractions. The main Pier (Satthorn Taksin) is also on skytrain line also, so really easy to get too. Go and visit the cities attractions from here and don't forget seeing Asiatique which is an evening place to go to, free boats going regularly, you can dine there, shop and have a good time and take a taxi back to your hotel afterwards if it gets a little late.

nice wat to travell. jam packed in to a river boat is just an experiance you must have.. just bring water for the ride. as the crowds get up n down the boat you will be amaze to find that even the aged in thailand are still able as the young. not like in my country where the old cant even cross the road alone.

Best way to explore the old city. Avoid teh huassle of the countless traffic jams and travel by river boat. 150 THB gets you unlimited daily rides on the tourist boats or for 15 baht you can ride the local boat but be aware the stops are slightly different.

If you haven't been on the river you haven't been in Bangkok.. I can sit for hours just looking at the activity on the river. Small boats and bigger once, sightseeing boats and restaurant boats goes up and down the river most of the day. Great.

Only as transportation. Taking the ferry on the Chao Phraya River a perfect way to get around in Bangkok. But from my point of view it stops there. There's nothing charming with these old boats spitting out black smoke all over the place. The captains are very stressed and runs the engines just below their limits. Getting on and off is also stressful, especially travelling with a child. But again, a perfect and cheap way to get around in Bangkok quickly.

great experience. I used the boat services on Chao Phraya River to get to some temples, and it was a really great experience, it feels great being on the boats, you get to see some of the city while your on your way to were your heading, overall its a pleasant and to some (like me) amazing experience.

Nice views from boat but be careful of dishonest locals. We came to the river to get a ferry up to The Grand Palace pier after having read about it in our guide book. We however got railroaded into getting a long boat instead. The views were nice as we went up the river but it wasn't a journey I enjoyed! Because of the type of boat it felt as though we were going extremely fast and as though the boat would be turned over at any time. When we disembarked at the pier locals were there waiting saying we'd now got to pay a landing fee! We ignored them and carried on walking but some other tourists were getting sucked in..

The cruise experience on this river is worth it!!. There are night cruises on the Chao Phraya river almost every day. These cruises takes you through the length of the river and you can have an amazing night view of bangkok via it. A very apt experience for couples.We opted for Chao Phraya Princess IV cruise which interesting offers Indian dining option. They had an amazing indian food buffet (both veg and non veg) with an indian DJ to dance on.. I guess most of our desis' opt for it.The cruise was well managed, beautifully lit with candle lights. We were placed at the lower which was air conditioned. The upper deck was open view and non air conditioned, with amazing view open view of river serving international cuisines( only problem with upper deck was handling Bangkok's high temperature and a typical stink coming from the river water).The avg per person ticket for the cruise is in between 800-1000THB.You can actually bargain on the ticket charges. Also remember the cruise starts and finishes at River Mall, from where if you have to take a taxi to your hotel, the taxi driver will not go as per meter and will charge you double therefore plan your commute prior to the cruise begins.

Rapid Transit. This is without doubt the best way to get around in Bangkok. Linked to a Skytrain day pass you never need to be held up again in Bangkok. Avoid the over priced Tourist Boats and get the orange flag boat which stops everywhere to get the full experience. Wonderful views of Bangkok and stops near Grand Palace, Wat Arun and Wat Pho. Marvellous day out.
busy. This is an important river so it is very busy and zero traffic control. Lots of trash in the water too.Several boats to hire for taxi or a dinner cruise. It can get cool at night.

Awesome place to spend in the evening. This is an awesome for dinner cruise and a stroll along the shore. The ASIATIQUE THE RIVERFRONT mall is situated on the shore of this river and gives a good view of the Bangkok skyline

Grand river. The river adds to charm of the city. Waters are very clean and ferry services are excellent with reasonable fares. Asiatique the riverfront is must visit on bank of the river along with various temples

Easy and cheap form of transport. We had the choice of paying a tour guide and taking longer time or DIY at our own pace. After reading a few forums and other travellers' experiences, I decided to DIY. I'm glad we did.At first, it was a little tricky to find the right pier because of the tour group counters trying to sell you 'tours' at inflated prices but we merged with other english travellers wandering around and eventually found the right way. Do your homework (tripadvisor forums) so you know which boat is right for you and you should be ok! Boats are busy and knowing the courtesy is appreciated (move to the front unless you are getting off). Convenient and cheap and glad we DIY'd.

pick the orange flag boat. Enjoy my river boating here :) . I got confused for the first time at Central Pier. There was two pier, right and left when u came out from BTS Saphan Taksin. If you go to the right pier, there was like informal ticket counter there. They will ask you where you wanna go and will charge 100 bath to Grand palace or Wat Arun for one way trip. If u go to the left pier there is ticket counter and if you look like tourist they will offer you one day pass ticket which is 150 bath. If you want the cheaper option just ignore it. Follow the queue with the local, take the boat with orange flag. it only cost 15 bath one way, or take the tourist boat with blue flag, it cost 40 bath one way.

Princess Dinner Cruise at Chao Phraya River on Christmas Eve. A visit at Bangkok without Chao Phraya River cruise is incomplete. My family considered this ride as a memorable one, if not an excellent experience. It all started with warm reception at River City pier where each one of us, as guests, were pinned with a garland of Jasmine flowers by a Thai lady. We boarded Princess Cruise at 7:45 PM for such a beautiful night scenery sailing along the Phraya River. Left and right of the river, as the cruise gradually glides through, unfold to us some wonders by night in Bangkok, the like of WAT Arun, The Grand Palace, The Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the wonderful Rama VIII suspension, expensive bridge. Dinner was served under candle light, in buffet style with array of choices from authentic Thai to International cuisine. We had our sumptuous meal, while being entertained by a live professional singer, from the Philippines, too versatile to render romantic songs and pop to jazz music, inviting guests of different nationalities to dance with friends at upper deck disco floor. It took us almost 2 hours of camaraderie and fun, no barrier can ever break the joy and cheer of everyone filled with excitement and wonders at its beauty of the surroundings. This experience is worth remembering, worth treasuring in our lives. What a place to revisit someday. Would you like to be part of this wonderful and unforgettable experience? See it for yourself.

Great way to see Bangkok. We took "private" boat and guide and had about an hour cruise. We saw local houses, water markets, water monitors(huge lizards) etc. Soothing breeze under scorching hot sun and great views, don't miss!

Try to take the locals ferries. From the Central Pier (Taksin stop on the BTS Skytrain), you will likely be herded onto a tourist boat. Tourist boats cost double or more than the locals' ferries and include some "narration" of the stops -- which was so heavily accented that it was almost indecipherable. They will also try to sell you a day pass for 150THB -- only good if you will be traveling four or more segments in one day -- if not, just pay by the segment. The tourist boats go a bit more slowly and are more gentle in off loading passengers, while the locals' ferries are fast, efficient, and fun -- the bang into the pier and people hop off and on in seconds and then, off again! If you can't get a locals boat at the Central Pier, try to take one later in the day.You can organize your own river tour by using the ferries -- a trip to the end is only 40THB or less, so double that for round trip. It is very scenic along the way and spectacular at night as you see Wat Arun in magnificent silhouette, and the Grand Palace sparkling from the lights on its cut glass mosaic facades. (note that the Grand Palace lights turn on when the boat approaches on the river and turn off once it passes). You can exit on one of the pier for the large, fancy hotels and have a drink to watch the lights of the city, or get off at the Chinatown exit and spend a few hours in the very large and vibrant section of Bangkok -- go during the weekday when people are out shopping to see all manner of things -- many you will see for the first time. We found these boats to be fun, fast and efficient -- uniquely Bangkok experience.

Good for sight seeing and food tripping. We payed for 1000baht each person and bought fish food for 20baht. I agree it is expensive. An alternative to this is to ride frim the China town station upstream and do your sight seeing. But in our case we were brought to a canal and to the market when we ate a lot of Thai street food. The river is not clean but we paid for the gas and the service and the destination. We enjoyed the food tripping and got very full by taking a little of this and that.

Complete your Siamese Experience. Riding a boat on the Chao Phraya River completes anyone's visit of Bangkok. Its wide expanse is impressive and some of the sights are best shot from the river. It's also the best way to get around to the many historical sites, skipping traffic or crowds. Probably the best way to get to it is by riding the train all the way to the end of the route (from Silom Road) then taking the boat. At the pier, you can just hop the boat (don't be bothered by the signs selling you a one-day pass to the many sights cause you can't finish it all in one day and it'll be a waste) and the conductor will be walking around, and you can pay them directly. It's significantly cheaper that way.
Dinner cruise over Chao Phraya River. I had my end of year dinner on a cruise . Fireworks, music, ladyboys just fantastic. Don't miss, competing packages with many tourism agents.

Best way to get around the old town. Not only are the river taxis fun but this is the fastest way to get around. Also consider a dinner tour to see a different view of old Bangkok. Asiatique shopping center has their own boat from Central ... which can have a long wait!

Take it in. What a great way to view Bangkok separate from the hustle and bustle of being in the city. Take the river boat to one of the nearby attractions and enjoy the cruise. Trying to figure out the times where you won't be the one standing up while on the boat is a challenge, but understand that the weekends are prime times. The water is not clean, so don't expect pristine surroundings, but there is something about water that is calming.

Disgusting river and we were robbed by the driver. . I'm sad to leave my first 'terrible' rated review but terrible doesn't begin to describe this. We started walking from our hotel (Lebua) to the pier near Shangri La but a lovely tuk tuk driver told us this was an expensive pier to catch the boat from and for 20baht would take us somewhere cheaper. Joke!!! He took us just down the road to another pier where we were told it would cost 1500baht per person. We only had 1600 between us. After we said we couldn't afford it they halved it and charged 1500 for the two of us. We were told we'd see a heap of landmarks and get to walk around while the boat waited for us, then return to the same pier. Joke! The boat was falling apart and I'm pretty sure it was taking on water. We got soaked by the disgusting water that was full of dead fish and rubbish. Had to change clothes, underwear and all, and wash our hair after that. It was disgusting. The boat driver was extremely rude. We didn't see any of the landmarks we were told we would then when we were up a canal and out of sight of anyone he demanded the money we had left on our wallets. We gave him the little amount we had left and he demanded more in euros or dollars! We had nothing on us so said he'd take us to an ATM! Realising we were being robbed I yelled at him in my 'I'm not taking this nonsense' tone and he reluctantly got moving. I was willing to jump overboard and swim for it if he continued. After fleecing us of any cash we had left he dropped us at a completely different pier over 10kms from where we got on with no money to get home. Disgusting, dirty, shameless man. Do yourself a favour and just view pictures of this river online. That would be better than actually riding it. If you must ride the river go on the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat for 40baht per person. Tickets are available in board. Avoid the privately run long boats at all costs.

Some cheap options. Riding the river is an excellent way to see a fair bit of Bangkok. The public ferrie are incredibly cheap-15baht for the length of the service fron Sathorn/Central for about an hour up the river; then the same back.Particularly if you want to save a little, this is a lot cheaper than the 150 baht for the tourist express and, on the day we did, was much less crowded than the tourist boats.

Great idea to hop on a boat tour. Great idea to hop on a boat tour and see the river. We left from appear the lebua state tower hotel, made a 15 minute stop at the palace of darkness (which was awesome), went through a canal, stopped fed a ton of catfish then ended at khoasan road. Highly recommend d!

DIRTY. As usual in Thailand, dirty and dirty.
Dozens of long boats running faster as posible , making waves .
Water as dirty and not really easy to see fishes .
SOme people offers bread for fishes. MAybe some people needs more bread thn fishes
Take the river boat. You can take the free boat if you wait long enough. Otherwise 30 baht is worth the trip down to Asiatique for some night shopping.

Cheapest and faster mode of travel.. If one does not want to get cought in traffic they should use this river transport. Use orange line for 15TBH to rach your destination. Best to visit Grand palace and Emerald Buddha. While traveling in boat one can appreciate the architecture of few temples like wat Arun and Thai Naval premises.

One of the best things to do in bangkok.. Just jump on a boat, it doesn`t really matter which and ride to the end of the line, get off and look around and see real Thailand! There are fast boats and very slow ones but it`s all very easy.

Great experience at night. No trip would be complete to Bangkok without at least getting onto the river at some point. Try the ferry to get around Bangkok centre saving your baht on taxi's. Go on a cruise during the day and see city life from the river. Better still book a river cruise at night along with food and drink relax and enjoy the attractions of the city in lights

life line of bangkok. the mighty chao phyara is the life line of bangkok.it is a source of seafood.chao phraya is also a channel of transportation - for tourists and locals.commercial and private boats ply up and down the river.the river is also used for transporting heavy merchandise using barge trains - construction materials, heavy machinery, vehicles etc.the river is a site for some of the most beautiful hotels and condos that line the river banks. you can take private cruises alsong the river in private boats (specially dedicated) or in the regular boats used for general transportaion purposes. the river really helps to ease some of the traffic situation in bangkok.the cost is neglible in the commercial boats - about 30bahts a trip or a day pass for 150bahts with unlimited access. it is a good option as many tourist attractions like the chinatown, little india, local markets (wang lang being one of the more popular) the wats and the palace can be accessed via this means of transportaion.take an evening cruise for truly stunning views of the bangkok sunset and skyline.more specialised dinner cruises are also available.alas as in most countries some abuse has now left the river water muddy (discharge of polutants and human waste?).the mighty river is still functional but it would be spectular if the river water were to be clean and clear.

A great way to get about Bangkok. The first thing you have to do is to understand the river taxi system. They cover a huge length of the river and are identified as to where they go and how much they charge by the colour of the flags flown at their rear end. During the rush hours the boats are hopelessly overloaded so try to avoid these times, I would hate to think what would happen if there was an accident during these hours, I do not get the feeling that they carry enough life jackets for everyone on board.

Good But Pricey. Hiring a private boat to take you up the river for about US$130 for an hour is a bit pricey for Bangkok but its a quick way of taking in what is on the main river there. I would strongly urge you to hire a slim boat with the egg beater propeller faster and more enjoyable than one of the flat bottom boats that chugs along (have ridden both).
long boat. We did a long boat ride on the river. It was very enjoyable. The only hard part was getting out of it at a dock not made for long boats. They had to drag us up.

Love the river skip the canal tour. The river is critical to Bangkok/Thai life. Rice barges go up and down, and other shipping. The dinner cruises are great - especially Loy Nava - in a traditional teak boat with a 7 course tasting menu.

Different view of the city. Although we ended up taking a boat because of a sneaky cab driver, we were glad we did. A teak boat picked us up and we cruised up the river to the locks to tour the canals. The river is so busy but the boat drivers are accustomed to that and maneuver much like they do on the road! It is amazing to see so much activity on and along the river. Most likely if you visit the Temple of Dawn, you'll be taking the ferry across the river as it is one of the quicker ways to get there. Its a good way to get some fresher air after being in the city.
dinner cruise. buy the dinner cruise from hotels2Thailand online.not bad for experience.love the scenery.food is good but depends on which cruise you choose.

Better than a taxi. We wanted to visit the Grand palace so decided the river would be the perfect route. We were based at the Centara Grand in Central World so we took the train from Siam Square to Saphan Thaksin - the fare was round 24 baht form memory. We then took the tourist boat at 40 baht up to the palace - an all day boat ticket would cost 150 baht. A great way to get around!

Great fun 2 hours. Well the entertainment began when we left the Hotel to be refused access to one of the main roads by one of the Protest Groups. No problem - fins another way. The actual bot trip was excellent - great musical entertainment, buffet food reasonable, staff excellent. the highlight was when they put Gangnam style on and boy did the mostly Asian crowd go crazy. That plus some very pervy Indian men leering at the cute young Japanese girls dancing. Very entertaining and highly recommended.
Canal life. Do get on the river and onto the canals.Makes you appreciate how some of the Thais actually live.Look at for the large monitor lizards swimming around
perfect way to get around. Such an easy and cheap way to get around, I avoid the tourist boats as these are more expensive, jump on the locals orange or yellow flag boats to numbered piers.

Good Experience. If you haven't been to Chao Phraya River you haven't been to Bangkok. It is a totally new experience to be on the boat along the old and new developments of the riverside. The type of the boat you choose will affect the experience as well. Certainly it is a quicker way to travel rather than getting stuck in the traffic jam.We were staying at Shangri La and the Central Pier is just next to the Hotel and our destination is the Reclining Buddha ( Wat Pho ) and the Palace. I read at TA to wait for an orange flag boat and it will cost us THB15. We were told at the counter that the orange flag would not arrive till an hour later and we were short of time- so we took the 'sampan' like boat which I guess the one people refer as the long tail ?? It costs THB 100 per person and we shared with about 10 other people. I don't know about you, but for me stepping down into the boat from the pier with a foot of water in between and the boat swaying further was an intimidating experience. We were given life jackets and the boat cruise in various speed with occasional spray. It was pleasant with water gleaming in the sun. When we reached Pier no. 8; I found it easier to step up; however a lady behind me fell right on her back, and when she gained strength to try again only to fall on her knee at the pier.From the Palace we walked to Pier no. 9, and was quoted THB 200 per person to r eturn to Central Pier ! We walked to the right where there was another booth and THB 40/person ! After ten minutes waiting the boat/ferry arrived- this one is the same level as the pier- thanks God ! It has blue flag and only made 5 stops to Central Pier - like every other stop. Half way- all seats were taken- lots of people standing, while someone on microphone kept on repeating in English and Thai the destinations. It was not as pleasant as our first trip and it took half an hour including waiting despite they are pretty fast in stopping and starting at every stop.Of course, another experience and a lot pleasant one would be the cruise dinner which is a totally different ambience instead of trying to get from point A to B !

busy river.... good to see. used the ferry a few... to move around from chinatown to the grand palace and Wat Arun... good fun.. lots of action on the river and loads of long tail boats around... in evening lots of floating restaurants going up and down.. a must see and do. to take local ferry and or a trip along the side canals..

must go once for a dinner and live thai band and indian music. HAD BEEN THERE FOR A DINNER THE CRICE LEAVES AT 7 TILL 8 ITS 2 hour dinner cruise start with a welcome drink the u can enjoy the chef special dinner dishes from prawns fish chicken meat and so on .......it cost 1000baht per pax u can get tickets from there at the entrance .if u love to dance u can have a nice dance on indian and thai music and songs sung by thai singer. its a nice way to watch Thailand by night with all the big hotels near bye the river and enjoy the cool breeze don't forget to take the seat on the first floor .its good to walk on open having fun and blast .

River taxi. A cheap and fun way to access the city. 3 stops cost us 15 Baat each. Be careful of being ripped off by the canal boat trips, it shouldn't cost you more than 2000 Baat which is expensive if you're on a budget.

River Life. This is great to see life on the river in Bangkok. Just get on the Chao Phraya Express (not the tourist boat) and see the sights as it cruises up the river then wander back through the streets and markets
Great way to see the city. Didn't bother with a day ticket, just bought individual tickets for each journey which is only 15 baht. Fantastic and authentic way to see the city.

'Meh'. Lower deck, middle row is the worst it could get. Go in for a window seat, the view is worth it! Out in the deck is pleasant. The lower deck had Indian food (average in the taste factor, but a good spread) and people grooving at Bollywood numbers. The upper deck is certainly more serene, the lower more happening. Take your pick!

Great way to get around. Our family of 4 just returned from Bangkok, and the tourist boats on the Chao Phraya River was one of our main modes of transportation. Renting a long boat was quoted to us at 1500 THB for an hour, so we opted for the cheaper and more public transport route and bought day passes on the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat for 150 THB each. The Central Pier, where we bought our passes, is right by one of the Sky Train stops (S6-Saphan Taksin), so it's really easy to get to the river via public transportation from just about any hotel in Bangkok. The nice thing about the day pass is that you have unlimited on and off priveleges, and you also get a nice little guide of the highlights of each of the 8 pier stops. We really enjoyed Chinatown (Ratchawongse Pier), Wat Pho (Tha Tien Pier), The Grand Palace & Wat Phra Kaeo (Tha Chang Pier), and Phra Arthit Road and Banglumpoo Market (Phra Athit Pier). Definitely take the tourist boat from Central Pier all the way to Phra Athit Pier once so that you see the entire section of the river that the tourist boat runs. And, yes, the river is dirty...not a big surprise in a city of this size.Be sure to travel the river at least once at night so that you see the night lights...the night skyline is beautiful, and the view of Wat Arun lit up at night is amazing. Be prepared for some close quarters on the boat during busy times...we found weekdays 9-10am and 4-6pm to be really busy.

A good way to get around. Used boats to do the temples - day ticket was 150 baht per person, so around £3 and you could use as much as you wanted. Plenty going on around the water, different way to see the city

Lovely way to get about in Bangkok. The river is like a living organism and changes during the day. The early morning calm and glistening, weed and other detritus idly flowing past. As the day warms up the river starts to breath, frantic with all sorts of motor craft , racing madly about, grappling for position on the quai. Take a public boat and travel the river pier13 to Central pier and just watch! The crazy struggle for places on board, the endless blowing whistles as the boats arrive and disgorge their passengers, the water thick and brown churning and swirling beneath. Fabulous temples, restaurants, incredible hotels and slums pass by. In the evening the river is filled with tourist boats, bright lights, blaring music, diners speeding up the river and back, reflections in the night. It is probably dirty - I'm not suggesting a swim, but it is the centre of Bangkok life and its an interesting insight into the city, avoiding haggling for taxis and tuk-tuks and their exhaust fumes!

alot to tell... Chao phraya river can be one way to avoid the busy traffic on the roads in Bangkok. Its also beautifull to see the bangkok skyline from a boat on the chao phraya river.. for instance to go to China town... a must see and experience ;)

A big sewer. This river is really useful for commuting to major sites. If you are on the river do not look down, clogged with trash and debris, filthy and do not eat near it thinking you have a romantic vantage point. Evenings are a bit better when lights are on the boats and you cannot see this revolting body of water.

If you swim here for 5 minutes you would be sick. It is very dirty river with many unidentified staffs floating. I believe if you swim in this river you would be sick and regret. Thai people say they love their country but they can not keep their loving country clean as same as Chinese people.
Boat cruise, with Ayothayya. Little expensive, book online for best rates, but guide was good, lunch in boat and cruise down river makes it worth it.

What An Experience. The River is very busy - don't fall in - it is very smelly and lots of stuff floating - very polluted! We went on several boat rides - very interesting - keep an open mind and you'll enjoy it.

A good overview of Thonburi. We took a longboat along the River and the canals, which gave us an interesting picture of life along the banks. Amid the swirling waves created by the wake of the motors and the green floating plants, a brave Thai pedlar was selling her wares from her small boat.

Mixed feeling. Loved the colorfully decorated loud boats but unlike other places, i have a moxed feeling about the boat tour. You see a nice building adjacent to slums. The guide was discrubbing the buildings along the river but i did not understand a single word she was saying. the river provides an easy access to Wat Pho and Wat Arun from Subway via boat

blood circulation of Bangkok. It is real "blood circulation" of the city.You cannot mist the cruise by this river. The best way is to hire a boat at Central Pier for a 1 or 2 hours trip on the river and khlongs (canals). You can also take the Chao Phraya River Express ( water tram like in Venice!) and admire Bangkok from the river. You must do it!

Choose the right express boat. I love this transport. Never miss to ride it to get to several points of interest in bangkok. Most people only use it for a cheap sightseeing trip, but it also stops near Kao San, Wat's , Royal Castle, cheap shopping in China Town and connecting to the BTS near Taksin Bridge. Taking the express boat at evenings are also a nice experience but it does not run too late. Beware at Taksin Bridge where there is a boot selling prepaid tickets for 40B , instead of paying 15B onboard the boat. For the regular boat choose the 'no ticket' line instead of 'with ticket'. Also dont miss using the other regular boat lines like the Khlong boats.

Inexpensive ride with a great view.. We really enjoyed this. Not sure how much we paid but it was very inexpensive. The ride was about an hour and we saw all kinds of things that displayed the culture of Thailand. I was happy that we had our own boat as it was kind of romantic. :) We would definitely do this again.

Peace and quiet. Well, peace and quiet most of the time, once your got through the crowds to board a boat! But the best is being able to stop off at all sorts of places that catch your eyes. Three of my favourites - the Black Canyon Coffee House on the West bank near Siriraj Hospital (where the King often goes for treatment) that is perched above the river with a wonderful view of boats meandering the river; the view from River View Guest House of a bend in the river (best from their rooftop restaurant at night) and the small park up along Thanon Athit, near a bunch of nice cafes.
Liked it!!. Super nice on big tail boat. Amazing. Liked everything about the ride. Big lezard on people's balconies.

great people watching. great way to get around bangkok get ferries to temples and shops connect to mrt railway cheap get on or off were you like. the large long ferries go along the river. the shorter wide boats go just from one side to the other. lots of great people watching and boats on river. night time dinner cruise on river was highlight of our three days in bangkok.

A Must Visit Attraction....!. Taking a cruise along the Chao Phraya River is one of the main attractions offered by different tour operators.The view at night is awesome.One can see a lot of important buildings on both sides of the river. Lighting on all of the buildings make them stand out and give a grandeur to the city.While you wait for the start of the cruise,thai girls in their traditional dresses welcome you and pose with you for photographs,which one can purchase for 200Bht.The food is traditional & continental both.There is music on board with singing & dancing,which makes the cruise entirely enjoyable.No matter how many times you go,every time is as enjoyable as the first.

Great fun.. Try the Oriental teak boat and have a cocktail at the hotel. Get a longboat and venture into the smaller canals where the tourist boats and ferries don't go. Take a candlelit dinner teak boat along the river - we went with Wan fan which was very good (small boat as opposed to large and impersonal one). All life is on this river. The boats go fairly frequently, you just need to suss out the blue, green and orange flags!
Best place and time : near Wat Arun at night. there is nothing there but Bangkok can't be separated with this river. See the Wat Arun from this river would give you a great experience.

Lovin' the Cruisin'. Don't let the murky brownish water put you off. The cruise up and down the tourist boat was worth the experience as a lot of Bangkok's attractions are along the river banks. And I'm especially grateful to the river boats that I don't have to take one of the confusing buses or the tuktuks and taxis that overcharge if I want to go to the Old Siam district. Some garbage can be seen floating on the river though :(
Nice place. Is easy to get lost, just a little people speak english and dont have signs for tourist information, need more
Great way to see Bangkok. Cruising up the river on the water taxis is a great way to see the city and sometimes quicker than taking a taxi.

Busy place. Lots going on on this river .Plenty of ferries at the pier . Some free ones are available to go to Asiatique, a very modern large mall wit a huge Ferris Wheel like the Eye in London.Also free ferries to the local hotels . Other boats go regularly for cheap transport or just a fun ride.

Take a relaxing trip. We took a trip from Sapphan Taksin pier - think we were probably fleeced on price, but didn't mind. You can go on 1hr or 2hr trips. The 2hr trip gives you the chance to see different parts of the city from the waterways. We enjoyed the sights, colours... and even the smells (flowers rather than what we were expecting!)

This is the way to get around Bangkok.... When we started our Indo China tour we began with a stay in Bangkok for a few days. Unknown to us there were demonstrations and protests by the yellow shirts(democrats) against the red shirts- the government, when we landed. Consequently our pre booked tour was cancelled. However the gem of a duty manager -Benz - at The Landmark hotel, found us a way round this- to avoid any processions along the roads she suggested we take take the sky train and then the canal boat to our destinations.This is how we came across a wonderful sail-along the river and we also booked a tour in the boat round the canals and the villages that still exist in the old part of Bangjkojk along the water's edge. It was SO relaxing- we were the only ones on the boat, we saw the LOVELY giant water lizard- he was massive I thought we were approaching a croc ! The people in the houses waving to us, a couple of folk trying to sell us souveniers from their boats, everyone was so friendly.We stopped off at the rickety pier and were en route to our visit of The Grand Palace etc. Sailing back was just as relaxing- seeing the huge tall skyscrapers is quite awesome, the old temples look quite pretty in comparison to all the new builds along the water edge, seeing all the variety of boats on the river is also interesting. Such a breath of fresh air away from all the bustle and pollution of the roadway system.
Great way to travel. The Phraya River boats were a great way to get around the city, jump off and on with a day pass and you see some fabulous sights.

A great experience at an affordable price for young and old and all ages in between.. The best place to start is Sathorn Taksin. This is the ‘central pier’ and you get there by taking the Silom branch of the BTS (skytrain) to “Sathorn Taksin” station then get out and walk downward towards the river…just follow the crowd downwards staying under the BTS skyrail overhead tracks. It is just a couple of hundred metres to the water’s edge and the pier head. You will see 3 short piers ahead of you. The righthand one is for chartering the longtail boat privately if you wish and have the money. Go for the central pier which has a small kiosk with 2 openings and both people speak good English.Now do not buy The” Tourist Express Boat” ticket unless you plan to be on the river all day as you can take any of the other ferries very cheaply. My wife and I took the longest ferry boat up to Nonthaburi and back which is 1.25 hours each way with about a 15 minute break at the far end. That cost us 15 bhat each plus the same for the return journey. Remember that you pay on the boat and try to sit at the outer edge of the boats for the best view. Therefore if you are late in the group boarding, we suggest, consider waiting for the next boat but do not lose you place in the queue.Despite the heat of Bangkok, averaging mid 30’s in January there is a breeze which will keep you cool but put on sunblock if you want protection.The exchange rate is about to deteriorate again but at the moment it is 50+ bhat to the UK pound and the full ferry fare is 15 bhat! Children will like this trip only if they are tall enough to see over the edge of the boat but Mum’s and Dads keep your eye on them. Perhaps the little ones could sit on your lap and get a good view however I do not think they will want to stay put for 1.25 hours each way.Buy a map (street plan before you come) or visit any branch of “Asia books” when in Bangkok and know the stops either number S… followed by a number going South or N followed by a number for North. We went north. Of course this is a very easy way to get to the Imperial Palace which is by the river although quite a walk to the entrance! This is called N9 (The Chang Ferry Pier) … if you tell the boat conductress “The Chang “ and draw N9 in the palm of your hand and even say ‘Palace’, she will understand and charge you the right amount. However you still need a map as you have to recognise when you have reached the right location.Usually when you get to a Ferry Pier there is a little interconnecting ferry to reach attractions on the other side of the river. Many of the stops are NOT near road bridges and it has been a couple of years since we used these interconnecting ferries but they should be very cheap. Beware of central Bangkok though so have a bunch of local coins in your hands when inviting the ferryman to take you across the river, do not be displaying notes! Be wise as Westerners are perceived as rich and some (not all) will see you as a target. We tell you this because you will need the ‘your interconnnecting ferry boat to cross to Wat Arun from N8 after you have been to The Imperial Palace at N9.  Area. It looks tat by day but it is very different at night.N8 is called “Thian Pier” but pronounced “Tian”. Remember to point at Wat Arun in plain sight across the river. Remember Wat Pho pronounced ‘Wat Poh’is at N8 and there is no need to cross the river…(Reclining emerald Buddha). We think that both the Imperial Palace, Wat Pho and Wat Arun are your three ‘must see’ sights….. although there are plenty of others. Remember City traffic can be frightful so take trains and the Ferries to keep the costs down and have an adventure.Now back to the ferry trip (more like a cruise). OK for the walking infirm because there is not much walking but you have to be ready at the ferry exit when it is your stop and remember these boats get packed in high season. Use the handrails. Now if you are a wheelchair user I think you are better off using a private longtail boat or arranging the trip through a travel agent who will probably charter a longtail boat for you. We still recommend the ferry experience because it is thrilling to ride the crest of the prow wave and the ever changing scenery. This trip will definitely lift your spirit. HOWEVER NOTE WE SAW NO TOILETS ON THE FERRIES so ‘go before you go’.If you are young single adult (20’s) this trip is still for you as N13 “Banglamphoo” is the area to reconnoitre your evening hotspots…clubs/bars. You just walk inland until you get to The Khao San RoadIt is is often called “Pra Artit” actually Phra Arthit but when you have done your scouting get to Phra Sumen (a little riverside fort) which is just minutes from the Ferry Pier, enjoy a brief rest in the gardens before heading back.Be blessed and go home with some wonderful memories.Kind Regards.Chris & AnnaPS Mums and Dads, space on the boat is so tight that I did not see one buggy anywhere on a boat. They may have a minimum age restriction so check on the internet before you go.

Dirty. I've travel with River Sun Cruise. The boat was good but the river makes me sick.
What a dirty river. Smells so bad.
Nothing is good with this river. Don't waste your time.

One of the Beauty in Bangkok. I must say without this Bangkok will lose its beauty. This alone can be an attraction or on the other is also one of the main mode of transport. Especially visiting Grand Palace.
toured the river at night. great meal on a dining experience of a lifetime entertainment superb not the super luxury modern boats try the ancient style boats they add charactor to the evening

Sailing with a rice bark. The river is very special; lots of beautiful sights from the water; large temples and Budha statues, the Royal palace, people living near the river etc.
We made a tour with an old rice bark which was rather special.

Vibrant and exciting. This is a great way to explore and get around in Bangkok and very affordable. A tour of the canals are really interesting and watching the scenery from the boat is a great experience. A must do when in Bangkok.

Dinner cruise Loy nava. I love dinner cruise with Loy Nava because its very intimate.It's a seated dinner and everything will be served to you unlike those buffet dinner cruise that are crowded. I think we were only more than 20 guests on the cruise. Very intimate. My hubby availed the traditional and modern Thai food and he got the premium seats (we were seated in front). Excellent customer service and the food was great too. They Los served wine and other cocktail drinks.I like the idea that they played the traditional Thai music with traditional Thai dance. Their costumes were very beautiful and intricate. We were also given close glimpse of Wat arun and the national barges museum. The dinner cruise lasted for 2hrs and 30 minutes.It was very intimate and romantic. This is what I enjoyed most during our Bangkok vacation.I definitely recommend this because I really loved this dinner cruise as my hubby's dinner date surprise for me. It's truly a wonderful experience.

The heart of the city. Use the public water taxibus service for 15 baht flat fare. Escape from the air pollution, enjoy the breeze and great views of the city. Each jetty has a number but beware, the express misses out several piers, so you need to be alert to make sure you don't miss your stop. Don't rely on counting.
Still a must do. There is lots of traffic on the river particularly near the Taksin bridge, which means its rather polluted & dirty...
Watch it for hours. Fantastic river that winds through the city. Can watch it for hours as the multitude of craft zoom around, not for the faint hearted.

Dont go to private piers! Take the bus boat!. Take the bus boat only 15 baht along the river from start to finish.Get off at any pier you want to explore, get back on the boat for another 15 baht, value for money.But if you prefer a guide telling you about the sites then take the "Tourist chao prayah express" boat costing 40 baht.
Great. Very good cruise on the river. The quality is very good and so the trip. Must see place in Bangkok visit.

Easiest and cheapest way to get around. You can easily get to most of the tourist attractions using the river. The local boats are the easiest and cheapest way to get around, you also get rewarded with a wonderful breeze and great views.

A Must. A trip up the river is a must. You can catch the public boats or hire or be part of a group. The river is so central to life in Bangkok that you must use it . its also a very convenient way to get about and very cheap if they get around to asking for a fare. The ferries can get quite busy but they are fast and frequent and open so lots of airflow

Cultural heritage along the river. For any first-timers to Bangkok, I would recommend taking a boat ride along this amazing river where early civilization first began. Take BTS Skytrain to Saphan Taksin and proceed to Oriental Pier where you can purchase boat tickets. I would suggest buying a one-day pass and board the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat. Along the river bank, one would see the way of life of the local people living in dilapidated and stilted houses, temples, famous hotels like the Oriental Hotel, etc. You'll probably need to spend a day here because along the bank, there are some famous temples like Wat Phra Kaeo (Temple of Emerald Buddha, get off at Maharaj Pier), Wat Pho (Temple of Reclining Buddha, get off at Tha Tien Pier) and Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn). There are admission fees for these temples. Wat Phra Kaeo charges 500 bahts whereas the other two 100 bahts. Besides these temples, you can stop at Rajchawong Pier to visit Chinatown and Wang Lang Pier to visit Khao San, famous for backpackers. Do spend the evening at the Asiatique, a large shopping mall where you can buy souvenirs. There are many restaurants and I would recommend a Thai restaurant called Baan Khanitha which overlooks the river. The night scene is very different from the day so spending the evening here will give you two versions.

You must try the 2 hr river cruise by longtail boat! Forget the big tour boats. If you take the longtail 2 hr cruise you are able to also travel the canals of Bangkok and get to see both the light and shade to this beautiful city. Highly recommended.

Not pretty by day but it's the best way to get around. Trains do not get you close enough to the main attractions but their river boat system is like a metro on the water for the historic tourist areas. It can be a little confusing at first but the boats stop frequently in both directions. If you stick just to the tour boats, you will be fine. It pays to get a day pass if you plan on going to 3 or more stops. The river itself is brown and dirty but being on it all day with the boats gives you a real sense of life in the area. The river bank is lined with temples and hotels to floating markets and dilapidated houses. In the night time, the river takes on an entirely different look and the views are nothing short of amazing.

Must do Bangkok experience. One of the best ways to experience Bangkok is by taking the public ferry up past the 5 star hotels to some of the most amazing temples and sights in Bangkok. Simply catch the BTS to Saphan Taksin station and it is a 2min walk to the public ferry. Once aboard the ferry why not get off at Tha Tien stop and have a look at the Grand Palace and Wat Pho (reclining buddha temple). These are both must visit attractions. Once you are finished you can walk back to the pier and pay just 3 baht for a different ferry to the opposite side of the river to have a look at Wat Arun (temple of the dawn). This should take up several hours for some and possibly a full day for others. I always do this trip at least 2 or 3 times when in Bangkok as I enjoy the river and temples so much. If so desired, you can stop off at the peninsula or shangri la hotel on your way for some truly fantastic food.

Nice way to relax-cool Off. First; don't get my average rating wrong way. I very much enjoyed our excursion on the river, the average rating mostly reflects that this is not a must do in Bangkok nor is it a major attraction for me. However, I do recommend it and believe even families with children will enjoy a tailboat ride through the canals of Bangkok. Being less adventuresome than my fellow travelers ( I envy your taking the local way of hoping on and off the tailboats and exploring), we did our site seeing as part of my city private tour. We started in the middle of the afternoon at the height of the heat/humidity and explored many of the canals along the city. Our guide not overly intrusive, pointing out famous landmarks or letting us just enjoy the breeze and sights of the city. Unlike in the US where mansions are only found along the river, the canal is the life blood of the city-- many very poor people live and work along the canal. Some only having access to the outside world via the canal. So, either be adventurous and jump on a boat like our fellow TA writers suggest, or take a nice guided tour of the river as I did as part of a tour. The evening tours are also very nice as the city is lit up at night. The boats are not for the handicap or hard to get around person- i am not very nimble and had a hard time (it was very choppy day) getting on and off. I skinned my knee getting off; but, it is well worth a trip through the real part of the city.

great experience. most of the attractions are located on either side along the length of the river.i took the one day pass (as far as i can rmember) so that i was able to hop on and hop off at every destination and i think it was worth it. i spent the entire afternoon and evening using the boat service to reach all major landmarks.the river itself was fascinating with great history as ive learnt about this river from my highschool textbook so when i got to be there for myself, it was truly amazing
Long & winding river ;p. very long river across few countriesmany places at the side of river become shops and restaurantsunfortunately i have no time to try the boat and sail along the river
Lovely way to travel. My dad loved travelling to visit the tourist sites via the Chao Praya River. It was very relaxing and gives you a different side of Bangkok.

Shangri-La. I had evening cocktails by the river in the Shangri La. A perfect end to the evening. What made it that much more special was the feeding of the fish using leftovers. Some of the koi karp were massive. I would recommend this venue.

Great Idea. Worthwhile taking the BTS to Saphan Taksin and getting the river taxi north. We took a one way journey (40Bahts each) and got off at the Grand Place. However, a one day pass for 150 Bahts will allow hop-on-off jouneyes for the whole length of the river. Great idea to see Bangkok from the river and get a cool breeze at the same time.

Busy Waterway. Either get a ticket from the Chao Phraya Riverboat service that plies the river, making stops along the way. Alternatively charter a long tail boat for one and half hours for around Baht1500 for a personal cruise through the canals, floating market, feed the carps and Wat Arun.

Lively Day & Night tour. All land marks of Bangkok are located on bank of this river. One should try night tourist tour. Travel by tourist boat and normal ferry during day time. It is a great experience. At night it is tourist fun time on live band on the boat. During day in tourist boat, you have space and time for photography. Camera is a must. Day & night photography is a good contrast. Local ferry gets you experience of local culture. Overall an Excellent activity.

Great cruise, love the sites!. This river cuts through Bangkok and is lined with fantastic buildings and monuments that present Thailand history while cruising along. I have done this cruise twice, once at night and once during the day. Better pictures during the day, but quite lovely at night. Oh, the water is dirty as the Ganges-don't drink or swim in it!
Big River. First time we took the tickets by the higher value but next time we learned that there is another little boath 15 BT... I advise you to go and experience it.

take the chao praya express. be sure not to take the boat specialy dedicated to tourists, its loud and not interesting, and their english is strange, take the locas boat, and travel the river, getting off at watt poh, watt aarrun, have cofee at the oriental hotel, and proceed to asiatique night bazar. you can also take the boat to kaoh sun road..... real great.
Evening cruise. What a beautiful river at night. Take a cruise on the river and see everything lit up. During the day to congested to see.

to visit by boat. The best and cheapest way to visit the river, is to take a normal boat with an orange flag. It sost only 30 THB, even how far you go by this boat. The river is very busy.The orange flag boat is also very easy to transport tourist from one place to another.

Heart of old Bangkok. Had a little daytime cruise / boat-trip. Was great to see the city from different perspective and imagine how Bangkok would have been when the whole city revolved around the river.

Must see - The Chao Praya River. The Chao Praya River is long and winding. You can book an expensive dinner cruise for $75 USD per person. Or take a public transportation boat for under $1 USD per person. Take an camera and water. Travel up and down the River of Kings! Amazing Thailand!

Enjoy The Breeze. If you're heading towards Asiatique, take this free boat service. Do not be alarm with the long queue and it will move very fast. While cruising Chao Phraya River, enjoy the scenery and breeze. Do not miss this experience

Sightseeing. You need not to pay expensive Chao Phraya River cruise packages to go sightseeing.You can board an Express Boat at Sathorn Pier which is few steps away from the west exit of Saphan Taksin Station of the BRT or Skytrain and get off at Tha Chang Pier to reach the Grand Palace. This trip is a sightseeing itself. Just be sure to seat or stand on the side or at the back of the boat.

Excellent Boat Trip. Took an hour to travel around the city by boat. Would recommend going about 45 minutes before sunset as it's hot out there and the setting sun will given an incredible view as the light dims.

Overwhelming. River goes up and down on level.We stayed at the Mandarin Oriental, what a treat!see all the boats up and down with people and merchandise; come at night to really enjoy it.might appear dirty on the daylight.

Love cruising on the River of Kings. Took the river taxi from the BTS station over to River City by using the mall's complimentary shuttle. Back over to the Hilton for a Macciato and then from there back to the BTS station's pier. Not the cleanest of waters but always a delight to see the interesting traffic on the river.

An experience to experience. I didn't take a tour on the river, I took the regular ferry boat that stops at numerous docks on the river. This is how the locals and a few tourist get around and you should experience it. One day I took the ferry with a friend up the river for about 45 minutes to about the end of the route at Nonthanburi. It was a great way to experience the real Bangkok. Each stop is a flurry of activity and whistle blows by the deck hands to the captian. While it may appear to be chaos, it was an amazing dance of efficiency and movement.
Beautiful. WE went to the palce via a free ferry to a place called Asiateque and the place is very nice with loads of resturants and shopping shops. Must visit

Excellent. I had a excellent time there with my family our tour guide tiger from grand alpine hotel booked the package of cruise .Dinner is included in a trip. The trip is of about 4 hours they show us the whole thailand by river its awsome there was also a music and dance on a cruise . I had memorable time want to go again.The conveinsce is also included in the package must go there.

it is the lifeline, and gives you great views. take a boat from the pier, and hop on to the chao phraya expedition. i took the local travel boat, from the canals, then change over at Saphan Taksin to board the big boat, which makes it way through the river and depicts you culture of bangkok. the view, the feel all are too amazing to be described. you cross the temples (the Wat Arun) on your left, the grand palace on the right and easiest way to reach to grand palace/khao san is through the ferry ;leh. you can also touch the sub urbs, to get real feel. do remember the pier boat station names as it many times tend to land you at the wrong pier. must visit. must try. of course there are dinner hoasted at night time. breath taking view again. the Queens is the most famous, live music, thai cuisine authentic food. jsut makes your trip better and better. in love with Bkk.

Interesting sighseeing.. It is a interesting sight and I would recommend to do it once, although be on the watch out as there are many chancers who would want to double charge you. Bargain whatever you do!

An enjoyable night river cruise ( with dinner n show). The white orchid river cruise which we joined was a good, fun experience. Food was ok and the entertainment excellent...singers were good, ladyboy dancers performed one by one and we had a good view of a few attractions/buildings along the river as we had on the top open air floor.The only unpleasant part was the disorganised waiting crowd.....no proper queves/lines. Our cruise was supposed to depart from Asiatique at 7.45 pm but when we arrived at about 7, the whole pier was crowded with people embarking on the various cruises.
River ride. Going for River ride from Ayutthaya to Bangkok. The view and weather is excellent.Food was very so so.

Great way to spend a couple of hours. If you are in Bangkok for a few days you must buy a Rabbit ticket for the SkyTrain. Saves you hours queueing for coins and tickets. Get off at Taksin and walk fifty metres down towards the river to the Saphan Taksin Ferry Terminal. Buy a half day ticket on the ferry and get off and on at stations along the river. Great way to see the sights, temples and famous streets of Bangkok. You get a map where you buy the ticket so you can easily find points of interest and where the next ferry stop is.

Chao Phraya is the nerve of Bangkok.. We took the riverbus from the pier at Saphan Taksin and went with them to the final stn and then we went back. It was a hot day so it was nice with the breeze. Very interesting to see how people live nearby the river, and many temples etc. We also hired a longtail for a roundtrip in the chanels (Klongs).

Alright.... The best of this place it is seeing Wat Arun form the boat and the River Cruise. Just take the river cruise that costs 40 Bht :) and enjoy the view... I wish though the municipality of Bangkok or the ministry of tourism could take care of this river much better as it is a very beautiful place to hang out...

A Cheap river cruise to Nonthaburi. We boarded the orange flag boat from Sathorn pier for our personal cruise to Nonthaburi for a fare of 15bht collected by an old lady with a shaking tin coin box.We were fortunate to have a Thai lady with her farang husband sitting behind giving commentary on various sites along the river to her husband as the cruise up to Nonthaburi pier.We alighted an hour later at Nonthaburi Pier but unable to locate the Rim Fung Floating restaurant for lunch.We just walked for about a km ahead from the pier and decided to stop for lunch at local eating shop selling soya sauce duck.As we were new to this town and tired to explore further,took a 6.5 Bht fare ,red non A/C bus 63 to Victory Monument .

Good boat experience. The river has a pretty good current especially during rainy season. The level can get way high that causes flood to the park around market around it. I recommend to wear good traction shoe when boarding the boat.

Best way to relax & explorer city at night. Best way to enjoy bangkok is take a cruise on this river, which will take you up the stream and back showing all the best places & major attraction while you have authentic thai food. there are various boat services which you can avail.You will get a chance to see 32+ main attractions in just 2 hrs ride.

Depressing. It is rather a canal where few boats ply and is a pure trap for tourists.
A filthy canal which has some of the top hotels on its bank isn't a great experience as expected.
Avoid this and if really looking forward to it then book the evening cruise wherein dinner too is served.

A Good Sight of Bangkok City by the River. Dislike : Ticketing and Embarking are not very systematic.
Like : Catch a good full view of Bangkok City Buildings by the river.

Nice river ride.. We took a boat shuttle service from Saphan Taksin Ferry Terminal to Asiatique. It was free of charge and we got to see amazing views of Bangkok from the boat. Make sure you get to the correct terminal if you wanna go to Asiatique by boat as there are two terminals in Saphan Taksin. One is a private cruise which is chargeable and the other are the free boat shuttles to the hotel as well as Asiatique.

So scary ride.... We took the boat from Saphan Taksin Bts station. As soon as you get off the train you can see the river right away. We were so excited to ride the boat as we heard the best way to see Bangkok City view. As soon as you get out the train you'll see that sign that say boat ride to Grand Palace, Wat Arun and Wat Po for 5o00 baht. You will then directed to get to the boat. I saw the boat a bigger one like a ferry. I sat down with my son right away but we were told to go down the boat. I looked down and see the small tiny boat below...looked a kayak boat only a little bigger with a motor. OMG..my heart start pounding because it was so low and so small and so narrow like you are riding a skate board. Well there is no even time to think because they grabbed you and rushed into the boat with the rest of the tourists. When the boat started moving I screamed as it goes so fast and it goes up due to the waves then it smack you back down not to mention the tilting left and right. OMG...It feel as like the boat would split in half and goes realllllly fassttt. I screamed the whole time and i thought that was the end of me. The driver pointed at Wat Arun but no one even bother to look as everyone holding for their lives.The ride is the longest 30 min. in my life. What's worse is there is no one single life jacket. How can you ride a boat, paid 500 baht and no life jacket? It's a joke. It's suicide riding the express boat. This is a warning. If they rush you in into this tiny boat, wave your hands and say you want the other boat/ferry. The good thing is the Grand Palace is right there when you get off boat.

Not as good as 30 years ago. 30 years ago there were not the river defences alongside that there are now and we went down lots of the klongs and got a real feel for the environment. This time we only went down one, where we stopped to buy bread and throw it to the voracious catfish, which appeared out of nowhere, it seemed. We stopped to visit one temple, which was interesting, and then the Grand Palace. Our recommendation would be that if you are only going to do one long-tail boat trip, go for the trip to the floating markets, which we did along with the Bridge over the River Kwai. It was a splendid day out - the floating markets were all colour and bustle and tremendous fun.

Best way to get to the Temples. I took small ferries (not tourist boats) from the BTS Saphan Taksin Station to Wat Arun and Wat Po & the Grand Palace. It is a convenient way to get to some of the temple sites and also offers a great view and perspective of Bangkok that you can't get from a taxi.

Great way to spend a morning. Taking a long-tail boat or even just the ferry and cruising along the chao praya is one of the best things to do in Bangkok. Really nice and especially heading into the khlongs it gives you a real sense of the old Bangkok, plus it's a great way to get the dust and grit of Bangkok out of your eyes for a while.

Best thing to do in BKK. Avoid the tourist river bus if you can. Somehow all lines tend to lead to the tourist boat and it seems impossible to catch the regular boats. Hire your own longtail and explore the klongs for a couple of hours.

meet the old town. Took the boat for 500bat( abot 16 AUD) , not cheap but worthy. We went croos the river and all of us we wer excited with the ride. We saw the temples( Without stoping ) and the old town and the life styule as well. It was a must gio ride and it is hiogly recomended.
river tour to Temples. Took a tour by boat to the temples and Wats north of BangkokA very nice day tripCame back by busMany nice gift shops along the sites

Plenty of options to enjoy the scenery. Take a short boat trip across from Wat Pho to Wat Arun, or take a longer boat ride to the other stops, or even have a dinner on a boat cruise. Any way you choose, you will enjoy the views from the river.

Interesting Dinner Cruise. Had dinner cruise with Chao Phraya Princess River Cruise on 5th Dec, Thailand Revered King's birthday. Had cruised this river during the day 2 years back via the tourist hop on, hop off boat. The dinner river cruise starts and ends at River City shopping centre. Duration is about 2 hours. Seated on upper deck with its own international buffet. Food is good and value for money. Free flow of cold water, coffee & tea. Since it is night, can see only buildings that are lighted up-hotels, Wat Arun, Wat Phra Kaew, Grand Palace. If intend to join this dinner cruise, suggest to purchase via website hotels2thailand which is much cheaper than official website. And also transport is provided from selected hotels in Bangkok from this website. Paid dinner cruise plus transport about 800baht(excluding VAT). Official website 1400baht(excluding VAT).Day cruise via tourist boat starts at the pier below Saphan Taksin BTS station. It will stop at selected piers only, esp near tourist sites. Ticket valid whole day and unlimited rides. More things to see.
It's a river...what do you want?. The Chao Praya can be a good way to get around, But it is a polluted nasty river full of garbage. Not sure why it is showing up on here for a review.

Romantic!. I booked a Chao Phraya river cruise with dinner and boy it was amazing. The float was romantic with all the great sceneries of the river and the live band playing while we leisurely travel. The food was great too!

Nice riverview in night. Take a ferry to asiatique .Fantastic views in night and excellent shopping and dining at asiatique.Rates at asiatique are surprisingly at par with night market.Fantastic food for dining.
Nice!. We hired a private longtail boat and it was great! :) our guide wasn't that good at english - but we understood a bit of it :-p

Not A Pretty River. The sights along the river were good. We got to see temples, grand palace and a beautiful skyline. However, the river was muddy and filled with trash. It spoilt the experience somewhat.

Nice Water Taxi Tourism, Affordable & Tasting Bangkok Through This River. For Asian country this river is considered clean, yes the water is brown/chocolate but the trash is not that many. You can stop at any stop you want, in front of certain hotel, in Chinatown, in Wat Po. The price is also cheap for water taxi service (public). It will cost around 50 Baht, this taxi will have speaker on it/person who will give explanation about places that we will pass by during the journey.If you only need to cross the river from1 side to another it will cost you only 5 Baht/person, ie from WatPo to Chinatown.Cheers. . .

Chao Praya Express Boat. I decided to write this separately from all the other reviews entitled "Chao Praya River" because I am talking about a very different, and decidedly non-tourist experience. Forget the long tail boats. Forget the tourist boats. You will need to look for the Chao Praya Express Boat, and it might not be easy, as you will probably be the only non-Thai on the boat. It will cost less than $1US to ride to the end of the line. Suggest you go upriver to Nonthaburi. Get off, walk 100 meters back downriver to a restaurant floating on the river. Three of us had wonderful food, several Singha beers, and all for less than $25. Then take the boat back to Central. What you will see is how the Thais actually live along the river. I lived in Bangkok and have visited multiple times. Trust me, after the temples, palaces, museums, and nightlife have swamped you, this river trip is what you will actually remember.

Bangkok is a river city. You don't typically imagine that Bangkok is a river city, but once you get on the water it's hard to think of the city any other way. The river is full of boat traffic with everything from traditional Thai longtail boats to massive multi-tugboat barges, and the city's development right up to the water's edge is interesting to watch as you pass by.We frequently travel on the Chao Phraya Express Boats ferries as a way to travel around the city; you can take the SkyTrain to the Saphan Taksin stop, and then it's about a 45 second walk to the Sathorn ferry pier (which is the main pier of the ferry service). There will be people telling you that you need to purchase a ฿150/person all-day ferry ticket, but you can ignore them; when you ignore them, they will tell you that you still need to pay ฿150 and you can't get in the boat. However, once the boat pulls up they will finally get out of the way and let you board, and it's only ฿15/person to ride the public ferry. All of the ferries travel the river flying different flags, and it's important to note the color of the flag; orange flags are the ฿15 public ferries, but blue flags are the more expensive tourist boats for ฿40/person. The ferry makes a trip down a large segment of the river, and from Sathorn you can get to Tha Tien (near the Grand Palace and Wat Pho) or Phra Arthit (the closest stop to Khao San Road). If you want to ride the river, but don't want to take the ferry, there are other options. From Saphan Taksin there are a variety of hotels across the river, and many of them offer free hotel shuttle ferries across the river; you can tell them you're staying at the hotel for a free trip, or you can grab a drink at a hotel bar and be a legitimate customer without lying. Another option is to take the ฿3 ferry from Tha Tien (near Wat Pho) across the river to Wat Arun. And, as yet another option, there are luxury dinner cruises that will take you out on the river for sunset and feed you a delicious meal.

Daytime Sighting without the Traffic. Traffic, of course, of a different kind - boats not motor vehicles. A great experience in a long boat with others whizzing by on all sides. A bit of spray to keep you cool. Having done the river by night with all its dazzling light displays, so vibrant by day. Even a trip across by public or hotel boat is worthwhile. Close by the hotel seawall you may be lucky enough to catch sight of some of the large fish inhabitants, or maybe a small frog occupying a lily pad on its way down river, as we did.
Good fun and great hop on and off. Use the local water bus transfer, cheap and day pass is great way to jump on and off. Good maps on offer you can plan your day and have fun all along the river -
River ride. A great experience for me. I have never been on any type of boat before but I felt safe and it was efficient. The water is filthy tough but it didn't bother me at all.
Mandatory. A boat ride on the Chao Phraya is a mandatory Bangkok tourist activity for a reason. It's a great way to get a glimpse river culture that most of us have no exposure to.

Lots of boat traffic. I road the boats several times and they are fine for getting to the temples and the Grand Palace. There are always lots of other boats on the river and some drivers like to show off with sprays from their propellers.

An Enjoyable Cruise to see the old side of Bangkok. It is always pleasant to cruise down the Chao Phraya River. There are a million operator of night cruises, the view is always lovely, however beware that the food they served. It is pretty much the same - horrible. So the best way to enjoy the river is to take an early morning tourist boat ride at Saphan Taksin around 9:30 am when the boats arent too crowded. It is breezy and not as hot as later on during the day. The boat ride takes about 1:30 hr the last station, then you get out and then go to the pier next door to catch a boat back. You can also hop on and off the tourist boat whenever and wherever you want. Then in the evening, go up to 360 :ounge at Millennium Hilton hotel for sunset drinks, you will get a bird's eye view of the rive, then pick a restaurant by the river to enjoy some good foodof your choice.

Chao Phraya River lets you see Bangkok with a beautiful perspective!. Chao Phraya River lets you the see this amazing city in a very beautiful perspective. This river lets you see some of the attractions, temples, bridges which are located close to the river.
