Also taking a boat on this river can help you reach your destination much faster as compared to the roads.As a tourist you must take a long boat at early morning or evening post sunset or you also have an option to take one of the river cruises. For people who prefer comfortable ride, must go for the cruise.The experience is amazing and you will love this city more :D

Watch out for the boat rental!!!. Since it my first visit to Bangkok i set my expectation for this river quite high considering how famous this river is.. I had planned my second day to visit grand palace by rent a boat to cross the river.. In my way there i had bumped into a random thailand guy who said the grand palace was closed until 12.00 pm(at that time is 10.30 am), so he recommended us to take a boat rental to get a tour by boat for 1hour while wait for the grand palace to open and he was,''generously '' get a tuk tuk for us just 20baht about 3km ride to the pier.. At the pier we had charged for 2100baht for 3person but i bargain 600baht each person and she said okay.. My expectation had been already high, but instead we get the city view, we all get trash, green moss, dirty water and slum residence along the river... So it's not even worth the money, time and energy we spent... Don't bother to even rent a boat.. It was my deepest regret while I was in Bangkok.. And FYI the closed Grand Palace is the biggest scam in Bangkok.. You better watch out!
River Tour. We did not find the longtail boat ride very interesting and would have rather spent the time doing something else, since we were only in Bangkok for one full day.

Health and Safety - forget it, but brilliant. Express ferry or as we called it - the cattle boatA 30 pence, packed tight woosh along the busiest section of river you are likely to come across - just do it.

Another side of Bangkok. If you love the metropolitan face of Bangkok, then try cruise along Chao Phraya river. It caters both the economic one as well as classy one. But the experience was amazing, where we could see the other face of Bangkok

Rip Off Alert !!!. If you want to hire a river boat from the Chang Pier (beside the Emerald Buddha Temple - Grand Palace - Wat Pho), DO NOT use the vendor which is the first on the left as you walk into the boat rental area. Our group complained of the following: The boats were worn out and in poor mechanical condition, the drivers were inexperienced; and two of the group complained that they paid for a 2 hour boat ride but were left stranded after only 50 minutes at a riverside temple. The boat driver dropped them off and did not return, leaving them stranded. This vendor is easy to locate...their stall is the very first one as you enter the pier rental boat area (on the left side). BE WARNED !!!
Best way to get around Bangkok - and avoid traffic jams. Traveling by boat is cheap, fast and pleasant: if you can get to your destination by boat, go for that option.

Must travel on. Great way to get around the City, best way to get to the temples and Grand Palace. Only 150 B for the day on the ferries and run till late into the evening. Don't be phased by the busyness of the ferries or river, only way to travel the river

Long tail boat fun. Take a long tail boat for a 80 minute trip along the river and backwaters of this amazing river which is so full of life around a thousand Baht haggle and get it a bit cheaper for a boat for two

Good to travel down and see city from the river. But can be uncomfortable.. Should do it at least once while in BKK. Especially for temple visits like Wat Arun and Wat Pho. Can see some interesting things from the river but the express boats can be extremely crowded and uncomfortable. Not bad, but not a relaxing experience!

Unhelpful staff one side of the river, great the other!. Ok so the problem we had was on the Khao San road side of the river (chang pier) the sellers are determined to get foreigners to buy the most expensive tourist tickets they can possibly push on you. Wanting to head down the river a few stops to china town we were told it would cost 600 baht for 2 people, crazy money. So we paid 3 baht pr person to get on the ferry to take us to the other side of the river, once on the other side of the river the helpful staff sold us the ticket to china town one way for 15 baht....simple.It would be helpful to have better signing coming from the Khao san road area but this im guessing is where they make a lot of their money.If you get sea sick try not to eat before because although the river itself is calm-ish, unfortunately the drivers of the boats tend to swing the boats around like a scene from fast and furious and smack the boats right into the pier sending shock waves through the boat passengers and the people about to board...Stick to your guns, know where you want to go, push for local prices and you'll have a fun boat ride!

Easy way to travel. Very easy way to travel, but be carefull so you don't buy a sightseeing ticket that cost 40 bath instead of an ordinary that cost 15 bath. But it's sad that the river is so dirty. One day it smelled very, very bad the whole day, even at the streets. It smelled dirt, dirt, dirt.

Good way to see the city. There are a few ways to do this....1,) book an organised tour on a Dao boat with tourists which is a good introduction to the river and will get you round all the major sites for a price....2.) Hire yourself a private long tail boat...(think James Bond man with the Golden Gun)...immense fun if you don't mind the speeds and waves....3.) get the river taxi service and hope on and off at various points at your own leisure....for 2.) and 3.) take your own water (and toilet paper)

Get a Longtail and a ferry. What fun....try the ferries and stand in the correct place away from the monks but with all the locals, at just 15 baht a fabulous experience. Make the effort to negotiate a deal with a Longtail boat owner to race around Pho Kret to see the pottery kilns and buy some wonderfully cheap Thai pots.

visit by boat. This is only way, the reaching various tourist attractions can be made easy. one gets ticket for this day trip and hop on and off . one should get into the general public boat that is cheap and many company operates these boats.
The metro can also be used, but using taxi is misleading and costly.

The river and the khlongs are not to be missed. To have a different feeling of the city you should take a regular ferry to go up and down the river. Sunset is a good time to do that since Wat Arun, the temple of dawn is at its best then.But what is really amazing is to take a private boat and go inside the khlongs (canals). A 2 hour visit will show you a vision of Bangkok that is hard to imagine while you are stuck in traffic or in a huge modern department store. You will see life as it must have been 40 years ago, people fishing, swimming, washing their clothes, mango and jackfruit trees, orchid and banana farms. It was my favorite thing to do 15 years ago and it still is!

Noisy and dirty water. Our guide offered a tour on a private boat which went on the main river and onto the side canals. It was pricey by Thailand standards and not worth the money. The river itself is dirty and really loud from all the boat traffic. We rode on the public boat as well and were not impressed by the views.
Sailing soon the water. Great trip on the local bus boats up and down the river, some fantastic sights, some not so but that's Bangkok.

One Of The Best. The Chao Phraya River is my favorite Bangkok attraction. I have ridden it many times in the last 30 years and lament the commercialization that has taken place. I still think the Express Taxi is the best way to travel, but there is now a large tourist boat which, of course, means you only meet tourists. It's more expensive as a day pass is required...I think. The long tail boat ride through the klongs is a hoot, but here again, it used to be better. One could hire a private boat for an our long ride at a cost of about 200 baht. But now riders are channeled into an operation that packs as many folks onto one boat as possible. Hardly fun, but profitable for them. I invite readers to tell me where these things can be avoided in today's times, as I prefer the private klong tour, and want to meet Thais on the taxis, not tourists. I'll met you soon enough!

A wonderful smelling experience.. We took a riverboat, not a tourist but a so called river bus-boat. According to us, it was more fun to go into a long boat filled with locals than a tourist boat. There are a lot of tourists who goes with this boats too. The crew operates so incredibly fast and arrival and departure goes very quickly with great precision. This was fun.

Interesting and Sad.. I took a trip down this river with a friend of mine. He was local but felt it was worth a trip and assured me its a lot quicker than taxis to get to our destination. Really nice way to see the city and something different for sure. A couple of things I noticed (Just my opinions) the river was filthy the city doesn't seem to keep it or any rubbish out of the water ..off putting . Just my 2 cents.
Dinner cruise. The river cruise while having dinner is fantastic! Tourist crowd the ferry in the buffet but the food is plenty enough for all. I like the not spicy foods and dislike the spicy ones.

Good way to see many attractions. There are ferries that go regularly but best for tourists is a special day ticket that get you on the tourist ferry. Unlike other 'tourist traps' this is well worth it -day passes are inexpensive & allow you to get on & off wherever you like along the ferry route all day. Many temples and markets are close to a lot of the ferry stops. The tourist ferry also has a multi-lingual tour guide who is very helpful at letting you know what's at each stop. Only downer is it can be very crowded and hot on the ferry (but told the tourist one is much more comfortable and less crowded than regular ferries).

Main river through Bangkok. If you like to travel boat the do the following. Take the Skytrain, hop off at Takshin station and walk down to the boat landing. CAUTION: Book the tourist ferry which costs you 40 Baht. The office is headed on the right side at the boat landing. Private boat tours at the left hand side try to get you in a private boat tour, which vcan also be nice, but the charge you 10times more.Furthermore, you can buy a all day ticket for 150Baht and the you can hop on and off at every ferry landing the whole day and the landings take you directly to all main attractions!

Drinks on the river. An absolute must in BKK is a cocktail on the boardwalk at the Oriental Hotel. It is so lovely at sundown overlooking the river. Lovely fairy lights everywhere. This was recommended to me in 1989 and I have been making this a must do every trip since.

Escape from the Roads !. The best way to get an overview of the City and escape from the hideous road traffic. All the major Temples can be seen. We were lucky that we were also offered stops at various places. The pace on the river is pretty frantic and quite exciting. Be careful not to keep your mouth open though! A mouthful of the water would definitely not be recommended !!!

Could have been better if I had seen it in the morn. Went on a nice cruise on Yok Yor Cruise Boat on the Chao Phraya River. The sights were incredible, the lighting across both sides were eye-candy and the dinner spread was mouth-watering. Wish I had an opportunity to see the river in the morning too - was too busy to get there and I guess I would regret missing it till the next visit to Bangkok ...

The review is about the dinner cruise on Chaophraya Princess-2. We chose Chaophraya Princess-2 for our dinner cruise on the Chaophraya river.The view of the Bangkok city from the cruise was one of its kind.The city looked nice in lights during the late evening.Need to mention the temple and the palace was decorated with stunning lights.But if you are looking for a romantic cruise on a river, chose any other river expect this one.The ambiance inside the cruise will resemble some old karaoke party with middle aged people eating Indian food and an Asian girl singing Indian songs(apt for a romantic dinner.)The cruise is suitable for small and big sized family dinner where people can eat and enjoying the rest of the evening singing and dancing in the cruise. The food they serve is below average, especially when u had a long day touring the city you would plan to have a pretty descent meal for dinner.Just for the sake of a river flowing through the city and the views it can offer i would recommend Chaophraya.But the cruise facilities needs to improve a lot in the food and hospitality.

Enjoyable. I enjoyed taking this as it was cheap and regular. Only problem for me is I'm a bit claustrophobic so didn't like taking it during peak times or standing in the middle of the boat. I preferred to stand near the edge of the boat near an open side panel

Good way to see the city. If you are looking to get away from the smell, the traffic and bustle of bangkok but still see the city, get on a barge up and down the river. THey are very cheap and you see a lot of the sights from the river and get a feel of the real city.

There's a lot to see. Just take you about nearly 30 ms with cheap price, a boat trip in Chao phraya river is a real experience of discovering Bangkok daily's life with unusual sight of riverside inhabitants .In the evening, there is also class boats which bring you a twinkle and live Bangkok at night. You can find many restaurants and shops along the way.

How do you rate a river?. Travelling on the river is a great way to experience the heart of Bangkok. From the scarlet and gold of the Royal Palace complex, and the temple Wats, to major hotels, shopping, and access to the klongs (canals) to see slices of everyday life.

The River of Kings. Whether you choose to take one of the River boat "buses" that ply their trade along both banks of the River, or take an evening cruise with dinner with one of the numerous cruise companies or hotels, or even if you just sit at any of the seemingly countless riverside restaurants, hotels or bars, a visit to the Chao Phraya River is well worth it.Easily accessible from the city centre of Bangkok! the sights and sounds of the River give a wonderful perspective on the life of the city and the lives of many of its inhabitants. Endless choices to select from.

Dirty Attraction. My top experiences in Bangkok were all on the river. The 1-hour long-tail ride into the canals, the crowded Chao Phraya express (the only way to get to our hotel during the protests in Old Bangkok), the Wat Arun temple, and our lovely Green Room at the Loy La Long - all on the Chao Phraya river!

The way to Travel Easy in Bangkok. Imagine the Hudson River in NYC during the 1940's; but cleaner and more colorful sites to see. The River Ferry's run every 20 minutes, and cost less than a dollar to ride anywhere along the river. I loved my entire experience along the river.

Chao phraya river. Longest river in thailand . Can go on boat trip in the evening through this river. The boat arranges food and there is live dance and music too in these boat , at the same time enjoy the lightings on the side of river while the boat is moving. Beat time is go in the evening. Then the weather will be pleasant too

Wonderful boat trip experience!. Went on a boat trip in the chao phraya river in Bangkok on my 4th day there. After all the things that I saw, It was the best so far. I recommend every traveler to visit it specially by night. We had a superb boat trip, we could see all of Bangkok beauty. After the ride we went to have dinner as you can find lots of restaurants and even shops along the way. Was worth it!

It was an experience. It was an experience watching the other boats coming so close to ours and watching people having bath in the canal full of crocodiles and other reptiles. You see big part of Bangkok on this boat.

Cheap and fast transportation. For getting a first glimpse of Bangkok and for a fast way to move in between various hotels and attractions this is a perfect way. The public boats have a very tight schedule and there are stations neat Wat Arun (you have to cross the river by ferry there) the big palace, the chinese quarter. Transport is cheap but not very comfy, the ferries are crowded and you need some moderate fitness to get into the boats. Be aware of the low ceiling of many of the stations.If you have a hotel close to the river this should be the way to go.

It's the heart of BKK -- See it!. To me, the Chao Phraya River is the "heart" of Bangkok. I rode up and down the river on the water taxi, took the Dinner Cruise at night on the river, and just watched it from River City and the Mandarin Oriental hotel. I love watching the long boats fly by with those long poles and propeller at the back of the boat.

A great boat trip. A lot of fun. Worth every minute. Just beware that when you get on the boat you make sure you are paying the cheapest price. There are a lot of boats that go to the same places for different prices. No matter what, it's a fun ride and worth the trip
Cchao Phraya. Very nice Bangkok river, with great view.With small & big ferries and many tourist round-trip boats.But dirty water. the must do something about this.

Use the Ferry!. We used the ferry with the Orange flag (= the main commuter ferry) every day. It gave us a chance to see Bangkok from the river. At 15 BHT you can opt to go from one end of the line to the other to see the entire stretch of Bangkok along the river, or use it to get to a ferry landing close to a site you want to visit. The commuter ferry is not a hop-on hop-off deal, so if you get off somewhere you'll need to pay another 15 BHT if you get back on, but it is less than the visitor ferry (Blue flag) which is 140 BHT, but does allow hop-on, hop-off.Be ready to move when you see the ferry getting close; this is no-nonsense boarding - you are expected to get on and off quickly.There are also plenty of additional ferries and water taxies running smaller stretches and going from one side of the river to the other; and there are the longtail boats which run about 1000 BHT for a one hour trip along the river - more romantic perhaps than the ferry, but the view is the same.

Great way to bypass Bangkok gridlock. We took two boat rides on the Chaophraya, one was a tour of the back channels on the west side of the river in small ferry, rides in the long boat are faster. Amazing to see the close adjacency of modern building, humble poverty and abandoned colonial estates. On another day we use the larger riverboat to ride form the end of the BST elevated train route to the doc at Golden Palace. Fast, cheap, comfortable and great sights including Wat Arun along the way.

river trip bangkok. we did a 'long boat' tour-takes about an hour and a fascinating way to see the city. A strong recommendation. Shows some poor parts of the city where residents live in corrugated shacks on stilts over the water, and market traders on boats ply their trade . Catch fish by hand , and see huge salamanders on the waterside.

get the local boat 15bht vs 150bht. it's just as comfy as the tourist boat and includes more stops and goes further up the river to Northaburi. there's no need to get off the boat as there is so much to see..how bangkok is developing..numerous temples and historic sites plus riverside shacks and locals going about their business. great overview

Best attraction in Bangkok if not elsewhere. We took the BRT to Saphan Taksin station, which is a very short walk from the river. We boarded the public ferry where for15 baht we rode to the end of the line out in the suburbs, well over an hour. We disembarked and looked around and came back.On another trip we got off half way and found ourselves in a monastery complexThe Grand Palace complex is only a few stops from Taksin station - saves you from haggling with the taxi and tuk-tuk drivers outside the palace.

best way to see the layout of the city. take a local ferry with the coloured flags for a real flavour of the heart of the city - or the tourist boat which stops at less places and is less busy generally. You get to see many of the tourist sights on both banks of this very busy river, as well as some of the underbelly with ramshackle structures used as homes clinging to the banks. I even saw a guy drop a line in and hook two fish in just a minute - probably heading straight to market or his food stall.

busy river. we took the bts down to the taksin station. from here, we boarded the red boat (15thb) for our hour long trip up the river to nonthaburi. great value for a sightseeing trip!note that at the pier there are other options for river transport - 40 thb or 140 thb - for faster methods of river travel and most likely valid for a day.this boat is a regular method of transport for many locals and also for the tourists. it was a surprisingly long boat that could carry many passengers..along the way, we saw wat arun, wat pho and various grand hotels.it was a good way to spend some time away from the crowds and the bustle of bangkok city.

Nice View for spending an evening. Went for the Chao Phraya river cruise and it was a fun ride...awesome view, nice people, good food with live music...what else do you need? It contains a good view of the overall Bangkok City as well.
day out on river. for a few hours to an hour, whatever you have time for be it dinner or a day out, on a longtail boat to a motor launch, or even a rice barge
Cool Experience. a cool experience to get on boat on Chao Phraya river.only cost 40 bath per person, a worth to try experience. love the view and the feel of the wind touch my face.

Cool way to travel. Getting around for your sight seeing, you will certainly enjoy it more using the river buses, start at Satorn pier, from the BTS Krungthon bridge. There are Blue flag boats for tourists or the orange flag boats for locals.

Quite murky water but great to see the city. When in Bangkok last year, we decided to take the regular (and cheap) taxi-boat to one end of the city - just to get a tour from the river.... It didn't disappoint as the views from the boat are amazing!! Although the river is pretty dirty looking, there are plenty of fish in the river which are pretty exciting to see as they jump up very close to the boat.
river of life. yes dont forget to take a cruise on this river. at night this river looks amazing. on this river u wil see all major attractions in bangkok.
Night lights of Bangkok. Though touristy, it is an enjoyable night river cruise on this river. The dinner fare is very good and delicious. A beautiful way to see Bangkok at night.

Take the local ferry. We were staying at a Riverside hotel so using the local ferry was ideal and the best way to get around. It’s a great way to take in life in Bangkok, it’s cooler than being in a taxi and can see the attractions as you cruising along the river. Accessible to many attractions and cheap. There is so much going on ferries, tourist boats, cargo being moved, long tail boats etc and people going about their daily lives. Along the river you will see big modern hotels, run down shacks, temples, such a contrast. I just loved watching all the activity along the river an, at night it’s equally as interesting and busy and the city looks beautiful lit up.

Not To Be Missed. Take the regular boat NOT the Tourist Boat - it's a quarter of the price. I take the 36 or 93 bus down to Si Phrayya and get the boat going right as far as Pra Pinkolao - perfect if you want to get to Kaosan Road.The boat ride takes about 20 minutes and you get to experience the real Bangkok rather than the touristy side. The boats do get crowded and you sometimes have to wait for a seat, however it is one of the joys if visiting Bangkok

Long River with Great views but still a River. We did a long tail boat ride through the Chao Praya and saw Bangkok from the river. We also went through one of the canals where there was a place where you can feed HUGE catfishes with bread for 20 baht. Enjoyed that part of the boat ride. There were so many of them that I was scared they were gonna topple the boat over! The boat was fast.. and the waters were choppy.. Scared me at first but then got used to it.

River boat - fast and easy to use. I enjoyed taking this as it was cheap and regular. Only problem for me is I'm a bit claustophobic so didn't like taking it during peak times or standing in the middle of the boat. I preferred to stand near the edge of the boat near an open side panel.
Good experience. The ferry jet on the river was so fun, you can actually see so much of thai culture, people hoppin in-out. We had so much fun

Fantastic public transport. Chao Phraya River is not only just worth seeing, it also gives you easy access to many of the attractions in Bangkok. Because of the river, I hardly notice that Bangkok is a large city. It is so simple to go by boat from Wat Pho to China town to... etc., etc. Bus, boat, skytrain – same, same, as the Thais would have said while I find the boat rides so exotic and interesting.

Many fun ways to travel a fascinating river.. Lots of hotels on the river have a free ferry shuttle that takes you to Sathon pier. From here you can link with the Skytrain and explore Central Bangkok or use the river to get to places. The public ferry 15 bhats a trip is great to visit the royal palace and reclining Buddha up river. These ferrys can be very crowded, often standing room only. Be aware where you are getting off before boarding as if in rush hour and packed like a sardine orientation may be difficult.There are various tourist boats 150 bhats or so which we didn't do as they seem to cruise the same stretch that the public ferries do.Our favourite are the long tail boats. You can do trip up river for 150bhats and experience a speedboat thrill dodging congested traffic on the river. We hired a long tail boat just to ourselves for 1 hr for 1,100 bhats. We got taken down river at speed lots of spray and bouncing on other boats wakes and the through a lock system ( flood prevention) into the western canals. Fascinating to see the life on the canals with houses of various descriptions on either bank. A more lesiurely cruise through the canal system. Slight irritation is that the log tail stopped for a small boat laden with tourist tat trying to sell stuff to you. Just be firm. Mind you I did appreciate buying two cold beers for 150 bhat. Got the log tail to drop of us at the Palace pier rather than where we started. If you are not a stickler for "health & safety" a brilliant way to see Bangkok and get a thrill ride thrown in.

Bangkok by River- The off the beaten path "hood" zoo and river houses. If you are on The Chao Phraya you must take the tributaries off the River into the Hood! Turn right before the bridge on the side opposite form the City. There is an amazing Ad Hoc Zoo. The Kamodo Dragons, Tigers and Alligators are behind chain link fence. Guys are picking up pit vipers with their mouths 3 feet from you! I forgot that you are greeted by a man putting a10 foot python on your neck saying that its good luck! I was there 7 years ago so I really hope this place is still there, either way you will get a great vie of Hood Bangkok from your long boat. Fantastic !

Vibrant and fascinating. We took the public ferry which cost all of 30 baht and travelled for an hour north to nontanburi. On the way you see the Grand Palace and a fascinating slice of Thai life as people work on and around this great river. An hour back same price and you catch life on the other side. There cannot be a cheaper or more interesting tour anywhere in the world.

River and canal cruise.Hectic and chaotic waterway,but fun.. A long tail boat trip along the river,and off up the western canal system,interesting experience on this vibrant waterway system.Not much regard given to the international collision regulations,being a professional mariner, I cringed at times at some of the vessels manoeuvres ,but all in all,an experience,keep your hands well inside the boats!

Public boats along the Chao Phraya River - best way to get around in Bangkok. We found that the best way to travel around the main attractions in Bangkok was by taking the public boats along the Chao Phraya River (only 12 to 40 baht per journey). The boat system covers all the portion of the river you are likely to need. At Saphin Taksin, change for the SkyTrain, to expand your horizons (42 baht maximum per journey). Watch for the blue or orange flagged boats - these are the cheap fares. You will either pay the fare on the boat or at your starting point, depending on the particular stop. Scenic views of temples and high end hotels as you cruise the river. Also pretty at night.

Be Careful Who You Hire. The river is just that; a river, and a somewhat dirty one at that. That being said, taking a run up or down the river is a great way to see some of the main attractions around Bangkok. My only word of caution is to check before you book a service. Not realizing there were other options, we booked a long boat tour for 2500 baht. It did seem a little steep but we hadn't planned to do a river tour today so we hadn't done any research and didn't know what was normal or fair. After the fact, we discovered there is an actual ferry that goes up and down the river stopping at fifteen different stations on the east side of the river. It only costs 30-150 baht and, as long as you aren't set on riding in a long boat, feeding fish, etc. it will allow you to see just as much as the tours. The river is what it is and, I feel, is definitely worth seeing. Just check your options and find what you really want before you pay.

Chao Phraya River Star Princess Cruise. Took a 2hr dinner cruise which started at about 7.30 pm. Good food and music. Traditional dances. Spectacular night view of some of the historical buildings from the boat. A considerable amount of dishes are halal, with certified labels (issued by Halal Committe of Thailand) attached to the name tags. Had an enjoyable time.

Quick, cheap and easy way to get around Bangkok. I've visited Bangkok many times and always spend some time on the river. I find it absolutely fascinating, and love seeing the contrast between shiny, new hotels, and little residential dwellings. There is so much to see along the Chao Phraya River and one of the best ways to see it is by ferry. These are frequent and so cheap, costing 15 baht per person. The ferry stops at all the main attractions, like Chinatown, the Emerald Buddha, the Grand Palace etc, so if you are looking to see quite a few places, this is an ideal way to get around. People complain about the river being dirty, but its all part of the experience. Yes, you will feel hot and sticky at the end of a day out on ferries, but that's what travel is about. It's about experiencing different cultures and ways of life.I highly recommend the Chao Phraya River, and all that goes along with it.

It's a choppy ride through dirty water in a long boat. My wife and I got into one of these long boats with an outsized motor for our private Chao Phraya cruise. The first thing I noticed is that they misspelled the name of the river. It should be Chaos. All these boats were zooming by, churning up the dirty water with may unidentified objects floating in it. No need to say that the boat was bobbing up and down the whole time while I tried to avoid being sprayed by the dirty water. It got a little better when the boat was in a side canal. All in all, I was glad that it was over.

to bad it's so dirty. I was surprised it was not more bad smelly as it's so dirty.there are many small river (road with water) in Bangkok.why they do not clean it sometimes. you do not know if it's oil or water. maybe you can drive with this water as it so full of oil.

A very nice and fast way to move in Bangkok. A good option to go to some of the best Bangkok's attractions without wasting time in traffic. Try to use it during the day for the temples and to have dinner in the evenings. A lot of good hotels in Bangkok are in this area and offer free shuttle to the Taksin BTS station by the river.

Little Disappointed. We went on a dinner cruise in 2004 and really loved it. This time is wasn't as good, The boat was ok but the hot food was actually cold (and I mean all of it) and the entertainment was more like a kareoke bar. Not impressed so won't be doing that again.
big river. It is a very big river. A flood seems to be sometimes caused, but feels that it is one of the Thai symbols. Famous hotels stand along the river. The water of the river is messy.
Great fun. We took a few ferries up and down the river to reach avrious destinations,a great way to see the real Bangkok.

there is no Bangkok without he Chao Phraya River. For 40 baths we can get a lot: the real feeling of Bangkok. Take the public boat transportation system and you will feel the real life of this busy city.
Take a ride. If nothing else in Bangkok take a ride up and down the river. It's an amazing voyage, a little bumpy at times too.
Best in Bangkok. I used extensively the public boats and I must say I enjoyed doing it in the mornings and evenings. So much to see of this beautiful river.

Quick ferry access to the main sights. Bangkok is so hot and steamy it is a relief to take a walk or a tuk tuk down to the river and get on the ferry which is very reasonably priced. Who wants to wait in traffic, breathing in fuel fumes when you can have a cool breeze on your face as the ferry slices through the water. You can hop off to see whatever attraction takes your fancy. From the river stations you can choose a long tail boat to take you to the various smaller klongs and see orchids farms and the people who live on the river. Just be careful that they take you back to where you started or to the main river and don't abandon you at an attraction never to be seen again. Going through the locks is something else - no space is wasted and the boats crowd in so tight that various crewmen walk across from boat to boat exchanging cigarettes, lunch and catching up on the daily happenings as the water fills. On the main Chao Praya you will see huge barges transporting enormous loads along the river, glimpse various wats and statues as well as the Grand Palace, besides other attractions. This is definitely a face of Bangkok you won't want to miss.

Great experience, worth it!. Tip: make sure you ask about the speed of the boats.Our group got stuck with the slowest man in the river, which is why 4 and not 5 stars.Stopped by the floating market to get food, and also got to release a couple of turtles and fish as the Thais do for making merit.

Great view!. Had a chance to cruise the Chao Phraya River on our way to visit the Grand Palace, Wat Arun and Wat Pho. We took the Sky train to Saphin Taksin and walked to the pier to catch the orange flagged boat. It was very confusing/frustrating at first coz we couldnt figure out where to take the boat for our destination, no signs in English to guide the tourists. We asked a few locals and helped us out, then off we go! Scenic views of temples and high end hotels as we cruise river, pretty sight.

The River of Kings is romantic, exciting, and fun. Hire a long-tail boat for a tour of the riverside area and you will experience everything from old wooded houses to modern luxury high-rise hotels. The river bustles with energy with ferries, express taxi boats, sightseeing boats, rice barges, and working tugs plying the churning water. Another world hides up the side canals where life goes on like it did scores of years ago.For the ultimate adrenaline high, hire a small, short, flat-bottomed long-tail to bounce you up the river at fast speeds. You won't forget the experience.Visitors who go to Bangkok and don't visit the river are missing one of the things that makes Bangkok special.
Full of life. It is well worth just taking a boat up and down the river. The Chao Praya express runs often.It is a busy river and will take you to some of the tourist sites.

Heart of the City. Admittedly its not the cleanest stretch of water on the planet, but it exemplifies that which is Bangkok; frantic, atmospheric, totally Asian & terrific fun to be on.....but not in! Hire one of the long-tail boats and get the driver to take you on a ride along the river and also into the backwaters [the Klongs] which stray off the main waterway. Here you can still glimpse Thai life as it exists on a daily basis, untouched by the influences of cosmopolitan lifestyle and the Tourist buck. If James Bond has done it and lived, so can you!

Huge river. Been there via Saphin Taksin BTS and took the 1-day pass tour for the river cruise.There was a friendly tour guide from the boat who makes us laugh and with all the information from him regarding the famous and historical places to visit.Worth to sit the tourist 1-day boat pass,simply a good experience!

Quick, comfy and cheap. We just took the normal ferry that the locals take to and fro from the work place to their homes. We took a BTS train till Saphan Takshin and then got down and walked to the pier (5mins). Then we got a ticket to Phra Athit as that was closer to China Town and Khao San areas which we wanted to check out. The boats are basic with hard seating and can get crowded between 5-7 pm. The water ways have hotels and posh tall condos. It’s a peaceful and relaxing way to spend time and is very economical to get to areas which are not covered by the BTS/MRT network. I guess we paid only around 20baht or so per person.

Ok but not worth the money. We did this at night on the White Orchrid dinner cruise. Being on the river at night was great but the dinner cruise was lacking. The food was below average and the entertainment was a joke. Thank goodness we did I've cruise with good friends it made the night.

Small cruize is best. Hire a small long boat from near the Shangri-la hotel by the river - be careful not to geted duped. Bankok is notorious for swindlers who are polite as punch !! Ask to be taken to feed the fish place on the river and then to wat Arun fo half hour and then back to the jetty.

Wonderful cruising experience.. Me & my family had a wonderful cruising experience. The view & scenery was good. Feeding the giant fishes were awesome. Whoever travelling to Bangkok, cruising in Chao Phraya River is not to be missed.

cheap river cruise for 150baht. The cruise starts at central pier (2 minutes walk from Saphan taksin BTS station). It stops at 9 piers which is the locations for some major attractions like chinatown, little india, wat po, wat arun and golden palace. You just hop in and out of the ferries as they come and go along the river piers. very convenient and definitely a must do for a first timer to Bangkok
Orange flag boats. Easy to get the local boats and pay just 15 THB each per trip rather than 40 THB each on the Tourist boats

night Vs day. I went to a river cruise dinner on Chao Phraya River which was awesome. The lighting on both the sides of the river was very charming at night. I also traveled by Orange flag boat from central pier to Tha Tien Pier and from Tha Chang Pier to Pier 5 at day time on Chao Phraya River which was also an awesome experience. The crowd on the boat, the ticket system, the wave of the river - all were very close to earth and I liked it very much.

must see and do. Time in Bangkok to spare, a must do is a trip on the river. Take the skytrain to Taksin station which is right on the river at the main pier. From there catch a local ferry to the end of the run and return for a few baht. Catch a free boat to any of the main hotels for a coffee, the boats are marked which hotel they belong to, pick one the furtherest away from the pier. Maps are on the pier. Do a regular tourist run of an hour or so or even a half day with commentary etc. Options are limitless and depends on the time you have. The river was the main travel centre of action however with the building of bridges the river traffic is not as hectic as it used to be but still considerable and certainly worth some time there, even if only to sit on the pier for awhile and watch what goes on. Suitable for families with kids.

a working river 24/7. we stayed at chatrium riverside in a corner apartment with a huge balcony and floor to ceiling glass windows where we could watch this exciting working river 24/7. tug boats, ferry's, longtails all sorts of craft and activity including fishing and swimming. get on the local or tourist ferries and explore this fantastic river.

Nice Way To See Bangkok. The Chao Phraya river is a major part of the Bangkok landscape and is used by locals for many different reasons. Many of the landmark temples are located on or near the river and there are ferries whose only purposes is to ferry people from one side of the river to the other (for just a few cents).There is a ferry that traverses the river for a lot of it's length through Bangkok with orange flags that stops several times and for which the fare is 15 Baht and is paid to the lady on board. This is a great option for tourists that don't want to go to the expenses of a private longboat tour but still want to get a sense of Bangkok from the river.

Traveled the river with $1 and it was fun. I took the BTS to Taksin station and arrived at central boat station.Took the orange flag (i.e. cheap line for locals) for 15BHT (you pay inside the boat). Once you are in the boat you can travel to the last (northern) station on the river. But that would take perhaps 1-1.5 hours. The return path is the same and costs 15 BHT. If you feel board or tired, find a suitable station in the middle (which has seats etc.) and wait there for another orange flag boat to bring you back.All in all, it was a fun travel, I could see the city, temples and people for a mere $1. What more could I want?

Take A Ride On The River. Were in Bangkok recently and hired a private boat to take us on a tour of the River.It was very interesting as you get to see how life is on this river and most of the sights of the city.

Catch the ordinary ferry. We used the ferry quite a few times - straight off the Skytrain to the ferry. They tried to steer us onto the "tourist ferry" which went to the same places but cost more. Used this transport to get to Khao San Road, Chinatown, and Nonthaburi. Lovely tranquil ride down the river for about $1. (don't travel during peak times though - not pleasant)

Best way to get around (Low Price). Great transportation to/from all the tourist hotspots. Some of the hotels provide free transportation to certain locations (i.e.: evening transport to/from the Night Market), or you can get on a tourist boat with all day on/off privileges for 150 BHT - what a deal!

Must Do. To tour on the Chao Phraya River is a must-do but rather than spend unnecessary big baht to tour agencies, just go to Central Pier and pay a small proportion of the price to have a tour of the river. You do share the ferry with regular commuters (mainly tourists) but its a cheap and better alternative and you also get a running commentary of the landmarks of Bangkok. Its a good way to get a river view of Bangkok.

Good Food Good Ambience. We're joining the Chao Phraya River Cruise, the foods were really good! While you have dinner you can see the nice places along the river at night, really beautiful scenes. And also they provide with live music and you can also dance there.

Transportation with a view. WE took the boat the locals use to Wat Pho. Then the ferry across the river to Wat Arun for a few cents. When we returned to Wat Pho side we accidentally got the boat going to wrong way. We decided to stay o for the ride. After riding an hour we decided we had better turn back so we got off and with in minutes caught a boat in the other directions. All boats with Orange flag were non tourist boats. The boat for any distance costs 15 baht and a woman comes through shaking a container and you pay her.We met some interesting people in our river travels also

Travelling is a breeze.. First I would like to encourage visitors to try the Chao Phraya River Express Boat Service.It is not only economical but you can also take good pictures at most of the pier stations. These pictures you could hardly taken them if you are travelling on land.You will also feel the warmth and homage when you took the ferry with the locals. You will feel like you are a local too.The only disadvantage is that you have to understand the different colour flags of the boat that they are plying the routes. They are sharing the same berth so you need to be very careful not to board the wrong colour flag boats

A don't miss.. Like all great cities, its life can be seen on the river. Find a bar and watch life go by. A river boat trip, both during the day and at night present two distinct views of this vibrant metropolise. All the lights of the city temples can be seen in Thai splendour.

Great experience. Do not hesitate to take the public transportation along the river. Private boats are not better, and much more expensive. Learn how to take the orange, yellow or blue flags boats in the "piers".
Appart from nice and an experience by itself, it is cheap and very fast for moving within Bangkok.

Living Hell. Take this river bus from end to end and count all the different types of pollutants floating by. Watch monks throw garbage in their sacred river. See environmental destruction like no where else on Earth

Worth The Effort. Take a ferry from Saphan Thaksin to get a great view of the city, Wat Arun looks fantastic when it's lit up at night. A full day pass for the ferries will be around 140baht - great value.

Very muddy and rough river around Bangkok. Did a trip in long boat of a section of river near Bangkok and it was not a great look of a day time, we will be doing a dinner cruise before we leave as we have been told it is good experience by some people, will let you know afterwards. The long boat then took us through the canal area and I would not recommend this part to anyone, a good section of the canals stank and the water looked stagnant with dead fish floating.

"Sit, watch and wonder". Thanks to Bangkok's many riverside restaurants the river traffic provides a continuous show for the serial beer drinker. For added fun try a river express boat to the end of the line and back again. And you could always spend too much and have dinner on a tourist cruise boat...

Nice ride. Its nice & it can be both a picnic & a kode of transportaion to go to the grand palance & the temple of dawn, use the public furry costs 40 baht, some will try to rob you & convince yiu with a private boat that costs 1000 baht, it isnt worth it

main water way. This is the main river in Bangkok. From this river you can travel up and down Thailand and see the the major hotels and sights of the city. Their is a lot of action on the river, and it is fun to take the water taxi and get off at any stop and wander around, and then get back on. very cheap way to see Bangkok.

The river that represents Bangkok. This is the river that cuts across Bangkok and early days, the thais use this river to transport merchandise around. I understand that the river has been cleaned but somehow, I still notice that there is a stench. Many small cruises operate on this river which serve dinner (Buffet) while cruising along the river at night. Wat arun and the various tourist spots can be seen while cruising along this river.

Try once to understand how locals travel. In Bangkok. this is the preferred mode of transport for the locals as I believed that had no been recorded incidents of traffic jam in a canal. Don't take the tourist boat as it is overcharging and run the same route as the boat which locals take. Use it to get to the Grand Palace and enjoy the scenery along the way. Do be careful of the water splashing up as you wouldn't really want to know what is in that river. Hope you have a fun time.

A cheap way to explore the city. amazing but time goes by the river is not clean but one thing it's not smelly...the water is dark but its ok, you can reach different places in bkk and one thing its cheap...

Boat Ride on Chao Phraya. When you walk to the ticket counter, you will be offered 150baht per pax all day round trip fare. So if you are only planning one way, just buy the normal ticket. From Saphan Taksin to Pier 9 Grand Palace is only 40 baht per pax. Just ask and ask !

A must do. No trip to Bangkok is complete without having a long tail ride up the Chao Praya river and through the inlets. The river is not that clean, the shanties by the river not marvelous but it gives you and idea of the culture and how some people live.
The lifeblood of Bangkok. A trip across the river on Tha Tien ferry is worth doing. You see how much life there is on this river. Fascinating place to be.
the action never ends. could spend days just watching the various watercraft moving in every direction, up, down, sideways; barges, luxury craft, party boats, ferries, you name it, it's there

Great River. This river is almost essential to travel on since the metro system only crosses the river in one place so the river is a great way to attraction hop. You can take a longtail boat, a tourist ferry, a regular ferry, or a water taxi. The regular ferry and the tourist ferry are both inexpensive (around 40 baht per person), but if you're not sure what you're doing as you approach the ferry building someone will try to scam you into paying 250 baht for a water taxi...swearing uphill and down dale that it is the river ferry! Out of all of the modes of river transport, my favorite is the tourist ferry....it's cheap and there is commentary in English on all the buildings along the river. In the late afternoon the river breeze is lovely so after a hot day sightseeing it's good to get on the ferry, grab a seat and relax. Lots of interesting buildings to see and even more interesting boats to look at. Great way to travel in Bangkok.
Amazing experience. Taking a long-tail boat is the best way to see how people live along the river. It gives you a real sense of life in Bangkok away from the high-rise hotels and malls.
Ok for a look but stinky. We went for a look and it was nice to see the old style boats floating around- we had planned to go out for a ride but it was too stinky and dirty looking.
River boat ride. Something different to cross the river, we have used the boat, instead of the bridge. Fancy view on both sides of the river.
Best view of Bangkok. I fyou would like to take a look of Bangkok City, Cha Phraya River is the most famous river that you must come to see and travel along this river to sightseeing around.

Use the transport. A day or night cruise on the Chao Phraya river is on every single Bangkok to do list you can find. If you around the river area you will come across locals offering you hour or so tours in a long tail boats for 1600 Baht and above. Get yourself a local transport map and get to one of the many jetties, hop on on of the many public transport boats and a conductor will ask you for about 20 Baht. When you have had enough hop off have a look around where you are then hop back on another boat going the other way. Simple and very very cheep

Great way to see Thailand!. The tickets are cheap and the ferry can take you virtually anywhere you want to go in Bangkok! Love it! Easy, efficient and affordable. Use it as much as you can and save on the scams waiting around the corner lol

Nice evening dinner cruise. We took the evening dinner cruise. The liner was neat, well decorated and the dinner spread was a surprise with Indian food. As vegetarians, we had good choice. The entertainement was also good. The night time ride on the river was breathtaking with many photo opportunities.

Busy. If you are looking to use the river as a way to get around in Bangkok the boat service is quite efficient, but as everything in Bangkok these days the river too is becoming a tourist trapPrepared to stand on the boats

great way to see parts of Bangkok. We have cruised the river a number of times now. We generally take the tourist boat as it only cost 40 THB per person per trip. If you are planning to get on and off numerous times, consider a day pass at around 150 THB each.A round trip takes a about 90 minutes. It will take you to Chinatown, the Grand Palace and a number of other significant Wats. The last time we wnet out, the river was flowing quickly after heavy rains up north but it did not present a problem to the river boat operators. At night, you can also get a boat to Asiatique but that is for another review...
take a cruise look a bangkok. I have take a cruise and have dinner with my girl friend look very simple but she like it. so sweet. good wind

Boat Ride. Brilliant experience, get on a boat and it will take you to one of the temples and show you how people live on the river. We loved it but we were a bit worry about how dirty the water was :(

cruise on the river. we booked for the cruise on the river with chao praya .we were picked up from the hotel at 6 pm but the traffic and distance was just killing.we reached the cruise at 7.30pm and there were just too many people,it was uncomfortable .once the cruise began we had a crooner who bombarded with constant singing,the music was too loud and nonstop.the food was good but scramble for the same.the river is beautiful and the sights on the banks were mystifying but overall we did not really relish this.tourists should take the smaller cruises and without the noise.

Must Do Chao Phraya River. Just got back from Bangkok. During this trip, I did the Chao Phraya river cruise with the local express boat (not the tourist express which cost THB150 per day). Board the orange boat at Central Pier (Saphan Taksin BTS station). Pay THB15 and take the boat up north until Nonthaburi (final stop for the orange boat). The whole journey takes about an hour. You may walk around the town. Then take the boat back to Central Pier for another THB15. Time your journey that the return trip leaves Nonthaburi at about 6.00-6.15pm. By this time, the buildings/temples and bridges along the river would have been lighted up and gives opportunities for some great photography. Cost only THB30 but an amazing experience. Highly recommended.

Best 17 baht you can ever spend!. Every time I come to Bangkok, I always make time to take the ordinary express boat (not the tourist boat) from the central jetty near the BTS station up to the end of the line (about an hour or so) where I hop off for a drink or lunch.There is just so much happening on the river - it's always fascinating and fun.Don't miss this all-time bargain!
Long tail boat. Get a glimpse of the real Bangkok. People bathing, fishing, washing clothes, varans sitting on the riverside.

Evening Dinner Cruise. If you get the chance take an evening river cruise which can be booked from most hotels and enjoy stunning views of the Grand Palace at night and temple of dawn. Evening includes a lovely meal and very good entertainment.

Scammed into it, but ended up enjoying it. Some guys told my friend and I that they could show us the entire city from there small boat. It ended up being a tourist trap and not getting to spend time looking at temples as we would have liked. The river tour cost around 600 baht when it probably should have been around 200. It ended up being a pretty fun adventure , despite the fact I lost about $15 USD

This is a MUST!. This used to be the main mode of the transportation in the heart of this kingdom. We had to travel from Sathorn Pier to take the boat ferry. It will pass by some of the hot spots like Wat Arun and right opposite of the bank of the river to get to the Grand Palace. We tried taking a night river cruise ( with nice buffet dinner with good live-band entertainment) You shouldn't miss this. Both trip in the day and night is very different. Especially the night river cruise when passing those sites. Great scenes too.
Very Scary if river is rough. People use it for daily commute. Since the river was very rough last week, the trip was s bit scary. Otherwise i think it should be a nice way to see the city.

Very convenient, quick, and cheap in bangkok. Its website is very informative..there are a lot of armada so you don't have to wait long for one boat..the price is cheap although for long distance..the boat is clean and convenient..it covers a lot of tourist places with its routes..I will definitely use this river and service again when I go to bangkok next time..

Great boat ride!. We travelled on the local ( cheaper) boats and also on the tourist boats . Both have their plus points - fun to travel with the local and enjoy the hustle and bustle of life but more comfortable on the tourist boat especially if you want to take photos- still in reality cheap at 40 bhat

Always something different to see on this busy river. From 5 star hotels to small shacks. The river is a great place. The river is a great place to spend some time. From 5 star hotels to little shacks . There is always something different to see. Especially at night when the temples are lit up and the bridges too. Take a tourist oat and yo will get a running commentary on what to see and where to stop.

Floating market, Chao Phraya River. Its a pale remnant of what it used to be. Now, its just a few vendors paddling their sampans, coming alongside your boat to sell you the usual tourist souveniers.Spend your time elsewhere.

Great boat ride!. We took a 3 hour boat cruise along this river, riding past the Grand Palace, many sky-scrapers, poor ramshackled houses, boat people, and many water-lilies! Very interesting, friendly tour guide, lots to see and look at, but once done, probably not again.

Travel with the. Locals. I travelled on the express boat, there is a tourist. Boat yo can buy a ticket for, but I preferred the pay on. Board, very cheap and very crowded, and you. Need to be quick on your feet, but great fun

River of Kings. Thailand’s mighty Chao Phraya, “The River of Kings”, flows from the northern central plains to the Gulf of Thailand. One of the best ways of sightseeing is from the water, and seeing Bangkok from its river is no exception.Possibly the easiest way to explore the Chao Phraya is by getting the excellent BTS/Skytrain to Saphan Taksin stop, and taking a Chao Phraya River Express boat from the nearby pier. This is a great way to get to the Grand Palace (get off at Tha Chang) and far quicker than sitting in Bangkok’s treacly traffic. Fares are cheap, but you need to know when to get off if wishing to visit other attractions. The Express boats go at a fair clip, so be aware of swallowing any spray from the polluted river.While river cruises are touristy, they provide a brief overview of the bustling waterway. You will see history, from ancient teak rice barges and colonial buildings to modern skyscrapers. A klong (canal) cruise offers a glimpse of the rapidly disappearing klong-dwellers on the west (Thonburi) bank. It was the klongs that gave Bangkok the epithet ‘The Venice of the East’. A totally different experience is to take a dinner cruise. These can vary in quality, so choose carefully and in fine weather, ensure you get a top deck table as these offer the best views of this exotic city.

City tempo on the Chaopraya river. No one should leave the city of angels without taking at least one trip on this amazing river.The Chaopraya river originates in central Thailand north of Bangkok and connects to the gulf of Thailand some 384 Km later.The river is a main vain of transportation for cargo and passengers.Avoid the commercialized tourist cruise boat. They charge you 150 Baht daily free rides.Practically you will take 2-3 trips at most.Instead hop on one of the numerous river boats with an orange flag. The fee is 15 Baht regardless of the distance. There is a pier at any important place of interest along the central part of Bangkok.You can stop by Kaosan road, Pinklao bridge, Grand palace, Reclining Budha temple, The temple of Dawn (you will take the ferry, 3 Baht, to cross the river), Memorial bridge, China town, Oriental hotel and The bridge of Thaksin (Sky train station).It is a wonderful opportunity to feel the heart beat of Bangkok and mingle with the locals.

boat ride along the Chao Phraya river. There ia a new Chao Phraya tourist boat service that starts from the central pier ( sathorn pier). Take the BTS skytrain to saphan taksin station and exit to the pier. single trip is 40 baht regardless of how many stops. can be quite expensive if you stop at every pier. common stop would be Tha Tien Pier. then take a cross river ferry to Wat Arun. next common is Rajawongse (at chinatown). the boats run every half an hour either way.

Great way to see the city. 150 baht for unlimited travel all day which includes all the river boats and not just the tourist one, the tourist boat comes with an English speaking guide who points out various sights along the river, 40 baht if you just want a one way trip, Interchanges with the BTS at Saphan Taksin station on the Silom line, really regret not spending a day just on the river but there's always next time.

You can NEVER get enough of Bangkok..... After 5 visits to BKK and 8 different hotels, cant wait to get back again...We like to stay near the river its so interesting to watch. How do they manoeuvre those crazy long boats with a V8 engine on a stick ?!! Fantastic. Had many rides on the river...yes its not clear like the waters of the Bahamas, but its teaming with life. And all those interesting tributaries...what a place....No wonder its the River of Kings.

Dinner Cruise With Loy Nava. We did the 6pm dinner cruise with Loy Nava. They have smaller more intimate wooden boats with table service rather than buffet style. They picked us up at the pier of our hotel (Milennium Hilton) which was very convenient. The food and drink was good quality and tasty. A woman played soft Thai music on a stringed instrument throughout the cruise which was nice and soothing compared to the blaring music and flashing lights we saw on the larger boats we passed. Two others performed a couple of traditional dances too.The staff gave us a "menu" with all the sights listed and a blurb about each one. As we passed each point of interest they told us which number on the list to refer to. It was fun! I would recommend this cruise for those preferring a quieter experience.

Great way to get around. I've taken a boat to go up river many times. It is a great way to see many of the attractions Bangkok has to offer in a short time. It is also the way to get to the Old City. A must if you really want to know the history of Thailand.

A busy waterway. We enjoyed our stay along the river at the Anantara Resort. All of the large hotels have water taxis that transport you to shopping and boats on the other side of the river. We bought a day pass for about $5.00 and took a 3 hour trip down the river, sightseeing. You can get on and off as much as you like. It was interesting to see so many different boats moving people and cargo.

River transport. You can travel with the ferrys for a day long with one ticket. With your day pass you can hop on and off the ferrys and visit markets, temples and other sites along the river. With your ticket you also receive a map of the river with the stops, as well as a list of places you can visit! There is a train station close to one of the ferry stations, so you can travel to the river by train and catch a ferry!

Exciting!. Wow, I took a long-boat ride to a Thai cooking class on this river. Waiting for the lock to open so that we could go through was exciting. I saw something that looked like a large alligator laying on the tile floor of someone's patio (?) as we rode past. Also saw some beautiful species of birds. However, the river is pollutted.

Do what the locals do.. Easy to get around. Atleast once you gotta try going down the Chao Phraya River. Used the ferries to get to the temples.However, unfortunately i have an irregular fear of things that creak. And all of the piers creaked a lot :S But that's just me.

Wide and interesting river. The river is so deep,long and wide,it is brown and looks like dirty,but it is interesting because we can go to some famous places in Bangkok through this river. It helps us so much from traffic Bangkok. Public boat it costs cheap,it is different with chao praya cruise, you can pay when you already boarded on boat,eventhough it is cheap but it is safety and comfortable. And you can have dinner on chao praya cruise, some travel agents offer some prices for that.

A must-do for any stay in Bangkok. Get out there and see it all, especially at night. Great views and a totally different perspective on Bangkook, a nice relaxing way to experience a very busy and often congested city. Avoid the longtail boats and stick to the local or Tourist ferry - 150Bht for a day pass. Don't pay more!

memorable experience. While a tourist ferry is cheaper a private tour makes all the sense if you want a wonderful time. The sightseeing was wonderful including the views of grand palace, wat arun. We actually got surprised to see a different way of living and the lifestyle of people living by the river and the bustling activity around and even on the river. lots of photographic sites especially the lifestyle photography. you can feed the fishes. boats zipping past yours, barges moving slowly, floating restaurants, lavish cruises, soaring buildings all seem like a great experience.

Be careful to get the right ticket for the River Ferry!. When you get your ticket, don't bother going to the booths to get the tourist ticket - just hop on ANY of the flagged boats, and you pay on the boat (usually 3 bht (yes really) per section of the river. We found the tourist ticket extremely poor value for money.

The heart of Bangkok. The journey along the Chao Phrya river depends on the time of the day, morning and evening Chao Phrya is lively with school children, parents, people of all ages using the river as a mode of tranportation. Late morning to afteroon, here come the tourist boats, then evening-there are many of dinner cruises along the river. Chao Phrya is most charming when it is on high tide and on the full moon day. Cruise inbound to see The Temple of Dawn at night, it is very stunning. At night time, there are many nice Catholic Churchs and lovely restuarants, beautiful world-class hotels includes the legendary -Oriental Hotel. The best night to see Chao Phraya is on "Loy Krathong Day" (Full moon festival, this year will fall on Sunday 17th Nov, 2014 will be on 7 Nov).

A must in Bangkok!!. I love travelling along the river in Bangkok and try to experience it as many times as possible. I have used the tourist express boat. I have traveled on a the local commuter boats and I have also used hotel transport and been on dinner cruises. I never get sick of the river and the ever changing landscape. Buildings coming down, buildings going up. Going from Central Pier at the Saphan Taksin BTS stop you will have a number of options. Long tail boat or the tourist boat etc. If you do not get a ticket at the counter you can pay once you are on-board. Keep some small change with you. Depending which boat you take the trip can cost 18Baht ++ depending on where you are travelling to, the tourist boat is more expensive but when I say more expensive I mean by a few cents not dollars.

Pier hopping the River of Kings. Whenever you find yourself tired of all the touristic places in Bangkok just jump into an express boat in the Chao Phraya, get off at a random pier and explore. You won't regret it. Full review at http://www.lifesauntering.com/2013/10/chao-phraya-pier-hopping-river-of-kings.html

Bangkok River. There are several ways to travel on Chao Phraya River, by public ferry, tourist ferry or by a private long boat. We have done all three and found the long boat the best. The tourist ferry is very crowded and has a guide (with a microphone) telling you what you are looking at. It is noisy and distracts from what you can see but does stop at all the main attractions along the river. The public ferry only takes you to certain docks and can be confusing without a local guide but a private tour in a long boat will stop wherever you want and is a bit quieter although more expensive. The sights along the river are wonderful and give a good insight into Bangkok and its opulence and its not so opulent. Well worth an hour or two and a easy way to bet the traffic when visiting Wat Arun, Wat Poh or the Grand Palace or Chinatown.

A must see when visiting Bangkok!. This was our second trip along the Chao Phraya river, as we enjoyed it so much the first time. This time we actually toured along the houses where locals live on the water and the sights were amazing. You can buy souvenirs, chicken satay and also bread to feed the many large fish that swim near the surface, from the passing boats. Just make sure you hold on tight, as the boats zip along quite fast and the water can be choppy!

Bustling Boats Bob Daily on Chao Phraya River. I never tire of watching the "symphony-without-a-conductor" that plays out daily on the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok. Barges, tugs, water taxis, pleasure craft, hotel ferries, sightseeing boats, police speedboats, long-tailed canoes, and floating restaurants are just some of the many vessels plying the waters of this fascinating river.Suggestion--take the BTS to Saphan Taksin stop, walk 100 meters toward the river, and board one of the free hotel boats to get a feel for the river. Then, if (like me) you are hooked, get on one of the water taxis going north to the Grand Palace (or further) for a few baht (~25). It will be a very inexpensive trip, but certainly entertaining.

Easy access to many exciting destinations. I purposely chose a hotel near the Chao Phraya River because I want a river view with the tall buildings in a picture I saw and also to save time on traveling. Traveling from one area to another is much more faster than taking a taxi or a bus and less costly too. It is also the fastest route to major tourist destinations like the temples (Wat Arun and Wat Po), Asiatique, etc. The dinner cruise along the river is really nice and gives you a golden view of the Wat Arun Temple at night.The water is muddy brown and luckily it doesn't smell like a stinky canal. The boats are constructed well, maybe crowded at times but looks safe for me.Some boats causes the river water to splash on you so stay in an area where the water doesn't reach you especially when it's running fast.

Chao phraya river is a must. We stayed in bangkok hotel right on the river fantastic sight at night and really good ferry service through the day we used it to go to the grand palace and seen some fantastic sights on the way really cheap and easy to use just pay when you get on there is a ticket lady sells tickets on board.

Must do, but be careful with the scammers. I prepared heavily to tour Bangkok, and built my knowledge on the common tourist's scams going on. There are some scams you can't stay away from, and this is one of them. I told my taxi driver I wanted to go to the jetti where the water taxi (public) docks. He off course took me to the river tour company that gives him an incentive for bringing tourist. I knew that this tour was way overpriced and wanted to go with the public water taxi. The problem, it was way too far to walk there. We started walking there, but got to the "wrong jetti" according to the attendant. Everyone keeps pointing you at the overpriced tour company (organized scam). Well, my time there was way more valuable than the money I was going to throw away, therefore we took the river tour with that company.There is no better way to see BKK. You will see the entire river front to include the Temple of the Dawn, a small floating market, the Navy base, a slum area (worth seeing) etc. Plan for an hour or so, and specify where do you want to be dropped off. No need to go back to the originating point.

The first thing to do when arrive to Bangkok. My suggestion is to start to discover Bangkok through a boat ride on the Chao Phraya River. Buy a ticket One Day River Pass at the Chao Praya River Tourist Boat for 150 baht/person. It is the best way to visit some monuments such as Wat Pho, The Grand Palace, Wat Phra Kaeo and Wat Arun my favorites, plus enjoy a beautiful ride on the river.

Pleased to have seen it once but will not be returning.. I am pleased to to put it on my list of "been there, done that" but will not be returning it is amazing the speed of the river and the traffic takes some believing but it really is very dirty, the ferry however is very reasonable at 150 baht for the day which includes a guide but again watch out for the con-men.

Busy river. Chao Phraya River is a busy river. Take a cruise along this river then you can see the beauty of the Wat in this City of Angels. The river is considered clean, no funny smells and dirty trashed. It was not getting the WOW out of me, yet it was still considered worth a cruise.

An beautiful river spoilt by severe pollution. I love the fact that Thailand used to be called The Venice of the east The basics still exist there are some nice Klong but most are polluted and overgrown. Its a shame that its lost that title On the river boats wear a mask and be prepared to have a gas . I believe that this will change . there is a concern about pollution and slowly its getting better.

Long boat excursion. Hi , we went on one of the long boats that you can hire at the side of the river usually beside the public transport boats. All in all the trip lasted around 1hr maybe slightly longer , the river itself was a bit on the Choppy side the day we went , the boat itself was pretty big and the four of us had plenty room to turn around and enjoy the views. I can't remember the price that we were charged but I know it wasn't expensive. After entering the canals that are off the river the scenery changes and you get a good insight to river living of the locals and also got great views of the temples that are littered along the length of the canals , feeding the fish was also good , expect the boat your on to pull up beside a local vendor on a smaller boat selling beer and food and trying to flog you fish food. All in id say it's great value and very interesting.

Cheap fast and easy. Cheap fast and easy. Stay away from the tourist-traps if you want to keep it that way. If a tuktuk is nice and wants to help you to the harbor, they sometimes drives you to an overprices touristboat instead.
Cruise and dinner on River boat Loy Nava cruise. Nice way to see the sights from the river. Dinner is fairly good. Guide speaks excellent English. It is a rice barge converted for sight seeing.

Koh Kret. On a Sunday there is a ferry ride that runs from Silom to the island of Koh Kret. It stops to pick up passengers on he Chaopraya River. Most landings sell tickets and will phone for the boat to pick you up if it is not a normally designated stop. The boat stops off on the way at a well known wat where you can feed the cat fish in the river and the wat gardens make for a nice stroll about. After about an hour the boat continues upriver to Koh Kret.Koh Kret is an island that has a long history of pottery making. Wandering around the kilns and watching the production process is interesting and photogenic opportunities are there if you look for them. The island people seem very friendly and walking the small lanes will take you through a very Thai style area - complete with a very fine boar that followed us for most of the day like a pet dog. We got quite fond of him and gave him the name, "Herbert." Check out the insane speed boats running locals about around the island.As an alternative to catching the ferry back we caught a taxi ride to Chatuchak Markets and from there a sky train ride back to Silom.Generally enjoyed by all and a good value days outing

River cruise is suberb,having good dinner,and on deck live dance & music. One of attraction in Bangkok is river cruise tour after sunset,u will enjoy fully touring in the middle of bangkok,very good scenerio all over,.lot of varieties in food,veg/ non veg fruits.above all there is bellly dance on english/ urdu/hindi songs which has a class,u should tour in river cruise ,they pick & drop u at ur hotel.
awesome. great view excellent atmosphere i cant believe its really such a imagine view if really wanna enjoy and use ur time please go there u will love it

dinner cruise. Must for every traveller to Bangkok .If you are Indian ,take the Indian dinner cruise that leaves at 8 p.m. Excellent food and great performance of Bollywood songs by Thai music band . Lovely view from the deck .Try taking the upper deck reservation while booking.The cost is same ,but if you don`t ask they will book you on lower deck which has a restricted view of outside buildings.

well worth doing. was flooding when we were there but they were still touring on it. Great temples etc but we just loved oberving how people along the river livedbooked it through the hotel so paid a premium but our guide was amazing and had so much knowledge of not just the area but thai history

Saves shiploads of Time. I mean... it saves trafficjams-with-taxi-bus-or-tuktuk-of-time. It;s the most pleasant way to move around Bangkok. A taxi is comfortable but you do not smell the fresh air of the river. And you are not 'moving'. Like MOVING. On the river you have 3 kind of lines which differ in price and comfort. Take the first boat is my suggestion. The Orange Line for 15 Baht, a Green Line for 25 Baht and a YellowLine for 30 Baht. Especially Tha Chang stop ( pier N9 ) and surrounding piers ( pier 8 and 7 ) are special because of the things to do overthere.. But the whole double curve in the Chao Phraya river from pier N1 till pier N14 is great. We took several boats to nowhere. Got out just to see what happened overthere. Stayed for longer or short time. We had a superb meal at pier N9 for 1 dollar (!) in the evening at a stall in the open air. Chicken with garlic and rice. Ans fish with rice. Could not be better. You buy tickets at ticket offices at the piers. We had a hotel there which was great too.. The Royal Tha Tien village.
Nice travel option. I found river boat as a nice travel option. Mostly i use river boat to go at Asiatique as reaching there by taxi is very time consuming. River view at day time look really nice.
Chao phrya river. River is very clean and it is beautiful at night one can have drinks and thai food and one can be there whole night.
Still a better option than the private boats. Much better option than bargaining with the small private boats for a tour especially when you know where you want to go.
Taxiboat. Take the taxiboat and sail up and down the river .> you can see a lot of tempels and other boats,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,.

Good way to travel but check prices!!. There are a number of ticket sellers that try and sell you expensive tours. Check out the boards until you find one with individual prices going to your destination. Lovely way to see life on and alongside the river.

Nice for One day outside. You can take the BTS until Saphan Taksin station, and then take the Chao Praya Tourist Boat for 150 Baht for all day (you can hop on and hop off every time you want for one day). You can see many attractions, and buildings near the river shore.
