Also you can go to asiatique river marquet with the same boat (but remember that it opens at 5 PM, so boats will start going there since that time).It is one of the best ways to reach the Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) and Grand Palace.Enjoy it!!
Tourist boat. If you take the tourist boat with the light blue flag, you'll see all the attractions along the river. Excellent full day trip.

River cruise. Some of my Thai friends took me on an evening buffet cruise on the Chao Phraya.We passed the illuminated Wat Arun and the Royal Palace,whilst being entertained by an excellent Filipino group and a ladyboy cabaret-brilliant!
Good way to see the sights. Good trip along the river on the river taxi. Convenient way to travel from sight to sight or to spend a pleasant time on the river.
long boat ride. Negotiate the price as you can get the ride for at least 10% less than they ask. the trip takes a few hours and it is interesting seeing how people live on the river.
It's really dirty. If you take a boat to go around Bangkok, close your mouth to avoid entering any drop!It's a nice way, but you must haggle a lot with the boat company!

Dinner cruise. You get on a two-deck light-decorated boat, and you eat a buffet meal, entertained with single music & singer. The meal is average, but quite various. There are sushi, spaghetti, french fries, fried rice, tom yam, pad thai, and small pastries and fruit for dessert. The only sights you can see is buildings around. But completed with lights, it was quite a nice experience.

Best way to get around, but dirty. I know, you didn't go there to swim, but the amount of debris i the river is a bit disturbing. The cost on the 'local' boat is 40 Baht and can get you a one way ride to anywhere along the river. The shear number if Temples, The Grand Palace and other sights along the river is mind boggling. We had to take the river for two days to catch all the places that we had planned for. The boats don't waste any time at the stops, so be ready to move on and off quickly!! Quite an experience~~

Better than going by road!. You need to use the river like a main road but without the fumes and with better scenery. The river is huge and snakes through the city past it's most ancient monuments, high rise hotels and riverside dwellings. Use the shuttle boats and ferries to pier hop to different parts of the city.The journey becomes part of the adventure and you get a sense of how important this river is to everyday life for the people of Bangkok by watching the comings and goings of daily life. Try to take a journey at night also to see the river in a different way

Beautiful body of water that's impossible to miss. The Chao Phraya is a large river, teaming with life - just try throwing some bread in there and watch the fish go crazy. Often you'll see locals fishing off the bridges. A tour by river taxi or boat is cheap, even for tourists and will allow you a great view of the river side homes on stilts as well as some of the most striking angles to view some of the riverside Wats, including Wat Arun. There are also annual festivals held along the river, such as the King's annual boat procession and the rehearsals for it. Also Loy Krathong on November 26th is a good time to visit the water's edge to watch the annual festival of atonement. Although the water's muddy and you'd never dream of swimming in it there is something very relaxing about taking a water taxi, rather than braving the road traffic. A great way to travel around the old city especially.

The Lifeline of Bangkok even in this Modern Day. Its the lifeline of local Thai people, who use it as floating Markets, for transit, Fishing, restaurants on the bay and many more ways. It has been a cause of pain too at times with flooding but Thai people respect the river humbly for its bounty & purpose. Night cruise & cruise in river & canals is a good way to enjoy some nice sightseeing off the road in Bangkok.

A big river in Bangkok also called King Rama's River. We went on a boat in this river for 1.30 hours for 1800 baht and saw a floating market. The sailing through the river in a small boat was little frightening in the beginning but slowly adjusted to that. Don't forget to buy bread pieces to feed the fish during the sailing. The floating market was big compared to the one we visited on the outskirts of Bangkok with more bargains and shops here.
good. River is good but water is quite dirty. can enjoy cheap food around. boats are there. nice in evenings

Boat ride. It was interesting to take the boat ride to have a view of how everyday Thai people move around. It is advisable to use the orange flag boat (costs 15 Baht) as opposed to the blue flagged one (40 Baht). Just pay for the ticket when you board the boat.

Visit asiatique for the best river eating. We visited asiatique which is a shopping/dining area created at the old docks. Great promenade to walk along the river front and lots of places to eat and shop at. The river is like all other major rivers and was quite swollen when we saw it due to the rainy season.
Great way to see Bangkok. Very cheap way to see Bangkok and get your bearings as to where everything is. Jump on and off the water taxis. Be sure to take your camera.

YOU CANNOT LEAVE BANGKOK WITHOUT VISITING THIS. I have lived in Bangkok for ten years and still enjoy riding the river taxi up the Chao River. Take the skytrain to the Saphin Taskin stop, which is the main river port. You then have three choices. The first is a private small boat for about 1500 baht which will take you through the narrow klongs of the river. Definitely the best if you want to spend the money. Another is the public river taxi for 10 baht which stops at many places on the river, then there is a narrated tour boat that allows you to get on and off at several attractions along the river. You can easily get to the Grand Palace, River City, The Reclining Buda, Several Temples, The floating market, The Barge Museum, and many other attractions by boat that will take you hours by tour bus. No need to spend a fortune on tours that spend a half of day at a worlds largest jewelry store when you can use public transportation to see these places. There are always guides hanging around the attractions that will give your a nice tour for a reasonable price. Note: you have to negotiate price because they start at the moon.Enjoy Bangkok

So much to see and do on the river. There are many boats you can take up and down the river to see lots and lots of tourist attractions.Disliked - being taken for a tourist. Watch out for being ripped off.Best thing - The breeze.Good dining. Take the dining cruise from the Sheraton Hotel and you won't be disappointed. I have recommended this to friends and they loved it.

one river multiple WAT and palaces. It is an excellent oppurtinity to see the entire old city over a boat ride. Though you may find little hard to understand the guide, the view is simply excellent. Must Try

The Dying River. We have watched this river over many years and it gets sadder and sadder.The weed is terrible and they don't seem to know how to get rid of it..And the water quality is dreadful and it really does stink.If you are on a boat crossing the river the people keep something up to their mouth so that if the water happens to splash inside the boat they won't get sick from it.We went in a rather large boat to Auyttha and It was terrible pushing through the weed and then almost impossible to park the boat at the jetty because there was so much weed.

One of the most amazing rivers!. Absolutely take a ride with one of the hundreds of boats or longtails that criss cross the river all day long. It is an amazing experience and it is also very fast if you visit the sites of Bangkok.

No trip to Bankok without a rivertrip. This is the lifeline of Bankok. You can get almost anywere on the river and quite a lot faster then on land. If you are not going somwhere special, just take a trip. There is loads to see.

Easy way to roam around. Well managed river just through the middle of the Bangkok. Very fast,cheap, and frequent public boats connect north and south of the city. Don't use tourist boats rather use orange flag public boat, pay only 15 TBH for a ride. Views of the city from the river is awesome and have a dinner in the cruises, you will remember it for a long time.

The highway through Bangkok. Floating through Bangkok, this river is the scene of a lot of water traffic: tourist tours, dinner o the boat (evening), water taxi, shuttles from various hotels and not forget the water bus. The latter one, initially not easy to understand where to pay and what to pay, but it is so cheap, you can take any ticket and get rather fast through Bangkok without traffic jam. unfortunately the river is dirty and sometimes smelly. Even though a lot of fish still live in it.
Amazing at night from the Dinner Cruise. Book a night dinner cruise trip on Chao Phraya River, the activities are nice, nice singing, nice atmosphere and romantic views.

a great alternative to get around. Loved the ability to avoid traffic and just take either a river taxi or long boat to your destination a lot quicker. The river is quite murky so do not expect blue water. For the budget minded, take the public ferry up the river for 15B per person and get off at any pier but keep in mind the color of the flags on top of the ferry as they indicate what stops they stop at on their ferry schedule.Be careful of touts who insist you take a long boat if you do not want to take one. They are 100B per person and yes should be enjoyed if you havent been one before. But dont be pressured to take one if you are happy to wait for the ferry.The river is a great way also to see the temples faster too.

A nice view of the city from the water. Travel by a private boat or public transportation to get a view of the canal and the two sides of the river. You can see the Grand Palace on the boat, stop by Wat Arun, and end up at Wat Pho for a massage. Great itinerary for a day. We already went to the Grand Palace, so we did not stop there. Stopping by all three sights would be too much for one day unless you only have one day to spend in Bangkok.
Canal taxi. Take a canal taxi ride up and down the river but I recommend in the evening where it all looks more magical because wats are lit up and so many buildings and restaurants.

Nice experience with double thumbs up. We take a long boat along the river and have our lunch in one of the best local buffet halal restaurant. It is really amazing and we got the chance to feed the fish in the boat and get to see local Thai house built on the river.

Go by public boat - cheaper and immersed with local culture!. The river is the best way to travel the city and see the main attractions. Use the public ferry boat as its far cheaper than long boats and tour operators.

RICE BARGE TOUR ON THE RIVER. This is a very good trip long boat down the river then transfer to a rice barge for the return trip with free fruit and drinks .You also get to feed the fish at one point on the river fantastic.You get to see how the people live by the riverside.

Chao Phaya Ferry riding. This for me was the best of Bangkok, a must do. Leave the full day and if your lucky you can get on the ferry passing Wat Arun at sunset - spectacular. There are many tour companies touting for boat business. They sell overpriced tickets and provide the same service. Get on the boat and pay 15 Baht for each leg you travel regardless of distance. There are at least 5 wharves where getting off and walking round is recommended, the standard brochures will explain what to see at each stop. The ferry is fast and there is access to food drink and facilities at each stop. The ferry dock is easily accessible by BTS to Saphan Taksin station, and a short walk to the dockside.
Good place to eat. We tried 2 restaurants here and both of them are fantastic. The food is good and you also can take a boat on the river. Walking in the night time is very relax.

Something different. Another great and convenient way of travelling around bangkok. The boats are cheap and easy to use. Stay away from the Tourist boats! Stick to the normal orange flag boats which brings you to the same places as the tourist boats do. A ride on the orange flag boats will cost only THB 15, about a tenth of the price of the tourist boat! The river might be dirty but it's really a great way to see another side of bangkok.

Ferry go round. You should not be having very high hopes for this river but if you want to visit the places like Wat Arun, you have to take a ferry which runs across this river. The river is not clean and also stinks but the good part is that the boats are pretty big and carry lot many people across everyday so are safe to travel in. While in the ferry , you can have a view of lot many big river side hotels and it is overall a good experience as it is not very expensive.
River is nasty with pollution; take the boat tour anyway. We took the monorail system to the River, then took the boat ride with English tour guide pointing out points of interest.

not interesting. you can get boat and go trough the river but i belive there is nothing interesting to see. the river is not clean and you can not see many things from there. i do not recommend you to take the turistic boat trough the river.

Boat ride along the Chao Praya river. We had a private boat ride with our tour guide along the Chao Praya River. It was interesting to view the sights along the river. The water is dirty and muddy. We saw a rice barge and other boats with lots of tourists. It was fun but would only do it once.

Stunning View From Hotel. I stayed at the Shangri-La Hotel and had a riverfront balcony room. The night view of the Chao Phraya River from the top floor is magnificent. I would definitely suggest staying at a riverfront hotel if staying in Bangkok.

Use to get around Bangkok. It took us a while to work out that there are 'buses' and 'taxi's' on the river. Travelloing around Bangkok by road is tiresome and the tuk tuk are expensive, travel between temples and shopping centres by boat and pay far less for a quicker journey. And it's much more fun and the airs cleaner.............

River is very dirty. Chao Praya famed river has become very dirty and smelly to the point it looks toxic due to red colour waters. The small motor powered jet boats that travel around the river are very noisy and polluted and always overcrowded.

Take a ride. This is a great river to travel and a heck of a lot faster than the subway or driving. Actually, walking is faster than driving in this city. There are fancy little ferries and cheap little dragon boats and they are all fun. It is also dirt cheap and a great way to watch the ebb and flow of commerce in Bangkok.
Boat Rides Are A Must. We hopped on the tourist express and not only did we get to where we wanted, we had a laugh on the crazy boat ride.We sure don't have anything like this at home.

A RIVER WITH LIFE. This river flows through the city of Bangkok. This river is fully used for transportation of manufactured goods from upstream to the port and also has a night life in the form of river cruise which reverberates the mood of Bangkok.

A River Alive!. Life's stories perpetually unfolds as the Chao Phraya River flows. People, resources, commerce - unwinds like clockwork daily. Water taxis, dining cruises, long speedboats ala James Bond's Man With The Golden Gun, floating markets, colossal catfishes.Perhaps I have been satiated beyond reason. Having done the Chao Phraya River cruise that covers Wat Arun, a dinner cruise, and having boated to Kom Kret in Nontaburi Province and back has taken the river out of me.Still, others might find it teeming with new life and stuff.
Great Insight into a fascinating way of life. Life on the backwaters of the Bangkok waterways is a unique. We took a private long tail boat and could stop where we wanted.Our visitors were fascinated
The life of the city. I would recommend a river taxi to go as far up as possible and come back down to admire everything that Bangkok has laid out by the Chao Phraya River.

Very Pleasant River Dinner Cruise. We boarded the boat about an hour before sailing and started with dinner and drinks. You have a choice of inside or outside dining. We choose the upper deck which was crowded but not in a bad way. Everyone seemed to be having a good time. The menu had quite a variety of mostly Thai food, but it was really well prepared, tasted great and was served very hot. Service was exceptional, the waitress was attentive and even topped up your drink when it was getting low. The cruise was quite long and slow, which is perfect for sightseeing. We travelled downstream under 6 bridges as the travellers cheered as we went under each one. On the way back, they boat went much faster and we went below to a live band and dancing. The commentator only spoke Thai, but we had an interpretor who filled us in with the important stuff. Good value all in US$100 for 3, including booze.

Great way to travel when in Bangkok. Try and take a trip on the water taxi when in Bangkok. It's very much still a working river and you get to see all sorts of boats plying their trade up and down the river. There are great views of the city as well. The fares are because it is geared towards the inhabitants rather than tourists. It always seemed to be crowded.

the lifeline of BAngkok. Whatever reason brings you to BKK- the river always runs through it. A must do.A trip on the river makes you understand how trade started the story and how it will continue the history of BKK. There is no need to take the tourist boats, the local public transport one's serve serve the same stops. Thr smell, the wind, the view of the original BKK..go, go

If you stay in BKK, stay near the river. The river is not necessarily near all the main shopping, but you can shop in a lot of places. A 150 Baht ticket allows for a full one day pass on a river boat that takes you to several stops, including Old Town where you can visit Wat Pho and the Grand Palace, Chinatown, the Mandarin Oriental Hotel and more. It is absolutely beautiful to watch the various boats. Surprisingly, we saw fish after fish in the river.

Lovely View. Gives one a lovely view of Bangkok. The river was a little dirty, full of weed, but maybe it has not been removed for the marine life's interest. Have a lot of street food nearby and makes it a foodie's paradise

Pricing in Thailand. I've been to Thailand 4 years ago with my friend and the experience of travelling on the river within a distance from Khaosan area was authentic, with monks, all local and not touristic at all. We stopped at a park then we can walked to Rambuttri, met the local doing exercise in the park and I was given a nice perfumed flower by an old lady. So this time I took the tour with the hope of giving my friends the same wonderful feeling I had 4 years ago about this river travel in BKK.But I was wrong. I was so crowded and we took the long tail boat. The price was first 2000 or 1000 for 1 person but it was not the price I knew before so I tried to make a bargain. The one at the pier immediately gave another table of price of 560B/ each and then we got 2000B for 4 people, but the driver did not speak English at all. And the feeling of driving is not relax and authentic as I had before. This is just a thing for tourist if you don't have other things to do or never seen the life along the river before in your life, It's not all beautiful and clean, if you might expect.In general we all feel waste of time and money to take this. But I would have to tell another story relate to this tour. We got a friendly taxi driver with nice English speaking skill the other day in Bangkok of our stay. We talked on the way about what to do, where to go, and my friend just tried to be friendly to him. Then piece by piece, he gave us the leaflet about the tour in Bangkok and recommend us to travel around Bangkok on the long tail boat, and this is a must for a perfect Bangkok experience. My friend, again tried to be nice by saying " ok, we might try it later, but today we want to visit the Siam paragon" without telling him we didn't enjoy the river tour as It might be unnecessary to tell him so. We took the taxi about 4km from the Paragon (the Google map told us so) but he took us further away to our destination as we took the conversation with him. As soon as I realized it shouldn't take that long for 4 km, and he was travelling with the wrong direction, we asked to leave immediately, he didn't allow us to do so, even we asked for 5 times more, he took another 2 km to the pier and drop us there with my friends full of anger. I guess he must have the commission money for each tourist he drops there. Of course we wouldn't do the tour again but be careful with the nice English talking taxi and nice suggestion.So took the flat boat (which the local use, is much better, if your idea is not visiting the whole riverside of the city) and take the stop as your choice. Don't go for the very long and feel greedy to know it all because however, you just have the view of the tourist, and go by the route they choose for you.Have good time travelling. Traveled in Aug 2013
GREAT place to stay. Klong tour is highly recommended. DON'T MISS IT!!! we tryed several boat and loved the high speed long tail
its ok. not very good, as its overly crowded, food they serve is also not very good . If you go, please try to sit inside.
A must when in Bangkok.. When in Bangkok you must take a boat down the river.It's a great experience, is very cheap and is a good way of getting around.The views are spectacular too!

Best way to travel in Bangkok. Seems strange to rate river with 5 stars however the Chao Phraya River transit is the fastest and best way to travel along the Chao Phraya River, especially during high traffic times.Its a delightful adventure for first timers and the fastest way between certain points for regulars. Be sure to check whether the boat is a local or express so you don't overshoot your chosen destination. Even if you do its easy to catch another boat back. The prices are very low and the experience is worth many times the fare.

breath taking view of the city!. we enjoyed the Rice boat with a buffet of fruit on the river and the river taxis! awesome history and Thai homes and lifestyles as you pass along. the highlight was feeding Catfish and you just see hundreds of them jumping for joy!
Majestic River encircling Bangkok. Even though the river wasn't clean, but a boat ride through the river gives an amazing look of Bangkok.

Voyage Through Time. It feels like you are traveling through a 60's Vietnam War movie, with the many houseboats on the river. The shanty's that line the river give the place texture and a look at life in a foreign land. Old ladies in boats will stop your tour boat to sell trinkets and drinks. It is easy to say yes to help these people. The tour is cheap and if you pay a guide, they will take you to the temples. A must see in Bangkok

Dinner Cruise. We had a great dinner cruise down the River! We traveled with Gate 1 and booked the cruise on one of their optional tours. Dinner was very good (buffet), a band played and people danced! Board when the door opens to get a table upstairs in the fresh air! Oh and wear bug spray! Views are wonderful, it's worth the price of the cruise!

Make Sure You take A Boat Ride. Excellent way to get around town. One thing though! Avoid the "Venice of the east boat tour of the Western Bangkok canals" unless you enjoy sewers. Don't pay extra for the Tourist Boats unless you are infirm. The orange flag boats at a fraction of the price are much more enjoyable.

Excellent views. This is a must do for any visitor to Bangkok. Take a dinner cruise and enjoy the view as the boat sails down the river. do some search on net and tripadvisor on the best cruise options before you book.
Boat trip. We took a boat trip on this to get around. Had a great time watching people feed the fish, different boats. Well worth the trip;
Nice cruise. We took a daily cruise which was nice we had a tour around bangkok,and gives you the opertunity to see bangkok from the river and not from the busy road.

Evening Cruise. Booked trip through Travel Agent @ First Hotel. Transport to Cruise Centre was provided in a van. Easy to get lost as no announcements are made regarding departures of cruises. You need to keep a sharp on your watch and the arriving boats. Huge difference between Cruise boats, do your homework prior to avoid being sorely disappointed. Price included a buffet meal onboard. You can have a few hundred fellow-passengers so dinner time is a jostle to the table. Things tend to quieten down after dinner and onboard entertainment. Plenty to see and this trip is highly recommended.

Night cruise - must do. We went for a dinner cruise on the river. Had an outside table, really beautiful sights. Unfortunately, 90% of the people were of Indian origin, so the menu consisted of Indian dishes.

Cruisin'. The water current was not that strong and the weather was very hot and humid.
The boat ride was nice, though one has to learn to negotiate on the fee. The boat person who took us to the floating market was trustworthy.

Best cruise experience ever. River cruise and tour is an excellent experience. Great food, great music and dancing! Love the people around. Waiter service and banquet is great. Good and variable secetion of food! DJ and music hosts were great. we danced with japanese, Chinese tourists. The experience was memorable!

food on the river. We had a evening dinner cruise on the river which came recommended to us and it didn't fail , we had a great night of food and dancing.The cabaret was great and he gets everybody involved

Nothing much. The boat we rented was not so informative and kind of exaggerated the things that we will see. So it's not particularly the river, it's the cruise. It's good to see how people live by the river but no for me. There was nothing really to see. Except maybe at night time.

We got scammed!. We were on our way to the Grand Palace. We stopped by Stadium Station to grab a tuk tuk there. They told us that the Grand Palace was close for half a day and that it will only be open after lunch. He advice us to take the Dragon Boat ride during the closure. We later found out that the Grand Palace was open the whole day.The tuk tuk cost us 40 Batt and the Dragon Boat ride cost us 400 Batt per person just to go up stream to Wat Arun. Travelers please beware.

A River which I envy of. The government really make use of the River maximally. The river provide a good transportation alternative in a busy City. The river is quite clean in my opinion. Taking a boat in the river can be a refreshing activity comparing to riding vehicles on the road. Moreover, it gives the opportunity to open a tourist site with a river view. A River which I envy of.

Cruise was very good. We booked Cruise with most of Indian on it, therefore the music, food and all the things were according to the Indian Taste. The 2 hour cruise was very good, we had lot of fun during this time.
At your own risk!. Smelly, hot, but different at least give it a try.But way better take a cab, even when some of them are smelly too!
Just another river. Went on a cruise, nothing too fancy i guess during the night.Might be better during the day from a high building when/if you can see the river in its entirety

a great way to travel with children. We were staying close to the Central Pier, so it made sense for us to use the river taxis as much as possible. We went to Wat Pho one day, and right up to Nonthauri (orange flag boat) another - and back at night, which was lovely, and very cheap (15 baht each per journey). At rush hour the taxis can get very crowded, so one of our trips home was done by hiring a long-tailed boat (a la James Bond) - we paid 600 baht (should have bartered probably, but it was worth it to see the looks of delight on the children's faces when we went fast!)
Ayutthaya to Bangkok. We took us tour bus to Ayutthaya to view ruins, from here we cruised down the Chao Prayer River back to Bangkok. Very scenic cruise and lovely buffet luncheon served.
Amazing View. Go see this at right it truly is huge. Its actually part man made and the current is very strong. Some great attractions along the way.

A proper working river. Now this would never be allowed in a health and safety lead culture, that's why it's fun. Express and tour boats rush up and down the river between massive barges and other working ships. It's cheap 15 baht for the tourist boat and 40 for the express. Everyone uses it so there's no you need to as well! Be expected to be bumped!

Relaxing Time. It's very cheap transportation with extraordinary view. Price:Around 40 or below, depends on type of ferry and length of your journey.Type of Chao Phraya Express Boat: Blue flag( Tourist), yellow flag, orange flag, etc.I don't use it often but I noticed that the blue flag came more often than others. Price is the most expensive but seat is better. (40 Baht: December 2012) They have guide tour who provide you basic info of many place on route but sound quality was very poor. Do not expect too much. Tips:If you travel from Sapantaksin BTS Station up north. The Temple of Dawn would be on your left side, please find good seat if you want good picture. Temple of Dawn is amazing beautiful at night but the express boat do not provide service until late night. Please check its operation hour. Warning:Avoid using river ferry in rush hour. It is totally crowded and could be dangerous when overloaded, More information about river express boat, please google 'Chao Phraya Express Boat'

Efficient water transportation in Bangkok. We visited and experienced the water transportation in the Chao Phraya river when we visited the Wat Arun and The Royal Barges Museum.The journey started from our hotel in Sukhumvit area, we ride BTS for a small fare to Saphan Taksin BTS/Pier.Its easy , just be sure you hold a Bangkok City Map in your hands.There are several boat/ferry operators at the pier , some are for cruising ,and some for acrossing the Chao Phraya river to the other end.Just be sure you dont board the wrong boat.There are 2 methods of boarding these boats, 1st you can buy tickets from the ticket counter (a tourist boat kinda type ) ,or its cheaper if you hop on a commuter orange flagged boats and pay the fare, it will be charged on your way with a tin can, the fare depends on the distance.The boats with Orange Flag operates all day in 20 minutes intervals.Operationg hours is between 6 am - 19.30 pmPleasant ride , if you dont mind sharing the boat with many other peoples.

Take the Chao Phraya express taxi boat for a quick trip on the River. Take a tour of the city of Bangkok on your own with a taxie boat on the Chao Phraya river. Jump on the dark green line of the BTS skytrain and get off at Central Pier/ Saphan Taksin. Follow the signs to Central Pier and look for the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat. The ticket will cost 120 baht for a round trip ticket good for the day stamped, with unlimited travel to their 8 piers. When you purchase their ticket you will get a travel guide to show you where to get off to see all of the famous tourist sites along the river. There are other taxi boats at a cheaper rate but they stop at different piers and may take longer. Famous tourist places include the Grand Palace, along with Wat Phra Kaeo, Museum of Siam, Flower Market, The Royal Barge Museum, Chinatown, and many more. The busy life on the river will give anybody a whole different view of Bangkok.

Great experience. We took the cheap local option of getting the boat along the river for around 17 Baht, it was very packed but it lets you get pictures of the Temple of Dawn that you wouldn't be able to get on land.There are also several speedboat options but they are extremely overpriced. Regardless, I would recommend this unless you're happy enough with a restricted view and lots of bodies on the same boat.

River cruise. We took a night time dinner cruise with Loy Nava dinner cruises which included food and traditional Thai dancing. It was wonderful to see the river and the sights at night lit up in the splendour. We also used the commuter boat to travel along the river which was quick, inexpensive and definitely an experience at busy times!

Boat trip from Silom to centre Bangkok. The boat trip/boat taxi cost 40 thb per person and included a number of stops. There was also an attempt at providing information, but this was hard to understand/inaudible. It is simply a good way to travel the distance up to many tourist sites and see Bangkok from a different perspective.
View from a boat. fabulous way to see Bangkok. Negociate a deal with the boss and make sure you buy your skipper a lager from the floating market!

the best way to get to the key attractions. The river is vibrant and has some great views and is the best transport for accessing the main tourist attractions - the Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Wat Arun etc. We picked up the boat most days from the central pier, where the sky train has a stop. We purchased One Day River Passes for 150baht which means you have free access to hop off and on. Its a pleasurable way of getting around.We also rented a fast boat to take us on a tour of the canals. Do barter. This was a great experience and you see a different sort of Bangkok. The journey took about an hour.

The pollution from the long tailed boats. Although this is the way that I would recommend travelling in Bangkok the pollution from the long tailed boats and ferries (clouds of diesel fumes) make the river environment unpleasant. However travel by road is even worse! The Sky Train is excellent so a hotel such as the Mandarin Oriental may be best as it is one of the closest to a terminal and the river.

private river cruise was phenomonal. my wife and i got a private river cruise on the Chao Praya. the water was a bit choppy and i was a little worried but need'nt have been. the captain knew what he was doing and we soon made it to the safety of the canals where it was fascinating to see the homes of real people so close up. feeding the fish was amazing as was scouring the banks and river for the giant lizards. my wife was constantly on edge but it was perfectly safe. hated getting wet as the water is so polluted. only downside really

Enjoy the water taxi, with on off stops. We did the Chao Phraya expess and got on and off at various stops. it was a fantastic way to see the scenery along the River. We purchased a full day ticket and spent several hours cruising the river. Due to the summer heat the temperature with the wind was quite comfortable.

very romantic. For a very pleasant romantic evening, have a Dinner Cruise. A slow ride with the Grand Palace and other temples on the shore line. The weather is warm, not a hint of chill. You are picked up from the hotel and taken to the pier and returned.After you have eaten you are invited to join in the dancing on the top deck.Good to see the different nationalities enjoying themselves together
Great experience. A wonderful experience travelling on a water taxi, although there was obviously no evidence of health and safety measures! How many people can you fit onto 1 boat?

Hotel on the river. We stayed at the Chatrium but I expect the same applies for all the river hotels - highly recommend this location. Stayed in the centre previously and found the constant attention from tuk tuk drivers etc irritating after a while. At the river you can get to most places by boat or sky train - much more relaxing.

To get away from the crowds. Nice river with loads of boat taxi and I suppose you call them ferries. Once you have worked out the colour system of the Boats flags then you no which ones don't stop at every dock. Great for seeing loads of stuff without the heat and hassle and bustle of walking.

Good fun.. We hired a private boat for 2000thb. A bit steep for what we got. It was good fun. The boat took us down some of the side canals to see how people live on the waters edge. Our boat dropped us of for 30mins at Wat Arun. It was good to get on shore after bobbing about. We then headed across the river to the grand palace where we left the boat. It would have taken us all the way back down the river but by then we had had enough.

Enjoy the full cruise. We decided to visit Khlong Om and its market. We used the Chao Phraya express from Taksin to Nonthaburi and then we got a long tail boat to the khlongs. I suggest to use the express cruise and not the tourist one which is expensive and leave people only at touristic places. If you enjoy Bangkok, from its true spirit, you can't love touristic places only. The CPE is a good way to visit the city from its hearth at a very low price (30 THB) The farer you go from the center of the city, the truer the city looks.

Big River. Wooowww..the river were big and clean, many boats from surrounding back and forth during the day..
I just enjoy the sunset and sunrise from the hotel with a river view, very traditional and fortunately the river didn't smell bad..

The Cruise. Dont miss the river cruise which cost around 100 baht offering 2 hours of river cruise and dinner on board.The view on both sides of river is worth capturing aso take your cameras along.The deck is excellent place to take pictures of palace,temples ,bridges which are very well lit

Ordinary River but Good place to mixed with locals. To be honest, the river is just like the common river in another part of the world, the good thing is that you can ride a boat with cheap prices, and were able to be mixed with the locals, and understands that chao praya is having an important value for their daily life

So busy!!!. Like a busy city street the river has boats of all shapes and sizes whizzing here and there. You can pay 20 Bhat for a large highly populated boat ride or 1500+Bhat for a ride in a much smaller private hire boat.

Bangkok River. Was a fun boat ride around a waterway that so many live off.
A great way to gain an understanding of how some of the locals live as the boat trip takes you past so many houses and dwellings of the local people.

Wonderful exotic place. Do not forget to take the boar from Taksin bridge to Wat Arun and look around the people, the businesses and the life around the river. It is one of the most genuine part of Thailand you can see in Bangkok.

Ride the river ferry. We wanted to see the Chao Phraya River but didn't want to go and ride the cruise. What we did was ride the local boat for 15 baht at the Central Pier (go down BTS Sathorn station). We were able to see the Wat Arun temple from a far. This attraction is a steal for only 15 baht!
adds charm to the wat arun. the river added more charm to the pics of the wat arun when taken near it. I liked the easy distance going to wat arun by crossing the river.

Bangkoks big River. Such a beautiful View of the City with this nice River in the front. Many Hotels and one famous Hospital are located near the River because of its spectacular view over Bangkok. It is an important Place for us in Bangkok.

Best transport in the city from Banglampoo. If you are staying khao san area, it´s a really nice way to go downtown by boat. There is a tourist boat for 40 Baht or a local boat for 15 Baht. The tourist boat is more comfy because you have more space and normally a seat beause it´s not so full. But you should expierence the orange flag boat for 15 Baht at least once - do it like the locals - cramped and have fun!

Great way to see how the locals live... We thought this was an amazing way to see how the locals live..It was cheap too..Highly recommend doing this..My husband and I (in our forties)and our Daughter and her partner(in their 20's) all thoroughly enjoyed this experience...highly recommend

Baht 15 only - have fun. On my earlier visits I had used it to reach China Town and Pahurat markets from Saphan Teksin pier. This time I used N9 pier to reach Wat Arun and also Thewat pier to go to The Ananda Samakhom Throne Hall. I think its Baht 15 pp each time you board. It will be very fast, very reliable, quite cheap and most important you need not haggle with the cab drivers to use the meter. Whenever one can use the river taxi, go for it.

OK sights if you have patience and time. We got sold on taking this private river tour on our way to the Grand Palace by a tuk-tuk driver (big mistake!). While it was OK, the sights were mediocre and the boat never stopped on any of the places it 'promised' to stop (feeding catfish, floating market, etc.); boatwoman was very rude and finally let us off on an dock where we had to pay more money to get off!!! I had really bad experiences with many of the locals-- they seemed to be tourist-weary (and I don't blame them) and quite rude, unlike our experiences with other Asian countries (i.e., Philippines, Indonesia, Korea, Japan, Cambodia, Turkey). So far, Bangkok is not my favorite--I should say, however, that we were entertained by all the huge monitor lizards we saw along the banks of the river (on top of cement bridges, docks, etc.) sunning themselves, maybe 15 or 20 of these. I don't think many of the tourists saw these since they seemed focused on the houses and buildings around... at least we didn't see anyone on the other boats excitedly pointing at these lizards! It's quite hard to spot them but we were very bored...

Take the long boat trip!. We hired a long boat driver for a trip on the river and surrounding canals. It was one of the most interesting things we did in Bangkok, as we got "off the beaten path" to see how many of the people really live along the canals. Much of their livelihood takes place by little boats, and it is fascinating to see them coming and going to market with tall loads in little tiny boats.

Great way to see the old Thailand!. Rent a skipper for your own private long boat cruise. You'll need 1 1/2 hours at least to meandering down the river and explore the canals. Be sure to ask the skipper, at the start of your cruise, to stop at one of the "floating markets"

Lifeline of Bangkok. The river is the lifeline of Bangkok and is a commercial hub as well as a tourist attraction with may prominent attractions including the Grand Palace and the Temple of Dawn located along its banks.There are two good ways to see the river. The first is to hire a long tail boat and go on a private cruise. The boat will take you to the various attractions along the banks and allow you to visit them. The tour takes around half a day, is more personal and can be customized. The other is to take one of the many scheduled river cruises which run along the river. Some of these start from river city mall and take you along the river include lunch / dinner depending on the time and have some sort of entertainment on board. These do not stop at the attractions, last for about 2 hours and have a large crowd. Personally, I prefer the long tail boat cruise.Definitely worth a visit.

Nice boat trip. If you would like to see Bangkok from the river it's best to take a boat trip on Chao Phraya. Very reasonable priced. Tourist boat from Pier to Grand Palace 40 bahts. If you are located on Sukhumvit or Silom Road don't take a cab to Grand Palace, take a boat ride (one with a yellow seats and tour guide). It will be much more interesting and you will see how local people live by the river.

Life Watching at its best. I just love going on the Chao Phraya river. Anytime of the day, you will see so much life and activity going on. There are a few boat services available including one for tourists. Its very cheap to go up all the way to Nonthaburi for amazing rural river life.This is a must do when visiting Bangkok
Nice to cruise on it on a cloudy weather. As I was staying by the River, our main transportation was using the ferry. Pay for the tourist ferry which is less crowded.

Amazing river.... I liked it much coz it provides a good transportation area that has no traffic, ridding on the boats going from one stop or port to the other makes our tour reach more places,,, it is also an experience ridding on the fast and sometimes congested boats, commuters can reach their destinations fast. I had the chance to ride in the chao praya express and the river cruises, the sight and experience at night is more beautiful and romAntic too,,,,the beautiful And breathtaking view of the lighted temples, the bridges, and the hotels along the way gives a magnificent experience. The river is also being used by traders, as i saw some barges bringing/carrying cargo, and fast boAts being enjoyed by tourists...hope that we can also utilize our rivers like the chao phraya...
a wonderful journey. I enjoyed this river as the river taxis made traveling very easy & fun. The experience with mixing with many people on a boat for a short period of time is stunning
Cheap trip across the river. Very reasonable fares on a boat the locals use - 3 bhat. Just a short crossing buy a good way to get to the other side. And visited Wat Arun which is just off the pier.

Day and night. It´s a large river, Bangkok´s life runs through this waters. it can be just a means of transportation or a great attraction having dinner and watching the temples, and enjoying the shows in the boats. The floating Market with it flowers in the early morning.

Good experience though it could be much better. Took a dinner cruise on the river and enjoyed the scenic views with plenty of lights in the city. I wish the food was more international and continental and if there was more of commentary rather than just singing with karaoke.

a ride on the gondola a program not to be missed. the river is stinky, and not in par with the rapid changes of Bangkok for a positive image of a megacity. Yet, the inception is on the running of the water, having an imagery of vitality and continuity when water splashes on the sides of the gondola. A 50 minute ride, private, would add flavour to an already spicy dish of Thai--you would remember this: a thai is still a thai, though the Mcdonald is every where.

river cruise to remember. day cruise and night cruise with dinner is something one must plan before landing at Bangkok; one more day extra. its worth the time and money spent. just be in a cruise on the mighty chao Phraya river and you will feel what it is. a must in Bangkok.

Easy to do on a day pass. We went on the evening dinner cruise on the river in a rice barge. It was one of the highlights of our stay, very romantic. You can get a day pass for the river and this was worth doing. We visited the Grand Palace and Reclining Buddha, then we went across on the river ferry to Wat Arun. Then we got off at the Sheraton to find a restaurant by the river. It was all very straightforward and easy to do on your own without having to book a tour.
Fast and inexpensive. The river is a great way to get around, no getting stuck in traffic and not expensive. but be quick on and off, they dont wait.
river that connected bangkok. Nice transportation system by the riverYou can go to several attractions by this river.and every pier is conected

The River of Culture. It was great. The colourful horde of locals and tourists alike make their way through a thriving market of food and memorabilia. The river rides are tourist attractions and regular taxis at the same time. So sit back in a Chao Phraya boat and see the diverse culture, bothy modern and historical along the banks.

Must do when in Bangkok. Once you've dealt with the aggressive and unfriendly characters who run the long-tailed boats, it is worth doing despite the unsavoury haggling.
Yes, it's dirty & smelly - but it's also lots of fun!
Great way to see different parts of the city from a very different perspective.

Amazing Thailand. Very entertaining / bustling with activities. Heard not so good reviews about it, but was determined to try it on our recent trip to Bangkok. Worth it ! - Yes, absolutely vibrant with Asian Hospitality - food was good, the live band was good too - the evening cruise was worth it as we passed the landmark buildings of Bangkok , TRY IT OUT !

Long tail boat cruise...a must!. With just a 10 minute advance notice, the concierge at our hotel arranged for a long tail boat cruise. We boarded the slender vessel and in just a few minutes we were navigating the narrow klongs on the Chao Praya River. Not only did we get a front-row view of life on the river, but we also saw half a dozen large (6'+) monitor lizards. It was spectacular!

Enjoyable. Traveling by boat in Bangkok is the best way. No traffic jam, no pollution, cheap, and very relax. I took a boat from the central pier, under Sapan Taksin skytrain station to the grand palace. It cost me only 1.5$, very cheap. Highly recommend if you tired of Bangkok traffic and Tuk Tuk scam.
Private boat ride. We rented a private boat taxi for our selves and went at nite it was great to see all the sights buy the water and very relaxing.

A watery perspective on a bustling city. Full disclosure: I lived in Bangkok for over five years, and return frequently. And whenever I visit anew, I always try to find time to ride the river. The water bus is my favorite, especially standing in the back, with the wind in my hair and a good view of temples, hotels, warehouses, docks, restaurants, boat traffic, and much more. The river nourishes plenty of commerce, and the waterbus pilots are masters at pulling smoothly, more or less, into each stop. Those who want a more leisurely tour can hire a private boat for a few hundred baht, and if you are staying on a riverside hotel, arrangements are easily made. The sights, sounds, and smells provide a perspective on Bangkok that you can enjoy only from getting down on the river.

i don't know what's the goodof this river???. i went to bangkok 2 times with travel agent..& i regreted it because a lot of beautiful places weren't included in the itinerary, but why with this river???...just a lot of big hungry fishes...& the buildings around this river aren't good enough to be captured from the river???...so why we have to go around this river???...or the travel agent arranged it just to cross the river to go to the temple of dawn (Wat Arun Temple)????...i don't really get it until now???...2 times..& i don't understand what's the good from this river???

The boats never stop.. We stayed at a river front hotel and just loved to watch the river flow by. We used the river taxi several times it's an experience. Also you should do the long tail boat trip, be brave and enjoy.
Dirty. This large river should be more clean. The water is brown and there is garbage floating. The boats are cheap and it's easy to reach many temples if we use this river.
Must do!!!!. Very nice for all ages. But be away from tourist boat, its expansive. Use the public transportation for 15 bath. Nice views!!!

River cruise with a view. This is a must do, to travel down a section of the river that is the life line of this huge city. See the lovely Wats and some monuments, modern condos to wooden houses on the riverside. Unless you want a tour, make sure you buy the local tickets (cheaper - Baht40 vs Baht150) for the ride.

Go to Shangri-La Hotel for Long Boat Tour. There are many Long Boat tours--go to the Shangri-La Hotel for the most reputable. They have their own dock and assure the best contracted operators. Inexpensive tour of the Klongs (canals)--one hour is sufficient but they offer longer ones. A great opportunity to see some of old Bangkok that many tourists miss. I recommend: don't miss a one-hour long-boat tour of the Klongs. It's a treat.
STUNNING!!. This is a treat everyone should experience. The food was good, the cruise was great. The temples at night was awesome. All in all money well spent.

The Easy Way to Get to the Grand Palace and Wat Arun. The river is full of boats, coming and going, of all shapes and sizes and speeds. We opted for a long boat which cost a lot more than the public transportation but the speed of zipping from place to place is worth it. Negotiate the price in advance. Be sure to ask about the specific drop off place. On one occasion our boat operator dropped us off at a private pier and the people there demanded 20 bhat to land. While that is not a large amount of money, our other transfers had included the landing charge in the total price. There are several nice restaurants that line the river and at night there are dinner cruises with a fabulous view of the temples and the Grand Palace lit up. Worth the trip.

Stunning. Excellent views of the river from some of the hotels. We did the Chao Phraya dinner river cruise booked before we went through Trip advisor, we would thoroughly recommend going on this as it was really good entertainment and the food was very good, being a buffet there was plenty of choice, the entertainment was good and everyone was up dancing.

Take the boat!. We did a boat ride on the river (one of our friends highly recommended it). The kids loved it and we had a nice time too. The water is not particularly clean but it gives you a nice window into the daily lives of people.
fun. we took a ride on the local ferry to the end of the route and back. The whole journey was about 80 mins. and very cheap. Its busy so don't go in peak times or you wont get a seat.

So so. we took a boat on the river and found the water to be very choppy and not very clean at all. The little canals were another story altogether and we had a great time touring the Khlong Mon canal by boat, which set us back 1000 Baht for an hour ride.

too exciting and very cheap. I don’t think river boats are such a prominent form of transportation anywhere else to the extent as it is in Bangkok. River cruise here in Bangkok gives you a feeling that one is travelling in a train, similar stops in the cruise station. It’s wonderful and exciting.

Don't Miss the River!. Apart from being as scenic as it is, the Chao Praya is also a great, time-saving way of zipping around a traffic-clogged city. Hop on a riverboat, and then connect to other public transportation, and you'll get to where you need to be in no time.

Main waterway of Bangkok. Most great cities in the world are born on the banks of rivers, this is Bangkok's version. You can take a boat and see the different canals that feed the river and the way of life of those who live in their banks. From the affluent to the needy. A bit stinky though.
Basic "tourist" boat is all you need. Not the cleanest thing to do, but being in Bangkok, I'd recommend using the water taxi "tourist" boat at least once to see the old city via the river.
dirty. So dirty and uncleaned river. You'll discover the basic of poor environment. It's smell bad and seen to be so dirt that it's shame due to the beauty of lands around

Rice Barge Dinner Cruise. Beware! Nice idea, watch the food I had acute gastric entiritis after my visit, there are several differnt companies and some are obviously better than others. it is a great evening cruise

Unless you are on a honeymoon .... Unless you are on a honeymoon and very conscience of crowd around you, in that case get an exclusive boat, else get a day pass and you will get access to an express boat that allows you to hop-off and hop-in at any pier. If you are short on time, get off at Pier N5 (Chinatown) and N8 (Wat Arun).

Old-fashioned fun.. Take a private long boat ride on the river and to a few local canals and imagine Bangkok without the skyscrapers. Negotiate the price to include stops at Wat Arun, Wat Phra Keao, and the Oriental dock and you may really enjoy the river and its gems.

Great river buses. The river buses work well but, perhaps, the tourist boats are better. Certainly worth looking at in any case. The river has many piers so it's easy to get on and off at different locations which makes it a user friendly mode of transport. It also gets you away from the heat of the city and is a great way to see the city.

Its relaxing. The river is big and nice. There are lots of station in the bank.I take the chao phraya river pier from Saphan Taskin BTS station to Khaosan and also Asiatique river front a nice adventure to me.The pier are nice by decorating light at night and the light of bangkok Big towers among the banks looking stunning and the asiatique view is really worthlooking from the river.

One of Bangkok's Largest Rivers. You will see this river when you enter and exit from Bangkok. Its a sign to see the river to know if you are close to the city. Flows through the city and its quite a large river.
Klong Tour is a Bangkok Must. If you are visiting Bangkok it is a must for a Klong Tour through the canals on the west side of the river. We have done this twice now and it is 100% worth the trip.

Grab a long tailed boat!. You can grab a long tailed boat at any of the river stops and agree a price for a tour of the river and canals with a few site seeing stops thrown in. For the five of us it was 2000 bahts for 3 hours. We stopped at the Floating Market and the Leaning Buddha Temple - Wat Pho. The 'skipper' pointed out sites and wildlife on our way around. It was a great way to get our bearings on our first day in Bangkok.

take a cruise. the river is definitely worth a visit...a lot of business of bangkok happesn through the river....take a nice dinner cruise on the river and see bangkok by night...the wat arun looks heavenly at night from the river

Nice break from shopping. Take the skytrain to Saphan Taksin and then you are close to the river. There you can buy a One day river pass ticket to Chao Phraya Tourisboat and then you can hop on and of of at any pier you want for the whole day.

Fish feeding frenzy!. We wondered down to the river from our guesthouse this afternoon and were surprised to see the water around the pier alive with huge, metre long catfish. there were so many of them you could have walked on the water! Some Thai people make their living by selling big bags of bread, with which people feed the wrestling hordes of fish.I asked our guesthouse manager if there was a reason for this fish feeding phenomenon and he said it was simply because it is forbidden to catch fish near temples, so instead, the Thai people feed them. So the fish grow fat on the free food and the sight is a spectacle along the whole river wherever you see a riverside temple. The kids and I spent a happy hour there dodging the splashes of the fishes' tails as they leapt on the bread being thrown in. An easy outing and a fun tuk tuk ride home to top off the experience.
Another way to travel in Bangkok. it's better if you go in the afternoon because the water is kinda dirty and smell. Best if you go when its dark.

Plan your tour and take the cruise. Grab a map, and locate all the places near the river. and instead of the expensive tuk tuk or cab, give the transfer boats a try. You may also want a dinner buffet while cruising the river and witness the astonishing view of the temple of dawn for 1000-2000 baht ($32-$64)

Fabulous River. The best way to travel the river is to get the BTS Skytrain to Saphan Thaksin station. Leave the station and take short walk to the Main Pier on the river. At the main pier you can get a tour boat but the best and cheapest way is to get a River Taxi, which run frequently and used by locals. The fare is collected when on board and you will know when they arrive when you hear a loud whistle, just follow the queue. This is a great way to see the river and to get to the Grand Palace.

No trip to bangkok would be complete without a long tail boat trip. We hired a long tail boat for around one hour to travel through the canal-ways off the main river. Getting on and off the boat is not for the faint-hearted! We saw a variety of homes on stilts, people selling their wares from boats (far less staged than the floating market) and stunning views of the Grand Palace.

Beautiful River. This river is a main mode of transportation, you catch a boat like a taxi and get off at any stop along the river. You see the temples going up and down the river, the only way to travel in Bangkok
Chao Phraya River Boat Freebie!!!. What a way to return home from downtown Bangkok via the hotel chatrium river boat free of course takes about ten minutes amazing experience

A great way to get a feel for this city. We travelled by river more than once and it was a great way to get a real feel for this vibrant city. Feeling a little intimidated we went for the tourist boat the first day. Unlimited trips up and down the river is not bad value at 150 baht (approx 4 euros) for 24 hours. There is an English speaking guide on the boat which helps you get your bearings.After day one we took the local boats. One trip for 15 baht (40c) is cheap and easy if you just want to use the boats like a bus service. Once you have got the map from the tourist boat it is easy to navigate.The river itself is not pretty but the view of the temples and sights from the river are beautiful

The way to get around in BKK. The combo BTS and boat is what allowed us to actually get somewhere in Bangkok. The traffic is so intense that taking anything on the road would mean hours wasted (literally). Go for the express buses or local, but avoid the tourist boats. They are just the same but 3 times the cost!

The lifeblood of Bangkok. The river has numerous water crossing do not bother with the long tail tour when you can hop on one of the ferries for about 1us. It is a great way to see the Grand Palace and get to Wat Arun<Temple of dawn>. If you follow along the river traveling towards China town its another world along the waterfront including an amazing flower market. I have seen the river in many different phases including the floods of 2011. It was remarkable seeing the river 1 meter over the crest being held back by massive pumps.
Dirty. Chao Phraya River, at day time is not so good, because you see Dirty, by at Night time is Ok, The River view is quite good.
Major transportation. Its more than a river. You can go places along the river, eat on it even. Some hotels even have private piers that have boat shuttles.

I like cruising by the Express boat. I enjoy cruising by Chao Phraya Express boat when I have a time. I can forget the hot weather in Bangkok when I'm on the boat. We can get on the boat at BTS Saphan Taksin Station. The water of Chao Phraya is not clear but has no bad smell average level in south-eastern country.

A unique perspective of Bangkok. The river itself is dirty and not terribly pleasant but it's certainly an interesting way to see Bangkok! Catch a long tail boat or private ferry from Saphin Taksin Pier down to the Grand Palace or Wat Arun. Takes about 20mins and there are some awe-inspiring sights.

Nice night scenery by Apsara missed Day Cruise. We wanted to go for a day cruise using the river tourist boat but was spoilt by a rogue pink taxi driver scouting near Wat Trimit. Wasted our time helping him collect petrol voucher and sending us to a dark alley near the river for a private expensive cruise. Wish the authorities get rid of these pests. Luckily we read and advise by trip advisors and not fleece by these touts. We escape but Wasted our time, if not , we would have a lovely day cruise up and down the river making many stops and visiting most holy temples, museum and palaces. I hope others reading this will not encountered these pest. Hot and angry we changed to terminal 21 mall for a cool respite! I keep warning tourists because we saw a European old couple falling into their trap and we could not help because we are tourists not knowing our enemies from nearby...?
relaxing. just get on and relax and see the sights along the river , very cheap to do this and get rewards at the end of the trip , with the exp[experience you have jut done
ordinaire. if you dont want to take the special water taxis just take the regular up/down river ferry,cheap as chips and a great breezy break from bangkok fumes
The landmark in Bangkok. A long but muddy river. you can see it at most of the places when travelling in Bangkok. The best place is just take a river cruise and you can enjoy it day and night

A refreshing break from traffic jams!. Whether you hire a long-tailed boat or ride the Chaophraya Express Boat, a ride on the river gives you a glimpse into another part of Bangkok life. The river is still very much a means of getting around town, and I think it's also a great break from the stifling traffic jams to feel the river breeze. Hopping on and off the boat is in itself a small adventure (if you have a stroller, though, you'll have to fold it and carry it on board; it helps if you have extra hands. Definitely not wheelchair accessible). If you can get a khlong tour, that's also highly recommended.

Good experience to see canal. I have join a sightseeing short tour of the canal and is quite an interesting trip if you have nothing to do in Bangkok. I go to the pier by BTS train and drop off at saphan taksin station and straight to the pier and there are a few stalls selling the tickets for the ride and they called it "long tail boat" and it took about one and half hour trip. It started from taksin pier and passing through all the riverside hotels ,grand palace and wat arun and entering the small canal to a small floating market called Tanglin Chan floating market and along the the narrow canal , you can see the thai way of life living by the canal from old and new buldings and finally back to the same pier. And also see the slow moving commercial boats carrying goods as a form of transportation. A very good memory trip.

pleasant way to get around. you can hire a private longtail boat for about 1500 Bt per hour or you can hop on the regular Express Boat River Taxis for 18 Bt and go all the way up to Nonthaburi, stroll around the local market there, get back on the boat, pay another 18 Bt and go all the way down to Saphan Taksin where you can take the sky-train into the centre of Bangkok. On this trip you pass various temples and old wooden houses of times long gone.

chao phraya river. this was our first visit to Bangkok so we wanted to see as much as possible in the 4days we were there.we did a canal trip on a longtail boat which took you down a lot of the side canals off the river, this was very interesting as you floated past many houses and could get an idea how the people along the river live. this trip also took you to some of the main attractions temples and palaces along the river which you could stop at if you wished. we also did a dinner cruise along the river which I couldn't recommend more. we had a candlelit table on the deck of the boat which slowly floated past all the lit up building along the banks. this was a great way to see the palace, and wats as well as the most impressive bridge as you ate a delicious dinner and listened to music. the chao phraya is a most amazing part of Bangkok lifestyle and well worth a trip down.

The fun and fast way to travel in BKK by the river boat. If you are visiting Bangkok and would like to experience the fun and fast way to travel in Bangkok I recommend you to try the Chao Phraya River boat service. You can travel from the city center (Sathorn Pier) to the Grand Palace (Tha Chang Pier) and the other attractions just near by that area. Have fun in Bangkok.

Wonderful Evening. We did the evening river cruise with a buffet style meal. Fantastic from start to finish.The trip was done through the hotel and worth every penny approx £60 each. We were taken to the harbour by taxi, we had a drink on the harbour whilst waiting for the boat,it was lovely to see all the different boats lit up, with bands playing to welcome you on board.Once on board we had a table at the window, there was music playing and the views of the hotelsbridges was beautiful. The food was very good a real good selection, plenty of it, you could get as much as you wanted. We had a bottle of wine which was very reasonable. After Dinner therewas a show which was different! The boat then turns and comes back which gives you the chance to go up on the deck giving you some stunning views. It was one of the best things we did whilst in Bangkok 100% recommended.

You can imagine heaven during all night in a ship there.. Do not miss a night on ship at chaopraya the Great king Rama9 River. You can arrange a nice romance fest and wonderful dinner in chaophraya River.

See how the real Bangkok residents live. Do spend a couple of hours on a boat cruising up the canals and waterways of Bangkok, it's the best way to appreciate why the city was once known as the Venice if the east. It's easy to get a boat at any one if the public piers on the Chao Praya river and then negotiate a price. Avoid the so called floating markets if you can and just savor the sights and sounds of Thai people living their lives on or near the water

Cruising the Chao Phraya in the water taxi. Ticket prices have gone up, but it's still one of the best deals in BKK. Enjoy cruising up and down the waterway taking in the scenery. Service is great, as there are frequent boats whisking people up and down the river. Take the BTS to the Sathorn Ferry pier and wait for the water taxi. You can spend more for the fancier tourist boats.

Well worth a trip. No visit to bkk is complete without a journey up the chao praya river.There are a number of operators that climb over each other to get you onto their boat but by far the very inexpensive public boat at any number of locations on the river is the best.The boats leave from predetermined locations and zig zag across the river with a speed that lewis hamilton would envy. That said, there are few other ways to see the vibrant river than this and it is certainly worth a try.

One of the worlds most romantic and interesting rivers. Chao Prya is full of history and mystique. Maybe the best experience to understand Bangkok is to take a Klong or river cruise from the Oriental Hotel. This is real history . I first took a long tailed boat 40 years ago and have never forgotten the impact of the River of Kings. From the fantastic views of Wat Arun to the life on the river and klongs with the fresh fruit and vegetables snake farms this trip had changed less than many of the touristy tours availailsble around Bangkok.It is worth paying the extra to take the Oriental Hotel BoatLike the Normandy Grill restaurant and Poets Lounge sometimes it is worth paying the extra to go back in time and Auudhya is the real deal. I spent first day of one of my many marriages floating down the river on a luxurious boat to Ayudhya .... This will live with me for the rest of my days. Do it .

Cool and beautiful. Always a nice ride on a boat, whether the regular bus-boats of Chao Phraya express, or a chartered taxi. Breezes across the water are cooling on a hot Bangkok day and plenty of choices of tourist havens or hidden treasures available on the banks. Try a tour from Wat Arun through the canals and the river, or just take the trip up to Koh Kred.

007. Some of the water taxies are like somthing out of James Bond.Some are more relaxing and some are just ferries.They are inexpensive for those with a family and if planned well can provide a good day out.The river is Big!!See the little tugs pulling massive loads see the monasteries. It is a good day out.you can drop off and eat when you want to.

Take A Tour of The River. Sure, it looks a little polluted. But Bangkok was at one point (and maybe still is by some) called the Venice of Asia as it has several smaller canals that branch off of the river. You can and should take a tour of these to really see and experience Bangkok. Several of the temples and markets are located within close proximity to river stops so you may be able to avoid a lot of traffic if you go by boat.

Great River Views. We took a dinner river cruise at night on 7/6/13 and had a great time. The views of all the beautiful Wats, bridges, and hotels all lit up at night made for great picture taking and conversation. The dinner cruise was great with a terrific selection of foods (buffet style). During dinner, great saxophone musician for background music. After dinner, things got more lively as you could indulge in the music of a very entertaining singer and also walk around the ship. Well worth the money and time.

Black & polluted. Diesel motor boats are main culprits as agent of pollution, so much that the usually delicious 'Patin' fish is spared. The once-famous floating market are banned, purportedly for high chance of food poisoning. Nothing much to see along the banks, while nasty odor & diesel fumes fill your nostils. Wonder when will this part of the city reclaim its former glory...

Nice View. It was pretty easy to get to from the MRT and if you would like to make numerous stops, I would advice you to buy the day trip. The guides were helpful but it did get too crowded in the late afternoon.

Worth the experience. If you're in BKK, you must tour the river =) Jump on a local ferry and get lost among the locals, skip the tour operators they charge up way too much! Normal costs 15baht, with a tour operator ranges from 1000 - 2000 baht!!! If you're on a budget, stick to the way the locals do things. Fantastic experience, better done during the daytime as the evening can seem a bit eerie and probably not so safe if something happens. There's a stop that connects to the train, research the name and plan your day according - worth the experience!

Dont miss the klongs.. A half day trip on a long boat coupled in with a visit to the temple of dawn is a great trip. The klongs are a great experience with the houses on each side giving a great insight into river life in Bangkok. Choose any dinner cruise trip carefully. The views are awesome but the food on some leaves a bit to be desired. We went on the Grand Pearl. The boat was good but the food was very ordinary with many guests near us not finishing their meals.

Worth doing. It's worth doing a river cruise of the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok to orient yourself, and its probably worth doing early in your trip. We left it to a bit late, but I'm glad we went.It's a really cheap way to see some of the sights, the amazing hotels, and palaces fro the water.It's a little bit confusing when you get to the ferry terminal. The Chao Praya Tourist Boat has two types of fare. If you get on and stay on board for the trip up and back on the river, about 40- 50 minutes, it costs about 40 baht. If you choose to get off at different locations and explore, you can buy a day pass for 150 baht.Our boat was quite crowded, but that wasn't an issue and we got a seat. It was lovely to see the city from the water. The only think I objected to was the commentary. The PA system was so bad, we couldn't tell whether the guide was speaking Thai or English, or some other language. It was just noisy babble and really irritating. However for the cheap price of this ferry ride, it's really good value. I think some hotels also have boat cruises, which would be an even nicer way to see the river.

Worth seeing, but not as exciting or busy as I expected.. We used the boats to go from the hotel area to the grand palace. Although scenic in places, we did not find it spectacular. A trip into the smaller klongs would probably have been better.
boat ride on the river. Luckily my friend's hotel had a boat service from Saphan Taksin running, so I could enjoy a river cruise on my way to meet him
peaceful place / ride. if you have time do take ride especially in early morning or late evening / night. mandarin oriental has their own boat and the service is available till midnight

For the experience. The view is great but the water is muddy and can be choppy with criss crossing boats/waves. Do this if you must and preferably in the daytime. Night time can be pretty dark/scary (unless yours is a large boat) and there are no life jackets on most boats (even if there are they are insufficient). Over crowding is an issue and one must be wary at all times.

If you want to be in Bangkok, you must do this!. Call it what you want, but you haven't been to BKK if you don't pay your honorary visit to the Chao Phraya so don't even think about missing it and head over to the Saphan Taksin BTS station and hop on a boat for a short trip anywhere. Having said that, don't do as I did the first time and go to the very first place and pay your ticket, do a little walking and asking before you decide with whom to go. As it turned out, the first time I got on a boat I paid like 10X more than I should have paid because I listened to the first vendor. She wanted me to buy a 300Baht 1-hour tour but I just wanted to go to Chinatown which happens to be about 3 stops away. Well, she gave me a "special price" for 150Bahts to take me in a fast boat to Chinatown. Oh well, I was there was but that was the extent of it. The better choice is to go to the line for the local boats, the ones with the big crowd waiting for them, hop in with the crowd (as long as it's going the right direction of where you want to go) and then pay inside according to where you tell the attendant where you want to be dropped off. To Chinatown, and everywhere nearby it would be a total of 15Bahts (about US$0.50) rather than the $5.00 that I paid.If you want to taste the Chaop Praya even cheaper, actually free, then walk to the Shangri-La Hotel or the Oriental and ask for the boat to the Peninsula Hotel across the river. You'll go in luxury across the river and will not have to spend a dime on it.

Excellent. Everyone who visits this great Country must do the Chao Phraya River, we had such fun and a great experience that I wanted to do it every day, but the Wife says once is enough, but I disagree

A Must Do. One must take a ride up and down the river for an excellent experience and various views of the city. I would suggest that take the water taxi the you pay as you go and get off and on at different locations as you make your way up the river ....don't take the express boat to the Grand Palace and pay way more than you should. There are many fascinating stops along the river that one can explore.

Cruising and Boozing. We went on a dinner cruise down the river - the food was wonderful, with a massive selection including some lovely Thai dishes. The tables were then cleared away to make room for a disco, which the students loved. It was a superb way to see Bangkok by night from a different perspective and even the torrential rain at the start of e evening didn't dampen the spirits.

Really nice. Bangkok seems as busy in the main river as it is in the streets, its was fun touring with a long boat. Then going on the smaller channels gives you a bit a of break while seeing a more intimate part of the city. Feeding catfish common while on these boats and its a good experience.

Super long river. Took the Chao Phraya river taxi up and down the entire length of Chao Phraya. The place is wonderful with so many sights to see. Also, if you want to practice the art of giving, buy some bread and feed it to the hungry catfish by the piers.

Wonderful cameo of Thai Life.. Fabulous place to sit and just watch. Watch it from the bank, go for a long boat ride, or catch a ferry. Best, climb to the top of Wat Arun and get a view from there. Boats, piers, dining craft...all wonderful.

If you're not travelling by river, you're doing it wrong!. We did a street-level google map search of our closest ferry stop (Oriental).
