It was the best thing we could have done for ourselves because it's nearly impossible to know where the ferry stops are in some locations - no signs posted on streets. In the busier areas, you can tell where the ferry stops are by the concentrations of people and food! Forget the tourist boat - waste of time and why wouldn't you want the most authentic experience?! Just know that there are regular ferries and express ferries - 20 baht and 30 baht respectively. Even if you get it wrong, you can only get it a little bit wrong. You'll figure it out as you go along. Pay on the ferry to the lady jingling the can of coins - she'll come to you!
River cruise. Brilliant. We stayed on the boat for 3 hours just relaxing and taking it all in - so much to look at. 150thb was the cost.
Relax on the river. Wonderful views and delightful experiences on short or longer trips, courteous and helpful staff and excellent value for money.
A cruise. This is a must do - go either at dawn or dusk - excellent place to be. Go on a cruise and enjoy the food and scenery - excellent.

Definitely worth a trip.. Please don't waste your money on the Tourist ticket of 150 THB. Just stand in line with the people who have one and once you get on the boat (orange flag - stops at all the Tourist designations) buy a per ride ticket. I paid 15 THB and 40 THB for a ticket but its definitely cheaper than the all day pass because once you get off at a tourist stop for the grand palace and/or Wat Arun, you will end up walking for the rest of the day.Save your money and/or spend it on coconut water or sticky rice.
Nice :). The river is beautiful to look at from the top of the Temple of Dawn Wat Arun. Try taking a boat to cross to Wat Arun.

Take the water taxi like a localss. We seemed to always travel via river, either by taxi/shuttling with the locals or longtail boat. Just feels authentic and not staged as many local tourist places are

Chao Phraya River. a very big very wide river. This river has a lot of activity on it with boats ,ferries and barges moving up and down. Yes its quite polluted typical of Bangkok water ways. A cruise especially at night with the lights of Bangkok is a great sight.

Overcharged attraction. Worth It. We choose a one hr ride where we had instructed the boatman to show us the old houses and fishing boats. The water used to spill on us inside during our travel through disturbed waster but was a smooth ride most of the way. We even saw water monitors.
Definitely a good relaxing two hours.

Fun but filthy. Its bustling and gives you a different insight into Bangkok. I loved seeing the number of ferries tearing back and forth. At times the whole river is churning. The juxtaposition of poverty and affluence is jarring. The fish close to the temple were amazing. They were flashing silver all around us as they came up to feed. The pollution is bad, however. Bangkok needs to clean up its act.

Many ships on the river. There were many ships. The nights were quite beautiful. One could see the dinner cruise ships, people having food on the open restaurant housed inside the ship. They traveled at a good speed. The hotels all around the river, especially where the sky train station is, make it all the more beautiful.

COOLING OFF ON THE RIVER. Love to take the local river boats and just get on and off wherever you like or see a spot of interest.Nice cool way to see a bit of the scenery around Bangkok and also to get to certain areas in a quick way instead of sitting in the traffic fumes and noise.

Great way to travel. We took the river ferry every day and what a great way to travel through a big crowded city. The first day we took the tourist boat which cost us 3x the cost of the regular boats. We learned quickly and found that the stops and route were easy to figure out.

Nostalgia. Other than the posh hotels which dotted our short ferry ride from Saphan Thaksin to Chinatown, I soaked up the beautiful old houses along the riverbank. It is a thing of the past in my old hometown. so glad that over here, it remains untouched.Oops! I was so taken up, I forgot to take pictures.A ferry ride along Chao Phraya River is a must!!

Express boat is the way to go.. Beware the tourist boats that have now appeared and masquerade as public river transport. You will pay more than twice the fare and the boat will not stop at all piers, unless you are quick and stand at the back of the boat and warn the deckhand where you want to disembark.There is an assumption made that as a tourist, you are only interested in visiting the tourist spots i.e. Palace, Wats etc and that you are not using the boat as public transport like the locals are doing.

Chao Phraya River. Have been for several cruises on this river. Thai people will put themselves out to see that you have a good time wherever you visit in Thailand and this is no exception. My hubby particularly like the oyster and Pernod soup he was served on one cruise!

Excellent!. Take the boat on the river is an experience to do. For only 15 bhat you can go from the stop 7 to the stop 15, thats move a lot of with wave of the river. Don't forget to wake up before the stop because they dont stay a long time on it!!

Great Experience. Taking the water taxi along the river is a nice experience on the day with good weather. Try not to think about the polluted water. You can buy a day ticket for hop on and off tourist boat for less than $10 (not sure since I took the regular boats).It's crowded during rush hours because many Bangkokians use it as their daily transport to work or to school. Try to do the boat trip early in the morning. The afternoon is too steamy and it runs not that late in the night. You should check the route map prior to taking the boat since there are many boats, differentiated by flags in various colors e.g. yellow and orange. Some boats make all stops, some makes only limited stops. You should check the route carefully. But all boats stop at the Taksin pier so you can always come back to the sky train.

Don't visit during rainy season. It was drizzling and the boatman assured us that the floating market operates as usual unless it's heavy rain. We were taken for a ride, solely boat-ride.. and the river is very smelly.

Cheap way to pass time. Having time to kill before a train to chaing mai, my husband and I rode the orange line boat to the north (N30), to central pier and back again. The breeze is nice, the scenery great and a friendly splash of water here and there. AT 15 B each way it was well worth it.

Another epic city river. Seen plenty of them on travels! This one is a great experience like the others. It's really dirty water obviously but its an experience to go down part of it in one of the boats. Good thing to do if you have 30 mins spare!

Take the local boat!. Take a trip up or down the river on the local ferry boat. It is 15 baht and a great way to see the sights along the river. You can get on and off at many places, they are quick and efficient....have your 15 baht ready though.....the lady doesn't like waiting for you to fumble for change. Refreshing breeze helps a hot weary traveller.

Take a boat. Take a boat and go along the river. I did this trip three times, always got off every stop and it was always interesting. It is also not very expensive considering what you get for the price.

Chao Phraya River. Took the ferry from Saphan Taksin to get to the temples. I didn't pay the 150 bhat beforehand as I wasn't travelling on the river the whole day. I paid when I got on board - only 15bhat to Wat Pho and I got some nice views of buildings, hotels and also Wat Arun temple. It was a very busy river but and it took about 10 minutes to reach my destination.

Quick easy and cheap way of exploring Bangkok sites. Easy to purchase a day pass for the express ferry, cost 150THB then hop on and off at your leisure at the various ports to explore the temples, palaces, monuments, markets and secrets Bangkok has to offer. Dislike that the express day pass service terminates at 4pm daily. But then just hop onto another ferry service.
Nice Trip with Chao Praya Express Boat. Have a wonderful experience cruising the river with Express Boat. The fare of the boat is very affordable.

Chao phraya princess Cruise. Chao Phraya - King of the river...Wow Completely spectacular look everyside u see from cruise with Dining table veg-nonveg Unlimited food...Where as A Cute lady sing a song to make you relax on entire journey...I wish i'd have it again & again...wow what a wonderful night & costumes which welcomed & fascinates me whole night!Thank you bangkok..

Dirty, smelly, beware of the longtail boat hustle. River is very dirty and polluted but aren't most of Asia's rivers? Beware of anyone trying to sell you a river tour or longtail boat cruise. We were offered a 4 hr cruise for 3000 Thai baht and I talked her down to 2000 but we passed and took the local ferry boat for 15baht per person. If you go to the local ferry dock and ask questions you will figure out how it works. Some boat just go across and back while some go down and some go up the river.

Great for transportation. The Chao Phraya River is the lifeblood of Bangkok for so many local people. Visitors don't realise how extensive this water network is with the river and canals covering a major part of the city. Catching a taxi around town in peak times can be frustratingly slow, however there are never any traffic jams on the river. It is one of the easiest ways to travel quickly and inexpensively around Bangkok. So, don't be afraid, head down to one of the numerous piers and have yourself an adventure. The friendly people on the boats as well as the ticket sellers will always help you find the right boat and the right stop for your trip.

Catch the local express boat. I caught the orange flag local express boat from Central Pier all the way to Nonthanburi where it terminates. I paid the grand sum of 15 baht to a conductor on board the boat.The journey took about an hour and it was very pleasant to sit back and enjoy the sights, both on river and the river bank. Yes, the water is quite dirty, however I didn't find it to be smelly at all.At Nonthanburi you can get off the boat and have a look around the markets. It is a very local market and there are plenty of stalls selling all types of goods from fresh food to clothes and everything in between.It was an enjoyable morning's activity and I strongly recommend it for a taste of local atmosphere.

Took a ride on the Chao Phraya Express. Though i would take a trip along the Chao Phraya riding the Express boat. It was a good way to pass some time while in Bangkok. You get to see some interesting sites. Was not very pleased with the pushy way the Boat staff and the pier staff were though. Quite arrogant and rude. Not like other experiences i have had while in Thailand. The worst customer service in 2 weeks i got from them.

Great way to See Bangkok and get around. Be it for getting around or just to see the city from the river, its well worth a look. We took a tour on a long boat that took in some Khlongs (canals) and then dropped us near the Grand Palace. Take a look at real life along one of the many khlongs that criss cross the city. Pick up a guide for the ferries , the different coloured flags signify the destinations and stops, at one of the many piers along the river and it beats the road traffic. Get the BTS skytrain to Saphan Taksin, jump off the train, go down the escalator to your right and a quick walk down to Sathorn Pier where you can catc any number of ferries. Or you can catch the free ferry to the grand Mandarin Oriental (the Raffles of Bangkok) These are the teak looking boats, the peir for them is to the very left of the main pier. Take in a grand lunch at the Mandarin and walk thru to the old part of this amazing colonial hotel, prices aren't too bad and one of the best meals you will get. A taste of 'how the rich people live', at the end of lunch jump on the free boat back to the pier and to the sky train, the hotel is only 5 minutes from the pier.We also took a tour to the old capital Ayutthaya and walked the ruins of this ancient city, then returned on a boat where we had lunch on board. A great day and nice trip back to Bangkok via the river taking in heaps of sights enroute, Highly recommended!

Nice cruise. We went on this river cruise in June 2010. Its a very nice experience and the kids loved it. The only thing is that throughout the cruise, we couldn't stop noticing how dirty the river is at some places and it was very smelly too. But the kids had a great time and enjoyed the ride very well.

Good way to visit Bangkok. The Chao Phraya is a major river in Thailand, with its low alluvial plain forming the centre of the country. It flows through Bangkok and then into the Gulf of Thailand.In Bangkok, the Chao Phraya is a major transportation artery for a vast network of river buses, cross-river ferries and water taxis, also known as longtails. More than 15 boat lines operate on the rivers and canals of the city, including commuter lines. It really cheap. Good way to visit major places of Bangkok.

Needs cleaning. This is the real thing about Bangkok - a big working river with lots of boat tours to see the nice sights BUT the water is not clean at all. I know its difficult to keep a city center river clean but should try more effort to clean it.

great river cruise. It flows south through the nation’s fertile central plain for more than 225 miles (365 km) to the Gulf of Thailand.. The Chao Phraya constitutes a valuable waterway for the transport of the nation’s traditional exports of teak and rice south to Bangkok, though less bulky commodities are now moved overland by road or rail.A river cruise can be taken in front of orient hotel. the cruise will take you downriver and then into the Klongs (canals). There will be a couple of locks to go through and the sceneries you will get to see will surprise you..

Timeless Attraction. This is one of the things in Bangkok I have been doing several times over the last 30 years and it is about the only activity that has not changed significantly since I first visited the city. People who are interested in a river cruise can hire a boat with driver in front of Oriental Hotel. You will be taken past the backside of the hotel to the river where you board the boat. Depending on the route you take, the cruise will take you downriver and then into the Klongs (canals). There will be a couple of locks to go through and the sceneries you will get to see will surprise you. Evergreens among the sights along the way are the snake farm (can skip) and Wat Arun (recommended - best to be visited at sunset). The trip takes about 2 - 3 hours depending on the route and the length of the stops.

Cruise along the Chao Phraya River.... Paid 700 baht for an approximately an hour of cruise along the Chao Phraya River.Nice experience where you get to see houses along the rivers and many of its residents using boats/speed boats to conduct their daily routines. Do this if you have some spare time.

Good and attractive. waiting for the ship was painful. the table we got just near the kitchen. we did not like it.
Liked the cruise and the dinner.
Worth a ferry ride. Well worth taking a morning ferry ride up the river, enjoyable and showed various aspects of the city.
feeling the old and modern Thailand. Charter you'r own boat and ride it in the afternoon just before sunset, everything looks wonderful. This should be a try if you have time to explore Bangkok.

Family vacation. We enjoyed the view of the river from our hotel room and and the outdoor breakfast area right next to the river where we could feed the fish. We also enjoyed a dinner cruise with fabulous food and a view of the city lights.
Take a river taxi!. Take a river taxi - travel with the locals for 10 baht and see the city change from old town into ultra-modern skyscraper city from the big river!

Van Kessel bike tour includes a trip across the river. The bike tour was so much fun and ended with a trip up and across river to return to the start of tour. The river and views of the city was very fun and definitely something you want to do when in Bangkok. Take the bike tour with river excursions for a fun filled day.

peace in bangkok. if your in bangkok and don't know how to escape the busy city just head to the river. the river is wide and flows fast. there are many bridges to cross and some walkways along the banks of the river. in one pleace near khao San road there is a park where people dance and skate and meditate. very nice

Different ways to look at it. Well, as a tourist attraction, it really isn't worth taking a cruise or anything as the rive is quite dirty. But using it for transport is another story. Most places are brilliantly connected with the waterways. Just hop on to the government boat and get off at any pier closest to your destination. It is really fast and efficient.
nice trip to cool down. the boats run frequently and it is nice and cool on the river, especially when bangkok is hot. unfortunately it closes too early to take a late boat
Lovely. It was an interesting taxi boat drive on the Chao Praya river for me as first time came here. It was very busy but fun as I have never experience such a thing like this in my life.

One of the best experiences in Bangkok. It was very exciting for me to enjoy the steamer ride to China town. It was my first ride, and it looked very similar to a train, where it stopped at select junction, and then again ferried passengers to the next stop. I was also amazed at the dinner cruises. It was wonderful to find a full open restaurant inside the ship.

Busy!. Wow, crazy busy river. Boats coming from everywhere, i don't understand how they get around in this chaos, but still they manage. Thai people are amazing! The boats are really handy to get around to the temples and Khao San!

Ride on water to temples. Love the boat ride to temples. Its pretty amazing experience. Needs to be very careful and hold it tight when the boat speeds. And might not be a good idea to go if its raining.

river cruise. Loved river trip , don't buy from river boats that approach ,as the stuff is very expensive , also drinks are warm , buy drinks before younger on boat from the operator , buy the guy that drives the boat a drink hell make your trip , also tip him
Beautiful.. The river is so amazingly beautiful. Especially in the night time. Take a long tail boat ride, the free ferry to asiatique or the river pass. Either way its a must!!

The River Of Life.. You can see some of the most beautiful sights of Bangkok if you take a boat ride down this awsome river. Especially when the dawn is breaking and lights up the beautiful structures and bathes them in golden light.
Must see. If you have 2-3 hours you have to take a taxi to nearest pier on the river and take a trip by the river. It is extremely cheap if you use public boat 15-20 bath.

Awesome klong rides. We used the klong service to visit the wats. Also did an awesome trip to the Asiatique village and back using the free boat service from Sapna Taqsin. We also took a private boat trip and was definitely worth it for 1000 Bahts.Overall the klong rides are a must during your visit. Highly recommend !!
A confortable way to travel in bagkok. Take a boat in the Phraya River Is the best way to go to the grand palace, and get a different view from the city
Worth the experience. Thought this was relaxing, didn't agree with other reviewers re the smell. When we got off found this lovely little market place well worth a visit
Bus by boat. This is a really busy active river and getting the ferry is a great way to see the city and the sites from a different viewpoint. Cheap and convenient river cruise.

coming alive. I love going on the Chao Praya River with local boats. They cost a few penny, one feels part of the city, feels the bustle and hassle, smells the smells and enjoys the ride with monks, business people, tourists, market sellers and kids on their way to school
Excellent view. Take a boat or ferry and sail up and down the river. Excellent view along the river. Great for photo taking. The extreme contrast of Bangkok can be viewed along the river.
Must see!. We loved the boat ride on the river. Many great picture opportunities as well as a great history lesson. We enjoyed seeing how the people lived as well as the shopping available.

Sucked in! We were walking to Chinatown, we fell for tout's line... Chinatown closed until tonight (no it wasn't). Nicely dressed older man advised us to take a taxi to a pier and for us to take a longboat to the floating markets, then to be dropped off at Wat Arun and to then tuk tuk back to Chinatown which would then be open. Cant believe we fell for it. The longboat man was sullen, rude and at the end asked for a tip - no way!! There were interesting sights to see, so we still had a great afternoon and a wonderful late lunch at the floating markets. The river was dirty and smelly and I would think a lot of sewerage discharges directly into it, via the dwellings on the canals. Expensive, at 2500baht for two of us inclusive, plus disembarkation fee of 30baht at Wat Arun and he wanted a tip! Having reported that we were duped, it was expensive and the operator was rude, it was worth doing once. Just keep your mouth closed in the longboat, such is the state of the river, you really wouldn't want any splash into your mouth.

Something you have to do....!!. This a great way to get around and see the temples and the water taxi is so inexpensive, although very crowded. You should also rent a boat and take the canal and floating market trip. Expensive but worth it for one time and something you should not miss.

Beautiful.... It's a must you get on a boat on the Chao Praya river, bearing in mind it divides the city in two and it was the center of life back in time. It also connects some important touristic points in Bangkok, such as the Grand Palace, Wat Arun, the National Museum, a lot of MRT station points and Asiatique. Asiatique is a commercial centre with lots of restaurants, pubs, shops and activities to do, so recommendable to go on a sunset and stay for dinner.

The hop on hop off tourist boat is great. I think that this cost 150bht for an all day ticket and we really enjoyed being able to get on and off as we wanted. It was very hot whilst we were there and it was pleasant to sit and get some breeze and just watch the amazing scenery float past. This gives easy access to Wat Arun, The Grand Place, Wat Pho, Chinatown and many other places.
Nice to see. I was on this river every day from my hotel, its very dirty so not the great experience I expected but was good to see, I rathered sitting at the hotel watching the boats go by.
Bloody big lizard. Did a long tail boat tour of the river and canals, good fun for an hour and saw about a half dozen massive monitor lizards on the the canals. Worth a go.

Luncheon River cruise is wonderful.. We toured the Old City, Palace and enjoyed the Sun City lunch cruise in a nine and a half hour day after pick up at our hotel.Wonderful buffet style lunch and cruise back into Bangkok.Clean, well-presented comfortable dining. Would highly recommend.

The life blood of Bangkok. This river is awesome , I have travelled to Bangkok many times, I am always drawn to this huge powerful river. The ferries are so cheap and a great way to get around the city. Always something going on and the river is an easy way to get to some amazing temples ie Wat Po and Wat Arun..

Riding the River is a great experience. The best is to take the regular ferry on one of the stations along the river (15 bath). The long tail boat thing is a scam to me. They charge you 800 bath for 4 people ( if you are lucky, for they can charge as much as 2500 in some cases). Plus they take you to some filthy river side-lanes and show you floating markets that aren't even frequented anymore by hardly any Thai. It is all made up for tourist (Disneyland).

easy access to temples. this place was recommended by a friend to get to the Grand Palace and other temples. I was not disappointed since this is an easy transport facility. and the boat fares are affordable. you can choose for a day pass or a single route ticket. the boats are also clean. the river itself is likewise clean. it's also nice to see around the private boats of some five star hotels. My son and I loved the river ride.

Interesting. Take the long boat tours with caution. The tour along the canals are revealing: an underbelly of the glitter of Bangkok. Our kids could see the value of not polluting. Beware of the Snake Park — a rip off and absolutely depressing to see the appalling conditions the animals (snakes, crocodiles, bears, monkeys etc) tolerate. Take the boat but skip the stops.

Take a trip down the Chao. The Chao Praya is Bangkok's life line and a trip by public ferry, long tail or private boat is a must. You can do a trip through the canals to see the Venice of the East, or go futher down stream to the wonderful river-side garden restaurant Suan Thip. More comfortable in the cooler months.
Main Artery. The easiest and best way to get around Bangkok...15B the length of the ferry ride...value yes ..less people and very quick and convenient

A lesson in the great economic contrast. This is in fact a small river, though it is traditionally the most important river for central Thailand. What you'll see is the great contrast on the banks -- between large luxurious hotels and condominiums for the rich, and the filthy, dilapidated dwellings on stilts for the city's many down-trodden. On the river itself, this contrast plays out too. There are the luxury cruise restaurants for tourists and then there are the overcrowded commuter boats with standing-room only. One thing one might appreciate around the river is there is often a wind, giving a little relief to the city's chocking heat.

Hop on the boat and enjoy the ride!. We bought a day ticket and spent the day getting on and off the boat to see the sights (the wats, Golden Palace, Chinatown to name a few). Very efficient service and much cooler on the river than in the city. There are plenty of places to stop near the docks and get a cool drink or something to eat (and meet the locals!) Be sure and take your camera - there are lots of traditional long boats and funky watercraft to see. We also did a canal ride in a longboat, which was really interesting.

Travellers delight. Spend a good half day or more just up and down the river. Get on the Orange flagged ferry at the Saphan Taksin ferry terminal ( avoid the more expensive blue boats and resist the long tailed boats unless you want to hire one for 3 hours at about 400 baht ). This River will explain to to you so much about life in Bangkok without a word being spoken. The People , the industry, the history, the culture. Soak it up and enjoy the ride.

Chao Praya river near "Shanghai Mansion" hotel + Chinatown really won us!. Initialling didn't take to Bangkok but mercifully endured & was won over by this relaxed 4 storey, 1920's chinoiserie themed hotel.Shanghai Mansion is a funky and stylishly ambient oasis in the middle of Chinatown.Within easy walking to the great Chao Praya river - and I'm not fit or younger - with cooling river breezes, exotic water traffic & sights, adding to the value filled hotel. Don't fear the aisles and alleys of stalls in between. Everyone is well mannered and everything flows with considerate mindfulness even the hysterical road traffic..amazing drivers! Our standard Mei Hua room -extraordinarily affordable exotically comfy with good working everything esp. cooling in rooms. So great++ for the cost. Try larger, more luxurious rooms with more to offer if you wish but we were out so much to need more.Think Suzy Wong and more when the bar cafe/club restaurant get it's Shanghai 1960's makeover.

Cultural experience. The life of Bangkok really does revolve around the river. At the very least, ride one of the ferry routes (the tourist boat has a commentary in English). The best though is to ride one of the long-tail boats, touring the khlongs (canals).

Polluted but interesting. There is a lot of hustle and bustle on the river and definitely worth checking out, but I was practically choking on some of the fumes from the small boats. We were on a tourist boat which had an decent guide with an audience that seemed too exhausted from the heat to do much responding to his questions to the crowd. It is a great way to get around to the major temples of cultural sites of Bangkok though, as I found walking in this city in May to be unpleasant to the point of being intolerable.It was interesting though, to come from a polluted east coast American city and witness a harbor scene more full of trash and filth than my home.

One time experience. Whole journey takes 1 - 1.5 hours. Each person costs about 400 Baht.Enjoy the sightseeing on the boat, feed fishes with bread (20 Baht per packet) and buy souveniers from floating river market.

Nice boat ride. We tried both the common boat ride, and we hired a boat to take us around. Was refreshing to be on a river and alot to see around there. Easy to get to grand palace and the temples from the river and avoid hours in trafic. We took the skytrain to the first top of the ferry

Good value taking the tourist boat. Bought the river cruise tourist boat (exit no. 2 at Saphan Taksin BTS station) for unlimited hop-on and off at the different piers (150 Baht adult, 80 Baht kids) which is really good enough to explore the various attractions along the river. Had my 2 young boys along so exploring wasn't really on the agenda, just to bring them on a leisure river cruise from Sathorn Pier and hop off at Chang Pier to visit the Grand Palace. Take the seats on the left from Sathorn Pier for nice photo opportunities of Temple of Dawn as well as to avoid the morning sun which makes sitting on the right a bit hot. Along the main road going into the Grand Palace you probably will bump into people wanting to sell you the idea of tuk tuk ride to one other attraction + brief stops at souvenir/sale stores. Since they only charge 40 Baht for the trip, and it was not compulsory to buy anything from those stops, went on one round trip (Big Buddha, Chin Factory, Sale outlet). It was our first tuk tuk ride in Bangkok and the boys enjoyed this more than anything else. Eventually picked up some souvenirs at the souvenir shop in Chin Factory (which isn't that expensive) as well as local foodstuffs from the sale outlet. Just avoid the expensive stuff at all cost! They won't force you to buy so there is no pressure to make any purchases.

good way to explore all major sights in bangkok. the good thing is its connected with the bts line coming from siam ,n few yards from thaksin bts station .once u reach the ferry port u have many options line normal express or the private tours.i personally took a normal ferry as wanted to get down n see wat arun n grand palace ,the boats look quite long n r fast mode of travel .the minimum fare is 20 baht.I got down at ferry station no. 8 ,from here u can see the sleeping buddha which is just oppsite n the grand palace a lil away .From here itself u can take a ferry across to the other side to visit wat arun for as low as 3 baht.Worth a visit to see the old n new architecture on the way.

Afforable and relax river boat ride. Took the Chao Phraya River boat from Central to Tha Chang to visit the Grand Palace. The boat ride was cool and relaxing, thumbs up. I opt for the single trip tourist ticket at 40B instead of the 1 day tourist ticket at 150B. Alternatively you can also board the boat and pay directly to the ticket lady that was walking around shaking her coin case.
Overrated. There's not a whole lot to see, and its extremely hot out on the river. Only the temples and palaces look good at night, but you can also see it on land...

Take the tourist option for a cruise. Well what an experience in the express long boat that I thought was 30 mins up and 30 mins back. Well the boats are coloured coded and I took the commuter express by mistake. For 150 baht I ended up doing 2 hours plus cruising. Great value for money and saw more of the river. Absolutely fascinating. I eventually decided to get off where the Army camp stop was at Kiak Kai and waited about 25 mins and picked up another express to get back to Central. It is extremely easy to access the location where the ferry commences. You take the Silom BTS line from Siam Central and get off at Saphan Taksin. Then walk down the stairs (sign telling you which direction) under a covered walkway and there you are at the ticket office. My only suggestion is to clearly ask which boat to catch for a 1 hour cruise. If you have time and happy to explore then you can basically get off at any location and wait 10 to 15 mins Monday to Friday and 20 to 30 mins Sat and Sun for a return boat. It is a great experience. You dont need to do as part of a tour it is something you can do for yourself..despite me not checking it is very easy trip to do. have fun on the river and dont forget to bring your camera and water bottle.

Real Thailand. The river boats take you up into some of the few remaining canals flowing into the Chao Phraya river. The canals are are putrid in places, but you see the flimsy huts built out over the water and children waving and splashing about. It's the real Thailand, not the tourist orientated attractions normally visited.

River Cruise. We had a dinner river cruise on the Chao Phraya River: the dinner and organization were good, and the view really amazing: i strongly suggest this trip. You can book the trip in many hotels and travel agencies.

A bit boring. We took a boat and paid 1500 baht for an hour trip across the canal on sunday afternoon.the floating market was a dissapointed experience because we only saw 2 of them (boats). I guess you must go early. The river is not that dirty compare to rivers in my country. Make sure you seat at the middle if you dont want to get wet
Great. We used the river ever day to get about. The bus boats are quick easy and cheap. The river is a "must experience" when your in Bangkok.

Best kept Bangkok secret. When we first came to BAngkok we didn't have any idea about its river but we discovered that it's massive and very nice. Actually it's the best place where to stay, nice view and location. We took the boa to the Grand Palace and it was a discovery, not to be missed.

Excellent evening. It was my last evening at Bangkok with family and couldn't have asked for better way to end a trip. The team was there to help us and make us feel so special from the time we entered the cruise was fantastic and something that you can't explain in words

Definitely a must especially with children. Kids were thrilled with the orange flag ferry boat we took from Central Pier to Thewet. It was pretty crowded but most of the passengers got off at the stop for the Grand Palace. Water does tend to splash in but just some drops. Watch for fish popping in and out of the river, tons of them. At the Thewet stop people feed the HUGE fish with bread or fish food which you can buy for BHT20 to BHT50.

Just went for a sundowner drink to watch the sunset. This is quite a nice way to watch the sunset over the river while drinking an evening cocktail; in my case a rather large Long Island Iced tea. The river front location was very busy due to many dinner boat cruises departing from this area. However, this only enhanced the overall experience watching the boats being loaded with people with many of the crews being dressed in either sea farers cloths or traditional dress. In addition to the dinner cruises there were a lot of river taxi's and some very large tugs pulling huge boats laden with goods up and down the river. A wonderful way to spend a couple of hours away from the heat of down town Bangkok Next time we may actually try a dinner cruise too.

Chao Phraya Tourist Boat. Took the boat for 150 baht a person. Unlimited rides. But if you want to see the river and take photos, I suggest you take another type of boat. Here's why. We got on the boat that was already fully seated with tourists. So we had to stand. They continued to let people board so in the end, I think there were about 30 with no seats. If you are standing near the back of the boat, you could still get a view of the river. If you are standing along the aisle, not only do you block some of the seated passengers in the middle section, most average to tall people won't see much except the water and nearby boats. I saw some boats that are smaller, slimmer and seat about 20. You definitely get a good view on both sides of the boat. They are faster too.
Nice river ride. You should try seeing Bangkok by boat once. From the river you can see all the temples and palaces. And a nice cool breeze feels great!

Historical. This river carries a lot of history for this city and any special events in BKK are often carried a long this river. We were fortunate to spend a day going up and back down the river admiring famous monuments, Grand Palace etc.

Night cruise is the way to go.... Lovely at night on a luxury cruise. No heat, fuss or muss. Decent food and entertainment for a few hours. You can see many landmarks along the way and meet nice people. 1800 baht all in or go during the day if on a budget.

Beware of tourist traps.. NEVER trust the taxi driver from the front of the hotel. Never ask taxi drivers for suggestions. Find out from the hotel or a local. Eg: A trip across the river is 3Bhat. They will try to get you onto a 1500Bhat "cruise".

Magnificant Views!. We took a FREE boat ride (by Asiatique) from the BTS station near the Chao Phraya River to the Asiatique Riverfront shopping center in the evening (6pm). The views were great! We also took the dinner cruise on Chaa Phraya River at night. The light along Chao Phraya River was amazing!

unique experience. A must-do item. the river is much cleaned up as compared to 10 years ago. a unique way to travel around. if you are adventurous, use the normal express boat, else buy the more expensive tourist ticket.
Great trip. This was a great night lovely buffet staff we friendly. It did take a while to drive to the boat the night lights we wer fantastic

Cooling down. The express boat gives go unlimted transport possibilities for 150 BHT and the views from the river are the best, especially in the evening, when everything is beautifully lit, from the temples to the river cruise boats!

Cool, fun, and cheap!. Take the express boat to travel up and down Bangkok - it is cool, and much cheaper than taking tuk tuk or taxi! Best way to travel between points of interest in the old section of Bangkok.

Easy to go places. The river gives easy access all over Bangkok: to the riverfront hotels, places around the city and different restaurants without traffic jams.
The best from my opinion was to cross Chao Phraya to visit Phra Pradaeng by bicycles. This is Bangkok off the beaten track.
Nice to view the lovely sunset. Nice to take a trip along the river. The only problem is the smell & garbage in it, the same tourist guide trash it and they don't care

Good to have but not a MUST SEE. Went for the cruise + Dinner during our trip. We had quite a high expectations of this cruise given the good reviews.However, we were quite disappointed as the scenery ia not exactly fantastic. Maybe it would be better if its during the day time where you get to see more things.As for the food, its a real disappointment. Quality is not as good as we would have perceived. Would definitely not come back again

Good for first timers. Brought my parents for this river cruise. Do not take the packages from the tour agencies located at the Saphan Taksin BTS station. Go to the ferry pier which is located right below the BTS line, walk towards Shangri La Hotel. Is a totally ripped off if you get the package from the BTS station. 2000 baht per person if you get from them, But at the ferry pier, 2000 baht for a whole boat to yourself, regardless of how many pax you have. Our package was inclusive of the trip to Wat Arun and a floating market. There's a pier fee of 30 baht at Wat Arun and 50 baht per person entrance fee which is not inclusive. But all in all, the cruise was pretty good. We sailed through people's house and could see children playing in the river and all. Interesting.

Bangkok River. We just ride the boats t cross the river to the other side of Bangkok for THB3.00. We didn't ride it along the river way anymore since we saw it's kind of dirty anyway so there's not much to see.

Fascinating to see the river life!. This is a must! Great way to get about and see an alternate side to the city living. Fascinating how life is along the river. Don't be conned by the 'express boat' option offering 40THB one way to the palace... Get the orange line for 15THB!

Dine and dance. We booked the full cruise with our guests from abroad also and enjoyed the good food with drinks and enjoyed the dance by watching over the river side lighting, tall buildings and nice over bridge.
Ok. The river is dirty but some of the bridges are beautiful and the ferry is very cheap and convenient.
Great by boat. Went on a nighttime cruise on the "River Star Princess" with a very entertaining hostess, live band and great food.It's great way to soak up the sights along the river.
A must see. Take a guided tour and see BKK from the river, its amazing. From small sheds to luxury hotels and temples.

gr8 adventure. I liked everything that happened on the boat. I hate water transport simply because i cant swim but then I was here to tour, my fears couldnt get in my wayI liked the way the person on the Microphone would explain to us the history of all the views on both sides and i shd say she did a great joband the sights are great

The beating heart of Bangkok. EVerybody who rated this as "poor" or "terrible" should have their heads checked or should learn more about Bangkok instead of allowing themselves to get ripped off by any street taut. This is the heart of Bangkok, it takes you from one side of the city to the other for a few baht, there are many different ferry stations that are worth visiting, just pop off and go around the area (I strongly recommend the Wang Lang area, near the Siriraj hospital where the king is hospitalized) or go and feed the fishes at the Wat Rakang ferry (it's the next ferry to Wang Lang, but you can also walk there through the small and crowded streets besides the wang lang market and area). Ignore the 500 Baht trips and take the ferry and the water taxi, it's as good as free.

Use local boats. You can easily get to most of the tourist attractions using the river. The local boats are the easiest and cheapest way to get around (you just get on board and pay when the ticket person makes their way around)
You also get rewarded with a wonderful, breeze, a glimpse of local life and great views

Great way to see Bangkok, and very cheap. Jump on one of the local water ferries, for only 15 baht you can travel from one end of Bangkok to the other via the river, or just as an alternative to using a taxi or Tuk Tuk. Always plenty to see on the river, and it's so much more fun traveling with the locals than on one of the tourist boats. However, if you also want to see life on the canals, you can always hire a long boat for an hour or 2.

Amazing transportation. If you daily commute by car, taxi, trains, then do the river way for a change! Its simply amazing way to see Bangkok and all that it has to offer.Do not be too excited with the Baht150 pass, for you may never know when you want to take the tuk tuk or the train afterwards. Besides you can only see so much on a given day & that for me did not even add up to Baht150. I mostly did the river way, walked & hardly tuk tuk then head back to hotel using the nearest Train line.It was very relaxing should you have a seat or when standing, for the breeze & sights takes the stress of you. Though it gets pretty crowded daily. I will travel on the Chao Phraya again...
Long Boat Ride. Nothing special, over crowded boat doing river run between different points on the river. Priced well. Nothing special but quicker than a taxi.

Get your own boat!. We hired our own longtail boat, took a bottle of wine, and cruised the back canal's past the everyday riverside people and houses towards dusk, catching the sunset as we hit the main river on the way back. Was a very cool trip.

good cruise. Good cruise loved it, excellent food and well conducted and value for money. Especially the night cruise... lights everywhere. also like river boats during day an ferry service across river... good value.

Love Cruising the river. One of my favorite things to do in Bangkok is to sit back on the local ferry and just watch the city unfold - because it is so cheap if you see something interesting just jump off and go explore from there. I have found some amazing things that way - don't know if I will ever be able to find some of them again, but such great experiences

What a waterway !!!. The life blood of Bangkok are it's patient, tolerant and by world standards fantastic citizens / subjects and the Chao Phraya is theirs and your own gateway to cheap, fast and fun water transport to so many exciting places, restaurants and markets, in the city, you name it. Who would take a taxi to sight see riverside when you got this right ? And at night, even more beautiful. The waterway as with any poor River that is unfortunate enough to be surrounded by such a large population is a little polluted, but hey, so is the Thames. The river boats range frm expensive (luxury floating restaurants, to inexpensive fast and convenient tourist operators. My Tip, go with the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat company (big blue boats), when I went you can get an all day / night (not too late) pass for 150 baht ! Unbeatible Thai service. I came her 13 years ago and there were so many people living rough but happy literally on the River side & out above the River on make shift houses, but seem to have been moved on as they had vanished when I visited again in 2013. Where did they go ? I wonder. I hope they were looked after.
Bangkok by river. Nice to take a boat on this dirty river to see Bangkok like it is, some beautiful sights in an ugly city.
Nice way to see some popular places of Bangkok. I went 2 times along the river with the cruise and found nothing much special. The tour guide is so friendly and fare is cheap.

Great views of the city and of many temples.. A nice way to get a view of many of the famous places and sights, either on a dinner cruise boat or on one of the open boats that offer tours during the day.
Chao Phraya River Cruise. It was perfect, the food, the experience. But we went into a traffic jam as it was a rush hour on the way to Chao Phraya River.. We also enjoyed the Thai Dance presentation.

great views. We loved the river cruise and the views of Bangkok. Got off to see the grand palace, but beware we got fooled that we would not be allowed in due to wearing shorts. We were taken to so called other places then the jewellery Scam. So make sure you see the palace and do not be scammed like us.

IN BANGKOK, YOU MUST ENJOY EVENING with Dinner. What a lovely river ride....You need to pay 1500 Thai Bhat per person but worth to spend. Though so many visitors and very crowded place but in the same way very well manage by the cruise management. You will get table number at the time of purchasing ticket. Spectacular night view. Lovely ALLA-GRAND dinner. Worth to go...

Nice way to see Bangkok. the river is a pleasent way to see Bangkok, it's very cheap and you can hop on and off at a lot of places.
There are different kind of boats you can take, at every pier there is a description of them.

All about the experience. All about the experience, seeing Bangkok from the Chao Phraya River, the flow of traffic, the sights, sounds and smells are all a part of the Bangkok experience. Seems like "everyone" takes a river tour, it cost less than nothing, takes about 2 hours, you see how the local people live, the river commerce, alternate views of some of the temples from the river, all in all a good experience.

Only the local boats, many "tourist traps". As regarding the river it's magnificent & a must visit. But many tourist traps to make you get the express boat or a private one.. First i asked the taxi to get me to the local boat, he took me to a blind end road & told me here it's "the express boat" i told him i need the local one, he was very bad tempered & went to the street near by & dropped me in the middle of the street saying it's almost here to get the boat & left. I found myself pushed to take the private boat (as a tourist & with 4 persons & a child in the heat) they said they'd give me a discount (instead of 800 they'd give me for 600 BAHT !!!), I knew they were thieves, i tried to explain that i need the local boat but they said this is the only way to go for now.. (they were very rude).....Well, i took the private boat & tried to enjoy the trip by the river anyway. The scenes of temples is great. I do really recommend all people to go & visit.. But write down the address in Thai before going , not to make taxi driver takes you to where he wants & not what you want..

Take the local ferry!. Of course, you can partake in one of the many, many available river cruises if that's your thing. If you just want to have an affordable and easy look at the river and surrounding area as the locals would, then hop on one of the state-run ferries.They were ridiculously cheap and take you as far as the outer northern limits of Bangkok (as we found out by staying on too long!) if you want to go there. And don't fear, a return ferry went back the other way about 15 minutes later (phew).Great little way to get around and of course see the large river at a very cheap price.

Historic & Interesting. We booked this tour through the tour desk at Ibis Bangkok, after reading the history of Bangkok which said that it used to be called "The Venice of the Orient", because most of the commerce and travel was done on the river and canals - called Khlongs.The tour took nearly 2 hours, commences at the river and after a couple of kilometres, turns into fairly narrow canals in the very old part of Bangkok. Many of the dwellings on the banks were obviously quite old. The trip was very interesting and I guess our only complaint would be that the lady boat driver and her young assistant could not speak any English, and were unable to explain to us about various sites of interest. This is part of the city that a lot of tourists don't see, but when booking, try to get someone to speak your language.
Its very stunning. I love the river cruise, the attractions like wat arun, can be seen from the river cruise.I had dinner.It was awesome
River Cruise. When one travel to Bangkok he/she must at least go for a dinner cruise on the Chao Phraya River. The beautiful skyline of BKK is just breath taking. Remember to bring a good camera. LOL
Try a river cruise with your loved one. And she/he will practically beg you to marry him/her. Very romantic in the sunset and well worth the money to chose a good boat.

Get the Express Boat much cheaper that a Tourist boat. Get the express boat that only costs 15 Bhat a single trip otherwise you will pay 40 Bhat for a single trip if your caught by the tourist sharks.

The Real Bangkok!. One of the MUST visit attraction!
In Bangkok, the Chao Phraya is a major transportation artery for a vast network of river buses, cross-river ferries and water taxis, also known as longtails.
We took the ferry to the Wang Lang market! One of our favorite spot in Bangkok.

Life Blood of the City. The Chao Phraya River is a fascinating and vital experience. It is part home, part transportation, part business, part touristy, part local. Everything you can imagine happens on the River. Seeing rice barges floating empty twenty foot above the water and then returning with the waves lipping over the edge is unique.

Living on the river is a fantastic experience. We have been living roght on the chao praya river for the past 2 years - out of central bangkok but with traffic the way it is we are often better off than people moving from one end of sukhumvit to say sathorn. ( yes of course there is a jam packed sky train but sometimes it rains .....)We live 15 minutes drive from ISB ( not inside Nichada ) in a very beautiful complex with 240 degree river view.If you are thinking about relocating to bangkok you should think about Nonthaburi.

Dinner Cruise. Took a deightful dinner cruise n the Chao Phraya River-right outside the Shangri-la Hotel. Local entertainment, interesting food, excellent service. Sights were beautiful-everything is lit up.Lovey, relaxing evening

My first experience using a boat for daily commute. U gave seen rivers in many countries that are used only for tourist purpose but this one was used by locals to commute daily. The best part was the local boat with orange flag. It was cheap and I could travel among the locals. The view of skyscrapers around is also stunning.

Worth Doing. We headed right for the pier, and found a booth with some signs in english..but we still had no idea if we were buying the correct tickets. We paid, then we were quickly motioned on to the next boat without any tickets...and off we went. We seemed to be on a "tourist" boat, with an english speaking guide. We made a few stops, people were getting on and off and tickets were being collected...we kept avoiding eye contact since we had no tickets to show. We got off at the final stop, having no idea where we were. We waited for the next boat, hurried on, walked right past the ticket takers, again, eyes down. This time we were on a "locals" boat, stuffed in with the local students, residents, and other lost tourists. This boat did not stop at our original stop. Instead- it stopped across the river. We had to buy a ticket for a few cents for a ferry to take us back to our starting point. The ferry docked upriver from our original stop - so we had to walk thru alley ways to get back to our driver. In all - we had a blast!

Fun by long tailed boat. We hired a long tail boat for around one hour to travel through the canal-ways off the main river. Getting on and off the boat is not for the faint-hearted!We saw a variety of homes on stilts, people selling their wares from boats (far less staged than the floating market) and stunning views of the Grand Palace.No trip to bangkok would be complete without a long tail boat trip.

My Favorite Part of Bangkok. Every trip to Bangkok I take a day to ride the river ferry. Not only does it cool you does, but you get a real feel for the city. The khlong tours are nice as well, but the Chao Phraya is the heart of the city. Hoping on and off a river taxi is a must experience in Bangkok.

Excellent way to experience a lot!. My time in Bangkok was pretty short, so I was advised that this boat cruise would be an excellent way to see more of the city while, simultaneously experiencing some of the culture...I LOVED IT! During the boat trip, we had the opportunity to experience some of the local fruits popular in Thailand...and drinks! :) Overall, just a GREAT experience....highly recommended for the traveler who has limited time.

The real way to see Bangkok. Travelling by local ferry along the river was the best way to view some of the most interesting parts of Bangkok. The Grand Palace and various temples were impresive and travelling by river was relatively cool in this hot period of the year.
It just a canal. Basically not much thing to see, this is a boat trip to see the old part of Bangkok.The thing that I disliked is the whole canal is quite smelly.

unique experience. For better experience, hire better boat. This is the main river og Bangkok, People use it for sightseeing, tourist attraction to transportation. The experience will be different depend on what boat are you on.for romantic dinner, hire the Chao Praya boat cruise that sails at sundown (you can buy the tickets online). For transportation, the boat is quite cheap compare to BTS and metro - but don't stand near the edge sometimes water might washing in the boat. Some tuk-tuk driver will offer you a boat trip on the chao praya. They work for local boat owner. the boat is relatively small compares to the transport boat and look quite dangerous to me. So if you want a convienient river trip - say no to them. They will try to persuade you, but just keep saying no and the will eventually give up. Hope this help.

Very convenient. It's admirable how the Chao Phraya River is used not only for tourism but for affordable and convenient public transport for the locals. Bangkok public transport is so easy for both locals and residents and they managed to maintain order, system and cleanliness. When we got off the Chao Phraya Tourist route and transferred to the public routes, the personnel manning the docks were all conversant in english and were able to assist us effectively. Save for a few garbage near the docks, the river is clean and devoid of any bad smell.

Excellent Half-day fun. Keep it raw and keep it little unplanned. Unless you are on a honeymoon and very conscience of crowd around you, in that case get an exclusive boat, else get a day pass and you will get access to an express boat that allows you to hop-off and hop-in at any pier. If you are short on time, get off at Pier N5 (Chinatown) and N8 (Wat Arun). You can try local delicacies at China-town and shop shop and shop. Wat Arun is a very different temple to see. At pier N8 you will be dropped-off at the opposite side and you would have to take a ferry to the other side. It costs just 3 bhat and very convenient to take.

The tail boat cruise tour. The canal tour was worth a cruise. It took around 45mins to complete the cruise. Only negative is boarding and disembark from the long tail boat due to strong wave. Recommend to try.
River Taxis. River Taxis are a great way to see the city without getting stuck in the road traffic if you are going to Kohsan Road.
The Venice of the East!. To experience the real Bangkok a long tail boat ride on the Chao Phraya river is a must. See a different side of Bangkok on the side channels of the river!

Dinner cruise. Many evening dinner cruises to take a night trip up and down the river, food average but well priced, views great, good for sight seeing Bangkok at night. Done 3 cruises now always a pleasant evening out and makes a change from a restaurant.

The Lifeline of Bangkok. You haven't been to Bangkok unless you travel on the Chao Phraya River. It's beautiful by day and at night they have dinner cruises that are great. Can't wait to get back there.
Fun way to transport. Lovely and scenic ride to attractions. Skip the tourist scams and go straight to the pier, you buy your ticket on the boat and shouldn't be more than 20 baht.

unexpensive and fast. you can enjoy the river, the view, the wind , and seeing bangkok from another side.
This is an experience to be done, and it s much faster, cheaper and easier to reach a lot
of places and attractions. To be recommended with no hesitations.

Choose for fast transport, not for fun of river cruise. I was short of time so I chose the chao phraya river cruise costing 40B for half hour to have a look at bangkok skyline across the river. The river is polluted, not clean, and burnt diesel fumes that emanate from ferry boats are suffocating. Please use this only as mode of trasnport across attractions near river bank. You will see five star hotels, wat Arun, Rama IX suspension bridge lit beautifully in one view of eye at night. This will not fulfill experience of refreshing cruise over river that will relax you at the end of hectic day.

Take public boat over Chao Phraya River. You can take the public boat over the Chao Phraya river. This is the fastest way to go to What Po, Grand Palace and Khao San Road. Express boat cost 15B per ride.

definately worth a few hours. Go to one of the piers, smell, sense and take in the activities of Bangkok, and jump one of the river buses up or down the river, I personally love to go the island in Nontaburi.Long tail Boats are another option, here a trip to Thonburi with it channels and gardens is real nice, personally a trip with the luxurious vessels provided by the oriental and other top hotels are fantastic strongly recommendable even a day tour to the city of Adhyothaya.Enjoy

Cruising BKK's big river. Chao Phraya River - what a great way to see the city and some of the most beautiful sites. Use the express Boats cruising up and down the river for 15 bath per trip. Try not to get confused when arriving at the pier as there are several companies operating different types of cruises and services. Ask for the express boat entrance and pay as you go on the boat! A fantastic way to see BKK from a different perspective. forget the Mississippi - it's the Chao Phraya River in the Angel City, y'all. ;-))
Ordinary big city river. A narrow long river, as usual in any big city (please dont even compare with Yamuna)! Shuttle service throughout.

river ride. there are 2-3 kinds of boats on the river, one is the public boat which takes 15 baht and stops at every public peir in which the locals travel. the other one is the tourist boat for 40 baht geared at only tourists and stops at selected stops.the last ones are the private chartered ones on which you can customise your ride.the views of bkk city in either of them are great speccially in the night when the city lights up....the river is although dirty but the ride is a must when in bangkok.

The River of Kings - The Chao Phraya. Great river activity at all times, all sizes and uses vessels engaged in river traffic. Always enchanting to be on the river in river taxi or restaurant boat or sitting riverside at hotel verandas to watch all sorts of vessels plying the river.

Muddy Old River? Murray Head was wrong, this is great. One of the best ways to explore the historic center is the speedboat on Chao Phraya River. It costs very little and as the name already suggests, it is speedy.You will most likely stand between other tourists, locals, and the occasional monk. If you stand close to the sides, you will get wet, but in Bangkok's fantastic climate everything dries quickly (Germs? Who cares? Have a Singha and calm down).You will see an amazing array of traditional temples, modern and ancient residential building, mega-hotels, and river life from the small longtail boat to bigger ships. Fantastic - you will not often have so much fun & travel value for so little money.

Amazing Views. Excellent river tour and not too expensive. Best to go around sunset as you get fantastic views of the Temples. Tour lasts about 45 minutes and you navigate through some of the rural waterways on the outskirts of the city

A tip more than a review!. When you go to Saphin Taksin Pier it is easy to get confused between the different ferries!If you want the cheapest you need to catch the public ferry, the Chao Phraya river boat with an orange flag, you purchase the tickets on board, and they will give you change if you need it, it costs 15 baht for the trip whatever the distance, at the pier is a ticket office for the tourist boat at 40 baht per trip or 150 baht for the day,hope this helps the confusion I experienced. if you plan a short trip then the public ferry is the cheapest alternative, if you plan lots of trips then consider the day pass, but remember it is v hot so you may find you have had enough after 1 or 2 stops and seeing the attractions.
Easy transport option. The boats from Saphin Taksin pier are cheap and frequent. Easiy to get to many places along the river, just hop on hop off as you wish.

quick tour. if you are traveling in BKK and got a spare half day of nothing to do, taking the boat trip from Sathon pier up to Nonthaburi pier is probably one of the very good thing i would like to recommend. I cant really recall how much it is but i'm pretty sure it's less than a dollar for that 2 hours memorable trip (one way). from there, you'll get to enjoy the Bangkok life along the river as well as have a brief look at some beautiful places such as Wat Arun, Wat Prakeaw (the Grand Palace), Rama VIII bridge and Nonthaburi City Hall.Once finished at Nonthaburi pier, you can also enjoy some delicious food and traditional Thai dessert such as Tong Yip, Tong Yod, and Foy Tong at the market which it's around 5 mins walk from the pier)

Fun khlong ride thru the canals. The river itself is a major thoroughfare in the middle of the city. We enjoyed a klong (long tail boat) ride through the canals and up the river. Amazing to see the flood levels from a few years ago and the new works to avoid future damage to properties by floods. Great big catfish in the river, and homes on stilts/poles line the canals. Enjoyable for all ages!
Klongs. Highly recommend a klong(canal) tour but just book your own and negotiate your terms with the guys at Taksan station (at the pier) we went for one hour and that was long enough.

Not the Seine, but don't miss the riverboat system!. Definitely not so picturesque as the Seine, but still a great way to see Bangkok from a different perspective. The riverboats run like a water-train. Each boat has a different colored flag, denoting which "line" it is. Once you figure out the basics, it's easy and inexpensive.

Chao Phraya River winds through heart of Bangkok. The Chao Phraya River meanders north to south, through the heart of Bangkok. Handling a good deal of the people traffic, and flows past many historic sight. Water tends to be a muddy brown. Best to avoid falling in. I did someone swimming in it day!. It is a useful way of avoiding the street traffic and very pleasant way to get were you need to go. Take one boats described below as far as you can and then get off at the nearest stop to where you need to go. Then jump on of one of Taxis or tuk tuks.There are multiple river boat lines plying the waters. As well as freight & cargo boats, I noticed three main passenger lines. On is the tourist sightseeing boat (ticket about 140BHT from most piers), this allows ticket holders to jump off at any of sights explore and jump on next passing boat to next attraction. Second is (also) tourist line (known as the Blue Flag Chaophraya Tourist Boat (CTB)) this also stops of at most of the piers cost about 40 BHT. There is guide on board who will point out the sites over the speaker system, as you go by. 3rd is the regular commuter traffic Orange Flag, used mostly by local people, you pay on board - 15BHT. The conductor will come through rattling a coin box. Pay when they reach you.more info can be found at the boat website. English version here;http://www.chaophrayaexpressboat.com/en/home/

Chao Phraya River. Chao Praya River begin in Nakhon Sawan Province at the confluence of rivers Ping and Nan, it is a long river around 300 km, along the river have important cities like Uthai Thani, Ang Ton, Ayuthaya and Bangkok, where the river is mainly used as transportation.

Nice trip away from the busy centre. By taking the boat from the Thaksin pier under the BTS station, you can escape the busy traffic of BKK just for a few baht.For just a couple of box you can enjoy the river from the boat and see a totally different aspect of the city.You can take the boat all the way to the notorious Bangkok Hilton prison, and get a glimpse of the surroundings before catching the boat back.

BOATS. What a busy river, this is the busiest i have seen. The boats to get across the river are cheap as chips and it is a lot easier than you think just be careful when attending the boat stations there are some people trying to sell you private speed boat transfers but there is approx 1000% mark up on these prices. Very easy to navigate, you ouoldnt fancy a swim though!!

Chao Phraya River. Took a river cruise on the Chao Phraya. The duration was 2 hours with an excellent and a very tasteful dinner spread. The cruise ship had a upper and lower deck. The lower deck was air conditioned whilst the upper deck was open to air. Both the decks served food. European/continental and Indian food on the lower deck. The city view from the river was very good in the evening/night...some temples and kings palace looked very beautiful. recommended for families atleast once
using the river as transport. this was good and the guides on the boats are really knowledgeable and good. the boats are on time and you can hop of at any pier! very very nice!

Not to be missed.. Bangkok's atmosphere and action all to take in whether it's a long boat, ferry or cruiser. Best to make the trip during the day and night to observe the lit up features which are many. The evening dinner cruise is a must for all romantics !
Grand Pearl Dinner Cruise. I like the scenery on both sides of river and the food served on the cruise. However the cruise can improve by giving introduction to the landmarks on both river sides.

Another Experience to see Bangkok Landscape. Like : the patin fishes when we threw bread , they are so many.  Can see the grand palace and wat arun from the riverDislike : the river is not too clean :D

great cruise experience. when you come to bangkok, don't forget to try the cruise in chao phraya river. you can purchase the one day unlimited ride for only THB150. It's cheaper than when you purchase the one way ride to grand palace that will cost you for THB100 one way

Easy to travel using regular Express Boat Service. We have been to Bangkok many times, and most recently, this Spring. We learned very quickly to avoid the tourist tuk,tuk, the private boat hires and the organised Tourist Ferry by the Chao Phraya River. These are all too expensive. You can catch the normal express Boat ferry's (orange flag is on the bow of the boat). This is used by the Thai commuters. For 15 bahts (2013 charge), you can travel one ferry stop or 30 of them if you want (the first stop is Central Pier, the 8th stop is the Palace and Wat Arun, the end of the service is at Nonthaburi where there is a very cheap market... clothes, goods, etc). The last ferry that will bring you back to Central Pier (by the Saphan Taksin stop on the BTS Skytrain), is at 4:30 pm from Nonthaburi.Going the whole length of the service is over 12 miles of sightseeing for 15 bahts (instead of the 200 baht you might pay to use the tourist service). While there is no commentary, if you pick up one of the tourists maps available at all visitor centres in Bangkok, the river is marked with all the stops and all the tourist attractions for you to follow. Each stop has a corresponding number on the shoreside to that on the map so you know when you are at a particular stop of interest, to get off the boat for a look around.If you only want to do one or two sight-seeng stops on the river during the day... you are still not going to spend more than 60 bahts. You generally don't have enough time to do much more than this so you are wasting 140 bahts on the tourist boat (hop on and off).The river is busy, with lots of barges and ferries - it is lovely on a sunny day and well worth considering for a cheap day out.

I live next to it. Verious things to do, Newly built is asiatique, a mall with almost everything... only negative is stuff there are kinda expensive.
You can take boat tours... Dining cruises... visit Wat Arun and many more.

Great day, easily travelled at your own pace. The full-day river pass is a great way to spend a day in Bangkok. The boat guides are very informative and try to be funny and engaging. It kinda works? But for real, there are so many sights to see along the river, and you will receive a little guide book with your pass puchase.

You should come to see!. I took the taxi down the stress.its leaves from Central & Asiatique Pier (5.00.p.m.-10.00.p.m.). I paid f for 150 which is a cheap way to see the numerous tourist attractions lining the Chao Praya River.

Not to be missed when weather is fine. You want it to be a nice day and travel outside of peak travel periods ie rush hour. I wouldn't recommend babies on board. Have small change and know how to pronounce your destination as the ticket seller will ask on board.If travelling long distance take a drink to sip along the way.Great video opportunity. Link to information provided in this review

Super easy and cheap. Hey fellow travelersIt is super easy and cheap to get on the Chao Phraya RiverBoats take you from one part of the city to the other in no time and for very little moneyI think one day pass is only 150 Thai B !! a bargain Definitely a good way to go around without being sweating or stuck in traffic specially at this time of the year !A must to do in BkkEnjoy the ride !Henya

Chao Phraya Tourist Boat...cheap as chips day out.. This boat leaves from Central Pier (9.30.a.m.-4.30.p.m.) & Asiatique Pier (5.00.p.m.-10.00.p.m.). We purchased a day pass for 150 BHT (AUS$ 4.65) which is a cheap way to see the numerous tourist attractions lining the Chao Praya River. You are provided with a small handbook when you purchase a ticket, which names every pier & all attractions at that stop. The thing I like about this service is, you can get on & off whenever you like, no need to rush through a stop because you're scared you'll miss the boat, it goes back & forth ALL day. Chinatown is worth a visit, you have to do a little bit of walking but, so worth it-get off the boat at N5 (Ratchawongse Pier). River City shopping complex is a must see, hop off the boat at N3 (Si Phraya Pier)...hope you've got a load of cash, very expensive upper class venue. Very busy river with all of the boat traffic & a very dirty river, a real eye opener. Enjoy.

Very cheap Boat If you know how much the price should be... from Saphan Taksin BTS. just go to the central pier. There's three gate to access the boat. just go to the middle gate with more queue than anothers, Please be remind, ignore all help and offering for rent an exclusive boat. i think Its too expensive (average 150 baht per person) because is nothing different from regular boat. If you take a boat with an orange flag on middle gate. The cost is only 15 Baht per person. dont ask the staff how much, because they will ask you to pay 30 baht.
The Venice of Asia. A must see for any visitor, Get a long boat to take you into the suburban areas of Bangkok, or have dinner cruise and see the night beauty of bangkok .

Best way of getting around in Bangkok. Every time I go to Bangkok I spend a few hours on the river. The Chao Phraya Express is a brilliant - and cheap! - way of getting to visit the various tourist sites and temples which can be found along the river. A must!

Riverfront Asiatique. Great place to shop, but bargain. Great restaurants and great foodAvoid Calypso Cabaret as it is the worst form of rape on decent Theatre. Theatre is a great record of the History of what was a port and Bronze Statues of its heritage and History. Some of the original features have been maintained and are supposedly going to be restored. The Place is great for Music and 9E Restaurant and Bar is great for that on wed to sat with a duo called Melody Walk. Flan O'Briens is also a good food and music venue. There are many more but I can't remember their names. Needless to say you will be entertained and fed no matter where you are from. There is also a free Boat from 4 Pm from Sapan Taksin BTS station to the Riverfront. Well worth a Visit and it does get packed. Only comment. Could stay open Later to 2Am and I say that as a resident within a stones throw of the venue.

The boat ride. It was brilliant, we took a ferry ride from Sathorn to go to Grand Palace one morning. The river life is interesting, you can see some poverty of old houses, places by the river, then with a blink of an eye, you see luxurious malls and tall Hotel buildings. There are temples along the Chao Phraya River, so the ferry ride is interesting and a great way to get from A to B.

take a river bus for cheapest trips. catch a river bus (at the end of the sky train) which all the locals use for a cheap way to experience the river rush hour!Ive taken the tour longtails too which take you into the klongs and more of a tourist experience
LOTS TO SEE.. Fast, convenient way to get places, also very cheap. Good to see the city from a different perspective. Lots to look at and pretty busy.
Venice of the East.... Try a cruise of the khlongs in a longtail boat, you won't ever regret it! It allows to see another, lesser known yet very charming side of Bangkok.

Chao Phraya cruise is a must do. A trip to Bangkok is incomplete without a cruise along the Chao Phraya river. I took an additional step, I wanted a hotel so that I can stay right across the river. I booked Ibis Riverside and I got a river facing room, from where I could enjoy the beauty of the river at different times of the day. Ibis has the coffee shop on the rivershore, so if you chose Ibis and don't get a river facing room, you still can enjoy the river view from the coffee shop. I planned my sight seeing through cruises along Chao Phraya. This plan has the following advantages :a. saving time and stress from the terrible Bangkok road traffic b. almost 70% cheaper than a land transport. There's a all day pass for the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat at 150 Bahts / head, with unlimited rides, hop-on and offs, which is extremely economical. The map that comes with the ticket has details of all the places to visit along with corresponding river pier to alight to.c. all the 'to see' places are accessible from the river frontd. the cruise on the river Chao Phraya is itelf a very nice experience
A river of life churning through Central Bangkok. The Chao Phraya River is like a huge artery winding its way through Bangkok - great to get out on a longtail boat at disk to watch the city light up.

A great way to escape the heat and still see the town. At high tide, it is a great way to see Bangkok without its traffic, ah well there is a bit of traffic on the river but it is still much better than all the honking on the roads.

Nice ride through calm river. - Chao Phraya river runs inside the city dividing Bangkok. Water itself is so bad and maintenance was not good. Lot of people use boat service on this river to travel for work.- There are plenty of options available for a ride in Chao Phraya River Cruise boat service, private long tail boats, Tourist boats, Night dinning cruise etc.,- I used the tourist boat service which cost 80 THB for a round tirp, I heard there are some tourist boat service which cost around 150 THB for a round trip service.- The private boats cost from 400 THB per person.- Regular transportation boats cost from 3 THB to 20 THB I guess.My suggestion would be to take a tourist boat service in the evening which is really nice.

Best way to see Bangkok. The best way to experience this "attraction" is to get an all day pass for 160 Baht. That way, you can hop on and hop off the boat all the way down (and up) the river. It is basically a water taxi.

Great if you're going somewhere.. Take the public boats, typically 15 bath and go the whole trip. Coloured flags indicate where they stop and piers are numbered, ie pier 8 will take you to the palace. Fares are collected on boat, conductor circulates constantly. Tourist boat charges 40 bath, not getting much more. Great at night, and watch the tourist boats move around like a fashion parade, light and music at full bore.
