If you ask the question, they will always steer you to the tourist one. From the main pier, most things are reasonably well accessible.

My two cents worth.... As countless others have said, this is one of the best things one can do in Bangkok. The cost is negligible and you can get on anywhere along the line with little waiting. The best things in Bangkok are just serendipitous....get off in an unfamiliar area and explore....this water route makes such exploring easy!
River traffic. After Wat Po, take a walk down to the river, great just to watch boat traffic. Boat taxis and long boats for canal tours available, very cool and very interesting!

A motorway of a waterway. We used the hop on, hop off shuttle on the river which is too fascinating for words. Vessels of every description, each with their floating story to tell. The contrast between apparently shabby, little,wooden houses on stilts built in the river with a backdrop of gleaming temples. Hustle and bustle non-stop. A wonderful experience.
Nice and relaxing. Take a boat(Red and white)- its only 150thb pp and takes U all over Bangkok sites,U can Jump Off and on wherever U Want!

Great way to see the sites. buy the day pass and hop on hop off at all the tourist attractions. Was quite busy on some routes but the breeze in your hair the smells and sights was a great way to travel. keep your mouth closed in case of splashes the river is dirty. We did see locals swimming though. The private hires of long tail boats was expensive so try and double up with others the canla visists are a muts
The best thing we did in bangkok. We took a private boat tour along the river and loved it. Its was easily the bets thing we did during our trip and would highly recommend it.

nice view. it felt like in the village. you cross the river with a traditonal boat. from this river, you can see the view of Wat Arun temple with a great light from bottom to top of the temple. the lights from the temple made the river sparkle.

Good for Transportation. For me this is more a way of transportation and not really a tourist attraction. The river is VERY dirty and there is not a lot to see as other reviewers have said (at least that is my opinion). But it is a very good way to get to different tourist attractions like the temples, Khao Sam Road, Chinatown, etc. We bought the tourist pass that cost 150 Bahts and you can use it for the whole day, so if you are planning a lot of stops this is the way to go.

Take the Day Pass and Enjoy the River. Traveling along the Chao Phraya River with the day pass allows you to stop at any of the dozen stations. It's a great way to get around to several sites in one day.

Best way to go to most of Bangkok's attractions. Best way to go to most of Bangkok's tourist attractions like Wat Arun, the Grand Palace, Chinatown, etc is thru this famous river via the water taxi. Very cheap mode of transportation. You can buy a One Day Pass for THB 150 if you plan to go to multiple places. You will be given a map and schedules of departures at each of the pier stations. Be at the lower end of the boat if your stop is next because they disembark pretty fast, less than a minute in some, so you might miss your stop and especially at night where stations are not well lighted. The river has become dirty because of human activity but not stinky. At night, it could be very romantic especially if your dining in one of the hotel restos along the river. Better yet try the river cruise. To start your river tour, go to Saphan Taksin BTS along the Silom line from there walk towards the river and buy your pass at the Central Pier(Saphan Taksin Pier).

Nice experience. Cool breeze, nice express boat ride to Wat Pho and Wat Arun!
Comfortable ride with an English speaking guide on the boat who tells you which Pier you should get off.

A great way to see so much. Get the sky train, get the boat with a yellow flag, costs so little, stay on until the palace. The captains have it down to a tee setting down, taking off at each wharf. Real people on board, workers and holiday makers all together, feel a part of it! Safe.
A great first day in Bangkok. A fun ride in a longtail boat! Kids swimming, we fed fish, a woman pulled up with cold beer- couldn't have been a more fun excursion on our first day!

Wondrous dragon of light!. Like the vaporattos of Venice, you can spend whole days riding on various water vehicles up and down this marvelous river enjoying life on and next to this main artery of Bangkok! I recommend spending at least one day here and a day on the canals.
The river ride is a MUST. Locals and tourists alike get to share the panorama of sights along the Chao Phraya river for less than 25 cents US.
Relaxing. Very scenic whilst on boat. We took subway to a stop further south to get the boat to gravel up to see the grand palace.

The Main Artery of Bangkok. This is the place from which to see Bangkok. Use the public river boats to go up and down the river, and hop off when you reach an area you want to explore. Our concierge at the Sheraton Orchid did an excellent job orienting us with the city map. The river boat fares are dirt cheap. Walking the neighborhoods and riding the river boats are the way to see the real Bangkok.
Big city river. As you could expect from big city river is dirty and stinks.Also transport needs some improvement.Good views at the city though.

Efficient transport, but lack of quality explanatory signage. Given how much this is used by tourists, I would think that they would improve the explanation of the various 'lines' and their respective destinations. I had researched this online before visiting, so I knew which colour of boat to take to get to the stop I needed - otherwise I would've been completely lost!
go there!. its the best way to see Chao Phraya River is Just get onboard and pay small change to travel the river. Cheap, great .do not lisen to anyone

Make sure you hop on a ferry- even just for a short ride. We went on the ferry with our guide Joker from the stop at the Shangri la down to The Grand palae. It;s a great way to arrive.I don't know if I could have spent hours on the river, but it's very interesting to be on it for a little while as it's like a busy highway just with boats not cars. Good to see BKK from a different angle.Quicker than being stuck in traffic

Bit grotty since everyone just chucks all their rubbish in it, but a nice experience on the boat. Very cheap to travel by the boats, which is a good way to get between north and south of the city. Let-down by the fact that the boats stop at approx 6pm so you can't go out for the evening.

Good choice if you want to go sightseeing in Bangkok. The boats running up and down the Chao Phraya River are cheap and fairly quick. There are two different kinds of boats for transporting passengers. The one is the Tourist Express Boat (40baht), and the other is the local boat which stops at every pier (15baht). Both are good. Just get on the boat and pay for a ticket once you are on the boat, a lady will come around and collect your fare.I think China Town is Pier 5, where you can buy lots of cheap goodies, also in bulk if you wish, but be warned, a lot of the stuff is really poorly made.The Grand Palace is Pier 8 or 9. Avoid the Tuk Tuk drivers, who will swear to you on their mother's grave that the Palace is closed today and will offer to take you elsewhere (usually a tailor or a gem store). The Palace is always open (unless it's a particularly significant holiday).Pier 13 is Khao San Road, where all the backpackers and budget travellers hang out. Worth a visit for the cheap food, clothing market and atmosphere.A day pass, if you are going to do a full day travelling up and down the river sightseeing costs R150baht.This is Bangkok, a city of millions of people, so don't expect the river to be pristine and clear. There is a night market called Asiatique alongside the river. You can get a free boat to the night market and back (think the boat starts running at 6pm) from the Central Pier. Take the Sky Train to Saphan Taksin, get off at the station and walk down to the pier which is to your left as you exit the station. If you cannot find the pickup point ask one of the ticket sellers at the pier.There are also many river cruises at night which offer dinner and a beautiful view of Bangkok. There are also other boats that take you up and down the river for sightseeing. Just ask at the Pier or go to any travel agent for details (there are a couple at Saphan Taksin station).

Buy tickets ON-BOARD. Don't be ripped off by people trying to sell you tickets at the pier. Just get onboard and pay small change to travel the river. Cheap, great photo opportunities, you avoid traffic and feel a nice breeze. Excellent.
a must see for nightime.. An amazing river, especially at night time. We went on the Chao Phraya Princess cruise and the sights of the temples we saw as the sun went down were a memorable moment.

Interesting if a little smelly at times!. We took a longboat tour on the river and in the canals. Extremely interesting. Loved feeding the catfish at one temple and enjoyed looking at the wildlife (water monitor!) and waterfront housing which ranged from rich to very poor.
A GOOD WAY OF TRAVELING. It's really practical taking the taxi boat (there is also an express one) and a quick way for discovering other places. Whatsmore, it is very enjoyable and cheap!!!

Watch out for the long tail boats. You can use the river as a main thoroughfare when traversing the city. Use the local ferry taxis which take you to most tourist and interesting sites. You can use the slow service which stops at nearly all the piers or semi-fast or express services with limited stops. Then there are the cross river ferries which are very chepa. Next come the private boats linking hotels with other areas and then the long tail boats which whip you along the river at breakneck speed( sometimes too fast!!) A great waterway very scenic when travelling past the palaces and temples.

utilize the transport system of the Chao Phraya river. Since I stayed in the Khao San area during my stay last week, the best transportation was via the boats that travel along the Mae Nam Chao Phraya (Chao Phraya river). Tha Phra Athit was the closest in Khao San, and from there you can get to different ports, specified by a port number in the Bangkok map. Careful though that some of the ports are not accessible by some of the boat. The best boat to take (as a tourist) if you're on a budget is the orange one (with the orange flag), which costs 15 Baht on all ports. There are tourist boats that cost 100 baht, or buy an all-day ticket at 150Baht.Sight to see along the river: The Wat Arun temple (get off at Tha Tien and take the ferry that goes to the other side 3 Baht), The Wat Pho and Grand Palace is accessible via Tha Tien ferry.The Rama VIII suspension bridge, get off at Tha Thewet bridge since the Tha Rama 8 is unavailable (not sure if due to renovation or it is permanently closed). Tha Thewet is kinda far to the bridge compared to the Tha Rama 8, you have to walk to Thanon Samsen from the port and walk along the road and turn right when you reach the bridge. Make sure to go up and cross the other side of the bridge as this is the only side you can get a nice view, aside from the view when you're in the boat, of course. If you have time, wait until it gets dark as the view gets better when the bridge lights are on.Accessible via the river ports:the Wat temples (mentioned above)Asiatique at the Central portSa Tha Ni Saphan Taksin (Saphan Taksin Station of the BTS Silom line) is accessible at the Central portYaowarat is accessible at RachawongseKhao San is accessible at Phra Athit
Little dirty, but nice to tour. Convenient way to get around the city during high traffic.Very easy to jump on a boat and quickly get accross Bangkok.Will be nice if its cleaner :)

Very Humbling experience!!. This is definitely worth doing as you get to see what real life is like in the klon's of Bangkok...some stunning sights but also some eye opening sights, the heart of BKK that covers all parts of society!! Be prepared to be visited by a local floating market trader to buy some goods(with a small commission paid to boat owner) but hey thats BKK ha ha!!

Don't get a taxi - enjoy a real Bangkok experience. When it's really hot do you really want to spend time haggling for a taxi when you know they will rip you off in Bangkok anyway? - they always do. Take the Riverboat. It's about 15 Baht to anywhere and the service is fast and frequent. It will take you to most attractions including Grand Palace and Khao San Road. Look it up - you can visit most places on your Bangkok itinery. And it's fun and most importantly - cool. A lovely way to travel feeling the wind blowing and getting some fresh air - better than suffering pollution in the back of a tuk tuk stuck in a notorious Bangkok traffic jam. Take to the water.

However You Experience It, Experience the River of Kings!. You have to go some miles up the Chao Phraya from Bangkok to experience the kind of National Geographic photo-ops that are still readily available from the hotel balconies of cities along the Ganges, Tigris, Yellow, Nile of even the Ping, but the Chao Phraya is still worty of its name "The River of Kings". While I had reason to fear it greatly when filling sand bags to hold it back during the 2011 flooding, on every other occasion, this river has easily connected with my psyche. It will connect to anyone with a soul. It is wonderful on Loy Krathong, amazing when the Royal Barges come out, and breathtaking on the King's 60-year-reign celebration, but it is great on any day of the year. Just go to Phra Sumen Fort and look out on it, or take a water taxi (take the whole route for fun!) during the day, or a dinner cruise, or any one of the excellent tours of the river to see how greatly it still impacts Bangkok life. Climb up Wat Arun's central Prang and look up and dwon-river a while. A boat tour up-river to Ayutthaya is another way to do so, and on that trip you will find your National Geographic moments. Day or night, rain or shine, the Chao Phraya is a must-see in Bangkok!

Great way to see Bangkok. Although we kept getting funneled onto the "tourist" boat (blue flag) with limited stops, this was a great way to see Bangkok. We went from Central Pier to No. 13 several times. Although the ticket booths are only open til about 3 or 4 pm, you can buy tickets on the boat after that (boats run til 10 pm). There were other boats (with different coloured flags) that stopped at different piers, but we never made it onto them. Still, the view was great and for 40 Baht, a great deal. Way better than taking a tuk-tuk and way cheaper.
Smelly and dirty. Bangkok rivers are just so smelly and dirty. Even though it is nice to go on a boat, I didn't like the smell of the water. It stunk.

Water taxi. One good way of seeing Bangkok is from the river and the cheapest way to see this is to catch the water taxi, for about 15 baht about 30p you can travel along the river a fair distance, there are plenty of stops along the way at all the main sights & attractions

It symbolizes Thai culture. Like most country, Thai civilization also originated near the Chao Phraya River. Despite being dirty, its worth taking a ferry tour across the river. You will find popular hotels situated near the river. The famous Grand palace, Wat Arun and the temple of the Reclining Buddha are also situated near the river. So it is easily accessible via river boat. Though boats are available till 6.30 pm.

Don't expect a clean river, but still an enjoyable view.. This river is probably as dirty as you would expect a river that runs through the city to be. There are many boats all along the river for transportation and recreation. The windy path has a wonderful presence throughout the city, so if you aren't staying at a hotel where you can take in the view, I do recommend enjoying a sunset dinner/drink to watch it flow.

Dinner cruise experience - Amazing. Very nice arrangement for the cruise...already allocated seats on dinner cruise booking which is really nice as you get your personal space to sit, eat and enjoy the live performance/DJ.Very good food too...and you get the option to try the food on other deck as well if you want to.

Do it. Paid 350 Bhat (Aud 10) for a river taxi day pass. Excellent value. Take the underground and overhead rail to the pier and purchase your ticket there. Do not listen to any of the touts who may approach you in the street, you will be ripped off. You can spend a full day visiting the various sites (Wats, Temples, Royal Palace etc). Purchase a map first.

Excellent. A must watch if you are making a trip to Bangkok....need to get to the Chao Praya River and head for any of the cruise offers that are available...I invariably take the Grand Pearl River cruise and have always been happy with their service.

another way to see the city. 150 baht for a day cruise along chao phraya river.
another option to enjoy the city. short trip but worthed.

Great. This place its amazing, you can get a boat for about 500 baht per person and they will tour you around i.e.floating market and flower market.
Brilliant afternoon, it's good if you get early as it will be busy and very hot in mid-day.
Great experience.
Great to cruise along. Not badly priced 150 Bahts to cruise up and down jumping on and off where ever you want to see different Temples. It's nice and relaxing too.
Nice !!. It was really nice to cruise the river as it will pass by the different tourist attraction of the city of Bangkok...we even wen to the dinner cruise to see the sites at night......

Bangkok's lifeblood is this river. Transportation of people, raw materials and manufactured goods...you see it all on this river that flows threw central Bangkok. We really enjoyed setting by the river in the morning an watching the fish jumping and all the activity of the river while we eat breakfast.

can be quite hairy. Don't expect a calm river. This one has lost all aspects of serene karma. Go on it to see a heaving mass of river boats of all types with loads of character but expect very rough water. Sometimes, depending on the craft you get on, it can be quite hairy - like getting on a bucking bronco! Super to see some aspects of this fantastic city or on a journey back from the ancient kingdom
Chap Praya River. You can travel by BTS to Taksin station and catch the orange flagged boat for 15 bhat for any destination. The easiest way to travel to Wat Pho, Wat Arun and the Grand Palace.

Love it.... Compared to the other packages (THB1300-1,400), we got our Chao Phraya River Cruise ticket for a cheaper price (THB 800 per person) at Riverside, Bangkok. Apparently, it was because of Songkran festival. Thanks to a friend who helped us do the last minute booking. From trip advisor's reviews we found out that for a limited time in Bangkok, this is the best thing to do, so we did. Indeed, it was good. We came early without expectations...through the help of a friendly crew, we get a good spot near the stage. There were many people from different countries, bu there were locals as well. There were several choices of food from local to Japanese and Western food. Food was great. The crew checked our table from time to time to refill our drinks or to take unused plates. We were entertained by a local band. It wasn't that great but we still enjoyed it. The other guests were in fact enjoying it more, probably because they were just simply enjoying it. We were a bunch of critics :-P We had a chance to witness Bangkok at night far from the busy streets. It was worth our time...and money...check out www.riversidebangkok.com. It is highly recommended. We have seen the other cruise and we believe that this one is really good. What i like most about it is its open air deck.

Integral part of Bangkok. In a city on a river, it holds many surprises and insights into the lives of those that live close by! We took a private long tail boat on the River, but also thru many of the little canals. we ate at a floating market. delicious and CHEAp food. Very charming look at the city.

Wan Fah cruise. I took a rivercruise in the evening at sunset. It was a very nice experience, but the food could have been warmer and tastier. I chose the thai menu but maybe the seaffod menu would have been better. They did not serve wine by the glass, only bottles and they were very expensive!!
Dirty, but fast. To avoid the crowded traffic of the streets of Bangkok, it is very convenient to use the river to get where you want. Fast and effective, with a nice view from the seaside.

Not great value for money. We were promised a Thai banquet and excellent view of all of the pretty lights along the river. Having been kept waiting at the harbour for nearly an hour we were heralded onto the boat and shown to our table. Buffet was announced open and there was an almighty rush as everyone queued up for food, that frankly was not worth the wait. Yes, there was plenty of it and lots of choice but none of it particularly good and the free for all nature of service sort of dampened the appetite. The high point was the band that were very good and did a great job of creating a party atmosphere. Aside from the good view of the golden palace at night not much else to see.

Great way to navigate the city. Teriffic views! The ferry service on the river is fast and reliable. And very inexpensive. Opt for the express boat service (orange flagged boats) instead of the tourist boats which are decidedly more expensive and make fewer stops. If you have the time, take it all the way north to the last stop, Nonthatburi. This little subub has a great local market and is much less touristed than downtown.

Great fun a must see. Get a ferry ticket for 40 Bht a journey or 150 Bht for the day, hop on and off the ferry along the river. Great sights to see but do be carful as the ferry moves from the pier very very quickly.
Manic and wonderful. A very lively river. Total bargain - approx 25 Baht (60 pence) for a trip right up the river, and stopping at all the key places. A nice breeze in the 40 degree heat.
river boats. used hotel shuttle boats and express river boats to explore up and down and side to sidealso to Saphin Taksin pier for Skytrain

"an experience of a lifetime". I would say that a boat ride on the Chao Phraya River is a must for an experience of a lifetime; for the sights and the sound of Thailand’s most important river in which the Thai people depended on for many generations. The water is quite dirty but it is a nice way to travel up and down the river on the public ferries...Well worth a trip to see Bangkok from a different aspect especially in the evening as the sun is setting. Good for Photography : )

A day trip in itself. Which ever type of ticket you take on the Chao Phraya boat, omnibus with multi stops or express, it is a good opportunity to see a bit more off the city out of the tourist areas. Take the boat north to the last stop and visit the town of Nonthaburi with its local market full of surprises and heaven for pictures.

Two different worlds on both sides. This is one attraction in Bangkok which caught my attention not only for its beauty but for the great contrast on its both sides...One one side is the historical city of Ayutthaya and the other side is the bustling metropolis with high rises and world class hotels...A long tail boat can be taken to travel up the river and immerse in the diversity this city has to offer.. Evenings cruise with dinner onboard can also be a nice option..for a romatic dining experience..

Try a Night Cruise. We went on a dinner boat for the night cruise to see the beautiful buildings a temples at night from the river. We choose an outside table on the deck for the best view. Great and relaxing evening.

Best for tourists. We took the tourist boat to visit the temples. Catching the inexpensive monorail to the river and then taking the boat has to be the way to go for any tourist wishing to avoid the hectic road system of Bangkok. As other reviewers have said once you see past the dirty river it is fascinating to see all the unusual boats and houses by the riverside barely supported on thin wooden stilts. There are cheaper alternatives than the tourist boats but if you want flexibility then this option is fine.
Excellent. The main artery of the city and plenty to watch and do. Easy to travel along on the water buses once you get the hang of what goes where and cheap ticket prices into the bargain.
Smelly. Onr can do away with this sightseeing, everythign else is amazing in Bangkok, but this place is smelly and polluted

Take a boat up the river. Take the tourist ferry up the Chao Praya river - it's a picturesque trip and you get all the facts from the tour guide on board. You get to see unbelievable skyscrapers and small river houses along the way and for 150 Baht you can buy a day ticket and hop on/off to your hearts content, from 10h to 22h. It's a cheap and wonderful way to sightsee from a different perspective.

All day 150baht tourist boat is worth it!!!. Please be at the terminal just off the BTS Saphan Taksin station by 9am or you will be in line forever! The boats run up and down every 30 min so you can get off wherever you like, wlak around, just remember to be back in 30, 1hr etc. Can ride tourist boat all day up and down river. Just to be on the river and seeing the sights is worth it. Can see main temples, attractions from this boat.The main boat terminal is also the place where you catch the boat to Asiatique and also the Sheraton Cocktail cruise.
Long Tail Boats. Took a private long tail boat tour along the Klongs of Bangkok. Stopped at a orchard farm and the Artist's House. This four hour private tour was well worth it.

River of diverse sights.. Tour East rice barge trip took us on the main river and canals. It was great to see many of the temples from the river, modern hotels and Thai houses. A variety of boats were on the river which was interesting and made the trip surprisingly 'choppy'. On the canal you got an insight into how Thai families live and we saw children swimming in the muddy filthy water which had catfish and crocodiles in! :Ladies were also cooking in their boats by the floating market. Well worth a trip to see Bangkok from a different aspect.

Buy a day ticket!. Loved using the river to get about - I would say one of the easiest and best ways to see some of the city. Day pass was 150 baht - good ma & guide book to tell you how to visit all of the places.

A Worthy Sunset Ride. Engage one of the many private long-tailed boats along the piers near the Oriantal Hotel for a trip down the Chaopraya river and adjacent klongs. Most boats take you on a well-traveled route that start on the Chaopraya and maneuver through back klongs. There are stops at an alligator farm and other tourist shows, and if you've never been they're okay. One of my more memorable last-day-in-Bangkok experiences occurred a few decades ago on a warm January evening gliding along the river in a Long-Tailed boat. The sun was setting, Wat Arun glowed in the distance, and the large bottle of Singha beer purchased a few moments earlier from a vendor in a canoe tasted better and better as it disappeared with the sunset.River taxis are another way to experience the river, and are a worthwhile and inexpensive way to travel point to point.
Neat Experience. The water is very dirty but if you can look past that, it is a lovely way to travel up and down the river on the public ferries. A night is very lovely

Tourist boat. The daily ticket for travel up and down the river getting off at any of the piers is great value as you can see so much in the day.We spent four days doing this and still didn't see everything

Crusing down the river. the Chatrium hotel is located on this river. The hotel has its own free ferry service to take you to the sky train which takes you into the city to the malls. you can also do cruises up this river and wine and dine on a vessel in the evening.

Enjoy the night views of bangkok on a ride on Chao Phraya river. We booked cruise boat from our hotel , it's a 2 hour ride on river with buffet dinner, drinks and live music and danceWe arrived river city too soon because of maybe inconsideration of the guy who came to take us from hotel so we had to spend an hour and a half in river city building which was too exhausting because it doesn't really have much attractionThe food was ok and the crowd was live and the view of bangkok in the night is the best thing about it, you pass old temples that are shining in the night , also tall buildings And banks of riverThis 2 hour ride almost made that night one of the most memorable nights from our 7 night visit to bangkok

A dinner cruise is also a must to enjoy Bangkok. Normally I am particularly suspicious of organized tours, but I do recognize that they are an option when you have little time to spare and is not in the company of people that live in the place you are visiting. So there we went to buy a Chao Pharaya River dinner cruise tour. You have the option between modern and traditional vessels and we have opted for the latter because the service was at the table while in the modern vessels we would have air conditionned but buffet style dinner and being maladroit I do not feel confortable in serving myself. The food was correct but not a gastronomic experience and the view of the river and surrounding at the sunset is the big attraction and not the food.
Life on the river. Hi, the river is great. A water-highway right through the Center of Bankok !! I loved it, expecially the large barges during the day and the fun+dance boats in the evening !

cheap, but so enjoyable. my wife and i have travelled the length and breadth of the river in bangkok using the ferry crossings and the fast water buses. both are a great way to visit and see the sights sounds and flavours of the city, however avoid rush hours as these boats are normal methods of transport for daily commutors. it is possible to travel from the thaksin bridge in the south to nonthaburi city in the north and get a great view of bangkok, by the river. hop on and off is easy and it is cheap by any standards, many sites of interest can be visited, including our favourite wat po. some sites available going north, others on the return journey. it is possible to create a geat day out, whilst stopping to shop and eat beside the river, or visit a temple. one of the worlds great river journeys and so easy to do.
Great sights. Traveled on the river both by the local ferries and also on the Mekala River cruise. Both were great!
lovely ride. a ride on Chao Phraya River is a must I think in Bangkok, you can take the tourist boat where you have a guide and just enjoy the view

avoid the wasted long boat trip. wait until you go to the floating market to do a boat trip, the one in bangkok is over rated and over priced..we were initally asked to pay 600 bht per perosn, and settled on 350 bht per person, for effectvely a 90 minute cruise around the sewers of bangkok..the side canals are dirty, very little on them/too see and it really is just a noise , bumpy ride..save your money

Take the public boat for a cruise. For 40 Bahts you can get a one and a half hour round trip on the River. With the wind in your face, you can forget the oppressive heat of Bangkok and get a feel of the river life, while passing some of the major tourist sights like Wat Arun and Royal Palace.half the character of Bangkok come from the Chao Phraya and hence no visit to Bangkok can be complete without it.

Eye opener. We took a Longtail boat ride from near the Mandarin Oriental through the canals and back for an hour. We were charged a 1000bht.To see how some people live and to experience this extremes was a real eye opener. We are so glad we did it. We didn’t buy anything from the few “shop boats” that came up alongside.Not sure of the rules of the waterway because our guy seemed to slow for everyone but no one slowed for himIf you’re in Bangkok, take the time and go on one of these rides, it is worth it.

A comfortable experience. At night we took a boat trip across the Chao Phraya river, as we travelled across the river we saw beautiful sights including really, really, really big golden temples and amazing bridges, especially because at night all the lights are on. There is also a very relaxing breeze, that is definitely worth your time and money, the Chao Phraya river is very long and if you take a boat trip you should go for about 2-3 hours, absolutely amazing experience that you can not miss!!!!!

river trip. Go for it. Get to the river by sky train and take the boat. Just walk on and pay the boat lady. Really great trip along the river. Jump off and on with a day ticket to visit various sites.

Knew it when it was dirtier and likes it more. But now it is.... Worth a trip on the water taxis and or tours. Still interesting places if you know where to go. Bangkok is modern and exiting if you give it half a chance and the river runs through it.

delightful. We took a delightful long boat tour on the river and it was very revealing of the "have" and "have nots" of Bangkok. Lots of alters to see along the river and at one point you can stop the boat, buy loaves of bread from a wharf and feed giant, fat, hungry catfish! Great experience for families with kids. We really enjoyed the river; relaxing and beautiful.
Good for a few hours. It's a nice place to come and cruise for a few hours very historical but also very hot day and I melted away but was worth the visit

Rain Rain. when we were there it had rained most of the summer and the shops by the taxi depot were flooded it was sad to see the old people sweeping out the water for their shops, we went on all the taxi boats the public one is cheaper than the government one 10p each ish for a 20 min trip well worth it.

Hectic but interesting.. As I decided in my nieve wisdom to travel to Asia at the hight of summer (nobody bloody well told me!) the heat is a problem, so a trip on one of the tourist boats is a welcome respite from the heat of the city.For just 150Baht (about $5) you get an all day ticket to get on & off the regular boats that stop at 10 different places along the river.I didn't bother getting off & just enjoyed the 1 hour round trip on which you get to see lots of monuments/temples/palace/shanty houses & fkinbig fancy hotels!This place almost makes 'Vegas look small, the city is definately bigger than Vegas, & maybe even bigger than London, but what a transport system they have!!!Anyway, time to get my head down now as I get an 8am train to Chiang Mai 2morrow & it's a 12hr trip!!(luckily in a 1st class air conditioned coach)Night-night!

The Cheapest & Best Way To See Bangkok. The Chao Phraya River to me is the heart and soul of Bangkok. It still amazes me how many boats use this river and it often to the untrained eye seems to be sheer chaos but the Thai's really understand how to use this beautiful water way very efficiently.If you are unsure what to do or how to get around using the river these are my tips.There are 4 lines on the river, the cheapest being the orange flag boats. These are the ones to use. They will stop at all the major piers and at only 15 baht per person to go as far as you want per trip they are amazing value for money and being on the river is the coolest way to travel.Print off a river map before you go and some websites even have lists of the attractions at each pier. Checkout Bangkok.Com for a printable guide.Take a private long tail boat around this river. You can get a 2 hour trip which usually includes Taling Chan floating market for 750 per person and even less if you barter harder.It is an unforgettable experience as you will go along the canals off the main river and see the real Bangkok which possibly has not changed for centuries.

Unschedule trip on a tourist boat to Sarthorn Pier.. After buying some dry seafood goods at Tien Market,we decided to take a taxi back to Suk soi 11 and after numerous tries we managed to hail a cab who only willing to take 4 passengers.As the taxi move off,I headed to Ta Tien to take the boat to Sathorn,a while later my friends from the taxi called me to wait for them because they were been chase out of the taxi because the driver was complaining of the smell coming from the dry seafood.As the 5 of us gathered at the Pier,a boat arrived and the users told us to board and without asking & lookout for the Flag,we went on board.It wasn't crowded and mostly farang and a lady giving commentary on the PA system in English.The conductor came and asked for 200 Bht fare for 5 of us and I realise that it was a tourist boat and that take us on an unscheduled tour on the Chao Phraya river all the way to Sathorn Pier to catch the Bts train to Nana Station.The lady commentary on the site along the river gave us a clearer information of river bank buildings and hotels.

Chao Phraya river tour. Took the BTS to the Taksin station and walked pass the Longtail boat tours to buy a ticket for the hop-on-hop-off river tour. For 150 baht (roughly $5) you can get off and back on anytime - all day. There is commentary on the boat, if you can understand it, pointing out the points of interest. You can get off in Chinatown, or near the temples, or at one of the high-end hotels....Be prepared for a little moisture from the river if you are sitting by the window. Definitely a shower is needed after the river tour.It's a good way to get around and see sights from a different perspective, and worth every baht you pay for the whole day pass.

Interesting river scene. Best way to see Bangkok, get an all day pass on one of the "tourist boats" and sit back and see the sights. One can get on and off at any of the seven stops. Beware if you are pressed for time and plan to return to a specific stop, not all boats stop at each place, so you could get stuck at the wrong pier for a while.Very enjoyable river.
Ferry trip. A good cheap way to see some of the sights, but quite far away to see much. Catch the ferry, not the tourist boat.
The Ferries. Being on the water in this country is like taking everything with you where you go. You can eat, sleep, fish, make friends and feel very good just being here. Excellent hotels.
Certainly worth a look. Take the ferry and cover as many piers (stations) as you can....great mode of transport for people in bangkok. Some good hotels around it. Also boasts of dinner cruises

The river is amazing. we did a Klongs tour,and temples one day with a guide .we went another day by ourself and bought a tourist ticket so we could get on and off at all the stops there is commentry on the boat ,is is great value.

Cool trip. Take a trip on the tourist boat or any of the river boats. It's a cool way to experience Bangkok and if you avoid the booked excursions it is incredibly cheap. The hop on/hop off tourist boat daily ticket costs just 150 baht and the regualr river boats can be as little as 15 baht per trip.

Chao Phraya conundrum. Its a conundrum for us because the river is a polluted and unpleasant waterway to be in close proximity to. However it's enjoyable to ride on the river and see the extremely broad spectrum of life that Asia in particular seems to offer and how the river fills a vital role in the day to day life of so many people. Go for a ride or three, don't fall in.

Best thing I did. I ended up at central pier without planning to take a river trip but thought 'why not ?' - the river taxi stops at various points and you just jump off onto land when you want to and then wait for the next boat when you have had enough - it was a great way to orientate to the original layout of the city and I would gladly have done the trip again - the stops are not especially tourist orientated which s great if you just want to explore and wander around - very highly recommended and not an expensive option even on the tourist orientated ticket
Busy but dirty river. The river was really busy with all the boats but very dirty. They should really clean it up. It will be a great tourist place if the river is cleaner.
So much to do!. Ended up going on this a couple of times whilst staying in Bangkok. Visited the temple, night markets and enjoyed a nice meal. Great pricing and view (and weather) was great.

Take a River Taxi. A cruise on the Chao Phraya river is something you wont repent while visiting Bangkok, but stay away from the expensive dinner cruise and the costly tourist boats. Instead take a normal river taxi and pay on board like the locals do. You would have a great voyage and that too without burning your pocket. You can take the sky train to sephan taskin station and start the journey and can get down anywhere in the chinatown, Wat Pho, Grand Palace or can go further off and come back.
Easy to navigate.. Take a boat and stop anywhere that looks interesting. We took the express boat as far North as we could for a river cruise just to sight see. For the cost, its worth it.

Heart of Bangkok. The river is the main river in Bangkok. It is a good way to experience Bangkok. We went there with a tourist guide which she told us the origin of the river that connect to Ayudhia (former capital city of Thailand). There is also locals who sells vegetables, fruits, handicrafts etc in a boat.The river cruise takes about 45 minutes which i think more than enough.

River traffic is ever fascinating!. We stayed at a hotel on the river. Their restaurant was at the river's edge, and they were at a ferry pier (#13). The constant traffic of ferries, barges, long-tailed boats, etc. was a never ending source of enjoyment.I really enjoyed listening to the whistles of the ferry "handlers", signaling the driver when to stop/reverse/etc.. Then directing people to wait, then giving the signal to disembark. Great people watching!!
Great way to get around. A good way to see the city and get around like the local. very inexpensive and can get you to all the important sights in Bangkok.

River of Life. The River connects Bangkok with Ayudhia where one can see the largest statue of Budhha outdoors, in a resting position. It is said that when Lord Budhha was taking Nirvana, he laid in this position. The boats and ships in the river also provides alternative transportation to tourists and local commuters. This is an excellent way to see the life in the country side as well as the living, farming and day to day activities by the Thai villagers. Also, you can enjoy floating markets where the farmers sell their produce (fruits, vegetable, fish, sea-food, flowers, bouquets, handicrafts etc.). The river follows interesting lanscapes and provides beautiful scenery.

Best way to see local Thai life. Plenty of local life around the river. I highly recommended river cruise along the river to see some of the Thai life style. WARNING; DO NOT HIRE A LONG TAIL BOST AROUND THERE, RIP OFF PRICE FROM SCAMMERS. There is a speed boat that will cruise along the river for tourist at a much cheaper price. Plan for a long day trip around the area also. Start you day with aThai massage at Wat Pho, then Wat Phra keow, then river cruise, lunch at riverside restaurant, amulet market, if time is left then do china town. Use Taxi meter only, NO TUK-TUK. You walk to the pier to see some local markets also. Along the river, there are some major hospital, major universities and, of course, the famous Wat Arun is another must visit. There is never enough time to see and do around there. Take lost of pictures. It will a trip of your lifetime !!

Murky river, but still such a nice experience!. The river is green and dark, but its such a lovely thing to see Bangkok from a different side than the bustle of the city. It seems so peaceful when you are sailing on the river. However, from the river, you also get to see some of the darker sides og Bangkok, with poor people washing their clothes in the river, and living in run down houses overhanging the river, it usually does not seem that safe, but it is very interesting to see. I go down the river everytime I am in Bangkok.You can get to the river by taking the Skytrain to Saphan Taksin. Here you can sail with the local commuting boats or the tourist boats. I have always preferred the commuting boats. They cost 14 baht per trip and you get the same experience of sailing on the river than with the tourist boats. Granted, you do get a guide with the tourist boats, but for me its not worth the 500-600 baht for at tour down the river.

Its a must. Even if you dont go for a cruise ..you will definitely aboard express boat Chao Phraya a few times to see no of tourist attractions.
No matter how many times you get aboard, it is always a great experience,with a cool breeze.
I simply loved the fact how Thai people use it as their daily transport system.

"THE GREAT RUSH'. Almost every time I go to Bangkok I hire a boat to go around the Chao Phraya River. It is different every time as the scenery changes every minute. As a photographer it's all about the lighting, the action and the people. On the river all this changes all the time.I have seen Thais of all ages washing everything imaginable. From babies to windows ,motorcycles,cars carpets laundry and even a bathtub.The Thais are very photogenic and will strike a pose as you go by and if you wave they return your wave and smile big for you.Everybody bathes from young to ancient and even the odd Coconut lady will row out and sell you a cool coconut milk drink after she cuts the top off with a very large machette.The houses are fancy mansions to tin shacks and everything in between and you get to see all the different boats that were ever made from dugouts to sleek speedboats,You pas Temples and Wats and your driver will stop when you want so you can get a better picture or talk to someone interesting in another boat and you can alo go to the snake temple and handle the snakes.(or not) They always stop at the china Temple where the entire Temple is decorated with China plates and pieces. Here you climb narrow stairs on the exterior and they are steep and you can go very high for magnificent views. You also pass by many Giant Golden Budha. very impressive. It is amazing how many awesome photos or videos you get on this ride.Now here is the rush. The boat your on is long and slim and is called a long tail boat as the motor is on the boat and looks like a car or truck motor It is very large and powerful and the drive shaft comes straight out of the motor and goes back to the prop which is about 12feet back or more and it is balnce so the driver can raise and lower the engine by hand easily and also steer by swing the engine from one side to another. some times the drives controls the boat with a foot it is that well balanced Now to say these boats can go fast is an understatement. So you have to talk to the driver about his boat and how impressed you are with his boat and driving abilities and you love to go fast He can't go fast during the tour. So, wait until you have left the China Temple and reach a big wide part of the river and he is now itching to show off and you can tell him to open it up Now thats a rush.

Must do a river cruise!. You can simply take a water taxi and enjoy busy river or take a river cruise (which I recommend). There is a lot to see and definitely make a point to visit a river market! You will have long tails and other small boats come up along side your long tail selling all kinds of suviniers, food, and beer. It's an awesome experience and one you don't want to pass on! We even saw a Water Monitor (2nd largest lizard in the world to the Komodo Dragon)! It looked like a giant alligator! Taking a cruise on the Chao Phraya River gives you another perspective of Bangkok and you get to see how people live on the river...which can be eye opening.

A great place for a swim. when trudging around the city its nice to know that there is a lovely river to have a dip in a cool off. This is not a nudest river so make sure you have your swimmers to hand so not to offend people. This is by far one of the cleanest prettyest rivers i have ever swam in.

Amazing Scenic Views. We enjoyed the long ride on the boat on this river. The views were amazing of traditional historic Thai buildings coupled with ultra modern buildings on both banks of the Chao Phraya river.There were a huge number of people on our boat at some stages of the ride which made it a little uncomfortable at times.

Pleasant rice barge cruise. We took this afternoon cruise which consisted of a speed boat trip up the river and back on a rice barge with an exotic fruit buffet. The cruise started at 2:30pm and lasted about 2 hours.The cruise was a nice attraction for our young family.Note that if you do not fancy the rice barge and its exotic fruit buffet option, you can go for a cheaper speed boat cruise.TIP:Go to a travel agency to get discounted price.

great way to make a transportation. i have a many river back in my country.. not even close to this one.. thailand can make chao phraya as a great water transport.. it's cheap, fast, and no traffic jam :)
Busy. This is the main thoroughfare in Bangkok. The locals use the boats as daily transport and mingle with the tourists. An experience I will always remember.

Use public boats. Most visitors arriving at the boat piers approach the kiosk and buy the tourist boat tickets at 70baht each or 150 per day. While this seems reasonable at first glance it is alot better value to simply board the more regular public boats from the same piers and pay the conductor on board like the locals. The prices are fixed for any journey length and depending on the boat are 15 baht or less per person.The boats are often the quicket and most scenic way to get between the north and south of the city with many of the top hotels and tourist attractions alongide the river.
Do not miss the Cruise here. The cruise is a leisure on water, great food and drinks, amazing view specially at night. Wonderful way to pass a memorable evening

A river to travel once.. It was a long wait at a hard- to- find wharf for an insanely packed long boat manned by a cranky crew. The river was interesting enough but very polluted, as are most natural areas in Thailand. Pity really, something should be done, it can't be healthy for the population.

Khlong Bangkok Noi. Take a long-tail boat from Wat Muang Kae pier, just north of the Oriental hotel, down a narrow road with CAT building (green glass) on your left. The 1.5 hour trip through the back khlongs will cost 1500bht from here, & at least 2,500bht from the big hotel piers. It's an enjoyable trip through the back canals of Bangkok & shows a very different way of life. You pass various temples & a small floating market, but the boat doesn't stop. There were children swimming & fishing, but it didn't look a suitable swimming place for our delicate Western stomachs!

Candle light dinner in cruise. one of the best thing to do while you are in bangkok is to go to chao phraya river cruise. Àwesome music, candle light dinner excellent surroundings. A lovely romantic experience.
it is a must. if you are in Bangkok and have plenty of time, you should try this place. The scene was amazing and you could stay there all day long. It was an excellent excursion for all foreigners.
Take a short tour on a private boat. Take a short tour on a private boat to see the environment of Chao Phraya River! It's worth, as you'll manage to see absolutely different Bangkok!

River Life. We love to catch the local taxi boats on the Chao Praya River just to see the local life and some of the best monuments in Bangkok. Do it both in the day and night, you will experience two very different views of life on the river.

beatiful river. We took a long tail boat ride all around the city.an express river taxi for a few baht to spend as long as you like checking out life along Bangkoks .its good palace for you to spend a day there.

A great way to see some of the real Bangkok. Take a local long boat up the river and along the canals - here you can see where many of the local people live along side the waters edge. There are tourist places that driver might wish you to see as well like their zoo, temples and gardens. There is a nice memorial garden to the Princess along side the river but we haven't made it yet but it sounds lovely.

Make sure you get on the right boat!!!. This is a good way of getting a flavour of Bangkok if you have very limited time. We had just 3 hours so did our homework before leaving the UK. Get down to Sathorn (Central) pier as all the ferries stop there. We took the orange flag boat as that stopped at the places we were interested in. Don't get the tourist boat as you won't get your money's worth if you have limited time. Also watch out for the ferry "sharks" at Central who try to get you to take their boats for 100 bahts each whereas the orange flag boat was 15 Bahts each all the way to the pier for the Grand Palace. If you are returning to Central mid afternoon, we aware that the boats are VERY crowded!! You get a good view from the ferries of life on the river - you would never get this in a taxi or even walking. Don't get a taxi in Bangkok unless you want to spend hours in a traffic jam with the taxi meter clocking up the fare!!

Slowish river travel. when you think of the Chao Phraya river, visions of loud, colourful & smokey long boats come to mind but there is a different way to get along this watery highway. The Chao Phraya ferry service runs regularly from Nonthaburi in the north to Saphan Taksin where it meets up with the BTS lite rail. For a relatively cheap trip you can jump on and off at various points of interest and hook up with the tiny & Very cheap (7tbht) river crossing boats. All sorts of interesting options open up to you as you work your way up & down this busy river. Sit at a riverside restaurant to watch the passing parade of barges sunk to their decks chugging up river carting all sorts of things from the docks further down river. Army & Navy boats wizz past with solders on board. Pleasure boats cruise along serving lunch & dinner with blaring music & bright neon lights and converted rice barges bob along offering a more stately form of travel on their way to Ayutthayu up river. Lots of photo opportunities as you pass homes and gardens that back onto the river. Some days kids are jumping into the water to cool off and men & women throw out their fishing lines. Life along the river is constantly changing as with the rise & fall of the tides.

Your gateway to some of the best attractions in Bangkok. One of the best ways to get to Grand Palace and other famous sites around it is by river boat through the Chao Phraya River. It might seem odd to take a boat like a taxi but you get used to it after a few stops :)I recommend taking a direct boat to the Aquatique square (just catch the boat that says 'Aquatique' on it) around noon because come night the lights are just stunning. It's a sort of amusement park/town square filled with restaurants and little stalls of cute souvenirs & knick knacks. There are also a few shows to check out (ladyboy cabaret is a must see!), just buy a ticket at the Aquatique ticket counter. NOTE: You can get to Aquatique by road, but not very convenient for tourists who don't want to rely on taxis as there are no MRT stations nearby. Boats operate until 11 PM so make sure you don't miss the boat ride back home.

Best way to see main sights. A very busy river with working boats vying with tourist boats all day long. It is the easiest way to travel up and down all the sights both during the day and night. There are landing stages all along the river and at most, if not all, there are little ferries to transport you across the river (normally about 3/4 Baht pp).There are 4 different river buses ranging from the public boat, at 15 Baht pp per trip, to the tourist boat (boat with orange flag on the back)offering unlimited travel by that company, for 135 Baht pp per day (this is the boat with a blue flag on the back).The temples at night are well worth seeing from the river, but check the finishing times of the services.Also a must, is a long tailboat ride around the backwaters. Cost about 500 Baht per person for approx 1 hour journey.

Ride the water taxi. If you want to avoid the traffic on the roads take the water taxi on the river. The river taxi is very cheap and fast and fun to travel with the locals. The river is busy with all kinds of boats, and there is a lot to look at as you pass temples ad building along the route.

a key for transportation. River that flows from north to south of Bangkok, the Chao Phraya River. Sound of smth. Floating duckweed floats, river of brown color, such as gutter. Lovers can also participate in the river cruise river tourism. However, if you want to enjoy the scenery of Thailand Recommended folksy during the day, and to explore in the Chao Phraya Express Boat is water transport! Then it is possible to lap the main temple, you can also see the appearance of children, such as jumping into the river if you go to a little suburb. Also enjoy fun and thrill that flies sometimes repel Wed.

Cool way to see the city!!. We took a long tail boat ride all around the city! It was really fun! We got to see the traditional Thai houses on the water, we went by many many temples, and saw lots of locals doing different chores and jobs just living their everyday lives which was really neat. Beware if you get off the boat on a dock at a temple they often charge you a few baht!!! (We didn't know this and literally had no Bahts left, they were not too happy but we ended up giving them a few American dollars instead and that seemed to ease things over:)

Take the local ferry if you are tired of temples. After 2 days of non stop temple tours, with the heat of summer starting to crush us, we hopped a local ferry and rode it up river to the end of the line. Interesting to see the history of Bangkok reflected in buildings along the river. Watch monks and military commuting to their places of work. We hoped off for lunching strolled around the back packer paradise, got bored and grossed out, and got back on the ferry. Jumped off at the Oriental hotel for cocktails on the terrace at dusk.,lovely.

Great way to explore the sights. With many of Bangkok's major attractions within walking distance of the river, the Chao Praya Tourist Boat makes it easy to get around. The free guide book produced by the operator is really excellent and provides information on which attraction is located near which pier and includes directions to reach them on foot. A day ticket cost us 150Baht each and could be used on the tourist boat or any of the other express river boats. The starting point is Central Pier, which is just next to Saphan Taksin Skytrain station. Buy your ticket at the central pier from the permanent ticket office building and not from the guys outside selling river tours.

all day boat pass, not worth it.. Do not buy the all day boat pass, it is not worth it. The cost of a ticket is 150 THB but you don’t have enough time to take the boat to most of the piers, it’s better to take one way tickets, since it will take almost the whole day to see both the grand palace, Temple of the dawn and wat pho temple so you will run out of time to use the day pass since the boat service stops at 1700

Great way to see Bangkok. We used the river for transport almost every day, it was wonderful. There is no need to take a tour, just hop on an orange flagged boat, grab a seat if you can and then pay the conductor the B15 fee, ( a flat rate) for how ever far you want to go, one stop or 10! You see all sides of Bangkok, the tall hotels, the busy piers, the spires of the temples and the activity of the boats plying up and down the river, its facinating. Central Pier connects you to the Skytrain and with that you never have to sit in traffic. Its a a great way to get around and see the sights at the same time.
Love that dirty water. Best way to travel across down during the day on the colored flag commuter boats. Didn't and wouldn't do the tourist boats.
Nice views. the views are really nice. Get ready to be yelled at by the crew members of the boat who dont speak english and only mind of checking tickets. But it is a very nice view.

Bangkok River. Hop on an express river taxi for a few baht to spend as long as you like checking out life along Bangkoks river See everything from palaces to poverty and experience the friendliness of Thai passengers This river is alive and used by so many people in so many ways

Xmas New Year 2012-12 Bangkok. Taking boats up and down the river, touring the Klongs by long boat one of our favoutite things to do in Bangkok. Had a great night out on Manroa Rice Barge restaurant. Bust with rice barges and ferries. Great way to get around

river of live. For Bangkok and his citizens is river of live. On booth sides were building capital cities of Siam (Thonburi and Bangkok). For me it is possibility to used boat and looking aroud banks of river to live of citizens and visitors. Very interesting is to sail around "the klongs".

Avoid the heat and the traffic jam. Many of Bangkok attractions can be reached with the boat. A ticket costs 10 baht. The tourist boat for the whole day costs 150 baht and stops at 5 pm, but you don't really need it. Just get in and out as you please , enjoy the freshness of the water and the locals going about their business. Lots of interesting places to stop and loose a couple of hours.

Great way to see different parts along river. Bought the Tourist boat day pass for 150 baht. Can jump on and off any of the boats, but the Tourist boat has guide with microphone, but difficult to hear and understand at times. Stops near Wat Pho, Grand Palace, Chinatown, Khao San Road (where foreign backpackers hang out). Be careful of jumping on the Express boat which can take you all the way up the river and makes many non-tourist stops. Overall, great way to travel and see different parts along the river.

Travelling by boat on the Chao Phraya River. I found it fascinating to see the huge variety of boats while travelling on the river! It was such fun to see how gaily colorful some of them were, and there were large and small tourist boats, tug boats, express boats and boats that just travelled a certain distance; many of those could be distinguished by the color of the flag flying at the back of the boat.The other thing is that they are a very cheap mode of transportation, and the scenery along both banks of the river as you travel along are constantly changing and it gives you a good idea of how the local Thai people live, and also how modern the buildings are in certain areas. You can stop at numerous piers to see temples or markets, and get to Chachuchak Market or Chinatown by boat or to Nonthamburi where there is also a very good market and access to Koh Kred by taxi from there... Many sights can be seen by travelling on the river.I did a dinner cruise with Loy Nava on this river, and after dark, the temples and wats are all lit up and quite beautiful, especially if seen from the water!I would call the Chayo Phraya River the "river of Thai life" because that is definitely what you see, on the river and on land as you go by... The boats themselves are very pretty to see at night as they are all lit up with lights.The other good thing about them is that the Bangkok transit system (BTS) gets you to the piers where you can catch these boats, quite easily, and that is a cheap and easy way to get around Bangkok, especially as the vehicle traffic is so bad!I highly recommend taking a trip on one of the boats on the river, and even staying at a hotel by the river as they sometimes have their own little boats to ferry you here and there and the views at night from a riverside hotel would be lovely....

Cheap and interesting activity. We had some time to kill, so our hotel recommended that we take a ride on the express boat. It was super cheap (we didn't do a tour--not necessary). Looking back, I wish we would have taken a boat up to the temples instead of wasting time in stressful traffic. The boat ride alone was interesting and it was a nice alternative to taxis.

The Lifeline of Bangkok. The Chao Phraya is a major source of commerce as well as a means of getting around in Bangkok. It is impressive and usually one of the first and last things I want to visit when arriving and departing from Bangkok. It's part of what makes the city what it is.
Different view. From the boat, you will get a different view on Bangkok, however the cruise I attended had a guide with strong Thai accent, so I did not understand her at all.

Take a Rice Barge Tour, not a dinner cruise!. On a Rice Barge Tour that's during the day, you'll travel along the river in a motorized boat before transferring to the rice barge for a lavish sweets and tropical fruits buffet.On a dinner cruise, flourescent lighting along the banks makes it almost impossible to get good pictures; ditto couples who stand up at their assigned tables for endless pictures of each other.

wonders and relaxation on water ride. Beautiful costless trip on chao phraya that shoud not missed by any bangkok visitors. If you are on your first visit try special tourist boat that cost 150 bth. because of guide and introduces of all attractions each side of the river otherwise orange boat is enough for a round trip ride on the river. Taskin pier station would be the best point to start. About the beauty of this trip every body should try and then think about it !

A good way to see a nicer side of Bangkok. Easy to use and get around, hop on and off at leisure with an all day ticket, however I think a single to the palace is all you need (20 thb as opposed to 130 thb) as you will probably end up getting a taxi or tuk tuk back rather than walk back to the docks.A good tip though if you do have an all day ticket is to get off at memorial bridge and walk through the flower market to the recling Buddha .

Excellent way to see sites along the river. Excellent way to visit sites north or south of the BTS (skytrain) Silom line. The BTS now crosses the river. Take the passenger boats north of the BTS to visit the Grand Palace, Chinatown, Kao Son Road, just to name a few sites. The view from Lebua Tower at sunset provides a spectacular view of the river and Bangkok. Get away from Sukhumvit road and visit the river.

Clean river. Cruise is a must to see the city highlights, visit the temples. A good tour guide also helps. We were able to visit the Wat Po temple, the Teak Museum, the Royal Barges museum during the river tour too.

Great Observation Deck. Really enjoyed our half hour trip from Mandarin Oriental to The Grand Palace by the riverboat. Best people/place viewing you can get for 15 baht (around 50c Aussie). Highly recommended.

Great experience. I decided, that I have to try every mean of transport in Bangkok. So, Chao Phraya river it is. We were strolling throughout Bangkok, and wanted to see Wat Arun. Because we were on the other bank of river we had to took a "river taxi" a boat. There is one boat that floating up and down the river, and there is another which takes you from one bank to another. Great experience and its pretty cheap. We paid around 13 bahts to get from one pier to another - it was like 6 stops. And then 3 bahts to cross the river from one bank to another.

A must!. I don't think you can go to Thailand and not try to commute on the Chao Phraya River. It was a good experience. They do have different types of commuter boats. There are those that stop only at tourist spots which is more expensive. We took the cheaper one (15 baht if I remember correctly) which was perfectly fine and efficient. Unfortunately, we never got to go on the river during sunset which I would imagine to be a sight especially with the Wat Arun.

A Good Way To Get Around. If you are planning on doing several site seeing excursions in one day with places close to the Chao Phraya River butting the one day unlimited pass for 150 Baht is the way to go. Otherwise just buying two one way tickets one it for 40 Baht each is the best value. Either way you go it is a great way to get places and offers some wonder views of the Choa Phraya River and the shoreline.

Boat Watching. The Millenium Hilton hotel is right on the Chao Phraya river and suitably located rooms can provide hours of gentle entertainment watching the unusual variety of boats as they motor there way up and down the river. However, to get the flavour of the place you really need to sit on or near the banks of the river at water level and watch. A trip up the river is also a delight as you can see a number of temples from the river, and if your tour goes up one of the major tributaries you will see the permanent shoreline dwellings that have replaced the 'floating city'.
Good overview. Tells you where you are! We had a terrific guide with us from Abercrombie and Kent which added to the richness of the info.

very nice trip along the river. it was a very nice trip along the river after I change from BTS to the boat at S6 station to go along the river, it's only cost me 15 Baht for 1 long trip. But please be aware that the return boat will only service you until 7pm. We missed the last boat and we should take a bus to go to BTS station at Victory monumen.

cheap, great views of the city, and quite an experience. The ferry is crowded, but cheap and definitely an experience you need in to have in Bangkok! Also, it beats taking a taxi or tuk tuk thru the heavily trafficked streets
not very scenic. Interesting to see Bangkok but the Seine or the Thames it is not. More a workaday river flanked by mainly uninteresting buildings.

Chao Phraya. We tried a number of different boats on the river, and if you want to take pictures, take a larger boat which is slower, giving more time to look around, you'll see everything from new sparkling tower blocks to temples to what look like derelict almost falling down ruins, with kids jumping in for a swim, it is also a fast way to travel within the city especially at rush hour

cruise ship. Would be great if you come here and buy tickets travelling by ship, there are many types of tickets for you to choose. In this journey you also can enjoy views of the city and the palace, University Thammasat. and sure you will be surprised to see a lot of fish in this river.

we took a boat. the trip up the river was fantastic. this is the way to view all the temples and palaces without having to sit in bangkoks traffic. the fish were stupendous in size and come up to the side of the boat. with ice cold chang and crisps give me the simple life everytime
Orange Flag. If you want to see the city from a great perspective, take the Orange Flagged river boat for Baht 15 and see the from the water.
Worth a look. terrific to do a boat cruise at night, lots of lights and sights. Nice peaceful trip, we loved it. however be careful which boat you take as the one we were on had terrible food.

Not Pretty but Useful. I have never been to such a well used river. Everything natural about it is dead I'm sure, but it is one of the best ways to get around town cheaply. The taxi drivers seem drunk or suicidal, the tuk tuks will try and cheat you, and the motorcycles will kill you. If you are going to the temples, the grand palace, the museum or khao san road this is the way to do it. Do not expect too much help from the lady at the info desk. Basically you need to go to the right hand side of the info counter to the pier(of sorts). Try and get to the front of the line so you can get a seat on the right side of the boat. Otherwise you will be packed in standing, and the right side allows you to see the numbers at each port so you know when to get off. It is packed at night-cover your ears and follow directions because the ticket collector means business. She is so loud that you will both love and hate her. This is not a tourist boat.

A must see and Do. We were in Bangkok in Mid Feb. We set aside one day to spend on and near the river. It was a relaxing and memorable day. We found a tourist line of boats that run up and down the river much like site seeing buses in some cities in Europe. For the price of 150 TB or about $5.00 we could get on and off at our leisure at designated stops along the way. (There are several boats in the line.) We enjoyed and had lunch in China Town. Visited Wat Po, the Palace, Little India. We then hailed a Tuc Tuc and saw more of the city on the way back to our hotel. Chao Phraya was a great way to see some of the older parts of the City and with the boat pass and fairly inexpensive way as well.
Best Experience. Awesome Cruise experience. The food was also good and the music was awesome!!! The crew was very helpful and made you feel at home.

Interesting to see. Lots of interesting sights on either side of the river plus varied and colourful boats on the river itself. You can also take a trip into the area where people live on the river - interesting although not as spectacular as it used to be when there was a floating market - now just a few boats selling tourist stuff
Busy Dirty. A trip on the river has to be taken. It will give you a glimpse of another side of Bangkok. The Klongs (canals) are always worth exploring. Do not make it more than 1 hour.

River trip Bangkok. Although the river does look very dirty you have to remember that it is a working river not just for tourists. Many long tail boats will take you on trips but it is good fun to travel on the local ferries. In the evening take a trip and see the Wats and Temples lite up.

Must do once if you are in Bangkok. It is a preferable way to see all the other attractions in Bangkok.The river is not very scenic or blue or an attraction in itself.The view it affords however is quite unique.There is a great view of Wat Arun.You can reach the Grand Palace or Wat Phra as well.It also makes for some great photo op as well against the backdrop of some old heritage locations.Carry a camera with a working flash or you will be left looking very dark against the bright backdrops.We took the BTS sky train to Central Pier and then took the boat to the pier we wanted to go .The metro come directly to the pier.It a walk downstairs.That's it.Much better and faster than getting stick in taxis in the traffic.People are friendly at the pier and most of them will be able to help you with the boats if you tell them what you wanted to see.Avoid touristy boats and use the one locals use.Use their express maps to guide you .You can visit temples and palaces and select the respective piers using the river guide maps Piers are chaotic .Fruits and Juices are available everywhere.The price is cheap about 15 baht or so.Carry hats and sunsglasses since it is generally very hot and humid.if you are visiting during rainy season in July & August carry an umbrella/rain coat .They are also sold at the piers though.Must do once in Bangkok.Its an escape from the city hustle & traffic and much better beautiful way of exploring the city's landcape and attractions !

Local colour. A must for a taste of Bangkok life with floating market boats.Be prepared for constant hustling and barter for the best price.The tourist market boats had all the same wares, but it is fun to buy from them and support the traders. I was shocked at the huge difference between rich and poor society in the city, all were friendly smiles but can be unnerving in the narrow canals.
Dinner Cruise. Went on the Wanfah Restaurant and Cruise. Awesome food, Thai dancing, and spectacular views in the evening.

Incredible and chaotic but it works.. We used the Chao Phraya Tourist Ferry which is a hop on/off boat service. Day pass about £3 per day. You can seat a lot from the river but it is an experience in itself to see how the boats operate. There do not seem to be any rules of the river, some boats going very fast some slow all going in different directions. Total chaos but it works.Also use the free Asiatique river boat shuttle that operates between 4pm and 11pm from central pier to the Asiatique Shopping Market which in itself is great, lots of bars, restaurants and small market stalls.

Good way to see the city. A good way to see the city especially after walking a lot. Yes the water is not always the cleanest but take the local boats, it's very cheap and way to travel like many of the locals. Can get crowded on the boats during rush hour, but don't go to Bangkok if you don't like crowds. You can also stop at many stops to visit important places throughout the city.
Still the best trip in Bangkok. We get the river boat at the Praya Athip ferry point near Ko Sahn road. It costs 15 Bht for a normal ride down the river.

A Rubbish Dump. Good to take a trip on the river, but would not recommend the long-tail boat trip. Over-priced and no commentary. Some good views of temples from the river and other buildings, but the rubbish was disgusting. Yes, the fish will eat some of it, but not all.

Go for a ride. It is very easy to take the local boat shuttle service up or down the river. Boats run every few minutes and have slow, fast and express services. US$1+ covers an interesting ride on the river and for not much more you can buy a day pass and become a local
Try It!!. When in Bangkok, you gotta try the river. It's great to be on the boat and watch the world float by.

Dirty stuff. The river is getting more and more polluted, with all kinds of stuff floating in it.
The amount of garbage floating down the river is astonishing.

Great views. We travelled along the Chao Phraya a number of times and would certainly recommend it. You can either use the tourist boat or public boats to get around - either is fine. The views at night are impressive

Bangkok on the river!. You're in the City, surrounded by buildings, and then you see it - the river, huge, such a surprise. A boat-trip here is a wonderful adventure for all, cheap to move between stops which take you to many wierd and wonderful places. River taxi's (can get very busy) are an easy and fun way to get around and see the City from a different viewpoint. Don't miss out!

Can see lots of monuments, and much of old Bangkok from the river. The old canals and buildings, monuments, people going about daily life make a cruise down the river and then a long boat tide around the older areas a must do in Bangkok.
Chao Phraya River. Nice way to see the city from a different angle. I took a long tail which was bumpy and I've also taken the local boat taxi, which was nice as well.

boat ride to flower market. We took a boat ride from the BTS station to the Flower Market. Not many tourist at the flower market, but the price for flowers was great. Bought the wife 6 dozen roses for six dollars. Give a go if feeling adventureous, or you can hire BKK tours (Chao) for indepth knowledge of the area

Have to take a longboat ride on the canals. Taking a ride on the khlongs ( canals) of the river was one of the highlights of our trip to see how people have lived for 100's of years. We also took the water taxis frequently and they were a very good way to maneuver across this huge city. It is beautiful at nite.
This is a must. The private Long Tail Boat ride was an experience I will never forget. Going through the canal and seeing Bangkok life first-hand was incredible. It humbles a person.
the real bangkok. just to sit and watch the daily life of the river pass you by is wonderful,this is my favorite part of bangkok
