For an authentic Bangkok experience. The Chao Phraya river is busy all day long and is one of the best way to travel within the city and avoid the traffic jams. There are passenger boats that navigate the river all day long. For an authentic experience, avoid the touristic boats and jump onto one of the regular boats that locals and monks use. It only costs 15 bahts and it's worth it.

The River of Life. The Chao Phraya River is the "River of Kings"....and indeed so...the importance of the Chao Phraya transcends tourism...it's the single most watershed in the city. But to most tourists, it's just another facet of Bangkok. And indeed so, with so many attraction and riverside hotels sprouting beside the river and with it's providence of jobs creation. ... calling it the River of Life would not be far fetched.The most convenient to commence your adventure on the Chao Phraya would be to take a skytrain to BTS - Central Pier / Saphan Taksin (S6) on the dark green line. Walk down the elevated stairway and a short 200 yards walk down Charoen Krung Road, pass the rolls of red songthaews (pick up trucks) and road side snack stalls brings you the jetty embarkation point. For value for money river cruise, I recommend the 150 baht one-fare all day ticket (0930hrs - 1600hrs)... From the Central Pier, you can hop on various jetties (like the Tha Tien jetty) to visit the Grand Palace... and enroute back, stop by Wat Arun (the Temple of Dawn)...Just follow the travel advisory printed on the ferry pass....and you will be rewarded with a day filled day...

Quickly Quickly. Great tour C'P'River tour cruise for 150 bht. Can get on an off at all the piers...all day to 7pm One needs to be agile getting on and off they dont wait, run to a very tight schedule. Value

Nothing special. We have taken a private long tail boat ride along the River. There was nothing special to see. The water of the river was dirty. It's not worth the money, we have paid 500 Baht per person for the ride. When we reached the destination pier, which is the Grand Palace pier, we are forced to pay a 20 Baht private boat docking fare, which is ridiculous! What a ripped off.

Be very careful if not using your Hotel shuttle boat.. Staying in a riverside Hotel, we used their shuttle boat all the time and were warned to take care if using the Public Ferries. On the odd occassion that we used this, we were amazed at how punctual they were. However, although there are staff to help, this service is very busy, and you will have to watch your step boarding and leaving the craft, as time seems to be the essence, they`re always crowded and there`s no helping hand!!

The best way. Taking a tour on Chao Phraya River is the best way to see the city. You can take a boat and make it like your hop on hop off-tour. With the boat you can see many of the "must see" without hazzling with the traffic!

Well worth a trip. We went to the Central Pier and caught the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat for 150Baht, we were given a booklet and map that explained everything. It is a hop on, hop off boat but we stayed on for the whole trip up and down the river and then went back to where we had decided to get off. It's a very busy river, with a lot to see on both sides. The boat is open but has a roof so you can take photos.

Best way to travel!. Aside from the Skytrain this is the way to travel. Buy your ticket on the boat itself. No need to stand in a queue at the pier.15 Baht for as far as the boat travels ! Definitely a bargain. The boat stops off at points on both sides of the river. If you want to cross the river - most of the stopping points have cross river ferrys.

The best way to travel. In Bangkok, the distances are huge, the BTS and the MRT are great, but when it comes to see the Wat and palaces, go to the river and take a river taxy, cheap and very convenient, I did it couple of times, just budget extra time, the BTS goes to the water and you can go back to your hotel taking the BTS if you are close by. The river is pretty interesting, you can see both worlds of Bangkok, it is a most do, even if you just want to go around the river without leaving the water-taxy is great and relaxing.
Overrated. Nice to see the boats light up when it got dark, but otherwise, just like any other river. boats were seriously overcrowded and tourist boats were just too overpriced.

Beautiful Chao Phraya Cruise. We went on the Chao Phraya River in a well decorated Cruise. It was a 2 hour cruise and we got to see the brilliant skyline of Bangkok and absolutely stunning temples buildings and the local sights.
An evenig of enjoyment. This was our first night ln Bagkok. We thoroughly enjoyed the cruise. Food was very good. Music was great. Staff friendly and helpful.

We needed peace after a visit to the Grand Palace. So we got onto a public express ferry, green or yellow flag, and for the paltry sum of 15 baht travelled for about 45 minutes up river to the Nonthanburi pier.It was last Saturday morning, so after a few stops we were able to get a good seat and watch the city go by, a very pleasant way to spend the time. The river was fairly clean, as there has been no rain in the catchment for several months. At the Nonthanburi pier we got off and walked downstream for about 100metres to a peaceful floating restaurant where we enjoyed a nice meal, including a great catfish dish. You can feed the huge catfish in the river at this restaurant, the water boils with them.Then it was back on the public express boat for another 15 baht trip down river to the Saphan Taksin pier for the connection to the Syktrain. We had previously done an evening dinner cruise, so with the public ferry trip we were able to see the riverside life during the daytime, a great way to spend a few hours.

Nice experience.. Taking the public boats on the Chao Phraya is a very nice way to get around Bangkok. You'll be with Thai people going to work and living their day to day life. You can get also take a private boat for a cruise around different temples which is a great way to see a different side of town.

See how the other half live. A 2 hour cruise down the river was part of a tour I went on. It was interesting to see the differences in housing as we got closer to Bangkok and I was very surprised to see some boys swimming in the river. You don't need a two hour cruise but I recommend at least a ferry ride.

Chao Phraya Tourist Ferry if you want sightseeing. It has an English guide and the ferry stops at major sightseeing spots. A day pass with unlimited trips to and fro costs 150 baht. Otherwise each trip costs 40 baht.Good for phototaking and a quick view tour of the various sightseeing buildings along Chao Phraya River.
Amazing!. Wonderful trips up and down this river on water taxis. The best was a trip up to Ayuttayha and a boat trip down the river with lunch. There is also a wonderful evening trip.

very nice sightseeing, but difficult to make clear on tickets. i like travel on this river, sights are great and also very convience in transportation. but the tickets are complex, i have travelled many times on the river, but still not very sure how to get cheaper tickets. --- everytime is difference!

Fast and cheap!. The best way to commute from central Bangkok to the old part of Bangkok like China Town and the Grand Palace. Look for the orange flag or the yellow flag boats. It costs 15 Baht the whole way! The traffic on the ground is horrific at the moment as they are constructing the underground. Best to avoid!

Bangkok Must Do!. We took a long-boat from a small, local company on the side of the river. The boat was beautiful and definitely made you feel like you were in Thailand. No need for a tour guide, the driver was basically informative which is all you need. We got to see the Palace (which was amazing!) and instead of doing the full-circle, we got dropped off at Siriraj Hospital on the way back which the driver had no problem with. I'd highly recommend doing this - plenty to see!

Definitely a different experience!. I have been in Bangkok several times and traveling on Chao Phraya River is a totally different experience from the previous visits. Many places of interests can be access through the river taxis, like Royal palace, Chinatown and temples for a price of 15 baht. What I enjoyed most is to travel to Wang Lang pier where you can try to local street foods opposite the Siriraj Hospital. However, this should be attempted if you are adventurous enough as there are not many tourist there and it can get pretty hot there.

You have to take a boat trip..... You haven't been to Bangkok if you haven;t been on a boat trip....it's the best way to get round,,yup it gets crowded and crazy but that's part of the fun.....good way to pick up metro connections too if staying round Khao San road.....

good way to see Bangkok river life. I agree with the previous reviewer. NO need to take the 'tourist' boat tours unless you want to. The tourist boats have a commentator on board but will charge 40-50 baht per person..paid at the dock window. The local boat won't have a commentator but the charge is only 15 baht (paid ON BOARD the boat). All the boats are different and distinct in color. When the local Thais get on, that will most likely be your local boat. Do your research to know which stop to get off to see what sights along the river. Get a good Bangkok map that shows all the stops the local boat makes and the connection point to the BTS (Skytrain). I think travelling along the Chao Praya River is a wonderful way to aquaint yourself with Bangkok.

Go for the River cruise. While it is very touristy, the river cruise is great fun. As you float down the river, various buildings which are flood lit pass by. . The river breeze is balmy, the band plays old sentimental numbers, and while the food is nothing to write home about, it is 100 % enjoyment.

Well utilised and great for getting about. Going up and down the river is a wonderful way to see parts of the city that range from the old temples, spanking new hotels, and squalid riverside hovels that are lived in by locals. There is a plethora of ways of getting about on the river and the express boat at 15bht is about the best value. Don't be conned into taking an expensive option as you really don't need it.

White orchid river cruise. Wow, I'm just from the cruise - great, spirits, I'm pleased and joyfull. The best one is "white orchid". When you will be against dilemma (choise), try to think about condition of programs. Before you buy ticket go inside the shop center "city river". There are the authorized seller. He give you the lowest price - today it was 1400 BAT.

Wow...wow....wow. We took the Chao Phraya Boat ride 9 not the cruise) which is a common mode of travel for local people and traveled from Pier 4 till Pier 17. The whole boat ride was so scenic seeing villages, tall buildings, nice bridges, temples etc. Definitely worth doing it.

easy and cheap. there are so many options on the river, whether its dining or just getting from a to b. if its your first time take the tourist boat you book at sathorn pier it gives you an uncrowded boat with commentary for the day with as many hop ons and offs as you want, i also think it may give you free rides on any of the other river boats for the day, but check on that when you book your ticket.there are also nice weekend trips to kok kret island and other places.if you use the normal boats during the day they can be busy but its the best way to get up and down the river.i like to take the 5pm orange boat to the end of the line theres some street food and a 711 buy some beers and watch the boats and the people.

busy. Never a dull moment on the river a must do when in bangkok so much to see best bet is choose which flag colour boat you need and buy one way ticket works out a lot cheaper than buying a one day ticket for the tourist boat.

Heart and Soul. The Chao Phraya River is the heart and soul of Bangkok. It is a means of commerce and a major part of the public transportation system in this huge city. Many of the attractions of interest to visitors are located along its shores. The Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Wat Arun, Chinatown, flower market and more are all found along the river. Connecting all these attractions with land based public transport is a river ferry system which is frequent, relatively comfortable and inexpensive. Pick up a map at any River Taxi dock. Ferry boats are color coded by the flag they are flying at the front and rear of the boat. Blue flagged boats are designated for tourists and stop only at the tourist related docks. Orange flagged ferry boats stop at MOST of the docks up and down the river and grey flagged boats stop at ALL the docks. I would recommend using the orange flagged ferries to get to all the site along the shore. If you're a little more adventurous you might consider chartering a long-tail boat for a 2 hour journey into the narrower canals which spur off the main river. This will allow you to get up close to everyday Bangkok. The canal side neighbourhoods, smaller temples and people coming and going in their boats are an interesting sight. Long-tail boats can be chartered at most of the larger docks. I chartered one for 2,000 baht/per entire boat for two hours from the Central Pier (Saphan Taskin) and split this with two other passengers making my cost 700 baht with tip. One way or the other, a journey on the river is not to be missed!
Worth taking the boat!. We travelled on the skytrain then the fast boat to the Grand Palace. Crowded later in the day but not in the morning. Only 15drs. Great way to see a bit of the city.

River Tours. Whether your using a long tail boat, one of the dinner tours, or the ferry..its all worth the trip. Each one is a unique experience..be careful of all the long tail boat vendors and be sure your getting what you want. The river itself is busy and has lot's of sites worth seeing. Take a camera to keep the memories fresh.

Excellent Value. Very easy to use,caught the boat at Central pier,an all day pass is 150 Bhat and the piers that it stops at allow you to visit the main attractions.A usefull booklet is giving with the ticket showing which pier to get off and the directions from the pier to the temple etc that you are visiting.

An adventure!. Our tour included a ride on the Chao Phraya river - the water seems polluted but the ride was quite an adventure. We were on a small boat and were sloshed around quite a bit. Fun times and we made it to shore alive!

a very lively artery. One way of experiencing this mighty river is very easy and cheap. Just take a public boat, yellow line, from the start, take a nice seat and go all the way to the terminus. It will cost you 15 Bath one way and it takes about one hour.
Easy Access to Bangkok Attractions. Quick, no traffic access to Bangkok attractions. Cheap, negotiable ferry/boat costs. Did not like smells, polluted waters, hot humid

Scenic river tour. The chao phraya river Thailand, the world famous chao phraya river which runs through bangkok and reaches as far as Ayutthaya, the ancient capital of old Siam(Thailand). Cruising along the river takes you past the Famous ancient buddhist monument, the Wat Arun as well as many interesting sights outside bangkok. You can detour into smaller rivers where you can watch the daily activities of the floating markets, a must scene to see for foreigners as it is very different from landbased - markets.The best time to tour the river markets is in the morning. The river can take you from bangkok to Ayutthaya city from a 2 hours tour to a full day depending where you want to visit. You can catch a river boat anytime and everywhere along the river in bangkok. It is very cheap to take a river boat tour.
A day on the river. Buy an all day ticket for 150 bhat and hop on and off the ferries and tourst boats. A great way to see the city.

Great way to explore Bangkok. You must take a trip on the river whilst in Bangkok. It's not the prettiest or cleanest river but it a nice, cheap & easy way to travel to Bangkok's sights. Try the Express Ferry for 40baht for a single trip.
Chao Phraya dinner cruise. We took a dinner and cruise from the dock at RiverCity. OK buffet. No narration of sights. Good music/dancing.

Ideal for initial reccy. Yes you can take an orange flag boat up the Chao Phraya River for 15 baht but it is also only 40 baht one way on the blue flag tourist boat and if you embark at Saphorn pier and stay on till Phra Arthit Pier (about 30 minutes) you get a tour guide commentary about both sides of the river that is a great introduction to the city sights. You can pay 150 baht to hop on and off but we opted for the 40 baht ticket one way ticket. You can pay for either ticket once onboard the boat, without having to queue at the ticket booth. We stopped for a cooling watermelon drink at the restaurant at Pak Kret pier then jumped on a 15 baht orange flag boat for the return journey. Great way to get an initial reccy. Take the dark green Silom Line BTS to Saphan Taksin then take Exit 2 to Saphorn pier. It's also not far to walk from the BTS stop to the Lebua Hotel at State Tower for wonderful views from its bars and restaurants - Sky Bar, Sirocco, Breeze, 64th floor - and incredibly attentive service. The river boat is also an ideal way to avoid traffic jams by accessing the Grand Palace at Tha Tien pier.

Hire a Longboat!. We hired a private long boat for 1 hour which took us up and down the river (approx £16.00) this is an excellent way to see the city and you may even catch a few surprises on the way!

Spend as little time or as long as you like on the river. No need for expensive tours all you need is a Chao Phraya Tourist Boat one day River Pass ticket 150 baht around $5 Australian and a good map a sufficient one is issued with your ticket and you can hop on and off at your own pace along the river. Service times 9.30 -16.00. You may also use the Chao Praya Express boat using the same route until 19.30 with the same ticket. The ticket services 8 piers giving access to some of Bangkok's tourist attractions. You can also change boats and proceed further up the river to pier N30 on the same ticket just show the girl on board.Your journey starts from the Sathorn (Central) pier adjacent to BTS Saphan Taskin monorail Station. We got off and walked around china town Ratchawongse Pier N5 up and down the small alleyways with motor bikes loaded with boxes doing deliveries to all the stall-shop owners. Then back on board we set our sights on Tha Tien Pier N8 visiting the Museum of Siam a quick clean bathroom stop here & a visit to the Reclining Buddha...remember girls to take a sarong to cover up as polite dress is required no short sleeves or shorts allowed. A few more stops I will let you discover. A great relaxing way to see Bangkok but be warned the boats pull into the jetty and you need to be quick to get on and off. Make sure you wear good shoes as no waiting here for you but it all appears to work seamlessly.

An inexpensive ride along the river. First of all, make sure you don't get on the tourist boat. It's 150 baht. You see the same thing on the commuter express boat (look for the orange flag) for 15 baht. It's a great way to sightsee for almost free. Apparently, humanity can't use a river without turning it dark green, but if you look up and out you'll enjoy yourself. Sit near the back so you don't get splashed, unless of course, you don't mind being splashed with green water. Go up one side, down the other and enjoy the breeze and the sights on a sunny day. It's the best!

Convenient traveling. While the river, like almost all rivers in urban areas, was a bit dirty, cruising up and down it was fascinating. Not only is it a very convenient and a relatively quick way to move around the city it also offers some really beautiful views of Bangkok.

Cheap cheap cheap.... If you are a tourist and want to see all the historic spots... You can either buy a day pass on the local boat 'bus' from 9 am to 4 pm or pay as you go for so cheap - as you need it. We bought the pass and never really were able to benefit from all the possible stops because the Grand Palace alone took over 3 hours to visit!
Cool drive. But alot of pollution in the river :( The boat drive was cool and it's cheap :) good view of the town and temples on the boat

Nice view. You can take a boat with cheaper price to travel along the main river at night. Or you can take a cuisine ship to dine in romance. There are many hotels along the river. However, the river isn't clean and clear, therefore, I dislike to walk near the river. You may prefer the top view from the high sky building where you can see the small towns under you. Choose the condominium or restaurants on the highest floor to get a good view at night. Many bridges across the river turn on the light at night including the cuisine ships running along the river.

A busy river. From Saphan Taksin wharf, next to the Skytrain stop, you can get the tourist boat to Nontaburi (where there is a daily market) It's some 70 minutes and dirt cheap. The boat stops at many places along the way. If you are staying in the KSR area, you can get a 32, 33 or 64 bus back to Samsen Road, nearby.

Love the river. Great way to see Bangkok is to take a river taxi downtown. I never tire of seeing the houses, hotels and buildings that line the river and somehow there always seems to be a new that i have never seen.
Good cruise. The river is not the cleanest of rivers. However the cruise is decent and value for money. You will have a good time especially if you go in a group.

Absolute must - take a bus boat. Crowded, maybe, but the best and cheapest way to see the life along the Chao Praya river or to get to the main attractions of Bangkok.I prefer to take the usual line (yellow?) which stops everywhere in order not to miss any detail of everyday life.

Always, always, always. I love this river, the water txies, the tour boats, the long-tailed boats, the people, the houses, the hotels, the...Do not miss time on the river. It IS Bangkok as far as I am concerned.
A bit of a disappointment. There is a lot of activity on the river, but, in my opinion, the flotsam takes away from the experience. It may be more romantic on a night cruise.

Bangkok's Liquid Super Highway. In 2009 we stayed in Millenium Hilton Bangkok which is on the banks of Chao. This massive river plays a vital rold in thais way of life. It's not just a massive freeway from boats of all sizes who travels in both directions but its also a source of food for some thai who goes fishing here. You can go on a romantic dinner cruise at night or just simply ride a james bond boat and see the city from a different perspective. For me I used the water taxi service to get me to Saphan thaksin station from all of the palaces in tha thien station.
wonderful!. awesome,especially in night!temples in the river bank look cool in the light!everyone visiting bangkok should take a dinner cruise!

Action guaranteed. Went on public transport boats. Easy way to go to the different attractions of Bangkok: Wat Pho, the Buddha, the Palace and the chinese quarter. When you take a tourist boat you can easily hop on and off and the guide will tell you about the top attractions.
explore Chao praya !. explore the river with a boat ,rent a boat the price are traded !!! don't forget your camera !! ...................

Rather a transportation mean than a tourist view point. Don't be disappointed. If you want to "experince" it, then you have to book one of these long boat, which can be quite expensive. Otherwise, you are fixed to the "River Bus", which is crowded and you are not allowed to sit outside (don't aks me why)

romantic cruise and easy way to travel on express boat. We actually got open tickets and first went round the Chao Praya river taking loads of pictures and enjoying kind of a romantic cruise! Then we used the boat hoping on and off to get to different interesting places such as temples, the Grand Palace. If you stay in Koh San Road, there is a pier at Phra Arthit. I loved it.

Enjoy the ride. In the first place, do not pay for the 150B to get the one day pass, this one day pass is mainly for tourists, and the boat will have a blue flag. Take the orange flag boat, where it practically covers all the way to the last stop (N30)Per trip cost 15B, and you only need to purchase the ticket while you on the boat.Prepared to spent 50 mins for one way trip from Central Pier to N30, of cos, you can stop at any point to visit different attractions, if not, it will be a good ride up and down to enjoy the scene
How about lunch nearby the Chao Phraya?. If you have time, get on a boat for a Chao Phraya River Tour and Canal Tour. You will see Bangkok from a very interesting perspective.

Don't take the tourist boats!. Make sure you get the public transport boat and do not do a river tour or take the tourist boats. Take the yellow or orange line - marked by yellow or orange flags. You get transport for almost nothing if you don't take the tourist boats.

A must. This is a must for anyone visiting Bangkok for the first time. If you can run to it, hire a long tail boat and let the driver take you along the river at speed and then - in a more leisurely way - off up the khlongs (canals) that remain one of the nhighlights of Bangkok. You can hire by the hour and negotiate hard on price. But be prepared for a few extras: once into the khlongs there will be passing boats offering souvenirs and food and its hard to escape them. But that's part of the experience.Alternatively take the cheap option of either the tourist or regular boats that ferry people endlessly up and down the river. You can hop on and off at various piers for the price of a single day ticket. Piers let you have easy access to most of the main tourist attractions and to lesser known parts of the city, such as the graet wholesale fruit, veg and flower market. That's a genuinely cheap option for getting round the city, but boats can be crowded.The great thing about the Chao Phraya is that it is relatively cool, particularly when Bangkok is at its most humid. It's also a working river, with much to see; you've forever passing heavily laden barges, towed by incongrously small tugs. It's easy to spend a few hours on and off the water, without breaking a sweat. Well, kind of.

Transportation, Not Site Seeing. The river is a great way to get around, but its filthy, noisy and it smells. With that said, the site seeing boat is a quick cheap way to see the river. Not sure if children would appreciate it as much as adults.
Essential transit. It is a good way to get around different parts of Bangkok, with many impressive and charming sights along the way.

Blend of water and land. I have seen cities with and without rivers but Bangkok is the only city where land and water mingle with each other like they were always meant to be together. I discovered the river purely by chance when I walked from Pahurat to the Victory Bridge. There I got on to a ferry that was going to the Harbor Department jetty where my hotel was. It was evening. The experience of traveling over the river Chao Phraya was out of this world. Seeing all those amazing Wats on both the banks, taking in the diversity of passengers on the steamer, the gentle river breeze- all together made up an unforgettable experience. Bangkok without a river cruise is just not the same.

Great for Cheap Transportation, Dirtier than expected. PAY ON THE BOAT!. Travelling in Bangkok through Taxi, Tuk Tuks and other means can be quite exhausting and stressful, however, through the river and their ferries, we found it be pretty simple, cheap and haggle-free. The only issue is that the ferries can be jam packed with people but still for 15THB, you get what you pay for and you avoid the traffic jams on the road. It is an easy way to get to main tourist attractions and you can see Bangkok through a different means of transportation. There will be a lady that walks around collecting the 15THB, unless you buy a day pass for 150THB that will get you on and off the ferries unlimited.Beware, you can get splashed by the water, which we found to be filthy.

Another city, another river. Gosh.. I had occasion to cross over the Chao Phraya to get to Wat Arun, and, in a more leisurely context, to sit on a hotel terrace with a cold beer and watch boats and stuff float by.By and large I find rivers to be just that - rivers, or bodies of boring (often mucky) water, but sometimes with interesting things lining the banks. BKK has such a fascination for farangs because of all the Oriental stuff that one can see from a boat, including the aforementioned wat and also, big tall modern buildings proclaiming Bangkok's place amongst the ranks of 'modern' capital cities. I expect that further upriver there may be jungles and furry animals and stuff like that, but I never got that far. What I did see, however, is fish! Yes, when necking said beer, there were things swimming around in the water which is probably a healthy sign. Maybe not too mucky, after all.

Fun way to see the city. Obviously traveling up and down the river isn't as convenient as the BTS line in Bangkok, but it's a terrific way to step back in time and see the city in a whole new light.There are plenty of ferry boats to take you up and down the river, but buying tickets can be a bit frustrating. But after you see how it's done, it all makes sense.Last time we were in Bangkok we took a ferry from Lebua at State Tower to the Royal Palce by ferry and it was a great experience. You get to see things you'd never see going by other means.

Great views but quite smelly. This is a great way of getting around the sights of Bangkok or the temples at least using a tourist ticket from the central pier which links to the Skytrain. Boats are very crowded but you get a pleasant breeze and with a day tourist pass you can hop on and off these tourist boats at will. Be aware there are other boat companies, touts and some cons so keep your eyes open and your head screwed on. The views are at times stunning and at other times the poverty that some of the locals live in in shanties by the river is evident and quite thought provoking. It is however so much better than the road transport in Bangkok which is a choking mess of traffic and pollution.

Chao Phraya River Tour. As promised i will recommend a 3rd place in Bangkok where i like to go.After the Rembrandt Hotel and Little Italy restaurant i want to recommend you to go make a cruise on chayo praya river. I did it different way. day time 2 hours, night time 2 hours and 2 days cruise.I really appreciate particularly night time with mekhala cruise. we spent a fabulous moment with my friends.
dirty river. nothing to shout about! why would you want to have a River Boat Cruise Dinner when what you see is "Tea with Milk" colour river! LOL

Excellent. We went with Thai private tour guide. Just excellent time on long tail boat although our son was very scared of the noise of long tail boat. We preffer River that all the temples as we could get some idea how people live there. Must see in BKK.

Must Try!!!. By travelling in a local boat through Chao Phraya River, you will have a chance to see interesting sites located on the both sides of the river. I always prefer the local boats (not the tourist boats) which are very cheap (around 15 Bath per ride!) and are the popular transport mode amongst the locals as well as the tourists. Once when I mistakenly boarded a tourist boat, I witnessed the boat staff harassing an Indian couple who also mistakenly joined the boat and who were trying to explain it to the staff but the staff kept harassing them and were asking them to pay 40 Bhat!! The best time to visit / have a ride on a boat is early in the morning or in the evening during sunset!

Amazing river and canal tour. We did an amazing river and canal cruise on a rice barge! The canal cruise and seeing how the people live on the river was really interesting!! I booked the tour through the hotels2thailand website - actually I booked a total of 6 tours with this company and everyone of them was great. They pick you up at your hotel (mostly punctually), you travel in a airconditioned minibus and the tourguides are (mostly) great, with a wealth of knowledge about the area you are seeing. Definitely good value for money (and it is a LOT cheaper - about 50% - booking with them rather than the multitude of tourism places you will see when you get there).
filthy but fascinating. See Bangkok by river. Dirtier than the Mississippi but a wonderful way to see the sights and beat the traffic. Try a Klong tour.

Do go on the river. You really must try a trip on the river - it's a great way to see the sights! You can go on a tourist boat or a ferry which is much cheaper - we did find it difficult to work out the differences and how to pay.

Take a Boat Tour. This was so relaxing. Pay a little extra and get a boat with a tarp that provides some shade, especially if you are going in the afternoon. We went on the boat for an hour or so and fed catfish along the way. This is a nice excursion to save until the afternoon when you might be tired after a day of walking around.

Fun rides. Fascinating waterway. Both hotels we stayed in were on the river. Loved watching the "action". Boats lit up at night very special. Able to avoid awful street traffic to some extent by using public transport on the river which was very cheap. Best physical feature by far in Bangkok - don't miss it.

Try the local ferry. From Central Pier tourist boat leaves for 40Bhat one way to any other pier. If you will ask the Blue Tourist boat counter they will tell that right now its the only boat available BUT its not true. Just go and sit behind the blue Tourist boat booth on the benches, you will see many locals and tourists seating there. There are other lines yellow, red and orange, rates vary from 8-15bhat. It's a good experience getting on the boat and getting off. River water is dirty but the boat ride is good especially for experience sake or to go to China town (Pier 5) etc. The Cruise starts at Pier 3.

Not quite the cruise you would be expecting. Ferries travel all day and do not pay 150 baht for a day pass on the chayo tourist boat - its a rip off - you will not use it enough to make it money worthwhile. Pay as you go - much cheaper and you can pay on the boat too

Life of Bangkok. Travelling the Chayo Praya River is a great way to experience Bangkok life! we took a small river boat, & went to a small island just out of bangkok called koh kret. Great place to rent a bike, & take a tour of the island!! We love it!

Take a long tailed boat and enjoy. Only way to really get a sense of the traditional way of life in Bangkok is to take an expensive long tailed boat and explore the klongs (and see the Temple of the Dawn in the process). Warning -- when you board the boat there is always a LOT of choppy wave action - not great if you are not steady on your pins... most boat operators are very helpful boarding but this is not for the mobility challenged. Exiting is easier....
Nice cruise !!!. There are classic cruise ships and modern cruise ships !!!Both, very nice, with delicious food and drinks, good music and dance !!!

the venice of the east. USe the river screw the trains. its awesome. also take a boat into the canals. Its sad and incredible to see the slums right on the river where I am suer it used to be a gold mine property to live right on tha canals. but use the ferry as musch as possible to travel. its cheap and less crowded than the bangkok streets
Busy sewer. This waterway is a major artery through the city, and often faster than taking a taxi. It's too bad that there is so much floating garbage flung in by uncaring people!
Best river trip for the price. Catch a local (i.e. not the tourist) bost and for a few baht enjoy an exciting and interesting river trip. One of the best things to do in Bangkok.

This is THE Transportation Through the City. You can take the ferries almost everywhere... they are fast and cheap and reasonably easy to figure out. They're great for getting around and great just to ride up and down the river. Take the "tourist" ferry if you must but for the real local experience take the regular transportation ferries (orange or yellow flags). For an action-packed speedy ride, catch one of the "long tails"... cheap and fast transportation.Do not miss this part of Bangkok.

Chao Phraya River. Didn't doa riverboat tour, just wandered down from my hostel in Silom. It's a "river" lots of boats & as expected a lot of junk floating around, even saw what I thought was a dead turtle, unsure if a pet thrown in or was unlucky enough to go for a swim & dead from all the junk that's in there!

river to take you to the palace. This river is one of the greatest means of transportation in Bangkok. If you have much time to explore the palace through this river you better use the chao phraya express, it cost THB 40 per way. well, the water is not really clean.

Your leading star in Bkk. the chao phraya river is the dorsal spine of bangkok, whatever you do you will finish to cross it, use it to go fast from a point to another, or sightseeing from a terrace, a restaurant, or a bar... Inévitable

Yeah must visit. I loved this place as its historical and our tour guide was so helpful and friendly. He stayed with us all the time and tld us all about the hsitory of this plave and I strogly recommend you come here
Great river. I only passed Chao Phraya on my way to Wat Arun. The water is not really clean, but the river is big and lots of local catfish which is yummy.

You can't miss. This is a place that you can't miss when you come to Bangkok the First time. Along the River, you can visit 5 stars hotel, wonderful temples and lovely markets. If you come to Thailand and you didn't come to Chao Phraya River means you never come to Thaialand.

Boat trip!. We took a boat trip down the river and it was great! The water isn't the cleanest so you definitely wouldn't want to jump in, but we had a goood time. There are lots of fish swimming in the river and you can see them jumping around. There are also boats floating around that come up to you so you can buy drinks and food while you're cruising on the river
Nice. A one time visit. We went on the Asiatique ferry at around 8pm and had a fabulous time dining and enjoying the place. You wouldn't guess how time flew by.
Very nice ferry service. Though its not that frequent, but the ferry service is good. Sometimes gets a bit crowded, but beats the walk on the sun.

boat tour. River divided the city in to two pieces. there are some ferries (touristic and local ones). In your map (take one from airport) you will see different colos on the river , it shows the route of different ferries. we took the local one (15baht, less than 50cent) and it stops at some important points (like Wat Karev, grand palace and Wat Pho) when you go out the ferry you have to buy another ticket. some touristic ones starting from 1000 baht (100% make bargain, possibly it will cost to you 100 baht) complete tour will take almost 1.5 hour.

Big dirty river. My girlfriend and I got very lost at one of the ferry terminals here. It was unused and a man had to be called to come pick us up. He hummed along on his longtail and then took us across the river. A very different trip to the one many tourists try. Give it a go, get away from the hordes, pay a 10th of the price and have a true thai boat ride with a man that has no teeth but smiles always.

Take a passenger boat ride for a rapid adrenaline rush.. Chao Phraya Express Boat Co operates boat services which can be accessed from the Central Pier ( Saphan Taksin BTS) to reach mostly all of the places of historic importance and the monuments situated on each side of the river. The river is the lifeblood of Bangkok. And not just because of this rich history. Around 50,000 people still use its ferries to get to each day.
A nice experience. A nice experience specially if you want to visit China Town or places nearby the river like the Grand Palace.
Great way to see the temples. What a nice way to see the sights........get along to one o the many piers and jump on the local boat....avoid the tourist one if you can

wish the ferries were a little faster. the Chao Phraya river really helps you understand the rhythm of Bangkok life. The river is a wonderful cacophony of Thai life. From fishermen to water taxis to various commercial water vehicles, you can gain a good appreciation for the city by watching the river. The fact that many of the temples are on the river is also very nice. Only problem is that the ferries are a bit slow -- takes 20-40 min to get almost anywhere along the river.
Skip the River Boats ;-(. All the travel books say to take the river boats to the various sites. We decided it's easier to take cabs or tuk-tuks (fun!).

A floating trash tip. If you wondered where all the debris in the river comes from, watch in horror as you see a cleaner near the ferry terminal tip a wheelie bin of rubbish into the river! The best trips on the river are at night when you see the beautifully illuminated buildings along the riverbank and cannot see the cesspool that the river is.

Nice place but dirty. I went with a boat on the river getting from A to B. It was a fun experience seeing the city from this side and also seeing the riverlife. But it was very dirty and trafficked so I wouldn't hang out there. And not booking a hotel just next to the river. It's easy though to buy tickets at the piers.

Great way to get around. We took upto Chinatown and after got on again and went to the end of the line. Very cheap some rides 15B, and can be cooling with a breeze but also can get crowded
Good to see the contrasts of society as well

Get On The River. Bangkok lives by the river. Yes you can take a tour but it is so easy that there is no need to feel nervous, just hop a local boat although preferably not peak hour. Even if you just hop on and don't get off until the end of the trip you will have viewed some incredible sights for 15baht. Its cool, interesting and just a great thing to do. If you want to explore the canals off the main river you can also hire drivers who will navigate you through these as well.
A must do. Cruising the river is a great way to see Bangkok. The breeze not only feels great in the heat but the view is spectacular! Wat arun can be seen from the river and it is a stunning sight.

Take a temple break and enjoy a canal tour. As awesome as Bangkok is it's also one of the hottest steamiest cities on the planet. After hours of walking and visiting the amazing temples and shrines treat yourself to a boat ride-you can pick up one of the long boats at most major docks on either side of the river. Cruising up the canals is wonderful-you'll get a glimpse at life along the river and it makes a delightful and fascinating break from the city sites. Glad we made time for this, definitely worth it.

A little Suprised!. Great way to get to some great attractions.Feel like its an easy way to get ripped off too..everyone is trying to sell you different versions of cruises, long boats, ferries...ho hum only if i spoke the language.Loads of fun anyway...Water is abit gross, lots of floating debris, rubbish, food scraps, plastic bags....Seriously we kept our hands over our mouths so we didnt get splashed between the teeth...ironically got splashed in the eye...hahaha

Good way to travel in bangkok. Most of the tourist spots are accessible by ferry (Grand palace/wat arun/reclining buddha temple/little india/china town). Its only 15 to 20 baht charge (In a public ferry) to visit these places. Its quick when compared to Bangkok's road traffic. And the river itself is really beautiful to miss out on these ferry rides.
A must do, a real eye opener n how some people live. Don't fall in, the river is very dirty.loved the trip in the long tail boat it was quite an experience.
Saphan Takshin. Just go to Saphan Takshin BTS and next to it is Chao Phraya River, Boating is very good to visit other old markets and Wat of Thailand. Wat Arun, Wat Pao.. Once at least must go.

River trip. Go to the public pier just down from the Royal Orchid hotel and negotiate a price for a couple of hours on a long tail boat. It's a great trip up the river then off to the left up a "klong" ( a canal ) to where the Royal barges are housed.Alternatively for a very modest sum just take the river bus for an hour up the river and back. Great views and you will pass famous temples and catch glimpses of the Royal palace!

Relaxed Time. We booked Chaopraya river cruise in Setember 2012 and I must say it was a good experience to see the city at night and having a relaxed time. You have dinner on board. One can also plan a party with friends if you book it exclusively for yourselves. Many cheap options are available as there are different categories of cruises.

One place to have a boat ride.. Good way of getting around places along the river like Grand Palace, Wat Arun and Chinatown. Always take the public ferry as its cheaper unless you come in a group to negotiate rates for a long tail boat. The river could be cleaner though. No complaints. Always board at the main ferry pier at Saphan Taksin as that's the main ferry terminal and English-speaking personnel and tour desks are available.
Express Boat Ride. Fast way to travel in the city and great way to see the shores. With only 15 Baht (~0,5 USD) you can travel the road and see the city.

SHOULD NOT MISS. This may not be as colorful and hypnotic like Victoria harbour Hongkong but a Night cruise ( late evening) by tourist boat is must . This cruise helps you understand why bangkok is called venice of east. Beware of long tail boats as they people try very hard to lure you into a trap.

Enjoyable. The best and cheapest way is to get on the boat and pay once you're on. You can buy a round trip ticket, which means you can get on and off as you like, which was more expensive than the pay as you go ticket. We found you only want to get on and off a couple of times. Nice way to relax ans see the riverside shacks among some 5* hotels. A few sights to be seen along the way, Wat Arun for one.
Take a tour. Brilliant tour on the Chao Phraya River. We had an amazing time and saw amazing things. Highly recommend it.

Well maintain and clean... The river is full with fat and big fishes,u can also buy bread that is sold in the boat to give to the fishes.From my tour guide i get to known tht these fishes r sacred and belong to temple.

Full of activity. The Chao Phraya river is the lifeline of Bangkok, and you just cannot miss it or avoid it. It is bubbling with water, full of all kinds of activities and generally a very happening place.
Fun!. Fun the travel the river with the public watertaxi.The paic, the noise when docking en leaving the dock is great to see. Be aware off getting soaked when you're on the back deck of the boat

Dirty and beautiful. The main road trough Bangkok is the river Chao Praya with its long tail water taxis, tourist boats, dinner cruises, tugs with their barges hundreds of meters long and of course, The Chao Praya Express, the cheap and reliable tough slow way of traveling from one sight to another. Try it, the locals do kit all the time, and the more educated tourists. Its cheap or really cheap, 40 or 15 baths. Never understood which rate applies and when.

great views and easy to travel, but manky!. The river is a working one and provides a great deal of the travel options up the city, there are some great views to be had and the trips round the old canals are beautiful and peaceful but there is a lot of pollution and rubbish - saying that something is alive in it so it cant be that bad. Probably no more polluted than the Thames but looks it!

Great experience.. We went on a long boat. Think we got scammed, as when we arrived to go to grand Palace by taxi when we got out a young man approached us and said he was astudent waiting for friends he recommended a trip on river which we were going to do anyway but he recommened a pier to go to and said to mention Thai friend when we got there. We paid 2800 baht for 1 hour trip. However we did enjoy the experience , definately would do again but would find out a cheaper price.

Great transport link. Use it like the locals do ... A fast cheap pleasant way to travel day times. A frequent service but I think, I am not sure as I did not use it, it either shuts or winds down after 7pm

A good way to see the city. Hop on and off wherever and whenever you like along the snaking river. This is a good way to ease yourself into the buzz of Bangkok city life before committing to the people and traffic on the street!
Fabulous Spot. This would have to be one of the busiesst water ways in Asia so much activity a day on a bangkok long tail is not to be missed
Always pulsing with activity. Great to use this as the way to get around in the city. The 15 bhat fare will take you to within easy walking distance of many of the main tourist and business areas.

The other road in Bangkok. Boat taxis is the other way of getting around many places in Bangkok. Seriously, unless you have to, dont even try to navigate the road traffic yourself and certainly not on a motorbike. And, unless you are young and believe you are immortal, motorbikes taxis are not that good an idea either. The boats, on the other hand are relaxing and a fast way of getting round many places. They are not as quick as the Metro or Skytrain but it is much more scenic. Wear mosquito repellant though
travel at the river with those who live in Bangkok. Nice and cheap way to travel in Bangkok. We always take a boat at the river when we are in bangkok. At rushhour it is very crowdy at the boats.

It's a great experience. The riverboat is definitely worth the experience. It's cheap, convenient and provides a glimpse of what life is like by the riverside. You have the option of taking the public riverboat or hire one, the latter would be more pricey but you can plan your route

A different view of Bangkok. What a great way to explore a different side of Bangkok; we took a long tail boat up the river and then explored the canals of Thon Buri; we stopped at an Orchid Farm for cold beers and some amazing flowers. This is well worth it...and oh yeah make sure you try the fritters that some old boat women sell along the canals.

A great way to see a different view of the city. We loved travelling up and down the chao praya riveron the water taxis that the locals used, we used the orange flag boats, only 15 bhat each way no matter how far you travel up or down the river. You squeeze on with the locals and it's a great experience. The river does look brown but then what city river doesn't. You wouldn't want to drink it but then that's common sense surely. The contradiction of old and new buildings on the side of the river is good to see. A great way to get about.

Not many tourists yet cool breeze and easy. Liked that it was cheap, simple, comfortable. Nice breeze on the water. Helpful people at the dock area to sort you out. Do not go on tourist boat, go on the middle (orange) level boats. They were easy to figure out and we enjoyed a trip north and a trip south. You pay, get on, get off, do what you wish, then come back and start again. So you pay per segment. It was about 14 B if I recall, so 50 cents. We rode all the way to each end. North went a long way. Saw the people and some of the sights of Bangkok. Convenient way to go to some attractions. As you approach any tourist site in Bangkok, scammers try to interest u in their taxi/boat/tuk tuk and will tell you something is closed or point you in wrong direction. Pay attention and brush these people off.

Busy River. Fascinating watching life on the river - our hotel terrace directly overlooked the river and we used the ferry daily to get across to our destinations. Some of the river trips by 'private' boat were overpriced.

OK If Your Not Tall. Used the Orange flag boats very good value at 15 baht a trip but very very overcrowded and if you can't get a seat you wont see a thing if you are over 5' 6" but the best way to get to the temples and other places of interest along the river

Take a free tour. Take the express ferry from pier 1 to 30. Specially on weekends pier 30 is an excellent place to be, with eateries popping up at the end of the day where local Thai come to spend their afternoon on the river banks. Excellent food!!!!

Rent a long Boat!!. This is a wonderful trip if you rent a long boat and see the canals. Don't go with 30 or 40 people in tours, just go to the pier and ask for the longboat to take you to the canals. It's about 1200 bhat and that's a good hour ride. We stopped at the longboat museum and saw the kings fleet. So beautiful.

Devine Ride. The river symbolises the life around the city and is the hub of several known buildings, hotels & markets. Offers an excellent opportunity to feel Bangkok. The water being not the cleanest, be careful not to let the river water go into your mouth during the boat ride.

Great value if you take the ferry. Don't mistake the tour for a simple ferry ride. You can pay 15 baht and go as far up (or down) the river as you like. A great, way to get to areas like the Grand Palace or Khao San Road that don't have BTS service.
River Cruize. I rented a small boat and went on a cruize for about one and half hour, it was a beautiful experience.

Take your chances with river transport!. We gota free shuttle boat to the Calypso ladyboy show from Saphin Taksin pier. The boat was overloaded and leaned a bit to the right. We made it safely to our destination but an accident was on the cards given the amount of water traffic and the near misses we saw!

Use the ferry boats like buses!. This river runs through the centre of the city and ferry boats are used like buses. The central terminus is 2 minutes walk from the Sky Train. Check how often and where the ferry boat stops using the maps at the terminus. Each boat has a (not very large) flag that matches the routes shown on the map. You can pay the crew on the boat, or sometimes buy tickets before boarding.Boats are used mostly by local people; they are modern, clean and fast.

Great views. If you are near the river you should make a point to take a private long tail boat ride for about an hour. The cost for us was 1000 Baht. I'm sure you could negotiate that down a bit. You can get these at any pier. I went to one other before this one that said 2000 Baht so I moved on. I'd recommend checking out the klongs to see how the lower income residents live. Also make sure to go by Wat Arun. If you want to have the view for cheaper, you can take a water taxi and just stay on through all the stops.
A wonderful river. Go on the river bus or go to River City and have a coffee and watch the world of thew river - it is endlessly fascinating

Great place to end your day with good food and live music. Only thing which i disliked was all indians were given seperate boat. Good food with lots of fruits, desserts. Beautiful view of the city and river. Good live music with Hindi songs.

Floating Market. The River is a central part of the historic district in Bangkok. Royal Barges are seen floating here during important festival and housed in hangars when not in use. The once bustling floating market is now to be found elsewhere but a few boats ply their ware and sell some simple tourist mementos at reasonable prices.
slow down.... find some time to take this slow boat trip, enjoy the breeze and the river side view of old bangkok. recommend to take this trip during sunset time.

Night Cruise. Good food on the cruise. Nice scenery. Had about 2 hours plus on the cruise along the river. Upon disembarkation, had a shopping spree along the Asiatique Square. U can find lots of items like clothing, souvenirs, bags and food here.

Stop Rocking the Boat. The day my friends and I were on the river it was quite choppy. I have a bad knee and a friend(another senior) had some mobility problems. Getting into and out of the boat was a problem and we both got banged up a bit. The dock guys did try to steady the boat but it was a long drop to get in and a huge step up to get out. The ride itself was fun and Bangkok is beautiful from the water with the mix of old and new. Just be careful.

So much fun, well worth hiring a boat to explore!. As there was four of us, two couples, we decided to hire a boat for a couple of hours to explore the river and all the rivers and canals that interlink around it. This proved to be such an excellent decision. We paid 1500 Baht for a private engine-powered longboat and we powered down the Chao Phraya River. As we went off the main river a lady approached us in another boat and offered us beers and soft drinks to purchase. So we were taking in all the sights and sounds of our own magical private tour, at our own pace, sipping a cold beer relaxing in the sun. It was such a highlight and I'd really recommend it to anybody!During the boat ride we saw the Wat Arun, the Grand Palace and so many more sights. We boarded the boat at Sathorn Pier. Have a bit of a barter with the locals: last time I came to Bangkok I went on the public big boat and this smaller, more intimate experience was so much better and the boat really whipped up some pace too as we raced down the river! Was really interesting too to see the people who live by the rivers and canals and to have a brief insight into their lives. Make sure you leave a couple of hours in your holiday schedule to pencil this trip in as it was one of my favourite things to do.

An absolute must to do!. It is not only a (cheap) way to discover the main attractions of Bangkok. But to many places the river boots offer a faster way to get around than being stuck with a taxi or tuk tuk in traffic jam.

Take a stunning boat ride!!!.... Chao Praya is a mystic river and it is truly a stunnig trip to cross it just inside Bangkok, stopping at the main piers to visit each temple around, or even further to visit Ayutthaya, the former capital, some kilometers north, available by boat ride too (highly recommend it!!!...)Night boat trip is also amazing and nice to have dinner on boat, watching all the monuments on riverside along the riverI repeat it everytime I travel to Bangkok, as if it was the 1st time, and always find it lovely.To cross the river from pier to pier to visit the temples I prefer the traditional Thai tailboat, used by the locals as wellTo visit Ayutthaya, nice World Heritage site by Unesco, I would recommend the boat trip as the nicest way, lunch included

Great Tourist Boat. We used the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat to get up and down the river and visit various tourist sites. Really good value transport. Great to get to where you want to go with no traffic jams!

Secret love. I will not give away my secret favourite place on this river here, but take it from a Bangkokfan; there is not much that is nicer than to sit ON the Chao Phraya river with a 30 baht coffee in the morning, watching the barques and longtailboats go by.The Shangri-La, Oriental, Hilton and Continental may have nice views to, but feel the river on a rickety pier or hire your own boat and cruise it. Or take the ferry all the way down (up) to Nonthaburi and back for around 20 Baht.
Review !!. While cruising here in long tail boat is great. This boat also seen in a James Bond Movie but the water is too dirty.

cheap trick. A cheap way to see Bangkok at night from the river. It was good enough for me, but obviously you can pay 2000-10000 bath a person iso 25 and get some food and music and a 2 hour program. Up to you!

Use the public ferries or the express tourist ferries.. The best way to get to some parts of Bangkok is by this river. The ferries are cheap and quick. But you have to be agile in getting on and off.Best avoided are the long tail boats.

The best Bangkok Highway!. Whether you travel by ferry or longtail boat or water taxi this is probably the fastest and most fun way to get close to where you want to go in the city as far as attractions go. This was the way people traveled for commerce in the past with all the warehouses set up along the banks to receive goods off ships from far away ports and to ship out goods as well. Now lined with big hotels and new condo developments. Awesome place to watch fireworks during New Years Celebrations!

Use and abuse of traveling on Chao Phraya River. This is a fantastic way to travel in Bangkok! Dont hesitate to take the line until the end (1 hour) and you will discover a nice tawn with a typical market!!

do a long boat tour !. A compulsory part of the Bangkok experience. Cheap trips up and down the river.Be prepared for throngs of people and a crush when boarding and departing the boat.Be especially alert when disembarking the boat, as their is a real rush when everyone gets off and it can be really hard to push your way through all the people who are not getting off.Make sure you position yourself close to the exit before the boat arrives at your stop. Watch out for the sun. Try and get a seat on the side of the boat which is not exposed to the harsh sunlight.The river should by rights be totally polluted but it is in fact packed with catfish etc. You see them jumping around everywhere.An extension \from the Chao Phraya is to take a 2 hour long tail boat tour through the klongs. I think it cost about 500 baht each but is totally worth it.The tour travels on the Chao Phraya and then up through the canals to see local houses and lifestyle.

Great way to get to parts of the city. Great way to get to parts of the city the BTS & subway don't give access to. Also a great tourist attraction in its own right, so relaxing, just sitting watching as the boat quickly goes up/down the river. Cheap transport as well

Dinner Cruise - Chao Phraya River. Whilst in Bangkok do not miss the Chao Phraya River Cruise. There are quite a few cruises all of which start in the evening around 7 pm and end with dinner after a river cruise for around 2 hours. There is Indian as well as continental and Thai food served with music including filmy hindi songs

Take a shared cruise. We took a personal Cruise for an hour on the River (did not have other option) and it cost us 1300 Bahts. Perhaps a shared Cruise on the river along with Dinner (if you can eat Thai food) shall be better to take on the River. One can also hop-on and hop-off on the boats from different piers and visits different temples on the route. Can also visits some of the markets like China Market on the route.

Public ferry is excellent. the public ferry up the Chao Phraya River is just the same as the private companies but much quieter and much much cheaper 50 cents vs 20$ The views are lovely and it takes you right to the skytrain and the temples and reclining Buddha. the ferry runs until about 7pm

Must do!. You must take the time to ride either the tourist boat, or the water taxi. I took the water taxi & I think because I stood I wasn't charged. It was very interesting to see the contrast of local shakes & high rise buildings. Its also a great way to cool off from the heat & avoid Bangkok traffic.

Extremely nice and useful. While the klongs give you a good impression on everyday Bangkok life, the river is a good way of transportation for tourists. Certainly if you are willing to visit the Wat Arun, the easiest way is by taking the ferry to the other side of the river whereby it’s only a 100m walk to this great temple. Furthermore, there are several companies offering you a tour on the river. You have the public ferry company (extremely cheap and good time schedule), but also multiple private companies offering cruises during the day and (sunset) dinner cruises

taste of Bangkok. great way to travel in conjunction with sky train. not overurn with tourists cheap and easy to use just remember how to get to the marine dept terminal when heading to see the golden buddha or china town which is a short walk. But the thai people so friendly you will not have any problems using the river.

beware the long boats. The River is a convenient means to reach many sites in Bangkok. It is inexpensive, perhaps to a degree. I have used boats on the River on several visits. My most recent visit I failed to determine ahead of time what boat I would be taking. I was taken across two large, comfortable boats to a waiting long boat into which I literally was dumped. I enjoy the ride on these boats. If I were 18 I'd love it. However, my aging body does not take happily to the extreme distances one must jump, hurdle, fall, tumble, scramble to enter and exit the long boats from docks designed for the vessels of the well-to-do. Be cautious when agreeing to purchase a ticket; ask for a specific indication of the boat you will be riding. "Cheap" here means rugged, at water level. The boat operators were always courteous and helpful.
Charming and authentic. This is the old Bangkok. Enjoy the skyline and see old houses and busy Bangkok life.You can rent a Thai speed boat to discover also remote areas.
Take the Princess Cruise. Do NOT miss the Princess cruise on the river with dinner and music. We had a great time on the cruise with some lovely music and a well laid out buffet.
Enjoy a day (or night) on the river. Buy a day pass on the tourist boat and ride up and down the river to see many of the sights of Bangkok - great place to cool off in the heat of the day.

Bangkok as you would imagine. The river boats take you up into some of the few remaining canals flowing into the Chao Phraya river. The canals are are putrid in places, but you see the flimsy huts built out over the water and children waving and splashing about. It's the real Thailand, not the tourist orientated attractions normally visited.

Good cheap way to see the city from a different perspective. We travelled up and down the river on one of the ferries. We were actually originally trying to get across fro to Wat Arun. We got on at Pier No 6 and asked to go to Wat Arun. In hindsight I think the staff tried to explain that we had to go to Pier 8 and get a crossing boat. However, we did not understand and ended up going way up river. We then came back down to Pier 8 and did the crossing to Wat Arun. So we ended up on the river for the best part of an hour. It was a great way to see so many of the famous sites of Bangkok as well as the bridges of the river. Note these are not tourist boats.

river boat dinner cruise exceptional. the Chao Praya Princess boat dinner cruise was not your usual mundane dinner cruise. Best time ever! Great food, many lighted sights along the river to see at night, good band and singers and lots of fun dancing to American tunes. Boat crew and wait staff are very hospitable and you cannot help but have a great and memorable time!

A hive of industry and transport. Never ceased to be amazed at the variety of craft on the Chao Phraya. James Bond boats, river taxis, hotel shuttles, blue, yellow and orange flag boats up and down river, locals fishing and those huge barges with families living on them! Visit the famous locations via the river, or just hop off and see the local life.

Must visit place.... If you are in Bangkok and don't go there .. then it will be a great mistake, specially at the night time the river and surrounding environment is great .. go and explore .... U can purchase ticket of many of the river cruise to enjoy the place and the good part of the river cruise is that it comes with dinner so... you can fill both ur purposes...

Overrated experience. Chao Phraya is very important no doubt especially as a tourist it connects you to most attractions fast and cheap. However, it's not clean and "recreational". Long tail boat is just a big noisy engine on a small boat; i dont find anything thrilling there. On the other hand, those pricy dinner cruise is just money making device. Why to pay $30 when you can go up and down the river using river ferry in a fw Bahts? and price you pay wont change the view of Bangkok, or does it? I recommend taking the experience of Chao Phraya but using river taxi and mingling with locals. That is cheap and the best cultural immersion.

Cheap, Fast, and Interesting. Taking an Orange Line boat is a fast and cheap way to get to a few various areas in Bangkok. The river itself is not so beautiful, but the views from the river are worth seeing.

Fun way to take a break. Take a break from the Bangkok heat and enjoy a ride down the river. Its worth it just to relax and sit back and see the homes along the river. Its so fun to have a peak into the everyday lives of the people living along the river.
A must see destination. If you are in bangkok and free in the evening never miss the opportunity to have dinner while cursing in the river and the roof top bar its awesome...
Take the River Cruise!. We just loved the Chao Phraya river dinner cruise! It is a two hour dinner cruise along the river, with good food (both vegetarian and non-vegetarian) and entertainment.

A must to see but a river in Bangkok is a river in Bangkok.. I like to look at things from a locals perspective so this trip allowed me to see a little more of what the Thai folk do and how they live. I would reommend this excursion to first timers in particular.

A Must See. A must see. Get a very different view and feel of the city. Be warned however, the long tail boats can be a scam. We paid for one and half hours and got one hours. We also paid for food to feed the fish but we didn't stop so no fish!. When we got off the boat a man charged us 20 bart each to land..........total scam and a shame as the rest of our stay was excellent. Maybe try a tourist boat instead.

The unforgettable ride. Never miss on the small boat ride. Take a couple of bags of bread to feed the hundreds of scavenger fish!! They come to you in waves, layered one on top of another, you'd imagine they'll climb to the boat ( scary thought) you will see the slumb homes on both sides of the river, people washing dishes,others cooking, others washing clothes, etc.... It's a national geographic kind of tour. I wish I know where we took the boat from, we were invited:) ! If there is just one thing worthwhile doing in bangkok it's this boat ride. You'll rent a private.boat with someone who'll drive you... Enjoy it!

Not the prettiest but it's a must-see. Not the bluest water on the planet but if you're visiting Thailand, much of what you will want to see lies along the river. Great to take a dinner cruise or view from a rooftop bar.

Scams afoot. Be careful when going on the canal cruises. We scheduled one and were told it would be site-seeing at some specific attractions. They tried to charge us 1000 Baht each (we weren't about to pay that) and the site seeing was if you could see it from the canal, it counted. The driver didn't communicate with us at all. In the end, we realized it was a scam.

Cheap, effective, excellent views. 15 baht boat rides are the cheapest and most convenient way of getting to all the major sites. Grand Palace, Wat Pho and Khao San Rd are all stops along this line. Try to avoid the last two boats of the day however as they can get quite crowded, although you will get to see the gorgeous night lights along the river for a steal. Also make sure you know what time the last boats are because they can vary for different stops!

Don't miss it!. Take a long boat, take a ferry, take a commuter boat, but make sure that you spend lots of time on this river to get a real feel of the life of people in Bangkok and the role that the river plays in people's lives. If possible, take a long boat into the canals and see the homes, the trade, the intensity of the water experience. Do remember if taking the commuter boats that many of them stop running at an early time. You may need to find alternate transportation back if the service has stopped. Walk along the river at night and see the tourist boats lit up and the dinner cruise boats. The sight is quite nice.

Venice with winter sun. I love the river I'm looking at it now from hotel.the water bus is amazing value as little as 15 baht a ride . Don't buy the all day 150 baht not good value . Try the Klingon water bus also a great trip. Visit the riverside hotels on thir free boats .
The river is life. Certainly a must-do in BKK, you can experience the hectic pace of river life. The Chao Phraya runs right down the middle of BKK, affording views of many aspects of life.

Dirty & hectic. There is lots of traffic on the river particularly near the Taksin bridge, which means its rather polluted & dirty. We went on a river trip which was a good way to see many city attractions, but parts were very smelly & not pleasant.

Amazing experience, a must do in bkk. I LOVED the ferry rides on the Chao Phraya River. Breathtakingly beautiful at night. I'm sure the dinner cruises are amazing! Its very cheap and saves a lot of time to travel to the city and back. A must do in bkk! Try visiting the Asiatique Riverfront at night from the ferry.

Love it!. Some people find this river dirty and unappealing, but to me, there is something so romantic and lovely about it. I don't think I would ever tire of traveling up and down it's lengths- there is always something interesting to see.

You have to take a trip along it...... The life blood of Bangkok and the old part of the city looks very different when viewed from the river. The regular boats will drop you at many of the sites, Grand Palace etc. Try it in the evening as well as it looks great all lit up as well

Fascinating waterway.. Our hotel (the Shangri-La) was on the river and we found the ferry was often the most convenient, interesting (and cheap) way of getting around Bangkok. There is a constant stream of boats using the river, from long tail boats, hotel boats, ferries right up to huge barges (towed by comparatively tiny tugs) - all making for a fascinating show. One evening we had dinner on the hotel boat. You get a very different view from what you see during the day time with many of the buildings lit up at night. Wat Arun is particularly beautiful at night.

Love it!. The best way to travel in Bangkok - use the river! The river taxis cost only 15 baht and are frequent, fast and reliable. From Kaosan ara hop on at Pier 13 (Pier Arthit) and hop of at the Palace/. Reclining Buddha, or the Flower Market, or Central Pier where you connect with the Skytrain to wherever you want to go.

Great way to get around. Probably the best way to get around Bangkok is by using the excellent regular ferry service up & down this energetic river. There's always a lot going on here and it's also a great alternative way to simply explore the city. Get's you away from the hustle & bustle of the streets.
Arrange your own long tail tour it's easy. We did a private long tail tour - just go to the boat side stop - and you can haggle the operators - the options are endless.

Great way to see Bangkok. While staying along the river, we found the tourist boats to be great for getting around - much better than sitting in a traffic jam on the streets of Bangkok. Direct access to the palace and Wat Arun from our hotel. A must see in Bangkok

River Taxis. We loved using the river taxis to travel up and down the river. Our hotel was near one of the taxi stops so we used river taxis as much as possible. Just be careful to plan your trips before dark because the taxi stop in the early evening.

feed the fish, you'll love it. the river is clean, there are plenty of temples on the banks of the river that gives a great photo moment. the highlight was the feeding if the large numbers of fish in the river that take you back to the days of feeding birds in the city or ducks in a pond.

Be brave. You have to go on the river boat up the Chao Phraya, it's an experience!. The boats are cheap and convenient but often very busy so be prepared to be herded. Buying a ticket is a bit confusing to start with but if you stand around looking gormless for long enough there's always a friendly Thai person happy to shout instructions at you. The tourist boats are more expensive but it's all relative.Be careful getting on and off. Jump on board and enjoy another mad Bangkok experience.

Fascinating view of Bangkok. I travelled across and through this river as part of a canal tour of Bangkok. It was fascinating to see the houses / villages on the river. As part of this tour, I visited the Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) which was well worth a visit.

One of the best way to discover Bangkok. The Chao Praya river is a great and relaxing way to discover BKK, away from the city crazy traffic. Boats are cheap to go from one point to another. A lot of tours available from there. To add on your to-do list.

Always something to see. We didn't spend extra on special long boats or tours.. just taking the very cheap river buses was a perfect way to see everyday river life and the sights as you go along. Jumping on and off keeps you fit!

Cheap transportation plus entertainment. There are a lot of boat services along the Chao Phraya river, some for tourist trips that go into the adjoining klongs or small rivers to visit zoos, snake farms and temples and some that are only water bus transportation up and down the river. I highly recommend both. If you take the BTS to the river and transfer to a boat to go to Wat Po or the Grand Palace it is a much more enjoyable trip than a taxi. If you take a long tailed boat tour of the rive and it's tributaries you will see many sites plus you will understand why Bangkok was once called the Venice of the Orient.

The heart beat of the old city. The river is still a functioning commercial waterway and a trip up and down gives a fascinating insight into the lives of the local people, many of whom still live and work by the riverside

The top attraction in BKK. It's actually not an attraction, but a river. Not just a river, the central nerve system of a bustling city. Give it a go, and take the longtail boat tour through the Khlongs, and you know what I mean. This is Bangkok for real. And watch out for those alligators, I have just seen one last week!

One of the best things in BKK. A wild pulsating artery with ships, boats and ferries travelling up and down it non stop, the Chao Phraya river is overwhelming and fascinating. I recommend taking a longtail boat trip along the river around dusk and especially along the canals (khlongs in Thai), this is a real eye opener and lets one see an entirely different side of Bangkok, the water living Thais and some of the best sights one will see - and Im not just referrign to the kids jumping in the canals or the old ladies fishing for food or the monitor lizards swimming alongside you! Highly recommended

Educational and interesting. The river trip by long tail boat shows sides of Bangkok that are not readily seen from the road. Passing through the smaller canals you get to see both sides of life from new offices and lush houses to rundown riverside shacks built from old wood. But it also gives an insight into the way of life and the industrious nature of the Thai people. Stop off at the floating market for grilled giant prawns!

Life nerve through Bangkok. The river is crowded from morning to late night with vessels of all kinds. Hotel transfer boats, longtail boats, dinner and lunch cruises, express river boats, other route boats, small private boats etc. etc.A fantastic scenery to watch eg from one of the hotels situated along the riverside.
