Or a great way of transport from one place to another. Or to eat a meal while cruising up and down the river.Most beautiful at night time.
River Cruise. Had dinner on board the river cruise which was excellent. It was a lovely experience with a wide variety of food.

fun boat cruise. I had a really fun cruise on the river from one of the docks. It was cheap and i went to several places and got off and walked around. The river was very choppy because fo all the traffic on it. I like the view it gave into the everyday lives of the people who live along it in Bangkok. some of the houses arew shacks and some are mansions

A must do when in Bangkok. This is one of our favorite pass times in Bangkok...China Town is easily accessed from the river .Starting from the Taskin Bridge Pier we get a Hop on/off ferry pass to many destinations ending at pier 33.

Take a ride on the wild river. Take a regular boat (no flag or one of the flag boats, no need for the tourist boat) and enjoy the ride. There is so much to see from the boats and the river is very lively, it is not calm so if you enjoy a fun ride with many sites (including jumping fish in some areas I saw near the Palace), then you should take a ride on the Chao Phraya River.

Brilliant way to see both old & new Bangkok. Took private hire of boat for full tour of the central part of the river. Great photo opportunities, interesting buildings & other boats, also passing Royal Barge Museum.

River in Bangkok. Many ways to see t he river and all should be experienced. Take a long tail boat, you will probably get a little wet but they can take you into side canals, take the dinner cruise to see the Golden Buddha in a different light, and see the city at night, but the best view is from the bar at Sirocco 270 degree views of the city but make sure to get the hours it is opened and it will be crowded. This was the hotel in Hangover 2
Pleasant ride along Chao Phraya River. If possible, go in the morning and it will be good if the weather is good too. You feel relax during the ride and enjoyed the temples visit around this area.

A relaxing trip. You can skip the tourist boat and take the ferry -- The express boat takes about 45 minutes to Nonthaburi, fares are very low, 11-25 baht. There is a more convenient "tourist boat" which can be used to hop on and off. But if you just want a leisurely view of the Grand Palace, Wat Po and daily life on the river, the ferry is a very low cost alternative.

Great atmosphere on the river. I have stayed in Bangkok twice and the second time I wanted to be in a hotel that was on the river again. We stayed at the Ramada Plaza menam Riverside hotel and it was fantastic. The river is so busy and always has something going on. You can also use the many ferries to get aroiund to the tourist sights.

A great way to see this city. We decided to jump on the ferry and head into town for the day as we were staying at the Lebua at State Tower which was 500 meters from the river. It was an easy walk down to the pier and once we boarded the ferry there was much to see, the river bank is filled with interesting sights, temples and the river is filled with other boats, ferrys and barges. We took the ferry all the way down to the Grand Palace; which was a fantastic and it was definitely the best way to arrive.There is a few things you need to know about the river, taxi and tuk tuk drivers will attempt to convince you to take a long tail boat instead which is overly expensive and not as nice, and there really wasn't any signs in English when we went down to the pier to catch the ferry, you may have to ask for assistance from a staff member.Also we took the tourist ferry which is probably a little more expensive but its a more modern ferry, It cost around 60b ($2 AUD) but they had English speaking staff who directed when to get off for certain attractions.Overall its a great way to see the city from another view point, just don't get conned
The not so good in Bangkok. While the river cruise was fascinating, be prepared for the sight of serious pollution and poverty. Both are prevalent right there with the rich and famous.

A must everytime you visit Bangkok. This time we booked a trip at our hotel, pick up and transfer to River City, where we got on the boat. The trip took 2 hours and we saw a lot of things from the boat, the guide told us about everything we saw and a lot more about life in Bangkok. We got fruit and drinks, ver nicely served on the boat.

Free shuttle to Asiatic and one hour river cruise for 80 baht.. The Chao Phraya River is a lively area. Get on a free shuttle boat and go to the Asiatic (new night market). It's a fun little ride in the boat to the market, and this market is absolutely awesome! Great restaurants from chic to cheap - I've been to the Capri twice and thoroughly enjoyed it. Try the Mohito mocktail - divine (the one with ginger and lemongrass). There is a booth where you can buy a ticket for 80 baht for a one hour river cruise - do it!!! It was really enjoyable and I have put it on my list of things to take all my visitors to.

boat trip. We did a night boat trip on the river, including outdoor dining. THe food was excellent, and the service decent. The main reason for the three stars is that the tour guide talked incessantly in Thai (of course) over very loud speakers. I guess since there were not many foreigners on board a translation would not be worth it, but turn it down during dinner at least!
Interesting and cheap experience. A must do experience in Bangkok. Easy to use and cheap way of seeing the city. We liked the view and the fish we could see from the boat as we whistles along!

Not dirty at all. I had dinner at the Mandarin Orient, outside which serves a stunning buffet of the most delightful food. Open skies right on the river bank. Was very romantic, extremely fun to watch so much happening on the water with all the hotel water ferries coming and going

Cruising. Nothing better in Bangkok than cruising up and down on the public ferries, hopping off here and there to eat, check out footpath markets and see sights. It's cool, there's heaps to see, and it's very relaxing

A view from the river. Chao Phraya River is impressive not just because is the mayor water system in Bangkok, but because a navigation trip through out it can give you a very great view of the city. I do not recommend you to use "the public" boat system, always overcrowded. Hire instead a private boat at the same piers and enjoy a more comfortable trip.

Just get on the public water taxis and ride to the end. It is fun to ride the public water taxis on the river. Just get on and ride for under a US dollar. If the fare is super cheap then it probably just takes you across the river to the other side. Get off at a crowded dock and take the taxi back the way you came or just hire a taxi to take you back to your hotel or wherever. Your own private long tail boat will set you back about $85 for a 90 minute ride and it is not worth it. Many scammers will try to get you on one of these boats for a kickback. If you are offered a cheap tuk tuk ride to the river, don't take it. They will try to sell you the $85 ride on the long tail.
Where Bangkok starts to resemble Venice. Most romantic place in all of Bangkok, where the city starts to resemble Venice. Unfortunately there is no walkway to wander up and down the river.

The best and the cheapest water transport in the world. Its always very nice to travel by boat to Chao Phraya River. The river is really great way to see Bangkok. One can stop in many important place to visit and its very cheap. It can get very crowded, but its worth riding the boat or get a long tail boat if one want your own private tour. Just negotiate the price at Tha Chang pier (No.9)

A must!. Use the ferry boats to go fast through the city. Prices of regular services (not the tourist boats) are ridiculous cheap (15 Bath per person to cross the entire city!) and from the water side you understand Bangkok, how it is, was and will be.
Good way to travel. We crossed this river many times during our stay from Anantara Riverside to Central pier. We also went upriver to the old city and enjoyed the transport.

Bangkok bustling artery. It's amazing how crowded the Chao Phraya is - longboats, ferries, catfish...
Still on a nice day you can see many of the cities main sights from the river. A khlong tour is breezy and fun and can show you some of the less ostensible parts of the city. Great during the Loy Krathong festival.

Snake river.. A classic example of what more the city has to offer besides sex sleaze and shopping. Take an evening off to enjoy this lovel serpentine river that cuts across the city. Avoid the fancy loud dinner cruises and hop on to the Chao Phraya Express Boat (15 baht for a 45 min ride) and enjoy the ride local style. We took a BTS till Taskhin bridge and took the express boat from the pier right under the station. A 15 baht ride took us to Phra Athit pier (40 min ride), which is basically the entry to Khao San Road. The ride was fun and un touristy and gave us a glimpse of the uber posh bangkok with the 5 stars lining the river, to the real dilapidated dreary side of bangkok 30 min into the ride. Must do for true travelers.
Go for a cruise. for about 50 cents take the Chao Phraya River Express for as far as you want. Great entertainment and best views of some of the monuments.
Nice view but very dirty waters.... doing a tour on the chao phraya by ordinary mass transit boats is great and very cheap. you will see a lot. just the water is way to dirty...

Take the local ferry :). a) it is cheaperb) they are more frequent than the tourist (blue flag) ferryc) you never do as many trips as you think you will doNormal ferry is just 15 baht per trip, tourist ferry is 150 baht a day but they run every 30 mins or so, limiting your movement.The river is a fun way to spend a few hours. So much to see and smell and hear :)

The cities main artery. An inexpensive trip up the river shouldn't be missed. day passes/single trips are available which will allow you to stop at all the sights along the river. you can't come to bangkok and not take a trip on the river in some form!

Great way to see Bangkok and miss the traffic. We bought a day pass for the Chao Praya Express which allowed us to hop on and off all day and it was so nice and easy to get around to some of the key sights of Bangkok and not have to sit in road traffic.

good way in discover bangkok. tourists can take the chao phraya river cruise express boat which provides few stops at the tourist place (comes with a booklet and a day pass - unlimited ride). alternatively, you can choose to use the yellow, green or orange flag boat to go to any destinations alongside the river. the view from the saphan taksin bridge is great and beautiful.

go for a boat ride!. I took the longboat water taxi, and it was really a cool way to see the river and get a feel for Bangkok. super innexpensive, (I think it was like 15 baht) and it was much more interesting than a cab ride. I recommend it!

Cheap and cheerful. The Chao Phraya river is the artery that powers bangkok it's also a efficient and quite confusing form of mass transit. All of the stops on the river are marked with a number relating to their number of stops from the central pier. Whilst waiting you'll be approached by boats which look like river buses but are infact tour boats ignore them and look for the boats staffed by persons in bright orange shirts and communicate via shouting and whistling and more obviously bangkok residents onboard. Well worth trying and extremely cheap

Busy river. I was amazed to see the traffic on the river from early morning to late. The river is a good way to travel especially if you are going to the Great Palace. The passenger boats are crowded but so interesting.

Great way to sight see. Anytime you can get on local river transportation, it's a plus. I have loved doing this since Venice, Italy. Also as a transplanted Floridian overseas, it is great to be on the water. It's relaxing and you get to see so much and learn so much more of the culture. The river is full of traffic. . .large boats, small boats carrying fruits and vegetables, etc. The stops along the way afford you opportunities to get on and off to view the city. Cheap way to sight see. . .much better than a cab or tuk tuk driver, who may tend to overcharge you.
Dirtier then the Thames!. Very dirty river. Yes... nice scenes but do you really want to get this water into your face.... Think about it

Many choices. Cross the river for about half a dollar, or use it as transport...I came from BRT Thaksin station to my hotel for a buck, also visited the klongs, and they were all good. Mistake took river cruise with way to many ppl and was a total bore. While I didn't do dinner I knew it would be horrible.But this massive river is amazing and it's muddy waters splits two Bangkok's and is a must do.
River cruise a definite to do.. Liked the river cruise. I will definitely recommend it. A great family evening out. Also recommended for couples.

So much to see with very little fee!. Before you take a trip on the river - a word of warning - Tuk Tuk Drivers will tell you they will take you to the river for a small fee - you think "great!" then they try and push you into getting a long tail down the river - If this is the case - get out and get a cab - otherwise you are going to get absolutely SATURATED! Now, onto why you MUST have a trip down the river! Imagine this... sitting on a ferry, watching the world go by, when all of a sudden out of nowhere, this magnificent temple building just appears.... just as you've finished taking in the wonderful architecture of said temple, there's another one just appearing... The river has plenty of places to stop and sit and have a cup of tea and watch life pass you by, as well as plenty of tourist attractions (The Grand Palace, Temple of the Emerald Buddha) and a million other temples to see as well. A ride along this beautiful river shouldn't be missed. It's peaceful, beautiful and intriguing.

A good view. My travel agent told me that the Chao Phraya river cruise would be a romantic event. Unfortunately I realised that the river cruise was along with another 3500 other people and we ended up sharing our table with another family of four...'How Romantic' never the less the food was good and so was the sight of the city of Bangkok from the vessel...

Good. Took a longboat tour across the river. It was very interesting to see how the Thais live, it also gave us a better understanding of why Bangkok is known as the Venice of the east. We saw tons of little boats filled with fruits and veggies. We fed the fish outside a middle school. Fun trip.

Average Boat Trip. We decided to do a boat trip as it was my husbands birthday and we were looking at something to do, other than shop. We booked through our hotel and were picked up in a mini van, taken to the wharf area, had a sticker slapped on our chest, an orchid pinned on, a photo taken then told to go and wait and pier 1. Well we went outside to an absolute shermozzle. People and boats everywhere. Nobody seemed to know what to do, the announcements (the few that they were) were indecipherable so if you choose to do a boat trip, keep your ears open.Our boat finally arrived but to get to it we had to go through another of the boats tied up at the pier. If you are disabled either in a wheelchair or use a walking stick I'd forget it. There are no ramps to the wharf. Just stairs. The food on our boat was below average. They cater for the western tourist so if you like western buffets then you'll have a lovely feed. If you think you will get something Thai, forget it. The cruise itself was nice but a bit disconcerting to have the commentary provided by the male singer in the band, so mid sentence in his song he'd suddenly say "and on my right is the....." and then go straight back to his song again. If you have nothing better to do, then go for a cruise but I wouldn't rate it highly

A little too muddle. It's not a clear blue flowing river; its a little muddy and many of the cruise boats, commuter ferries and hotels/restaurants along the way seems to throw trash into the river. A cruise on the Chao Phraya princess will ensure you see all of the temples in Bangkok from a distance tho you probably will get a better view of the 5 star hotels than the temples!

enjoy the river while you're in BKK. i always stay near the chao phraya river when i'm in bangkok (either rent a condo or stay at one of the hotels) and love to just cruise around on the river boats-- hop on a hotel shuttle or one of the 3 baht local ferries and take in the beautiful city skyline...
Another river that tells the story of a civilization. Enormous, majestic. Completes bangkok in many ways. Rich in tradition and embanks several world heritage temples.

Chao Phraya River you shouldn't miss it. The price is right. There are many boats that go from docks all over this influential river at about 50 cents for a one way ticket. You can explore it any day of the week. During holiday season it can be overly crowded so be prepared.....

Boatrides on the Mighty Chap Phraya. Such an easyway to get around, either by tailboat of hotel shuttleor the bigger mass transport or boutique cruise boats, so much to see hear and do. A must for all who come to BKK

Have a boat trip..... For just 150 BATH you can buy a day's ticket and cruise the river for the day. You can get of and on as you please. Ideal if you want to avoid Tuk - Tuk or Taxi. The boats can be very busy as people are going to work on it, it's not only a tourist's thing, but absolutely recommendable.
waterway. absolutely wonderful waterway with great views of modern and rustic bangkok esp in the evening....beautiful views
Boat madness. Busy busy busyExcellent way to get around but mayhemLow prices good system make sure you check which boat is the right one and get on and off fast

U will have a great day/night. i dislike it water abit smelly!! some time get traffic boats on the river from other hotel bear by.. what i like it make more tourist come to visit and stay hotel near riverside

Frugal and amazing sightseeing. The first ticket stand you get to when you arrive at Taksin Pier is the one selling tourist boat trips -- you cant miss it.... but you should. Ignore the tourist ticket boats - these cost 150ThB per head. Instead, go behind the ticket booth and wait in the area where passengers are hanging around waiting to board the assortment of ferries that stop here. If you wait until one of the tourist boats (signified by a Blue Flag) has passed and the area has cleared you can stroll past the back of the ticket booth and find the public ferry map. The public ferries (there are a number of different ones - signified by the flag color - which stop at different places) are listed. If you know where you want to go just wait and hop on - typically a 20 - 30 minutes journey will be 15 ThB (pay on the boat). Ferry stops are numbered so its a simple task to decide when to get off. (recommended to arm yourself with a River guide beforehand - there are numerous on Google) The Orange flag boats run all day and leave every 20 minutes. They go upstream and downstream from Taksin for some distance and for a few ThB (for example, 20- 30 minutes to Tha Chan is 15ThB). You can chose to see BKK from the River - stay on the boat and see everything the river can offer or hop off near to your (tourist) destination. Definitely worth a trip - and try to do it both at night and in the day for great contrasts.

Exciting way to travel. We used the riverboats extensively during an eight day stay and it was always an experience, as sometimes they were so packed you could hardly move. The tourist boats were pretty good and less crowded as they cost a bit more but it was more of an experience to use the ordinary express boats. They whizzed up and down the river stopping at all the little ports and also ferried people back and forth across the river. A very inexpensive and quick way to get around in this city which has very congested road traffic and the boats also connected very conveniently at Sathorn pier to the skytrain.

Relax on the River. You can get the skytrain to Saphan Taksin and then go down to the pier and get the boat to various hotels along the river where you can have lunch or just generally chill out. There is also a boat to the new Asiatique night market and restaurant complex which is open from 5.30pm. It's right opposite the old Marriott Resort and Spa which is now owned by Anantara. This has a Beni Hana and Trader Vics restaurant. There are also tourist boats and express boats from the same pier which can take you to various places along the river for very little money.

Inexpensive ride, good views from the river. The water taxi ride is great, especially on a hot day (every day there!). You get some great views of the city and the temples from the water. You also see some very expensive real estate, and some very old building, poverty.

Not so clean. The river go throu the city and though is nice to go for a boat ride...we'll...it smelled quite bad. So we decided to just stroll by the river side and found a couple of nice restaurant there
Crossing the River. Love the river but the accomodation itself I think can be better. We used a boat to cross to Wat Arun and can be confusing experience if you didn't know where you wanna go

Great views of the BKK Skyline!. Awesome views of BKK, and the river ferry provides a very cheap form of public transport! Possible to get to and from Khaosan this way if you're heading there, just take the ferry from the Skytrain station Saphan Taksin. Dinner cruises abound here, they're a bit overpriced but worth it if that's your thing! Go during the daytime to see awesome views of Wat Arun without having to actually visit.

River cruise interesting but not the lunch/dinner cruise. It is very interesting to cruise the river and see the various sights. What was not so enjoyable was the lunch cruise and another cruise on the river for dinner - food was just tolerable

Busy Busy River breathes Life into Bangkok. I love the river and love using the ferry service, it's a shame it doesn't run late at night because it can be a real hassle getting back from some areas. Don't get sucked into using the tourist boat because the local ferry does the same for a fraction of the cost.

The best place to stay in Bangkok. There is no better place to stay than on the Chao Phraya River in BKK. Staying in a 5 star resort with its river shuttle adds a whole new dimension to a stay in Bangkok. We love going up and down the river to the BTS station.

Great experience. We arrived at the central pier, and was given clear instructions by the counter staff on which boat to get into as there are certain locations the boat doesnt stop. It was scenic and enjoyable as it was smooth journey unlike traffic jams or crowds

Busy. Used the Orange taxi boats on the river a couple of times. River very busy with traffic, commercial and water taxis plus pleasure cruisers. Lots of vegetation floating along the river. Quite a few slums mixed in with posh hotels and temples along the river bank.
Great experience. Different sort of feeling travelling on boat to shop , many small shops selling souvenirs on the sides of river. boat is clean and stable,well maintained and safe to ride on.
Good & cheap trip. The river itself is not clean, but it's a good ride & you get to get good photos of the vicinity. Take the non tourist as well to experience like local

A great way to see Bangkok. Caught the Phraya tourist boat up the river. There are three different boats, a cheap water taxi one, the tourist boat which has commentary (though very hard to understand at times) or a 'James Bond' style uniquely fashioned speed boat for a much higher cost. We chose a day pass on the tourist boat which cost us 150 baht each (around $5 dollars), and enabled us to ride the boat as far, and as much as we wanted. Great value for money !This is a great choice for taking pics from the boat of both the lovely, as not so lovely buildings on the river banks. Be wary of keeping your camera dry though when the James Bond boats whizz by a little too close.
CP River Tour. We took the ferry to go to Grand Palace. Overall a normal view - once is enough. Not much of a looker. But the ferry guide was lively and interesting.

Great river experience. If you're planning to explore all the areas where the boats stops at, I would suggest that you buy an "all in" ticket, which will be cheaper than the tickets bought on a "per pier" basis. The "all in" ticket will entitle you to a return trip will cost around 150 bahts.However, the ticket does not cover the trip across the river to Wat Arun, which ticket will cost you only 3 bahts.

take the ordinary transport its cheaper and better experience. rather than spending extra money on renting boat, better take this ordinary public transportation you can go and back to wat arun temple with less than 10 baht, as its around 3 bath only for 1 trip so round trip is 6 bath

Great way to get from BTS or MRT to Khao San Area. It can be a challenge to get around Bangkok from the Khao San road to other parts of Bangkok without taking a taxi or tuk tuk. Both of those options are pretty pricy compared to the 15-40B ferries that can take you anywhere up and down the river. Its a nice relaxing (but not super fast) way to get around. Heads Up: the ferries get pretty crowded with both tourists and school kids from the early afternoon through evening.

Get off the beaten track. We stayed at the Mandarin which is South of the Old Town on the River so we tended to use the river as our main form of transport during the day. The river is an amazing working river so you see all sorts of transport going up or down it. The Chao Phraya express is a great and cheap way to travel and you can get off and explore from many stations. We hired a long tail boat from our hotel pier for two hours and it took us around the canals to the west of the river where all the locals live. Its a real eye opener and if you are interested in photography like me, there are some great 'street scenes' to be shot. Also I thoroughly recommend Pak Khlong market which is near Raginee boat station. This is a working market for fruit, veg and flowers and really gives you an insight into Thai culture. There are not to many westerners there and despite appearances its very safe.

The Lifeline of Bangkok. The express river boat is a great way to visit sites along the river. Just make sure you are ready to hop off quickly when you get to your destination. Use the Nancy Chandler map of Bangkok to find out what there is to see..

Do two boat rides. We rented a long tail boat and four of us went out before sundown. Great choice because we mostly did the side inlets and canals viewing a whole slice of middle and upper and working echelon Fascinating peaceful and fun to go through one set f locks. Returning you Di catch the glow of the Wat Arun and glitz of the BKK skyline. You move along smoothly and quietly privately. We packed some snax and libation and had a mini picnic cocktail party. Boat rental was 2000 baht for 4 of us or $65Next day we bought the Chaya praya tourist express boat pass and used it. A different area to explore if you ride it the who,e run.

The heart of Bangkok. The activity on this river is amazing. Bring your camera. From hawkers to children bathing and huge cargo boats. Take a tour down the small branches off this river to see some of the local life.

Main transport. Chao Phraya is one of the main rivers for locals and tourists to travel to work or going to another side of city to work. There are 20 piers if not mistaken and ferry boat service available. It only cost you 14 Bahts to travel for entire single journey. If you are looking for a budget travel, this ferry service can be your choices, just be aware of crowded and hot sun under the clear blue sky.

Best river cruise by river taxi. If you want the best of the river cruise view in cheapest cost, take the river taxi for one end to another. Start 6pm so you can see the buildings, bridges and Grand Palace and Wat Arun lit up at night. Great trip at 15 Bhat only as public river taxi fare very cheap.

Long tailboat "cruise". My family did not want to do a long 3 hour trip to the main floating village. We then decided to hire a long tailed boat and go through the very many canals and see how many locals live. We also stopped at a floating market and had a walk around . The floating market wasnt very big but you could certainly get a delicious meal. It seems that there is no shortage of fish. You can buy bread and feed it to the fish. The fish appear starving and really fight with each other to get the bread.  We took the boat at Taksin Pier for 2 hours. It cost bht 2400. It was also the first time I have seen first hand how locks work in the canals.

Nice but a bit dirty!. The river of course gives the city a nice atmosphere. I would recommend to take a boat ride for seeing the klongs (river arms) of the Chao Phraya river. We saw very different houses, huge lizzards and lots of fish on the way with amazing views of the Wats and colorful houses on the river front.
Great View. I love the Thai restaurants beside the river as they have great views of the Wat's. These Thai restaurants has more thai taste than fusion.

"Terribly Disappointing!". The river waters were choppy and we got turn-off by the stinky smell! The sights were not impressive as you see a lot of run-down and dilapidated houses along the way. The boatman was very annoying as he kept on asking for tips which we refuse to give. The very few river boats selling wares, drinks and snacks were ripped-offs. We did not stop at the various temples/farms along the way for fear the boatman might 'drift-away' as I was traveling with my family and had already paid up front, at a high price!

Great way to see the city and avoid the traffic. Taking a regular river taxi/bus is a great way to see the Bangkok sky line. It doesn't cost much more than a dollar to see everything you want to if you take the regular service. Don't pay over the odds and get fleeced for $20 to take a special tourist boat, you don't see any more

river cruise, bangkok....best way to see most important places. Buses are congested, and cars are difficult in busy roads, some of them very expensive. Here is the best way to see bangkok. Go to sothorn ( saphan taskin) BTS station.and walk a few yards. You will see central pier .(N13) boat starting point. Buy one day river pass for 150 bahts which gives you unlimited boat travel 9.30 am to 7 pm. You will be given a booklet containing wealth of information.You can get down in any pier you like, spend as much time you want and catch the next boat for next destination. The boats are very comfortable and staff are reasonably friendly.Here are the places the boat stops with tourist attractions.N1. Oriental pier......mandarin/peninsular/shangrila hotelN3. Si phraya pier........Holy rosary church, siam commercial bank, river city, wat traimit N5 Rachwongse pier.....wat mangkok, china town, indian market, sampheng marketN8 Than tien pier...wat pho, wat arun (must see), flower market, tha tien market, siam museumN* Mahraja pier.......Grand palace, wat phra kaeo, national museum, pillar shrine,amulet mktN10 Wang lang pier....Royal Barge museum, supatra river house, wat rakhang N13....Pra athit pier.....phra sumane fort, banglumpo market, national theatre, exhibition hallNote: Start early......walk as much as you can...carry some food/drink......finish tour by 7pm....one of the best way to relax and see.

All the hustle and bustle of Bangkok. This time in Bangkok we hired a long tail boat to cruise the river for a couple of hours. Because we have done it before we knew to negotiate up front. No snake farm, no shopping, just cruising the river. We cruised until dusk and had the boat drop us at our restaurant on the river's edge. It was beautiful
Wonderful river!. Wonderful river! A kind of beach across crowded Bangkok. Hotels on the shore are the best in town. Try also a ride in boat. Beautiful skyline. A must see on Thailand's capital.

Take a Long Tail boat trip. So called because of the long rudders attached to the motors, this was a great way to get from the end of the Skytrain track to the Grand Palace. Health and safety does not seem to have a very high profile here but the trip up river was fun and fat and cheap. An experience you need to have when you visit Bangkok!
RIVER CRUISE. This was a good way to see BKK from the river, we bought a hop on hop off ticket. Was also a nice way to stay cool.

cheap transportation. The locals take the river for all kinds of transportation around the city.The fare is only a few cents, but you must be in good shape to get on. The boats only stop for a few seconds and then they pull away. This is not for the handicapped or people with slow reactions. Try it you only live once.

Do your own thing. Done this a couple of times before. Best to rent a longboat at the main pier for 2 hours and just ask the guy to take you around the backwaters of Thonburi. You can do a deal and avoid a boat with lots of other people. Floating market trips and sites are an expensive add on. You can get the guy to stop down river at the Palace if you want and drop you off at the end.

A busy and fascinating river passing through the heart of the city. A not to miss area however you travel on it, you must travel on it! Firstly, the tourist boat which leaves the Skytrain river terminus every 30 minutes for much of the day. It only goes as far as Pier 13 which is the stop off for the backpacking area known as Khaosan Road. They will try to sell you a Day Ticket for 150 Baht when the individual trip on this boat is 20 Baht and the Express Boat is only 15 Baht for as far as you want! It's your choice but you may not use 150 Baht worth of 20 Baht trips. You should watch your change if you don't tender the exact fare.It is worth going to the end of the Express Boat journey. It's just 15 Baht and takes an hour. There is a market at the terminus which has a lot of fruit and other stalls. as far as the River review is concerned, it is difficult to know what to leave out but many features can be explored on Trip Advisor under their own category, such as the Grand Palace and Wat Arun.

The best experience in Bangkok... Very nice experience..breezy air, good Indian food, good music and overall ship was really awesome.The only point of objection is that they segregated the Indian and western crowd.

This is a Must. Take the water taxi's, you can jump on, jump off all day and go to all the various amazing sites, esp the Grand Palace, there is even a bit up at the front of the boats where you can stand and watch the fish jumping in the river, you must do this trip while in Bangkok.
Nice. Always nice to get away from the streets of Bangkok, take the public boat and see the city from the river side .
One way to get to the Grand palace. Taake the Sky-train to Taksin station. Walk down the stairs towards the river and buy a ticket for the ferry boat to the Grand Palace for 40 baht.
Great. It was great to make a journey by boat in the river of Chao Praya. We fed the sacred fishes that amazed us, because they were so big.

Dinner cruise on a Rice Barge. The highlight of our trip for sure. We took our group of 40 on a dinner cruise up and down the Chao Phraya River at night...lovely views, okay food, excellent service and camera-worthy photos all night long. Highly recommended. Book either thru the Marriott or directly with the boat companies.

Snake boats galore. Yes, I know, they call them long boats. But I could not get enough of those long, super fast boats that look like snakes. To me at least. They have powerful car or truck engines and with the looooonnnng shafts installed they have the ultimate surface drives. And they are fast. What a delight.Should you wish to go up river, there are Tourist boats (that’s their brand name) that allow hop on-hop off privileges for 150 Baht (about US $5) but the best deal are the water taxis that sail up and down the river for 15 Baht (US $0.50). These are crowded most of the time and there is no tourist guide explaining the sights such as “on your left is the 5-star Peninsula hotel” etc. ☺At the Saphan Taksin (Taksin Bridge) stop you can hop on the Skytrain and go places in either direction. BTW there is an escalator on the left side of the station that saves several dozen steps of going up. After you get off the boat turn left, cross the small bridge and turn right (there is no other place to go) and follow the short alley. The escalator will be right there. No, there is no down escalator. Did you think you were in Hong Kong?

please go for dinner here on dinner cruise. nothing to dislike about the chao Phraya river you need to go on a dinner cruise boat it costs around 900 bhat per person for 2 and a half hours evening cruise including dinner first drink and pudding and entertainment it is fabulous you get much more and all for about £18-00

Must see attraction. You really haven't been to Bangkok if you've not taken a boat tour or at least sat at one of the many restaurants along the river. You can take the BTS to Taksin BTS station or any taxi can bring you there.

Good view of Bangkok old and modern. Rode the river cruise down Chao Phraya River and had a view of the old and modern Bangkok. Visited Wan Arun Temple along the way to pray. Subsequent journey saw the floating market (small one), passed by the royal boats dock area and got to feed fishes at one point. Feeding the fishes are said to bring prosperity to people. My kids all enjoyed the trip.
Great River View. I love the river cruise. It's so serene and calming. There are temples along the river.Beautiful buildings and even some boat selling souvenirs

photo shoot outing. we all went to phot shoot outing near Chao Phraya River because it has so many things to see. River cruise, eating along the river, taking photos, having a stroll, so many things you can do.it is a must if you are ever in Bangkok.

Interesting. If you no what your doing, you can take an ordinary boat from Thaksin Bridge to Nonthaburi terminus. Take a walk around the maket there and get something to eat, Thai style . It's about a one hour trip up and then go back again for less than $2. For the less adventurous take the Tourist boat, you can jump on and off as many times as you please for $3, this boat only goes half of distance that the ordinary one goes and not as much fun.Try to avoid the long tail boats. They are rip offs.
river. nasy river but a must do if you like being out on a boat or boats,all kinds of styles and speeds to choose from and no speed limits,small longboats with big v8s,very cool.
beautiful. great taking a boat ride and enjoying the city views on the way. There are floating bars in the rivers with excellent food.
Get around with a boat. Stay by the river! That will keep you away from a lot of traffic jams. And you will have a great view of most of the temples.

Busy River. We loved our long boat ride down the river and through the canals which have earned Bangkok the title of Venice of Asia...really beautiful trip...take a local tour guide to get the most from your experience. Everything from beautiful homes, to simple ones and monitor lizards swimming across the river.

good... looking through Bangkok at a different perspective by taking the Chao Phraya River cruise..we took the public transportation - the Chao Phraya River Express Boat..specifically we took the orange flag boat. its a very cheap way river cruising albeit the overcrowded passengers. Temples, business establishments, bridges etc. line along the river. its easy to hop on & hop off whatever sights you want to see along the way.

good night views. We went on a night river dinner cruise and it was good to see the shores from the river with the palace and temples lit up.would like to go back and visit during the day and explore some more as time just got away.

Klong trip. I adore this trip...hiring a long tailed boat for a couple of hours means you get to see so much of Thailands riverside life. The boatman takes you through the narrow klongs, past palaces, temples, local homes, children swimming in the river, all sorts. It is different from anything else in Bangkok. Certainly not luxurious, but fun and unique. You can hire the boats in several places, but I usually get one from near the Oriental Hotel. One hour would do if you are pushed for time, but I prefer a little longer to really get to savour this experience.

Public transport .. We used the local ferry system and found it very efficient and fast. Possibly a bit overcrowded, which could be a safety issue. The river is quite dirty and polluted. But the Thai's use as a major transport system.
It's good.. It's good, but I prefer the rivers outside of Bangkok better. More "postcard". However, if you are short for time, do visit.

pleasant cruise to do. For 150 BHT buy a ticket for the Chao Phraya cruise boats, to be used in teh day between 9 to 4pm: Please note the last boats are until 5/5.45pm not 4pm as it's written on the ticket !Great way to go to the Grand Palace, Wat Po, stop at hotels or guest house and restos with a terrase offering a great view on the sunset around 5pm.Or just jump in a speedboat and stay for the complete tour (2hours!! we did it by mistake but it was great actually)
Best place in the world. I live in a condo 32 floors above the Chao Phraya at Klongsan. Best views in the world. Boats, barges, lights, sounds. No place I would rather be....

Fabulous. A wonderful experience, and a great way to move around and to see Bangkok from the river. However, don't buy the 150baht all-day pass. A single journey, no matter how many stops, costs 15baht, and you'll never do 10 journeys in a day!

A Lovely Serene Experience. The cruise over the Chhao Pharaya river is a delightfully serene experience with a gentle lull of the river along with all the other beautifully decorated cruises. The major buildings and landmarks of the Bangkok city floating before your eyes give a great experience.
Like any other river. Its like any other river...if you want to do a cruise, sure youc an go there...but i guess if you are with family, then ther are better things to do

Love this. I could sit and watch the river all day.Just great to hop on and off the public boats, the best way to travel between sites, avoids those hot streets and the touts trying to sell you things, but make sure you don't get drawn onto the trips, the public boats get you there, only 15 baht per journey, and there's probably a day / multi journey ticket. Highly recommended especially if your hotel is near the river.
Take a ferry to the temples. The river feels like Venice, although more polluted. Worth a quick ferry ride to experience how Thai people used to travel around the city via waterways.
Too much pollution. I would have enjoyed the river cruise but the pollution was extremely bad. We went out late in the afternoon so it may be much better earlier in the morning.

Only a Night Time "Attraction". Fireworks for Loy Krathong was launched from barges on this river as well as the candles on biodegradable lantern floats. Some may be a little turned off by the garbage on the river but this is pretty much as good as it gets. You walk the streets of Bangkok and you can simply smell the fact that their wastewater and stormwater drainage system needs major improvement. You also cross this river from the BTS to get to Asiatique, which is another nice attraction in the evening with a lot of shops and the LadyBoy show Calypso.

Nice. We stayed at Lebua at State Tower and had a beautiful view of the river. Use the city boat to navigate the river, it is the cheapest. Also, avoid the dinner cruises...they are overpriced, the food is not good, and you can see if all from the city boats (with the orange flags) The city boats are 15 baht per person but there are also tourist boats for 40 baht person, so ask before you get on.

A Cheap Respite from the Chaos. Take the more comfortable Tourist Boat from the Saphan Taksin Pier (accessible right off the Silom line BTS) if you are unfamiliar with the river taxi system. Cost is reasonable and will take you to some of the primary temple sites. Otherwise select the public water craft and experience commuting Chao Phraya style. Ride it all the way to Nonthaburi get off and stop for a snack at any of the little bakeries or food vendors along the main street past the clock tower. Then jump back on for a scenic return trip. Round trip for less than a buck...one of the best bargains anywhere. Just avoid the rush hours for obvious reasons. Respect the fact that this is a system that locals use to get places and not set up to transport tourists. These boats can become very crowded. Observe the proper protocol when Monks are aboard. Thai people are estremely accommodating and welcoming...it would be a shame to ruin their sense of hospitality and generosity by abusing this public transit system.
Very dirty river... Once my company was located just next to the river, and smell bad..I recommend you to go there in night time. Then you do not need to see the color..
Nice and beautiful river. If you come to Bangkok, you have to visit Chao Phraya River, beautiful and exciting river. You can use boat to see many nice place and building surrounding

Life-line of Bangkok. We stayed in a hotel over-looking Chao Phraya river or in other way didn't stay in Siam area just bcoz of this river.Being from a country having dirty rivers, it was simply amazing to have a view of such a amazing river from my 26th floor hotel balcony. Enjoyed river-cruise and couldn't take tourist's river-cruise.Though just like any other developing city, Bangkok throw their garbage into this river bcoz of that It's not very clean...still best from few rest...

My highlight.. Please ride the boat down the river. Very Thai experience.. You get to feed the fish and shop on the river because the locals meet your boat on their little boats and sell you cool stuff. You also see how the Thai's live..

part of Bangkok history. when coming to bangkok you must see the chao phraya river as well and if 1st time than take a ride with the water taxi (it's fast and interesting) but dirty and in some area it really smells bad.

Brilliant way to get to the Royal Palace. We were staying in Silom, so we took the Skytrain to Taksin Bridge and walked down the steps and along to Central Pier. Here we took an Orange flag boat, paid the conductor 15B when she came around (flat fare, however far you go). For the Grand Palace, get off at the pier called Tha Chang. Great way to see the river !

River bus. Excellent way to get from a place to place along the river and to see the city from a different perspective.. The breeze cools you nicely on a hot day.. The boats with an orange flag are those ones which the locals use and the trip costs only 15 bahts which is way cheaper, and way more fun, than the touristy boats..

Dinner Cruise on River. I took the dinner cruise on river. The price we paid was about 1500 THB which seems to be a bit high as one welcome drink is included. In case you want to buy beer or any other drink, it is charged extra.We waited for about 20 minutes for boat to arrive and then we boarded the boat which was lit up completely. A buffet was laid out. As soon as the cruise started, there was a big rush to the buffet tables. We decided to wait out the rush. After some time, we also got our food. The variety of the food offered was reasonable not great!!View along the river is something worth mention as you see several Bangkok landmark and the boat cruises along the river.A live band played music and some of the crew was also dancing however, I felt that the music was too loud for a dinner. We were a group of friends and we had some good fun together.Overall, I would say the river cruise is worth doing at least once.

Fascinating. Our room at the Shangri-La overlooked the river and I could have spent hours just watching as it was continually busy with ferry boats, hotel shuttles and, in particular, the long-tail boats. We used the all day hop-on/off ticket for the tour guide boat which can also be used on any of the other regular ferries. Incredibly cheap way to get around the parts of the city near to the water. The catfish also have to be seen to be believed and can be fed with bits of bread, just like the ducks at home.

Busy river, selection of boats on offer to move you around. The Chao Phraya is the heart of Bangkok which offers not only a great way to travel about the city but provides great views of both the old & new.

JUST DO IT!. See Bangkok old and new from your boat. Water way transportation was a fun, fabulous way to move about, see the mixture of architectures and community living styles. No need to buy the one day pass it is only 30 or so baht each time you get on.

take a cruise.. We took a dinner river cruise, the food wash't the best but the experience is a must. We also took a fishing boat trip of the river. The river is dirty but the floating market is an amazing place to see the local culture and economy.

Good way to see how the water people live.. Done this tour several times over the years and still enjoy it. Love going up and down the canals off the Chao Phraya. Amazing how these people live. Be careful not to ingest anyof the river water from the boat's wake or you may be ill for a few days.

Romantic!. When we first visited Bangkok (me and my husband), his boss recommended that we should try the river cruise preferably at night.And his definitely right! The aura and the ambiance so romantic plus the food is great! I would recommend this!

Lovely river. The river itself is very pretty with all sorts of different boats floating up and down. We took the river taxi which is very good value for money. You not only get from A to B but can also float past the Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) and the Grand Palace getting a completely different view of them. Lovely way to travel!
How about finally taking care of the environement. This poor river has been used as a trash and sewage dumping ground for too many years now. Its time to clean up and take care of your future

Different. A great experience and different way of getting around town ,the taxi ferries are lunatic drivers ,but i suppose they do it every day ...make sure you hang on and dont fall in and never take a mouthful if you want to survive lol
Should visit twice... All travelers must visit twice. Once in the night and another in the day time. Other than cruise you should also enjoy the boat rides.

Unforgettable day. We were in a "Dinner Cruise" one night and were lucky to have dinner there, it was excellent. I believer that the guests should be able to enjoy the surroundings. But due to the western music guests who like to enjoy the scenery could not enjoy it fullest level.

Stay afloat. A great ride on any boat. Take the public boat as far as it will go north. Picture taking paradise and get off anywhere you please. Cheap ride for over an hour to the end in Nothanburi. Every time is a new adventure.
fun way to get around town. take some time to figure out the chao phraya express boat route up and down the river. it is a unique and great way to get to the sites and explore the city.

Remarkable experience. A boat trip on the Chao Phraya river is a must while in Bangkok. Would recommend to eater charter your own long tail boat, if you like the speed, or take the river bus (orange line) if you want to experience the rive the way the locals do if. A great way to get to the Grand Palace, Wat Pho and Wat Arun.

Dinner by the bridge was great. There are restaurants with view of the bridge. Food was nice and afterwards u can buy white bread n feed the fish in the river, i mean lots and lots and lots of fish.The view of the bridge is very nice at night although I wouldn't compare it anywhere near Sydney Harbour Bridge or Tower Bridge London. But it is a great one to see in Bangkok and south east asia.
Riverboats !. It's easy to take boats at the piers for visiting the temples and the palaces.No traffic Jam Cheap transportations every 10 minutes.

a very impressive connection. you can go by BTS to sapan thaksim bridge, there you can buy a days ticket and the shuttle boats can bring you every 15 minutes to any place, like wats, china town , markets and so on

Feel Bangok from Chao Phraya. My first impression of the River from the Central Pier off Satom Taksin BTS sky train was not great. But as we travelled down the River to visit Wat Arun on a yellow flag Chao Phrya express boat service , the variety of riverside views from posh hotels to Shanties to city landmarks such as the Oriuental Hotel all give you a pulse of the city. Standing on Taksin bridge gives you a great view. You can reach there by climbing up the stairs from Central Pier. The long tailed tourist boats zooming bye, the slower passenger ferrys and the river side view - all give you feel with a good after taste.

great river to cross. be careful when you get on the ship... it is so crowded. Watch out of pick pocket here... but you will got many thing to be told to all people after you have experience from this place... hmmm... all is about water and the crowded people who want to get-on in this tools of Thailand 's Transpportation.
Very nice at night only. This river is very dirty but beautiful at night whatever you do, do not take the ride on the canal just do the river

nice ride for litlle money!. go to the main ferry station after walking around the riverside or financial district on sunset and enjoy the lights lighting up in big hotels and restaurants. The ride up the river is just 15 THB!
River Taxi. Take the River Taxi only 15B one way, see the real bussle of everyday Chao Phraya River.Just be careful when getting on and off the ferry unless you want a guick swim.

The life vein of Bangkok. The river provides tourists with an adventurous ride to see the Grand Palace and Wat Arun, possibly , interact with the locals who also take the ferry boats to their daily grind. The views along the river varies from extravagant, commercial , old and decrepit to a view of Thailand's culture through the magnificent spires of the Grand Palace and the small temples that you can see along the way and the silent wonder that is Wat Arun. Taking a ride on the River of King is now a must do for me when in Bangkok, but I won't take the express boat again to The Chang pier.

Don't miss travelling on the river. Fun way to travel in Bangkok -- used by locals and visitors alike, there's nothing like the sound of the coin collector with her cylinder a-jingling and Thai pop music blaring from the captain's speakers. Easy to navigate and very entertaining. You don't even need a destination to enjoy the ride.

River transport fun..... My interest was seeing everyday Thai folks hopping on and off water taxis and the views of the city from the river. Crowded? Yes. Polluted? Yes. But worth a visit if you want to see the non-glitter of Bangkok. On our visit I was amazed at the fact I could not stay outside in the smog for more than a couple of hours. But Thai people are very friendly so the cultural exploration is worth the exposure to smog.....

Orange boat line. You pay 15 bath and can travel what ever way on the river with the boat with the orange flag in front. Great way to see places and cheap. You get a cool breeze too. If you want private tour in longtail it will make a damage for 800-1000 bath.

A bit disappointed. I was hoping there would be a nice boardwalk and a plethora of bars and rextaurants along the river bank. Unfortunately this wasn't the case. The river is quite polluted and is only used as means of transportation. We took the ferry a couple times, while it was a u ique experience we weren't too impressed.

one way to avoid the traffic. I took the ferry from china town area to get to Wat Pho, then back to central pier. They were enjoyable boat rides. Unfortunately, the weather was bad that day but you would get to see some interesting views of the city skyline on a clear day. It's a working river and there are a lot of boats and long tails travelling up and down, so a fascinating view.

Book boat from a legit hotel!. To say that Bangkok is a city of scams is an understatement. Only book any tour that you want to take through a legit hotel. Many five star hotels in Bangkok don't cost more than $100.00 a night and include a fabulous breakfast that can prevent a person from being hungry until evening so well worth the money.
vow the best river trip. visit at 7 pm & book a chao phraya river cruise,enjoy,excellent service for 1 hour in the cruise. watch the best view of the river on the terrace of the cruise

Lots to see,for a little money. You can get on the express boat,for 15 Baht,and ride to Nonthaburi,the end of the line,get off,go to the market there,feed the fish,then take the boat back to wherever you want to get off. It's breezy and a good way to relax from the heat.
Long tail boat hire to canals. best bit of our second vsit to Bangkok, hired long tail boat and did tour of canals on the other side of the river, absolutely brilliant experience, highly recommended

A busy river. Using the river transport, and go for the cheap ones, was a good way to get around. From our Hotel balcony we spent a lot of time just watching the river. Huge barges and little buzzy boats.

River Cruise. Nice experience. But still you have to negotiate the price. You can go to any jetty by TukTuk (which cost you 20Baht per trip). The cruise is about 1 hour or 1 hour 30 minutes. You should try this ;)

Another option to avoid traffic jam. Taking khlong or boat are good choice if you wish to go somewhere fast. ( Besides skytrain ). It's not hard to reach and it's cheap. You just have to know which pier you should wait for the boat/khlong and where you have to alight at. Ask the hotel guy you are staying about how to get to the nearest pier. And be aware of the touts or whatever they are called near the pier because when I was in Tha Tien pier, my friends and I were heading to Wat Arun. One of their guy told me that the boat fare is 200 bahts/pax. As I know it is much less than that. So when I declined their offer, they told me we can't enter to the pontoon. But you better ignore them. Just go straight inside and head to the correct pontoon. There will be an old lady sitting at the counter where you should pay the fare. And fyi, crossing over to Wat Arun only cost 3 bahts per pax per trip.You should try this transportation when you are in Bangkok. It is a good and interesting experience. Remember to look out for your friends. Don't leave any of them behind when you get on board. It is very crowded. Make sure all of you are together when the boat arrives.Have fun folks!
The River. Got a launch trip on the way back from Ayuthaya. Got a broad perspective of Bangkok - the traditional and modern, peacefully coexisting. Comfortable boat and excellent lunch!

Great scenic introduction to the "Temple district". Perfect way to beat the crowded streets and slow traffic jams. Bonus is the scenic view of all the temples and spires along the river. Jump off at the middle stop and you can walk up and down the river to a number of ancient and interesting spots. Ignore the scam artists who tell you the "temples are closed" with offers to take you to the open and better spots. It's a taxi scam.

What a well used resource!. The express boats are fast and very cheap. It's fun and gets you to places the sky train does reach. They stop early in the evening as the river gets pretty busy at night with the big barges.

Take a ride. Everytime I get to Bangkok I try to take a ride on a river boat whether it's a private speedboat, a public shuttle, an express boat or a tourist boat. Each of these has its own charm, a special tourist trip at weekends takes you a much longer way upriver, stopping at some temples and finally at the island of Koh Kreet. Private boats go through some of the older canals in Thonburi at quite high rates, but you won't see any floating markets here. If you want to see Bangkok from a canal I suggest the Klong Saen Sep Canal which provides public boats at minimal prices. Another option is the free hotek boat from Sampan Taksin to Antara resort or viceversa, very romatic at nighttime.

Easy , cheap, and full of wonderful sights!. Hop on any colour boat from station S6 (take from Siam station) and sit back, relax to simply take in the beautiful riverside scenery. Tickets are cheap...like 20 Bht per way.

Take a ride on the river, you won't regret it.. Whatever opportunity you have to ride on the river, take it. While this is a big river, it is also like the heart of Bangkok, plenty of boats coming and going, wonderful views, and it still actually has plants growing in it! My only regret was that I could not book a dinner cruise as they are so popular they were all booked up!

busy waterway with fast, cheap, exciting ferries. This river is so alive! Boats are zooming across, barges are chugging up and down, ferries are everywhere. For 15 baht, take a ride and enjoy the spectacle while experiencing a fresh breeze.

Horribly polluted, ferries feel unsafe. The river water stinks, the buildings alongside are dilapidated, and the fume belching boats do not seem water worthy. But I suppose it's all part of the experience.
Night visit. Make sure you visit the river at night, the lights are lovely. Be prepared for the smell though. It is like a massive open drain but not so bad if there is a breeze blowing

At least do it once.... A cruise on the river is necessary at least once to understand how the river is importan to the Thai capital city.
Interesting way to discover or rediscover the main monuments and sightseeings near by. Dislike: river smelly and very dirty
longtail boat cruise. this was so much fun. I really enjoyed the boat ride and its a good way to see bangkok. You can get around the city nicely on the river with out sitting in traffic.

River Trip on the Chao Phraya. We had a very interesting trip up the river on a fast boat around the canals and past temples and monasteries and then back to Bangkok on a rice barge leaving from the River City shopping complex

It's a must. You're getting into the real Bangkok experience. The people (besides the ones that are trying to make money from tourists), the smells (not so good sometimes), the sites (beautiful)... But it's a must! The long tail boat can be a bit pricey but it's an adventure, they're taking you in the little canals and you see the real way of living on the river and the Thai houses. If you don't want to spend too much and it's mostly for getting around sites, you have the much cheaper choice cost 5-10 bht and it's the "taxi boat" and you can get on and off at the stations and sites. DON'T go with people that grab you on the street the minute you arrive near the canal and offer you a boat ride, they are scams and charge you way too much and take advantage of tourists, also sometimes they stop at their "friend's watch shop" and such even without asking you first, you're just entering a trap. Go to the tickets office or book long tail boat from your hotel.We also took an early dinner cruise which was lovely, we went before the sunset, the view was amazing and the food was unique and good. Very touristy thing to do but it's a great experience and we had a great evening.

Interesting river of commerce and trade. It's a marvel how the Thais have put to good use this busy river. A lot of the produce that come into Bangkok come from the different provinces of Thailand and are unloaded in the city port via this river. In the early morning, if you take a boat to the floating market, you can buy fresh flowers, vegetables, crafts and the boat people who sell their wares skillfully sell their goods on the boat to tourists who are on another boat just experiencing this type of trade on the river.

Great River in a Great City. First I must admit that I love water so I enjoy travelling on the Chao Pharya River by express boat, long tailed boat or tour boat. Most tourists visit it in one way or another. It is pleasant and interesting to hire a long tailed boat to tour the side canals (klongs in Thai) as it offers views of a lifestyle not available to most tourists. While on the side klongs, be sure to visit the Thai Royal Barge Museum where you get take close-up photos of HM the Kings main royal barges. Truely magnificent workmanship in these craft. Tours (day and overnight) are available to Ayutthaya. And don't forget that many Thais use the express boats as roughly north-south transportation into and out of downtown Bangkok.

Sit and watch the world go by. Although I was only on the river as part of the hotel shuttle, I always saw something new and exciting when I was boating up and down. Watch for the giant catsish that can be seen from the pier of the Ramada Plaza Menam Riverside Hotel or in front of any temple that is located on the river.
Overpriced tourist spot.. It's basically a shopping trip on water, not advisable to buy anything there unless u are a good bargainer

Haven't REALLY been to BKK until you tour the Chao Phraya. This is truly a must see in BKK. It's crazy, it's stinky but it's just fantastic to explore the Chao Phraya river and its amazing canals. The river and canals are host to many Thai homes, both extremely poor and fancier ones. Enjoy its merchants, its traffic, stop by the Temple of Dawn, take IN Bangkok.
best way to enjoy bangkok. best way to enjoy bangkok if you have one or two days is take a river bus. it's not so hot and you can easily reach most of the best sites from the boat stops.
Night views excellent. Best to have an early dinner cruise to watch the sunset and night views. Prefered the show in Phuket as the Calypso show was not as impressive.
Worth A Boat Ride On THis Majestic River. Took a boat ride with fast boat on the river. Enjoy stop at snake farm and at some temples along the river route. Can bve a pleasant adventure.

rent a long tail boat for a river and canal cruise. Can't see the real Bangkok without getting on the water. We spent 3 hours on a long tail boat. Bring your camera and water as there are LOTS of photo ops, particularly in the canal area, and it is REALLY hot if you get stuck waiting in a lock!
I had been there get boat. I had nice diner time with boat about 2hours then nice music and good night view

All means of transport. You can go by the river with a rented long tail boat, but just as easy do as the Thai and go with the express boat. Hardly costs anything and you can get out at many places. Just be prepared as the boat only stops for a moment and at rush hour at can get crowded.

So lively and refreshing!. Chao Phraya river is a breath of refreshing air in an average steaming hot day in Bangkok. It is a great way to start/finish your Wat/historic Bangkok tour. Chao Phraya boat transport is cheap, regular and it is so convenient and fun. It meanders through the hart of the ancient part of Bangkok and gives you unique sightseeing opportunities to some famous and lots of hidden landmarks or spots. A must do....

Busy river by day but magical by night. We stayed in a hotel that overlooked this busy river, and watched every kind of boat speeding or tugging slowly up and down this river by day. We decided to take a night river cruise (with dinner) and saw a whole other side to it, all the sights (the Wat's. the Palace and bridges are lit up) and even the other boats are a sight to see.... well worth it
Rent a boat, see the city.. You can rent a boat and travel through the canal around the city, no traffic excellent value. Be sure to feed the catfish.

Poluted but interesting. The river is extremely poluted which is a shame but if you can get past that there are loads of interesting things to see when taking a trip down the river
Take a tour river cruise or just head down to Saphan Taksin BTS and get a private boat to take you on a cruise

wonderful two hours. this was on my last day in Bangkok and I had a late evening flight so it was a good idea to spend the afternoon in this excursion. you get on a nice boat in the river that takes you through the chao phraya river running through Bangkok, on your way you'll see many temples and gardens, then you go to some canals of the locals just like the floating market and they come trying to sell some souvenirs. After about one hour you change the boat to the bigger one, the rice barge, here you are offered a very generous selection of the tropical Thai fruits with a fruit juice as well, and yes eat as much fruit as you wish, it's lovely ...
back to the historial age :). antique, unique, very thai, expensive but reasonable from excellent original thai taste and best quality selection, good service and stunning view...
Best value sightseeing. Took the night tour 80baht from Asiatiques, too much commentry but silent on the way back. I loved messing about on the river & went by ferry as much as possible.

Such contrasts. Took a long-tail boat and also a river dinner cruise on the river. It has amazing contrasts between well-off housing and shanty huts right next to each other. The river is muddy looking and in some parts a bit smelly. Still, very nteresting though.

Great overview of the city. Gives everyone a real taste of the city of Bangkok. Would recommend that every visitor to Bangkok take a boat ride on the river and enjoy all the sounds and sights of a very eclectic city!

Always choppy water. I've been on this river on both longtail boats, tour boats and the ferries and it's always been rough. Not too rough that it causes sea-sickness but choppy and I've never seen it calm. The volume of traffic on the waterway does have an impact on this but I always love going on the river when I'm in BKK.
Food charges very high. The food is very expensive if you take it on cruise. But apart, the river is a good place to be and look around.

Bangkok's water attractions. No visit to Bangkok is complete without a trip along the river, which can be done using any of the variety of services available. The cheapest is the standard commuter boat trip which makes numerous stops along the way - arm yourself with a decent map so that you can identify the attractions on both banks of the river, and aim eventually to get a seat.In addition, take the Skytrain to Saphan Taksin (on the river) and then negotiate a longboat tour along some of the canals. The 90min-2hr tours give a really good view of Bangkok life around the many canals of what was "Venice of the East". Be prepared to negotiate the cost, based on how many passengers - the initial amount requested will be an ambit claim. Take a bottle of water, and have some baht to use to barter with the lady who will row out to your boat to sell you souvenirs along the way. A canal trip is a very different insight into how many people still live - very humbly, above the water.
Nice trip. A lovely trip on the river. Good views from the boat, commentary was minimal, but the meal was good.

Curise along!. There is plenty to do on the Chao Phraya. Just go with enough time and try to avoid the sun! It may be a good idea to take the ferry for visiting places close to the piers (ready walking distance) but for places further away, you may be better off taking a taxi or train.

Neat environment under development. The cruise by small boat is attractive one. The works related to
cleaning and deepening is on.Safety aspects like life jacket in boats is essential . The boat man must avoid going near the cranes
engaged ihn works.

Good service. 1) Chao Phraya tourist boat service should provided in all the hotel. It will improved Bangkok tourism. All the hotel, should know more information on where is the right pier for tourist. All the pier are charging different rate. Definate will spoit the thai tourism. Must really take good care of the tourist..without them, nobody will come again.2) Because the center pier, with the customer service. We enjoyed very much with the explanation n help.( Day before, we went to the wrong pier (Shangri-la). They charged us thai Baht 500 per person. Luckily, we're rejected the offer).
Important for Indian Travellers. Indian travellers who do not want to have Indian Food must specify that when taking your tickets..they allocate the boats according to skin colour

Well worth a boat trip. Best is to get the commuter's slow boat, cheap fares, eg 15THB for a long trip. Next is the Chao Phraya express, 40THB for a single trip. These do not stop all places, and it is a little confusing to find which ones they do. But Maharaj near Grand Palace is a good place to pick up the tourist boat, or cross the river for 3THB and pick up the slower boat there. No need to pay for tourist cruises at 150THB or more. Avoid the touts who lie about what is available.

want to see the length of bangkok, ride a boat taxi up and down and back to where u started. just get a basic one stop ticket. have a group of friend and food. and travel the whole length of the basic river taxi. the orange line. or the tourist blue line, (twice as much). can get off anywhere. just say admiring the view... and will get off when it goes back to xxxx pier... great people picture opportunities. like i nearly ran and jumbed to get onto a boat as it took off. now that would have been great picture to capture. or me falling in the river. or go up to Ko Kret for the day and come back on the express boat.plenty of good places to see the river from the banks, or bridges, or back of the bangkok tourist information office just north of thammasat university.and very nice park and student cafes and tables and power points in thamasat university on the edge of the river as well. there is part of the original wall of bangkok preserved there too.go up the 8 story building of the liberal arts department to get great view of the river.this is one of the best places to see the rehearsals of the royal barge procession done in early November each year. for the actual royal procession, all these buildings are locked up.it was one of the most spectacular sight and sound events i have experienced, looking down on the river with over 50 long boats all dressed up and all singing, paddling down the river. see photos and video on my facebook.
Chaotic but fun. We went on a public ferry. It's fun but chaotic. Keep your company close by. I hope the information level gets an upgrade. It's easy to get on the wrong ferry due to bad information.

The famous river of Bangkok. We traveled on this river to get to Wat Arun, Wat Pho and Grand Palace. It lives up to its status as one of world's busiest water transportation - a must do when you are in Bangkok.
Dirty river. Very nice view from a distance !The river is always dirty, and nobody care.Many tourist boats available.

Go by public transport. Don't use an expensive tourist boat, go by public transport. Tuk Tuk drivers will try to take you to a private jetty so they earn a commission. The Sky Train has a station right at the public jetty. Go as far upriver as the public ferry goes then get off and walk around the market. Some great food there.

Take the local ferries to get a taste of Bangkok.. If you are happy with a bit of local stuff then it is the best way to get a taste of BKK. Take the BTS to Sapin Taksin station. There are free feries to the night markets or get on the local boats to cruise the river. Look at the notice board to see which color flag gets you to the place you want to visit. BTW. Staff dont have much english but are very helpful.

Relaxing. The river has such a amazing boat life! It is really nice to sit with a drink and watch all the different boats go past!There are also weird fish that swim up to the surface and roll back down into the water. Very mesmerizing to watch
Just OK. The tour we have had, includes a ride of a tourist boat passing chao phraya river. We have seen the beautiful hotels and filty houses, but its ok, it was quite an experience! :)

Wonderful views. Definitely take a trip on the River. Private Boat tourist trip,everyday ferry or even on the Hotel ferries. Not to be missed. Watch daily life passing you by, see the sights and get a guide for a wonderful trip..be there for New Year for a spectacular show of fireworks !!!

A must do.... Hard to feel like you visited Bangkok if you have not travelled the river by boat. The river taxi boat is an experience by itself and the best way to get to several of the more prominent temples. Convenient and cheap too.

See Bankok as it really is. A trip along the Chao Phraya is a must, just to see how the locals really live. The ferry boats are cheap and very regular and take passengers to both sides of the river. Not clean or elegant and probably need much upgrading but a wonderful way to mix with the locals. Took this river boat to go to the Grand Palace and the Emerald Buddha....the Flower Market..also to China Town.. Foodis available in plenty at every stop, its where the locals eat and definitely worth a try..
the river. if you want to eat out , go to the river around 6-00 at night its loverly. see all the river lighting. but you must keep coverd up.....mosquitoees

Get a bus or ferry rather than a "cruise". There's plenty of cheap and frequent river buses and river ferries so there is absolutely no need to be ripped off paying for a cruise unless you want to go all the way up river and go to Ayudthaya.You can get the buses and ferries from near the Oriental hotel but there are plenty of other places.Best thing to do though is to find one of the many restaurants that overlook the River. Sit watching the River traffic whilst having a good meal, a beer, reading the paper, or whatever.whilst your wife is busy spending up big on the fashions!There are plenty of good restaurants overlooking the river close to Banglampoo.

Well Worth the Longboat Trip. If you decide to go on the River for a cruise I suggest you take a long boat. You are then able to go along the many canals that branch out from the River. This is where you will see the real people of Bangkok. See the conditions or lack of them they live in. The people here fish, wash and use the water to cook. It is amazing at the number of people who wave and say hello. They always have a smile on their face for you as you go past. Even though the water is dirty and does smell in some places I would certainly recommend you spend a couple of hours cruising the River.  Important thing to know is that the Ferries cannot take you up the canals. Only the longboats can do that.
Smelly river. The river is very smelly, poluted and has a high traffic of speeding boats going up and down the river

Floating down an open sewer.. The water was filthy, it even irritated my skin as I was splashed. It stank, was full of garbage and rubbish. Open sewer pipes pouring raw sewage into it as we drifted by. If you must go on it try the enclosed up-market converted rice barges with air con and buffet lunch or dinner. Open boats - forget it!

Fascinating but dirty. We travelled in the ferry and then later on a river cruise/dinner package on the Chao Phraya. Apart from the torrential rain and average meal on the dinner cruise, this river is well worth experiencing but not a great advert for healthy waterways
