This is why I always stay at a riverside hotel. Love it, there is always something to watch and its easy and very cheap to pop on and off the frequent water taxis and lots of the better hotels have their own converted rice barges to drop you off at the MTR train station

Lifeblood of Thailand. This river has been used by the people of Thailand for centuries for food, commerce, trade and living. The river is not the cleanest in the whole world, nor the busiest but taking the ferry across to see the sites is a great way to spend some time. There are also many dinner cruises that go up and down the river at night which gives you some beautiful sites such as the Rama 8 Bridge over the river

What a great way to get a feel for Bangkok.. Catch a free boat from River City to one of the big hotels, such as The Oriental, Peninsular or The Shangri-La and wander through their gardens and boutique shops, or go the other way, these hotels have their own free boats to River city and back all day.Take a ride in a 'long tail' boat to China town or the Flower Market, get the wind in you face and feel the freedom.A night cruise on a rice boat restaurant or big diner cruiser is a great way to see the city from the river at night.

unforgettable evening. my hubby and i had a dinner cruise on Chao Phraya river, and it was also a very good evening, the food was excellent. and we could see some historical places. the grand palace, some temples.
Wonderful experience of the Grand Dame of Bangkok. Love the long tail boat and the rice barge tour. Wonderful experience, working out the historical significance of Thailand over the centuries/.
Good experience. Taking a boat is a good way to travel to China town and at the same time experience the sights along the river.

007 licence to thrill. bit pongy but those longtail boats dont alf shift and when you get in to the klongs (canals) away from the main flow of the river they dont slow down and all you bigger boys with bigger toys out there you can feel like james bond for 1/2 an hour

Hire a long tail boat via your hotel for a trip around the canals off the main river.. We arranged a tour via our hotel for 1500 baht. It was a two hour trip starting at our hotel Anantara Bangkok Riverside, via Wat Arun then finishing at the Grand Palace. After a tour of the Grand Palace we made our way back on the Chao Phraya river express boat but from a safety point of view I don't think I would set foot on it again. It's clear they have to dock and leave as fast as possible. When we were on the boat we saw another boat accidentally leave one of the ropes attached to the pier. The boat set off, then there was an almighty bang as the rope snapped! Amazingly nobody was hurt.
It will give you another perspective of Bangkok. Take a river tour and experience Bangkok from a different point of view. It's another way to get around also, to avoid the heavy traffic.

Dinnercruise. The dinner cruise in the evening is a beautiful and romantic thing to do. A big buffe with alot of food, dancing after eating if you want, music and the boat going slow up and down the river with all the beautiful things to see.

One of the most important locations in Thailand. The Chao Phraya River is the one of the most imporatant locations in Thailand. It has done everything from given them transporation to protecting the capital from invaders (in past history).

Some of the best views of Bangkok can be seen from here........... From its source at the Ocean end and Port of Bangkok the river flows around the city and onwards.the most popular areas can be viewed from long boats or from the hotel shuttles crossing from side to side.Check out the Shangrila,The Oriental and the River City Shopping complex as either start or exit points the trip on the water taxi's cost only a few Baht and the more adventurous can hire a longboat to tour the canals as well as the main waterway that travels past quite a few major temples and tourist attractions including some of the most iconic hotels to be found in Bangkok.On a sunny day the trip can be pleasurable,on a wet day it is a dirty grey road for all maritime boats plying their cargoes along its length.It is deep and dangerous so be careful and giant fish can be caught from jetties close to the hotels.All in all its worth a half a day to look at and enjoy,the possibilities are endless....................

Beautiful way to see Bangkok.. You have to take the ride at least once. Buy the day pass for 150 baht and exit where you like and hop back on to see more sights. You can travel the length of Bangkok, have the best possible view and avoid the traffic. Avoiding the traffic in Bangkok is always a welcome treat.

Venice of Asia. The main Thai river, the Chao Praya, runs through Bangkok and on into the Gulf of Thailand. In Bangkok, the Chao Praya River is wide and full of river traffic, making it a wonderful place to eat dinner next to, as you watch the tour boats, ferry boats and barges coming down from China, as well as locals selling their wares or just taking the boat home from work. Bangkok has many beautiful riverside restaurants, serving both international and Thai cuisines.Spent 2 days up and down the river. We saw templs and buddha statues on the way. Stopped off at Chinatown and Pier 8 for Wat Po and little markets - worth the visits. Highly recommend.

See it day and night!. An excellent way to see the city. Take a river cruise in the daytime, and then do it again at night. Night time cruises offer dinner, and the city lights are spectacular. Also, ride a long-tailed boat for a REAL THRILL!!!

Just take a boat. If you are staying even for a short time in Bankok, you have to see what is the Chao Phraya river.Take a little boat, or just a bus boat but you have to discover the town by this way. you will see many things that you could not discover by taxi or metro.It can be very cheap if you want to take the "bus boat", but you can also decide do take a little traditionnal Thaï boat.The truth is that Bangkok without the Chao Phraya river will not be the same

Another "must do" while in Bangkok!. A Bangkok visit will not be complete without a river tour! There are many to choose from and you may opt for the long tail boat tour which takes about 3-4 hours and takes you on a little speedy ride into little side rivers or so called "Klongs" and to floating market etc..

ALIVE. Take the boat and just allow yourself to go up and down the river - great trip, with the local people - beautiful scenary
inexpensive way for another look at beautifu bangkok

See Bangkok from the River. The ferry terminals range from acceptable to weird to dirty but they are all interesting. We used the Express Boats regularly and the cross river ferries too. You get to see all sorts of districts if you jump on and off. Fares are a few cents and well worth the price for dodging Bangkok traffic for some of the areas you can't get to by the Skytrain. If you can afford it, hire a long tail boat for an hour or so and tour the canals. Haggle down the price though. The initial asking price can be pretty steep.
I just love getting around in a longtail.... ... watching the Bangkok world flying by. Everything about Bangkok used to revolve around the river, it's cool to get a taste of this in the 21st century.
Dirty. Very dirty river- we saw dead fish there and a lot of garbage! The river taxi on the other hand is one of the fastest, cheapest and nice way to visit Wat Pho, King's palace and Wat Arun.

Truly Venice of ASIA. HOT, price is reasonable. be prepared to pay more for long boat experience. 1000 - 1200 baht for 1 hr!!!!! and then the boat driver asks for another 100 baht. But still it is very interesting to go exploring the canal, and really see how the ppl live by the river.... Try to research whn the city floating markets are and go early in morning - otherwise they take to random single boat sellers who are waiting JUST for tourists. Still, they don't mind if you smile and politely decline any sales.

An interesting way to get around the city~. Other than the BTS, Taxis and tuk tuks, the boat is another way to get around the city. Apparently there are different there are 2 types of ferries, one for tourists (30b) and another for locals getting around (15b). The one for tourists has a guide, more comfortable seats and a more pleasant ride. Be prepared to squeeze on the one for locals. It's faster and a more bumpy ride. Both are pleasant experiences!

Below our expectations. The river cruise on the Chao Praya River was a little disappoiniting. We had chosen the option with dinner. The buffet dinner was not very good and lacked in taste. The cruise was noisy and after a while it became a drag. We were happy when it ended. Also suprised at the discrimination in alloting boats. There seemed to be different boats for Europeans, South Asians and so on. Wonder why? This was probably the only part of our trip which we did not enjoy.
River Barge cruise. If you do anything as a tour, do this. It is a view of life of old Thailand and the way people live. A barge and long boat cruise add to the overal value.

Night boat on the river. We booked this trip via the hotel reception. Unfortunately we were the first to be collected by the taxi bus and it took ages to get to the boat. The trip itself was supposedly about seeing the river by night and the lights around the city. This was disappointing but the buffet supplied was good and the cabaret was ok. Not a trip I would bother doing again.

Take the long tail boat ride. Took ride down river in a long tail boat. Stopped and saw temples and buddha statues on the way. Even stopped for beer mid river. Awesome way to see Bangkok, Wat Arun was beautiful. I would recommend this trip to anyone who has the time

gotta go and ride the ferry to JW Marriott. there is a FREE ferry from the pier to the JW Marriott and you cross the river and see all the hustle and bussle... you can get to the pier from the BTS sky train... also ride to the Oriental Hotel and have drinks at their resturant & bar... a real history lesson.

Love rivers. Spent 2 days up and down the river. Lovely little cafe/kitchens - don't need to go for expensive ones - eat where the locals eat. Stopped off at Chinatown and Pier 8 for Wat Po and little markets - worth the visits.

Dirty. The river is muggy and smelly in some areas. The jettys along the river are also dirty, don't thing a Binman has removed rubbish for months. They are also a magnet for people sleeping rough, quite threatening at night really. Could do with a clean up as so many tourists use the river.

A nice break to the city sprawl. Nice to view from your hotel window and watch the water traffic go by...but I personally don't like the muddy look of it...but it s clean and not smelly...we use it on the river ferries to asiatique...and I believe there are some wonderful day trips along it...
TREAT YOURSELF TO THIS. We did a Dinner Cruise on the Grand Pearl on the Chao Phraya River - it is awesome!!!! Best experience you can ask for.

Must Do!. I took the BTS to Sapsan Thaksin station and the river is only a few steps away. Bought the whole day pass at 150Baht for unlimited trips (from 9am to 7pm). You can stop at different piers to visit different temples and other attractions. I went to Wat Arun, Wat Pho and Grand Palace which all 3 are a must-see definitely. It's a great way to see Bangkok from a different perspective. You get a taste of how the locals live.

Not very scenic. City river that you can use to commute sounds exciting but it is such a hassle bargaining with the taxi boats and the occasional smell did not really make up for the views of Bangkok.
EXPRESS TOURIST BOAT. We bought single tickets to travel from the mrt to the grand Palace and National Museum stop. A great way to explore Bangkok.
dirty, dirty. Very dirty river only used to trave, did not do a diner cruise. efficient for seeing all the temples. Can buy a tourist day pass for 150Bt per person

very good ride. Its used as a public transport and the city is connected through the river. We used it to visit grand palace. Its just perfect to beat the traffic and a cheap way to reach your destination
nice ride. Dirty river, but the ride on a luxury boat in the evening is a nice experience. Take a ride on the Chao Phraya Princess.

Fascinating local scene. A very good place to mingle around with the locals, along this river you can reach several big and famous Thai temple like the temple of dawn (Wat Arun) and Temple of Reclining Buddha (Wat Pho) and many more. When cruising this river, be aware that the boats have several different stop and they are differentiated by flags which is Blue, yellow, orange and no flag, for details of the stop for each flag you can easily get it from the main station. To get to the main station, just hop on to BTS and get down at Saphan Thaksin BTS station, Chao Phraya River is just few minute walk from it. A single trip cause you less than 50 bath and you get to see how locals ranging from executive, students and monks on how they utilize this river for their daily transportation. Do check out the floating marketing as well along the river as well.

great way to see Bangkok. We bought a day ticket so we could hop on and off the tourist boat. Very good value. Each stop is announced so you know when to get off. It's a great way to travel up and down the river

Take the Skytrain and a boat. This is a nice trip. Take the Skytrain to the Chao Phraya River and than an boat on the river. That is so cheap and easy but let you feel like a Thai himself. Great experience.

A long boat must. We have always loved going down the river by long boat and have many fun stories to tell. This time because of a celebration the tours through Tour East weren't running so they sent us to the Sheraton on the river. We hired a private long boat to so the klongs and feed the fish. We were sure the driver was drunk, he reluctantly stopped to feed the fish and there were no klongs in sight. Very disappointing and will stick to the tour east next time. We did give feedback but they didn't care
lame.. polluted, noisy, dirty boats on dirty river is a waste of money. i would not go back there. and beware of scammers. .

Great way to spend a few hours in Bangkok. We frequently take the river ferries up and down the Chao Phraya to simply pass a couple of slow hours. Great views of old embassies and historic sites a plenty. All for a few Baht and well worth doing. Connects to BTS Skytrain a Saphin Taksin. Couldn't be simpler!

loved this way of seeing Bangkok. Listened to the advice of others, and I used the 15 bhat local boat to see Bangkok by river...My favourite place was actually the last stop at nonthaburi..I took the time to walk up the street, past the town centre clock tower, and found a little thai cafe about 200m up on the left,, serving the best Thai Beef Noodles I tasted in all my travels :-) yum ...and all for 20bhat!!! away from my stomach, the Chao Phraya River boat excursion was relaxing (apart from the fact you should ALWAYS try to sit towards the back of the boat, so you can get off at a stop in time- yes i failed!)..you get to see and feel more a part of the spiritual Bangkok, rather than the Hedonist side...

Always busy. The river is just bustling with noise all through the day and night. It provides cheap boats to the spots on the river where most tourists go and links to the Skytrain so that the rest of Bangkok is accessible

A lovely river, which provides an interesting view of Bangkok river life. Spent a really nice afternoon sailing down the Chao Phraya river on a tour boat. It was nice to see the variety of houses along the river, and the barges coming into and out of the city. Nice to also see the Grand Palace from the river side, and of course the views of Wat Arun. Loved it. Also did the ferry service along the river to Wat Arun on another day, and fun way to get around, not to mention really cheap.

refreshing time!. bangkok is a really crowded, full of traffic, hot and sometimes exhausting place. so the best thing is to take a boat and touring on muddy water of chao phraya! it should be done at least one time, if possible more.
A great river to sightsee. We boarded the public ferry and travelled the complete distance. That was a great way to get our bearings.

Ot is a "must"to make a boat trip over the Chao Phraya River.. You can make amazing photo's and see how the people from Bangkok live along the klongs of the river. You can go with group tour or rent a private boat that brings you everywhere you want. There are even boat taxis you can use for your own transport.

Means of transportation and place for celebration. Bangkok residents love their river and make good use of it. River taxis are a common way of transportation from one side of the city to the other, as it goes throughout the city.

Another perspective of BKK life. Great way to see the city - while enjoying a cooling breeze from the water. Ferry system is easy once you work it out : and easier still if you jump on the Tourist express boat ( although a lot more expensive - but it's SO cheap compared to Europe, we went with the easy option) This is by far the best way to get to the Grand Palace & Wat Pho. Avoid BKK traffic whenever you can...

Take a boat for cool view of Bangkok. We got the tourist boat from the pier near Khao San Rd down to Sathorn pier, it made a nice refreshing way to see some of Bangkok, and a cool escape from the heat. Cheap way of seeing the city, little bit of commentary as well.

Boat tour gives interesting perspective on the city. Did a private boat tour (400B each for 3 people) from Oriental pier (watch out for taxi drivers taking you to a different pier to get you to pay more so they get commission!). Tour takes you round some of the back canals around Bangkok as well as down the Chao Phraya River and its definitely worth the trip. It was a nice day and we got to see some extravagant temples contrasting with houses on stilts in the river which were certainly on their last legs. Enjoyable ride and gives you an insight into the city.

Pretty but Polluted. River is polluted but serves as a great mode of transportation via riverboat to avoid Bangkok's notorious traffic jams. Also a good place to travel so you can see the many Wat's riverside. I'd recomend taking the airtrain to a riverboat if you want to visit the Grand Palace, etc.
another good public transport service .. able to get a better feel for the city of Bangkok,..its layout and the way it works.It is used by travellers and tourists alike as a means of transport.
Easy travel. it's easy to travel up and down Bangkok's river using the local river boats - the stops are numbered - just hope on and the ticket lady will sell you the cheap ticket

I love this river. The river was in flood when the tide was high some little piers had gone under, the river was churned up but so alive. this river makes Bangkok special. Catch the regular ferry anywhere any distance up and down the river for 15 baht. it is so much fun, you are on it with the every day people of Bangkok, monks included and at some point on the journey you end up having a great conversation with the local Thais that includes the monks. I think this is so much better than the tourist ferry as you are a part of the river experience. I love this river

Cruising at Chao Phraya River. Cruising the Chao Phraya River is a nice way to explore Bangkok. We took an evening cruise which goes with dinner and live entertainment on board. Nice but too crowded with people.

take a public ferry up the river .. If you want a great ride on the river to see Bangkok from the water take the public ferry and you can get off at any of the numeruos stops and take a look around .Best of all it is dirt cheap and very relaxing .

Seeing Bangkok from a different perspective. One day in Bangkok at around 12:30 mid-day, found out that I am done for that day. Was thinking how to get the best outta remaining half day! Chatting with the tour desk at my hotel, found out a tailor-made half day Chao Praya river cruise called Rice Barge Cruise - reasonable priced, included hotel pick-up and drop off in air-conditioned vehicle and complimentary tropical fruits and drinks treat. Was picked up at 1:00 pm and reached river city by 2. The cruise starts at 2:30pm at river city pier and lasts for about 2 hours. The trip started in a traditional boat converted in to an express boat which went up stream the river and offered wonderful view of wonderful temples and other historical structures on both banks of the river. Just after crossing the Memorial bridge on the left side, first temple was the 'Temple of Good Relationship' (sorry, forgot the Thai name for this temple); then was the Majestic Wat Arun; almost opposite was the most famous of Bangkok attractions, Grand Palace & Wat Phra Kew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha). In my earlier trips, I have visited both these historical sites; but seeing it from the vibrant river leaves an unique impression in the mind! The cruise continues crossing the Phrapinklao bridge and Rama 8 bridge, then it takes a left small river/canal towards Nontaburi offering view of life on the waterways. The express boat then makes a return and moves towards a 'Traditional Rice Barge' conveniently converted in to a tourist boat. Second part of this cruise continues in this wonderful Rice Barge. Guests are treated with traditional tropical fruits and drinks. The barge returns to the Chao Praya river, crosses the river city goes further down-stream offering view of this vibrant river and landmark structures on both banks of the river. It travels close to the Sathorn bridge and the BTS (Sky train) river crossing then makes a turnaround towards the River City where we got on board. A wonderful river cruise of a different kind - for me a memorable utilization of an supposedly idle half-day :)

Good for sight seeing. Good for sight seeing but don't eat near the river (in an open air). Side of the river near the riverbanks are dirty and smelly. Looks nice when sunrise so pick a hotel near chao phraya.

An interesting way to see Bangkok. We had one really wet day on our trip, so decided to go on the ferry for the whole journey. We started at Sathorn Pier (the main station - stop no. 1) and stayed on the boat all the way up to - I think - stop 33 for the princely sum of 15 baht! It took about an hour and gave a fascinating insight into Thai life - the trainee Buddhists, the ladies standing fishing in the river, the Barge / long-boat crews practising for the regatta to celebrate the king's birthday, the amazing houses along the river ... A lovely way to spend a wet day!

Interesting journey at a very reasonable cost. Join the river by travelling from your hotel to Tasking Saphan Sky train station and then walk about 50 meters to the central pier station of the Chao Phraya River. The only easy way to travel to Khao San Road from the Silom/Sathorn area. Don't take the tourist boat [40 Baht], wait for the express boat [15 Baht], travel with the locals and pay less.

great fun. A great way to travel like a local. There are few signs in English or any language other than Thai, so you have to figure out what to do by watching. When a boat arrives, the fun begins. Crowds pour out. You and others pour in. A woman banging a coin pot comes around and collects a few bhat for the ride. Then you watch the scenery on both sides of the river, watch the crowd on the boat, and get off at your chosen destination. It is much more fun and much cheaper to travel the river this way than to take a tour!
Cruise is the way to see. I took a cruise. A dinner cruise to be precise. It took us over all the stretch of Bangkok and we could see wonderful places while enjoying great food
La Noya Boat Cruise along the river. This was well worth the value 3-4 course dinner experience along the river great sights of the grand Palace and other lit up sights.

Ask the price before you order the food. Don't ever try and have a drink at the cruise, you will regret for paying too much. A cruise and light snacks will be good. Solo travelers will find it boring, that's what I felt.

Cardiff lassie. We went on the evening dinner cruise, it is a buffet meal of good quality, the meal doesn't include drinks. We ordered wine before looking at the price list and we paid the equivalent of forty british pounds, wine is expensive everywhere in Thailand. After the buffet we were entertained by live entertainment, which was very good. It ended with Thai dancers.we paid 1200 baht each approx £24 It was very good value for money. I would recommend .

One Time Worth. To Cruise on the Boat is good experience.You need to take care that you start when sun starts coming down. There are some boat Cruise which serve dinner as well. But prices they charge are quite high and not value for money.
Cruise!. We did the river cruise with buffet dinner which was a fantastic experience! Don't forget your camera!

See a different angle of Bangkok. Get some reasonably fresh air and use the river taxi to get about. River taxis can get somewhat over-crowded so if you're a bit claustrophobic you may want to give it a miss.

Boats on the river Phraya. Easy to use from the central pier,explain that you want to go across or up to a station near the Palace or Temple,They are cheap and if you whant to go night shopping there is a free barge from Asiatique.Avoid the Tourist boat as they are more expensive

Get on and watch Bangkok go by!. Great, cheap way of getting up the river to the sights at Wat Po, Emerald Buddha, Grand Palace. Convenient when staying near central pier and Saphan Taksin BTS station. Have some time to kill, go up to Nonthaburi, its takes about an hour from central pier, nice journey and an hour back. Bargain at 30bht each way.

Cheesy cruise. Went on a cruise down the river and thought it would be a classy experience but really was a bit cheesy, live music was really just a karaoke singer and the decor was a bit 1980s, food was ok but not great for the price, but it was cool to see Wat Arun from the river.

be carefull while u travel in boat. dont say it river all the waste water of the city goes in river it is stinking be carefull when u r traveling otherwise u will make your cloths wet as boat run very fast n when they cross each other water comes inn

Take the public ferry. Don't be conned into using a long tail boat at the pier. The touts will take you on a 15 minute hot walk to another private pier and you will be exposed to a noisy and sometimes smelly and damp journey. They travel so quickly that you don't see most of the features on the river and the driver will not speak English so you will not have any of the attractions pointed out. Keep to the public multi-stop ferries which are cheap and provide a multi-stop hop on hop off service will running commentary. Go between the rush hours and use the pier by the Shangrila Hotel where there is a skytrain station.

Chao Phraya River Dinner Cruise. This was my fourth time on this dinner cruise along Chao Phraya River and I still love to see sites along the river: We passed some wonderful bridges some it seems we can almost touch it as we passed underneath, then we reached Wat Phra Kaew and my most favorite is the Temple of Dawn (better save batteries on your cameras beacause for me this is the climax of this cruise). The view of Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) for me is very stunning and mesmerizing at night. I will always love to see this image in person. I recommend this cruise if you are here in Bangkok. There are two choices: either you pay only what you ordered or the buffet. You have to pay the minimal cruise fare. Check it out on their website or call River Side Hotel.

Nice cruise by river. It is very nice to spend some time on Chao Praya River in Bangkok. You can buy one way ticket (max. 40 THB) - I recommend it or all day (150 THB). It is easy to reach main pier by sky train.

Fun!. It's just pure fun to get on to a river taxi and mingle! I just loved it, as it is a special experience. One has to be very fast when you want to go on or off the boat. The conducters are fun to watch, you have a great view and it is a very inexpensive way to enjoy the river!

great views and a lovely experience. Ditch the tour boats and guided tours! Jump on a river bus and pay just 20 Baht to go the entire length of the river. Get off for a walk at the end, then take another to get back where you started. You can easily spend 3 or 4 hours doing the length of the river and see all the sights for not much more than a dollar!

View of Bangkok. One of our favorite activities is to get on a river taxi at stop one and ride it to stop 30, get off at Nonthaburi, and walk down the dock to the floating restaurant for one of the best Thai meals ever.

Nice view from the water. Cheap and enjoyable to cruise down the river like the locals do. Stopping along the way to pick up and drop off passengers. Nice views from the water of the towering and not so towering buildings.

Artery of commerce, cheap transport, a slice of old Bangkok. Barges constantly cruise up and down river pulled along by tugs transporting endless goods.The boat transport system is cheap and a sight to see. A grumble of engine, whistle blows, and the occasional splash of Bangkok river water. The river cuts through historical Bangkok. You can see Wat Arun, but it is best visited by land.It won't leave you breathless but it's a unique slice of life. Avoid the tourist boat trips and just get on any passing river boat.

Mixed feelings. A boat took me around for 1000 BAT along the canals stemming from the main river. A mix of some nice temples with a very degraded reality of what was the capital of thailand. Very little left of such grandeur. However, having the time, it is still worth a tour, but avoid the floating market (non existent) and the crocodile and snake farm (only one snake and non crocodiles)

constant movement. The Chao Praya River is a source of constant visual interest: the "fishtail" boats churning up their "rooster-tail" plumes of water as they noisily race by or the brightly colored tugboats pulling dully colored barges with tarps concealing their contents.The teak boats with their temple-inspired roofs, the water taxis filled to the brim landing and departing with such efficiency.The fishermen with multiple lines, occasionally holding up a tiny fish in triumph.so many different boats.fascinating.

the biggest river in Bangkok and u can have a dinner over the river. Chao Phraya River has been part of Thai people's daily life. The river is everything for them. If u want to have an experience with the river, u can start by riding the boat from the pratunam pier. Or, u also can buy the ticket to have a dinner in the boat floating on the river. When I viisted Bangkok, my frined invited me for dinner in the restaurant established on Chao Praya river. It has nice view however the food is expensive:)...But it is worth eating because u also get beautiful view of Chao Phraya River

great. GGreat way to travel through the city, but also did a river cruise which was really good grand pearl. Buffet and traditional dancing while cruising the river at night. All the sights beautifully lit and attractive. Suburb.

Go for a trip on it. Its a good idea to go for a trip on this river. There is lots to see. You can take a big boat and eat a nice dinner and listen to live bands or you can take a river taxi, cheap and fun.

great way to see bangkok in an hour!. a great way to see the city from a different angle.. the piers are every step of the way so it is also a good way to cross from one side to the other without a taxi!

Did a private tour: watch out for the details. We hired a private boat to take us up the river, to the floating market, to Wat Arun and then lastly to the Grand Palace. Though we were lured into the deal (another thing to watch for) we were happy with the price IF the captain had really taken us to all these places. We didnt know exactly what to expect, but we didnt get it in the end either. When we were wisened to the real deal it was almost too late, but we managed to get something of the deal back.

River boat tour. We jumped on a small boat that was motored by a car engine, as most of them seem to be! Terrible smell but what an experience! Went round the river, past the real peoples houses and saw river living. Had a couple of boats stop, as they were seling wares and bought a couple of bits, including a hat that doubled up as a fan, which came in use later on during our stay. Was a great expereince!

Nice way to see Bangkok's heritage sights. This is a "must-do" experience for anyone visiting Bangkok. One easy route is to take the Skytrain (Silom line) to Saphan Thaksin station, walk to the riverfront and board either the regular or tourist boat heading toward Nonthaburi.The regular boat makes more stops, is less expensive and much more crowded. The tourist boat hits the major stops - the best known wats (temples) and Chinatown - costs about 40TB and even has a tour giude announcing the various sights.

Don't forget to get off. The public ferry up the river from Central under the bridge at "saphan taksin" sky train stop is really cheap only about $1.40 for 5 stops or 45 stops so if your like us and just want a bit of a look around don't forget to get off and catch one going back or you will be on the ferry for about 3 hours if you go to the end and back. It takes you to a few of the most popular tourist temples but not much else to see.
To see real Bangkok. From grand old boats to Night river cruises...You can see the real Bangkok by travelling in the river!!~

River trip. Loved the boats their speed and curtesy when passing other boats. Seem that their are rules for the waterways and every one follows them. Able to see the locals and their homes and gardens

tourism. We wanted to do a short river trip but were directed to the wrong boat by the staff and became quite alarmed when it did not turn back. We were not the only tourists caught in this predicament and it was difficult to return back to base.
River Cruise was Soothing. Chao Praya Princess tour was a pleasant river cruise at night. Night scenery of the river was good to enjoy with family.
Banyan Tree boat wonderful night. saw Bangkok from different aspect. Meal and staff excellent, could not have been more helpful. Drive from Hotel and back was great, got to see other parts of city

Refresher. The Chao Phraya river is one of the coolest places in Bangkok, also literary. Easiest is to board a ferry at Saphan Taksin which you reach via the Skytrain (dark green line). You can choose between the local version on the left, cheap but crowded or the tourist version on the right which is slightly more expensive has more sitting room. You can just go to the end and back or make stops near the Royal Palace or Wat Arun temple. Using it is very simple and the desk selling tickets will tell you where to get off. Cruising the river is a treat with the bustling traffic of all kinds of boats. It is a must do.

never a doll monent.. we absolutly loved the chao phraya river, there was always some thing to look at, or try.we had a boat ride in an longboat, they were very good and fast,we also had a river cruise down the river, following a tour.every day, we went with the hotels shuttle boat, which was good fun, it is amasing what the take up and down the mighty river chao phraya.

There really are crocodiles .... On our last visit to Bangkok (two years ago) we visited a floating market on a long tail boat. To get my two young daughters to keep their hands inside the boat I told them there were crocodiles in the river. They weren't quite sure whether to believe me or not but they kept their hands in the boat just in case.This year, older and wiser, they asked again whether there were crocodiles and I just gave them a knowing look although they claimed not to believe me. You can imagine their surprise when they spotted a huge monitor lizard sunning itself on a bridge pillar in the middle of one of the inlets to the Chao Phraya River, they immediately sat on their hands!!! They now have renewed belief in Father Christmas and the Easter Bunny!!I would thorougly recommend a long tail boat trip on the river, feeding the cat fish was amazing - we bought a loaf of bread from someone on the bank, lowered to us in a fishing net. The river just came alive with heaving cat fish desperate for the bread. It's also so much easier to visit temples and other tourist destinations rather than sitting in a cab in a traffic jam for ages.

Very nice view. we went with the boat ride but we were overpriced and you have to lower your price to the owners of the boat. At first they wanted to charge us 3 times as much but when we decided not to go they lowered the price by half and then by much more. We still think they might have overcharged us still but it was a very impressive ride on the whole.

Dirty river. Did a ferry. Worth a miss. It can just be used for transporting and not worth the cruises. If you taking the sky train to kha sarn road, you would be getting off at the ferry point and then you take a ferry to the other side.
worth a look. good way to travel to grand palace,,,, stop at china town , but hold onto your bag and keep ur wits about u
Ahhhhh..... I love the Chao Praya and all the options for water transit from Saphan Taksin. Great way to get to Chinatown and Khoa San Road when the streets a jammed with traffic.

River Cruise. We took a dinner cruise on this river and enjoyed the trip. The food on the boat was smorgasboard and the whole package was good value. Highly recommend a day trip on one of the little boats that have a V8 on the back, they zip along at great speeds and is a lot of fun as well.
Nice Views. Make sure you do this trip on the river while in Bangkok. It is really great, offering wonderful views of the Wat Arun and other temples along the way.

A "Must Do" for all visitors to the capital. A ride along the river is a must do - reminiscent of olden day travel in the Kingdom.
Not expensive - in fact very cheap.
Along the river view Temples and river life.
Highly recommend it.

Probably the least stressful form of travel. Taxi's, motorbike, and tuk-tuks, the Skytrain, all have some form of drawback; traffic, near death experiences, and quirky pricing schemes, and crowded cars, by far the ferry is probably the most straightforward, pleasant way to get around Bangkok, it's also fairly inexpensive.

Once in a lifetime. Spent a great afternoon with a group we were with going down the canals of the river, experiencing the floating market and all the various temples. Also the experience of feeding the local "catfish" for good luck. Be advised you do sit VERY low and close to the water but it is truly a once in a lifetime experience.

cheap and fast way of exploring bangkok. for 5 baht, the ferry taxi ride was so cheap and yet it was fast and comfortable. my only issue was the other tourists squeezing their way to fit in the ferry so there could be a danger of over loading.

A Must-do experience in Bangkok.. To get to the river take the Sky Train to Saphan Taksin. It's just a short walk from there to the pier. There is a kiosk that deals with tourists. You buy a day-ticket and they give you a brochure which has a simplified map of the river.The boats are very frequent and you won't wait long. However be ready to board, as the do not wait for stragglers! Getting on and off is a bit wobbly, but the effort is worth it as the stops along the river give you access to some of the popular spots in Bangkok. I have used the river boats to visit the Emerald Buddha, the Royal Grand Palace, the flower market and Sampeng Lane (Soi Wanit) market in Chinatown. You can get to all these places by taxi, but I recommend the river. You get to see Bangkok from a different perspective and it is quite convenient and cheap!

river crossing. We used the river taxi from our hotel down to the main pier to catch the sky train.Most hotels on the river run these boats from the main pier so if you fancy a meal or a drink in one of the famous hotels the river is a great way of arriving.

Long boat tours are worth it. We took a long boat tour of the river and saw the faxcinating sites and sounds of river life in Bangkok, We ate at a restaurant on the river and sampled many of the tastes of the local cuisine.

Good Place even for a Package Tour. I took a package tour that when along the river and several canals. We were able to see many local Bangkok citizens going about their daily lives without interrupting them. I got to see a part of Bangkok removed from the llights of Sukhumvit. Very plesant day even with a rain shower half way through
allright. did not enjoy this much boats hard to get on and off and not the best place to be if it rains not much to see

great way to spend a few hours. Rain or shine - you haven't seen Bangkok until you see it from the river. Buy a tourist day pass (ridiculously cheap) at the numbered stops - it comes complete with map - that allows you to hop on and off at leisure. Get some advice about the best stops for you - some offer wonderful hotels for lunch, some offer markets or the grand palace or temples and more. There is always something happening on the river and you can make the experience fit your time & schedule.Ferries are comfortable and quite frequent (20 min). If you want a fast way home from any stop, hail a meter taxi and negotiate before you get in. We found 100 baht gets you almost anywhere (within 10 min drive) in Bangkok with the driver quite happy.
Excellent. every person should go for a diner cruise it's so so amazing & romantic and you should sit on the top it's better.

Life line of Bangkok. Took a canal ride...good exposure to living. Huge lizards seen. The river is beautiful at night and very relaxing to watch the different kind of vessels plying along it....a good mode of travel.Klong san market has good picks

Fun!. Take a ferry, especially if you are going to visit the Royal Place. There a re dinner cruises at night. The food isn't too good, but the monuments, temples and palaces are lighted and it's gorgeous!

a different way to see the city. If you hate being stuck in traffic and want to do some sightseeing of the city from a different perspective then try a ferry ride down the river . Alternatively a long tail boat can take you around the Klongs to see how some of the locals live .

Use the orange flag boat.. We had read lots of tips on trip advisor site so we knew to use the orange flag boat for only 15bt instead of the tourist boat which costs 40bt. We had downloaded the maps off the internet so we knew which stop to get off at. This is a good, cheap form of transport.

A trip on the river is not to be missed!. Take a public ferr for the real Thai experience, or hire a long-tailed boat and visit the Royal Barge Collection going up river on the Chao Praya, and back via the klongs. Magical.

much wider than the Pasig River of metro manila. 5 star hotels on both sides of the Chao Praya River with their own service boats. I wished I could have stayed at one of these 5 star properties but it's still too rich for my blood!

Not Bad!. If you take the Chayo Praya river cruise make sure you sit on the top deck of the boat as it is open air & has a better view of Bangkok by night & more like a cruise atmosphere than the deck below which is indoors/airconditioned & feels more like a city retaurant with picture windows overlooking the river.The buffet dinner provide on the the 2 hour round trip of the river is below average.The band does covers of national favourites of the various nationalities of tourists on the boat & rends out extremely cheesy versions of them.On the whole seeing the Chayo Praya river is a major tourist attraction in Bangkok & is a must see by day or by night,be it on a cruise or just walking beside checking out the many attractions.

Clean River. Zai actually went zere with my mum, grandma and a bunch of young and old alike in 2010. Ze river is very clean and zere is no floating debris on ze river. Zai am recommending zis river to anyone heading to Thailand.

Get out on it and enjoy!. We had a long boat to take us to a few sights, but really loved moving through the many canals of Bangkok in order to see how Thai people lived on these canals - we found it fascinating and quite beautiful at times. We were amazed by the HUGE monitor lizards - some were almost crocodile-like in size! THe baot trip was a lot of fun!

Vancouver, Kolkata, San Franciscos, Hong Kong. Complete your ferry friendly city tour.Get lost and enjoy the ferries that ply the routes with more or fewer stops. Can be confusing. I end up in the wrong place all the time. Very cheap, atmospheric but no devoid of stink. Better than the fast boats plying the khlongs (canals) though.

Get on a boat and see Bangkok from the river!. River bank life, culture, buildings, and river traffic...experience of a life time! A day pass costs approx 150Bht and allows you unlimited travel along the length and breadth of the river bus service route.

Easiest way to get to the tourist sites. My wife and I had the same sales pitch experience described. We walked to the public pier and took advantage of the Orange Flag for 15 baht per person. It was excellent transportation and would have cost more and taken longer by wheeled transportation. If you want to see the sites along the river, this is the way to do it. (The hotel maps and tourist map from the airport describe how to use the Express boats.)
An easier way to travel. The view is pretty. It also provides a convenient way to travel with less pollution and not so many people.

Long tail boat ride. Caught the boat at TAKIN SAKIN and went along river to Grand Palace about 1/2 hour ride, the ride itself was ok but the river is muddy with lots of debris for the boat to dodge, the view around the palace temple area was good but the rest was ordinary, it is a bit cooler travelling on the river.Worth doing but not exceptional.

Great!. This river cruise is a great way to view the city at night, meet other people and try some good and new food all in one place. I did this the night I arrived and loved it. The view of the city is amazing lit up.

Great way to see the city. river taxis are easy to come by...note the colored flag system and read about it ahead of time to get the most out of the taxi system. the skinny motor boats are also a great option for direct trips.

Take a longboat ride to see the canals. We spent an hour going up and down the canals which really gave a feel for those living in Bangkok. Some are nice, some decent and some very old. We could see the damage from the 2011 flood. We even caught a glimpse of a crocodile floating.

good way to view the sites!. Good way to get place to place and a lot can be seen from the boat however its a little hard to understand which boat to use they are done by flags and they dont give you much chance to ask before setting off its quite hard to figure out the fare also!

Worth to see from regular river tram.. Warning: there are many catchers for touristc boats esspecially at taksin Bridge Pier.
The other side of the river looks nicer and got more natural style than the "city".
Excellent. Great experience that you all should try, helpful staff and you purchase your ticket on board! Many stops to get off and on at your leisure.

Best way to get around Bangkok. In my opinion this and walking are the best way to get around Bangkok. The river is the ultimate express way and cooler and fresher than sitting stuck in traffic in a tuk tuk or hot sticky taxi.Just get on and when you hear the little steel clacking of the ticket ladies, give them your baht (have small change available) and they'll give you a ticket. Be quick..these are commuter ferries so no dallying, have your money ready and save the tourist questions for trip advisor.The buses were a bit difficult for me to figure out but the ferries seemed very straight forward. Simply get yourself a map, pay attention to the flag colour and the piers you want off at and you are on the fast track to exploring Bangers.Be mindful of the monks (do not touch) and as usual it is always common courtesy to give others your seat if it looks like they need it more than you.

Couldnt see much. If you are thinking this will be a good way to see the sights of the city, think again. You only pass one or two interesting sight and even then it is difficult to take photos. Much better to go directly to the places you want to see.

The nicest way to do a tour of Bangkok. We really enjoyed travelling on the ferryboats - a cheap and colourful way to see the sights of Bangkok and even the temples from a distance. Keep an eye on the coloured flags on the boats to make sure youre travelling in the right direction - we ended up deep in the suburbs of Bangkok at dusk when the boats stopped running and had to get a taxi back to our hotel! - but the taxi wasnt expensive so it wasnt a problem. Good value
Great 2 hour trip. Very cheap and the trip was great, excellant value for money.The river is extremely polluted and there are many signs of poverty. We enjoyed the experience
What a great way to get around the city. Catch the local river boat...its cheaper and convenient.I liked the regular service the local boat provides.

Overcrowded. I went on the rivercruise and found it to be overcrowded with buffet food that wasnt that great, especially for the price (1500 baht per person which the agent said was a special promotion) and the music wasnt very good. A live band would have been much better.

Scenic if it's a nice day. We went during rainy season, so it was clear skies on the way toward the Grand Palace but torrential downpour on the way back. Definitely got wet. The Chao Phrya Express tourist boat is 40 THB per person, we ended up paying 50 THB on the way back from one of the other piers, and ferry crossings from one side of the river to the other was 3 THB. Appears to be 2-3 different ferry companies which can explain the differences in fares, but it's not super clear what's what!

Terrible river. Buy a one day ticket for sightseeing is more convinient than other offers you may find at the BTS exit Taksi. River looks very durty and the ships are fool if you have to use the normal transport boats. Take onle the sightseeing boat. They are in service up to 5 pm

Great Way to get to most significant temples. The river ferries are like an extension of the rail network. You can easily join it from the Skytrain and get a cool ride to Wat Arun, Wat Pho etc. Like a Red Bull racing car it seems to fly.
Express boats. Take the express boats, up and down the river, cheap, fast, fun and you get to see a lot without the waste of time in a tuk tuk or taxi

Cheap trip and v interesting. Take an 'orange' boat which is the regualar commuter boat up the river for miles and miles for 15THB! fantastic value. Forget the tourist boats and join the monks and working people. Do it,
river cruise. the river cruise with queen cruises was a great experience. perfect way to get a feel for bangkok life and ordinariry bangkokians. highly recommended.

Worth to take a taxi trip. To fully experience Bangkok a trip on Chao is a must. Travel is cheep, views near the old twon at dawn, dusk really nice. It is not a beautiful city river with coasts etc. it is polluted (attached photo) but worth a trip.

Very busy. The river is very busy with lots of traffic but Sunset is gorgeous and the building around it were so beautiful. That the slow boat ride actually helped us with taking in the scenery and appreciate the beautiful buildings along the way.

Chao Phraya Cruise. well organise cruise with good buffet! Drinks onboard is reasonable with 2 cocktails for 38THB and free flow of soft drinks at 100 THB.
Relax and enjoy the view and food!
A must for Bangkok!

Nice view always at this historic river.... I'm often near this river as living in BKK, either restaurants or visit the bridges or boat cruises all feeling good nearby river at least you should find some activity to see it.

Easy access to some of Bangkok's attractions. Take the BTS Skytrain Silom line down to Saphan Taksin terminal and catch one of the Chao Praya River boats for easy access to some of Bangkok's major attractions. Skip the Tourist boats that cost 150 baht if you only want to see specific attractions like we did. We were told to take the Orange Flag or Yellow Flag boat (fare is only 15 baht) on our way to the Grand Palace at N9 Tha Chang Pier. You pay your fare aboard at the ticket lady who makes rounds. You'll be amazed how she remembers who has already paid.On our way back from the Grand Palace, we took the Orange Flag boat to N5 Ratchawong to visit Bangkok's Chinatown. After Chinatown, we took another boat to head back to Central Pier so we can catch the BTS Skytrain back to where we started.If you want to check out Pak Khlong Flower market, get off at N6 Memorial Bridge Pier. The famous Khao San Road, an area popular with backpackers, can be reached through the N13 Phra Athit pier.

Night view on the cruise is fantastic. There are many cruises offered Chao Phraya River dinner cruise in Bangkok. The price, food and show are different depending on the cruise. However, the night view of the river is memorable. I love it!

do what the locals do. there are a lot of boat/ferry that travel on the river and you can experience like the locals. We were boarding on the jetty near Wat Pho and all the way down to the terminal, then transit to Bts Skytrain and head back to the town. Safety vise, it was a bit dangerous if you did not hold on something as you travel because the boat are quite swaying.
Tour of River. Our tour in the longboat once we managed to board the boat was good we went through the canals and could see how Thai people live.

Easy to navigate ferry system.. I use the Ferry to get from the Mandarin Oriental to the temples and Grand Palace. It does take longer than a taxi but it is nice to go up the river. You are only paying $20 BHT so it is cheaper than the railway or the taxi. You also get to see how a lot of the locals travel and I like how each ferry terminal has its own group of food stalls.
Great river trips. Do take a trip down the river, the price is very reasonable and the boats are very accessible. A nice way to see Bangkok and stop at different destinations.

A great way to travel. The water is one of the best ways to travel in Bangkok to avoid those horrendous traffic jams. For very reasonable costs you can get to some of those major attractions, enjoy the breeze on the river, get some great photos and relax. If you have some time to kill, take a boat as far as it will go to see more local scenery. Remember, go to the public dock at the end of the transit line rather than getting "taken" for a private boat ride which will cost you $$.

Glad we did it. My wife & I decided to take an evening dinner cruise to experience BKK's sights lit up at night. The trip to the wharf was a one & a half hour nightmare taxi ride in horrendous traffic, only to stand on the wharf with hundreds of other tourists waiting to board the boats. When we finally got aboard and were sat at our table, the boat left the wharf quickly and we were under way. The MC announced that the buffet dinner was now open so most of the passengers rushed up to get their dinner. We sat to let the masses thin out a bit, ordered a bottle of white wine and enjoyed the very talented female singer perform some truly entertaining numbers backed by a very complimentary band. It seems we were the only Aussies on board as we were surrounded by groups from many different ethnic backgrounds. No problems, we were here to experience the world. Turns out we were also the only ones drinking alcohol, water in front of everyone as far as the eye could see. Oh well, each to their own. We finally ate and while the food was ok, it was nothing to rave about. Then we took our wine and sat outside by the railing and watched the Bangkok skyline float by. This was great. Eventually the singer also moved outside where there was a bit of deck space. She started doing traditional songs to suit the nationality of the passengers. They followed her out and began joining in with the singing and dancing, this was very enjoyable to watch. We noted that in many cases it was the men who got up to dance rather than the women. This was an eye opener. In Australia it would be all the women with only the gay guy & the drunk bloke daring to perform in front of strangers. So all in all it was a fun night and we're glad we took the time to do it.

RIver which passes major attractions. you can have a great experience by cruising in this river, not only tourist boats but also there are other passenger boats with colored flags which go from sapan takshin ferry to other side of Bangkok. we went in a passenger boat and felt the real bangkok as its filled with school children, working class people etc , its great local experiance and on the otherside you can go on a romantic cruise which passes through major attractions and its amazing to see bridges and temples in night.

River cruising. Taking a trip up and down the Chao Phraya River is a MUST. There is NO need to spend too much travelling on a tourist boat. I suggest that you go by Sky Train to Taksin Bridge. Then board a standard Public River Bus Boat going UPRIVER as far as it goes (Approx 45 minutes). Get off, wander around then take the same type of Public Service boat back downriver and get off wherever it suits you. This costs pennys/cents rather than pound/dollars that a designated tourist boat tour costs.Have fun
River and the Cruise. This river is excellent with both the sides having skyscrappers and temples. We went for a river cruise which passed under 8 bridges along its way.
River boats up and down. A map of the river attractions is a must. Don't go to the Royal Barges by way of their directions. You can get a feel for the City with the many stopovers along the river.

A bit dirty. Not a particularly enjoyable ride as dirty water was splashing onto the boat, and I mean seriously disgusting sewage water. If you are going take a boat tour on the river, make sure you go in a nice big boat with no open sides, we went on a small boat and regretted it.

Cheap river boat ride. There is no better value than a ride down this river about 5p to travel as far as you want see the Wats on the way squeeze up against locals and tourists just doing what they do see extreme poverty and extreme wealth sat side by side but most of all see it all for a few pence and enjoy the river of life.

Absolutey loved the boats. Definitely one of the best things in the city. You can get a day pass - a bit like the hop on hop off buses in other cites - which takes you to all the older parts of the city. Excellent value!
not clean. I seen Sewerage open on riverand the river color not beautiful and Unpleasant odors from the river When you go to sit next to the river you can't because very hot area

Shangrila Cruise is the best !!. Slightly expensive..but very private..Small Cruise boat with a 5 star menu buffet...All the sea food you can eat and more !! Ambience is lovely..The river by night is beautiful..You can see all Bkk attractions fully lit up. Service is impeccable . Choose an open air table..Candle lit dinner is extremely romantic. Soft music..Sophisticated crowd and fewer tables make it a very private affair..Starts from the private pier of Shangrila Hotel..lasts about 2 hrs. value for money !!

Interesting. I still can not believe that a one hour one way trip on a 100 seat boat costs only 15baht, compared to the cost of on road tuk tuks, taxis and trains. Run down and new places on the banks of the river an interesting contrast. Only problem, the ferry staff at the jetty who sound impolite and understand very little English. Worth a trip.

What floating market?. We were supposed to experience the floating market on this river.All we got was 2 boats selling local handicraft.According to the tour guide, the floating market was essentially dead. We were told to buy from these 2 boats so as to ensure the survival of the 'market'!

Heart of Bangkok. The Chao Phraya river winds its way thru Bangkok and neatly divides the city into various segments. More than that the river is also the lifeline of the city providing not only its needs but also very important for cargo movement.My Hotel (montien riverside) was on the river and what an amazing sight from the room. I also took a half day cruise which was fantastic to say the least. The Rama bridges connecting the city on this river are also engineering marvels especially the new one. Wat Arun temple of Dawn is on this river and not to be missed.

Travel using the local ferries. Be prepared to use the Chao Phraya ferry and travel up to Nonthaburri - the fare is next to nothing (I think it was 12 baht). Once you are in Nonthaburri (about an hour depending if you get the ferry that stops at every jetty, or the Express service that misses quite a few jetties) walk along the main road from the ferry terminal to the Nonthaburri local markets which are well worth visiting if you like to get familiar with the local produce. In season the different fruits are worth trying - durian, mangosteen, salac, rambutans, lychees and longans (my favourite).The people at the market are friendly and will engage with tourists who are interested in asking about their produce. The meat and fish market area is not for those with weak stomachs but is still just as interesting as the rest of the markets.

Must do. Anybody visiting Bangkok who is not exploring the famous river is missing out on one of a great experience. Just hop on the public water bus and go. You can alight at any station, have a look around, and take the next boat. A good place to go to is Thonbury for it's bustling market and fine street food. See life as it really is for a few dollars before retreating to the peace of your hotel and a good foot massage

Excellent cheap and easy service.. To get around Bangkok, especially the temples etc this mode of transport is far the best and cheapest. It is simple to use and frequent. An excellent service. You do get to see some fascinating sights of Bangkok also.

Great views of the city. You don't need to travel on one of the expensive dinner cruise boats to see great views of Bangkok.
Just catch one of the cheap water taxis & watch the sites go by. Especially beautiful at dusk & night!

Express Boat Great Way to Get to Temples. This boat as well as many others connect at a central pier. You can catch a Skytrain to get to the pier, and travelling by boat is even faster than getting a tax, and travelling by boat is the best way to get to some of Wat Pho, the Emerald Buddah, and other popular place for tourist to visit.
Many sights of Bangkok. Many sights and attractions of Bangkok are viewable and easy accesible by Chao Praya river. Also very busy on water.
Dinner curies. The golden night seen of the temples was amazing. you can see how those beautiful temples at night in a ship in Chao Phraya river. An excellent experience.

a quiet romantic dinner cruise. I have taken the dinner cruise on the river a couple of times, with different sets of friends and it was a good experience. the food onboard is good and the entertainment was ok. it usually takes about 2 hours which is just enough for you to relax
A Waste Of Money. This is definitely a waste of money and time. Not something I would recommend to do in Bangkok. Boring yet you risk having dirty water splashing right on your face.

life around the river. Truly one of the best places to spend the evening in bangkok. start near wat arun and go towards shangri la hotel bangkok. on the way you see the majestic hotels and lovely wind blowing.i would recommend the local boat service to get an authentic feel of the life in bangkok.

must do, with the public transport. I have been commuting to work on the Chao Praya extress boats for years... and every day was worth it. This is a must do in BKK, to see some real life on the water. Take any of the orange or yellow flag boats and run a 20 minutes up(or down) stream, than go back. Just observe the life passing by. VERY crowded in the morning before 8 30 am., and get some change.

Take local boat. if you want to experience mix with local,take this local boat.I love when the lady come to collect some money and give you the ticket, as she really experience and can remember who paid and who is new comer in her boat

Scary!. We took the boat up to the Grand Palace and the river was Attis worse as it was raining. Not too clean, and scary during the rain. Maybe a good experience to see the lights on the temples at night or even a dinner cruise.
Hire a long tail boat.... 1000 baht for your own private long tail boat for 1 hour, well worth the money. We decided to take a trip down the old canals and see the older houses on the water.

Fun. Bangkok is vibrant and full of life. Take the boat to a destination or simply for fun. You can get another view of this marvelous city.
Easy to navigate and quite inexpensive.

Noisy. We love to take the ferry to China town.Take the sky train to Taksin pier,for a little while,this is being rejigged,only thb12 each way and such good fun seeing all the 'River Life'.Do not try to talk too noisy,very interesting

... for men may come and men may go, but I go on forever.... They say, the best things in life are free... True for The River indeed ! The city began around the river. Today, some of the historic sights (Wat Arun and parts of the city fortress from centuries past) and some of the most famous hotels in the city (Millenium Hilton, The Mandarin Oriental, et al) line the river along its course..You may want to take a boat ride along the river , which is a good idea. You have two options here:1) Private owned boats costing as much as 200THB/ Foreign national for a trip from the new city side of the river to Wat Arun and back, or2) Public Taxi boat service, that cost between 5THB to 15T

Vein of Bangkok. The river is the vein of Bangkok. It do has very good scene when you come in part of the old town. But don't expect too much for the rest. There is some pollution but not much compared with the Klong.

Great way to get from pier to pier. Although we would have saved a bit of money paying by pier instead of the day pass, this was a great way to learn a little bit about each stop and take pictures. After touring, the boat provided a nice refreshing breeze before embarking at the next attraction.
Crowded, hectic and a lot of fun. Great way to beat the Bangkok heat is to take public boats along the river. Suggest going to the smaller wats which are not crowded and very interesting.

Canal River Boat Cruise. My husband and I took the cigar boat cruise and loved it. You can rent your own boat and driver for 1 1/2 to 2 hours for 600 baht/hour. We took the 2 hour cruise and we were offered several choices of destinations. We picked an orchid farm (fabulous), the floating market, and the Royal Barge Museum. We love flowers and spent the majority of our time there, and it was well worth the trip. The smaller boat allows you to go into areas off the Chao Phraya River that the larger boats are unable to navigate, thus giving you and up close and more personal look at life on the river. It was an interesting opportunity, with a good slice of the variety of people living and working; and the variety of homes, etc. on the river. The photo opps were great!! We only cruised through the floating market and past the Royal Barge Museum since we stayed so long at the orchid farm. All in all the trip is great, our guide could not speak English, but in our view this was purely a visual journey, and so that was just fine. Absolutely fabulous and definitely a repeater for us.

Chao Phraya. I was on a cruise on the ship. We had dinner, we danced almost half of the night. It was fun. Though all the facilities were good but there was a group which misbehaved with dancers, so stay alert.

Chaophraya boats. The river has frequent transfer boats and water taxis between hotels and some sky train stations. There are also floating restaurants which look quite nice. You avoid all traffic and is a bit of calm in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Bangkok.

A pleasant outing.. Took a longboat to myself and saw the river and klongs. Interesting to see how people live on the watersedge, such a variety of homes. Most are fairly run down yet have cable tv in some of them, while there are some really lavish homes. You get a good view of the Palace and some of the flashier hotels. I paid 1000 Baht for 90 minutes. Well worth it. Saw some of it again coming back by boat from Ayathaya.

Great way to experience Bangkok. We spent a good deal of time on various activities on the Chao Phraya River, including a dinner cruise and using the Chao Phraya Express river taxis.This is certainly one of the great rivers and is a good and relaxing way – not to forget cool and refreshing – of visiting the various sights in Bangkok which are situated along the river. The views from the river are fantastic and are great for photography, especially at night when everything is lit up, e.g. the Temple of the Dawn and Grand Palace. But the highlight is the insight into the day to day living along the river, with houses built almost on the river and people going about their daily lives. The river fire station with fire engine boats was interesting – not something you see often.There are a lot of boats and other watercraft on the river from small long tail boats to enormous barges to large diner cruise boats.The river is relatively clean for such a large river used as a main thoroughfare through the city – we saw relatively little garbage floating and did see a lot of fish in the river.The Chao Phraya River is at the heart of Bangkok and no visit to Bangkok would be complete without spending some time on the river and it’s a great relaxing way to get around.

What an amazing boat cruise!. Arriving at River City we were very friendly greeted by traditionally dressed Thai girls who assisted us and directed us to our boat. We received little wreathed of orchards which was a very nice gesture as their flowers are so beautiful. Once we boarded our boat, we were directed to our table in the front of the deck of the boat very close to the band and kareoke singer which was awsome. We cruised on the river for 2 hrs and a tour guide referred us to the different temples and the Royal palace. Listening to the mellow tunes of the band while have our buffet meal was great. Food was really define and was a variety of dishes from starters,mains to dessert and coffee. What a phenomenal atmosphere when everyone started dancing after dinner, a really enjoyable evening spent with my hubby, memorable!

Always something new to see. Whether you travel the Chao Phraya everyday to commute, or are a first-time visitor to Bangkok, there's always something unexpected, pleasureable and/or fascinating to see on the river. The best and cheapest way to see Bangkok and river life is riding one of the many public river taxis. For one of the most enjoyable ways to experience the Chao Phraya, hop on any of the public express boats and head as far up or down the river as you care to go, then jump off and catch the return trip back, perhaps after enjoying a lunch or dinner at a river-side restaurant or food stall (virtually every boat landing has a good selection of local restaurants and dining/drinking choices, usually at a fraction of the cost of restaurants near the tourist centers).

Take a boat trip. The Chao Phraya river provides a way to see Bangkok from a different perspective. It's well worth taking a river cruise up and down to see the city from downtown to the outskirts. By some of the temples you can feed huge fish that come up to the surface when the boat arrives. And at night you can see trees full of fire-flies. These trips usually involve lunch or dinner and are definitely worth the experience.

Boat rides - Nice!!!. The boat rides for the tourists are very nice. I suggest that you buy a day pass as you can visit many places and you can get on and off as you please. The prices are reasonable and you get to explore many sites. just remember the colour of the flag of your boat company,

A romantic way to get to some of the city's attractions. If I had my choice to take a bus or the river ferry ,,IDE take the river ferry ,,it's quicker and ,,it gives one a chance to see the city and life along the river ,,,at night it takes on a romantic feel and there are many floating restaurants ,,that make a nice evening venue ,,you can catch one at the river city ,,shopping center ,,during the day ,,long tail boats can take you to fresh fruit markets and Simple life lifestyles of those that make thier home by the waters edge can be seen ,,very charming and interesting by the way of narrow waterways ,great for photographers ,,these long tail boats ,can be boarded the pier right next to the oriental pier ,,,and from the skytrain river stop you can board the tourist ferry or local Thai ferry ,,,single trip ,,or unlimited full day tickets can be purchased ,,,a nice way to spend a day but don't expect to see all the attractions in one day ,,,and the ,,service stops for the day around 7 pm ,,,

Best Mode of Transport and beautiful attraction. We not only used Chao Phraya river for tour, but it was the main mode of our transport while in bangkok. Cheapest and best way to move around to tourists places(historical places especially) without any traffic congestion. Well connected and best of all is damn cheap one way is just 15 TBH. Tickets has to be taken inside the boat usually except in N13 Pier (Barge) where I was forced to take the ticket from the pier itself. dunno why. Our hotel was just next to the Chao Phraya river and we got quite used to the boat way. I have explored most of the Pier in our rout N1....N13. Also there are some arranged tours across the river and inside. Chao Phraya museum is also good.

Great way to see Bangkok in a few hours.. Get a Pre arrange Tour. It's a bit more money but you will be taken to all the things to see and given a great lunch in the price. You will not be taken to all the boatmans family and friends shops so he gets commission. Also the tours pick you up from your hotel and you save on the taxi, train, or tuk tuk costs. We got ours £18 for the two of us and it was a really good tour. The tours don't stop at any of the sights so you can wear hat you want. If the day is windy be prepaid to get sprayed a little when on the main river. If you want the James Bond trip. Take sky train to Main Pier, go early as it gets busy. There you can bargain for a fast boat which will speed you around the main river and side waters. If you take this option you need to be pretty quick at taking photos. Exciting but not a tour for sightseeing, everything passes in a blur.

A river as busy as the streets. You can get a day ticket (150 bht)for the Express Boat. But we took single tickets : to Grand Palace uand Wat Pra Kaeo and back to get tthe ferry to Wat Arun. That was even cheaper. A great adventure to be on this busy river amidst longboats, luxury hotel shuttleboats etc. Interesting views.But if you've enough time you should also do a river-canal-tour to discover a diferent Bangkok!

Take a smaller, long-tailed boat if you can. The long-tailed boats give you a more intimate experience than the bigger boats. When we went, the boat took us to a couple wats and a lock, both of which were awesome. However, we also went through some slums, which was a very eye-opening experience. Great way to see Bangkok!
River Ferry. Great way to get about Bangkok. Efficient and affordable. Would recommend the cheaper orange flagged boats

Great river best way to see BK. This is by far the best way to avoid pollution hideous rip off taxi drivers and see many of the great sights Palce Wats Great hotel and dining expeiences Chinatown, Antique stores ( get off at the Sheraton hotel stop and turn Right ,Flower Markets, Teak house, Palaces and general people watching.
Great way to see Bangkok. Jump on anyone of the local ferries, sit back and enjoy the cooling breeze and great views of Bangkok.
River Transport. The best way to get around the Chao Phraya River is to buy the day pass on the orange boats. They come along every 15mins and were not expensive for a day pass.

Take a Long Boat along the Thonburi Klon. You can get to most sites from the river, green ferry slow, orange med and red ferry fast. The best trip is a long boat trip along the Thonburi Klon(canal) 1-2-3hr trips. Tour comanies charge around 1200baht each but if you find your own long boat you can get a hole boat to yourself. for a 2 hr trip which is enough. I found one at the Si-Phraya Peir (near the Sheridon Hotel) once you have been through the canal get the long boat driver to let you of at Wat Arun. A 30 baht ferry back across the river when finished there. The canals have all the private housing along the river which is very interesting. Bangkok of old.

interesting. worth going on a boat cruise to see & learn the history of BKK, they still use this river today as a main transport highway, when you see the size of the barges carrying trade products & getting it from one end to the other without any fuss & no big trucks on the road it makes you think
Great half hour. So different, so diverse, rich and poor living together... kids loved it also. The long tail boats ar fast. e then visited the wholesalers flower market. Superb! Not many tourists...
Good ambience. Good ambience on cruise. Dinner served was good, perhaps more variety would be good. Food are replenished at a fast speed. The night scenery was ok. (Chao Phraya Princess Cruise)

bof. crowdy,polluted, nothing's fancy. it is ok because the air is fresher
We took the chao Phraya express so maybe there is another way to appreciate it...

Reviewing a river??. I am surprised to see the Chao Praya river as an attraction to review... What can you say about a river? We took several boat tours on it over the years, and you have a great view of the city. Furher outside Bangkok it gets more boring, and otherwise there is really not much to say about the river... Other than people wash their clothes in it, bathe, fish river prawns, and seem to pollute it as much as they can...

A great way to get around and see the backside of Bangkok.. All the reviews are spot on, this is a great way to get around. All I will add is that the system is kind of confusing. No signs were in English and there was no one to show us how it was done. We had an idea of the direction we wanted, so it was a matter of looking at the map, seeing the color of the line we wanted to catch, and then waiting for the boat to come baring the color flag we were looking for. Once we figured that out, it was really enjoyable. For the older crowd, getting on and off is a quick process, with a moving boat, so be careful. It's not like in the Western world where safety comes first, this is about getting on and off, quickly.

Travelling up the river. We travelled by the ferry services that run up and down the river. We pre purchased our tickets from the hotel which covered us all day, there are all day tickets available and fares can be paid for on the ferry.
