Don't miss it. One of the joys of Bangkok is riding up and down the river on the various ferries. Very cheap and always interesting and much more relaxing than the roads or even the Skytrain or MRT. Use it to get around North and South. Connects with the SkyTrain at Sathorn Pier. Some ferries are essentially guided tours, with audio commentaries, and run a bit slower. Note the flag system that tells you which ferries stop at which piers (ferry maps are readily available on many free BKK maps.) Ferries are sometimes crowded, but the conductor will still find out who got on and check your ticket or sell you one. Wherever you get off will be interesting ...

The river itself is gross, and the dinner cruises....so-so.. I think that the only reason to go down to the river is to take a dinner cruise. For most tourists, who will not know where to go to book, you should make reservations though your hotel concierge. You may end up paying a bit more, but this is one of those signature Bangkok activities that you have to do in order to say that you "did Bangkok." If you do not have a hotel concierge, go to one of the big hotels on the river, and book through them. Yes, it will be expensive, but it will also be legit, and you will not get ripped off.Be forewarned that once the dinner cruise is over, however, you will realize that it was not that big of a deal. I recommend getting Thai food. It will be better than any other cuisine. I advise sitting outside, on the top deck. You will want the breeze. If you are below, in air conditioning, you will be subjected to unpleasant kitchen smells and the music, I guarantee it, will be too loud. I do not understand why the Thai love to assault your eardrums with loud music, but they do. The room will be too crowded. The bathrooms are horrid. You may not be able to continue to eat if you have to use them. They stink, and they are basically holes that drop down directly into the river. So much for concepts of river ecology. You will see some "enchanting" Wats and other cultural attractions appropriately lit up for your enjoyment as you pass by. You will pass beneath a bridge that spans the river, and you will be very close to it, which will be exciting for a moment. That is pretty much all that happens on a dinner cruise. The music, every time that I went, was execrable. Too loud, and plain not good. For a river cruise on the Chao Phraya to be enjoyable, in my opinion, you need to like the people with whom you dine. If you have good dinner company, you will not care about the somewhat cheesy quality of the excursion. Indeed, it can furnish much fodder for conversation. Do not mock it too loudly within earshot of any Thai people. They are extremely nationalistic and proud of their country, and they can get irrational if you point out shortcomings in a way that they interpret as an assault on themselves or on their society. Never forget that they have a concept of "face" that most Westerners will not understand. In fact, I advise that you google and research the concept before visiting Thailand. It will help you avoid brutal faux pas. Now that I think about it in retrospect, the coolest part of the two dinner cruises that my wife and I have been on was sitting for the couple's photograph. They laminate the photo onto a plate, which you can then hang on your wall. It makes a nice memento. Especially as we get older. I would absolutely avoid the river during daylight. It is an impenetrable disgusting brown, it looks like slowly moving mud water, and you will shudder when you see children jumping and frolicking in it. I do not even want to think about the liver flukes that certainly afflict them. The river often smells. Almost always. It is not picturesque, unless you are deluded. If you are going to a floating market or taking a water taxi, so be it, but my advice is to avoid the river during the day. Further, stay away from the tourist markets. They are overpriced, and you come into contact with the worst people in Thailand, which are those who make a living cheating and overcharging tourists. Do not waste your time or your money. If you want to shop, go to the Chatuchak Weekend Market, and learn how to dicker before you go. Do not waste time going anywhere else. Or, talk to a local Thai who can guide you to markets used by the denizens and who can help you negotiate prices. Too many Thai think that they are entitled to quote a "farang price." I never accept this. I do not mind paying very well for exceptional service. In other words, I reward excellence. I never reward larceny. Nor should you. Never forget that if you encounter a larcenous Thai, that you can and you should simply walk away. Do not say a word. Keep your face expressionless. Just look the thief in the face, blink two or three times, perhaps permit a shadow of pity to come into your eyes, and then walk away. They will not care. Other tourists are right behind you. Stupid tourists. Tourists who will pay absurd prices that are jacked up far beyond the norm. I understand that there is great poverty in Thailand. I would like to gently point out that the people who are ripping you off at various market venues are not among them. They are not poor. They do very well. If you go to real markets, real street markets, in real neighborhoods, or if you go to the Chatuchak Market, you will see that there is no need to subsidize rip-off artists. Those people will quote you un-inflated prices, and they will negotiate in good faith. It is better to purchase goods and services from honest people in Thailand. If you go to the right places, you will find that you are surrounded by them, and they will disarm you with their innate goodness and with their generosity. They are beautiful. If you stick to the tourist areas, you will be systematically abused. The choice is yours!Hope that this helps. Enjoy.
Nice, but cheesy. The river cruises that run the Chao Phraya are a bit like Vegas with a Tinglish accent. Food sucks and the music is loud and campy, but the views are really nice.

Cruise the Chao Phraya. We did a night cruise along the Chao Phraya river and it was amazing! Highly recommend it, although the dinners can get noisy with the entertainers. Dinners are buffet too. We had the opportunity to eat out on the deck so enjoyed great views and quieter dining. Perfect for what we wanted! Great photo opportunity, but you may need a steady hand and ability to quickly take photos!

River boat. We wanted to go on the river,but we were harassed by one woman who followed down the street so we didn't bother.We went to the night market which was very interesting.There is a lot of poverty in Bangkok.
Lovely at night. Went here on a river cruise really enjoyed ourselves
Very fun and classic boat ride.. How can you go to Bangkok as a tourist and not take a boat taxi?! Best way to get around much of the city and there's actually a breeze. Great sightseeing also.

Taxi with the locals. We were recommended this by another Trip Advisor member and for 14B travelled up the river to Nonthaburi. Great little markets and much cheaper than the longboats, and just as interesting. A fun, inexpensive day out and we found some great bargains!

Ship ahoy.. I love this river, it has more of a vibrancy than any other river I have seen, incidentally I live on the River Thames. I was in an apartment overlooking the river which never seem to go to sleep.We travelled up and down the river by taxi and it would seem that anything you would wish to see in Bangkok has been put on the river's edge for your gratification, magnifique.It is, to me, the main artery of the city and many other cities could learn well how to use their rivers by coming to Bangkok and observing. I will be back!

Nice ambience but the food total letdown.. We booked the cruise through a booking agent and got the upper deck.The cruise was really lovely and the ambience they created was very good.The candle light dinner the live band with singer was a complete wow.But the food was not upto the mark..though the upper deck had International Cuisine but the lower deck was having Indian dinner,but both the sections were not delicious,perhaps leaving two or three dishes all were complete let down.The Ride was enjoyable as U can enjoy the Bangkok beauty and along with it the live music with Dance.Overall OK OK.

Everything great about Bangkok. A trip on this mighty river, know as " the River of Kings", will allow you to see all that Bangkok stands for. From the Famous Oriental hotel, and a host of other Luxury Hotels to The majestic Temples Like Wat Arun,Take a normal ferry service ride with the locals, and see how the Thai's live. You can also hire a fast long boat to take you up the many canals that lead off the river.Bangkok was once know as the " Venice of the East" due to the canal system that ran through the City. Unfortunately most of these canans have been filled in to make way for progress.The few that are still left are worth the effort to visit. you will see children swimming in these canals, and all manner of boats selling goods or just moving goods from one place to the next.A truly " Bangkok Experience"
Make sure you take a guided tour. Make sure you take a guided tour up the river and into the canals.

use the tourist boat - english guide included. we used the tourist boat and bought a day ticket - 150 baht i think - this was well spent money...got a good palm size guide, english speaking tour guide on the boat and we hopped on and off all day - brilliant. went to the flower market (approached by scammer while walking there - just remember the flower market is NOT CLOSED and you dont need to take his taxi to see a 'special ceremony at the palace' ok)...so once we politely declined his offer and he walked off in disgust we found the fabulous flower market - great for any avid flower lover and gardener.went to some other markets - good opportunity to get a drink etc and look around - all in all a great day ....travelled up one way looking at it from one side of the boat then on the return sat on the other side and got a great view again....
Take a ride on a river boat cruise. Plan a few hours and see the backside of the river and how the people live. It is extremely interesting.
Express Boat. Definitely a must if you visit Bangkok. Take the Chao Phraya Express boat, which passes all the major temple attractions. Only 30 baht.

Get a new view of Bangkok- take the commuter ferry. We always travel in Bangkok by taxi, but it's even more fun to take the commuter boat up and down the Chao Phraya River. For something like 30 baht we were able to ride almost the whole length from north Bangkok to near the mouth of the river. Not your typical tourist destination but an authentic way that Bangkok people travel. For that reason we enjoyed it very much.

Best means of transport Bangkok has to offer. When I saw pictures of Chao Phraya I always thought of the "muddy old river" in this old song by Murray Head. But it's not like this at all. Fortunately, our hotel was right by the river and whenever no taxi was available or the Tuk Tuk drivers wanted to pull their infamous scams a boat tour was the best alternative: offering nice views of the city and a breath of fresh air.
Chao Phraya River. Crossed this or went up/down this a lot on my visit. Different types of boats. Big and wide, and great way to get a feel for greater Bangkok.

Best Transport to the Gand Palace. Taxi drivers refused to take me to Grand Palace, my guess is the traffic. So take a train to Samphan Taksin Station, and pay THB30 only to see the riverside view. Not fantastic but interesting. You will be able to see some beautiful buildings along the cruise.
just sit & chill. this is such a busy river, looks like chaos but works like clockwork
Don't miss it. One of the wonders of the modern world. Second only to the Mekong for boating, sightseeing, and capturing a way of life you don't see anywhere else.
Easy to use. The ferry is easy to use, just look at the colour of the flags, the staff speak english and it cost about £3 for an all day pass - a real bargain
Stay on the river!. The river is a hive of activity day and night, get a room with a river view and you will be entertained day and night.

Great relaxing way to see Bangkok river life. A trip along the Chao Phraya is a must when visitng Bangkok. Catch an orange flag express boat from Sathorn Pier to Nonthaburi, have a browse around, lunch on the waterfront and the express boat back. At 15B each way, a cheap and relaxing way to see the life and views of the river.
Fantastic Dinner Cruise. We took an evening dinner cruise on the river. The food was excellent, and the entertainment (music & dancing) was very good.
River of Life in the City of Angels. There is so much going on with this river. Jump in a Longtail boat at Sunset, watch the city light up and come alive. This is a must do in BKK

Private long tail boat ride. Excellent trip across the river and around the smaller klongs really gave a good idea of how people live, rich and poor all pushed up against each other in this huge city. A private boat makes sense if you have enough people to share the cost and/or you just want a bit more time and control.

This is a MUST in Bangkok. We take the Chao Phraya boat at least once every time we come to Bangkok. You can use it as a transportation to go to all the WATs/Temples, but just ride it "just because" is fun as well (and it's so cheap!)... You'll see amazing views that you can not see from anywhere else. Don't miss this!!!

water taxi and dinner cruise. You can see the Chao Phraya River from many of the room in the Lebua Hotel and the Sheraton Hotel. This water way hosts numerous water taxis and dinner cruises. I recommend taking an early dinner cruise that starts in daylight and ends in the night. The transformation from day to seeing the city light up is lovely. My guests enjoy the dinner cruises a lot. Food not the best but the cruise is relaxing and enjoyable,
Definitely worth a ride from beginning to end. A great way to see Bangkok. Just hop on, go to one end and back again. You can do the tourist boat or the local (cheaper). Day passes are available too.
Chilling time. We take a boat for this river trip. It's so great as we can see many temples and many places and many life's that depend on the river. Love love

We did a river tour and it was great.. We combined a trip out the Chao Phraya River with a visit to the Klongs and we loved it in a long tail boat. The kids thought it was especially great when we went really fast. From the river you can see the city in a totally different way, I would recommend this trip to anyone. You can get a boat trip from the banks of the river - ask at your hotel.
really nice. We took a cruise over the river - great experience and good for the first night in Bangkok as shows you all attractions alongside
a nice change. We caught the train to the river and got on one of the hop on hop off boats the cool breeze is a real relief
Forget the tourist boat and go with the locals. There is no point in paying 150 Bhat for a tourist day pass when a typical trip On the scheduled service costs 15 bhat
Great Ride. Grab a bite to eat from the street vendor and spend a couple hours riding the river! Amazing experience for less than a dollar!
All aboard. What a great day, see what you want to see or just stay on the boat
Very dirty and not scenic at all. It's big, it stinks and it's only good to commute between various Wats along its banks. Single boat ticket is 30 Baht.
very good river cruise princess- 3. very good romantic 1 hr dinner cruise. food was just excellent. if u cant afford star cruises day night trip package this one is really enjoyable.

The life of Bangkok. You could watch the activities on the river all day, but take a long boat and experience the klongs and see people going about their everyday lives living on the waters edge. Interesting now with the locks in place so that water levels can be controlled to protect people's homes from flooding
Local commuter boats are cheap, while tourist boats are a lot dearer. Jump on any boat going in any direction and find out where it takes you after you get on. Fun!

A Large Muddy River Runs Through It. The Chao Phraya River runs through Bangkok and has been the source of recent flooding, contributing to the garbage problem in the city. The River is plied by long-tailed sampan, which ferry people up and down the river to various stops. It remains an active method of transportation for a large portion of the population with stops in such areas as the King's Palace. An adventure in Asian travel awaits you.
Kids loved it. They try there atmost best to please you and achieve it

Great but take care. Think we got didlled paying 2500B for a 2 hour trip - was hoping for a longtail but ended up on a pu-put that took forever to get up to the floating market. Insist on a real longtail.
Great way to travel and see the city but.... No one speaks any English and we spent about 40 minutes trying to find the right boat to take us down river to China Town.

local way of travelling. bangkok has busy streets. locals take river taxi. this is a different way of travelling. a must to do if your iternary includes the the grand palace and wat arun. it is cheap. any taxi ride does not cost more then 45 baths. so dont get cheated to it. youpay in the boat. we took yellow flag boats. cost 15 bath. blue flag boats cost 30 bath. cross river boat 3 bath. its rush hour in the morning and evening on weekdays.

Best top ten in Bangkok. I asked my wife and son which is the top on the list for best of Bangkok? It is the Grande Phraya River Dinner Cruise! Great food, entertainment, and yes dancing! Beats the other boring cruises you will see in the river.

Exciting. This is a different way to travel in Bangkok and again very inexpensive. If you're staying in a riverside hotel the boats take you to the pontoon for the Grand Palace. Wat Po and Emerald Buddah temples.
long tail boat ride through the channels. on the trail of Mr Bond, James Bond.will cost about 1000Baht, but is worth the investment, look for Warans at the bank of the rivers

Worth doing it. A very good way to travel along the river, even if a little over crowded. Perhaps a little more official assistance upon purchasing appropriate tickets. Even if you miss the boat, another soon comes along.
Closed to CP river. 10 min walking to pier of CP river, very easy to getting through short pavement. Sunset Nice View for photoshooting

Great spot for a longtail boat tour. A tour on the river in one of the smaller longtail boats is a great way to get a feel for the city's vibe and to see the sights. The smaller boats are the way to go as you can get into the smaller canals to see how the locals live.
Great river to explore. One could watch the river traffic all day!!!. We took the hotel boat to the terminal, and then paid on another boat to see the sights.
One of the best things you can do in Bangkok. This is the best chance to see a lot of Bangkok in one hour. Just take the taxi-boat to Train-station Taksin. Quick, beautiful, cheap and local.
It's dirty but I love it all the same. Get a cheap water taxi and take in the sounds and sights of Bangkok - awesome

Nice Cruise Make Sure you Get the Top Deck!. I went for the night cruise on the Chao Phraya River which was quite beautiful and fun! Make sure however that you get the top deck as the view from the bottom is not quite the same. If you do get a lower deck talk to the hostess and she will get you one on top if its available. the food is so so but the sights are quite beautiful especially the temple of the dawn.

Wide brown, sometimes green river. Road traffic is so bad in BKK so travelling on the skybus, underground and by boat is your best option. If you must travel on the road, the tuk tuk goes like crazy weaving in and out of the traffic. You can also have motorbike taxis!! Dangerous though. Ask taxi driver to put the meter on and watch they don't drive so slow and all about Thailand to jack up the meter!! Waiting for the boat is the worst - hot and still under shade and even hotter and boiling under sun. When boat takes off, the wind is welcoming. There's stops along the way (water taxi), The first or last stop is Taksin where the skytrain meets. River is not inviting - dirty looking. Not much of a scenic river cruise if that's what you are wondering, but "interesting" and definitely an option mode of transport instead of road which is trying - took us 4 hours to get 20-25km from Watpo to Sukhumvit by taxi!!! 3.30pm from Wat Po and 7.30pm to Sukhumvit. Don't go when there's some sort of holiday - it's just chaos.
The life of Bangkok!. Live in this bustling city revolves around the C hai Phraya river. Don't miss a boat tour through the canals and a visit to the Royal Barge museum.

Wat arun,I fall in love with you.... When I looked over our pictures with a very high temple as our background....I'm so speachless how God gave a good talent to the people whose doing it,how they can climb over to the highest level of that temple.And when I showed our pictures to our daughter,which is couldn't come with us because she just started to work so couldn't take any day off yet make us promised her to go back there again next year and I'm so happy too....even my mother in law she dont mind to go one more time and see that temple also shopping more @the market over there....And it's not only that,the boat trip also,we enjoyed it.....Finally,...Wat Arun we'll be back to see you again soon....

Life on the river. Worth doing a river cruise to get a good idea of the scale and level of activity on the river. The further you go, the more you see how people live on the river and its very interesting. Some still bathe in the river, but it does look very dirty. You can see the damage caused by last year's floods which is sad. Worth a few hours exploring.

Great boating experience. The boat taxi up the river to the Grand Palace is a wonderful journey going past temples and dwellings that back right into the river. There is so much going on it is a job to know what to look at first. The boat is directed into the various jetties by a conductor on the boat who uses a series of whistles to ensure that the boat is in the right place for loading and unloading.When you arrive at the jetty for The Grand Palace, you will be accosted by thieves and vagabonds, also known as TUK TUK Drivers. They will lie to you. The story they give will be that the Palace is closed for ************ but will be open later. Let me take you to some place nice. my friends, don't believe them, and go and enjoy the wonderful sights.
Boat trip. Boat trip on the river is available by regular boat, The price is very low (less than 1$)
Typical Asian scene. It is worth taking a bite to eat beside the river somewhere and watching life go by. We always take our visitors here and eat at the cafe at the boat stop at Wat Pho

Take the Express Boat!. Don't go paying for the tourist boats that go up and down, not worth it really. Take the orange express boat costs just 20baht for the journey and you see exactly what you see on the tourist boat.The Chao Phraya river is a pretty dirty river but a very busy industrial river at the same time which is why it is like it is.If your not into boats then take a walk over one of the many bridges to get a good look at it.

Go and enjoy the adventure.. Take the ferry from central pier. 15 baht takes you up river. Stop at many oh the destinations on the way, including the flower markrket. I used this ferry all the time. Nearest BTS is Saphan Taksin. Walk to pier and cross footbridge to public ferry as tour boats operate from the first pier landing. Exciting and fun, more so in rush hour

ok if cheap trip. Of capital cities the river in Bangkok is less inspiring that a lot. However, get the sky train to Saphan Taksin station - you can get loads of cheap trips up the river from here. If early enough you can get a free commuters one. We got a one-way ticket for c.£1 each way so it was a nice way to see Bangkok if you haven't been before. You can also buy day tickets and get on and off as you like - which means you can go to the Grand Palace and Wat Arun by boat.
Main river in Thailand. I took a boat across the river and got to see many places in Bangkok. It's amazing

not that spectaculars. Well... the nice thing about is the lunch buffet....mix of thai and western food....The view from the boat is average .... not so much to see untill you are entering the city of Bangkok....

Narrow but provides nice view. The River isn't very wide (not as wide as River Kwai) but travelling down it can allow you to see the entire city by the river. Needs a bit of clean up though. Lovely views and cuts city into two.

The core of Bangkok. Don't miss taking a long tail or an express ferry up and down the river. Bangkok was built around the river and the most unique and interesting parts are still there. If you have time hire a long tail boat and do the canals (klongs)

Take the public "Orange" Boat. The secret to enjoying the river is to NOT get ripped off by paying Bt 1,500 for a private longtail boat, which will only take you down filthy sewers to the "floating market". Rather spend Bt15 and ride the public boats down the breezy river. When you are not fretting about when the boat tour ends, you can relax and enjoy the scenery. Get on at Sathorn Pier and get off at Wat Pho.

River cruise. The river cruise is a good way to see the city from another perspective. The river boats are well organised but can be very busy at peak times, to the point that you are packed in like sardines. The alternative is to hire private boat but those tend to be a lot more expensive. The river itself is murky and looks very polluted and there are many boats about. The views are good and if you have time you can stop at various locations explore the area and then hop onto another boat to continue your trip.

See the sites of Bangkok. Excellent way to see all the sites of Bangkok, We bought a day pass, there are numerous stops and you can hop on and off when ever you want. Boats are clean and surprisingly the water is quite clean and we saw numerous fish throughout the day. The Chao Praya river is very colorful at night with all the boats traveling along.
Hire a longboat. This is one of Bangkok's signature experiences, and it does not disappoint.

Great way to get around Bangkok. It's hard to beat river as a way to get around a city. Very easy, access to key attractions and sites, and a great spectacle when it gets busy! Its also a relaxing way to get across town at the end of an attraction filled day.

must do. This is things must do at Bangkok. Menam chao praya, 'menam' means river in Siam. Mother river of Thailand. Take the public ferry to go around, you will see real local life. It is main local residents tranportation. Fares is very cheap. 3-4 B per trip. Previously it is 2.5B to 3B.Blue piers is for ferry, piers in codes and black are for regular boats.Good experience that can see clearly locals people life. Can drop at any historical heritage along the river.Cheap and easy way to skip from traffic jam in Bangkok City.
Nice dining on the river boats. We spendt a lovley eavning on the river crusing up and down when we had dinner on board. Nice view of the city at night time.
the Express Boat is the way to go. What a bargain and so easy just buy the tickets on board 15 Baht will go a long way

Cool to ride the river and see its banks. An easy way to get around the town and see the sights! It's easy to grab the Tourist Ferry at the Saphan Taksin stop along the skytrain. It's reasonably priced too.It's just hard (and sad) to see everyone throw trash in the river like it's a big waste deposit system.
Great way to get around.. Loved transiting up and down the river to and from the Shangri-La. One of the easiest ways of getting around.
Great tour to join in Bangkok.. Taking the river ride after a day trip to Bang Pa In and Ayuthaya was a nice culminating experience.
Good way to see a different view of city. Very nice to spend an hour or so travelling on the boat. See a different view of the city.
Great day out. Travelled on a converted rice barge - excellent guides and the food was superb

Interesting perspective on Bangkok life.... It was interesting seeing Bangkok and it's way of life from the river. You can catch the Chao Phraya Express fairly inexpensively and ride it up and down the river. Avoid elderly women trying to sell you a long tail boat trip. You won't get what you paid for or expected. Speaking from experience, sad but true.

Venice of the east. Not everyone knows but behind the bustling Bangkokhides another Bangkok - calm and still, that lives on waterways, almost like Venice. There you can see how people who run the Bangkok realy lives.

Chao Phraya River. We stayed at the Sheraton Royal Orchid and the view of this very busy river was just amazing. It is never still and there are so many boats moving all the time- there is always something to see.. The long tail boats are a great way of experiencing this river and going down the small waterways to see the way...


More

An excellent way to see Bangkok. We have hired a private long-tail boat on Chao Pray River already twice and will do it also the next time we visit Bagkok. It is a fun way to see the city. I recommend making a tour around Thonburi, the old town and also stopping by at the Royal Barge museum (15 minutes is enough to see the 8...


More

Tourist Boat.. Bought the 150 baht all day ticket on the tourist boat. We traveled up and down the river getting on and off where required to visit the various temples. The tour guides on the boats are very knowledgeable.
Chao Phraya River A Must. Great way to see Bankok, by river taxi,see a show, have a meal , get to your hotel, go to a market, or get to the Sky Train.
Getting about. Get the sky train to the river, then a river boat trip to Wat Po and other amazing places.
Long Tail Boat. This was pretty much the same as any river boat in the world. Worth doing if you get a chance, but you're not going to miss anything if you don't.

Easy transportation up and down. River itself is quite filthy, but transportation across and up and down river using (public ferries) is quite easy. Just look up the ferry routes and jump on and off when you need to. Easy to reach Wat Pho and Wat Arun using orange line and it only costs 15 THB. You pay the fare once you're on the boat.
river cruise at night. great thing to do and gives you a different appearance of Bangkok

Great Value. 150 baht gets you an all day narrarated boat ride tour of the river which doubles as transportation to points of interest. Take an hour and have a beer or cheap food at the maharaj pier(grand palace stop) and people watch the tourists from all over the world, soldiers, monks, and locals getting on and off the boat.

life on the river. It is just another part of Bangkok that you should see on one of the boats that takes you to khoa San rd or any point along the way. Get on for as long as you like and just turn around and come the other way. Another big part of a vibrant city. You can visit the Big temples along the way if you like.

Really Cool. We hired a longtail boat to take us through the canals after Wat Arun. It was really interesting to float past real Thai homes. Lots of temples on the way too and the Floating Market was cool. Finally an escape from the tourists and an insight into real culture. The water is filthy so close your mouth in case it splashes. We saw a giant lizard (Komodo Dragon?) swimming around and a dead dog. Also saw people fishing and eating out of the water. Strange but cool to witness another way of life.

Chao Phraya River Express Boat. There is a tourist boat which costs 150 baht and the local which costs 15 baht. Since most tourists are only making one or two stops, the 15 baht is the better way to go. Just look for any express boat with an orange flag and it will go everywhere on the river. You can pay on the boat. Whether you just go for a few stops, or for the whole river ride, it is an enjoyable way to see Bangkok

Easy and Great Way to Visit the Sights. We took the BTS to Saphan Taksin, and the ferry terminal is a minute away. The first time we didn't realize that the terminal was so close and we walked 10+ mins the other way. So remember that when you come downstairs from the BTS, it should be right there. If you're walking more than 1-2 mins, you are going too far or the wrong way! At the ferry terminal, the signs aren't very clear so be sure to take the right boat. For 15B, the orange line will take you to most of the major sights- you pay on board. There is also an option for the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat (150B for all day) which wasn't worth it for us. Just give yourself ample travel time. This is a great way to avoid traffic and see the river.

Chao Phraya River. You mustn't visit Bangkok without a trip to the floating market on the river, it is beyond belief. You can buy just about anything here from a thimble up to some very ornate and delicate hand made artifacts. There are also the various types of local Thai food for sale some from stalls on the bank and some from small boats which are tied up at the side of the river. The whole world seemed to be there the day that we went and it was a bit chaotic but don't let that put you off, it is well worth the trouble.

Worth doing. We went up and down the river via ferry and it was well worth it, it was very cheap and easy to use and you can hop on and off along the way, a must do. You can get there by sky train so no hassle at all.
A great way to see the real Bangkok. catching one of the Chao Phraya express boats up and down the river gives you an real insight into the variety of people and living standards in Bangkok.

if you are tired of the traffic jam.... it's very simple: the chao phraya river is no place to jump in and swim, it's way too filthy, unfortunately. but in bangkok streets often are congested: going to the river and taking one of the very cheap boats can be a quick and very relaxing alternative. when you plan your sightseeing-tour, the river (combined with the sky train and/or the metro) can be an astonishingly peaceful and quick way to get along.

It depends what you are expecting.. We travelled down the river from the old capital (about 2 - 3 hours). It is built up all the way and apart from one or two great temples I found it surprisingly dull. I was hoping to get more a sense of rural Thailand as well as an impression of the life of the city. Must have missed it!
educational. lots to see from the river on a cruise we went on the river sun cruise which included bus to ayuthaya and then lunch onboard the boat there was a good choice of food
good trip. Good but not brilliant trip, had good guide but couldn't quite understand everything he was saying. Had lovely fruit buffet with sticky rice and drinks on the way back. good day out.

Ferries a Great Way to Go. It's a big, big river at Bangkok. But the very best thing about it is the Chao Praya Express river ferries, one of the cheapest and most pleasurable ways to get around western Bangkok. A trip of any length costs just 15 baht. Tip: You'd be an idiout to pay 150 baht for a full-day pass on the Tourist Ferry. Are you really going to take more than 10 trips in one day? And besides on the tourist boat it's just you and other tourists; on the regular boat, sure there are tourists, but there are far more actual Thais. Great way to get from Banglamphu/Khao San to the Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Wat Arun, and connections to the Skytrain system.

enjoy a water taxi on the river highway of BKK. pretty easy to figure out the system; just look for the flag colors and study a map beforehand to make sure you are going up or down the river. take the BTS to Saphin Taksin and hop aboard; this is a fun and easy way to get to the palace

Cheap tourism. We have visited Bangkok several times over the years and one of our highlights each time is a trip along the Chao Phraya river on a water bus. They are so regualr and cheap and a great way of getting about. You can often spot a small restaurant or cafe along the banks and then get off there on the way back to experience another fantastic meal, or see a new sight to visit. Sadly, one of our favourites at Pier 13 has been taken over and incorporated into a smart hotel but it is worth having a drink there just to sit and watch the world go by. Try going all the way the end of the line - it becomes more rural and you can see a bit more of Thai life.

An experience!. It is great to use the river to see BKK, no BKK traffic to deal with!Don't pay any attention to the toots that will try and get you to use their boats. The public boat is around 10 to 30 baht depending on how far you want to go and you can buy a ticket when you are already on board.

Manohra Dinner Cruise. It was interesting. Should have started earlier like 6, before the sun has completely set.
It would be nice if there were commentary about the sights - may be available but perhaps not done because this was a corporate function.
The food was way too spicy.

Very busy with lots to do. We hired a long boat, to go to the canals from the main jetty, a bit overwelming at first but with common sense this is not to hard. It was fantastic as we got to see the real Bangkok, with children swimming and playing and adults using the river for their livelihood. Well worth the time and money.

Water You Doing Today?. If you haven't got specific plans for visits to tourists sites, get on the ferry on the river -- a cheap and wonderful experience. Best is the "tourist boat" that costs a bit more but is more comfortable, less crowded, and more scenic. The regular ferry is great if you want more local colour and company.

Best Way to Travel Around Bangkok. We tried to get to an embassy by taxi one day. Big mistake. Another traveller pointed out that by using the tourist boats on the river and the Skytrain we could easily have reached the embassy in less time and for less money.Besides that the boats are a great way to explore the city. Get a day pass and hop on/off to see the sights. Go as far north/south as you can. Use the local ferries to reach other destinations. Getting too hot? Hop on a boat and chill.There's lots of life on the river and it's a great place to be.
Only way to get around town. Loved the river boat - get a great view from the river and a bargin at 15 Baht each

Good way to see the river, but be careful what time you travel. This can be a great way to get around and see the river, but remember it's a working ferry service not a tourist attraction, so at certain times it's VERY busy so getting on and off in time can be difficult.It connected with the BTS Sky Train and is a great way to get to places the Skytrain doesn't stop, e.g. Grand Palace, or closer to Khaosarn Road and Chinatown.
canal tour. we went by longtail boat 1400 BAHT for an hour.. it was extremely interesting insight into thai life... well worth a visit , dont forget to haggle
Chao Phraya Ride.. It is just a ride on a river and that's why I gave it an average rating. It is really nothing special.
feed the fishes. we fed the fishy fish fish, it was a great feeling dont forget to do that
enterteing to take a boat trip on it but dirty water. enterteing to take a boat trip on it but dirty waterbut also a good way of transport, better then the sky train
river with lots to see. get rid of traffic jams and travel the river. you can see many of the sites from the river, and the river taxi will have a stop near most of the areas you want to visit
Was an ok trip. I guess it being hot took the whole fun out of going on the river which is quite polluted with garbage etc., but it has some nice places to see along side.
superb experience. Best way to explore the City, some beautifull houses on the River. Nearer than the floating market and good value for money

Road to the architectural,cultural beauty of Bangkok. Excellent river cruise...easy access to many river facing hotels and grand places like the grand palace,wat pho, wat arun etc. Loved it .... The river transportation is pretty cheap as well ... No need actually to take a full fledged river cruise costing aroun 1500 THB.

A really good route for sightseeing. The water buses running along Chao Pray River provide a really handy and inexpensive means to access many of the tourist spots in Bankok: Grand Palace, Wat Arun, Chinatown, etc. While traveling the breeze is refreshing and you get an interesting view to the 'backside' of Bangkok. Stepping on and off the boats at the various piers gives you easy access to Bangkok communities that are less modernized and sanitized. You can find busy quaint markets, small temples, etc. in these neighborhoods without being hemmed in by huge crowds of tourists. Riding the water buses is an experience in itself, and much less difficult than doing the same in the Khlong Saen Saeb water taxi - I would take children to ride these boats. You can easily access the water bus network from the pier at Saphan Taksin BTS station.The night time dinner cruises along Chao Praya are also worth trying. The food was decent and you can gawk at the city lights. The price was not that cheap, but I have heard that you can easily find deals on the Internet.

Easy and cheap way to see Bangkok. The river ferries (regular or the tourist ferry) is such a great way to see Bangkok & easily get to the sites without dealing with traffic. There was always someone at the ferry stop to assist with locating the correct ferry. The tourist ferry and the ferry to Wat Arun were pre-pay at the dock, the rest you paid on board (they always had change). It was interesting to see how people live along the water. Were they affected by the floods? Hard to say, its all in a slight state of dissaray! My favorite part was the way the ferries wouldn't really come to a stop and instead smack against the dock....hold on tight! They don't wait either..have like a 10 second stop and they're off again. I had traveled the Hong Kong Star Ferry just 2 weeks prior to visiting Bangkok. The whole experience in Hong Kong is a little smoother....but I loved the rough and tumble feel of the Bangkok ferries (granted the tourist ferry is pretty nice).

The heart of Bangkok. The river is a lifeline running through the city allowing business, entertainment, a living space for some and an easier way to get about than the roads which are often clogged with traffic.We think you must try and stay in a hotel on the river.

Busy place. This river is hopping with all sorts of traffiic. Best way to see it is to jump on the water bus or rent a long tailed boat for an hour. That can be arranged at any of the local restaurants on the river.

See how the 'other' side live. Take a long tail boat along the canals and the river itself and see the real side of Bangkok. The boats are fast and the drivers are skillful as the river is busy and can be choppy. Traveling along the river also gives an insight into how the floods in Bangkok affected the city as many reminders are left after the water receded. An hour or two is long enough but definitely worth a look. If you have time also take a ride in the public transport boats along the river as well to get a good view of the city skyline. Cheap and cheerful!

interesting to see. cruise on Chao Phraya River was part of our tour (day tour one hour ride) It is nice to see how people live around the river, but the river is so polluted and dirty, all canalisation from the houses on the river goes directly in it

A must when in Bangkok. Be sure to take a boat ride through the canals and see how people have truly lived in Bangkok for hundreds of years. Our first time there, one of our guides quoted something one of the first British explorers said about the Thais--"They have no legs!"--meaning they used boats to get everywhere.
Splendid Scenery. Went through the river in the morning to reach Grand Palace. The view is nice. The experience of taking the boat ride with the locals there is one to remember.
Long tialed boat. Great - zipping around on long-tailed boat. More sedate passengers can take the ferry .. but they aren't as much fun
A must. Chao Prya is a must when visiting Bangkok, here you can get to Grand Palace and many of the luxurious hotels by the river. You will also see the great contrasts between wealth and poverty.
Longtail boat on the river. It was quite fun to do the longtail boat trip along the river. We got to ride inside these small canals where you could see people living and a lot of other things to see.

The best way to discover Bangkok !. You could have a tendancy to forget that there is a river in Bangkok when you are in busy areas like Sukkumvit, but Chao Phraya really represents a typical and unique part of Bangkok life.Hire a boat, and take it to go through the history of the city, see the temples and palace from a different angle, and see the 'real life' of thai people by the river.A must-do.

A Wonderful Mess. I love riding the boats on the Chao Phraya. It's a mess, it smells, it seems dangerous, and there's chaos. Yet, somehow, it relaxes you because the rest of Bangkok is even more like that. I love Bangkok and I love the Chao Phraya River!

Take the public water taxi. For the best value day trip in town, go to any pier along the river, and take the public water taxi right to the very last stop (Bt14). Then get off, and do it all over again on the way back.See the river from a local's perspective.Don't pay tourist trap prices for "Tourist Boats" !!! Go the way the locals do it, and you will enjoy much more.

An experience but look out for the rubbish in the water. We took a private Longtail Boat trip down the Chao Phraya and local Klongs during our stay in Bangkok and it was a fun experience. One i'd probably do again. Seeing how the locals live and admiring the city from the water is nice. Its also a good reason to put your feet up and relax while you take in the views :)
Chao Phraya. Despite offering good views, the river is terribly polluted. Express boats are somewhat irregular and crowds of people attempt to offer you pricy tourist cruises.

An efficient and fun way to move around.. The ferries are an efficient way to move from place to place along the river, to Wat Arun, the Royal Barge Museum, Chinatown. It is just a few Baht to ride, but can be crowded.

Hot? Grab a Boat!. The river taxis are the perfect solution to the sometimes sizzling weather in Bangkok. Just sit back, enjoy the cool breeze and watch riverside life go by. You can get off at almost any stop and find a small Thai restaurant for good food and a cold beer.
Get your own boat. Not too expensive and worth it as you can ask to stop and see what you want.

....a happy and wet excursion. We navigated the Chap Phraya River via the tourist route: we took the BTS to Sephan Thaksin and followed the signs to the dock. The tourist boat costs B150 and you can hop-on and hop-off on/from as many docks/piers within the day. The tourist boat is large with enough seats for a big group of tourists. It has numerous, interesting stops along the river which could make-up your day. The river is clean-ish along the main tourist route and gets murkier and nastier as you go further down.

Just sail from Wat Pho to Wat Arun. The river was, in past times, one of the main transportation routes of the city. It is still crowded and dirty, but sailing along it give some feeling of old times, looking over the warehouses and temples on the banks of the river. The river busses are very crowded, so for a feeling of the river, that is cheap, efficient and time saving – just sail from Wat Pho to Wat Arun, when visiting these sites. It is quick and sufficient.
Atmospheric. Unbelievable 'hive of activity' manic actually!! Looks a bit polluted though, odd considering 'monster' ray fish reputedly inhabit its depths!!!
Worth a look. The river it self is very dirty. With that being said it's nice to escape the heat and go on a boat trip and see how the real people of Bangkok live.
great. great way to see another way of life and lovely for sunset
The blood of Bangkok. The Chao Phraya River is a main river in Bangkok. You have to take a boat tour to see the attraction along the river. Or you have to have dinner on a cruise.
boat trip. interesting view of life on the river and an excursion through one of the canals back into the community was very nice.

It's the life blood of Bangkok.. It is not like other city rivers, it's like a highway with river taxi's regular 'bus boats', tourist boats, hotel boats, long tail speed boats and at night all the rice barges being pulled by tug boats.
Great cruise. The cruise was superb. We did the Princess Chao Phraya River Cruise. The food was nice, they catered for Indian food and the singer was good. Worth doing

Enjoy a tour to feel the specialty of BKK compared to other metropoles. Recommendation: Stay as close as possible to the river. A lot of hotels are direcly located there. Try all the different transfer possibilities. Public Ferry (ticket less than 1 euro). Is a perfect jump on and of transportantion system. Locals are using it mostly; so you can get breath the atmosphere. Hotel-shuttle-boats: belong to some 5 star hotels at the river an can be used by these guest for free. Longtail boat is really fun, because the are the fastest on the river. A tour with such a special boat is possible through the "klongs". On such a tour you can see how people are direcly living at water channels. That is fastinating!

Over rated. Since i am from asia, seeing this dirty river is not really interesting. The only interesting part of chao phraya river is the water bus stop, which also full of street sellers. The river is just over rated
Bangkok's river of life. Something to do during the daytime. A ferry across the river is only 10 Baht.
Lively river. It's lively. People are getting on and off the boat all day.
Great way to see the city. Brilliant way to see the city, especially at night when all lit up. lots of boat trips to suit, hop on and off wherever you decide.

Catch a boat and explore the riverside temples and markets.. We grabbed a ticket for the public ferries and rode alongside the locals. Be aware that part of the boat is reserved for monks. Lots of markets and temples to wander around at various ferry wharfs.
never stops. our room overlooked the river .something happening all day.worth a cruise up and down.

A Great River. The Chao Phraya River is more then just a waterway cutting through the heart of Bangkok, as it is alive with boats of all kinds. I was able to take a regular ferry several stops down the river, to connect with the Skytrain, which was very interesting. But the highlight was a long-tail boat tour of the canals on the east side of the river. This was fascinating to go past houses on stilts leaning out over the canals. The local residents were all friendly, and we got many smiles and waves as we went by. A great experience not to be missed. Asked your tour guide to set something up as part of your Bangkok tour.
Clean and scenic.. Travelling along the river will take you to many places of interests located along it. Is a public type of river transport so don't expect too much of comfort and can be pack.

Definitely an experience!. We took a river cruise- a private river cruise. It's a smaller boat for 4 of us. Felt like we were the fish in the river. It's very busy, very wavy and just wow... You should definitely do it if you have the time and the money. We got 2 hour private boat ride for 2600 bhat. Not bad.

To do. Ok, yes, the water is dirty but that's not it! Taking a long tail boat will cost you about 300 baht (there's also a ferry for 150 baht for the entire day but it's pretty crowded). You can see the wonderful temples, the big luxury hotels and also the "favelas" type houses where the poor Thai people are leaving.It's an experience not to be missed while in Bangkok.
Keep the River transport. I love to be able to travel up and down the river as a form of public transport
Great River. The muddy waters can be a little scary but it gives a nice touch to the city.
River ride. Fantastic value with interesting veiws along the river
All life is here.. Big, noisy, full of life and not as toxic as it used to be.

I always use the normal ferry. When you go to Saphan Taksin with the Skytrain you can take the normal ferry for like 14 THB and get off at the pier near Wat Pho and Wat Arun (which you can see when you arrive) Just make sure you dont use any of the commercial ferries when you are on a budget. The name of the pier to get out is Tha Tien. Next to tha Thien you can take the ferry that takes you accross the river to Wat Arun

Choa Praya River cruise/s a must. Cool, smooth, seated way of seeing a lot of the history & development of BKK, with running commentary. See the stunning disparity between ancient & new; & wealth & abject poverty. 150bht for ALL day, just staggeringly cheap.
Interesting. Plenty to see long the river, use the cheap and frequent river taxis, lots of stops for access to different attractions

River for Thailand. What a beautiful river, she run thru many big cities, good for tourists in Bangkok to take water taxi for sightseeing, to visit several temples. it is cheap way to travel, no traffic jam and beautiful sight along the river.

Excellent way to visit. The boat that takes you from one station to another is rapid and cheap. Just don't buy the tourist tickets which are more expensive. Except for certain stations ( skytravin) at certain hours you just pay on the boat.
The view is great.
A great river. A great Bangkok artery, and an excellent way to get around, but make sure you take the local, not the tourist boats!

Bangkok's Jugular Vein. A must to a boat trip on the river. Many day or night trips on offer.
I had a great dinner trip taking in many of the original Portuguese riverfront buildings as well as Palaces and wonderful Chinese architecture (who says Thailand has never been colonised!)
Romantic or just plain interesting!

need 2 do this. if u go 2 Bangkok u must get a boat down the canals we did this & got 2 feed huge cat fish purchase stuff off floating market boats & c a lot of temples along the river quicker than a taxi 2 alot of the attractions as traffic in Bangkok mental!!!

so beautiful at sunset. Highly recommend renting a long tail boat to take you through the river and into the Klong but even just the boats along the river we preferred to taxis for the main attractions.

Great fun to roam these busy waves. A splendid program to see and experience this busy artery of Bangkok at a very reasonable rate, by taking the local express boat, 15 bahts for a one hour ride from South to North or opposite, and obtain a glimpse into the lives of the average Thai as they commute to work via this spectacular waterway.

Great way to get around. It's a little tricky at times to get on and off the boat but, what an experience to have. Not only are most of the great Wats in Bangkok easily accessible from the river but, the river is a gate way into the Thai way of life. We took a Longtail boat on a two hour tour through the canals, were we cruised by homes on the river and visited a floating market. A highlite of our trip.

Cheap and nice. I would recommend to take a water-bus at least once and go at least up or down the river. The prices are so low that you can go back and return just in order to sit in the boat and enjoy the view from the river. But if you are spending some more time in Bangkok and the hostel is near at the river, it is a very good transportation to go downtown too

The best way to discover downtown Bangkok. We used to start at Thaksin bridge (wich you can join by skytrain ) to go to Chinatown or Royal Palace or even Wat Arun on thé Thonburi side of the river. Don't forget to stop at The Oriental Hotel where you can have lunch or sip a fresh fruit juice at sunset.Be careful when you take thé boat : thé different

Best tour value in Thailand!. Travel down the Chao Phraya on the public transit boats used by the Thai residents who live all along the river. Take the boat to Nothunburi and tour the town and the old colonial school. Have dinner at the open air restaurant while watching the sunset. Then take the boat back into Bangkok. A fabulous experience for a tiny cost. The sights from the river are amazing and take you back a 100 years or more.

Great fun and doesn't have to be expensive. The Chao Phraya is the lifeblood of Bangkok. It is bustling with boats of all kinds of descriptions. Thousands of Bangkokians criss cross the river daily.Two suggestions:Catch the Sky Train to Saphan Taksin station and then catch one of the many Government run boats that heads up the river. Then at the end, catch it back. Very very cheap way of taking in the river and all the great sites along the way.

Enjoy the river. Take the Chao Phya Express Boats for an easy way to travel along the river and get off at the various sites along the way. Take the ฿150 ticket for unlimited service per day for complete fun and flexibility, whilst seeing everything there is to offer.
River tour. The water was extremely rough the day we went out and I also feel I could've haggled the price down a little more for the long boat rental (my fault though)

Take a long-tail boat cruise to learn Bangkok's history. See how the locals live along the river and a visit to the imperial barge museum completes the experience. Good, scenic activity for a few hours to kill.
Old Bangkok. 85% of the sights are near the river. There are cheap , convenient boats to stop all along the way to see the main sights of Bangkok

Boat rides set the pulse racing. Ride on a long tail boat up the Chao Phraya river at breakneck speed and your heart begins to race, but turn off onto the side canals and you see a different, more tranquil side of the city. Good fun and cheap.

Highway to the Sights. Other than the BTS & MRT rail stations this may be the best way to move to the sights and avoid traffic. It's very cheap (less than $1 USD) and is more of an "experience" than standing in a train car, but maybe a little less of an experience than taking a Tuk Tuk. There are several stops at major sights (Wat Arun, Wat Po, Grand Palace and more). A must do if you are near the river. The main pier is next to the Taksin BTS station.
Fun!. I took a river taxi ride here and hopped off wherever looked interesting. A great way to spend a beautiful afternoon in Bangkok!

Be careful with the private tours. When you go to the River make sure you go to the "Public" tours. is a full day tour for about 150Baht you can get on and off many times. Be careful that the people on the street, taxis and Tuktuks may try to take you to a private tour. is very expensive (like 2000baht) and definetly now worth it.
Nice river... There are great places to visit along both sides of the river.. take the river cruise... it's worth it and I hope to be back again this year :)

Nice Dinner. We are going there with a friendly local tour guide, and 40 of us booked one ship / cruise / what ever you say for dinner and spending around 4 hours.Better you check weather condition, due if wind too strong is not good while u stay in second floor of the ship. Food is average, view is the best. you can see temple shining in the night, river is clean, and people above the bridges and street are friendly, they are not throwing anything in to the ship. nice people from Thailand, very friendly person

Don't miss this. Taking the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat was one of the highlights of our stay in Bangkok. Great views from the river and you have unlimited on/off boarding. The boat stops at the the major sites and temples along the river. Very easy!

Smelly and Dirty river but you need the boat to reach some of the destination .... Worth to visit for one or two trip but not more than that. Make sure that you know the price of the boat ticket(there are 3 types of boat at different price). If the ticket conductor ask you to pay more than what you understand, remember to ask around (tourist) before you pay them and remember to insist you want the receipt. Beware of dishonest ticket conductor. Majority of people of the boat are TOURIST. : )
Take a water taxi just for fun.. Cheap to take the Nonthaburi water taxi and hop off along the way.

Hire a long boat. If you have the time why not head down by skytrain to Saphan Thaksin Station and then hire a long boat for an exciting tour of the Chao Phraya River There are a lot of interesting sights and history along the river including the grand palace and the royal bargesThere is also a bridge crossing th river which is similar to the famous River Kwai bridgeThe river also has a lot of canals which the longs boats travel along you can see how a lot of the locals live along the river
Facinating "Venice of Asia". Amazing haw the Thai people turn the river into a place of interest. Good scenery, many good hotels along the river. Something different...

good way to see bangkok. So interesting. I caught the ferry to travel around and saw people buying some fish-like creature, pray to it and chuck it in the river. I saw others throwing their garbage in, and others fishing.

River of Kings. As we stayed in the Millennium Hilton Hotel, we were intimately involved with the river. A most pleasant view from the room and the river turns into a fairytale sight at night with glittering ferries and supper cruise boats negotiating their routes down and across the river
boat on the chao phraya. for 150 baht, hop on hop off this is not only the best way to see major attractions in bangkok good value.map supplied and i.d. all too easy to cover the big ones.
Not trip to Bangkok complete without river ride. At the very least you get a breeze...Cheap and well worth doing on a hot day...Cruise the River...and get off and on.....and see the sights

Cheap form of transport to outer areas.. Can use this to get to the Grand Palace and Kao San Road. Don't but a ticket before you get on the boat, there is a conductor and the charge is 15 bht each. Good views of nice hotels and shanty houses on the river. Not luxurious but good to do, get to river by Sky Train.

A longer ride than the one at Singapore River. The water here is muddy, just like SIngapore River. If you do not like muddy water to be splashed on your face, you had better not sit just beside the river; instead sit nearer to the aisle so you get splashed less. I got to feed big fat catfish at one point! Oh, there were so many & they were all hungry for my bread! The river ride is about 30 minutes long. Make sure you go to the toilet first before boarding one or else...

Love it. The river itself is pretty cloudy and I imagine quite dirty, but the riverbanks tell the story of Bangkok - lots of fancy places right next to old lean tos. I love that they don't try to hide anything - here is Bangkok, it is what it is. Highly recommend using the river as transport to the tourist sites.

Take a Ferry, Watch the Boats. One of the most fun things to do in Bangkok is to take a ferry on the Chao Phraya. Interesting, be part of the local scene, quick, inexpensive and cooling. This is a great river to watch--amazing variety of boat traffic. Don't get stuck in a taxi--take a ferry!

Great way to experience life in Bangkok. Take the sky train to Saphan Taksan and get on one of the boats heading up the river (heading to your right as you look at the river). You pay on the boat. I went all the way to Nonthaburi which takes you past the Palace, Wat Arun and under the suspension bridge. It is a great and cheap way to see Bangkok.Andrew

Gorgeous boat trip. The river is kind of a beautiful freeway through Bangkok lined further up by beautiful golden temples. Take the buffet lunch boat returning from the Kings Summer Palace. and cruise for a few hours back to Bangkok.Thrilling experience!

Bit of an adventure. Had a slap up meal on one of the river boats- fantastic food and atmosphere. Went on the cheap ferry up and down several times in the day but when we were put off at Pier 7 [Flower Market]it was partially submerged -no ferry would pick us up despite manic waving for over half an hour - so we had to wade through the water- which was choppy- on the storm damaged pier to get to dry land. Rest of trips less eventful, but shopping and sight seeing very good

Worth the effort. Take the skytrain to the river and transfer to a river ferry to a trip past temples, old teak homes and historic sights of Old Bangkok. Either get off close to the Grand Palace or make it a round trip and head back to the skytrain. Boats for tourists and another for locals. Your choice. Go with the locals for authentic experience but only outside rush hours and if you have patience for many stops.
The scenic view of Bangkok from the river. I enjoyed the thrill of travelling in a boat on the Chayo Phraya and viewing the beautiful city in a scenic way.

Fair enough. Buy the single ticket! Dont buy a day pas as it is a tourist trap!! I found myself trapped as normally people only use 3-5 trip (each trips cost you 15 bath).. While the day pass cost you 150 bath. amazing

The best place to be in Bangkok at sunset.. The busy river taxi is a really good find. 15baht a trip or 150 baht a day makes it really good value. It goes up and down the river and down the river regularly making it convienent with stops at a lot of the regular attractions.The bustle of people getting on and of adds to is charm. Our first trip was at sunset which was an amazing sight.
Dinner cruise on the Chao Phraya River - must do. They welcome you in the traditional manner. the cruise is excellent with information in English. The dinner was average with live entertainment.
the glory of bangkok. my best experience of bangkok is the chao phraya river tour. it is a must try when visiting the bangkok. take a boat from the central pier in bts sathorn station (s6)

River with nice locations. Went for dinner cruise, and enjoyed a very different but nice experience. All the building and places around river gives best view @ night from cruise.Nice food + location + live singing and dancing

Better tnan Disnelyland's Jungle ride. For 15B you can ride from central pier North for about 1 hour. Once past the tourist attactions you travel along the shores passing factories and house's, children swimming and fellows fishing for dinner, At the end of the line, pay another 15B and return down river.

Life is like a River.... The Chao Phraya is the life line of Bangkok in the old days and even now to many. Taking a cruise or just hopping on one of the river ferry boats and watching life on the river is a wonderful experience, and can be enjoyed at any time of day - my favorites are in the morning as the city comes alive, and as the sun sets and things wind down.

The best way to see Bankok. Take the public boat from the Central Pier (accessible by skytrain) for a great view of the life of the city without the exhaust fumes. You can disembark at various points to see the sights, or go to the furthest point upriver for 15 baht to a small town called Nonaburi I think. We had a fantastic meal at a floating restaurant there; I had steamed fish but you could sample delicacies like frogs legs or ducks feet with asparagus if you really felt brave!

Brilliant. Use the Boat service, don't buy one day pass unless you want go up and down the river more than 5-10 times, individual trips to various "stops" bouncing jetties, are so cheap 15 Baht per person (day pass 150Baht). the stops are near to many of the main sightseeing attractions and the river is great for seeing the city from a different angle, also so many other types of boat to see and the odd water spray keeps you cool, they all have canopies so avoiding the sun if you need to is easy.
Day Trip. Really good for a day trip, at night there are just too many dinner cruises
Muddy. River is muddy but you can see Thais fishing there. Lots of big fish... That's why I didn't eat seafood while I was in Bangkok ;)

Superb shopping center, don't miss it. In bangkok you've got several shopping mall, all of them are quite fabulous, the Siam paragon is the greater in terms of luxuous shopping names. The big aquarium is great for your children too. Also take a ride to the other shopping mall called "terminal 21", amazing and full of little shops of designer (not expensive)

Great for sightseeing. While you definitely don't want to fall into it (I've never seen a dirtier river; at times it looks as if all Bangkokians simply drop their trash into the river; I've even seen a dead dog float in it…) , the Chao Praya river offers some fantastic opportunities for sightseeing and is an easy way of getting around in a city that can become choked with traffic jams. Avoid getting stuck on the roads by opting for the Chao Praya River express as a means of transport when sightseeing. It's cheap and efficient.

great fun!. The river is the best way to see many of the tourist sites. learn how to take the ferries. the first day it may be worth it to get the all day tourist pass and take the tourist boat which provide an oveview in English and Thai. the passs is actually good aon all the diffeerent ferries of the major ferry company but take the time to figure out which ferry with what flag goes where. there is a map bhind the dock unger the skytrain that lists the stops and whichflag goes to what dock. the Flag colour is at the back of the ferry . they all have the yellow flags of the king at the front. the blue, orange, yellow and green are at the back.
lovely views. boat ride on the Chao Phraya - must do when visiting Bangkok. Done it many times for pleasure as well as transportation. Never did the cruise though.
a great river. up there with the Thames, Seine and Rhine for a view of river life...not to be missed...take a long tail boat and zoom around the klongs like JaMES bOND

Alternative transportation with excellent views..!. The Chao Phraya River might not be the cleanest in the world but what it does offer is an alternative form of transport in a city that is notorious for traffic on its over crowded roads and does so with some of the best views and attractions that Bangkok has to offer..! You have 3 choices of boats on the river... The "tourist boats" which cost 150 Baht for a 1 day ticket with unlimited stops... And, you have the traditional "Thai longtail boats" and with these the price will vary depending on how many are in your group and where or how long you want the boat for and your bargaining skills... Then there are the express/commuter boats (with yellow, orange or green flags on front) which are extremely cheap and cost only 10 to 30 Baht for the longest trip available... With that being said, many of the cities tourist attractions can be accessed by the river... Some of them include, The Grand Palace and Wat Pho (Temple of the Reclining Buddha)... Both of these are located at the Tha Tien Pier which is located 8 stops north of Sathorn Pier (the main commuting pier in Bangkok)... Another notable area is "Chinatown" which can be reached by Ratchawong Pier which is 5 stops north of Sathorn Pier... Sathorn Pier can easily be reached by the BTS/Skytrain at Saphan Taksin Station (S6)... The pier is located under the BTS/Skytrain Station... So, if you are interested in these or many of the other attractions along the river it is truly worth doing it from the water... You will avoid all the traffic and get to see the city from a different prospective with some great views..!
All human life is here!. In many ways, the river is Bangkok - day and night it is busy with ferries, water buses, water taxis, freight barges, motorised rafts, snaking along for what seems miles.
A good way to see the city. A trip on the river is a great way to see the city from a new perspective,weather you just take a river bus or do a dinner cruise
Very fun.. It's great fun for kids to have a boat ride down this river and a tour guide on the boat points out what attractions you can see from the river. I recommend this to families.

Bustling riverway. I felt like we were on the freeway on the river! A bustling river with lots of activity, boats everywhere, water taxi's taking people up and down river, a relatively clean looking river, great views of the city.
well i love bangkok. it's very good place for go alpng the river you can see the thai stye house and life stye of thailand.

alternative transport system. A very convenient way to visit most of the tourist sights including China Town, temples statues etc. Boats are normally every ten minutes or so but do not operate in the evenings.
A nice river for a boat ride.. While the river is uterly polluted, it's still nice to take a boat ride in it (for literally no money at all).

Longtail boat trip a MUST.. An hour's trip a short way up/down the Chao Phraya and, more interesting, around a couple of the residential canals off the river. Fascinating to see from the canal-side. Interesting to stop at fish farm en route as well...

must see. we did a rice barge tour on the river. it is very interesting, you get to see all the life on the river, from bathing and washing to cargo barges going by. there are many historical sites along way.you gat a good look at bangkok as well.

The Thames anyone?. Its a big river running through a large city, can't see why anyone would get too excited about that... go for a cruise and have dinner on one of the several floating restaurants if you want to see it in style, otherwise take a water taxi from Saphan Taksin to eg Chinatown and rub shoulders with the locals.

A must do in Bangkok. A ride on the Chao Phraya River is a must when in Bangkok. We used the ferries to go across from one side to the other. Cost 3 baht. We went on the Tourist Ferry which is a hop on hop off ferry at the most popular tourist places. A great way to see the Grand Palace, Wat Phoand Wat Arun as well as Chinatown and several smaller markets. Cost 150 baht for the whole day. We also rode the river on the express ferry using the ferries with the orange flags. This enabled us to travel the river with the locals. Good if you wanted to go to a particular place. Cost 30 baht. For fun we had a couple of hours in a long boat to the floating markets. You can barter for this so cost depends on your bartering skills. When you are sick of the traffic on the street you can join the traffic on the river abd see another aspect of Bangkok.
Area to overview Bangkok. It was the wrong period to be there because of the flood
Dirty But A Site To See. Every tourist should take a trip to the main Bangkok river. Take a boat cruise and stop at one of the snake farms for a show.

Take a taxi ferry and long tail boat to explore the river. If you stay in the new parts of BKK and use the snazzy new Sky Train or Metro you could miss the Chao Phraya River altogether. But dont miss it. Take the BTS to one of the piers and hop on and off a commuter taxi-ferry that run from 7AM-7Pm carrying locals up and down. Then hire a long tail boat (we paid 800THB for 3 people for an hour) to take you through the ancient canals of the real old BKK.

Great river cruises. The night time dinner cruises are very nice though a bit pricey at about $100 for two. The boats used for the cruises come in at River City next to the Royal Orchid Sheraton and for several hours cruise up and down the river. The high rise hotels on both sides of the river are beautiful at night and the food on the boat, though buffet style, is quite good. During the day, taking the regular water taxis provides a nice tour for much less cash though the romanticism is not there.

Take the river ferry. The river ferry is the best way to see the Chao Phraya river. It's very inexpensive (14 baht per person) and gives a great view of all the sites along the river. Check the online timetable and map of piers for details of where to hop on and off.
Magnificent. It's the King's River and... the heart of Thai lives
Fun to do once!. It is a must do in Bangkok, but it is only something you do once! I have been living here for many years now, and find it some what overpriced, but will still recommend it once!
interisting in the day time and magic at night time. Nice to go for a lunch in the daytime and magic to go in a cruise at night time
Wide veriotty of boats. Rhe city has many knalles that are hidden in the river. There are also hotel boats that go from Span Taxien (a train station)
Journey down the Chao Phraya. People say it's polluted, but I love to go for a ride on this river. It's a wonderful, peaceful cultural experience to look out and see Bangkok along the shores.

Mighty waterway. Made you think why the Thames isn't used in a similar way to transport commuters. On one of the smaller rivers in the town we noticed boats which must have had over 100 people getting on and off, and they seemed to come in every minute or so - amazing. Great sights to be seen, cheap tourist ferries. Try it and enjoy.

Great Experience. Having read that traveling by river was an unpleasant and smelly venture in Bangkok (but beat the traffic), we were very pleasantly surprised by our trip down the Chao Phraya River. It is a frenetically busy river and so full of local color and atmosphere, it was one of our highlights. Plus great city views and a cooling breeze.

All life is here. Rivers have a fasination for me and especially when thy are big and flow right through the heart of a major city. The Chao Phraya is only 370 kilometres long but can cause huge floods along it's way.From 5-6 star hotels, magnificent Wats, The Grand Palace to shacks on the waters edge that are near to collapse you will see it all. Always take a boat taxi and spend a couple of hours going one way or the other. You will be amazed at the local life right on the edge with luxury apartments right next door. The royal barges can be seen in their sheds near the naval base.Transport by barge huge barges pulled by 1 or 2 tiny tugs are a familiar sight. As are seriously fast long tail boats that fly along at speeds over 80 kph.Dinner is popular on a cruising ship and these can be fun if you choose a good ship. Food is buffet style and usually quite crowded.Don't miss a trip on this river!

River cruises on Praha river. Frankly, done it twice, bit disappointing unless you just need to just pass the time or must have a sundowner cruise. Not worth the time, much better things to see and do

River Cruise on The Grand Pearl. Wonderful buffet dinner! Saxophone player plays as the boat pulls up the the dock and the staff stand at attention saluting the passengers. The Bangkok skyline from the boat is phenomenal. So many temples and the Royal Palace. Well worth it.

a cool way to see the city. taking many of the boat options is not only a great way to see the city (and much cooler than the streets during the hot afternoons), but often a faster way to get from point a to point b. there is also a variety of tours available.
Express boat. Use the Thai river express boats,great experience and very cheap

Food, Adventure, Romance or Luxury. This is the best place to start in Bangkok if you are looking for something Romantic. Good restaurants and street markets, temples galore, islands upriver, boats and neighborhoods for exploring, luxury hotels and magnificent views at sunrise/sunset. The river will take you places and show you many faces. It is a great way to transport your self to different places for a day or two.
