klongs on a leaky boat. liked scenery,temples,fish-feeding frenzydisliked boatman had to bail almost continuously

Best staying by the river. I like this river and now I am always staying by the river when I come to Bangkok. I like the area of Thonburi by Saphan Taksin bridge, excellent hotels and holiday apartments.
Interesting Sailing. Always busy, good way to see the other side of Bangkok. Especially how goods are transported up and down river, good acces to temples and china town etc.

A dinner cruise is a must do in Bangkok. When in Bangkok, choose one of the many dinner cruises offered. Your hotel will have an agent who will book for you. You will be picked up around 6 pm from your hotel, and taken to the pier. There you will be given a badge for your particular cruise ship, and when your boat docks, you will be boarded. Its all very organized. For the next 3 hours, you will float up-river and see the fantastic sights on the banks - the royal palace, the temple of the dawn, etc. On board, there will be drinks and dinner and cultural entertainment, followed by a rock band and dancing on the top deck.At the end, you will be dropped back to your hotel. Its all very organised and enjoyable. A nice evening out.
Long Tail through the river. The best way to see Bangkok - you see the real Bangkok and temples that aren't the typical tourist sites

Great short trip! Great way to get to Chinatown quickly.. We just caught the tourist ferry from Saphan Taksin to Chinatown, it was 30 baht one way (or you can buy the all day ticket for 150baht). If you catch the local ferries they are cheaper.
Its great being on the water. There is commentary but I couldn't hear it very well.

Take a boat ride!. The best way to explore the city is by getting on one of the thousands of traditional boats and exploring the sites right from the river. Most of Bangkok's most famous sites are situated next or close to the river. The most interesting part is going through the section with all the traditional wooden houses to get insight into how the traditional people of Bangkok live!

River Cruise a lovely evening. I did a river cruise down the river and it was really lovely. Along the way they point out famous temples and buildings along the way. With all the lights at night its really nice.

Meh. You can take the river cruise if you have spare time...that's all...some taxi drivers have their own designated piers where they get incentives for bringing in clients..it happened to me. They boat proprietor wanted to charge me 2000 baht for the bot ride but when I argued saying it's too much and that I was a student, they dropped the price half!!! I wonder if it's way cheaper than that. Otherwise you better take the boats that locals use to go from one place to another.
Beautiful. It's interesting to see how the Thai's commute around by the river. The boat rides is a must thing to do

Good experience .... We did the Chao Phraya dinner cruise and it was good. The food was good, nice service standards. The Thai singer took pains to sing Hindi songs for the Indian passengers .... which was a nice touch

Eternal river. The river is busy with transport. For instances the rice barges that are really enourmous containers drawn by a dapper little boat. And the little ferry's that look like small tempels and float between the hotels. Especially illuminated at night they give a dream like impression. The river is a lifeline!
Long Tail Tour. We took a private long tail boat tour on the river for 1 hour. Great experience.
Take a boat ride!. The boat crossing from left to ride for next to nothing is a very good way to get from A to B and its a very nice experience too!

River with so many things around. We got couple of chances to travel through the River.First time we went to grand palace by river. There are 2 types of tickets available in the pier, one is a package which provided hop on hop off services in probably 8 spots of interest. However we took the ticket for Grand palace only. While going through you can have a look into Wat Arun and many other interesting places from the water taxi. There are also some restaurants in the bank of the river where you can have your meal and enjoy the beauty of nature. We had lunch on such one.The next time we took a dinner cruise on the river. The cruise was fantastic which was enhanced by the night beauty of chao phraya river.If you get the chance, you must grab a water taxi or boat in the river to see around.
Longboat. Excellent, shows the difference between rich and poor. Try to do it in a longboat, great fun
day and night. Worth visiting day and night for contrast. The service ends around 19hrs. So keep this in mind!
Chao Phraya River dinner cruise. It started off later than specified i.e. later than 7 pm

Worth a trip. There are a great many little ferry stops scattered along this river and they are also very cheap - have a short trip or a number of small trips OR get our own long tailed boat OR have a canoe - I did (http://timinphuket.blogspot.com/2012/01/christmas-paddle-on-chao-phraya-in.html).

Longtail Boat Tour of Canals (khlong) excellent. This is one of my strongest memories of Krung Thep (Bangkok) and taking the ride through the canals is a mazing thing. The sights, sounds and smells of the canals will remain with you and the people are just so friendly. Stop off and see Wat Arun and eat some Pad Thai at the floating market...it is amazing. Sights of a lifetime!

The only way to travel. Exploring Bangkok is really easy by using the ferries that go up and down the Chao Phraya river. For 20 to 30 baht you can go to Chinatown or Wat Pho or many other of the many tourist attractions without sitting in traffic jams on the Bangkok city roads. It is also a good way of observing authentic Thai life as the locals use the ferries for going about their daily business.It is also a good way of escaping the humidity of the crowded city streets.

Don't miss the boat ride. Though I have been to Bangkok 5 times in the past 6 years, this was the first time I took a boat ride on the Chao Prayo river. We took one of those long motor boats that we alighted at the pier near the Grand Palace. We paid 500 baths each and had the boat to oursleves. We could have bought it down even more but $15 for an hour's boat trip was a pretty good deal in my book. We were able to see how the real bangkok inhabitants lived along the river. And trust me - You will never see this in the brochures or websites. Definitley an eye opener. There were houses, temples all stretched along this route. I saw peopel fishing, soem people washing their clothes, kds palying in the water. We also got to see the major temples too - Wat Arun, Wat Pho, etc. One advice, sit near the middle or back. We sat in the front initailly and though the view is unobstructed, you do end of getting splashed by water from passing speed boats; unless you like that sort of thing !

Can be a fun excursion. The night cruise/dinner cruises are pretty good and the food is decent to very good. The afternoon crusies you see more and there is a lot of things to see, but mostly it's a relaxing time with a nice breeze to cool you down. Have to pay up the wazoo for the drinks though.

Nice but too croud; not for me. Before going to visit Wat Arun we wrogly take main boat to go there, but fro some reason including to many people we miss our stop. At the end we're surfing like in a "cattle truck" but over the Chao Phraya river. At the end we went from notrh to south crossing most of luxury hotels area and the color of the river was brown planty of green algae, trees barnchess, some flowers, and waht has schocked me was about people living in a house boat (wood wall and iron roof) where sanity is an option. By the way we had a good time to watch this as part of river side of the city and if you have time enough why don't you make it? Its is fun and rekaxing at the end.
Travel on a local boat. Going on the river on a local (commuter) boat is quite an experience and one not to be missed! (it's also very, very cheap)
River travel and sightseeing.. What a way to see some of Bangkok, you will see majestic buildings and temples but you will also see slums that show you the difference.

River Cruise. Quite a number of interesting buildings,and bridges along the river. We took the River Cruise which had a buffet dinner. Would have been better if there was some sort of commentary as to the sights along the river.But overall, thoroughly enjoyable. River cruise starts from Rivercity.

this is the best trip, especially a dinner cruise.. The river is busy but broad and attractive, many important sites can be viewed from tourist boats which are amazingly cheap. It is simply a great trip to go all the way up the river. Nightime is great if you take a dinner cruise

another way to see metropolitan bangkok. Liked: the fast and cheap way to reach my intended destination via the river. And the sunset is sublime.
Disliked: the mosquitoes at the pier while waiting for the ferry to arrive. So be ready with your mosquito repellant lotions.

monstrous size river. very wide and clean, the brown colour is just its muddy nature of the watercourse. You get to stop at various temples or museum along the river, or even feed the local fish that swim up to greet and demand some bread crumbs!

A great way to get around Bangkok. Ferries are a great way to move around Bangkok; avoiding the legendary traffic jams every time. Buy a Day Pass on the Chao Phraya Tourist ferries for 150 baht (approx AUD 5) and you can go up and down the river, and get on and off as many times as you like. The tourist ferries do not stop at all of the wharfs, but they do go to those that serve the major tourist attractions and you can easily spend a entire day moving seamlessly and easily between many of the must see sites. If you are so minded, the Day Pass also allows you to use the Express ferries which are favoured by the locals. The downside is that the river is very polluted. Experienced users of the ferries (i.e locals) can be seen covering their mouth and nose to avoid being splashed with water from the river, and it is a very sensible precaution. Buy a cheap mouth / nose mask from a pharmacy for a couple of baht and the problem is solved.

Interesting but tricky!. Your experience will depend on what you are looking for really. If you want to sit back and observe the real life of the real people you can hire a long tail and cruise by on a good day. It might smell and the water is not so clean but that's just how it is! Dinner cruises are also fun and some have nice entertainment programs. It is also a convenient way to get around if you want to visit the temple of dawn or the grand palace. Just be careful with those long tail folks and any unofficial transportation. We got into a long tail with two other couples to go to Wat Arun; we were charged 100 baht which is much cheeper than the regular fair, that should have been our sign for trouble but we took it. Instead we were dropped at a side dock which was somebody's house actually. The boat left us there and the girl on the other side refused to let us pass demanding that we each pay a 20 baht landing fee. We couldn't go through until we did after a short argument that was getting heated and slightly dangerous! Go figure...

take the boat. Take one of the regular boats at the public piers along the river. Thus, you avoid the traffic on the streets, and you enjoy both the modern skyline, the life on and along the river; and you can still see traditional houses and river-life. Most beautiful early in the morning or in the late afternoon

Dirty and Polluted. This is the second time we have done a trip on the River, and it was far more disappointing this time. The long tailed boats seem in less good shape, and the water was really dirty. The waves are big due to them hitting the sides and bouncing back - and the trip to the floating village is a scam.

special experience. to experience the Chao Prao River, you either that the Express Service Boat from for example Sapan Taksin BTS station to a pier. It is some puzzling what color flag boat to take but it is worth the hassle, THB 20-30. Instead you
So cheap!!!!. A must do and very cheap! If you are going to a lot of places get a day pass for 150 baht, if not then get singles for 30 baht each.

River Tour. A river tour gives insight into the lives of the people of Bangkok. Guided tours are great as they point out lots of interesting things that you would miss or not know if you were out touring by yourselves

unbeliveable river life. This river never sleeps, there is always some interesting traffic on the river. Can spend all day & night just watching the river scene. Suggest you get a iver view room at one of the riverside hotels.

Chao Phraya express. Purchase all day tickets for unlimited hop on hop off use. Great for visiting the grand palace, Wat po and Wat arun. Good value and great views. Can get really busy at peak hour so be warned!

Lazy afternoon. Take a klongtour on a lazy afternoon. Experience the way Thai live al the water from a longtailboat that is rather noisy. Feed the fish, see a temple anmd try not to doze off in the warm afternoon gliding over the water. I loved it and think it's a great way to get to know Bangkok.

Take the passenger ferry for a few baht. How cheap can you be on tour? this is it... Go all the ay and you leave Bangkok city precinct.The ride on the ferry is a spectacular way to see the city from the river, the old the new and the i can not believe they survived the flood houses....you can also see the nw hospital wing which is reputed to be the place built for His Majesty The King when he is ill.

Worth a trip. Rode on a public ferry - very crowded in daytime but not late afternoon/evening. Went to the end of the line for a round trip of about 2.5 hours. Hardly cost anything. Sunset setting over the many temples along the route on the way out and all lit up in the dark of the way home. Would gladly opt for this over the long tail boats which charge whatever the market will bear and are noisy.

Boat trip is a must at Night. Done this trip down river at night good night out,Food on the boat Help yourself Buffet.Going again Next week on my Birthday 8th Feb.Big one 65.Also on Feb 14th with my Thai Wife .Love it.

It's dirty, smelly and polluted!. It's dirty, smelly and polluted, like most rivers that run through major cities. We took the "tourist boat" ride along the river. Probably best to start using your ticket earlier in the day to get best value, we got on the boat at about 1pm so we went to the Grand Palace and back. the best place to get off the sky Train to get the boat is Siam.
good transport. good way of travelling where the sky train wont get you there, cheap

great spot to people watch. The river is a great spot to watch the boats and people pass by. You can also check out the architecture of a metropolis if you are in to that sort of thing. It's also a great spot to read a book and or smoke cigarettes if you poison yourself like i sometimes do.

You Must See This !. While places like Phuket and Koh Samui are great, they are really just Tourist Resorts, and you do not see the real Thailand. The best way to see this is to spend an hour in a longtail boat exploring the river and maze of canals along the river. Yes you will see numerous temples etc, but so will also see how the other half of Thailand lives, in dilapidated wooden shacks with corrugated iron roofs, rotten wooden floors with holes in the floor which double as toilet facilities while children are outside fishing in the river. And just when you think you have seen everything, you find another dilapidated shack with a satellite dish on the roof ! This tour is a real eye-opener, and one of the most memorable days of out two weeks in Thailand. The boats themselves are amazing with their huge V8 engines. And then you get the locals in their boats pulling up alongside you to sell you food, souvenirs etc. This is a trip everyone should do - Thailand really is a country of contrasts.
Take a longtail tour on the river.. It´s nice to go by longtail and "cool off" in the small narrow channels connecting to Chao Phraya.
Love it!!. Take a cheap express boat along the river in the non-rush hour is the save and nice way to travel between attractions along the river.

Must see. It is a very smelly dirty river but is the gateway to seeing how the people of Bangkok live and the floating market the locals use for lunch can't be beat. The long boats were fun and a neat experience. I had one myself for about $50 for two hours. Seemed expensive but it was a private excursion. Enjoyed it.

Nice to see both by daylight and at night.. One afternoon we took the skytrain down the to dock where we caught the tourist boat. Very cheap and very relaxing to move up and down the river and see all the sights. Also much cooler than trudging around the streets of Bangkok. The next night we had a dinner boat cruise. Also definitely worthwhile. The boat leaves from River City mall/complex and goes upstream past the modern suspension bridge. We were on the Grand Pearl. The entertainment was good and the food excellent. I highly recommend it. Even though we had seen the sights by daylight, this was more romantic and prettier.

Different aspect of a frenetic city. We have been on the `Orange Flag`. river service,several times. It can be used for easy access for most of the major attractions in the city or continue upstream, for the one hour journey to the suburb of Nonthaburi. Undeveloped and teeming with local life there is an interesting local market,not far from the pier and some good food stalls,close-by, which are popular with uniformed children,for a .post-school snack. Few `farangs` venture this far.! Arrange to do the trip ,mid-afternoon, when it`s cooler,returning around 5pm. You will find this view of Bangkok magical, at dusk, when the riverside is filled with fairy-lights and all the bridges , illuminated.
Main river of Thailand.. Nice screenary. Cruise dinning is offer. Boat day trip to temple along Chao Phraya River is a choise.
Nice all year round. Always nice and peaceful in all season. All year round.
Don't miss is.. Definitely worth a "one time" boat ride on the river, even if it's just a shuttle boat from your hotel to cross the river.
Travelling on the express boat is a lot of fun.. It's a great way to see the water side of Bangkok.

If you miss Chao Phraya, you've missed SE Asia. The Chao Phraya is the river of life. I love going up and down it on the river boats because you always see something new. As a westerner, it's totally cool b/c there's nothing like it in the West. And it's an efficient way to get around.

interesting. great to see the city from a different view, haggle for decent long tail boat price (1000baht for 3 we paid for 1hr tour) they do take you to floating sellers who have extortionate prices
Wonderful Time. I took a boat ride and was surprised with the flow of water so calm and smooth that the boat ride was just a wonderful experience.Suggest everyone to take it once when in Bangkok

Nice Evening Cruise. We went for a nice evening cruise on this river. Booking was done through our hotel. A lovely river cruise for almost 2 hours with food and music. There was Thai Cabarette on board.
The cruise takes one around the main manuments(temples, palace) which look amazing under the lights.

If you are in Bangkok you must take a ship at the Chao River. I took a dinner cuise, it was great, but if you don"t have time or interest to go to dinner, go only to see around, with public or private boats.

Best for Cruise!. Nice Cruise services they have and lot to chose from. Do go for dinner if possible and they offer international music on board. Booking can be done at all hotels in the city. Do bargain the price as its not fixed.
Food could be disappointment as its lacks variation and quality.

Great way to see another side of Bangkok. Taking a public tourist boat along the river is a great way to glimpse another side of Bangkok. Plus if there's a bit of a breeze, you'll get some respite from the heat.
You could spend all day on and around the river. Everything is there: efficient "exotic" transport, stunning views, easy access and stop anywhere for a new experience and snack

It's a river!. The river spans quite a long distance, so I'm not sure how to review it... There are some spots with nice views. The riverboats are useful for traveling back and forth. What can I say? It's a river!

Get a Bangkok map from 7-11. There are many piers and some big water taxis that make the trip up and down the river. We paid 52 baht on the boat. You can get the names of all the landmarks from the map. A rice Barge cruise costs 800 baht/ person to see some dilapidated homes on the canals and eat some basic fruit.

Hire a boat. Hired a boat for a private 1.5hr trip for our group of 8 and had a fantastic time cruising up and down the river - went through the smaller canals which gave us a much closer look at Bangkok experience, than any of the overcrowded tourist sites and/or guided tourboats would have provided.

River bus. It's definitely worth taking the river bus at least once. It goes really fast and you need to cover your mouth when you talk so water doesn't get in. It seems to be the way many locals travel, inexpensive and efficient.

Chao Phraya river ferry. You can get the skytrain to Taksin and go down and purchase a daypass for the ferry for 150baht. Hop on and off along the route all day they give you a map so you know which quay to get off at for all the sightseeing.

Main river in Bangkok. This was the river across which we did multiple ferry rides in Bangkok to visit various buddhist temples.The experience was awesome.The river is not very clean but the atmosphere is nice.Can also go to china town and the floating markets from here.

don't miss it. we traveled thru to go every were, we could see the Grand Palace.
We must be respectful with the monks, as they cannot be touched by women.

Relax and enjoy the vistas.. A river trip never fails to show you beauty and relax you. Very good for the heart and the psyche. Take a ride on the Tourist boat and the express boat, both of which connect to skytrain network at the opposite end of the line serving national stadium. Also try a canal trip (up the klongs!), which again leaves from the terminal serving the Imperial Palace.
Boat Ride along Chao Phraya River. Good if you can get an unlimited boat pass to hop on and off to visit the various places of interest
go to Oriental hotel and enjoy the view. breakfast or dinner, sit by the river and watch the scenery float by. Like you are in an earlier century.

Take a ride!. We took a ride down the river and were able to see the city from a whole new perspective. It was amazing how quickly the glitz and glitter of the city fell away when we were drifting down amongst the houses where the people live. A very different perspective, indeed.
Our favorite place in the World. So much to see and full of life and atmosphere, a special place in our view. Don't miss a trip on the express boats!
You have to do a longtail cruise. The river is best seen from the river. We did both a longtail cruise up the canals and a dinner cruise one evening. Best way to see the city by day and night!

Fun to take a ride down the Chao Praya. We liked riding the Ferry Express (although its all a bit confusing if you don't speak Thai when you get to the ticket counter) - but the river is a bit dirty these days. It would be great if they could clean things up a bit. We kept thinking perhaps some of it is remnants from the fall flooding. Great way to see Bangkok.

A private boat ride. A great experience to see the river and canals- loved that we stopped to buy souvenirs from a lady in a boat... some of the housing is sad (poverty) but I think you need to see all angles of Bangkok.

Most beautiful river in Bangkok. I did many trip on this Chao Phraya River whenever I have time or need to go somewhere that it saves my time for travelling, no traffric. You can also combined the trip with BTS at Thaksin Station. My las trip in Jan 2012 but need to share travelling information. Day time is good for tourist to vist temples, wholesales market for gift shop and shoes in Sampheng, cloth in Pahurat Market and Golden market in Yaowaraj. If you have time, you can do the day trip to Koh Kred in Nontaburi by public boat but should do in the weekend so that you can enjoy the local market on Koh Kred that has open on Friday, Saturday and Sunday only. Night time is another experience for this river, more beautiful but there is no pulbic boat to operate. You have to try the dinner cruise on Chao Phraya River. There are 2 kinds of cruises for wooden style and moder style that has operated for dinner for 2 hours. If you need some quiet and no light music, you can try the wooden boat. For modern style, there are many cruise with light music. All cruises have same view but after eating for one hour, you will see the different of each cruise. I would recommend Chaophraya Cruise that food is good, staffs are so friendly and entertainers. When you finish your dinner, the boat will return to the same route. The cruise staffs will invite you to dance with them so that you can feel as home and not boring if you have to see the same view again. A lot of fun on the cruise with these cruise's staffs.
A great place. Personally think being around river best place to stay, easy to move around
A great evening. We did a Grand Pearl dinner cruise in the evening along the river, the boat and food served were gorgeous and seeing the Temple's lit up in the evening was wonderful also

Go for an afternoon out on the river. We always (for the last fifteen years that we've been visiting Bangkok) take the river taxis that ferry the locals up and down the river. It costs mere cents to go from Oriental station down to the Wat Po station (you can visit this while you're there in a relatively short time). The best thing to do on your way home is stop in at the VERY BASIC cafe on the pier and drink a beer. There's total mayhem going on in that place all of the time. It's definitely not posh but loads of fun and the toilet is an adventure! We've never eaten there but see loads of tourists who do - food is literally cooked in front of you.

Great way to travel and see some of the city. We were staying by the river and found it quite handy when we were across the city and wanted to return to our hotel. Around rush hour many of the tuk tuk and taxi drivers don't like to drive across the city, but will take you to the river where you can easily hop on a ferry.

Perfect for all kinds of mood and movie-setting!:). I loved it. Especially the speedy ferry trips up and down of river. Crazy mixture of Hong Kong styled business buildings and Buddhist pagodas along the riverbank. Nice photogenic views from many places, i loved the theme of the park near Phra Sumen Fort for instance. A scent of long history, serious buisness mixed with adventure and romance in the air above the river stream:) A point not to miss while in Bangkok!

The lifeblood of old Bangkok. In the shadow of glimmering Wats, towering condos and spanning bridges is the most taken for granted treasure of Bangkok, the lowly Chao Phraya River. Slow old barges, zippy river buses and tourist-trap party boats all ply the river in number but the story of this river and its impact on modern Thai history make this heavily polluted, murky brown, waterway a must-see attraction in Bangkok. Sure you can take a tour boat or hire a long boat to take you on a tour (negotiate your price well) but there are also a few affordable ways to experience this ancient piece of Thai history.. You can ride the boat bus down the river and back for about 20-40 baht each way (depending on how far you go), or sit on the wall over looking the river in the park at the top corner of Pra Arit. I can't remember the name but you can't miss the white fort on the corner. Another great place we enjoyed watching the river life float by was at the Thai BBQ restaurant by the ferry dock on the ThonBuri side of the Pra PinKlao Bridge (which is at the end of Pra Arit). Just walk over the bridge and you can't miss the restaurant. All you can eat BBQ and soup (you cook it yourself and its an experience not to be missed), for 165 baht, which includes free water, pop and an entire night of live music (some good, some terrible). Beer is same price as the convenience stores! If you get there and are thoroughly confused as we were. Just watch the locals and you'll catch on quick. However you see it, enjoy Chao Phraya River! Cheers and happy travels.

Fresk and convenient. The Chao Praya River is a great escape from the city hustle and bustle. It gives a good idea of Bangkok fluvial activity. The skyline is also worth seeing from this angle. Another major advantage is that you can hop into one of the many water taxis, which will take you from the Shangri-La hotel to the Royal Palace quickly and at an unbeatable price.

New Year's Eve. We sailed down the river on N.Y.Eve on a 'dinner cruise'. Lovely Thai buffet, dancers, wonderful views and fireworks at midnight. A brilliant night. These cruises go nightly I believe (without the fireworks!) A lovely way to spend an evening.

Avoid Hotel Piers. There are different piers for hotels and for the public.Cabbies and tuk tuks will tend to take you to hotel piers where tour operators will try to sell you on a private boat tour, which is fine if that's what you're looking for.However, for DIY travelers who just want to take the water taxis for a buck and change, make sure you go to the public piers like Sathorn (Central Pier)Overall, it's a great, cheap way to see the city.

Sunrise. Try having early breakfast on the terrace of the Oriental Hotel. The view on the river and the rising sun make a perfect setting. Not cheap, but then most good things in life are a bit more expensive.
speedy and fun. sed the " locals " boat do do some cheap sightseeing along the river .... amazing views and an enjoyable experiance

Great river vew with local boat.... Crowed but a must do in Bangkok, go not with the touristboat but with the real public transport boat. Just get in en see where it ends, you always get back. Get off on every stop and look aroud.....
Interesting!. We went on a ferrie through here...Nice to get out on your own and explore.

A must do. This is an absolute must do for any visitor to bangkok. Do negotiate prices through your booking agent. Also insist on a on-deck seat, if possible close to the front where the artists perform live. A beautiful site seeing cruise with live music and a good buffet dinner is a memorable experience...
Join an evening cruise - many to choose from. Seeing Bangkok come alive at night time from a boating perspective was great. The lights and sight seeing brings a new perspective to the journey.
Spectacular. Best river in Asia. BAngkok cannot be known without having cruised this beautiful river. I recommend to choose and hotel by the river or a holiday rental.
best way to get around. cheap and convenient. best way to go around the city and do some sightseeing at the same time

The heart and soul of Bangkok. The best way to see the Chao Phraya River is to take the public water taxi service and grab a window seat. Highlights along the way will be the Oriental and Peninsula (two of the top hotels in the world) and Wat Arun. You can get off near the Grand Palace and Wat Pho and walk to those amazing attractions.
Great way to get around. The public boats are extremely cheap and offer some great photo opportunities, a guided tour on a longboat will cost considerably more so make sure you bargain hard

Great way to get to different attractions. from the BTS river station, take a fast ferry. Avoid the 150 Day pass unless you need as the trip fares are very cheap, 30 BHT onboard or less. Different routes also see http://chaophrayaexpressboat.com/ remember that the can be VERY crowded, dont expect a seat of view, and they don't stop for long, but are frequent.
Cheap fun and handy. Enjoyable and very cheap way to get around. Especially nice at dusk.
Busiest River in Bangkok. a great place to travel and hop around with public mode transportation for public to head to all main tourist attraction . .
Heart of the City. To some extent this is the very heart of Bangkok as people come and go on many, truly many, boats... unfortunately, it is also quite dirty and poluted...

Useful, interesting and modestly priced.. Some parts of old Bangkok are not that easy to reach by public transport, and that's where the river boats come in. For a few Baht, you can travel up the river, and got off at piers near many of the most interesting areas, Chinatown for example, or the Royal palace complex and the Wat Arun (hopping across the river on a ferry). The easiest way to gain access is from the BTS station of Saphan Taksin on the "Silom" line. A couple of hundred metres walk takes you to the Sathorn pier. Depemding on what you want to do, you can eithert take the ordinary boats, the Tourist boats or the Tourist Express. If you want to explore well up river and to hop on and off freely, the day trip ticket at 50Baht isn't such a bad idea. Otherwise, if all you want to do is to use the river as a means of access, just board one of the boats and pay the "boat conductor" who struggles past the crowds trying to collect from the people who have just boarded. Great fiun.
Nice River Boat Tour. Taking a tour down the river is nice but, beware of the individual boat rides. All day get off and get on boat tickets pretty cheap.

The heart of Bangkok. If you're in Bangkok a trip on the Chao Phraya River Express alongside local people is a must. The service is fast and efficient and it's a great way to get around the city and it's so cheap.
Even if you don't need to use the River Express, the ride is all part of the experience of being in Bangkok.

Cheap boat ride!. Very interesting! You get to see a lot of significant icons! The grand palace, Wat Arun, and lots of temples are visible from the river. It's also good for appreciating everyday life in Thailand.
Depending on where your boat lets you off there may be a small docking fee (around 20baht)

2nd Best Mode of Transportation In Bangkok. Best being the BTS! Tips on traveling the Chao Phraya River: Take BTS to Saphan Taksan Station, signs will lead you to stairs under the BTS to get to the boat dock, take the left dock, Do Not Prepay at the booth, they will charge you the tourist rate, cheaper to just get on the boat with the orange flag (all boats tend to look alike, except for their flags!!!), pay on board, ticket person will randomly come around for ticket purchase, about 50 Baht. Tourist boat more expensive, guide will point out sights but it is hard to hear and their English is not always good. You will know when to get off when you see the beautiful Wat Arun on the left of the river, stop also for the Reclining Buddha. You can get off here for Palace or wait for next stop. Traveling by river is always cooler and you can see all the great sights in Bangkok.
riverboat. As an attraction, there is not much to draw your attention. It is a convenient way to get around, though.

Fun for Sightseeing. We took one of the express ferry boats, it was about 18 baht for the entire route which took around an hour and a half. It was a fun way to see the city, wats and houses. We exited at the last stop and walked through a giant food market and had an amazing lunch. You can also get off at numerous stops and visit the attractions. Look for the flag on the boat to see what stops it makes and then buy your ticket on board.
Go by river. Everyone should catch a local ferry - you can view many temples along the way, enjoy the river and watch the boats & hop on and off easily. So cheap too.
amazing place to ride thru a motor boat. take the canals also, hire a private boat, see the lifes around the canals, feel like u are in Panama canal when waiting for the waters to be balanced.

Fabulous Overview of Bangkok from the Water. The Chao Phraya River is a main artery of Bangkok, and carries all manner of traffic. A trip on the boat will reveal up close, barges with recycled steel, houseboats of poor families, tourist boats of rich hotels, private boats of businesses and so much more. Some boats are marked tourist. These cost more and you will get a seat. They are also much less interesting than travels with local people carrying supplies, school children in uniform, monks in saffron, and so on. The color of the boat flag indicates the type of boat and I forget if yellow is tourist or not. Ask.
Ferry boat. Managed to go on this despite flooding and were glad we did! Inexpensive, great views and mixing with friendly locals.

flooding when we were there. The river was flooding when we were there and the water was muddy and lots of debris floating around. We took a short ride on a longtail boat but were not much impressed with the tour but the boats themselves are impressive.
Bustling beauty. It was so wonderful to see the activity on the water as well as on its banks ... booth by day and night.

Travel round bangkok by river boats.. The boats run up and down the river constantly. I went on the tourist boat for some of the trips. the information given by the guide can be quite amusing. And is informative to take once.
River system is very quick and at 15baht a trip is very affordable and fun.

Bangkok sightseeing by river. Take the Skytrain to Saphin Taksin, go down to the pier, take a The River express or one of the tour boats if you want a commentary (given In English & Thai ) on all the sights as you progress up the river.Very reasonably priced indeed, you can get on and off at will, and cross the river by ferry to visit the mighty Wat Arun, (Temple of Dawn) probably still Bangkok's most distinctive landmark.Try to avoid getting splashed by river water, especially around the mouth and the face.

Best way to travel in Bangkok. We love travelling in the local boats. Very cheap travelling and you get to mix with the locals. Costs 15 baht for any length of journey and you buy tickets on the boat. Avoid paying for tourist tickets at double the price. Express boats are even cheaper. Check out the stops by the coloured flags on back of boats to tell you what stops they make.

Good Way to see the city. This was one of the first tours we did in Bangkok and it was an eye-opener! the contrast of the high rise buildings next to the shacks that line the river where families live was a sight to behold. Make sure you take some cash with you to buy goods from the "floating market" which is basically men & women in small boats that come up to your boat. No pressure to buy either.

Sunset cruise, khlong tour, river trip.. Many ways to enjoy the river. You can use the ferries which act as river taxis, go on a dinner cruise, sunset cruise or cruise back from Ayuthaya, the ancient city. My favourite is to explore the khlongs or canals by Longboat. You need to go for a couple of hours, morning is best. You can take in the floating market, Wat Arun and finish at the Royal Palace. You can go on a tour or negotiate a private boat. Then If you don't want to stop at things like the croc farm,snake show etc simply tell your driver to keep going. It gives you a unique view of another side of life. I have seen giant iguana on the banks.
Good Fun. Good way to see parts of the city and cheap means of travel. Try to avoid ruch hour though - can feel claustrphobic and you cant believe how many people can fit onto a ferry!!!

The main artery of Transportation. The Chao Phraya River is about 370 kilometer Long, originated from the Central part of Thailand , Nakhon Sawan province , there are four river flow down from the north , meet together, then became the chao Phraya River. It became the main artery of Transportation since the old time untill present day, also now it become popular for tourists as River tour and Canal tour, which there are lifestyle of the people along the River and Canal ( nearby ) to be interested, also many important Temples and Grand Palace also situate on the River bank.
Taxi!. Loved the river taxi service. Fun and cheap! Hopped on at Wat Pho and arrived near the end of the service route to catch a Tuk-Tuk to our hotel.

Very Busy River. My wife and I took the boat (used like a city bus) from two stops further than the Grand Palace back to the Royal Orchid Sheraton Hotel a twenty five minute ride for the equilent of $1.00
interesting. great way to travel and to see Bangkok and the suburbs from the water
Terrific!. Use the Orange ferries to go up the river-so cheap and very interesting.
Busy. Loved travelling the river on the tourist boats. Great way to see the sights without all of the hustle and bustle of the streets.

No need to arrange private boat. Public water taxi works great.. Twice I've visited the Chao Phraya River, in January 2008 and again just this month (January 2012). When you get to the pier, there are several to choose from, vendors will be quick to try to have to arrange for a private boat or tour. In 2008 I purchased an open ticket for the day for the water taxi. They give you a sticker then you can get on and off where you want to, visit temples, go out to eat on shore then get back on the boat, etc. The public water taxi's are roaming up and down the river. This last trip, we arrived too early to our guest house to check-in (see my review of the Sri Ayuttaya Guest House in Bangkok), so we dropped off our bags and caught a Tuk Tuk to the pier not realizing how close we were. We couldn't figure out where to purchase the day pass that I did in 2008, but learned you can purchase a one-way ticket as you load the boat. For example, we caught the public taxi and paid 40B each. A woman is there to take your money, then you get off when you want. The boat is stopping at each pier so it is quite easy. We didn't know where we were but we kept track by remembering the bridges we'd pass. We got off at a pier, I think it was 22 and walked around. In short order we found food stands and lots of yummy treats, including grilled bananas. Then when we were ready, we went back to the pier and hopped on the boat once more. This time our ticket was 30THB each. We took a guess at where to get off and hit it right, at pier 15. There is a timelessness to floating down the river and taking in life: We had fun just taking in the sites of the river. Red and golden buddhist temples, rickety houses built on stilts, other boats zooming by, people netting snails and fish, monks getting on and off the public river taxis, etc. We did learn after our most recent boat trip that the seats in back are reserved for the monks, but luckily we didn't sit there. Enjoy! I know we did.
River of life. Thai people live with this river for many years so you will see from the original life style until the 5 star hotel around here ;) especially at night with pretty light in everywhere.

Nice boat ride experience.. It's a long boat ride along the river. You could see houses besides the river. You may encounter people selling souvenirs along the river & this is what they call "small floating market".

One of my Fave days out. I love taking a river taxi and going out on the Chao Phraya, you can go down klongs and see how life really is in the "real" bangkok, take a trip to the floating market where watching the traders jump from boat to boat selling their food or wares is a great experience, a trip to Bangkok should always include a trip along the River or Kings!
Great way to get around!. Very inexpensive for single location (less than .50c USD) for a single stop each way or you can get a hop on hop off deal all day for only $6USD

Nice way to get to the temples. We took the skytrain to the Sampan Taksin station and then decided to take the Chao Phraya tourist boat up the river to get off on the stop at Wat Phra Kaew and the Grand Palace. Nice experience to get on a longboat powerboat style ferry to cruise the river up to the area of the temples. Avoids the traffic in the area during peak times. Price was also very cheap (15 THB per person)

Don't miss a fast ferry ride on the Chao Phraya. I never miss this every time I come to Bangkok.. Ferries are cheap, fast and great fun. Great way to view the interesting variety of shipping along this prime artery of Bangkok. Nice sights along both shorelines as well.

Take the public boat. Taxi drivers mostly will bring you to a different pier and offer you tourist boat because they get commission. Or they will lie on you saying public boat runs every hour. DO NOT BELIEVE ANY of the drivers... The public express boat is actually 30Baht for one way and 150Baht All day pass while they charge 800 Baht for tourist boat.

A bit boring. Not much to see on the canal. Ladies on other long tail boats try and sell you over priced drinks and junky souvenirs. My driver was not friendly and went so fast that I had a hard time trying to take pictures. Don't go alone they charge a lot more, try and get a group together, better deal.

Busy Waterway!. A facinating place to be and watch what floats and sails bye... We have taken a long tail boat trip into the depths of where the locals live, we have also cruised in a rice barge and had a fruit smorgasboard (was lovely) and stayed in a 5 star hotel on the river and watched the world float bye. There is a nice sitting area at the Millenium Hilton hotel where you can dine out doors or sit on the lovely couches and watch the busy river.
very long river. most of the famous hotels are on the bank and many shuttles use it which is very pleasent for tourists, had a long trip that we enjoyed very much

Nice cheap transport and a good way to see the city. take the Express boat - hop on and off where you want (you have to pay everytime, but it's still cheap) use if for Grand Palace and Wat Poo, flowermarked and china town - connect with skytrain

Average Experience. There is not much to write home about the Chao Phraya River cruise. Other than seeing buildings, temples and major hotels there is not much to learn in terms of historic sites and history of thailand. However if you venture out on one of the stops to China Town or the temples am sure you will get better experiences.Warning: China Town is a hustle and bustle small lane with people bumper to bumper walking up and down.

Best kept secret. The river is quite an attraction for Bangkok but it seems that few tourists know about it, expecially the ones who stay in the Sukhumvit area. In fact living by he river is the right thing to do. Now many five stars hotels and vacation rentals are located in this beautiful area. Do not stay somewhere else, the river is charming.
Very busy waterway. We took the tourist boat, a long boat and the night cruise up the river. Gives a different perspective to the city. Trips are not expensive and there are lots of boats.

Public cruising. Use the public pier boat and cruise the full length of the river jumping off and on when you want to. Lovely breeze to take away the immense heat. There is also a speaker giving you some tourist info so make sure you get on the right boat. Each boat has a country flag so you know which one to get onto.

Awesome - cheap entertainment, great transport. Whether travelling by free Sheratob barge to Skytrain, using river bus to access an attraction (Wats, palaces, shopping, restaurants), crossing it on an absurdly cheap shuttle ferry, or just sitting in your room at the Sheraton watching all the activity, the river is great entertainment and is a real attraction of staying in this area.
Endless fun. Watching all the activity on the river. it looks dirty but its always active

A great overview of Bangkok. To get a feel for the city, take a tourist boat trip: you can hop on and off at different piers all day long for one ticket. As you go along the river you'll see temples, houses on stilts, longboats, barges, skyscrapers and luxury hotels. Markets, museums, the Grand Palace, temples, restaurants are all within walking distance of the pier stops, and the boats themselves are more comfortable than the local ferries.
Sailing down the river. Stayed at the Peninsula hotel so we had a boat take us across the river any time but we also did a long boat trip good fun.

Dinner cruise. A nice alternative - but not as festive or entertaining as expected. I know there are a large number to choose from - I know ours left from the Riverside Shopping Centre jetty (by the Sheraton). It was comfortable and organised but there was a long delay between arriving at the departure point (by shuttle) and departure. (I guess having to take Bangkok traffici nto consideration it may be unavoidable.)It was not advertised as a seafood cruise but even the salads / sushi and pastas mainly had seafood. There was also meant to be Thai traditional dancing which there wasnt - but the singer wa quite good and worked hard at getting people up and dancing.Perhaps it depends a lot on the group you are with.Its worth the outing - just dont have huge expectations.
Use the water Taxis they are cheap & efficient. Our hotel overlooked this busy river and we used the water taxis on it which were incredibly cheap to beat the Bangkok traffic. Well worth it.

Best way to see Bangkok’s appearance. We paid Bht. 500 for a full day boat trip named Chao Phraya Express, the Express started from Maharaj Pier at around 8pm at and finished at Sathorn Pier around 17pm. We passed almost beauty of Chao river, from Wat Chalerm Phrakiet to Wat Paramaiyikavart, we were surprised at the beauty of the golden terrace, amazed at the ancient of Wat Pailom , the lovely old temple in Trat town (visited outside only). You can buy the ticket at Pier (recommended way to getting away scammed. In any ways, this was such a memorable experience of a Bangkok.
Fun way to get around. One of the best ways to enjoy a leisurely day in Bangkok, see the sights, and to get around. Price is right too. Yes, the water is dirty, you're in Bangkok.

Nice trip down the river. Getting a long boat ride down the Chao Phraya is a great idea. We went on a trip to some floating markets. The water was dirty (it is a river afterall) and there was lots of plant material and some rubbish floating abount (maybe in part because of the recent floods?)Regardless it is a great way to see Bangkok and I would highly recommend a visit.
Excellant travel. A bargain in travel in Bangkok. Don't take the tourist boat as the regular boats are don't 50 cents and make all the same stops. Great sights along the way
express boat. the chao phraya express is very efficient way to get around bangkok
A Must. A boat/river trip is a must when you visit Bangkok. It is eye opening to observe just how the locals live up the canals on the river. good 1/2 day trip

Dinner cruise Chao Phraya. Had a wonderful evening cruising down the Chao Phraya with Chao Phraya cruises on Christmas Eve. Not only is it great to see the temples lit up at night, the food was absolutely scrumptious. Highly recommend you doing this one.

fun boat ride. be sure to take the regular boat as opposed to the tourist boat! It's off a big cement pier and you pay when you get on--12-13 baht for one way. If they are quoting you hundreds or even 50 baht that is not the right boat unless you want a personal long boat tour. The tourist boat also gets super crowded. The normal boat sometimes is less so. Pay attention to flag colors, they'll tell you which boats are which. You should be able to obtain a pamphlet at the pier that explains this or it should be in any guide book.

Lots to see as you travel along. Be sure to take a detour down a canal to see the tiny houses built on the river. The tv satellite dishes were a special touch on the houses with verandahs falling into the canal.
Sathorn pier. We recommend the company working out of this pier. I prefer the khlong tour rather than the river as you see more of how Thais live along the river.

Convenient Travel - a Must experience. Whether using the river for its efficient & convenient travel, it's a great Bangkok experience. Mix with the locals on these crowded, but safe boats There are also several "touristy" Barge trips with dinner. Take them for what they are you wil enjoy the evening cruises.Side trips down the many canals are also available, where you will catch a glimpse of real Bangkok life by the river.
Great place to spend an hour or 2. If you can get a room with a balcony overlooking the river then spend time watching the world go by.
Great views. we bought a day pass on the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat and spent the day hopping on and off to view the sites

Take a river taxi ride. For inexpensive travel and a nice afternoon, take the river taxi up and down the river for the afternoon. There are frequent stops as it pulls up to the many docs to take on new customers, but it gives you a great view of many of the sites in BKK and you can access several temples from there. Take a bag of fresh fruit along to snack on and enjoy the ride.

Cheap and Nice View. I loved travel by boat. From N1 to N13 was only THB15. Don't buy tourist pass because you have to pay THB150. Queue at Saphan Taksin pier and just get on the boat. You have to pay on the boat like what other Thais do.

Nice way to travel. A nice way to travel through the city, although the boats are a bit slow(did not try longtail). The water is very dirty. Can be a bit confusing with all the boats, and some piers are poorly marked (pier name not displayed). Still a nice way to get to many of the main attractions.

Oasis in the middle of hectic Bangkok. Traversed the river several times, including a trip up to N30, the most northern stop. Very pleasant trip that is in sharp contrast to the hectic chaotic mess that is Bangkok transportation. Nice way to see a more local side to Bangkok in a pleasant way.
Spend time on this river. Teaming with life, boat trips step on step of brilliant value for money

Great way to get around.. Make use of the local river ferry's ,it's the best way to mingle with the locals,very cheap & there are stops all up & down the river.Plenty of local food stalls at various stops,with great selections of local foods.
not much. there wasnt really much to see.but its still important you have an experience before you leave bangkok

Eh, it's a river.. Ok, do not let your hotel send you on one of those long boat rides... choppy choppy waters will make for a less than relaxing ride. The view from the river is best had from the terrace at the Mandarin Oriental or the boat buses that go up and down the river. But the view is just ok...

Highlight of our trip. We stayed at Chatrium hotel located along the banks of this river. I spent many hours sitting in the balcony just looking at the river. Never boring! Plus the X'mas eve fireworks on the river were a bonus!

love the river!. I remember a poem by T.S. Elliot in which he said, "I think that the river is a strong, brown god..." -this is the Chao Phraya. Bangkok is so pleasant from the river, whether on a ferry or a small rented boat - it is definitely worth spending some time on the river.
love it. really you will remember venice. just like venice when it gets busy only the buildings/ shanties are different. A lot of tourists too .

Amazingly alive. I expected Chao Phraya river to be really dirtly and not that appealing. However, when getting to its shores, it really amazed me. The river was filled with plants, but not only. It was also full of fish that fishermen caught and served fresh on its shored. We even saw a very big lizzard, similar to a Komodo dragon - quite scary, but so interesting. The river is also very large, taking you to the biggest attractions, and well served by boats. You can also see beautiful traditional barges on it and have a cruise at night to admire the beautiful lit city

Cruise the river on the way to the Grand Palace.. There are plenty of boats available daily if you just want a short cruise up the river and it is very cheap. You just pay on the boat. We took a short trip up the river to the Grand Palace. There is some great food available when you get off. Another way to enjoy the river is to take a dinner cruise.

Take a Boat Ride. A long tailed boat ride for an hour or two along the River and through the canals of Thonburi will give you a unique insight into a city that had almost no "roads" a century ago (hard to imagine currently).
Great way to spend half a day on the boat. Take the local boat here, the perfect thing to do....cheap, lots to see, surrounded by locals!

The river makes bangkok 'Venice of the south-east Asia'. To review a river is not easy. The natural resources have their great importance for the country directly or indirectly. So we must understand its importance for the locals before writing anything . A trip to Chao Phraya river is really cheap and exciting medium to see the city no traffic jam, no crowd, not much cost, no tension.....to visit temple just across the river is only 3 bhatt one way...you can either take a long tailed boat or dinner cruise to experience this river and see how the river has become the integral part of the life of locals. We enjoyed a lot in 'flowing' with the water of the river. A must among few must attractions while in Bangkok.

One of the Biggest River in Thailand!. I was told by a tour guide that it is one of the biggest river in Thailand. It was a shame to see that it was not well maintained. I learned that the recent floods had made the river to overflow.The banks of the river look beautiful.. If not for the river, the banks are a must visit.

a must try. A relaxing 30 minute cruise along the river. You can view the lights of the riverside hotels, wat arun, rama bridges and the backside of the grandpalace. Dinner buffet usually comes with thai and intercontinental buffet. A must try at least once when visiting Bangkok. I want to try the ones with old rice barge though next time.
River restaurants. On the river and next to the river are so many places to eat and enjoy. The choice of the restaurants are to much! Also the dinner cruises on the river are great.

Public transport. Thw metro and sky train do not extend into the "hub" of the city where the temples and riverfront areas are concerned. So the boat piers are a 10 minute walk from the train station metro and can take you a long way up the river. Not quite the "Venice of Asia" like some suggest but still beautiful. Just look for the colour flag and pay the 15-150 baht for the ride. Worth the trip

You really MUST take a boat trip down Chao Phraya when in Bangkok.. The last five trips to Bangkok have been with friends or colleagues and I've been their main tour guide. Every trip includes a trip on one of the tour boats that ply the Chao Phraya River as it gives you a unique perspective on the city and most of them allow you to get on or off the boat at any one of the marked piers so you can explore and then continue your adventure. My advice is to take the entire tour first if you have time - a bit more than an hour - and then go back to the places that most interest you. Do not buy tickets from anywhere except at the piers where they originate and look for the ones that go down the main river - not the little side canals unless you have lots of time and have already toured the Chao Phraya first.

Important. Whoever sees the banks do not realize the importance of the river to the city of Bangkok. There are transported people, products, food, everything is possible. Although not a clean river, it is not hard to see people fishing for fish and the boat trips. It's great to pick up the Chao Phraya Express and feel a little closer to the local population, not to mention that this is an excellent, cheap and safe means of transport.
Ferry boats.. Great place for a day exploring sight seeing, and looking at temples.

Nice part of the Bangkok experience. Another unique experience of a Bangkok visit. It is a water taxi, not a tour. Buy tickets at the Ticket Booth immediately before the Pier for THB 15. (Hawkers outside will try to rip you off). The trip provides another different view of the city. A bargain of an experience.
Take a Long Tail ride along the river. This is a must... Get a real sense of Thailand; visit the many historical places along the river. You will be glad you did....
A very busy river. before cruising on those fast local boatsAdvice number 1 Put suncream on your faceGet your own and visit temples along the river and forget alligators farm

Great views and a good Cheap trip. You get to see the old and the new, the palaces, the hotels, the shacks and can get a longtail boat to venture off into the backwaters. We got one day passes each so you can get on and off as many times as you like at a variety of different 'piers'. These are like floating platforms into which the boat driver has a kind of controlled crash during which passenegers jump on and off the boat!

Senery. This river and and the spots alongside are always great to see. There is a tourist boat every day, every hour giving you explanations in English about the interesting spots around the river. You can also go off and take the next one to visit places you like to see.
Try the dinner cruise!. We had our dinner on a Dinner Cruise and also night tour at the Chao Phraya River, which is lovely and unforgettable experience!
Great Trip. Do travel the Chao Praya River and for example take a trip to Ayutthia. You be amazed what you see along the River.

A good way to see Bangkok. Took a river cruise that served buffet dinner and had a band entertaining the guests. There was a good spread of food including prawns and roast beef but the best thing was the picturesque temples and bridges beautifully lit up at night.

Great place to sight see. You get to see everything in this river. Depending on which area you're in you get to see the luxury hotels or very poor houses right on the water. The transportation boats came pretty often and were comfortable to ride in. Definitely worth doing while there. If you don't know how to use the system and feel like you can't figure it out go with a guide, like I did :)
Take a river taxi. For 15 baht (50 cents) it is a wonderful ride along the river. No need to pay for a tourist boat.

By boat in 1 hour. We rented a boat (with its driver of course) for 750B each (scaaam) and went along the river. I saw the big difference between rich and poor and scared me! Big modern buildings and wooden houses wrecked by the recent floodings. Interesting but a bit strong. In addition, the boat was so not safe!

Beautiful and good for transport!. Sit on one of the restaurants along the river and soak in the atmposhpere. Watch the boats of all kinds. Go for a river cruise. Use it for fast transport. Use the luxury hotels free hotel shuttles for free sightseeing! You will enjoy the cool breeze from the river after a day in the city. When I stay in Bangkok i always want to stay in a hotel by the river.

River Travel!. Travel by river gets you around the city quickly. The express boats really are quick! Forget about Health & Safety regulations. You have to jump on quick, before the gap opens too much, or they go without you. Allow about one minute to off load all passengers and pick up the next ones! The ferry that plies across the river is very cheap and efficient though the landing stages leaves a bit to be desired.All craft compete for the same water so ferries, river boat cruises and enormous rice barges make sure that the river is alwas busy. An eveing dinner cruise is good fun and the boats are so colourful with their flourescent and neon lights .

One of my favourite places. Always something different on the river. One can take an hour trip on the express boat for 15 Baht which is the best bargain in Thailand. The tourist boat costs 30 Baht but only goes to Khaosan Road area. The prices are per trip for however many stops you travel.

Cruise and Buffet. Super enjoyed the cruise along Chao Phraya river from Ayutthaya back to the city. Loved the buffet especially the chicken curry! I'm not a fan of spicy food but their curry made me a believer!

The place to be in Bangkok. We stayed at a riverside hotel......adoring the changing light and personality of the Chao Phraya. We actually think the air is cleaner at the river.....another plus!We took the Orange Express boat to it's last stop: Nonthaburi, and enjoyed walking around.The only activity we couldn't do: take a long tail boat thru the khlongs. Water too high.For us.....memories of Bangkok always include the Chao Phraya.

Perfect Way to Get Around In Bangkok. The Chao Phraya Express Boats are a convenient, pleasant way to reach some of the top Bangkok tourist attractions, including the Grand Palace, Wat Po, and Wat Arun. Don't buy the expensive tourist ticket; simply pay on the boat--much cheaper.

Chao Phraya River. Brilliant. We missed our stop on the ferry so decided to go right to the end of the river and back again. Excellent way to see Bangkok. Still quite a bit of flooding and debris along the way, together with some people still being homeless.
The Floating Mrket.. The Floating Market which is about 110 KMS away from Bangkok is a must for anyone visiting Bangkok
GOOD EXPERIENCE. Great live music, brilliant atmosphere and some stunning visuals.the only downside was food but a good experience overall.

Something to do but.... It's better to observe the goings-on of the river than be on it. A lot happens in one hour - transport of good/people etc. The water looks filthy and has lots of unmentionables floating in it. Take the public transit up or down - it's an adventure and a cheap way to do 'the river'. Fancier tourist boats are available but I don't see the point in being on a slightly nicer boat over an equally gross river. Ah well

Great way to get around and see BKK from whole new perspective!. There are so many things to do along the Chao Phraya river! Even just walking the little lanes from pier to pier is quite the experience! We did that once when we went to the wrong pier and it ended up being one of the most fascinating parts of our trip! Anyhow, buying the one day pass for the chao phraya express boat is a great deal. it stops at 8 different piers. all the major tourist attractions are along here. You see Bangkok from a whole different perspective, and you miss and the heavy traffic jams! this is a great website to plan your journeys and find out where to buy your tickets:http://www.chaophrayaexpressboat.com/en/tourist/
Nice Boating experience. You can get a complete view of major Bangkok attractions by taking a Chao Phraya river cruise. Real nice experience.

nice sight seeing opportunity in Bangkok. If you want to do some sight seeing, take the ordinary boat going to Nonthaburi. This is a trip of 1 hour. Along the river, you'll see plenty of interesting sights. The fare is only 14 baht.

Scenic route. Although still in flood, the river was a great way to travel and see the sights at the same time. There was much flotsam but also many fish in evidence. The river is a very convenient and stress free way to get to your next destination and provides access to many of Bangkok's main attractions including the Grand Palace. Stay riverside and utilise the hotels' free boats too.

Great way to get around Bangkok. Buy a one day pass in the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat, and hop on and off. The boat make stops close to all the main attractions and it is the best way to avoid the insane traffic jams you´ll most likely end up in parts of the day. The saphan Taksin pier connects with the skytrain, and can take you to MBK and the other shopping malls in no time! You also get great views of Wat Arun.
Cheap and fast. Given the traffic in Bangkok the river boats are cheap and quick

Rice Barge Cruise - a great afternoon. We took the afternoon Rice Barge Cruise and it was a wonderful way to spend our first day in Bangkok, as we were all tired and didn't really fancy walking. We were picked up from our hotel and taken to Riverside where we climbed into a longtail boat for the trip around Thonburi. Very interesting as we got to see people living on the river and our kids enjoyed seeing the huge water monitors that live under the houses. For our return journey we transferred to a converted Rice Barge and got to eat heaps of local fruits.Well worth it.

relax and view. For only a few baht you can take one of the river boats up and down the river and get a different perspective on the city. There are many stops and it is easy to hop on and off. Better than sitting in a taxi trying to get to some of the attractions.

Use riverboat taxi. Fast.. We took it from Saphan Taksin station. The left side. There is only a sign for 150baht one day on the ticket office so you could think there is only that kind of ticket and you shall buy, but you could just pay in the boat in a very cheaper price. The boat runs until 7:30pm. It is faster than tuktuk or taxi and the view is nice. Sometimes the whistle which boatman makes is a little loud for you so take the seat far from the whistleman if you have so superior hearings.

Nonthaburi and back. If you are thinking of something different to shopping and want some fresh air the Chao Phrya Express to Nonthaburi is an ideal trip. The trip takes about 70 minutes (but is a little quicker coming back as it is downstream) and the boat terminates there so you know when to get off. Wander through the local shops, have a drink and then have lunch. A good choice for this is the riverside restaurant some 100 metres downstream from the terminal building. Boats for the return trip leave every ten minutes or so and sit on a different side coming back to wherever in the city you want to go next. It is a very inexpensive and enjoyable trip.

Second best thing to do in Bangkok. To the left of the Sheraton Royal Orchid on the river is a public dock to take a boat up or down river....HOWEVER there is also a man here who will rent you a boat and driver to take you on a private klong tour....for like $40 for two people. Tell him No alligator farm or boxing show....they are tourist traps. That said, life on the klongs is interesting and you will see giant lizards and people swimming and beautiful flowers....typical Thailand....of days past. Tell them only 1 hour...otherwise the wooden seat will get the best of you....You can also arrange for a stop at Wat Arun (temple of the dawn) and that is also beautiful to see. Cheers...Happy Travels! NYC

Extraordinaire. Lovely experience, we took a fast boat, the gentleman took us into the channel system back alleys we could see children's bathing and dipping into the river, locks doors allow you to move forwards into the channels, so you sit and wait until water is pump to the level required and you go into the next channel system, Highlights is the king fish feeding near the temple off the channel where the King fishes live, you are not allowed to fish but to feed them a very ingenious system of strings allow you to put your baths into a bucket in return you get bags of bread about a dollar a full bread bag aprox. half a kilo and you feed the King fish on tha,t you may be able to walk (joking) on the fish there is so many fish the water turns into a frenzy feeding thing, we love it. not cheap about USD 40.00 per head the trip but worth every cent.

River boat taxi. Take the local riverboat taxi from Saphan Taksin BTS station to the Grand Palace for a refreshing and unique experience of Bangkok river life. I still haven't figured out the whistle codes the drivers and dock hands use to slow the boats for 30 sec to let the passengers jump on and off. If you have more time, and want a more personal tour of the canals, a long tail boat for an hour is worth the extra expense. The riverboat taxi costs about 10 B while the long tail boat is about 1000 B.

"Bangkok River". This body of water is not to be avoided. The river is the main mode of transportation for Thai people. Long Tail Boats and Ferries constantly travel up and down this river. The Ferries are inexpensive and a great way to move around the city. A Long Tail Boat adventure is fun (especially to the floating market) but is relatively costly.
Relax and watch life on the river. Great and fun to be near the water and watch life float by. Also the areas and neighborhoods near the river are fun to walk around in.

Do not buy the tourist pass for 150bahts.. The promoters at the Saphan Taksin Station will advise you that it's a good deal, & the normal ferry tickets are not available. not true! DO NOT fall for the scam. Ticket vendors at other stations are more honest in advising the right fare.Just pay for the ticket as & when you need it.
Best way to get around and sightsee. The river taxi is the best and nicest way to get from Banglampu to the shopping malls!

Great Way to Experience a Different Side of Bangkok. I would highly recommend taking a boat on the Chao Phraya River. No need to rent an expensive boat or even take the boat cruise, just catch the ferry from one of the piers in Bangkok. A ticket from the Central Pier (2 minutes away from the Taskin BTS station) to Maharaja Pier will cost you 15 baht and will take you to the foot of the Grand Palace and other tourist attractions in the city. Take the boat with the orange flag - it stops at all the piers. There are also more 'express' ferries (blue and yellow flags if I am not mistaken) that cost a little bit more and stop only at the major piers. If you want to take the Chao Phraya Express at Central Pier you do not need to buy a ticket at the booth; line up as the locals do in the area behind the booth closest to the river. A ticket collector travels on each boat and you will pay on board.The ride is cheap, esay, and fast. Locals as well as toursits frequently use the ferry service - making this one of the more 'authentic' experiences in BKK. I work in Bankok, yet this remains one of my favourite activities when I need to clear my mind and forget that I am actually in Bangkok.
A sail down a fascinating River for 15 Bahts. Very dirty with flood water but quite an experience. Take the public river boat. I spent an hour on it for 15 bahts!
it was raining that night but the dinner cruise was great. water in river was high due to weather but all was great

Chao Phraya River Cruise - Excellent!!. It's a 2-hour cruise along the Chao Phraya with buffet dinner and a nice band playing easy-listening music. My family and I enjoyed this cruise tremendously. Food is satisfactory though not fantastic. The river is clean and does not smell bad like some river cruise in Malaysia. The scenery along the river is fabulous --- all the temples and major tourist attractions are lighted up at night and it is a very romantic cruise. After dinner, you can dance on the deck and the staff will dance with you if you dont have a partner. The toilets are hotel standard. I am most impressed and would highly recommend this cruise although it is a bit steep in price. Nevertheless, it is worth the price. There are 2 or 3 companies running the cruises, but I think the Chao Phraya cruise has the highest standards.

Ride the Long Tail Boats. the trip through the canals is a lot of fun and you see many styles of living on the river and in the canals. Make the stops at the tourist sites and if you see something you like and want to photo tell the driver and he will stop or back up for you.There are many sellers of things at high prices floating in the canals in their little boats.Fun. I do this whenever we come to Bangkok

Lots to see along the river & canals. Get a $5 all day pass on the express tourist ferry to get on and off for attractions such as the grand palace.Royal Barge musuem closed in November because of floods (no barges there). It is best accessed by water. It is a long walk (not very attractive after the bridge over the canal) from the ferry wharf so catch a taxi. Long tail speedo boats are about $30 each per hour and will get you around the canals as well as river. This is very expensive by Thai standards

I didn't get the hype.. We hired a boat for an hour tour along the river. It is a nice way to spend your time looking at the city, but I didn't find the sights to be very impressive. The river is definitely not the cleanest you'll find, and I suppose due to the recent floods there's lack of activity on the river. The "floating market" was a miserable boat selling souvenirs, and the "fish farm" was just swimming fishes in the river!

Boating the Chao Phraya River. What a fantastic way to spend a few hours. Get on and off whenever you like - there's lots to see apart from temples and palaces. Things such as the Medical museum, Chinatown, little India - it's all great - and the food - yummy to try lots of different styles and tastes.

River cruises from Ayutthaya. I've taken a small cruise on the Chao Phraya River while coming back from Ayutthaya. I liked the trip, but as it was a nice part of a already beautiful trip. So, I suggest to do the same, to make the cruise as part of another day trip, or maybe to make a evening cruise and enjoy a romantic dinner on board.

Good for transport - nothing else. Maybe I have been spoiled by Sydney Harbour and the Seine but the Chao Phraya is not a tourist attraction. The Express boats are only a means of transport - not an attraction in themselves (unlike the ferries on Sydney Harbour).

ferry service needs help. as suggested by the travel books and the hotel staff, we took the ferry in between most sights in Bangkok. Unless you keep chekcing with the ticket taker on the ferry, you will have no way of knowing when to get off. Flooding comes right up to the pier so we had to walk through filthy water to get to and from all the ferries. Also had to wait about 20 minutes for one of the ferries. That being said-it is the cheapest way to get around!

Great way to take in the city!. Travelling along the Chao Phraya river is a great way to take in the city. The boats are so cheap to travel on and stop regularly along the river. Even if you have no where in particular to get off along the river, take a trip on the boat its worth it!
must do. amazing scenery and tour. definitely get out at Wat Arun--wish i had time to do it.

Flooding has wiped out floating market. Many of the houses and buildings along the canals adjacent to the river remain under as much as ten feet of water (late November, 2011) and the many vendors who used to sell their wares by boat were completely absent during my trip. Make sure to bargain for your boat price unless you use one of the big vendors. By outward appearances, tourism is way off and you should be able to get a one-hour boat trip for 500 baht--or less.
Flood. We just visited the river and we would like to have a night trip, but We weren't on the trip because of the flood. The river is nice and is just 15 minutes walking from our hotel.

Best 'cheap activity' in Bangkok. Get a public river taxi-boat from Saphan Taksin Sky Train station (Silom Line of SkyTrain). The boat fare is only a few baht, and it will take you all the way up to Nonthaburi province, a ride of 1.5hrs if you get the non-express boat. The boat stops off at lots of little Wats, and landing jetties, on the way. You get a great sense of Bangkok from the water, and see a lot of river-life.
nice views. and strolling-on and nearbye being able to see a lot of non-touristic spots and wats (temples); the (cheap and fast) ferries
