Excellent long boat ride. It was one of the highlights of our trip, hiring a long boat driver to take us for a one hour cruise. He took us past all the temples along the river plus down a canal. We then asked him to drop us at Wat Pho instead of taking us back to where we started and he obliged. Very relaxing and interesting ride.

Cheap way to see the sights.. Good views of the attractions but ignore the touts who will pounce on you offering overpriced tours. At least they can't tell you the river is closed and try to steer you somewhere else.

Very nice way to see Bangkok. I have take a few trips up the Chao Phraya River. One was on a long boat up to the Floating Markets and the other was an organised river cruise. Both very different but each gave me a chance to see how life goes about on the river. You can witness how people live their lives on the river. A very interesting and memorable experience.

Bleurgh!. Firstly don't get me wrong - the Chao Phraya river in Bangkok isn't really an attraction - you'll only really encounter it as a means to travel. However it stinks, is a fetching shade of grey and choppy and fast flowing. On the plus side - it offers regular water taxis (though making sense of these is a art in itself), it's fascinating watching minah birds perching atop and flitting between the many plants that float on it's surface, and spotting the varied architecture and shanty homes along the waters edge. offers great views of Wat Arun too.Just keep it in context as a ways from A to B and NOT a place to soak up the sun and paddle.
A busy river. The river did not look clean but it was a very interesting river with boats and barges going back and forth all day and night, which made for very interesting viewing.
A bit of old Thailand!. Another got to see - have a boat ride and enjoy the view!

Worth the ride to see the sights. Take the BTS Skytrain to the last stop and you can transfer to the river boat. Grab a ticket and head towards the Grand Palace where you can see many temples along the way. You can also see the reclining Buddha. The Chao Phraya River also joins many klongs that will take you through to Sukhumvit via Jim Thampson house and many other attractions including the Golden Mountain Temple and Bo Bae Markets.

Boating adventures!. The river is both a spot for adventure as well as a major commuting highway for the city. Get a map and make sure to tell the captain what stop you want then enjoy the colorful decorations and the cool breeze. For fun, tip the captain some baht and ask to drive the long-tail boats for a little bit! Great times to be had on the river!
river cruise. the dinner cruise on the river is another must do.the scenes from the boat are absolutely stunning

Thailand's Lifeline-Chao phraya. I went to Thailand twice and both times i enjoyed Visiting the Chao Phraya river.As i lived near Khao san road it was easy for me to go there almost anytime.The river is magnificent as you'll see lot of boats,people going here and there,over there for a moment i forgot if iam on river or some highway.Anyways i loved to view boats,i loved sailing on it but its kind of dirty though as the water isn't clean but never mind i enjoyed a lot.I used the river to travel to a temple across the river.They charge just 30 baht and take 10 mins to travel.The ferry gets full of people during peak hours as students and other people travel through it. The best activity which you must not forget to do is visit night cruise at Chao Phraya river.It costs like 750 baht for a person i think but i recommend it.You will love to sail across the river and have yummy Thai food.They will show you Wat Arun temple which looks very beautiful at night when it is lit with lights.Well cheers hope you will like to visit it soon too.

An eye opener. We thoroughly enjoyed our trip on the river but were shown not only the magnificient splendor of the Kings fleet of boats docked along there but also all the homes damaged by recent flooding and people still trying to make them a comfortable home to live in.We had a good laugh feeding the fish at the temple, so many come to the boat and splash...

take a Grand Pearl river cruise, unforgettable. we booked a cruise on the grand pearl which included a buffet dinner, pick up from hotel and return, live band on board and it was awesome all round. the staff, entertainment and food was fantastic. seeing the city skyline lit up at night cruising up and down the river, sipping cocktails and having a dance on the top deck with family was a highlight and the facilities and restaurants down the river were awesome. wish melbourne has some more of these facilities!

Chao Phraya River - Dinner cruises. I traveled on the Chao Phraya river through the ferry boat service which is cheap fast and efficient. The water isn't shiny clean but one thing I love of this place is that there are a lot of companies offering dinner cruises on the river.After sunset, the climate will be good enough to enjoy a fine dinner on a open boat but you can fine air conditioned boats as well if you can't stand the weather.I enjoyed a full course dinner with musicians and I spent a good romantic evening.
Boat tours. A great way to see the city sights for cheap, using the oldest means to get around Bangkok. Relaxing and interesting!
A working river. This is a must see if you are in Bangkok. The commercial and tourist boat traffic is amazing to experience, with some great hotels Temples and restaurants along it.

Don't buy one day boat trip pass. we don't know that the single way ticket is just around 10 baht, we bought a one day ticket at 150 baht, as there is only one booth selling ticket here. OMG, the ticket is sold on the boat

One of the best places to be in BKK. On, or next to, this river.. Bangkok is a major heat island. After awhile in the city, getting out in any direction can be a relief. The best breaks within the city are the parks, and this river. Anyone who has visited the Phnom Penh riverside can dream about what could be along the Chao Phraya in Bangkok. But that's a small lament. Riding on the Chao Phraya Express Boat (the local equivalent to vaporetti in the "Venice of the East" - with BKK's version being more enjoyable IMHO), crossing on a cross-river ferry to Wat Arun, eating at one of the restaurants along the river bank, or making merit by feading the fish at Thewet Pier (Express Boat Pier N15) - and watching the others also enjoying a bit of fresher air along the river - can all be supremely enjoyable!
Take the river taxi!. If you are bringing friends or - better yet - children to Bangkok, you have to treat them to a trip on this famous river with the local River Taxi.

We were the only boat on the river!!!. Our private boat trip on the Chao Phraya was during the flooding in Bangkok and we were literally the only ones on the river. The government had closed down the dinner cruise boats, the Chao Phraya express boats and the commercial barges due to the severe flooding. We felt very privileged to have the place to our selves!

An excellent alternative to road and rail. The Chao Phraya Express Boat runs very cheap commuter services between all major stops on the river and is also a great way for tourists to see Bangkok and get around.Don't pay over the top for the tourist boar - get on the commuter boat and pay per trip. The commuter boat service also starts earlier in the morning than the tourist boat.It can get quite busy, but the river breezes are nice and you get a superb view of the city and all the sights along the banks.
Must do in Bangkok. We were talking today, saying that it may not be as beautiful as The Seine, the Danube etc, but it's a must do in Bangkok - take a long tail boat, get out on the river!

A mighty river. The waves and the flow of the river. the long speedy boats going to & fro with people. The massive cargo ships and the contemporary hotel boats carrying guests. all was quite fascinating about this lake. The tourist spots along side the river were attractive.

worth a look. huge river with lots going on really interesting, you can take a variety of boats and stop off at different places, there are tourist sites and local peoples homes along the river which look quite poor but they also look cosy and the locals will wave as you go buy. Boats will come up to you and you can buy beer to drink as you sail down the river. There are hotels along the banks that you can stop off at. always barter a price as it can vary quite a lot When you get off the boat there are lots of food stalls for you to get a bit of lunsh and they are really cheap i had pad thai and it was fantastic and so cheap , we then took a tuk tuk back to sukummvit road which was an experience in itself and should not be missed..
A fantastic view of BKK. Take a longtail boat trip on the river and see the city from the waterside. You will not regret! A perfect way to discover sites you will not see in a taxi or by foot.

Great river. This is a great river and if you have a chance to do a Chao Phaya river cruise to Auythia, do it as its a great tour to do. Take the bus to ancient city of Auythia and after the sight seeing board the river cruise boat for lunch and a relaxing ride down river. Here you can see life along the river banks.. very rustic scenery, great for photogrpahy as well.

Well the best way to Orientation. Well its an expereince on its own, a slow crusing boat with an open deck for you to see the most famous attraction like, Temple of dawn & summer palace, with the city lit to its glorry its a must experience, With the Food & berverage on Board, its an expereince and a nice dinner venue to

Big. The river was very interesting and busy. It is a good way to see some of the sites. It was flooding when we were there,so it was very interestind to see how the homes and businesses delt with it.

Best travelled by express riverboat. Plenty of piers (like river bus stops) make the express riverboats an extremely effective way of getiing around Bangkok, and like all public transport here, the price is very affordable

Best way of travel in a gridlock town. This year using the river boats was especially exciting since all along the river people tried to add to their high water barriers to avoid flooding. We never got wet and in spite of all the flooding problems this means of transportation still works the best. Use it whenever you can.

Fascinating, but watch out for scams. We were there during the floods of october so some of the boat companies weren't running. We paid 1500 baht - more than we should have - and then had to pay a docking fee at every stop! Do some research so you avoid this. But what a view of a different life. The homes along the canals were flooded - we saw people in knee-deep water hanging laundry in the eaves.
A great way to travel. Although the river was very high due to the flooding that didn't stop everyone from using this great service. A lovely way to see a different aspect of Bangkok life.

Evening River trip. Whilst at the marriott we had a free evening river criuse and it gives you another view of this bustling city. We also used the hotel ferry to travel in to and out of the city. But for the real local flavour hire a long tail boat for a trip on the river and the adjacent canals (klongs) to see the hidden part of this city

Relaxing Fun. Rent a private longtail boat and hire or take a guide along, it is relaxing and fun - go into the side canals and places the big boats dont get to. Also late at night a Diner river cruise can be fun and /or romantic!

Long-Tail Boat Ride Recommended. Take a long-tail boat ride up and down the river and you will be amazed at the life and buildings that you will see along the rivers edges. A very busy river with many things to offer.

An amazing travel system in Bangkok. We stayed in a hotel along the river and used the river taxis to get to the Grand Palace. It is amazing how the locals use the river to transport themselves and goods.
At night the party boats the ply the river are fantastic!

river tuned into tourist spot. This is not really a clean river because I can see some garbage floating and the water is not clear. However, this river was made into a tourist attraction. It connects many tourist destinations in Bangkok.

dont mis. a different view of Bangkok,
and cool things to see and do
fish feeding really crazy
Water bus service very cheaply and quickly
Great Service. Very easy to use the water buses. It is much cheaper to NOT use the tourist boat. Regular and fast service of all the other boats
Best views of Bangkok from the water. A must if in Bangkok. take a river boat to get the best from your trip. Also a dinner cruise at night is magical.

Boat on the River. Well worth taking a boat trip down the Phraya River to view the stunning temples and sites.
Would also recommend a dinner cruise. A bit touristy, but the meal was good and the city by night amazing!!

River Cruise. Great way to see the local attraction & also get a feel of the Bangkok city..You get a great view of the city from all directions. It's good breeze in the evening & a respite from a sticky weather...

The Chao Phraya is Not To Miss. We happened upon a recommendation to travel within Bangkok using the Chao Phraya ferry service. It was excellent advice as it turns out. The river corridor seemed about ten degree (f) cooler than the rest of the city and combined with the opportunity to get out on the water was welcome.Be careful, the loading and unloading of passengers occurs fast and the boat does not wait. It is off to its next stop fast. I was caught jumping over a gap a few times. There is an excellent stop for coffee near the ticket counter at the Khoa San area stop. Best of all is that the ferry accesses a huge swath of the city and is a fast method to travel. No tuk tuk necessary.
Just before the floods!. Quite brown and very fast-flowing but the hotel river taxi negotiated it very nicely to get us to the nearest skytrain station.

Cheap and exciting. Take a trip on the same boats that locals use to cross the river or travel through Bangkok on. Cheap, good quality, safe boats with a taste of the experience of the Thais and you get to see so many great temples, bridges and palaces to fill up your pictography and from a clear water view.

great views. It is a must do to take a tour through the river and side canals. it will give you a different perspective of Thailand and thai life. i think a day and night trip would both be worthwhile. You get to see the temples and normal Thai life. I personally have done this trip many many times....including taking water taxi's up and down the canals.
River. Take a boat down the river and see Bangkok from the river. Because of the floods the river was high and rough and most of the riverside homes flooded.

FEEDING THE CATFISH..?. After leaving the Grand palace we headed towards Changs pier and the Chao phraya river where we boarded a "Touristy" boat , we then settled back to enjoy the 30min ride which took in the many landmarks along the way. Looking at the bigger picture this river water level had been rising for some time and was evident by the flooding of the many houses along the banks, seeing these poor people made me think and as we all now know worse was coming..! Putting this aside we were treated to the many wonderful sights including the large temples etc, after a mile or so the boat stopped and everyone was handed a loaf of bread each. And to my surprise we began to feed the many large Catfish which would rise and jump out of the water grabbing the pieces of bread, we then set off again down river on the opposite side this time giving everyone the opportunity to get more photos etc.! When you arrive back at the pier be careful as its a free for all as you have to climb Thai style over the bow of the boat, and there are large queues waiting to get on total chaos and certainly not wheelchair friendly. Also check out the Thai/Chinese restaurant around the corner, say no more...!

It’s a river... more useful then interesting but very nice nevertheless. We stayed at the Millennium Hilton which is situated on the Chao Phraya River, the Hilton operated a free river taxi which was invaluable when coming or going from a night out. It is nice to see Bangkok from the river and certainly practical for a way of getting from A to B.....
Hilton private tour of Floating Market. The day we arrived we took a private tour of Floating Market - it lasted 2 hours and was most entertaining - great way to see parts of the city
Beautiful city.. Beautiful city. Nice culture. Very busy and rush city. Good value travel destination.
nice and relaxing. this was one of the trips recommended by the hotel and it was great. i went in the evening and had a meal on the boat and great views of bangkok by night
fun stuff. This river ride was fun, I laughed for 20 min, just couldn't believe I was in Bangkok on a boat. Give it a try, you won't be dissapointed. Cheap tour and fun.

Lifeline Of Bangkok. Even before I visited Bangkok, I have seen a lot of photos, documentaries and movies depicting the Chao Phraya River. As such, the magnificent river ride down the mighty Chao Phraya was one of the must-see and must-visit site high on my list.Despite having seen the river in photos before, the sheer size of the river the moment I set eyes on it was absolutely mind blowing. Not only that. The various activities on the river, in particular river cruises, certainly makes this river one of the most active in this region.Looking at the river and how the locals depended on it, it is no wonder the Chao Phraya has often being described as the life line of Bangkok.Standing on the banks of the Chao Phraya is not sufficient to see what the river has to offer. One has to take the cruise on many of the ride available. Taking a cruise along the river is one of the best and fastest way to get acquainted with the city as most of the magnificent structures are located along the river bank.Despite the eagerness to ride on one of the cruises, I must admit I had my apprehension in the beginning. This was because no life jackets were provided. For a non-swimmer like me, that was enough to put me off. However, that apprehension disappeared once the cruise started. It was indeed a relaxing feeling with the wind blowing into your face and at the same time, getting a first hand look at how things are in Bangkok.So sit back and lets rock and roll.

Nice sightseeing!. Liked to cost of the Tourist day pass. Liked the fact that you could travel on any boat with the day pass. Great way to get to the sights if you are on a budget! Relaxing travelling up and down the river by boat...
Big big department store. Really a big big department store in Bangkok. So many people! The location is really very convenient. Go for crazy shopping at thise good place.
nice to look at. The river is worth a visit, if not just to look at, you can take a dinner cruise which is quite worth while.

Business as usual. This river is outstanding, to watch the boats here not only carrying holiday makers but Thai people who travel over and on it for work. The amount of goods that are carried on it and the boats that cross it were fascinating to watch and never an accident

Lovely. We had a dinner cruise along the Chao Phraya and thoroughly enjoyed it. The views along the river are really good and seeing The Wat Arun lit up at night looks magnificent! We also saw a bikini competition taking place next to The River City Mall!!

Pay the 15bt and take a river trip.. Its great value and you see an other side of Bangkok. The river is the express way for the city, and unlike the roads is never at a standstill. At the rear of the boat on the port side is an area "reserved for monks".

Different look to the city from river. We have used these public boats just to see river embankments.From Saphin Taksin skytrain station, you directly go to the pier. We sailed to the end and back. From Saphan Taksin we used orange flag and back with no flag boats.http://www.chaophrayaexpressboat.com/en/home/ is the site where you find any necessary information.From Saphan Taksin to Nonthaburi it will take more or less 1 hours one way.You pay on board, so no need to buy ticket before hand. The boat almost does not come to a complete stop at piers, so it is really not for disabled and pushchairs.I strongly recommend to choose evening just before sun set. But it is not very good in dark.Just sit relax and look around. You see modernization and poverty at the same time. High rise buildings at the bank is combined with small houses. You see also long connected river transports
swollen with the rains. cheap trip (3 baht) cross the river from wat pho to wat arun and see the difference between the two temples!

Great form of public transport and cheap. A really great way to get around the city and you can connect to the skytrain at Saphin Taksin (central pier) carry a map so you can just say the pier number you want to get off at, helps with the language barrier. Quick, cheap, efficient service.

Dinner River Cruise-Excellent. We only had 2 nights in Bangkok so this dinner cruise was beautiful, great value, lots of food, then entertainment and dancing for us also..Cocktails were cheap also. Would recommend it..

Cool stuff....a lot to see and does not cost so much.. Suggest going early in the morning to spend all day wandering around Wats till you drop. AVOID TUK TUK drivers that will try to get free gas for taking you all over the city to by stuff while you visit several Wats. Easier to just go to Khao San and walk around there or just walk to the Wats.

True essence of Bangkok. Great views and also provides a great way of transportation in Bangkok. Its definitely a must during your Bangkok trip. All the major historical sites are located on either sides of the river like temple of reclining buddha, wat arun, grand palace etc. A boat ride will take you to within walking distance of these places. Boats are neat and clean and also very cheap and comfortable. The frequency of these boats is also very good. You also have an option of taking "Tourist Boat" with live commentary which connects to all these tourist sites, but is more expensive than the other boats. Dinner cruise options are also available.

Best way to get around Bangkok!. When in Bangkok there is no easier way to get around to the temples, resorts, spas, etc than via the Chao Phraya River. And the cheapest and easiest way to travel the river....the public taxi. Don't bother going to the docks and asking for the boats, because it is likely that you will end up over-paying for a tour boat. These are nice as well, but for about 12 bhat you can take a public taxi to the same spots. And, you get to ride along with Thai commuters and schoolchildren instead of other tourists! Once you get to the dock, just ask around for the "Public Boat" and the residents will point you in the right direction. Navigating the river is easy since the stops are clearly marked on the signs at each dock and the taxi operator announces each stop as they approach.

A different view of Bangkok. I bought the tourist day pass for 120 baht, which gave me unlimited boat rides for both tourist or public boats plying the Chao Phraya river. Many of the tourist attractions in BKK may be accessed through the river, so you can conveniently hop on and off to go the temples, restaurants, Khao san road, shopping areas,etc. You should start in the morning so you can visit many places, then stay until the night, because the view along the entire river is amazing at night. The tourist boat is less crowded but until 4pm only. Beyond 4pm, you may take the public boats, which the local people use in their daily commute so it's more crowded, but you are still seated, so that's ok. I would really recommend to try both to really experience the other side of old Bangkok.

A must do in Bangkok: Take a Dinner Cruise Package. We only have a weekend in Bangkok, but still want to enjoy the most of it. This 2 hours cruise is really worth our time. We enjoyed the glow of Wat Arun Temple, Grand Palace, and Rama Bridge while enjoying our candle light dinner on the deck with a nice live music.The cruise we took have a 15 mins cabaret show as well. It is good if you just want to see how's the famous ladyboy looks like without spending good money only to watch 2 hours of lip-sync concert at Tiffany of Calypso Cabaret.

Chao Phraya River – Dinner Cruise. Give your evening in Bangkok with dinner cruise on Chao Phraya River the programmed to get you along the Chao Phraya River aboard the cruiser fully of equipped with all facilities. A selection of international and Thai delicacies is served, while you enjoy delightful moments with panoramic view of Bangkok at night, beautiful light and river life, music performance conducted to spice up your cruise on the river. Sightseeing a night on Bangkok main river will give you the another vision of capital.

A river excursion is a must while in Bangkok. There are many ways to see the Chao Phraya river and klongs, but one of the best is to take the Skytrain to Saphan Taksin station, then down the stairs to Central Pier, below the bridge, where you can rent a boat for a two hour klong tour, try the circle formed by klong Mon, Klong Noi and the Chao Phraya about 1200 Bhat per hour on a slower boat, which is best for taking camera shots from or a much quicker ride on a long-tail boat for about 1800 Baht per hour, but you pass by things so fast that don't have time to get a photo of the unexpected little things about klong life. For rides up and down the Chao Phraya River only you can purchase all day tourist boat pass in advance or pay for each ride once on board, different color flags( orange, blue, etc.) mean different stops alone the river. This is an excellent way to just get around the river area. Many river hotels run their own boats for guest and River City Shopping Center runs one free to their place. Be sure to see everything on and around the river lit-up at night.

Cheap Way to cruise the Chao Phraya River. From the Sathorn Pier, directly under the Saphan Taksin Train Station, Tourists can take the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat in a hop on hop off style at 150 Baht only. Tickets are available at the entrance. It stops at 8 Piers. It leaves every 30 minutes. Operation starts at 9:30 AM and ends at 3:00 PMBut if you only plan to visit the Grand Palace, the reclining Buddha and the Temple of Dawn, you can only pay one way at 30 Baht. From the Sathorn Pier, get down at Tha Tien Pier. The Reclining Buddha is only about 5 minutes walk and the Grand Palace about 15 minutes walk. If you want to take the Tuk Tuk to the Grand Palace, they charge 50 Baht. From the Tha Tien Pier, you can visit the Temple of Dawn by crossing the river in a boat that leaves 10 minutes at one way fare of 3 Bahts.

Beautiful !. While we were in Bangkok, we took a boat ride in Chao Phraya river daily. River is very muddy but is clean otherwise; no stinking water. We even saw people fishing near the Piers. I don't know whether it was because of weekend, the boats were never too crowded. We always took the boat from the Pier near Taksin station. Minimum fare to Pier 8 ( from where you can walk to Grand Palace and Temple of Reclining Buddha) on a boat with orange flag costs 15 Baht per person. But if you forget to be on time, you will miss it. So, remember to be up there on the boat before the boat reaches the pier or else you’ll miss it. Frequency of the boat is quite less in the evening. We never took the tourist or express boat, just didn’t feel the need. Khao San midnight market is very close from Pier 13( I will not say walkable)Long Tailed boats are very noisy and emit lot of smoke. Difficult to get inside also.I’d say, atleast once take a ride in the boat during the sunset. Despite the heat, wind is always so cool. You just sit in the boat, look around you and relax. The moon looks lovely from the boat and all the hotels near the river are beautifully lit in the evening. So are the bridges. The restrau near the river look very inviting and probably next time, we will get down at one of the Pier and have something. When you are on the boat, you feel what is the big deal. But later, you feel wow, it was so relaxing, wish I could sleep there on the rocking boat!! And yes, we also got to know how the Thais move their cargo in the river. I know next time, we’ll book the hotel near the river instead of Sukhumvit, specially because most of the attractions are located on the banks of this river.

Best way to discover Bangkok. The Chao Phraya River cruise would definitely be the highlight of each vacation to Bangkok. I've been to several cruise trips in Asia and this one tops it all off. Get yourself to River City or find a booking referral through your hotel's travel desk. Shuttle service would pick up you up from your hotel and escort you to the River city. The two hour long cruise would be one of the most organized and tourist-friendly evening entertainment for Bangkok. through this, you get to see Bangkok's famous temples and monuments, all well-lit for your eyes to behold. The trip also includes dinner buffet that's serves authentic Thai cuisine.This definitely tops my best experience of Bangkok, hands down!

The only sensible way to see the city. We went one day on the locals boat with the orange flag two days and two days on the Express Tourist Boat. Both had their pluses. The locals boat was cheap and full of smiley faces and monks etc. Less than $1. The touristy boat was a few dollars but was more comfortable and had a running commentary and you can hop on and off with the same ticket. The local boat however, seems like it runs more often. Certainly worth doing the boat if you are north to get downtown and to the Grand Palace and temples and worth doing if you are downtown because it gets you easily to Kho San Rd.Above all it is a great overview of Bangkok with its mix of new and old and a hassle free way of travelling. The roads are a nightmare.There are plenty of stops. along the way and because you are moving you do not feel the oppressive heat as much as on the land. On the locals boat we made a stop off along one of the side canals of the river with houses on stilts etc. Easy access from the river boats to Wat Po and Grand Palace, as well as downtown and easy access to the Skytrain that then takes you to the more modern parts of the city. To get to Wat Arun which is on the other side (west?) of the river you get a boat from the main Grand Palace stop. It is literally pennies to make the journey and is a far cooler way to arrive than all stinky from a tuk tuk or long walk. Not quite sure how clean the river is? It is quite murky, but that could just be because it is pretty much at the end of the river and has picked up silt etc. on its long journey.The touristy boat has a little more speed to it = a bit more wind = a bit cooler temperature

Must do night time cruise in Bangkok. Everyone coming to Bangkok must do the dinner cruise on Chao Phraya river! It's not very cheap, but so worth it. We booked the whole cruise online at Thaicruise.com. A car picked us up and dropped us at Pier 1. We then found our company's representative and climbed on board the new-looking and very clean yacht-like boat called Chao Princess 1. The boat made a slow round trip passing the major landmarks of Bangkok. Included was a very elaborate buffet catering to all palates. Also on the menu was disco night! Even my (normally shy) parents enjoyed the disco part of it. There is also a small deck from where you can take pictures. We went in December and it was not cold at all - just the right breezy temperature to enjoy the night. I didn't even need a cardigan! If you are from a cold country, you can wear a spagetti strap and feel awesome :)

Colorful trip. If you happen to be in Bangkok - please go for this river trip, we loved it. Especially our little girl (aged 4) enjoyed it too...It lasted an hour and you have a chance to feel the culture, see the people, see the city and all those attractions alone the shore... Very nice!It's like a compact version of the floating market.Lots of pictures to take as you go along!There are different ways to take a boat, better to take the private one, it wont cost you much if there few of you, you can share the price, as far as I remember it costed us 1500 Baht for 5 people.Enjoy!

Great way to get around Bangkok. One of the highlights for me visiting Bangkok was travelling everywhere by river taxi boat on the Chao Phraya. We used the Express boat with the orange flag (13 baht each) to get to the Grand Palace (boat stop is called "Tha Chang". We caught the tourist boat which is more expensive to go to Banglampoo (boat stop is called "Tha Phra Arthit"). On both boats you can buy tickets on board. When riding on the express boats just a word of warning if you have sensitive hearing, they let off this really loud whistle when they arrive at a boat stop !!On the tourist boat they have a running commentary of the sights you pass which is good. You get lovely views of Wat Arun, Wat Rakang and many other temples, churches and interesting buildings. We did a day trip to Bang Pa In and Ayutthaya and the 2 hour trip back on the Chao Phraya was just wonderful, there was so much to see. Dotted on the riverbanks were buddhas, dozens of temples, traditional Thai houses, mosques, statues etc. It is also interesting watching all the barges and many other boats on the river.It is a great way to take a reprieve from the chaos and traffic of central Bangkok. It is also great fun catching the local boats on the other canals, then you see the real Bangkok, just be careful getting in and out of the boats - we paid 9 baht to go from Phan Fah (by the Golden Mount) to the Central Shopping area on the Klong Saen Saep. What ever you do make sure you include some time on the river when in Bangkok, you won't regret it.

love it or hate it. in contrary with others said, the food was good, but the view is not. well, if you find the asian food is tasty then you'll enjoy the food, for me it tasted good. but the view of the floating restaurant is ordinary, nothing's special. but i did enjoy feeding tons of fishes in the river (near a temple). dont forget to bring your lots of breads to feed them.
great view but food was such a let down,. was lovely on the river at night time ! the food was a disgrace,staff were polite,toilets clean,

Chao Phraya - Visit real Bangkok. I had a very nice trip in Chao Phraya , in a traditional boat . The river may not be that clean (dirty actually) but if you ask your driver or guide to get out of the standard tourist route , then you'll discover a very genuine part of Bangkok . Small wooden houses , built in the river , small but beautiful temples, floating groceries even schools will be in your way . A boating in CP river can be very interesting but as soon as you don't forget to go to the really interesting part of the city .

Quick way to get to tourist attractions in Bangkok. The boats on the Chao Phraya are a quick, inexpensive and enjoyable way to get to the tourist attractions in Bangkok. We jumped on and off the boats several times to go to Wat Pho, Grand Palace, the Mandarin Oriental and then to the BTS Skytrain. Tip: The boat stops only for a few seconds at each location so be ready to get on or off the boat or you will miss your opportunity.

Dinner Cruise on Chao Phraya River - Memorable Experience. A truly great experience in bangkok was the dinner cruise on the Chao Phraya River. The entire experience right from the time we boarded the cruise ship till the end was awesome. We got the fornt row table right at the front to the ship with a excellent view in front aswell as around us..The buffet spread was excellent with seafood, non veg and veg items to suite all tastes. A must try thing to do in bangkok especially for newly married couple... Then ther eis live music and dance floor on the ship in case u want to shake a leg...

Great way to visit most tourist places along the river. Having read the reviews on TA, we knew we had a choice of spending very little money for a river boat or expend more on the tourist boat (Express Boat) We decided for the latter because we could make as many stops as we wished and there was an English-speaking tour guide aboard which turned out to be extremely helpful. Even paying the higher fee for the tourist boat, the ride is not expensive considering that it has eight stops where you can get on and off as you wish for the day. We used it mainly for a tour of the river and to stop in China Town and Wat Aru. Had we known about this boat before hand, we could have saved a ton of money in cab fares to and from the Grand Palace and Wat Pho two days earlier. You can get to the pier by BTS.The river is muddy as expected, but the views of Bangkok are fantastic. In addition to taking you to most historic sites, you get to see the modern Bangkok as well as how the not too fortunate live. Well worth the fare: 150 bath per person.

Great value for money. Don't know why everyone on here is paying 100s of Baht to go on a boat on the Chao Phaya river.It costs me 14B on a river taxi for a one hour journey from Sathon Bridge up the river to journeys end Nonthaburi. These boats go every 20 minutes from Sathon Pier. I see many tourists at Sathon Pier getting fleeced going on organised river taxis and paying 100s even 1000s of Baht.The river taxis stop at many points but there is some great photos to be taken of the rickety shack dwelling, the temples, the superb Rama bridges.Your not always sure to get a seat as many of the locals use this cheaper way to get about town. But once your past the Khao Sans Rd exit most of the people have gone and you can enjoy a seat and truely relax.A hour there two hours at the delightful market town Nonthaburi and an hour return journey. It's a great cheap way to spend a long half day in Bangkok

A must in Bangkok. There are various ways of seeing the Chao Phraya River. We did a dinner cruise with La Noya which was a fantastic experience. We saw day, sunset and then nightfall. Very relaxing having dinner and a few drinks taking in the river sights. We also travelled on the tourist boat which has running commentary and where you can visit the sights such as The Grand Palace etc. The cheapest option is to use the local ferry. You can also hire your own longtail boat and have a look at how the Thai people really live.

A Must do experience.. Taking a longboat down the Chao Phraya River is a fabulous way to see & experience Bangkok. The Chao Phraya River runs through the centre of Bangkok and flows into the Gulf of Thailand.We negotiated a price for a private long tail boat for 4 people at the pier. There are piers next to any of the major waterfront hotels. We started ours from Sathorn just below the Skytrain Station at Taksin Bridge.One can use the long tail boats as a hop on/ hop off system to visit any of the major historical sites along the river. We decided just to pass on the attractions like the Grand Palace,Wat Arun Temple,Wat Pho (The Temple of the reclining Buddah) andWat Phra Khaew(Temple of the Emerald Buddah) as all of us had seen them before. The river cruise also allows you to view the 5* hotels along the way like Oriental, Marriott, Sheraton, the Peninsula & others. The boat rides takes approx two hours and the time goes very quickly as the journey takes you down the many canals where the Thai’s conduct their daily routines and business beside the river. Overall: A wonderful way to taste & experience the essence of Bangkok & its people.

Lovely To Be On The River. On the 16th of Dec, 2010, my wife, sister-in-law & I took an orange-flag express boat from Tha Si Phraya to Tha Tien & then the cross-river ferry to Wat Arun. We thoroughly enjoyed our time on the Chao Phraya River.

Worth a visit - to see how the 'other half' of Thailand live. An amazing mix of things to see on this trip - we took a long-tail boat around - they can be fairly uncomfortable and hard on the bum so try and get one with a cushion at least!The differences in the places you pass is incredible - from the palaces, to yacht clubs to slums it certainly a huge mix - but more real than a lot of the 'touristy stuff.'Don't go if the weather's poor or it's raining as there's no-where to hide!

Dinner Cruise on Chao Phraya River, Bangkok-A great experience. Our trip was coming to an end and we were searching for what more we can do during our Bangkok Trip and our travel agent suggested us the cruise. At first we were not interested but having nothing to do that evening me and my wife decided to go to the cruise. It was breathtaking. Believe you me. The ship named Grand Parle was superb and wandering in the river under the moon in gentle breeze was a gem of an experience. The buffet dinner was good. The live music was excellent and the whole atmosphere was too good. The Thai Cultural show was worth watching. The dinner cruise cost us 1000 Baht per person and the picked us from our hotel and after the cruise dropped us also. You can arrange this tour by contacting any travel agent whom you will find around your hotel. You will float by the side of Wat Arun, The Grand Palace and some other attractions and their views from the river are worth watching.Don't miss it.

Remember nothing is free. Took the cruise down th river, it was intresting and worth the time. At our jump off point at the Grand Place we were offered a free ride form the ferry stop to the Grand Palace (by the boat company). I would have rather walked, but the people I was traveling with decided to accept the free ride from the boat company. Everything was going fine, we were even given our our guide (free of course)that tagged along in the van to the Grand Palace (a five min ride). The problem started when we couldn't get rid of the guy, even when we told him we had other plans. Upon leaving the Grand Palace he gave us a sob story of having already arranged a van to a jewerly factory. Stupid us said ok, we were basically highjacked on a wild wild through Bangkok for about 20 minutes, having no idea were we were. We walked in the jewerly factory and basically I walked right out as soon as I stepped into the door, leaving the receptionist and other people standing there with their mouths open. We were lucky to get a cab back to the water front, but it cost us time and extra money. Also beware of the tuk tuk drivers by the entrance to the tour boat of Chao Phray, they were trying to tell us it would take 3 hours to get to the Grand Palace (because of the river current) I was smart enough on that one so passed on their offer, it actually takes about 30 mins. Please remeber in Bangkok nothing is free.

Great way to see the many of the tourist sites. The Chao Phraya runs through Bangkok, its low alluvial river plain marking the mainland of the country. The Chao Phraya is a major transportation artery for a vast network of ferries and water taxis, also known as longtails. More than 15 boat lines operate on the riverways and canals of the city.Our hotel, the Shangri La was conveniently located for both the Skytrain and Pier on the river. We purchased the one day pass for the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat.With the ticket you get a small guide and map describing places to visit from the Central pier to the pier leading to the Grand Palace. This is a wonderful way to see the various tourist sites. The main temples and the Grand Palace are accessible, you do not get stuck in any traffic jams. You also get to see the riverside hotels and even get to Chinatown.The river is somewhat murky and there is a bit of plenty of flotsam and jetsam about. Whatever you do, do not jump in for a swim. There is a great deal of happening in the river and any visit to Bangkok would not be complete without a trip on the river.

See Another Side of Bangkok!. We took one of the long boats down the river on about a 30 minute cruise. Cost us 1000 THB (about $30.00) for 3 people to have a private boat. Not only do you cruise through the 5-star hotels, which are probably interesting at night, but you get to see the locals living on the river in their houses up on stilts, fishing off their porches, and swimming. You can see some beautiful teak wood houses and several temples. The boat is fast, and because there are lots of other boats too, the water is kind of rough. We also took the public boat which was about 10 THB (30 cents) per person. It is a water bus, so it's stopping every few minutes to take on new passengers and let off others. Not nearly the experience as the long boat. There is also a ferry we were going to take across the river, but that takes like one minute, so not an attraction. There are many river cruises you can take further upstream, dinner cruises, sunset cruises, tea cruises, rice barges, etc. I think 30 minutes was enough to get the feel of the river though - as long as you're on the fast boat. Glad we went. Would go again and do a night cruise out of curiosity - maybe the water would be smoother later at night.

Wonderful way to get around --- Make sure you see the Canals too!. If you are up for a little adventure, the River is the way to see the city. We did this with a guide from Tour with Tong (Get), and it was a wonderful experience!After taking the shuttle boat from the Bangkok Marriott Resort and Spa to one of the main piers, we jumped on one of the river ferries with the locals. Fare was 13 baht per person. It’s much faster to get many places using the river instead of the streets. There is also a tourist specific boat with narration and a higher cost. The local boat makes a few more stops, but it was lots of fun! I don't know that I'd pay the extra for the tourist boat. One tip – you have to be ready to get on / off when the ferry stops --- it makes very quick stops!We hired a private long-tail boat for a couple of hours (1200 baht) for a tour of the canals and to see how some of the local people live and work. Stops included the Royal Barges Museum, Floating Market, Wat Arun and touring the canals (2-2 ½ hours). Water was a little rough going across the river, but much calmer once we were in the canals off the main river. We made a quick stop at the Royal Barges Museum (100 Baht / person and 100 Baht / camera) to get a little insight into some of the pomp and circumstance of Thai culture. It was interesting, but probably not on the must see list for most people. Our boat was waiting for us to continue when we were done. Further up the canal, we bought beverages from a woman in a boat as we approached a local market. This was a weekend only floating market – the Taling Chan Floating market on canal Khlong Chak Phra. This market is a little different from the floating market that most of the tourists visit, as it is primarily for locals. Foods, fruits and vegetables far outnumber the souvenirs here! Exploring the market allowed us to try several local fruits and dishes — the odd part was seeing people cooking in small wooden boats! Being with a guide that could answer questions about the local fruits and vegetables, as well as some of the Thai specialties we’d encountered was wonderful. Additionally, Get was able to point us toward the local dishes we had to try. Since we sampled a number of things in the market, we didn’t make a separate lunch stop. The crispy Thai noodles, the satays and the pomelos were our favorites. Along the canals, we saw people going about their daily life – cooking, washing, and enjoying the afternoon. We learned a little from Get about the spirit houses we saw outside each home (and many of the businesses) along the canal and throughout Thailand. We saw several water monitors in the water and on the rocks along the canals, as well as lots of fish (especially around the market). We finished our tour for the day at Wat Arun – The Temple of Dawn (50 Baht / person)–a very steep climb but a great way to get a bit of a bird’s eye view of the city. Both at the pier in front of Wat Arun and the main Ferry Pier across the river, we had to pay a 20 Baht fee for docking our boat there, since it was privately chartered. We hopped back on the local ferry to get back to the pier where we would catch the hotel shuttle boat.

Most underrated thing to do in Bangkok. I have been to Bangkok about 12 times over 30 years and my favorite thing to do is find a restaurant or bar that has a patio on the river. I could watch the boat traffic all day, there are so many different types of boats carrying things you will never see anywhere else. #1 best place for kicking back is the Oriental Hotel, if you can splurge hit it for breakfast the boat traffic in the morning is amaizing.....very good food any time of day and the view is worth the price. Just go right out to the terrace and order a pot of tea or an ice cold beer or pick up a cuban cigar and a single malt....it is best during the day as the traffic tapers off at night.

Dont get sucked in. We were hoping to travel like the locals as we had read on Trip Advisor. We went from The Grand Palace to Tha Chang Pier and was also told we could get a boat like the locals for around 30BHT. We could not see any colour coded options and was sucked into a boat ride to Sathorn which cost is 300BHT each. We also knew some other travellers who actually paid 400BHT each. It was our own fault as we were aware of scams but our kids were so hot and bothered that we just wanted o get going. As for the river itself, it really was a beautiful way to travel down the river.

Crossing The River. It's a bit hard to review 'a river' isn't it? After reading a few of the previous reviews I think that cruises and snake farms should really have their own section. Anyway, There’s one thing I have done that I haven't seen mentioned that was quite fun - Crossing the river! The Chao Phraya River is a big river running through Bangkok and there are lots of interesting sites on the banks of either side. There are many, many tours and cruises to go on but even just watching the river from the land can be fun too. Unless your driving or in a taxi or tuk tuk, you can get across the river by the rafts/boats that go back and fourth all day. It’s only about 4/5 baht each way and is quite a fun experience. We caught one from the pier at Wat Arun to get back to the Grand Palace area. Once the boat had enough people on, we made our way across the river through all the other bouts going up and down, it was quite hectic!

Travel like the locals. Travelling on the river is more of a sensible practicality as well as a trip in itself. The Chao Phraya river boats are quite an experience and a really good way to get to the Grand Palace complex. There is a stop (Sathorn) about 50m from the exit of Saphan Taksin skytrain terminus. There is lady who will take your fare - around 20 Baht to get to the stop for the Grand Palace (number 9 - Tha Chang)Basically there are 4 routes which are coded by the colour flage the express boat is flying. You want the orange flag if you want the palaces, the yellow route stops fewer times and the grey stops everywhere and takes ages! The blue really only is a one stop to Nonthaburi and probably won't really be used by tourists much. As for the boats well it's a hop on service - no health and safety stuff here, squeeze on and watch the river world whizz by. Once you understand the colour codes for the stops it's easy to work out and away you go!

Sit and relax at Phra Sumen Fort gardens. Phra Sumen Fort on the banks of the Chao Phraya River is a brilliant place to relax and escape the madness of the busy Bangkok streets. The beautiful surroundings make it a excellent place to reflect on all that you have seen and done in Thailand. Phra Sumen fort it's self was built during the reign of King Rama I. Although I never went inside I am informed that there is a museum inside which displays items found during the recent modernisation.It's a short walk for the world famous Ko San Road (if you go the right way, unlike me!) and a good place to meet some locals. While I was there I met a young student from a local university who interviewed me for here project on sustainable tourism in Thailand. For people intersent in photography it is also a good place to get some pictures of the relaxed side of Bangkok and the river.

Almost free. The best way to experience the Chao Phraya in all its beauty (and might) is to take one of the numerous boats - which is nothing but the quickest means of public transportation to the locals. Just hop on, hop off and hop back on. You won't have to pay hundreds of Baht. In fact, fares start as low as 9 Baht (there's always someone to sell you the ticket onboard, just tell them where approximately you want to get off, and they'll tell you how much to pay). While it may be a bit complicated to work out the routes and whatnot, it's still pretty obvious - boats go either up or down the river.

Great dinner cruise. Had a great cruise down the Chao Phraya river recently. You have great views of all the major sights like the Grand Palace, Wat Arun and Rama VIII bridge, all lit up at night.The cruise itself was very good value, great food and good on board entertainment from, what i presume, are the local stars of the karaoke scene. Quite a good game to see who can be the first to guess which song it is they're destroying! All part of the fun.A top evening out.

Dinner Cruise. A great way to see the sights of Bangkok illuminated at night. As soon as you leave the pier, the buffet is opened. This may sound cliche but there really is "something for everyone"! Even the kids are catered for, with chips, pizza etc. During dinner there is a display of classical thai dancing, a sax player and some singers. A guide also points out the various places of interest.Once the boat has travelled to a certain point, it turns around and a DJ plays some classic tunes. The dining area turns into a disco. Don't think you're not going to join in, the waiters/waitresses won't have it!!

Easy Transportation and Cool Breezes!. From our hotel, the Amari Atrium, we took the subway to the Skytram's Saphan Taksin station and took a very short walk to the Central Pier on the river. We bought a One Day River Pass for the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat, which "...provides service to nine piers, which gives access to Bangkok's most famous attractions... You can freely get on and off any pier to explore..." Price was 100 baht and operates 9:30 - 15:00 hrs. Includes drinking water! You can also take any other Chao Phraya Express Boat within the same route area. It came with a small guide describing the sites and places to visit at the nine piers, from the Central Pier to the Banglumpoo Pier north of the Grand Palace. (The river is main transportation cooridor and you can take normal commuter boats further north and south).This is a great way to get to the various tourist sites on the river and there's a cool breeze! No traffic jams! No scams! Grand Palace area, Oriental and Shangri-La hotels, Rivercity (mall), Markets, Wats on both side of the river. We viewed this as merely a way to get to River City for our Rice Barge Tour, and didn't take advantage of this enough (jet lag!). We should have planned a day of traveling up and down the river and stopping at each of the nine sites, from Central Pier to the Grand Palace. The view of the city from the boat is worth the trip in and of itself. Definitely plan a day around this Tourist Boat.
